man has done much, and blased what he can: yet in the end he is but one, one
mind, one power, one birth, one life, and one death. Then sithen he is but one,
let no man presume to know more then one. Of al these good princes which I have
named in the roll of justice, the last was Marcus Aurelius, to the intent that
he should weaue his web. For suppose we read of many princes that have
compyled notable things, the which are to be read and known: but all that
Marcus Aurelius said, or did is worthy to be known, and necessary to be
followed. I do not mean this prince in his heathen law, but in his virtuous
deeds. Let us not stay at his belyef: but let us embrace the good that he did
For compare many chrystians with some of the heathen, and look how far we
leave them behynd in faith: so far they excel us in virtuous works. Al ye old
princes in times past, had some philosophers to their familiars, as Alexander,
Aristotle. King Darius, Herodotus. Augustus, Pisto. Pompeius, Plauto. Titus,
Pliny. Adrian, Secundus. Traian, Plutarchus. Anthonius, Apolonius. Theodotius,
Claudius. Seuerus, Fabatus. Finally I say, yt philosophers then had such
authority in princes palaces: that children acknowledged them for fathers and
fathers reverenced them as masters. These sage me^ were alive in the company of
princes: but the good Marcus Aurelius (whose doctrine is before your majesty)
is not alive, but dead. Yet therefore that is no cause why his doctrine should
not be admitted. For it may be (paraduenture) that this shall profit us more,
which he wrate with his hands, then that which others spoke with their tongues.
Plutarche says, in the time of Alexander the great, Aristotle was alive, and
Homere was dead. But let us see how he loved the one, and reverenced the other:
for of truth he slept always with Homers book in his hands, and waking he red
the same with his eyes, and always kept the doctrine thereof in his memory, and
laid (when he rested) the book under his head. The which privilege Aristotle
had not, who at al times cold not be heard, and much less at al seasons be
believed: so that Alexander had Homere for his friend, and Aristotle for a
master. Other of these philosophers were but simple men: but our Marcus
Aurelius, was both a wise philosopher, and a valiant prince: and therefore
reason would he should be credited before others. For as a prince he will
declare the troubles, and as a philosopher he will redress them. Take you
therefore (Puisaunt Prince) this wise philosopher and noble emperor, for a
teacher in your youth, for a father in your government, for a captain general
in your wars, for a guide in your iourneys, for a friend in your affairs, for
an example in your virtues, for a master in your sciences for a pure white in
your desires, and for equal match in your deeds.

I will declare unto you the life of an other being a heathen, and not the life
of an other being a chrystian. For how much glory this heathen prince had in
this world, being good and virtuous: so much pains your majesty shall have in
the other, if you shall be wicked and vycious. Behold, behold noble prince, the
life of this Emperor, and you shall se how clear he was in his judgment, how
upright in his justice, how circumspect in his life, how loving to his friends,
how pacient in his troubles, how he dissembled with his enemies, how severe
against Tyraunts, how quiet among ye quiet, how great a friend to the sage, and
lover of the simple, how aduenturous in his wars, and amyable in peace, and
above al things, how high in words, and profound in sentences. Many times I
have been in doubt with my self whether the Eternal majesty (which gives unto
you princes the temporal majesty, to rule above al other in power and
authorytie) did exempt you that are princes, more from human frayltye: then
he did us that be but subjects: and at the last I knew he did not. For I see
even as you are children of the world, so you do live according to the world. I
see even as you travail in the world: so you can know nothing but things of
the world. I se because you live in the flesh, that you are subject to the
myseryes of the flesh. I see though for a time you prolong your life: yet at
the last you are brought to your grave. I see your travail is great, and that
within your gates there dwells no rest. I se you are cold in the winter, and
hot in the summer. I se that hunger feels you, and thirst troubles you, I
se your friends forsake you, and your enemies assault you. I se that you are
sad, and lack joy. I se you are sick, and be not well served. I see you have
much and yet that which you lack is more. What will ye se more, seeing that
prince^ die? O noble princes and great Lords, syns you must die, and become
worms meat, why do you not in your life time search for good counsel? If the
princes and noble men commit an ^rroure no man dare chastise them, wherefore
they stand in greater need of advise and counsel. For the trauailer who is
out of his way, the more he goes foreward, the more he errethe. If the people
do amiss, they ought to be punyshed: but if the prince err, he should be
admonished, And as the Prince will the people should at his hands have
punishment: so it is reason that he at their hands should receive counsel.

For as the wealth of the one depends on the wealth of the other: so
truly if the prince be vycious, the people can not be virtuous. If your
majesty will punyshe your people with words, command them to prynt this
present work in their hearts. And if your people would serve your hyghnes with
their advise: let them likewise beseech you to read over this book. For
therein the subjects shall find how they may amend, and you Lords shall se all that you ought to do, wdether this present work be profitable, or no, I will
not that my pen shall declare: but they which reed it shall judge.

For we aucthours take pains to make and translate, and others for us use to
give judgment and sentence, From my tender years until this present, I have
lived in the world, occupieng my self, in reading and studieng human and
deuyne books, and although I confess my debilitie to be such, that I have not
read so much as I might, nor studied so much as I ought: yet not withstandinge
all that I have red, has not caused me to muse so much, as the doctrine of
Marcus Aurelius has, since that in the mouth of an heathen, god has put such a
great treasor. The greatest part of al his works were in Greek: yet he wrote
also many in latin. I have drawn this out of greek through the help of my
friends, and afterward out of latin into our vulgar tongue by the travail of
my hands. Let al men judge what I have suffered in drawing it out of Greek into
latin, out of the latin into the vulgar, and out of a plain vulgar, into a
sweet and pleasant style. For that banquet is not counted sumptuous, unless
there be both pleasant meats, and sauory sauces. To call sentences to mind, to
place the words, to examine languages, to correct sillables: what swette I
have suffered in the hot summer, what bitter cold in the sharp winter, what
abstinence from meats when I desired to eat, what watching in the night when
I would have slept, what cares I have suffered in steed of rest that I might
have enjoyed: let other prove, if me they will not credit. The intencion of my
painful travails, I offer to the divine majesty upon my knees, and to your
highness (noble prince) I present this my work, and humbly beseech god, that
the doctrine of this book may be as profitable unto you, and the common wealth
in your life: as it has been to me tedious, and hinderaunce to my health. I
have thought it good to offer to your majesty the effect of my labors,
though you peradventure will little regard my pains: for the requyting of my
travail, and reward of my good will, I require naught else of your highness, but
that the rudeness of my understanding, the baseness of my style, the smalnes of
my eloquence, the evil order of my sentences, the vanity of my words, be no
occasion, why so excellent and goodly a work should be little regarded. For it
is not reason, that a good horse should be the less esteemed, for that the
ryder knows not how to make him run his carrier. I have done what I could
do, do you now that you ought to do, in gyuynge to this present work
grauytye, and to me the interpretor thereof aucthority. I say no more, but
humbly beseech god to maintain your estimacion and power in earth: and that you
may afterward enjoy the fruicion of his deuyne presence in heaven.

The Argument of the book called the Dial of Princes. Wherein the aucthour
declares, his intencion and manner of proceadinge.
ARchimenedes, the great and famous philosopher, (to whom Marcus Marcellus for
his knowledge sake granted life, and after using Nygromancie deserved death)
being demanded what time was, said: that time was the inuentor of al
noueltyes, and a Regestre certain of antiquities, which sees of it self the
beginning, the midst, and the ending of al things. And finally, time is he
that ends al. No man can deny but the diffinition of this Philosopher is
true: for if time could speak, he would certifye us of sundry things wherein we
doubt, and declare them as a witness of sight. Admyt al things perish, and have
an end: yet one thing is exempted, and never has end, which is truth, that
amongst al things is priuileged in such wise, that she triumphs of time, and
not time of her. For according to the dyuine saying it shall be more easy to se
heaven, and earth to fall: then once truth to perish. There is nothing so
entyer, but may be diminished: nothing so healthful, but may be diseased:
nothing so strong, but may be broken: neither any thing so well kept, but may be
corrupted. And finally I say, there is nothing but by time is ruled and
governed, save only truth, which is subject to none The fruits of the spring
time have no force to give sustenaunce, nor perfait swetenes to give any
savor, but after that the summer is past, and harvest comes, they ripe, and
then all that we eat nourishes more and gives a better taste, I mean by
this, when the world began to have wise men, the more Philosophers were
esteemed for their good manners, the more they deserved to be reproved for their
evil understanding. Plato in his second book of the common wealth said, that
the ancient Philosophers) as well Greeks, as Egiptians, and Caldees) which
first began to behold the stars of heaven, and ascended to the top of
the mount Olimpus, to view the influences, and mocions of the planets on the
earth, deserved rather pardon of their ignorance, then praise for their
knowledge. Plato said further, that the Philosophers which were before us,
were the first that gave themselves to search out the truth of the Elements in
the heaven, and the first which sowed errors in things natural of the earth.
Homere in his Iliade agreyng with Plato, says. I condemn all that the ancient
Philosophers knew, but I greatly commend them for that they desired to know.
Certes Homere said well, and Plato said not amysse: for if amongst the first
Philosophers this ignorance had not raygned, there had not been such contrary
sects in every school. He that has read, not the books which are lost, but
the opinions which the ancient philosophers had, will grant me: though the
knowledge were one, yet their sects were diverse: that is to say. Cinici,
Stoici, Academici, Platonici, and Epicurei, which were as variable the one from
the other in their opinions, as they were repugnaunt in their conditions. I
will not, neither reason requires, that my pen should be so much dysmesured,
as to reprove those which are dead, for to give the glory al only to them
that are alive: for the one of them knew not al, neither were the other
ignorant of all. If he deserves thanks that shows me the way, whereby I
ought to go: no less then meriteth he, which warns me of the place wherein
we may err, The ignorance of our forefathers, was but a gyde to keep us from
^rryng: for the error of them showed us the truth, to their much praise, and
to our great shame. Therefore I dare boldly say, if we yt are now, had been
then, we had known less then they knew, And if those were now, which were
then, they would have known more then we know. And that this is true it
appears well, for that the ancient philosophers, through the great desire
they had to know the troth, of small and bypathes have made broad and large
ways, the which we now will not see, nor yet walk therein. Wherefore we have not
so much cause to bewail their ignorance, as they had reason to complain of
our negligence, For truth, which is (as Aulus Gelius says) the daughter of
time, has reveled unto us the errors which we ought to eschew: and the true
doctrine which we ought to follow. What is there to se, but has been seen? what
to dyscouer, but has been discovered? what is there to read, but has been
red? what to write, but has been written? what is there to know, but has been
known? now a days human malice is so expert, men so we ^able, and our
wits so subtyl, that we want nothing to understand, neither good, nor evil,
And we undo our selves by sekyng that vain knowledge, which is not necessary
for our life. No man under the pretense of ignorance can excuse his fault,
since al men know, al men read, and al men learn, the which is evident in
this case, as it shall appear. Suppose the ploughe man, and the learned man do
go to the law, and you shall perceive the labourer (under that simple garment)
to forge to his counselor half a dosen of malicious tricks, to delude his
adversary as fynely: as the other that is leerned shall be able to expound. 2. or
3. chapters of this book. If men would employ their knowledge to honesty,
wisdom, patience, and mercy, it were well: but I am sorry they know so much,
only for that they subtly disceiue, and by usury abuse their neighbors, and
keep that they have unjustly gotten, and daily getting more inuenting new
trades Finally I say if they have any knowledge, it is not to amend their life:
but rather to increase their goods. If the diuil could sleep, as men do, he
might safely sleep: for whereas he waketh to deceive us, we wake to undo our
selves, well, suppose that al these heretofore I have said is true: Let us now
leave aside craft, and take in hand knowledge, The knowledge which we attain to
is small, and that which we should attain to so great: that al yt we know, is ye
least part of yt we are ignorant Even as in things natural, the elamentes have
their operacions, according to the variety of time: so moral doctrines (as the
aged have succeeded) and sciences were discovered. Truly al fruits come not
together, but when one fails, another comes in season. I mean, that
neither all the Doctors among the Christians, nor all the philosophers among the
gentyles were concurrant at one time, but after the death of one good, there
came another better. The chief wisdom, which measures al things by justice:
and disparseth them according to his bounty, will not that at one time they
should be al wise men, and at an other time al simple. For it had not ben
reason the one should have had the fruit, and the other the leaves, The old
world that ran in Saturnes days (otherwise called the golden world) was of a
truth much esteemed of them that saw it, and greatly commended of them that
wrote of it. That is to say, it was not gilded by the Sages, which did gilde
it: but because there was no evil men, which did vngild it. For as thexperience
of the mean estate and nobility teaches us, of one only parson depends
as well the fame and renoume, as the infamy of a hole house, and parentage. That
age was called golden, that is to say of gold: and this our age is called
yronne, that is to say of iron. This dyfference was not, for that gold then was
found, and now iron: nor for that in this our age there is want of them that be
sage: but because the number of them surmounteth, that be at this day
malicious. I confess one thing, and suppose many will favor me in ye same.
Phauorin the philosopher (which was master to Aulus Gellius, and his especial
friend) said ofttimes, that the philosophers in old time were holden in
reputacion, because there were few teachers, and many learners. We now a days
se the contrary, for infinite are they which presume to be masters: but few
are they which humble them selves to be scholars. A man may know how little
wise men are esteemed at this hour, by the great veneracion that the
philosophers had in the old time. What a matter is it to se Homere amongst the
Grecians Solomon amongst the Hebrews, Lycurgus amongst the Lacedomoniens:
Phoromeus also amongst the Greeks, Ptolomeus amongeste the Egiptians. Liui
amongeste the Romans, and Cicero likewise amongeste the Latins? Appolonius
among the Indians, and Secundus amongst the Assirians.

How happy were those philosophers (to be as they were in those days) when the
world was so full of simple persons, and so destitute of sage men: that there
flocked great nombers out of diverse contries, and straung nations, not only to
here their doctrine: but also to se their persons. The glorious saint Hierome
in the prologue to the bible says. When Rome was in her prosperity, then
wrote Titus Liuius his decades: yet notwithstanding, men came to Rome more to
speak with Titus Liuius, then to se Rome or the high capitol thereof Marcus
Aurelius writing to his friend Pulio, said these words. Thou shall understand my
friend, I was not chosen Emperor for the noble blood of my predecessors, nor
for the favor I had amongst them now present: for there were in Rome of
greater blood and riches then I, but the Emperor Adrian my master set his
eyes upon me, and the emperor Anthony my father in law chose me for his son
in law, for no other cause, but for that they saw me a friend of the sages, and
an enemy of the ignorant. Happy was Rome to chose so wise an emperor, and
no less happy was he to attain to so great an empire. Not for that he was
heir to his predecessoure, but for that he gave his mind to study. Truly, if
that age then were happy to enjoy his person: no less happy shall ours be
now at this present, to enjoy his doctrine. Salust says, they deserved great
glory, which did worthy feats: and no lesser renown merited they, which wrote
them in high style. What had Alexander the great ben, if Quintus Curtius had
not written of him? what of Ulysses, if Homere had not been borne? what had
Alcibiades been, if Zenophon had not exalted him? what of Cirus, if the
philosopher Chilo had not put his acts in memory? what had been of Pirrus,
king of the Epirotes, if Hermicles cronicles were not? what had been of Scipio
the great Affricane, if it had not been for the decades of T^tus Liuius? what
had been of Traiane, if the renowned Plutarche had not been his friend? what of
Nerua and Anthonius the meke, if Phocion the Greek had not made mention of
them? how should we have known the stout courage of Caesar, and the great
prowess of Pompeius, if Lucanus had not written them? what of the twelve
Cesars, if Suetonius tranquillus had not compiled a book of their lives? and
how should we have known the antiquityes of the Hebrews, if the upright
Iosephe had not ben? who could have known the coming of the Lombardes into
Italy, if Paulus Diaconus had not writ it? how could we have known the coming
in, ye going out, and end of the Goths in Spain, if the curious Rodericus had
not showed it unto us? By these things that we have spoken of before, the
readers may perceive what is dew unto the Historiographers: who in my opinion,
have left as great memory of them for that they wrote with their pens: as
the princes have done for that they did with their swords. I confess I
deserve not to be named amongst the sages, neither for that I have written and
translated, nor yet for that I have composed. Therefore (the sacred and deuyne
letters set a side) there is nothing in the world so curiouslye written, but
neadeth correction, and as I say of the one, so will I say of the other, and
that is: as I with my will do renounce the glory, which the good for my
learning would give me: so in like manner evil men shall not want, that against
my will will seek to defame it, We other writers, smally esteem the labor and
pains we have to write, although in deed we are not ignorant of a thousand
enuyous tongues, that will backbite it, Many now a days are so evil taught, or
to say better, so enuyous, that when the aucthour laboreth in his study, they
play in the streates: when he waketh, they sleep. When he fasteth, they eat:
when he sits turninge the leaves of the book they go huntyng after vices
abroad: yet for all that, they will presume to judge, deprave, and condeme an
other man's doctrine, as if they had the aucthoritye that Plato had in greece, or
the eloquence that Cicero had in Rome. When I find a man in the latin tongue
well seen, his vulgar tongue well polished, in histories well grounded, in Greek
letters very expert, and desirous to spend his time with good books: this so
heroical and noble a parsonage, I would desire him to put my doctrine under his
fete For it is no shame, for a virtuous and wise man, to be corrected of an
other wise man. Yet I would gladly know what patience can suffer, or heart
dissemble, when two or three be assembled togithers at meat, and after (at the
table, or otherwise) one of them takes a book at adventure in his hands,
against the which another will say it is to long, and another will say it
speaks not to the purpose: another it is obscure, and another the words are
not well couched: another will say, all that that is spoken is fained, one will
say he speaks nothing of profit, another he is to curious, and the other he
is to malicious. So that in speaking thus, the doctrine remains suspicious,
and the author scapeth not scotte fre. Suppose them to be therefore such that
speak it (as I have spoken of) and that at the table do find such faults,
suer they deserve pardon: for they speak not according to the books which
they have read, but accord^nge to the cups of wine which they have drunk.
For he that takes not that in geste, which is spoken at the table, knows
not what gesting means. It is an old custom to murmr at virtuous deeds,
and into this rule enters not only those that make them, but also those
which wryt them afterward: Which thing seems to be true, for that Socrates
was reproved of Plato* Plato of Aristotle. Aristotle of Auerois, Sicilius of
Vulpitius. Lelius of Varro, Marinus of Ptolomens, Ennius of Horace, Seneca of
Aulus Gellius, Crastonestes of Strabo, Thessale of Gallian, Hermagoras of
Cicero. Cicero of Salust, Origines of saint Hierome, Hierome of Rufinus,
Rufinus of Donatus, Donatus of Prosper, and Prosper of Lupus. Then sith that
in these men, and in their works has been such neade of correction, which
were men of great knowledge, and Lanternes of the world: it is no maruayle at
all that I have such fortune, since I know so little as I do He may worthily
be counted vain and light, which at the first sight, as for only once
reading, will rashely judge that, which a wise man with much diligence, and
study has written. The authors, and writers are ofttimes reproved, not of
them which can translate, and compile works: but of those which can not
read, and yet less understand them. to the intent simple folks should count
them wise, and take their parts in condemning this work and esteem him for a
great wise man. I take God to witness, who can judge, whether my intention were
good or ill to compile this work, and also I say this my doctrine at the feet
of wise and virtuous men, to the end they may be protectours, and defendours
of the same. For I trust in God, though some would come to blame (as diverse
do) the simple words which I spoke: yet others would not fail to relate the
good intention that I meant. And to declare further I say, that diverse have
written of the time of the said Marcus Aurelius, as Herodian wrote little,
Eutropius less, Lampridius not so much, and Julius capitolinus somewhat more.
Likewise ye ought to know, that the masters which taught Marcus Aurelius
sciences, were Iunius Rusticus, Cinna Catullus, Sextus Cheronensis, which was
nephewe to the great Plutarque. These three were those, that principally as
witnesses of sight, wrate the most part of his life and doctrine. Many may
marvel to hear tell of the doctrine of Marcus Aurelius, saying, it has been
kept hid and secret a great while, and that of mine own head I have invented
it. And that there never was any Marcus Aurelius in the world. I know not what
to say now unto them, for it is evident to all those which have red any
thing, that Marcus Aurelius was husband to Faustine, father to Comodus,
brother to Annius Verus, and son in law to Antonius Pius, the seventh (of
Rome) Emperor. Those which say I only have made this doctrine, truly I thank
them for so saying, but not for their so meaning For truly, the Romans would
have set my Image in Rome for perpetual renown, if so grave sentences should
have proceaded from my head. We see that in our time, which was never seen
before, and hear that we never heard before. We practice not in a new world,
and yet we marueyle that there is at this present a new book. Not for that I
was curious to discover Marcus Aurelius, or studious to translate him. For
truly it is worthy he be noted of wise persons, and not accused of equious
tongues. For it chances oftentimes in hunting that the most simplest man
kills the dear. The last thing which the Romans conquered in Spain, was
Cantabria, which was a city in Nauarra, over against Lagrogne, and situated
in a high country, where there is now a vain of vynes. And the Emperor
Augustus which destroyed it, made ten books De bello Cantabrico, where are
things worthy of notinge, and no less pleasant in reading, which happened
unto him in the same conquest. As Marcus Aurelius was brought me from Florence,
so was this other book of the wars of Cantabrie brought me from Colleine. If
perhaps I took pains to translate this book, as few have done which have
seen it, they would speak the like of it, that they did of Marcus Aurelius.
Because men are so long in speaking, and so brief in studienge, that without
any let or shame, they will a vow no book to be in the world this day, but
that they have read, or seen it. I have as much profited in this writynge,
which is human: as other doctors have done in matters, which are divine.
It is not translated word for word, but sentence for sentence. For we other
interpreters are not bound, to give words by measure: but it suffiseth us, to
give sentencis by wayghte. I began to study this work in the year, a
thousand, five hundred, and eyghtene, and until the year, a thousand, five
hundred, twenty and four, I could neither understand, nor know, wherein I
was occupied. and albeit I kept it secreat.vi. years yet it was known abroad
whereupon the Emperor his majesty being with the fever diseased, sent to me
for it to pass the time away And I (according to his commandment) showed him
Marcus Aurelius that then was uncorrected, and humbly beseaching him said:
that for recompense of all my travail, I desired no other reward, but that no
man in his chamber might copye the book. And I in the mean time proceeded to
accomplish the work, Because I did not mean in such manner to publyshe it:
for otherwise, I said his majesty should be evil served, and I also of my
purpose prevented: but my sins caused, that the book was copyed, and
conveyed from one to another. And by the hands of Pages sondrie times written*
so that there increased daily in it errors, and faults. And since there was
but one original copye, they brought it unto me to correct, which if it
could have spoken, would have complained it self, more of them that did
write it: then of those which did steal it. And thus when I had finyshed
the work, and thought to have publysshed it, I perceived that Marcus Aurelius
was now imprinted at Civil. And in this case, I take the readers to be judges,
between me and the Imprinters, because they may see, whether it may stand
with law, and justice, that a book which was to his imperial majesty
dedicated, the auctour thereof being but an infant, and the book so vnparfecte
and vncorrect, without my consent or knowledge should be published.

Notwithstanding they ceased not, but printed it again in Portugal, and also
in the kingdom of Navarre, And if the first impression was faultye, truly the
second and the third were no less. So that which was written for the wealth
of all men generallye, each man did apply to the profit of him self
particularlye. There chanced another thing of this book called the golden
book of Marcus Aurelius, which I am ashamed to speak, but greater shame they
should have, that so dishonestly have done. That is, some made them selves to
be auctours of the whole work, others say that part of it was made, and
compyled of their own heads: the which appears in a book in print,
wherein the auctour did like a man void of all honestye, and in another book,
one used likewise the words which Marcus Aurelius spoke to Faustine, when she
asked him the key of his study. After these thieves came to my knowledge, judge
you whether it were inoughe to prove my patience. For I had rather they had
robbed me of my goods, then taken away my renown. By this all men shall see,
that Marcus Aurelius was not then corrected, nor in any place parfecte, whereby
they might perceive, that it was not my mind to translate Marcus Aurelius, but
to make a dial^ for Princes, whereby all christien people may be governed and
ruled. And as the doctrine is showed for the use of many: so I would profit
my self, with that which the wise men had spoken and written. And in this
sort proceadeth the work, wherein I put one, or two Chapiters of mine, and
after I put some epistles of Marcus Aurelius, and other doctrine of some
ancient men. Let not the reader be disceaued, to think that the one, and the
other is of the auctor. For although the phrase of the languag be mine, yet I
confess the greatest part that I knew, was of another man, although the
historiographers and doctors (with whom I was helped) were many: yet the
doctrine which I wrote, was but one. I will not deny, but I have left out
some things which were superfluous: in whose stead I have placed, things
more sweet, and profitable. So that it neadeth good wits, to make that which
seems in one language gross, in another to give it the apparaunce of gold. I
have divided into three books this present dial of Princes. The first
treats, that the Prince ought to be a good christian. The secound, how he
ought to govern his wife, and children. The third teaches, how he should
govern his person, and his commen wealth. I had begone another book, wherein
was contained, how a Prince should behave him self in his court, and
palace, but the importunity of my friends, caused me to withdraw my pen, to
the end I might bring this work to light.

The Table of the Dial of Princes
THe Prologue general of the Auctour The Prologue upon the book entitled
Marcus Aurelius, The Argument of the whole book. The first Chapter entreats
of the birth and lynage of Marcus Aurelius, where the Auctour recites at the
beginning of the book.iii Chapters in the which he declares the discourse of
his lief: for by his Epistles and doctrine this whole work is proved. Chap. i.
Of a letter which Marcus Aurelius, wrote to his friend Pulio: wherein he
recounteth the order of his lyef. and among other things declares the words
which a poor man of Nola spoke unto the Roman censor. Chap. ii. Macus
Aurelius concludes his letter, and mencioneth the scienses which he learned,
and all the masters he had, and in the end he recites five notable things in
the obseruaunce of the which the Romans were very curious. Chap. iii. Of the
excellencye of the Christian religion (whereby the true God is known) and of
the vanities of the auncientes in times past. Chap iiii. How among the
Auncientes the Philosopher Bruxellus was esteemed, and of the words he spoke
unto them at the hour of his death. Chap. v. Of the words which Bruxellus
the Philosopher spoke to the senate of Rome. Chap. vi. How the Gentiles
thought that one God was not of power sufficient to defend them from their
enemies. Chap. vii. Of a letter which the senate sent unto all those which were
subject to the empire. Chap. viii. Of the true and living God, and of the
maruailes he wroughte in the old law to manifest his divine power, and of the
superstition of the false gods Chap. ix. That there is but one true God, and
how that realm is hapie which has a King that is a good christian. Chap.
x. Of Sundry gods which the Ancients worshipped, of the office of those gods,
and how they were revenged of them that displeased them. Chap. xi. Of other
more natural and peculiar gods which the Ancient people had. Chap xii. How
Tyberius the knight was chosen governor of the empire, and afterward created
Emperor, only for being a good Christian: and how God deprived Iustinia^ the
younger both of his senses and empire for being an heretic. Chap. xiii. Of the
words the empress Sophia spoke to Tiberius Constantinus, which tended to his
reproffe for that he consumed the treasures which she had gathered. Chap.
xiiii. The answer of Tiberius unto the empress Sophia, wherein he declares
that Princes need not to hourde up great treasures. Chap. xv. How the
chieftaine Narsetes overcame many battles, only for that his wholle
confydence was in God. And what happened to him by the empress Sophia Augusta:
wherein may be noted the vnthanckfulnes of Princes toward their servants.
Chap. xvi. Of a letter the emperor Marcus Aurelius sent to the king of
Scicille, in the which he records the travails they endured to gether in
their youth, and reproves him of his small reverence toward the temples.
Chap. xvii. The Emperor proceeds in his letter to admonish Princes to be
fearful of their gods, and of the sentence which the senate gave upon this
king, for pullinge down the church. Chap. xviii. How the Gentiles honored
those which were devout in the service of the gods. Chap. xix. For five
causes Princes ought to be better Christians then their subjects. Chap. xx. Of
the Philosopher Bias, and of the.x. Laws which he gave, worthy to be had in
mind. Chap xxi. How God from the beginning punysshed evil men by his Justice,
and specially those Princes that despise his church and mansion house. Chap.
xxii. The auctour proves by.xii. examples that Princes are sharply punyshed
when they usurp boldlye upon the churches and violate the temples. Chap.
xxiii. How Valentine the Emperor because he was an evil christian, lost in
one day both the Empire and his lief, and was burned alive in a shepecoote.
Chap. xxiiii. Of the Emperor Valentinian and Gratian his son, which because
they were good Christians were always fortunate: and that God gives victories
unto Princes more through tears of them that pray, then through the weapons
of those that fight. Chap. xxv. Of the godly Oration which the Emperor
Gratian made to his soldiers before he gave the battle. Chap. xxvi. That
the captain Theodosius (which was father of the great Emperor Theodosius)
died a good Christian: of the king Hysmarus and the bishop Siluanus and the
holy laws which they made and established. Chap. xxvii. What a goodly thing
it is to have but one prince to rule in the public weal, for their is no
greater enemy to the common weal then he which procures many to command
therein. Chap. xxviii. That in a public weal there is no greater destruction,
then where Princes daily consent to new orders, and change old customs. Chap.
xxix When Tyrauntes begame to reign, and upon what occasion commanding and
obeing first began: and how the authority the Prince has is by the
ordinance of God. Chap. xxx. Of the golden age in times past, and worldly
myserie at this present. Chap. xxxi. What the Garamantes said unto king
Alexander the great when he went to co^quer India, and how that the purity of
lief has more power, then any force of war. Chap. xxxii. Of an Oration which
one of the sages of Garamantia made unto king Alexander, a goodlye lesson for
ambitious men. Chap. xxxiii. The sage Garamante continues his Oration, and
among other notable matters he makes mencyon of seven laws which they
observed. Chap. xxxiiii That Princes ought to consider for what cause they were
made Princes, and what Thales the Philosopher was, and of the questions
demanded him. Chap. xxxv. What Plutarke the philosopher was, the wise words he
spoke to Tra^an the emperor, and how the good Prince is the head of the
publyke weal. Chap. xxxvi. The Prince ought to hear the complayntes of all
his subjects, and to know them all to recompense their service. Chap. xxxvii.
Of a solemn feast the Romans celebrated to the God Ianus, and of the
bounty of the Emperor Marcus Aurelius the same day. Chap. xxxviii. Of the
Emperors answer to Fuluius the senator, wherein he peynteth envious men. Chap.
xxxix. Of a letter the emperor Marcus Aurelius wrote to his friend Pulio,
wherein he declares the opinions of certain Philosophers concerning the
felicity of man. Chap. xl. That Princes and great Lords ought not to esteem
them selves for being fayer and well proportioned of body. Chap. xli. Of a
letter which Marcus Aurelius wrote to his neuew Epesipus, worthy to be noted
of all young Gentlemen. Chap. xlii. How Princes and noble men in old time
were lovers of sages. Chap. xliii. How the Emperor Theodosius provided wise
men at the hour of his death for the education of his sons. Chap. xliiii.
Cresus king of Lidya was a great lover of sages of a letter, the same Cresus
wrote to the Philosopher, Anacarses, and of the Philosophers answer again to
the king. Chap. xlv. Of the wisdom and sentence of Phalaris the Tyraunte, and
how he put an Artisan to death for Inuenting new torments. Chap. xlvi. That
sondrye mighty and puyssant Princes were lovers and friends of the sages.
Chap. xlvii. The end of the Table of the first Book.

The table of the second Book.
OF what excellencye marriage is, and where as common people mary of free will,
princes and noble men ought to marye of necessity. Chap. i. How by means of
marriage many mortal enemies have been made parfitte friends. Chap. ii. Of
the sundry laws the ancients had in contracting matrimony, and of the manner
of celebrating marriage Chap. iii. How princesses and great ladies ought to love
their husbands: and that must be without any manner of witchcraft or sorcerye
but only procured by wisdom and obedience. Chap. iiii. The revenge of a
Greciane Lady on him that had slain her husband in hope to have her to wife.
Chap. v. That pryncesses and great Ladies should be obedient to their
husbands, and that it is a great shame to the husband to suffer to be
commanded by his wife. Chap vi. That women (especially princesses and great
ladies) should be very circumspect in goinge abroad out of their houses, and
that through the resort of them that come to their houses they be not ill
spoken of. Chap. vii. Of the commodities and discomodities which follow
princesses and great Ladies that go abroad to visit, or abide in the house.
cap viii. That women great with child (namely princesses and great Ladies)
ought to be very circumspect for the danger of the creatures they bear:
wherein is laid before you, many known and sorrowful mysfortunes happened to
women in that case. Cap ix. A further rehearsal of other inconveniences and
unlucky chances happened to women great with child. Chap. x. That women great
with child (chieflye princesses and great ladies) ought to be gently entreated
of their husbands. Chap. xi. What the Philosopher Pisto was, and of the rules
he gave concerning women with child. Chap. xii. Of three counsels which Lucius
Seneca gave unto a secretary his friend who served the emperor Nero. And how
Marcus Aurelius dsposed all the hours of the day. Cap. xiii. Of the Importunate
suit of ye empress Faustine to ye Emperor Marcus Aurelius her husband
concerning the key of his closet. Chap. xiiii. The Emperors answer to
Faustine touching the demand of the key of his closet. Chap. xv. The
Emperor follows his matter, admonishinge men of the plagues and great
dangers that follow those, which haunt to much the company of women. And
recites also certain rules for married men, which if they be matched with
shrowes and do observe them, may cause them live in quiet with their wives.
Chap. xvi. The Emperor answers more particularly concerning the key of his
closet. Chap. xvii. That princesses and noble women ought not to be ashamed
to give their children suck with their own breasts Chap. xviii. The auctour
still persuades women to give their own children suck. Chap. xix. That
princesses and great ladies ought to be very circumspecte in chosinge their
nurces, of seven properties which a good nource, should have. Chap. xx. The
auctor adds.3. other conditions to a good nource that gives suck. Chap.
xxi. Of the disputacion before Alexander the great concerning the sucking of
babes. Chap. xxii. Of wytchcraftes and sorceries which the nources used in old
time in geuinge their children suck. Chap xxiii. Marcus Aurelius writes to
his friend Dedalus, inueighenge against witches which cure children by
sorceries and charms. Chap. xxiiii. How excellent a thing it is for a
gentleman to have an eloquent tongue. cap. xxv. Of a letter which the Athenians
sent to the Lacedaemonians. Chap. xxvi. That nources which give suck to the
children of princes ought to be discret and sage women. Chap. xxvii. That women
may be no less wise then men, and though they be not it is not through default
of nature, but for want of good bringyng up. Chap. xxviii. Of a letter which
Pithagoras sent to his sister Theoclea she readinge at that time philosophy in
Samothracia. Chap. xxix. The auctor follows his purpose, persuading
princesses and great ladies to endeavor them selves to be wise as the women were
in old time. Chap xxx. Of the worthynes of the lady Cornelia, and of a notable
epistle she wrote to her.ii. sons Tyberius, and Caius: which served in the
wars. Chap. xxxi. Of the educacion and doctrine of children whiles they are
young. Chap. xxxii. Princes ought to take heed that their children be not
brought up in vain pleasures and delights. chap. xxxiii. That princes and
great lords ought to be careful in seeking men to bring up their children. Of
x. conditions that good school masters ought to have. Chap. xxxiiii. Of the
ii. sons of Marcus Aurelius of the which the eldest and best beloved dyed.
And of the masters he reproved for the other named Comodus. Chap. xxxv. How
Marcus Aurelius rebuked five of the xiiii. masters he had chosen for the
educacion of his son Comodus. And how he bannished the rest from his palace
for their light behauior at the feast of the god Genius. Chap. xxxvi. That
princes and other noble men ought to ouersee the tutours of their children lest
they conceal the secret faults of their scholars. Chap. xxxvii. Of the
Emperors determinacio^ when he committed his son to the tutoures, which he
had provided for his educacion. Chap. xxxviii. That tutours of princes and
noble men's sons ought to be very circumspect, that their scholars do not
accustom them selves in vices whiles they are young, and specially to keep
them from four vices. Chap xxxix. Of.ii. other vices perilous in youth which
the masters ought to keep them from. Chap. xl. The end of the Table of the
second Book.

The table of the third Book.
HOw Princes and great Lords ought to travail to administer to all equal
Justice. Chap. i. The way that Princes ought to use in choosing their Judges
and Officers in their contreyes. Chap. ii. Of an oration which a vilian of
Danuby made before the senators of Rome, concerning the tyranny and
oppressions which their officers use in his country. Chap. iii. The villayne
argues against the Romans, which without cause or reason concquered their
contreye and proved manifestely that they through offendyng of their gods were
vancquished of the Romans. Chap. iiii. The villayne concludes his oration
against the Judges which minister not Justice, and declares how prejudicial
such wicked men are to the common weal. Chap. v. That Princes and noble men
should be very circumspect in choosyng Judges and Officers for therein
consists the profyt of the publyke weal. Chap. vi. Of a letter which Marcus
Aurelius wrote to Antigonus his friend, wherein he speaks against the
crueltye of Judges and Officiers. Chap. vii. The Emperor Marcus continues his
letter against cruel Judges, and recites ii. examples: the one of a pitiefull
king of Cipres, and the other of a cruel Judge of Rome, and in this Chapter is
mentioned the erbe Ilabia (growing in Cipres, on the mount Arcladye) which
being cut droppeth blood. etc. Chap. viii. Of the words, which Nero spoke
concerning justice, and of the instruction, which the Emperor Augustus gave
to a judge which he sent into Dacia. Cap. ix. The Emperor follows his purpose
against cruel judges, and declares a notable imbassage which came from Judea
to the Senate of Rome, to complain of the judges that governed that Realm.
Chap. x. The Emperor concludes his letter against the cruel judges, and
declares what the grand father of king Boco spoke in the Senate. Chap. xi. An
exhortacion of the auctor to princes and noble men, to embrace peace, and to
eschew the occasions of war. Chapter xii. The commodities, which come of
peace. Chap. xiii. A letter of Marcus Aurelius to him fre^d Cornelius, wherein
he describes the discommodities of war, and the vanity of the triumph,
Chap. xiiii. The Emperor Marcus Aurelius declares the order that the Romans
used in setting forth men of war, and of the ou^tragious vilanies, which
captains and soldiers use in the wars. Chap. 15. Marcus Aurelius lamenteth
with tears the follye of the Romans, for that they made war with Asia. And
declarethe what great damage comes unto the people where the prince does begin
wars in a straung country. Chap. xvi. That princes and great lords (the more
they grow in years) should be the more discrete and virtuous to refrain from
vices. Chap. xvij. That princes when they are aged, should be temperate in
eating, sober in drynking, modest in apparel, and above al, true in their
communication. Chap. xviii.. Of a letter of the Emperor Marcus Aurelius to
Claudius, and Claudinus, wherein he reproves those that have many years, and
little discrecion. Chap. xix The emperor follows his letter, and persuades
those that are old, to give no more credit to the world, nor to any of his
flatteries. Chap. xx. The emperor procedith in his letter, and proves by good
reasons, that since the aged persons will be served and honored of the young:
they ought to be more virtuous and honest then the young. Chap. xxi. The
emperor concludes his letter, and shows what perilles those old men live
in, which dissolutly like young children pass their days, and gives unto them
holsom counsel for the remedy thereof. Chap. xxii. Princes ought to take heed
that they be not noted of Avarice, for that the covetous man is both of god and
man hated. Cap xxiii. The auctor follows his matter, and with great reasons
disco^mendeth the vices of covetous men, Chap. xxiiii, Of a letter which the
emperor M. Aurelius wrote to his fre^d Cincinatus wherein he touches those
gentlemen, which will take upon them the trade of marchaundise against their
vocations divided into 4. chapters, Chap, xxv. The Emperor proceeds his
letter, and declares what virtues men ought to use, and the vices which they
ought to eschew. Cap. xxvi. The Emperor concludes his letter, and parswadeth
his friend Cincinatus to despise the vanities of the world, and shows though a
man be never so wise yet he shall have need of a another man's counsel. chap.
xxvii. The auctor persuades princes and great lords to fly covetousness and
avarice, and to become liberal, which is a virtue semely for a Royal parson.
Cap. xxviii. The auctor parswadeth gentlemen, and those ye profess arms, not
to abase them selves by taking upon them any vile offices for gain sake. Cap.
xxix. Of a letter themperoure wrote to his neighbor Marcurius, wherein men may
learn the dangers of those which traffic by sea, and see the covetousness
of them that travail by land. Cap xxx. The Emperor follows his matter, and
concludes his leter, rebuking his friend Marcurius, for that he took thought
for the loss of his goods. He shows the nature of fortune, and the
conditions of the covetous man. Cap. xxxi. That princes and noble men ought to
consider the misery of man's nature, and that brute beasts are in some points
(reason set a part) to be preferred unto man. cap. xxxii The auctor compares
the misery of me^, with the liberty of beasts. Cap. xxxiii. The Emperor
writes his letter to Domicius to comfort him being banyshed for a quarrel
betwixt him and another about the running of a horse, very comfortable to al
them, that have been in prosperitye, and are now brought into adversity. Cap.
xxxiiii. That princes and noble men ought to be aduocattes for widows, fathers
of orphans, and helpers of al those which are comfortles. xxxv. That the
troubles, greefes, and sorrows of women are much greater then those of men,
wherefore princes and noble men ought to have more compassion upon women: then
on men. Cap. xxxvi. Of a letter which the Emperor wrote to a Roman lady named
Lauinia comforting her for the death of her husband, which is a great
consolation for all those, that are sorrowful, for the dissease of their
friends. Chap. xxxvii. The Emperor persuaded wid^es to put their wylles unto
the will of god, and exorteth them to live honestly. Chap. xxxviii. That
princes, and noble men ought to despise the world, for that there is nothing in
ye world but plain disceyte. Chap. xxxix. The emperor speaks vehemently
against th disceytes of the world. Chap. xl. Of a letter, which the Emperor
Mar. Aure. wrote to Torquatus to comfort him in his banishement, which is
notable for all men to learn the vanities of this world. Chap. xli. The
Emperor persuades al men by strong and high reasons, not to trust ye world
nor any thing therein. Chap. xlii. Princes and noble men ought not to bear
with Iuglers, iesters, parasites, minstrelles loyterers, nor with any such kind
of raskals And of the laws which the Romans made in this behalf. Chap.
xliii, How some loyterers were punished by the auncientes, and of these
raskalles of our time. Chap. xliiii. Of a letter which the Emperor wrote to a
friend of his, certifieng him, that he had banished from Rome, the iesters
iuglers, conterfet fools, parasytes, ruffia^s, minstrels, vacabondes, and al
other loyterers a notable letter for such as keep cou^terfait foles in their
houses. Chap. xlv. How the Emperor found the sepulchers of many learned
Philosophers in Helespont, whereunto he sent all these loyteres. Chap. xlvi.
The emperor declares the cause why these iesters and iuglers were admytted
into Rome. Chap. xlvii. That Princes and noble men ought to remember, that they
are mortal and must die, where are sundry notable consolations against the
fear of death. Chap xlviii. Of the death of ye Emperor. Mar. Aur. and how
they are few friends which dare say the truth unto sickmen. Chap. xlix. Of the
confortable words, which the secretarye Pannutius spoke to the Emperor
Marcus Aurelius, at the hour of his death. Chap. l. Pannutius the secretary
exorteth al men wyllingly to accept death and utterly to for sake the world and
his vanity. Chap. li. The answer of the Emperor. Marcus to Panutius his
secretary wherein he declared that he took no thought to forsake ye world: but
all his sorrow was to leave behind him an unhappy child to enherite the
Empire. Chap. lii. The Emperor Marcus Aurelius concludes his matter and
shows that sondrye young Princes for being vicious, have undone the^ selves,
and impouerished their Realms. Chap. liii. Of the words which the emperor M.
Arelius spoke unto his son Commodus necessary for all noble young gentlemen
to understand. Chap. liiii, The emperor. Mar. aur. among other wholesome
counsels exorteth his son to keep wise and sage me^ about him, for to give him
counsel in all his affairs. Chap. lv. The emperor follows his matter and
exorteth his son unto certain particular things worthy to be engraued in the
hearts of men. Char. lvi. The good Marcus Aurelius Emperor of Rome ends his
purpose, and life. And of the last words which he spoke to his son Co^modus
and of the table of counsels which he gave him. Chap. lvii. The end of the
Table of the third book.

The table of the fourth book.
The Epistle to the Reader. The Prologue. The Argument. That it is more
necessary for the courtier (abidyng in court) to be of lively spirit and
audacitie, the^ it is for the soldier, that goes to serve in the wars.
Chap. i. Of courtiers brawles and quarrels with the harbingers for ill lodging.
Chap. ii. How the courtier should entreat his host or master of the house
wheare he lies. Chap. iii. What the Courtier must do to win the Princes
favor. Chap. iiii. What manners and gestures become the courtier when he
speaks to the Prince. Chap. v. How the courtier should behave himself to
know, and to visit the noble men and gentle men, that be great with the
Prince and contynuing still in court. Chap. vi. Of the good countenance and
modesty the courtier should have in behauing himself at the prince or noble
man's table in yt time of his meal. Cap. vii. What company the courtier
should keep and how he should apparel himself. Chap. viii. Of the wise manner
the courtier should have to serve and honor the Ladies and gentlewomen, and
also to satisfye and please the ushers and porters of the kings house. Chap.
ix. Of the great pains and troubles the courtier has that is toild in suits
of law, and how he must suffer and behave himself with the Judges. Chap. x.
The auctor speaks of the beloved of the court, admonishing them to be pacient
in their troubles, and that they be not partial in thaffayres of the common
weal. Chap. xi. That thofficers and beloved of the court should be very
diligent, and careful in the dispatche of the affairs of the prince and common
weal, and in correctynge and reformyng their servant, they should also be
very circumspct and advised. Chap. xij. That the deerlings of the court beware
they be not proud, and high minded, for lightlye they never fall but through
this wicked vice. Chap. xiii, That it is not fit for courtiers to be to
covetous, if they mean to keape themselves, out of many troubles and dangers.
Chap. xiiii. That the favored of the court should not trust to much to
their favor and credit they have, nor to the great prosperity of their life, a
worthy chapter and full of good doctrine Chap. xv. The auctor admonysheth those
that are in favor, and great with the prince, that they take heed of the
deceipts of the world, and learn to live and dye honorably, and that they
leave the court before age overtake them. Chapter xvi. Of the continency of
favored courtiers and how they ought to shonne the company and conversation of
dishonest women, and to be careful quickly to dispatch al such as sue unto
them. Chap. xvii. That the nobles and beloved of princes excede not in
superfluous fare, and that they be not to sumptuous in their meats. A notable
chapter for those that use to much delicacye and superfluity. Chap. xviii. That
the favored of princes ought not to be dishonest of their tongues nor envious
of their words. Chap. xix. A comendacion of troth, which professed courtiers
ought to embrace, and in no respect to be found defective in the contrary,
telling one thing for another. Chap xx. The end of the table of the fourth
Book.

Hear begins the table of the letters, translated out of Spanishe, which
were not in the French Copye.
OF a huge monster which was seen in Scicilli in the time of Marcus Aurelius.
Chap. i. Of that which chanced, unto a neighbor of his in Rome, in the time
of his Empire. Chap. ii. How Marcus Aurelius the Emperor sought the wealth
of his people, and how his people loved him. Chap. iii. How at the intercession
of many, which the Empress had sent, the Emperor granted his daughter
Lucilla license to sport her self at the feasts. Chap. iiii. Of the sharp
words which Marcus Aurelius spoke to his wife, and too his daughter. Chap.
v. The Emperor exhorts his wife to take away all occasions of evil from her
daughter, where in is declared the frailetye of the tender flesh. Chap. vi. Of
the wysedom of Marcus Aurelius in procuryng husbands for his daughters. Chap.
vii Of a letter which the Emperor Marcus Aurelius sent to his especial friend,
to comfort him in his troubles. Chap. viii. A letter sent by the Emperor
Marcus Aurelius to Censorius, that was so sorrowful for the death of his son,
worthy to be red and noted. Chap. ix A letter sent by Marcus Aurelius Emperor
to Censorius of the news, which at that time were at Rome. Chap. x. Of a
sharp letter full of reprehensions sent by the Emperor Marcus Aurelius to the
amourous ladies of Rome, because in his absence they devised a play of him.
Cap. xi. Of a letter which he sent to his lover Bohemia, for that she desired
so earnestlye to go with him to the wars, wherein is to be noted the great
folly of young men, and the little shame of evil women. Cap. xii. The answer of
Bohemia to the Emperor Marcus Aurelius wherein is expressed the great malice,
and little patience of an evil woman. Chap. xiii. Of a letter which the Emperor
Marcus Aurelius sent to the lady Macrine, the Romayne, of whom (beholding her
at the window) he became enamoured, which declares what force the beauty of a
fair woman has in a weak man Chap. xiiii. Of an other letter, which the
Emperor sent to the lady Macrine, wherein he expresses the fiery flames which
consume sonest the gentle hearts. Chap. xv. Of a letter which the Emperor
Marcus Aurelius sent to the beautiful lady of Lybia, wherein he reproves that
love is natural, and that the most part of the philosophers and men have been
by love overcome. Chap. xvi. The end of the table.

The first book of the Dial of princes, with the famous Book of Marcus
Aurelius, wherein be entreats what excellency is in the prince, that is a
good Christian: and contrariwyse, what evils do follow him, that is a cruel
tyrante.
Where the Author speaks of the birth and lynage of the wise Philosopher and
Emperor, Marcus Aurelius And he puts also at the beginning of this Book
three Chapters, wherein he entreats of the discourse of his life: for by his
Epistles and doctrine, the whole of this present work is proved. Cap. i.
AFter the death of the Emperor Antonius Pius, in the 695. years from the
foundation of Rome, and in the 173. Olimpiade: Fuluius Cato, and Gneus
Patroclus then being consulles: the fourth day of October, in the high
Capitol of Rome, at suit of the whole Roman people and with thassent of the
sacred Senate Marcus Aurelius Antonius was proclaimed Emperor universal of
the whole Roman monarche. This noble prince was naturally of Rome borne in
the mount Celio, on the sixth day before the Kalendes of May, which after the
Latins accounte is the.xxvi. day of April. His Graundefather was called Annius
Verus, and was chosene senatoure in the time of the Emperors Titus, and
Vespasian, his great graunde fathere was named Annius Verus, which was borne
in Spain in the free town of Gububa, whenne the wars were most cruel
between Caesar and Pompeius: at what time many Spanyardes fled to Rome, and
many Romans ran into Spain. By this means this Emperor had a great
graundfather a Romayne, and a great graundmother a Spanyard. His father was
named Annius Verus after his grandfather and great grandfather, by reason
whereof the ancient historiographers call him Marcus Antonius Verus. And true
it is that the Emperor Adrian called him Marcus Verissimus, for that he never
forged lie nor swarued at any time from the truth. These Annij Very were a
kindred in Rome (as Julius Capitolinus reports) which vaunted themselves to
come of Numa Pompilius and Quintus Curtius the famous Roman: which (to work
the Roman people safety, and his own person everlasting memory) willingly
threw him self into the lake, which afterward was called Curtius. That as
then was seen in Rome. This Emperors mother was called Domitia Camilla, as
recounteth Cinna in the books that he wrote of Romain pedigrees. That stock
of Camilli, was in those days highly honored in Rome: for that they
conueighed their dissent from that Camillus, which was the renowned and
valiant Romain captain, who delivered Rome when the Gavvles had taken it and
besieged the Capitol. The men that sprange of this lineage bare the name of
Camilli, for remembrance of this Camillus. And the woman that came of the same
stock kept the name of Camille, in memory of a daughter of the said
Camillus. This Camilla refused marriage, and chose to live among the vessall
virgins: and there long space remained enduring a sharp and hard life. And
she was so virtuous a Romayne and precise in her life, that in the time of
Seuerus Emperor of Rome, her tomb was honored as a relic, whereon was
engraued this Epitaphe.

Camilla lo, does here engraued rest.
That only was, Camillus daughter dear
Twyse twenty years, and fix, she has possessed
A covert life, un touchte of any feere.
The king of Trinacry, could not her move
To taste the sweet delight of wedlockes band
Nor train by suit, her sacred mind to love,
^nclosde in breest, so deep did chastnes stand.
But oh, great wrong, the crawling worms her do
To gnawe, on that unspotted senceles corse
That rage of youth spent undefiled so
With sober life, in spite of Cupides force.
And this was written in heroycal verse in the Greek tongue with a maruelouse
haughty style. But to our matter, ye shall understand that the Romans kept a
certain Law in the 12. tables, the words whereof were these. We ordeyne and
command, that all the Romans shall for ever have special privilege in every
such place, where their auncestoures have done to the Romayne people any
notable service. For it is reason, that where the citizen aduentureth his life,
there the city should do him some honor after his death. By virtue of this
law, all the family of Camilli ever enjoyed the keeping of the high Capitol,
for that by his force and pollicye he chased the french men from the siege.
Truly it is not unknown that this noble knight and valyant captain Camille
did other things as great, and greater than this: but because it was done
within the circuit of Rome, it was esteemed above all his other acts and
prowes. And herein the Romans swarued not far from reason, for that
amongst all princelye virtues is esteemed to be the chiefest and worthyest,
which is employed to the profyt of the common wealth. The Romayne Croniclers
with tears cease not to lament the ruin of their country, seeing that
variety of time, the multitude of tyrauntes, the crueltye of cyuill wars
were occasion that the aunciente state of the Romayn government came to utter
destruction, and in steed thereof a new and evil trade of life to be placed.
And hereof no man ought to marvel, for it chaunseth throughout al realms and
nations, by often changing governors that among the people daily spryngeth
sundry new vices. Pulio says, that for no alteracion which befell to the
common weal, for no calamitye that ever Rome suffered, that privilege was
taken away from the Image of Camilli (I mean the government of the high
Capitol) except it were in the time of Silla the consul, when this familye was
soore persecuted, for none other cause but for that they favored the consul
Marius. This cruel Silla being dead, and the piteful Julius Caesar
preuailinge, all the banyshed men from Rome returned home again to the
commonne wealth. As touching the ancestors of the Emperor Marcus
Aurelius, what has been their trade of life, estate, pouertye, or riches,
standinge infauour or displeasoure, what prosperity or adversity they have
had or suffered, we find not in wrytinges, though with great dilygence they
have been serched for. And the cause hereof was, for that the ancient writers
of ye Roman histories, touched the lives of the emperors fathers (specially,
when they were made princes) more for the good merits that were in the
children, then for ye great estimacio^ that came from the fathers. Julius
Capitolinus says that Annius Verus (father of Marcus Aurelius) was Praetor of
the Rhodian armies, and also wardein in other frontiers, in the time of Traian
the good, Adrian the wise, and Antonye the merciful. Which Emperors trusted
none with their armies but discrete and valiant men. For good princes chose
always such captains as can with wisdom guide the army, and with
valiauntnes give the battle. Though the Romans had sondrye wars in
diverse places, yet chefelye they kept great garrisons always in four parts
of the world. That is to say, in Bizance (which now is Constantinople) to
resist the Parthiens, in Gades (which now is called Galiz) to withstand the
Portugales: in the river of Rein, to defend them selves from the Germans: and
at Colosses (which now is called the I Will of Rhodes) for to subdue the
Barbariens. In the month of January when the Senate distributed their offices,
the dictatoure being appointed for 6. months: and the. 2. Consulles chosen
for one year: incontinently in the.3. place they chose 4. of the most renowned
persons to defend the said 4, dangerous fro^tiers. For the Romans neither
feared the pains of hell, nor trusted for reward in heaven: but sought by all
occasions possible in their life to leave some notable memory of them after
their death. And that Roman was counted most valiante and of the Senate best
favored, to whom they committed the charge of the most cruel and dangerous
wars. For their strife was not to bear rule and to be in office to get money:
but to be in the frontiers to overcome their enemies. In what estimacion these
4. frontiers were we may easily perceive, by that we see the most noble Romans
have passed some part of their youth in those places as captains, until such
time that for more weyghtie affairs they were appointed from thense to some
other places. For at that time there was no word so greauous and injurious to
a citezin, as to say go, thou have never ben brought up in the wars: and to
prove the same by examples, the great Pompey passed the winter season in
Constantinople, the aduenturous Scipio in Colonges, the courageous Caesar in
Gades, and the renowned Marius in Rhodes. And these. 4. were not only in the
frontiers before said in their youth, but there they did such valiant acts,
that the memory of them remained evermore after their death. These things I
have spoken to prove, sithe we find that Marcus Aurelius father was captain
of one of those.4. frontiers: it follows that he was a man of singular
wisdom and prowess. For as Scipio said to his friend Masinissa. in affrike
it is not possible for a Roman captain to want either wisdom or courage,
for thereunto they were predestined at their birthe. We have no autentike
authorities that shows us from whence, when, or how, in what countries and
with what persons this captain passed his youth. And the cause is, for that
ye Romain Croniclers were not accustomed to write the things done by their
prince before they were created: but only the acts of young men, which from
their youth had their hearts stoutlye bent to great aduenturs. And in my
opinion it is well done. For it is greater honor to obtain, an empire by
policy and wisdom then to have it by descent, so yt there be no tirannie.
Suetonius Tranquillus in his first book of Emperors counts at large the
aduenturous enterprises taken in hand by Julius Caesar in his young age, and how
far unlikely they were from thought that he should ever obtain the Roman
Empiree writing this to show unto princes, how earnestlye Julius Cesars heart
was bent to win the Romayne Monarchy, and likewise how wisdom failed him in
behauing him self therein. A philosopher of Rome wrote to Phalaris the
tiraunt, which was in Cicilia, asking him why he possessed the Realm so long
by tirannye? Phalaris answered him again in another Epistle in these few
words Thou call me tyrant because I have taken this realm and kept it
this.32. years I grant the (quod he) that I was a tiraunte in vsurpyng it: For
no man occupyeth another man's right but by reason he is a tyraunte. But yet
I will not agree to be called a tyraunte, sith it is now.xxxii. years sins I
have possessed it. And though I have atcheued it by tyranny, yet I have
governed it by wisdom. And I let thee to understand, that to take an other
man's goods, it is an easy thing to conquer, but a hard thing to keep an easy
thing: but to keep them, I ensure the it is very hard. The Emperor Marcus
Aurelius married the daughter of Antonius Pius, the 16. Emperor of Rome, and
she was named Faustina, who as sole heir had the Empire: and so through
marriage Marcus Aurelius came to be Emperor: this Faustine was not so honest
and chaste: as she was fair and beautiful. She had by him two sons,
Commodus, and Verissimus, Marcus Aurelius triumphed twice, once when he
overcame the Perthians, and an other time when he conquered the Argonantes He
was a man very well learned and of a deep understanding, He was as excellent
both in the Greek and latin, as he was in his mother tongue. He was very
temperate in eating and drinking, he wrote many things full of good learning
and sweet sentences: He dyed in conquering the realm of Pannonia, which is
now called Hongarie. His death was as much bewailed, as his life was desired.
And he was loved so intierlye in the city of Rome, yt every Roman had a
statue of him in his house, to the end the memory of him (among them) should
never decay. The which was never red that they ever did for any other king or
Emperor of Rome, no not for Augustus Caesar who was best beloved of all other
Emperors of Rome. He governed the empire for the space of 18. years with
vprighte justice: and dyed at the age of 63 years with much honor, in the year
clymatericke, which is in the 60. and 3. years wherein the life of man ronneth
in great peril. For then are accomplyshed the nine seuens, or the seven nynes.
Aulus Gelius writes a chapter of this matter in ye book De noctibus Atticis.
Marcus Aurelius was a prince of life most pure, of doctrine most profound, and
of fortune most happy of all other princes in the world, save only for
Faustine his wife and Commodus his son And to the end we may see what
Marcus Aurelius was from his infancy, I have put here an epistle of his which
is this.

Of a letter which Marcus Aurelius sent to his friend Pulio, wherein he
declares the order of his whole life: and amongst other things he makes
mention of a thing that happened to a Roman Censor with his host of Campagna.
Cap. ii.
MArcus Aurelius only Emperor of Rome greteth the his old friend Pulio wishes
health to thy parson, and peace to the commen wealth. As I was in the temple of
the vestall virgens, a letter of thine was presented unto me, which was written
long before, and greatly desired of me: but the best thereof is, that thou
writing unto me briefly, desire that I should writ unto the at large. Which
is indecent for the authority of him that is chief of the empire, in especial
if such one be covetous: for to a prince there is no greater infamy, then to be
lauishe of words, and scant of rewards. Thou wrytest to me of thy grief in thy
leg, and that thy wound is great: and truly the pain thereof troubles me
at my heart, and I am right sorry that thou want that which is necessary for
thy health, and that good that I do wish the. For in the end all the
travails of the life may be endured, so that the body with diseases be not
troubled. Thou let me understand by thy letters that thou art arrived at
Rhodes, and requireste me to write unto the how I lived in that place when I
was young, what time I gave my mind to study, and likewise what the
discourse of my life was until the time of my being Emperor of Rome. In this
case truly I meruell at the not a little that thou should ask me such a
question, and so much the more that thou did not consider, yt I cannot
without great trouble and pain answer thy demand. For the doings of youth
in a young man were never so upright and honest, but it were more honesty to
amend them, then to declare them. Annius Verus my father showing unto me his
fatherly love (not accomplishing yet fully 13 years) drew me from the vices of
Rome, and sent me to Rhodes to learn science, howbeit better acccompanyed with
books, then laden with money, where I used such dilygence, and fortune so
favored me, that at the age of 26. years I red openly natutall and moral
philosophy, and also Rethoricke: and there was nothing gave me such occasion to
study, and read books, as the want of money, for poverty causes good men's
children to be virtuous, so that they attain to that by virtue, which others
come unto by riches. Truly friend Pulio I found great want of the pleasures of
Rome, specially at my first coming into the I Will, but after I had read
philosophy 10 years at Rhodes, I took my self as one borne in the country,
And I think my couersacion among them caused it to seem no less. For it is a
rule that never fails, that virtue makes a stranger grow natural in a
strange country: and vice makes the natural a stranger in his own country.
Thou know well how my father Annius Verus was 15. years a captain in the
frontiers against the Barbarous, by the commandment of Adrian my lord and
master, and Antonius Pius my father in law, both of them princes of famous
memory: which reco^mended me there to his old friends, who with fatherly
counsel exhorted me to forget the vices of Rome, and to accustom me to the
virtues of Rhodes. And truly it was but nedeful for me, for the natural love
of the country often times brings damage to him that is borne therein leadinge
his desire still to return home. Thou shall understand that the Rhodians are
men of much curtesy, and requyting benevolence, which chaunseth in few Isles:
because that naturally they are persons deceitful, subtle, unthankful, and
full of suspicio^. I speak this because my fathers friends always succored me
with counsel and money: which two things were so necessary, that I could
not tell which of them I had most need of. For the stranger makes his profit
with money to withstand disdainful poverty, and profitteth him self with
counsel to forget the sweet love of his country. I desired then to read
philosophy in Rhodes so long as my father continued there captain, But that
could not be, for Adrian my lord sent for me to return to Rome, which pleased
me not a little, albeit (as I have said) they used me as if I had been borne in
that Island, for in theend although the eyes be fed with delyght to see
strange things, yet therefore the heart is not satisfied. And this is all that
touches the Rhodians. I will now tell the also how before my going thither I
was borne and brought up in mount Celio (in Rome) with my father from mine
infancy. In the common wealth of Rome there was a law used, and by custom well
observed, that no citize^ which enjoyed any liberty of Rome (after their
sons had accomplyshed.10. years) should be so bold or hardy to suffer them
to walk the streates like vacabondes. For it was a custom in Rome, that the
children of the senators should suck til two years of age, til 4. they should
live at their own wylles, till 6. they should reed, till 8 they should write,
till 10. they should study gramer, and 10. years accomplished they should then
take some craft or occupacion, or give them selves to study, or go to the
wars, so yt throughout Rome no man was idell. In one of the laws of the 12
tables wear written these words. We ordeine and command that every cytizen
that dwells within the circuit of Rome or lybertyes of the same, from 10
years vpwardes to keep his son well ordered. And if perchance the child
being ydel, or that no man teaches him any craft or science, should thereby
peradventure fall to vice, or commyt some wicked offense, that then the father
no less then the son should be punyshed. For there is nothing so much
breadeth vice amongst the people, as when the fathers are to neclygent, and
the children to bold. And furthermore another law said. We ordeine and
command that after 10. years be past, for the first offense that the child
shall commyt in Rome, that the father shall be bound to send him forth some where
else, or to be bound suertye for the good demeanor of his son. For it is not
reason that the fond love of the father to the son should be an occasion why
the multitude should be sclaundered: because all the wealth of the Empire
consists in keeping and mayntaynyng quiet men, and in banishyng and expellyng
sedycious persons. I will tell the one thing my Pulyo, and I am sure thou
wylt meruell at it, and it is this. When Rome tryumphed and by good wysedom
governed all the world, the inhabitants in the same surmounted the number of
two hundredth thousand parsonnes, which was a maruelouse matter. Amongeste whom
(as a man may judge) there was above a hundredth thousand children. But they
which had the charge of them kept them in such awe and doctrine, that they
banyshed from Rome one of the sons of Cato vticensis for breakyng an erthen
pot in a maidens hands which went to fetch water. In like manner they
banyshed the son of good Cinna, only for entering into a garden to gather
fruit, And none of these two were as yet fyftyne years old. For at that time
they chastised them more for the offenses done in gest, then they do now for
those which are don in good earnest. Our Cicero says in his book De legibus,
that the Romans never took in any thing more pains, then to restreine the
children as well old as young from ydlenes. And so long endured the fear of
their law, and honor of their common wealth, as they suffered not their
children like vacabondes idelly to wander the streates. For that country may
above all other be counted happy, where each one enjoys his own labor,
and no man lives by the swette of another. I let the know my Pulio, that when
I was a child (although I am not yet very old) none durst be so hardy to go
commonly through Rome, without a token about him of the craft and occupacion
he exercysed, and whereby he lived. And if any man had been taken contrary,
the children did not only cry out of him in the streates as of a fool: but
also the Censour afterward condemned him to travail with the captynes in
common works. For in Rome they esteemed it no less shame to the child which
was idle, then they did in Greece to the philosopher which was ignorant. And to
the end thou may se this I write unto the to be no new thing, thou ought
to know, that the Emperor caused to be borne before him a brenning brand, and
the counsel an axe of arms, the priests a hat in manner of a coyfe, The
Senators a crusible on their arms, the Judges a little balance, the Tribunes
Maces, the governors a scepter, the Bishops hattes of flowers, The Orators
a book, the cutlers a swerd, the goldsmithes a pot to melt gold: and so forth
of al other offices, strangers excepted, which went al marked after one sort in
Rome: For they would not agree that a stranger should be apparailed and
marked according to the children of Rome. O my friend Pulio, it was such a joy
then to behold the discipline and prosperity of Rome, and it is now at this
present such a grefe to see the calamity thereof, that by the immortal gods
I swear to the, and so the god Mars guide my hand in wars, that the man
which now is best ordered, is not worth so much as the most dissolute person
was then. For then amongst a thousand they could not find one man vicious in
Rome, and now among twenty thousand they cannot find one virtuous in all
