Finally he that haunteth them, is by them sclaundered: and he that does not
frequent them, is esteamed less then a man. These things so seen, so hard,
and so known, what shall the poor and miserable man do, inespecially if he
be a man of understanding? For though he would absent him self from women, the
flesh does not give him license: and though he would follow women, wisdom will
not condiscende. Some men think in all their thoughts, that by services and
pleasures they may content women. But I let them know, if they know it not,
that the woman is never contented though man does what he can as maid, and
that he do all that he ought to do as a husband: though he takes pains for her
sake above his force, and though with the swet of his brows he releaueth her
neade: though every hour he puts him self in danger, ye in the end she
will give him no thanks: but will say that he loves an other, and that he does
but that to please and satisfy her. It is a long time since I desired to tell
thee this Faustine, but I have deferred it until this present hour, hoping
thou would not give occasion to tell it thee. For among wise men those words
ought chiefly to be esteamed, which fittely to the purpose are declared. I
remember that it is six years since Anthonius Pius (thy father) chose me to be
his son in law, and that thou chosest me for thy husband, and I thee for my
wife: all the which things were done, my woeful adventures permitting it, and
Adrian my lord commanding it. The good Anthonius Pius gave his only daughter
in marriage unto me, and gave me likewise his noble Empire with great treasures:
he gave me also the garde^s of Vulcanali to pass the time therein. But I think
that on both sides we were deceived. He in chosing me for his son in law,
and I in taking thee for my wife. O Faustine, thy father and my father in law
was called Anthonius Pius, because to al he was merciful, save only to me to
whom he was most cruel: for with a little flesh he gave me many bones. And I
confess the truth unto thee, that now I have no more teethe to byte, nor
heat in my stomach to digeaste: and the worste of all is, that many times I
have thought to rage on my self. I will tell thee one word, though it does
displease thee, which is, that for thy beauty thou art desired of many: and
for thy evil conditions thou art despised of all. For the fair women are like
unto the golden pylles: the which in sight are very pleasant, and in
eatinge very noisome. Thou know well Faustine and I also, that we saw on a
day Drusio, and Braxille his wife, which were our neighbors, and as they were
brauling togethers, I spoke unto Drusio such words: what means this lord
Drusio? that being now the feast of Berecinthia, and being as we are
adioyninge to her house, and present before so honorable assembly, and
furthermore thy wife being so fair as she is, how is it possible there
should be any strife between you? Men which are married to deformed
persons, to the end that they might kill them quicly, should always fall out
with their wives: but those that are married to fayer women, they ought always
to live togethers in joy and pleasure, to the end they may live long. For when
a fair woman dies, though she have lived a hundredth years, yer she dies to
sone: and though a deformed woman lives a small time, yet not withstandyng she
dies to late Drusio as a man being vexed, lifting up his eyes into the
heavens, fetchinge a grievous sighe from the bottom of his heart said these
words. The mother Berecinthia pardon me, and her holy house also, and all the
company besides forgive me, for by the immortal Gods I swear unto the, that I
had rather have been married with a Moore of Calde that is so foul, then being
married as I am, with a Roman being very faier: for she is not so fair and
white as my life is woeful and black. Thou know well Faustine that when
Drusio spoke these words, I did wype the tears from his eyes, and I gave him
a word in his ear that he should proceed no further in this matter: for such
women ought to be chastened in secret, and afterward to be honored openly O
thou art unfortunate Faustine: and the Gods have evil divided with the giving
the bewtye and riches to undo thy self: and denayeng thee the best, which is
wisdom and good conditions to keep thy honor, Oh what evil luck comes
unto a man, when God sends him a fayer daughter, unless furthermore the gods
do permyt that she be sage, and honest: for the woman which is young, folyshe,
and faier, distroyeth the common wealth, and defameth al her parentage. I say
unto the again Faustine, that the Gods were very cruel against thee, since
they swallowe the up by the goulfes, where all the evil perishes: and took from
the all the sails and owers, whereby the good do escape. I remained xxxviii.
years unmarried, and these vi. years only which I have been married, me thinks
I have passed vi. hundredth years of my life: for nothing can be called a
tormente, but the evil that man does suffer that is evil married. I will ensuer
the of one thing Faustine, that if I had known before, which now I know, and
that I had felt that which now I feel, though the gods had commanded me and
the emperor Adrian my Lord desired me, I had not changed my poverty for thy
riches, neither my rest for thy Empire: but since it is fallen to thine and
mine evil fortune, I am contented to speak little, and to suffer much. I have
so much dissembled with the Faustine, that I can no more: but I confess unto
the, that no husband does suffer his wife so much, but that he is bound to
suffer her more, considering that he is a man and that she is a woman. For the
man which willingly goes into ye briers, must think before to endure ye
pricks. The woman is to bold that does contend with her husband: but the
husband is more fool which openly quarrelleth with his wife. For if she be good,
he ought to favor her to the end she may be better: if she be unhappy, he
ought to suffer her to thend she be not worse. Truly when the woman thinks
that her husband takes her for evil, it is a great occasion to make her to be
worse: for women are so ambitious, that those which commonly are evil, will make
us believe yt they are better then others. Believe me Faustine, that if the fear
of the gods, the infamy of the person, and the speech of men do not refrain ye
woman, all the chastisements of ye world will not make her refrain from vice:
for all things suffers chastisemente and correction, the woman only except,
the which must be won by entreaty. The heart of the man is very noble, and
that of the woman very delycate: because for a little good he will give a great
reward, and for a great offense he will give no punishment. Before the wise man
marieth, let him beware what he does: and when he shall determine to take the
company of a woman, he ought to be like unto him that enters into the war,
that determines with himself to suffer all that may happen, be it good or
evil. I do not call that life a war without a cause, which the evil married
man leads in his house: for women do more hurt with their tongues, then the
enemies do with their swords. It is a great simplycitie for a wise man to make
account, or esteem the simplycitie of his wife at every time: for if they would
mark, and take heed to that which their wife does, or says, I let them know
that they shall never come to an end. O Faustine, if the Roman woman would
always one thing, that they would procure one thing, that they would be
resolved in one thing, though it were to our great charges we would have
pleasure to condescend unto their desires: but what shall we do, sinse yt which
now pleases you, a while after dipleaseth you, yt which you ask for in the
morning, ye will not have at none, that which you enjoy at none days, do
trouble you in the night, that which in the night you love, ye care not for in
the morninge, that which yesterday ye greatly esteemed, to day ye as much
despise. If ye desired to see a thing the last year, this year ye will not
hear talk of it, that which before made you to rejoice, does now make you to
be sad, that which ye were wont and ought to lament, at the self same thing a
man sees you laughe. Finally ye women are as children, which are appeased with
an aple, and casts the gold to the earth not wayeng it. I have diverse times
thought with my self, if I could say or write any good rule, in keeping the
which, I might teach men to be quiet in their house. And by my count I find
(having experimented it also with the Faustine) that it is impossible to give a
rule to married men: and if a man could give them, they should scarcely profit
therewith, sinse their wives live without rule. But notwithstanding that, I will
declare some rules how the married folks should keep themselves in their houses:
and how they shall (if they list) avoid strifes and debates between them. For
the husbands and the wives having wars together, it is impossible there
should be peace in the common wealth. And though this present writynge has
not profited me, vnluckey and unfortunate man: yet it may profit others which
have good wives. For often times the medycen which profits not for the tender
eyes, suffiseth to heal the hard heales. I know well Faustine, that for that I
have said, and for that I will say unto the, thou and others such like shall
greatly envy me. Ye will mark the words that I speak, more then the
intencion that I mean: but I protest before the Gods, that in this case my end
is for none other intent, but to advertise the good, whereof there are a great
many: and to punyshe the evil, which are many more. And though perchance
neither the one nor the other will believe, that my intencion in speaking these
things was good: yet therefore I will not cease to know the good from the evil,
and to choose the evil from the good. For in my fantasy the good wife is as the
feasaunt, whose feathers we little esteame, and regard much the body: but the
evil woman is as the Marterne, whose skin we greatly esteem, and utterly
despise the flesh. I will therefore declare the rules whereby the husbands may
live in peace with their own proper wives.

The Rules are these.
THe first, the husband must neades have patience and suffer his wife when she
is displeased: for in Libia there is no serpent so spiteful as an evil woman
when she is vexed.

The second, the husband ought to provide for his wife (according to his
abylitie) all that is necessary for her, as well for her person, as for her
house: for often times it chances, that women seking things necessary, find
things superfluous, and not very honest.

The third, the husband ought to provide that his wife do keep good company:
for women often times are more troubled, with the words that their evil
neighbors speak against them, then for any occasion that their husbands give
them.

The fourth, that the husband ought to use a mean, that his wife be not to
much a subject, nor that she stray to much abrod: for the woman that gaddeth
much in the streates, both loaseth her good name, and spends his goods.

The fifth, the husband ought to take heed that he strives not so with his
wife, that she be brought past shame: for the woman that toward her husband
is shameless, has no respect what dishonestye she commits.

The sixth, the husband ought to let his wife understand that he does trust her:
for the woman is of such condition, that that which a wise man would not she
should do: she will do sonest, and that wherein she should take pains, she will
do nothing.

The seventh, the husband ought to be circumspect that he do not holy trust his
wife with the goods and treasours of the house, nor yet utterly distrust her:
for if the wife have the charge of the goods of the house, truly she will
augment little, and if the husband do suspect her, she will steal much.

The.8. the husband ought to look upon his wife merrily, and at other times
again sadly: for women are of such condition, that when their husbands
shows them a merye countenance they love them, and when they show them
selves demure, the fear them.

The 9. the husband ought (if he be wise) in this to take good aduysement, that
his wife quarrel not with his neighbors, for we have often times seen in Rome,
that for the quarrel of his wife against his neighbor, the husband has lost
his life, she has lost her goods, and a slander has risen throughout the
common wealth.

The 10. the husband ought to be so pacient, yt if he saw his wife commit any
fault, in no wise he should correct her openly, but in secret: for the husband
that corrects his wife before witness, does as he which spitteth into the
element, and the spittel falls again into his eyes.

The 11. the husband ought to have much temperaunce, lest he lay hands on his
wife to punish her: for truly the wife that with sharp words does not amend,
with all the chastysementes of the world will never be good.

The 12. if the husband will be in quiet with his wife, he ought to praise her
before his neighbors and strangers: for amongst all other things women have
this propertye, that of all they would be praised, and of none corrected.

The.13. the husband ought to beware to praise any other then his own wife,
she being present: for women are of this condition, that the same day the
husband commends any other woman, the same day his wife will cast him out of
her heart, thinkinge that he loves another and dyspyseth her.

The.14. the husband ought to make his wife believe that she is faier, though
in deed she be foul: for there is between them no greater strife, then to
think that her husband forsakes her for being foul.

The 15. the husband ought to put his wife in remembrance of the infamye, that
they speak of them that be evil in the city: for women are glorious, and
because they would be loath that men should talk such thing by them, as they
talk of others, peradventure they will refrain from those vices that others
commit.

The 16. the husband ought to take heed that his wife accept no new friends:
for through acceptyng of new friends, there grow commenly between them great
discention.

The 17. the husband ought to take head that his wife believe, that he loves
not them whom she hates: for women are of such a condition, that if the
husbands loves al them that they hate, immediatlye they will hate all those
which they love.

The 18. the husband ought sometime in matters, which are not prejudicial unto
him, confess him self to be overcome: for women desire rather to be counted
the best in reasoning (though it be of no value) then to have otherwise a
greater jewel given them.

In this sort Faustine I will say no more to the, but wish that thou should
se what I se, and feel what I feel: and above al, that my dissimulacion should
suffice to amend thy life.

The Emperor answers more particularlye concerning the Key of his study.
Cap. xvii.
NOw Faustine, since I have the old venym from my heart expelled, I will answer
to thy present demand: for unto demaundes and aunswers that passes between
the sages, ye tongue ought never to speak word, but that first he ask the
heart license. And it is a general rule amongst the phisicians, that the
medicens do not profit the sick, unless they first take away the opilacions
of the stomach. I mean by this, that no man can speak to his friend (as he
ought) unless before he shows what thing greueth him: for it is better to
repaier the roufes of the houses that be old, then to go about to build them
new.

Thou requirest me Faustine that I give thee the Keye of my study, and thou
do threaten me that if I give it not unto the, that thou shall forthwith be
delivered. I marvel not at that thou say, neither I am abashed of that
thou demaundest, nor yet of that that thou would do: for you women are very
extreme in your desires, very suspicious in your demaundes, very obstinate in
your wills, and as impatient in your sufferinges. I say not without a cause
that women are extreme in their desires: for the^e are things whereof women
are so desirous, that it is wonder though never living creature saw them, nor
hard speak of them. I have not said without a cause that women are suspicious
in their demands: for the Roman women are of such a condition, that as soon
as a woman desires any thing, she forthwith commands the tongue to ask it,
the feet to seek it, the eyes to se it, the hands to feel it, and likewise the
heart to love it. I say not without a cause that women are obstinate in their
wills: for if a Roman woman bears any malice to any man, she will not
forbear to accuse him for any slander, nor fail to pursue him for any
poverty, nor fear to kill him for any Justice. I say not without a cause that
women are impatient to suffer: for many are of such condition (I say not al)
that if a man give not spedely that which they desire, they change their
coullour, their eyes look read, their tongues run quycke, their voices are
sharp, they frete with them selves, they trouble their neighbors abroad, and
are so out of order that no man dare speak unto them within. You have this
good trade among ye women that under coullour of being with child, you will that
we husbands grant ye al your desires. When the sacred senate, in the time of
the valiant Camillus, made a law in the favor of the Roman Matrones with
child, the women at that time longed not so much as they do at this present:
but I can not tell what this presently means, that al ye are anointed with
that that is good, and that ye are all desirous of that that is evil. I will tell
the (Faustine) the occasion why this law was made in Rome, and thereby thou
shall se if thou deseruest to enjoy the priuyledge thereof or no: For the laws
are but as yokes under the which the evil does labor, and they are wings
wherewith the good does fly. The case thereof was such, that Camillus the
valiant captain went forth to the wars, he made a solemn vow to the
mother Berecinthia, that if the gods gave him the vyctorie, he would offer unto
her an Image of silver: and after Camillus wanne the victory, and that he would
have accomplished his vow to ye mother Berecinthia: another he had any riches,
nor Rome had any silver. For at that time, Rome was rich of virtues, and poor
of money. And know thou Faustine, that our ancient fathers were devout toward
the gods, and curious in repairing the temples, the which they esteemed to be
great deuocions: and they were in such sort observed of their vows, that
neither for sloth, nor poverty, they would obmitte their promises toward
their gods. And in these things they were so precise, that they granted to no
man any triumph, unless he did swear that he had unto the gods made a vow,
and afterward also proved how he performed it.

At that time flourished in Rome many virtuous Romans, and many greek
philosophers, many hardye Captains, and many sumptuous buildinges: and above
all things, Rome was vnpeopeled of malyces, and adorned with virtuous Ladies.
The Historiographers made (and not without a cause) great account of these
virtuous matrones: For the commonne wealth has as much neade of virtuous
women, as the wars have of valyaunte Captains. They being therefore (as
they wear) so virtuous and noble Matrones (without the motion of any woman)
determined all to go into the high Capitol, and there to offer al their
Ieuelles and treasours that they had, their cheynes, their ringes, their
garments, their bracelettes, their girdels, their buttons, and hangers of
gold, of silver, and precious stones of all sorts with all their tablettes.
The Annals of this time say, that after the Roman women had laid so great
a multitude of riches, at the feet of the sacret senate, in the name of them
all one of them spoke, whose name was called Lucina, and said in this sort.
Fathers co^script, esteem not much these our Iewelles, which we give you to
make ye image of the mother Berecinthia: but esteem much this, that we
willynglye put in ieopardye our husbands, and children, to win you the
vyctory. And if in this case you accept our poor service, have no respect to
the little which we do offer: but to the great which (if we were able) we would
give. Truly ye Romans, though the treasure which their wives offered was
great: Yet notwithstanding they did more esteem the good will wherewith they gave
it, then they did the gifts them selves. For there was so much in deed, that
sufficed both to make the image of the goddess Berecinthia, and also for a
long time to maintain the wars. Therefore from that day that those matrones
presented their Iewelles in the high Capitol, the senate forthwith in
remembrance of the gentleness, granted them these five things as a
priuyledge: For at that time Rome never received service, or benefyt of any
person, but she rewarded it with double payment.

The first thing that the senate granted the Roman women was, that in the
day of their burial, the Orators might openly make oracions in the praise of
their lives: For in old time men used neither to exalt them when they were
dead, nor yet to accompany them to their graves.

The second thing that was granted them was, that they might sit in the
temples: for in the old time when the Romans did offer sacrifices to their
gods, the aged did always sit, the priests kneel, the married men did lean,
but the women, though they were of noble and high lineage, could neither be
suffered to talk, sit nor to lean.

The third thing that the senate granted the women of Rome was, that every one
of them might have.ii. rich gowns, and that they should not ask the Senate
leave to wear them: for in the old time if any women were apparelled, or did
bye any new gown without askinge license of the Senate, she should
immedyatlye loose her Gown, and because her husband did condiscende unto the
same, he was bannyshed the common wealth.

The fourth thing which they granted them was, that they should drink wine
when they were sick: for there was in Rome a custom inuyolable, that though
their life was in hazard, they durst not drink wine but water. For when Rome
was well corrected, a woman that druncke wine was as much slaundered among the
people: as if she had committed adulterye toward her husband.

The fifth thing granted by the senate unto the women was, that a man might not
denay a Roman being with child, any honest and lawful thing that she
demanded. I cannot tell why the auncientes of Rome esteamed more women with
child, then others that had no children.

Al these five things were justly granted to the Matrones, and noble Roman
Ladies. And I can tell the Faustine, that they were of the Senate most willingly
granted. For it is reason that women which in virtues do excel, should with
all means be honored. I will tell the Faustine the especial cause that moved
the Romans to grant unto you Matrones this last pryuyledge: that is to
wete, that a man cannot denay them any thing being with child. Thou ought
to know, that the others (as well Greeks as Latynes) did never give laws, nor
institutions unto their people, without great occasions: For the great
multitude of laws are commonly evil kept, and on the other part are cause of
sondrye troubles. We cannot denaye but that the auncientes did well avoid the
great number of institucions: For it is better for a man to live as reason
commands him, then as the law constrayneth him. The case therefore was, that
in the year of the foundation of Rome.364. Fuluius Torquatus then being Consul,
in the war against the Volces, the knights of Mauritania brought to Rome
an huge monster with one eye, called Monoculus: which he had found in the
deserts of Egypt. At that time the wife of Torquatus called Macrina, should
have been delivered of child: for the Consul did leave her great. This Macrina
amongst al was so honest, yt they spent as much time in Rome to praise her for
her virtues: as they did set forth her husband for his victories. They read in
the Annalles of that time that the first time that this Consul Torquatus went
into Asia, he was eleven years out of his country, and it is found for a
truth, that in all the time that Torquatus was absente, his wife was never seen
look out at the window, which was not a thing smally esteemed: for though it
was a custom in Rome to keep the door shut, it was lawful notwithstanding to
speak to women at the windows. Though men at that time were not so bold, and
the women were so honest: yet Macrina, wife to Torquatus, lived so close and
solitary to her self, that in all these 11. years there was never man that saw
her go through Rome, nor that ever saw her door open, neither that she
consented at any time (from the time that she was viii. years of age) that any
man should enter into her house: and more over, there was never man saw her face
wholly uncovered. This Roman Lady did this, to leave of her a memory: and to
give example of her virtue. She had also iii. children, whereof the eldest was
but v. years old: and so when they were viii. years of age, immediatlye she
sent them out of her house toward their parents, lest under the coullour to
vysite the children, others should come to visit her. O Faustine, how many
have I hard that have lamented this excellent Roman: and what will they think
that shall follow her life, Who could presently restraigne a Roman woman from
going to the window.11. years, since things now a days are so dissolute,
that they do not only desire to se them, but also run in the streates to
babble of them? Who should cause now a days a Roman woman, that in the 11.
years she should not open her doors, since it is so, that when the husband
commanded her to shut one door, she will make the hole house to ringe of her
voice? He that now would command his wife to tarry at home, and let her of her
vagaries into the town, shall perceive that there is no Basilie nor Viper that
carries such poison in her tail, as she will spitt with her tongue. Who could
make a Roman women to be 11. years continually without showing her face to
any man: since it is so that they spend the most part of their time in loking
in a glass, setting their ruffes, brushing their clothes, and painting their
faces? who would cause a Roman woman to keep her self, xi years from being
vysited of her neighbors, and friends, since it is true that now women think
them greatest enemies, which vysite them most seldom? Retournyng therefore to
the monstre, as they led this monstre before the door of Torquatus house, she
being great with child, and her husband in the war: by chance a maid of
his told her how that this monstre passed by, wherefore so great a desire took
her to see the monstre that for to keep that she had begone, sodeinly for this
desire she dyed. Truly I tell the Faustine, that this monstre had passed many
times by the streat where she dwelt, and she would never notwithstanding go to
the window: and much less go out of her door to see it. The death of this
Roman of many was lamented: for it was a long time that Rome had never heard
of so honest and virtuous a Roman wherefore at the peticion of all the Romayne
people, and by the commandment of all the sacred senate, they set on he^ tomb
these verses.

The worthy Macrine, rests here in grave
Whom wise Torquatus, lodged in Iunos bed
Who reked not, a happy life to have
So that for aye, her honest fame was spredde.
BEhold therefore Faustine, in my opinyon, the law was not made to remedy the
death of this noble Romayne, since she was already dead: but to the end that you
Princesses should take example of her life, and that through al Rome there
should be a memory of her death. It is reason, since the law was ordained for
those women which are honest, that it should be observed in none, but upon
those that are virtuous: let the women with child mark the words of the law,
which command them to ask things honest. Wherefore I let the know Faustine,
that in the seventh table of our laws are written these words. We will that
where there is corruption of manners, the man shall not be bound to observe their
liberties.

That princesses and noble women ought not to be ashamed to give their children
suck with their own breasts. Cap. xviii.
AL noble men, that are of hault courages, watch continually to bring that to
effect which they covet, and to keep that which they have: For by strength one
comes to honor, and by wisdom, honor, and life, are both preserved. By
these words I mean, that she that has borne.9. months (through travail)
the creature in her womb with so much pain and that afterward is delivered
with so great peril, and by the grace of god from so many dangers escaped,
me think it is not well that in this point (which for the norishment of the
babe is most expedient) the mothers should show them so negligent. For that
wants no folly, that by extreme labor is procured, and with much lightness
afterward despised. The things that women naturaly desire are infinite, among
the which, these are four cheafely.

The first thing that women desire, is to be very fair: For they had rather be
poor and fair, then to be rich and foul.

The second thing which they desire, is to se them selves married: for until
such time as the woman does see her self married, from the bottom of the heart
she always sigheth.

The third thing that women desire, is to se them selves great with child, and
herein they have reason. For until such time as the woman has had a child, it
seems that she takes him more for a lover then for a husband.

The fourth thing that they desire, is to se them selves delivered, and in this
case more then all the rest they have reason: For it is great pity to see in
the pryme time a young tree laden with blosomes: and afterward the fruit to be
destroyed through the abondaunce of caterpillars. Then since god suffers
that they are borne fair, that they se them selves married, that they be with
child, and that they are delivered: why be they so unkind, as to send them out
of their houses, to be nourished in other rude cotages? In my opinion the woman
that is virtuous, ought as soon as she is delivered, to lift up her eyes, and
with her heart to give god thanks for her fruit: For the woman that from her
delivery is escaped, ought to account her self as one newly borne. The woman
likewise seeing her self delivered of her creature, ought to give it suck with
her own breasts, for it is a monsterous thing, that she that has brought
forth the creature out of her own proper womb, should give it to be
nourished, of a strange dugge, In speaking more plainly (it is al one to me
whether she be a noble woman, or a woman of mean condition) I say and affirm,
that god has delivered her of al her travail, she her self ought with her
own pappes to nourish and give suck to their babes: for nature did not only
make women able to bear men, but also besides that provided milk in their
breasts, to nourishe their children. We have neither read until this present,
nor seen, that any beasts (wild or tame) after they had young, would commit
them to any other to be nourished. This which I have spoken is not so worthy of
noting, as that which I will speak. And it is, that many beasts newborn,
before they open their eyes to know their fathers, have now all ready taken
nourishment in the teates of their mothers: and more then that, to se some of
those little beasts have.x. little whealpes, the which without ye aid of any
others nourished them al with the substance of their own tears, and the
woman that has but one child disdaineth to give it suck. All that shall read
this writing shall find it true, and if they will, they may se as I have seen it
by experience: yt after the she Ape has had her yonglings, she always has
them in her arms so long as they suck, so yt oftentimes there is such strife
between the male, and the female, which of them shall have the yonglings in
their arms, that the beholders are enforced to part them with battes. Let us
leave the beasts that are in the fields, and talk of the birds that are in ye
neasts: the which do lay eggs to have young, yet have they no milk to bring
them up. What thing is so straung to se, as a small bird that has under her
wings v. or vi. little naked byrds, the which when she has hached, she has
neither milk to nourish them, nor corn to give them, they have neither wings
to fly, feathers to cover them, nor any other thing to defend them: yet in all
this weakness and poverty their mother forsakes them not, nor commits them
to any other but brings them up al her self. That which nature provided for
the swannes is no less marvelous, in especially when they nourishe their
young signettes in the water: Forasmuch as duringe the time that they can not
swim, the mothers always in the day are with their young signetts in their
neastes, and in the night the fathers carry them under their proper wings (to
refresh them) unto the water: It is therefore to be thought, since these
swannes so louyngly bear their yonglings under their wings, that they would
carry them in their arms if they were men, and also give them suck with their
own breasts if they were women Aristotle says in his fifth book De
animalibus, that the lions, the bears, the wolves, the Eagles, ye griffins,
and generally al beasts, never are, were, nor shall be seen so fierce nor so
cruel, as when they have yonglings, and this thing seems to be true: for at
that time, we se that many beasts might escape the hunters, yet to save their
yonglings they turn back and put their proper lives in danger. Plato says
in his book of laws, that the children are never so well-beloved of their
mothers, as when they are nourished with their proper breasts, and that their
fathers daunceth them of their knees. The which thing is true: for the first
love, in all things is the truest love. I was willing to show the bringing up of
brute beasts, to show the women with child, how pitiful parents they are in
nourishing their yonglings with their own breasts: and how cruel mothers women
are, in committing their children to strangers. It is a marvelous thing to
here the mothers say that they love their children, and on the contrary side to
se how they hate them. In this case, I cannot tell whether they love more,
either the child, or the money: for I se that they covet greatly to hourd up
riches into their cheastes, and likewise they desire as much to cast out their
children out of their houses. There are diverse reasons whereby the mothers
ought to be moved to norishe their children (which they bare in their wombes)
with their own propre breasts.

The first reason is, that the mother ought to have respect how ye young babe
was borne alone, how little he was, how poor, dilicate, naked, tender, and
without understanding: and since that the mother brought it forth so weak, and
feable, it is neither mete nor convenient that in time of such necessity she
should forsake it, and commit it into the hands of a straung nourse. Let women
pardon me, whether they be ladies, brought up in pleasures, or other of meaner
estate, accustomed with trauelles, I force not: but I say, that those which
forsake their children in such extremeties, are not pitiful mothers but cruel
enemies. If it be cruelty not to cloth him that is naked, who is more naked
then the child newborn? if it be cruelty not to comfort the sad, who is more
sad, desolate, and sorrowful, then the child which is borne weping? if it be
ungentleness not to succoure the poor nedy, who is more neady, or more poor
then the innocent child newly borne, that knows not as yet neither to go, nor
to speak? If it be cruelty to do evil to the innocent that cannot speak,
who is more innocent then the infant, that can not complain of that which is
done unto him? The mother that casts out of her house the children borne of
her own body, how can we believe that she will receive in any other of
strangers? when the infant is now great, when he is strong, when he can
speak, when he can goo, when he can profitte him self, and get his meat,
the mother makes much of him, and leads him about with her, but is little
thank unto her: For then the mother has more neade of the child to be served,
then the child has of the mother to be cherished: If the children were borne
of the nails, of the fingers, of the fete, or of the hands, it were a small
matter though their mothers sent them forth to noryshe: but I cannot tell what
heart can endure to suffer this, since the child is borne of their propre
intrayles, that they do commit it (to be brought up) into the hands of a
stranger. Is there paraduenture at this day in the world any Lady, that has
so great confidence in any of her friends, parents, or neighbors, that she
durst trust any of them with the key of her cofer, wherein her Iewelles, money,
and riches lies? truly I think none. O unkind mothers, my pen had almost
called you cruel stepmothers, since you lay up in your heart the cursed mou^ke
of the ground, and send out of your houses that which sprang of your blood.
And if women should say unto me yt they are weak, feable, and tender, and that
now they have found a good nourse, to this I answer: that ye nourse has small
love to ye child which she nourishes, when she sees the ungentleness of the
mother yt bare it. For truly she alone does norishe ye child with love, that
heretofore has borne it with pain.

The second reason is, that it is a thing very just that women should nourishe
their children, to the end they may be like unto their conditions: For
otherwise they are no children, but are enemies: for the child that does not
reverence his mother that bare him, can not enjoy a prosperous life, Since the
intention of the parents in bringing up their children is for none other
purpose, but to be served of them when they are old: they shall understand,
that for this purpose there is nothing more necessary, then the milk of the
proper mother: for where the child sucketh the milk of a stranger, it is
unlikely that it should have the conditions of the mother. If a kidde suck a
sheep, they shall perceive it shall have the wolle more fair, and the nature
more gentle, then if he had sucked a Goat, which has ye wolle more hard, and
of nature is more wild: wherein ye proverb is verefied, not from whence thou
come, but whereof thou feedest. It avails a man much to have a good
inclinacion: but it helps him much more from his infancye to be well taught.
For in the end we profit more, with the customs wherewith we live, then we do
by nature from whence we came.

The third reason is, that women ought to nourish their own children, because
they should be hole mothers, and not imperfect: for the woman is counted but
half a mother that bears it, and likewise half a mother that nourishes it:
but she is the hole mother, that both bears it, and nourishes it. After the
duty considered unto the father that has created us, and unto the son that
has redeamed us, me thinks next we owe ye greatest duty unto ye mother, that
has borne us in her body: and much more it is that we should bear unto her,
if she had nourished us with her own breasts. For when the good child shall
behold his mother, he ought more to love her because she nourished him with her
milk: then because she has borne him in her body.

The Aucthour still persuades women to give their own children suck. Cap. xix.
IN the year of the foundation of Rome five hundred and two, After the
obstinate and cruel war between Rome and Carthage, where the renowned
captains were Hannibal for the Carthagians and Scipio for the Romans: sone
after that war followed the war of Macedonie against king Philip, The
which when it was ended, that of Siria began against Antiochus king of Siria.
For in.630 years the Romans had always continual wars in Asia, in
Affricke, or in Europe. The noble Romans sent the consul Cornelius Scipio
(brother to the great Scipio ye Affrican) for captain of that war. And after
many battayles, fortune showed her force in a City called Sepila, the which is
in Asia the great, where king Antiochus was overcome, and all his realm
discomfited: for trees that have their roots plucked up, must needs within
short time lose their fruits. After that king Antiochus was overcome and his
land spoiled, Cornelius Scipio came unto Rome triumphinge, for the victory yt
he had of Asia: so that as his brother (for the victory that he had of
Africa) was called Affricane, so he was called Scipio the Asian, because he
vanquished Asia. The captains of Rome loved honor so much, that they would no
other reward, nor recompense of their travail, but yt they should give them
the renown of the realm which they had overcome. Truly they had reason, for
the noble hearts ought little to esteem the increase of their riches, and ought
greatly to esteem the perpetuite of their good name. As Sextus Cheronensis
says in his third book De ambigua iusticia, that Cornelius Scipio had a long
time the government of the people, forasmuch as he was consul, censour, and
Dictatour of Rome: for he was not only hardy and courageous, but also he was
sage and wise, which thing ought greatly to be esteamed in a man. For
Aristotle does not determine it, which of these two is most excellent: either
stoutnes to fight in ye wars, or policye to rule in peace. Scipio therefore
being Dictatour (which was an office then as the Emperor is now) it chanced
that the x. captains which had been with him in the wars, violently fought
to have entered into the Monastery of the virgins vestalles: wherefore the
Dictatour commanded their heads to be cut of. For the Romans punished more
cruelly those, that only required the virgins vestalls: then those that forced
the married matrones. Cornelius Scipio was besought of many in Rome, yt he would
moderate and change his so cruel sentence. And he which most in this case did
importune him, was his brother Scipio the Affrican whose prayer was not
accepted: how be it in the end they said the captains, were pardoned, by the
request of a sister of the said Dictatour Scipio ye Affrican. And because he
blamed his brother Scipio, that he had done more for the daughter of his
nourse: then for the son of his proper mother, he answered. I let the wete
brother, that I take her more for my mother that brought me up, and did not
bear me: then she which has borne me, and in my infancye has forsaken me.
And since I have had her for my true mother, it is but reasonne that I have
this for my dear and well-beloved sister. These were the words which passed
between these two brethren. I have diligently red in holy, and profane
wrytinges, that many tirauntes have caused their own mothers to be killed
which bare them: but I could never find that they have done any discurtesye or
disobedience, to the nourses which gave them milk. For the cruel tirauntes
do thirste after the blood of others: but they fear them whose milk they
suck,

The fourth reasonne that byndethe womenne to nourishe their children is, to
keep them in more obedience: for if the fathers live long time, they must of
force come into the hands of their children. And let not old fathers make
their accounts, saying that during the time that they shall have the
government of the house, their children shall be kept in obedience: for in so
doing they might abuse them selves. For young men in their youth, feel not the
trauayles of this life: nor know not as yet, what it means to make provision
for householde. For to the stomach that is full, and cloyed with eating, al
meats seameth both unsavory and noisome. It may well be, that since the
children are not nourished in the house, that they know not their servants,
that they love not their parents, that they come not nere their brethren, nor
talk with their sisters, that they are ignorant of their fathers, and do
disobey their mothers: wherefore since little fear does abound, and good will
fail, one day they commit some mischeauous offense, whereby they do loose
their life worthily, and the fathers loose the riches, and likewise their
honor deservedly, to the intent that the fathers always keape their proper
children under obedience, there is no better mean then to bring them up in
their own houses, the mother to give them suck, and the father to teach
them: for when the mother desires any thing of her child, she should not
show him the belly from whence he came, but the dugges which he did suck. For
all that which is asked us by the milk that we did suck, truly there is no
heart so hard that can denay her. The historiographers say that Antipater among
all the Gretians, was the most renowned tyrant: and among the Romans Nero.
And these two wicked princes were not great tyrauntes because they had committed
many tyrannies: but because they did commit one, which was most grievous of
all others. For they do not call a man a glutton, or cormoraunt, because he
eats every hour, but because he deuoureth more at one paste, then others do
in one day. The case was, that Antipater in Greece, and Nero in Rome,
determined to kill their own mothers. And the historiographers say, that when
Nero commanded his mother to be killed, she sent to ask of him why he would
put her to death: where unto he answered, that he was cloyed to behold the
arms wherein he was nourished, and therefore he caused her to be killed, to see
the intrailes out of the which he came. This case was so horrible, that it
seemed to many not to speak it: but concluding I say, as unjustly as the
mothers lost the mortal life: so justly did the children get for them
immortal imfamy. Nothing can be more wicked and detestable to the children,
then to kill their mothers which did bear them with pain, and did nourish them
with love: but notwithstanding all this, we do not read that ever they did kill,
dishonor, nor yet disobey their nourses, which gave them milk. Iunius
Rusticus, in the fifte book of the brynging up of children says, that ye two
Gracchi (renowned and famous Romans) had a third brother being a bastard, who
showed him self as valiant and hardy in the wars of Asia: as the other two
did in the wars of Africa. The which as he came one day to rome to visit his
house, he found therein his mother which bare him, and the nourse which gave him
suck. To yt which nourse he gave a girdle of gold, and to his own mother he
gave a jewel of silver. Of ye which things ye mother being ashamed, co^sidring
what her son had done, she asked him why he had given ye norse ye gold, which
did but only give him suck and that he had not given the gyrdle of gold to
her, as well as the Jewel of silver, since she had borne him, and brought him
into the world. Whereunto he answered in this manner, marvel not thereat mother
why I do this thing, for thou did bear me but nine months in thy womb,
and she has given me suck and nourished me these three years with her own
propre pappes: and when thou did cast me from thee out of thy sight, she
received me and nourished me in her propre arms.

Fifthly, women ought to enforce them selves to nourishe their children, to the
end they may keep them the better, and that in their cradels they be not
changed for others. Aristotle says, that the Cocowe comes to the neaste of
another bird when she has laid her eggs, and sucketh them, and lays in
the same place her own eggs: so that the other bird thinking that they are
her own, hatchieth and nourishes them up as her own, until such time as
they are able to fly. Then the Cocow kills, and eats the sily bird that
has nourished her, through the which occasion the males of those birds, are
at so great contention (that they have been so deceived) that the one of them
kills the other the which they might let, if every bird did nourishe her
own. In the same time that Philip reigned in Macedonia, (which was the father
of the great Alexander) Arthebanus was king of the Epirotes, who in his age
had a child borne, the which was stolen out of the cradell, and an other put
in his stead. The nourse which did nourishe it, through covetousness of money
consented to that treason: for the heart that is with covetousness overcome,
will not fear to commit any treason. It chanced not long after that king
Arthebanus died, and left (as he thought) his own son for his heir: but
within few days after the nourse her self, which had consented unto the
robbery, discovered the theft, and said that she could tell where the lawful
child of the good king Arthebanus was, and that that child which now was
heir, was but the son of a mean knight: but in deed it had been better for
those of the miserable realm, that the woman had never discovered the secret.
For it chances oftetimes that a man makes such haste of his horse, that he
hurts his leg, and through that occasion afterward falls and breaks
his neck. But what shall we say to the Plebeical women, of base and mean
estate (I do not mean the noble, gentle, and virtuous ladies) whereof they
are many, that though in great secret their chiefest friend tells them any
thing, yet before they drink they will utter it to another. Thus when the
treason was discovered, cruel wars between these two princes began: so that
in the end, in a great battle they were both slain, the one in defending,
and the other in assaulting. At that time Olimpias reigned, who was the fair
and worthy wife of Philip, and mother of Alexander. She had a brother named
Alexander, who was both politic, and hardy, and hearing the Epirotes were in
controversy, and that two kings were slain in the field, he placed him
self in the Realm, more of will, then of right. And let no man marvel, that
this king occupied the Realm: for in the old time, all the tyrannous princes
thought that all that which they could obtain without resistaunce: did unto
them belong by justice. This king Alexander was he, which came into Italy in
the favor of the Tarentines, when they rebelled against the Romans: who
afterward was slain in battle at Capua, where his body was unburied. And
truly it was a just sentence, that the tyrant which bereueth many of their
lives, should him self taste some shameful death. I have declared this
history to this end, that princesses and great ladies should see, that if the
wife of king Arthebanus had nourished his son, they could not have robbed it
in the cradell, nor these two princes had not been slain in battle, nor the
common wealth had not been destroyed, nor Alexander had not entered into the
land of another, nor had not come to conquer the country of Italy, nor the
dead corpse had not wanted his grave: for oftetimes it chances, for not
quenching a little coal of fire, a whole forest and house is burned. The divine
Plato among the Greeks, and Licurgus among the Lacedaemonians, commanded and
ordained in all their laws, that all the Plebeical women, and those of mean
estate, should nourishe al their children, and that those which were princesses
and great ladies, should at the least nourishe their eldest and first begotten.
Plutarche in the book of the reign of princes says, that the sixth king of
the Lacedaemonians was Thomistes, the which when he died left two children, of
which the second inherited the realm, because the Queen her self had brought
it up: and the first did not inherit, because a strange nource had given it
suck, and brought it up. And hereof remained a custom in the most part of
the realms of Asia, that the child which was not nourysshed with the pappes
of his mother, should inherit none of his mothers goods. There was never,
nor never shall be a mother that had such a son as the mother of God, which
had Jesus Christ: nor there was never, nor never shall be a son, which had
such a mother in the world. But the infant would never suck other milk,
because he would not be bound to call any other mother, nor the mother did
give him to nourish to any other mother, because that no other woman should
call him son. I do not marvel at al, that princesses and great ladies do
give their children forth to nourishe: but that which most I marvel at is,
that she which has conceived and brought forth a child, is a shamed to give
it suck and to nourishe it. I suppose that the ladies do think, that they
deserve to conceive them in their wombes, and that they sin in nourishing
them in their arms. I can not tell how to write, and much less how to utter
that which I would say: which is, that women are now a days come into such
folly: that they think and esteem it a state, to have in their arms some
little dogs: and they are ashamed to nourish and give the children suck with
their own breasts. O cruel mothers, I cannot think that your hearts can be so
stony, to endure to see and keape fantastical birds in the cages, unhappy
Monkeis in the wyndowes, fisting spaniels between your arms, and so neglect
and despise the sweet babes, casting them out of your houses where they were
borne, and to put them into a strange place where they are unknown? It is a
thing which cannot be in nature, neither that honesty can endure, conscience
permit, nor yet consonant either to divine or human laws, that those which
God has made mothers of children, should make them selves nourses of dogs.
Iunius Rusticus in the third book of the sayings of the auncientes says, that
Marcus Porcio whose life and doctrine, was a lantern and example to all the
Romain people, as a man much offended, said on a day to the senate. O fathers
conscripte, O cursed Rome, I can not tell what now I should say, sith I
have seen in Rome such monsterous things (that is to wete) to see women carry
Parrottes on their fistes, and to see women to nourishe dogs, giving them
milk from their own breasts. They replied in the senate and said. Tell us
Marcus Porcio what would thou we should do which live now, to resemble
our fathers which are dead? Marcus Portio answered them. The woman that
presumes to be a Roman Matrone, ought to be found weauing in her house, and
out of that to be found in the temple praying to God: and the noble and stout
Roman, ought to be found in his house reding books, and out of his house,
fighting in the plain field for the honor of his country. And suer these
were words worthy of such a man: Annius Minutius was a noble Roman, and
captain of great Pompeius, who was a great friend to Julius Caesar after the
battle of Farsaliae: for he was an ancient, and on that could give good
council, wherefore he never escaped, but that he was chosen in Rome for
Senator, Consul, or Censor every year, for Julius Caesar was so merciful to
them that he pardoned, that those which had been his most enemies in the
wars, were of him in peace best beloved. This Annius Minutius then being
chosen Censor within Rome (which was an office having charge of justice) by
chance as he went to visit the wife of an other friend of his, the which
lay in child bed, (because she had great abundance of milk) he found
that a little pretty bitche did suck her, upon the which occasion they say he
said these words to the Senate: fathers conscripte, a present mischief is
now at hand according to the token I have seen this day (that is to wete) I
have seen a Roman woman deny her own children her milk, and gave to suck
to a filthy bitche. And truly Annius had reason to esteem this case as a
wonder: for the true and sweet loves are not but between the fathers and
children, and where the mother embraces the brute beast, and forsakes her
natural child which she has brought forth, it cannot be otherwise, but
there either wisdom wants, or folly abounds: for the fool loves that he
ought to despise, and despises that which he ought to love. Yet though the
mothers will not give their children suck, they ought to do it for the
danger which may come to the health of their persons: for as the women
which bring forth children, do live more healthful then those which bear none:
so these which do nourish them, have more health, then those which do not
nourishe them. For although the brynging up of children be troublesome to
women, it is profitable for their health. I am ashamed to tell it, but it is
more shame for ladies to do it, to see what plasters they put to their breasts
to dry up their milk: and hereof comes the just judgment of God, that in
that place often times where they seek to stop their milk, in the self same
place, they them selves procure their sudden death. I ask now, if women do
not enjoy their children being young, what pleasure hope they to have of them
when they are old. What a great comfort is it for the parents to see the
young babe, when he will laughe, how he twincleth his little eyes: when he
will weape, how he will hang the pretty lip: when he would speak, how he
will make signs with his little fyngers: when he will go, how he casts
forward his feet: and above all, when he begins to babble, how he doubled
in his words. What thing is more pleasant to the father then to see them,
and to the mother to agree to it, when the children do suck, they pluck
forth the breasts with the one hand, and with the other they pluck their
here, and further they beat their feet together, and with their wanton eyes,
they cast on their parents a thousand loving looks? what is it to see them
when they are vexed and angry, how they will not be taken of the fathers, how
they stryke their mother: they cast away things of gold, and immediately they
are appeased with a little apple or russhe? what a thing is it to see the
innocents how they answer when a man asks them, what follies they speak,
when they speak to them, how they play with the dogs and run after the
cattes, how they dress them in wallowing in the dust, how they make houses of
earth in the streates, how they weape after the birds when they see them fly
away? All the which things are not to the eyes of the fathers and mothers, but
as Nitingales to sing, and as bread and meat to eat. The mothers peradventure
will say that they will not bring up their children, because when they are
young they are troublesome, but that after they should be nourished and
brought up, they would be glad. To this I answer them, that the mothers shall
not denay me, but that some of these things must neades meat in their
children: that when they be old, they shall be either proud, envious, covetous,
or negligent: that they shall be lecherous, or else thieves, that they shall be
blasphemours, or else glottons, that they shall be rebels, or fools, and
disobedient unto their fathers. I believe that at this day there are many
mothers in the world, which did hope to be honored, and served with the
children which they had brought up: and afterward perceiving their manners,
would willinglye forgo the pleasures which they hoped for, so that they might
also be delivered from the troubles, which through their evil demeanours are
like to ensue. For that time which the parents hoped to pass with their
children in pleasures, they consume (seeing their unthrifty life) in sorrowful
sighs. I council, admonish, and humbly require princesses, and great ladies,
to nourishe and enjoy their children when they are young and tender: for after
that they are great, a man shall bring them news every day of diverse sorts,
and manners they use, for as much as the one shall say that her son is in
prison, and another shall say that he is sore wounded, another that he is hid,
others that he has played his cloak, others that he is sclaundered with a
common harlot, another that he steals his goods from him, another that his
enemies do seek him, another that he accompanies with unthrifts, and finally
they are so sturdy, unhappy, and so far from that which is good: that
oftentimes the fathers would rejoice to see them die, rather then to see the^
live so evil a life. Me thinks that the knot of love between the mother and
the child is so great, that not only she ought not to suffer them to be
nourished out of the house one whole year: but also she ought not to suffer
the^ to be out of her presence one only day. For in seeing him, she sees yt
which is borne of her intrails she sees that which she has with so great
pains delivered, she sees him who ought to inherit all her goods, she sees
him in who the memory of their ancestors remains: and she sees him, who
after her death ought to have the charge of her affairs and business.
Concludynge therefore that which above is spoken, I say that which the
great Plutarche said, from whom I have drawn the most part of this
chapter: that the mother (to be a good mother) ought to have and keep her
child in her arms to nourishe him, and afterward when he shall be great, she
ought to have him in her heart to help him. For we see oftentimes great evils
ensewe, to the mother, and to the child, because she did not bring him up her
self: and to put him to nouryshe to a strange breaste, there comes neither
honor, nor profit.

That princesses and great Ladies ought to be very circumspecte in chosinge
their nources. Of seven properties which a good nource should have. Chap. xx.
THose which ordained laws for the people to live were these. Promotheus
which gave laws to the Egiptians, Solon Solmon to the Greeks, Moses to the
Jews, Licurgus to the Lacedaemonians, and Numa Pompilius to the Romans: for
before these princes came, their people were not governed by written laws, but
by good ancient customs. The intention of those excellent princes was, not to
give laws to their predecessors, for they were now dead: neither they gave
them only for those which lived in their time being wicked, but also for those
which were to come, whom they did presuppose would not be good. For the more
the world increases in years, so much the more it is laden with vices. By
this that I have spoken I mean, that if the princesses and great ladies, every
one of them would nourishe their own child, I neade not to give them
counsel. But since I suppose that the women which shall be delivered hereafter,
will be as proud, and vain glorious, as those which were in times past: we
will not let to declare here some laws and aduises how the lady ought to
behave her self with her nource, and how the nource ought to content her
self with the creature. For it is but just, that if the mother be cruel, and
hardy to forsake the creature: that she be sage, pitiefull, and advised, to
choose her nource. If a man find great treasoure, and afterward care not how
to keep it, but does commit it into the hands of suspected persons: truly we
would call him a fool. For that which naturally is beloved, is always of al
best kept. The woman ought more wisely keep the treasure of her own body,
then the treasure of all the earth if she had it. And the mother which does the
contrary, and that commits her child to the custody of a strange nource,
not to her whom she thinks best, but whom she finds best cheap: we will
not call her a foolish beast, (for the name is to vnseamely) but we will call
her a sotte, which is somewhat more honester. One of the things that does make
us most believe that the end of the world is at hand: is to see the little
love which the mother does bear to the child being young, and to see the want
of love which the child has to his mother being aged. That which the child
does to the father and the mother, is the just judgment of God, that even as
the father would not nourishe the child in his house, being young: so
likewise that the son should not suffer the father in his house, he being
old. Retourning therefore to the matter, that since the woman does determine
to dry and shut up the fountains of milk, which nature has given her, she
ought to be very diligent to search out a good nource: the which ought not only
to content her self to have her milk whole, but also that she be good of life.
For otherwise, the child shall not have so much profit by the milk which he
sucketh: as the nource shall do it harm, if she be a woman of an evil life. I
do advise princesses and great dames, that they watch diligently to know what
their nources are, before they commytte their children to them: for if such
nources be evil, and slaundered, they are as serpents which do byte the mother
with their mouth, and do stinge the child with her tail. In my opinion it were
less evil, the mother should suffer that her child should perish in
delivering it: then for to keep in her house an evil woman. For the sorrow of
the death of the child, is forgotten and brought to naught in time: but the
slander of her house, shall endure as long as she lives. Sextus Cheronensis
says, that the Emperor Marcus Aurelius commanded his son to be brought
up of a woman, the which was more fair then virtuous. And when the good
Emperor was advertised thereof, he did not only send her from his palace, but
also he banished and exyled her from Rome: swering that if she had not
nouryshed his sone with her pappes, he would have commanded her to have been
torn in pieces with beasts. For the woman of an evil renown, may justly be
condemned and put to death. Princesses and great ladies ought not greatly to
pass, whether the nources be fair or foul: for if the milk be sweet, whyt,
and tender, it littel skilleth though the face of ye nource be whit, or black.
Sextus Cheronensis says, in the book of the nourture of children, that even
as the black earth is more fertile then is the white earth: so likewise yt
woman which is brown in countenance, has always the most substaunciall
milk. Paulus Diaconus in his greatest history says, that the Emperor
Adocerus did mary him self with the daughter of an other emperor his
predecessor called Zeno, and the Empress was called Arielna. The which in
bringing forth a Son, had a woman of Hungarye marvelous fair to nourishe
it, and the case succeeded in such sort that the nource for being fair, had by
yt emperor.iii. children the one after the other: and his woeful wife never
had any but the first alone. A man ought to believe yt the empress Arielna did
not only repent her self, for taking into her house so fair a nource: but
also was sorry that ever she had any at all, sith the rybald thereby was
mystresse in the house, and she remained without husband all her life. I do not
say it, for that there are not many foul women vicious, nor yet because there
are not many fair women virtuous: but that princesses and great ladies
(according to the qualities of their husbands) ought to be profitable and
tender nources, to bring up their children. For in this case there are some men
of so weak co^plection, that in seeing a litell clean water, immediately they
dye to drink thereof. Let therefore this be the first counsel in chousing
nources, that the nource before she enter into ye house be examined, if she be
honest, and virtuous. For it is a tryfell whether ye nource be fair or foul:
but that she be of a good life, and of an honest behavior.

Secondarily, it is necessary that the nource which nourishes ye child, be not
only good in ye behavior of her life: but also it is necessary yt she be hole,
as touching ye bodily health. For it is a rule infallible, that of ye milk
which we do suck in our infancy, depends all ye corporal health of our life
A child given to the nource to nourish* is as a tree removed from one place to
an other. And if it be so (as in dead it is) it behooves in all points, that if
ye earth where in it shall be new put were no better, that at the lest it be not
worse: for this should be a great cruelty, that the mother being hole, strong,
and well disposed, should give her child to a lean woman to nource, which is
feable, sore, and diseased. Princesses and great la^es do chose lean wom^n,
weak, and sick, for to nourishe their infantes. And in that they do fail, it
is not for that they would err: but it is because that such feable and weak
nources (by a vain desire they have to be nources in a gentilma^s house) on
the one part they say they will litel money, and on the other part they do
make great suits. What a thing is it when a princess or a noble woman is
delivered of a child, to se the deuyses of other women among them selves, who
shall be the nource, and how those the which never nourished their own
children, do preserve ye milk to nouryshe the children of others. To procure
this thing for women* me thinks it proceadeth of abundance of folly: and to
condescend to their requests, me thinks it is for want of wisdom. They
look not always to the manners and ability of the nource, how apt she is
to nource their child, but how diligent she is in procuring to have it to
nourishe. They care not greatly whether they be good or no: for if the first
be not good, they will take the second, and if the second pleases them not,
they will have the third, and so vpwardes until they have found a good
nource. But I let you to wete (you princesses and great ladies) that it is more
danger for the children to change diverse mylkes: then unto the old men, to
eat diverse meats. We see daily by experience, that without comparison there
dies more children of noble women, then children of women of the meaner
estate. And we will not say, that it is for that they do flatter their children
more, nor for that the wives of laborers do eat fine meats: but that it
chau^ceth often times, that the children of a poor woman: does neither eat, nor
drink: but of one kind of meat, or milk in.ii. years, and the child of a
Lady shall chaung and alter.iii. nources in.ii. months. If princesses and
great ladies were circumspect in chousing their nources, and that they did look
whether they were hole without diseases, and honest in their manners, and would
not regard so much the importunity of their suits: the mothers should excuse
them selves from many sorrows, and the children likewise should be delivered
from many diseases. One of the most renowned princes in times past, was Titus
the son of Vaspasyan, and brother of Domitian. Lampridius says, that this
good Emperor Titus (the most part of his life) was subject to grievous
diseases and infirmities of his perso^ne, and the cause was, for that when he
was young he was given to a syck nourse to be nourished, so that this good
Emperor sucking her dugge but a while, was constrained to pass all his life
in pain.

Thirdely, Princesses and great Ladies ought to know, and understand the
complexion of their children, to the end yt according to the same they might
seek pitiful nources, that is to wete, if ye child were cholorycke,
flegmaticke, sanguine, or melancolye: For look what humor the child is of, of
the same quality the milk of the nource should be. If unto an old corrupted
man they ministre medecines, conformable to his diseases for to cure him: why
then should not the mother seek a wholesome nource to the tender babe, agreeable
to his complexion, to nourish him: And if thou say it is just, that the
flesh old and corrupted be sustained: I tell the likewise that it is much more
necessary, that the children should be curiously and well nourished, to
multiplye the world. For in the end we do not say, it is time that the young
leave the bread for the aged: but contrary it is time that ye old leave the
bread for the young. Aristotle in the book De secretis secretorum, and Iunius
Rusticus, in ye.x. book de gestis Persarum say, that the unfortunate king Darius
(who was overcome by Alexander the great) had a daughter of a merueilous
beauty. And they say that the nource which gave suck to this daughter all
the time that she did nourishe it, did neither eat nor drink any thing but
poison: and at the end of.iii, years, when the child was weyned, and plucked
from the dugge, she did eat nothing but Colubers, and other venomous worms. I
have heard say many times that the Emperors had a custom, to nourish their
heirs, and children with poisons when they were young: to the intent yt they
should not be hurt by poison, afterward when they were old. And this error
comes of those which presume much, and know litel. And therefore I say, that I
have heard say, without saying I have read it. For some declare histories, more
for that they have heard say of others: then for that they have read them
selves. The truth in this case is, that as we use at this present, to were
Cheynes of gold about our necks, or Jewels on our fingers, so did ye Gentiles in
times past a ring on their fingers, or some Jewel in their bosom replenished
with poison. And because ye Panims did neither fear hell, nor hope for heaven,
they had that custom, for if at any times in battle they should find them
selves in distress, they had rather end their lives with poison, then to
receive any injury of their enemies. Then if it were true that those Princes
had been nourished with ye poison, they would not have carried it about the^ to
have ended their lives. Further I say, that the princes of Persia did use when
they had any child borne, to give him milk to suck agreeable to ye complectio^
he had. Since this daughter of Darius was of melancholye humor, they
determined to bring her up with venim and poison, because all those which are
pure malancolye, do live with sorrow, and dye with pleasure. Ingnacius the
Venetian in the life of ye.v. emperors Palleolus (which were valiant emperors
in Constantinople) says, that the second of ye name called Palleolles ye
hardy, was after the.xl. years of his age so troubled with infirmities and
diseases, that always of the.xii. months of the year he was in his bed
sick ix. months: and being so sick as he was, the affairs and business of
the empire were but slenderly done and looked unto. For the prince can not have
so small a fever, but the people in the commen wealth must have it double. This
Emperor Palleolus had a wife, whose name was Huldouina, the which after she
had brought all the Physicians of Asia unto her husband, and that she had
ministered unto him all the medecins she could learn to healpe him, and in the
end seeing nothing avail: there came by chance an old woman, a Gretian borne,
who presumed to have great knowledge in herbs, and said unto the empress noble
Empress Huldouina, If thou will that the Emperor thy husband do live long,
see that thou chafe, anger, and vex him every week at the least twyse: for
he is of a pure malancoly humor, and therefore he that does him pleasure,
augmenteth his disease: and he that vexes him shall prolong his life. The
empress Huldouina followed the counsel of this Greek woman, which was occasion
that the emperor lived afterward sound and hole many years: so that of
the.ix. months which he was accustomed to be sick every year: in.xx. years
afterward he was not sick.iii. months. For where as this Greek woman
commanded the empress to anger her husband but twice in the week, she
accustomeablye angered him.iiii. times in the day.

Fourthly, the good mother ought to take heed, that the nource be very
temperate in eating, so that she should eat litell of diverse meats, and of
those few dishes she should not eat to much. To understand that thing ye must
know, that the white milk is no other then blod, which is soden, and that
which causes the good or evil blood, comes often times of no other thing,
but that either the person is temperate, or else a glutton in eating: and
therefore it is a thing both healthful and necessary, that the nource that
nourishes the child do eat good meats: for among men and women it is a
general rule, that in little eating, there is no danger: and of to much eating,
there is no profit. As all the Philosophers say, the wolf is one of the
beasts that deuoureth most, and is most gredyest, and therefore he is most
feared of all the sheppardes. But Aristotle in his third book de Animalibus
says, that when the wolf does once feel her self great with young, in all
her life after she never suffers her self to be couppled with the wolf
again: For otherwise, if the wolf should yearly bring forth.vii. or.viii.
whealpes (as commonly she does) and the sheep but one lamb, there would be in
short space more wolves then sheep. Besides all this the wolf has an other
property, which is, that though she be a beast most deuouryng and gredy: yet
when she has whealped, she eats very temperately, and it is to the end to
nouryshe here whealpes, and to have good milk. And besides that she does eat
but once in the day, the which the dog wolf does provide, both for the
byche, and her whealpes. Truly it is a monsterous thing to see, and noisome to
hear, and no less sclaunderous to speak, that a wolf which gives suck
to.viii. whealpes, eats but one only kind of meat: and a woman which
gives suck but to one child alone, will eat of eight sorts of meats. And
the cause hereof is, that the beast does not eat, but to sustain nature: and
the woman does not eat, but to satisfy her pleasure.

Princesses and great Ladies ought to watch narrowly, to know when, and how
much the nources do eat, which do nourish their children: For the child is
so tender, and the milk so delicate, that with eating of sondrye meats they
become corrupt, and with eating much they wax fat. If the children suck
those which are fat and gross, they are commonly sick: and if they suck
milk corrupted, they often times go to bed hole, and in the morning be found
dead. Isodore in his etimologies says, that men of the province of Thrace
were so cruel, that the one did eat the other, and they did not only this,
but also further to show more their immanitie, in the sculles of those that were
dead, they drank the blood of him that was lately alive. Though men were so
cruel to eat men's flesh, and to drynk the blood of the veins: yet the
women which nourished their children were so temperat, and moderat in eating,
tha^ ^hey did eat nothing but nettelles sodden and boiled in goats milk. And
^^ause the women of Thrace were so moderate in eatinge, the philosopher Solon
Solynon brought some to Athens: for the auncientes sought no less to have good
women in the commen wealth, then to have hardy and valiant captains in the
war.

The auctoure adds.iii. other conditions to a good nourse that gives suck:
that they drink no wine, that she be honest, and chiefly that she be well
conditioned. Chap. xxi.
THe Princesses and great ladies may know by this example, what difference
there is between the women of Thrace, which are fed with nettelles only, and
have brought forth such fierce men: and the women of our time, which through
their delicate and excessive eating, bring forth such weak and feable
children.

Fifthly, the Ladies ought to be very circumspecte, not only that nources eat
not much, and that they be not gready: but also that they be in drinking wine
temperat, the which in old time was not called wine, but ^enym. The reason
hereof is apparent and manifest enough, for if we do forbid the fat meats
which lies in the stomach: we should then much more forbid the moist wine,
which washes all the veins of the body. And further I say, that as the child
has no other nourishement but the milk only, and that the milk proceadeth of
blood, and that blood is nourished of the wine, and that wine is naturally
whot: from the first to the last. I say, the woman which drinks wine, and
gives the child suck, does as she that makes a great fire under the pan,
where there is but a little milk: so that ye pan burns, and the milk runs
over. I will not denaye, but that some times it may chance, that the child
shall be of a strong complexio^, and the nource of a feable and weak nature: and
the^ the child would more substanciall milk, when the women is not able to
give it him. In such a case (though with other things milk may be conferred)
I allow that the nource drink a litel wine: but it ought to be so litel, and so
well watered, that it should rather be to take away the vnsauorines of the
water, then for to taste of any savor of ye wine. I do not speak this without
a cause, for the nource being sick, and feable of her self, and her milk not
substancial, it often times moves her to eat more then necessity requires,
and to drink wine which is somewhat nutritive: so that they supposyng to give
the nource triacle, do give her poison to destroy her child. Those excellent
and ancient Romans, if they had been in our time, and that we had deserved
