to recyte them to the Senate always for his purpose.

And let no man marvel hereat, for there are some of so gross understanding
that that which they write and study, they can scarsely utter: and others
again are of such lively wits, that of that only which they have heard, it
seameth marvelous to hear with what eloquence they will talk. Because Sylla
had such and so excellent a daughter in his house, he was esteamed for a sage
and wise Counselor throughout all the common wealth.

He was counted very absolute in executing, strong in mayntaynynge, and for
right eloquent in speakinge. Finally, of this came this auncyente, proverb
which says. Lucius Sylla governs his own countreye with the eloquence of
his Tongue: and is Lord of strange nations by the force of his sword.

What the great Plato has been, and what great authority he has had
amongst his country men and amongst the strangers it is apparent: for so
much as the Greeks do acknowledge him of al other Philosophers to be the
Prince: and likewise the Latynes by one consent call him divine.

And me thinks that in doing this, they do no philosopher injury: for as
Plato in his life time had great modesty, so truly in his writing he exceaded
man's capacity. And Historian called Hyzearchus, declares that Lasterna and
Ax^othea were two Greeks very well learned, and amongst the scollers of Plato
chiefly renowned. The one was of so parfect a memory, and the other of so
high an understanding, that Plato often times being in the chair (and these two
not ready) he would not begin to read. And being asked wherefore he read not
his lecture, he answered? I will not read, for that there wants here
understanding to conceive, and also memory to retain. Meaning that Lasterna
was absent, that Axiothe was not yet come. The wisdom of those two women
ought to be much, since Plato without them would not utter one word, unless
they were present in his schole. For Plato esteamed more the understanding and
memory of those two women alone: then he did the Philosophy of his other
Scollers together. Aristippus the philosopher was Scholar to Socrates, and of
the most renowned of Athens. He had a daughter called Aretha, the which was so
well learned in Greek and Latin letters, that the common renown said, the soul
of Socrates was entered into Aretha: and the cause that moved them to say this
was, because she read and declared the doctrine of Socrates in such wise, that
it seamed to most men she had rather write by hand, then learn by study.
Boccace in the second book of the praise of women says, that this Aretha was
so excellent a woman, yt she did not only learn for her self, but also to
teach others: and did not only teach in diverse Schools, but also she wrote
many and sundry books, one inespecially in the praise of Socrates, an other of
the manner of bringing up children, an other of the wars of Athens, an other
of the tyrannical force, an other of the common wealth of Socrates, an other of
the infelicities of women, an other of the Tyllage of the auncientes, an other
of the wonders of mount Olympus, an other of the vain care of the Sepulcre, an
other of the provision of the Antes, an other of the workmanshippe of the Bees
in honnye: and she wrote two others the one of the vanities of youth, and the
other of the miseries of age. This woman did read openly natural and moral
Phylosophye in the Schools of Athens, for the space of five and twenty years:
she made forty books, she had a hundred and ten philosophers to her
Scholars, she dyed being at the age of seventy and seven years, and the
Athenians after her death, engraued on her grave these words.

THe slised stones within their bowels keape
Wise Aretha, the great and only wight
That forces envy gentle tears to weape.
For Greeks decay, on whom the loss does light.
The eye of fame, the heart of virtues life
The head of Greece, lie here engraued, lo
more heavenly form then had that heavenly wife
Which vndermind the phrigies joys with woe.
Within the chest of her unspotted mind
Lay Thirmas troth, and eke her honest faith
Within her hand (as by the gods assinde)
Stood Aristippus, pen that virtue wayeth.
Within the dongeon of her body eke
Imprisonde was, wise Socrates his soul
That liude so well, and did so wisely speak
That follies breast, he could to wisdom toule.
Within her head so over heapt with wit
Lay Homers tongue, to stayne the poets art
Erst was the golden age not half so fit
For virtues Impes, as when her life did part.
As Marcus Varro says, the sects of the philosophers were more then.lxx. but
in the end they were reduced into seven, and in the end they were brought
into three sects chiefly. That is to wete, Stoicques, Peripaeticques, and
Pithagoricques. Of these pithagoricques, Pithagoras was the prince. Hyzearcus,
Annius Rusticus and Laertius, with Eusebius and Boccace, all affirm one
thing, whereunto I did not greatly give credit, which is: that this
philosopher Pithagoras had a sister, not only learned, but (if it be lawful
to speak it) excellently learned. And they say, that not she of Pithagoras,
but Pithagoras of her learned philosophy. And of truth it is a matter whereof
I was so greatly abashed, that I can not tell who could be master of such a
woman: since she had Pithagoras the great philosopher to her scholar. The name
of the woman was Theoclea, to whom Pithagoras her brother, wrote and sent a
letter, when he red philosophy at Rhodes, and she at Samothracia doing the
like. The Pistle was thus as follows.

Of a letter which Pithagoras sent to his sister Theoclea, he being in Rhodes,
and she in Samothracia, reading both philosophy. Cap. xxix.
PIthagoras thy brother, and disciple, to thee Theoclea his sister, health and
increase of wisdom wysheth. I have red the book which thou did send
me, of fortune and misfortune, from the beginning to the end: and now I know
that thou art no less grave in making, then gracious in teaching. The which
does not chance very often to us, which are men: and much less (as we have
seen) to you women. For the philosopher Aristippus was rude in speaking, and
profound in writing: and Amenides was brief in writing, and eloquent in
speaking. Thou have studied and written in such sort, that in the learning
that thou show, thou seamest to have read all the philosophers: and in the
antiquities that thou do declare, it seems that thou have seen all the time
past. Wherein thou being a woman show thy self more then a woman: because
the nature of women is, to cast their eyes only in that that is present, and
commonly to forget that that is past. They tell me that thou do occupye thy
self now in writing of our country. And truly in this case I can not say but
that you have matter enough to write on: For the wars and trauayles of our
times have been such, and so great, that I had rather read them in books,
then see them with my eyes. And if it be so, as I suppose it is, I beseech thee
heartily, and by the immortal Gods I conjure thee, that in writing the affairs
of thy country thou do use thy pen discreatly. I mean, that thou do not
in this case bleamyshe thy writing, by putting therein any flattery, or
lesinge. For oftetimes Historiographers, in blasinge more then troth the
gifts of their country: cause worthily to be suspected their writing. Thou
know very well, how that in the battle paste the Rhodians were overcome,
and that ours remained victorious. Me thinks thou should not in this case
greatly magnify, extolle, or exalt ours, because in the end they fought to
revenge their injury: neither thou ought to blame the Rhodians, for they did
not fight but in the aid of Rome. I speak this (my Sister) because for to
defend their own, women show them selves Lions: and for to defend the
things of an other man, men show them selves chickens. For in the end he
only may be counted strong, the which defends not his own house: but
which dies defending his, and another man's. I will not deny the natural love
of my country, nor I will not deny but that I love them that write, and
speak well thereof: but me thinks it is not reason, that they should
disprayse the goodness and truth of other countries, nor that they should so
highly comend the evil and vileness of their own. For there is not in the
world this day so barren a Realm, but may be commended for some thing
therein: nor there is so perfect a nation, but in some things may be
reproved. Thou can not deny me, but that amongst thy brethren I am the
eldest, and thou canste not deny but that amongst all thy disciples I am the
youngest: and since that for being thy disciple I ought to obey thee, thou like
wise for that I am thy eldest brother ought to believe me. By the fayeth of a
people I do council thee, my sister, that thou do travail much to be
profound in thy words, upright in thy life, and honest of thy person: and
besides all this, true in thy writing. For I let thee understand, that if the
body of the man without the soul is little regarded: I swear unto thee that
the mouth of a man, without truth, is much less esteamed.

The author follows his purpose, persuading princesses and other ladies to
endeavor them selves to be wise, as the women were in old time. Cap. xxx.
THis therefore was the letter, the which Pithagoras sent to his sister
Theoclea, whereby is showed the great humility of him, and the high eloquence
of her. Hiarcus the Greek, and Plutarche also in the book of the government
of princes say, that Pithagoras had not only a sister (which was called
Theoclea) of whom he learned so much philosophy, but also he had a daughter,
the wisdom and knowledge of whom surmounted her aunte, and was equal to her
father. I think it no less incredible which is spoken of the daughter, then
that which is spoken of the aunte, which is that those of Athenes did rejoice
more to hear her speak in her house, then for to hear Pithagoras read in
the schole. And it ought to be believed: for the saying of the grave authors on
the one part: and by that we daily see on the other part. For in the end, it
is more pleasure to hear a man tell merry tales, having grace and comlines in
his words: then to hear a grave man speak the truth, with a rude and rough
tongue. I have found in many wrytinges, what they have spoken of Pithagoras,
and his daughter: but none tells her name, save only in a pistle that
Phalaris the tyrant wrate, I found this word written, where he says.
Polichrata, that was the daughter of the philosopher Pithagoras, was young, and
exceading wise, more fair then rich and was so much honored for the purity
of her life, and so high esteemed for her pleasant tongue: that the word which
she spoke spinning upon her distaffe, was more esteemed: then the philosophy
that her father red in the schole. And he said more. It is so great a pity to
see, and hear that women at this present are in their life so dishonest, and
in their tongues so malicious: that I have greater pleasure in the good renown
of one that is dead, then in the infamy of all them which are alive. For a
good woman is more worth with her distaffe spinning, then a hundred euel
queens, with their royal scepters reigning. By the words which Phalaris
said in his letter, it seamed that this daughter of Pithagoras was called
Polichrate. Pithagoras therefore made many commentaries, as well of his own
country, as of strangers. In the end he died in Mesopotamia, where at the
hour of his death he spoke unto his daughter Polichrate, and said these
words. I see my daughter that the hour wherein I must end my life
approaches. The Gods gave it me, and now they will take it from me: nature gave
me birth, and now she gives me death: the earth gave me the body, and now it
retourneth to ashes. The woeful fatal destinies gave me a little goods, mingled
with many travails, so that (daughter) of all things which I enjoyed in this
world, I carry none with me: for having all as I had it, by the way of
borowyng: now at my death each man takes his own. I die joyfully not for
that I leave thee rich: but for that I leave thee learned. And in token of my
tender heart, I bequethe unto the al my books, wherein thou shall find the
treasure of my travails. And I tell thee that that I give thee, is the riches
gotten with mine own sweat: and not obtained to the prejudice of an other. For
the love I bear unto thee, daughter I pray thee, and by the immortal gods I
conjure thee, that thou be such, and so good, that although I die, yet at the
least thou may keep my memory: for thou know well what Ho^ere says,
speaking of Achilles, and Pirrus, that the good life of the child that is
alive, keapeth the renown of the father that is dead. These were the words
which this philosopher spoke unto his daughter lieng in his death bed. And
though perhaps he spoke not these words: yet at the least this was the
meaning. As ye great poet Mantuan says, king Euander was father of the giant
Pallas, and he was a great friend of king Eneas, he vaunted him self to
descend of the lineage of the Troyans: and therefore when king Eneas, and prince
Turnus, had great wars between them, which of them should have the princess
Lauinia in marriage, (the which at yt time was only heir of Italy) king Euander
aided Eneas, not only with goods: but also sending him his own son in
person. For the friends ought for their true friends, willingly to shed their
blood, and in their behalf without demau^ding, they ought also to spend their
goods. This king Euander had a wife so well learned, that that which the Greeks
said of her seems to be fables. That is to say (of her eloquence and wisdom)
for they say, that if that which this woman wrote of the wars of Troy, had
not been through envy cast into the fire: the name of Homere had at this day
remained obscure. The reason hereof is, because the woman was in the time of
the destruction of Troy, and wrate as a witness of sight.

These words passed between the Roman Calphurnius and the poet Cornificius.
I desire to declare the excellency of those few ancient women (as well Greeks,
as Latins, and Romans) to the intent that princesses, and great ladies may
know, that the ancient women were more esteamed for their sciences, then for
their beauties. Therefore the princesses and great Ladies ought to think that
if they be women, they were also in like manner: and if they be frail, the
others were also weak. If they be married, the other also had husbands: if
they have their wylles, the other had also what they wanted: if they be tender,
the others were not strong: Finally they ought not to excuse them selves,
saying that for to learn women are unmeet. For a woman has more ability to
learn sciences in the schools: then the Parate has to speak words in the
cage. In my opinion princesses and great ladies ought not to esteame themselves
more then an other, for that they have fairer hears then other, or for that
they are better appareled then an other: or that they have more riches then an
other. But they ought therefore to esteame them selves, not for that they can
do more then others. To say the truth, the fair and yelow hears, the rich
and brave apparel, the great treasures, the sumptuous palaces and strong
buildinges, these and other like pleasures are not guides and leaders to
virtues, but rather spies and scout watches for vices. O what a noble thing
were it, that the noble ladies would esteem them selves not for that they can
do: but for that that they know. For it is more commendation to know how to
teach two philosophers: then to have authority to command a hundred
knights. It is a shame to write it, but it is more pity to see it, that is to
wete, to read that we read of the wisdom and worthiness of the ancient
matrones paste, and to see as we do see the frailenes of these young ladies
present. For they coueted to have disciples both learned and experimented: and
these of this present desire nothing but to have servants not only ignorant,
but deceitful and wicked. And I do not marvel seeing that which I se, that at
this present in court she is of little value and lest esteemed among ladies,
which has fairest servants, and is lest enterteined of gentlemen. What shall
I say more in this matter but that they in times past strive who should write
better, and compile the best books: and these at this present do not strive,
but who shall have the richest and most sumptuous apparel. For the ladies think
it a iolier matter, to wear a gown of a new fachion: then the auncientes did
to read a lesson of philosophy. The ancient ladies strive which of them was
wisest: but these of our days contend who shall be fairest. For at this day ye
ladies would chose rather to have the face adorned with beauty, then the heart
endued with wisdom. The ancient ladies contented which should be better able
to teach others: but these ladies now a days contend how they may most
finely apparel them selves. For in these days they give more honor to a woman
richely appareled, then they give to an other with honesty beautified. Finally
with this word I do conclude, and let him mark that shall read it, that in
the old time women were such, that their virtues caused al men to keep
silence: and now their vices be such, that they compel al men to speak. I
will not by this my word any man should be so bold in generally to speak evil
of all the ladies: for in this case I swear, yt there are not at this day so
many good virtuous women in ye world: but that I have more envy at the life
they lead in secreat, then at all the sciences which the ancient women red in
public. Wherefore my pen does not show it self extreme, but to those which
only in sumptuous apparel and in vain words do consume their whole life:
and to those which in readyng a good book would not spend one only hour. To
prove my intencion of that I have spoken, the above written suffiseth. But to
the end princesses and great ladies may se (at the lest) how much better it
shall be for them to know litel, then to have and possess much, and to be able
to do more. I will remember the^ of that which a Roman woman wrate to her
children, whereby they shall perceive how eloquent a woman she was in her
sayings, and how true a mother in her counsel. For in the end of her letter
she persuades her children to the travails of the war, not for any other
cause, but to avoid the pleasures of Rome.

Of the worthiness of the lady Cornelia, and of a notable epistle she wrote to
her.ii. sons which served in the wars Tyberius, and Caius diswadyng them
from the pleasures of rome, and exorting them to endure the travails of war.
Chap. xxxi.
ANnius Rusticus in the book of the antiquities of the Romans says, that in
Rome there were.v. principal linages, that is to wete Fabritij, Torquatij,
Brutij, Fabij, and Cornelij, though there were in Rome other new linages,
whereof there were many excellent personages: yet always these which came of
the.v. linages, were kept, placed, and preferred to the first offices of the
common wealth. For Rome honored those that were present in such sort, that it
was without the prejudice of those that are gone. Amongst those.v. linages,
the romans always counted the Cornelij most fortunat, the which were so
hardy and courageous in fight, and so modest in life, that of their family
there was never found any cowardly man in the feld, nor any defamed woman in
the town. They say of this lineage of the Cornelij, among many other there
were.iiii. singular and notable women among the which the chief was the
mother of Gracchi whose name was Cornelia and lived with more honor for the
sciences she red in Rome, then for the conquestes that her children had in
Affricke. Before her children were brought into the empire, they talked of none
other thing but of their strength and hardines, throughout all the world: and
therefore a Roman one day asked this woman Cornelia, whereof she took most
vain glory, to se her self mistres of so many disciples, or mother of so
valiant children. The lady Cornelia answered. I do esteem the science more
which I have learned, then the Children which I have brought forth. For in
the end, the children keep in honor the life: but the disciples continue the
renown after the death.

And she said further. I am assured that the disciples daily will wax better
and better: and it may be that my Children will wax worse and worse. The
desires of young men are so variable, that they daily have new inventions. With
one accord all the writers do greatly commend this woman Cornelia,
inespecially for being wise and honest, and furthermore because she red
philosophy in Rome openly.

And therefore after her death they set up in Rome a Statue, over the gate
Salaria, whereupon there was graven this Epigrame.

This heap of earth. Cornelie does encloose
Of wretched Gracches, that lo the mother was
Twyse happy in the sckollers, that she choose
Unhappy thrice, in the ofspringe that she has.
AMong the latins, Cicero was the Prince of all the Roman rethorike, and the
chiefest with his pen inditing of Epystles: yet they say, that he did not only
se the writings of this Cornelia, but red them, and did not only read them,
but also with the sentences thereof profited him self. And hereof a man ought
not to marvel: for there is no man in the world so wise of him self, but may
further his doings with the advice of another, Cicero so highly exalted these
writings, that he said in his rethorike these or such other like words. If
the name of a woman had not bleamyshed Cornelia, truly she deserved to be head
of all philosophers. For I never saw so grave sentences proceed from so frail
flesh. Since Cicero spoke these words of Cornelia, it can not be, but that the
writings of such a woman in her time were very lively, and of great reputacion
yet notwithstanding there is no memory of her, but that an author for his
purpose declares an epistel of this manner. Sextus Cheronensis in his book of
the praise of women, recites the letter which she sent to her children. She
remaynyng in Rome, and they being at the wars in Affrike.

The letter of Cornelia to her.ii. sons Tiberius and Caius otherwise called
Gracchi.
COrnelia the Roman, that by thy fathers side am of the Cornelij, and one the
mother side of the Fabij: to you my.ii. sons. Gracchii, which are in that
wars of Affrik, such health to you do wish, as a mother to her children ought
to desire. Ye have understood right well my children, how my father died, I
being but.iii. years of age, and that this.xxii. years I have remained wydow,
and that this.xx. years I have red Rethorike in Rome. It is.vii. years sins I
saw ye, and.xii. years sins your brethren my children dyed in the great
plage. You know.viii. years ar past since I left my study and came to se you in
Cicilia, because you should not forsake the wars, to come se me in rome: for
to me could come no greater pain, the^ to se you absent from the service of
the commonwealth. I desire my children to show you how I have passed my life in
labor and trauaill, to the intent you should not desire to spend youres, in
rest and idleness. For if to me that am in rome there can want no trobles: be ye
assured that unto you which are in the wars shall want no perils. For in
wars renoune is never sold but by weight, or changed with loss of life. The
young Fabius, son of my aunt the aged Fabia, at the.iii. Cale^des of March
brought me a letter the which you sent: and truly it was more brief then I
would have wyshed it. For between so dear children, and so louinge a mother, it
is not suffered that the absence of your parsonnes should be so far, and the
letters which you write so brief. By those that go from hence thither, I
always do send you commendations: and of those that come from thence hither.
I do enquire of news Some say they have seen you, other tell me they have
spoken with you, so that with this my heart is somewhat quieted. For between them
that love greatly, it may be endured that ^he sight be seldom, so that the
health be certain. I am sole, I am a widow, I (...) aged, and now all my kindred
is dead: I have endured many travails in Rome, and the greatest of all is (my
children) of your absence. For the pain is greater to be void of assured
friends: the^ assault is dangerous of cruel enemies. Since you are young, and
not very rich, since you are hardy, and brought up in the travails of Afrike,
I do not doubt but that you do desire to come to Rome, to se and know that
now you are men, which you have seen when you were children. For men do not
love their country so much, for that it is good: as they do love it, for that
it is natural. Believe me children, there is no man living that has seen or
hard speak of Rome in times past: but has great grief, sorrow, and pity, to
se it at this present. For as their hearts are pitiefull, and their eyes
tender: so they can not behold that without great sorrow, which in times past
they have seen in great glory. O my children, you shall know that Rome is
greatly changed from that it was wont to be. To read that that we do read of
it in times past, and to se that which we se of it now present: we must needs
esteem that which the auncientes have written as a gest, or else believe it but
as a dream. There is no other thing now at Rome, but to see justice corrupted,
the commen weal oppressed, lies blown abroad, the truth kept under, the
satires silent, the flatterers open mouthed, the inflamed persons to be
Lords, and the pacient to be servants, and above al, and worse then all, to
se the evil live in rest and contented, and the good troubled and displeased.
Forsake, forsake (my children) that city, where the good have occasion to
weape, and the evil have liberty to laugh. I can not tell what to say in this
matter, as I would say. Truly ye common weal is at this day such and so woeful,
that each wise man (without comparison) would have greater pleasure to be in ye
wars of Affrik: then in the peace at Rome. For in the good war, a man sees
of whom he should take heed: but in ye evil peace, no man knows whom to
trust. Therefore my children, since you are natural of Rome. I will tell you
what Rome is at this present. I let you know, yt the vestall virgins are now
dissolute, the honor of the gods is forgotten, ye profit of the common weal
no man seeks, of ye exercise of chiualry there is no memory for the orphans
and widows there is no man yt does answer, to ministre justice they have no
regard, and the dissolute vices of ye youth ar without measure. Finally, Rome
that in times past was a receypt of all the good and virtuous: is now made a
den of al thieves and vicious. I fear me, I fear me, least our mother rome
in short time will have some sodein and great fall. And I say not without a
cause some great fall, for both men and Cities, that fall from the top of their
felicity, purchase greater infamy with those yt shall com after: the^ the glory
yt they have had of the^ that be past. Peradventure (my children) you desire to
se the walls and buildinges of Rome: for those things which children se first
in their youth, the same they love and keep always in memory until their age.
As the ancient buildinges of rome are destroyed, and the few that are now
builte: so would I you should loose your earnest affection to come to se the^.
For in deed, the noble hearts are ashamed to se that thing amiss, which they
ca^ not remedy. Do not think, my children, though Rome be made worse in
manners, that therefore it is diminished in buildinges. For I let you understand,
if you know it not, yt if a wall does decay, there is no man that does repair
it. If a house fall, there is no man that will raise it up again. If a street be
foul, there is no man that will make it clean. If the river carry away any
bridge, there is no man that will set it up again. If any antiquity decay,
there is no man that will amend it. If any wood be cut, there is no man that will
keep it. If the trees wax old, there is no man that will plant the^ a new. If
the pauement of the streates be broken, there is no man that will ley it again.
Finally there is nothing in Rome at this day so evil handled, as those things
which by ye common voices ar ordered. These things (my children) though I do
greatly lament (as it is reason) yet you ought little to esteem them al: but
this al only ought to be esteemed, and with drops of blood to be lamented.
That now in Rome, when ye buildinges in many places fall down, ye vices all
wholly together are raised up. O woeful mother Rome, since that in the, the more
the walls decay, the more the vices increase. Peradventure (my children) since
you are in those frountiers of Affrike, you desire to se your parents here in
Rome. And thereat I marvel not, for the love which our natural countreye do
give, ye straung country can not take away. All those which come from those
parties do bring us no other certain news, but of the multitude of those
which dye and are slain in Afrik, therefore since you send us such news from
thence, look not that we should send you any other then the like from hence.
For death has such authority, yt it kills the armed in the wars: and
sleyeth the quiet in peace. I let you know that Licia your sister is dead.
Drusio your uncle is dead. Torcquatus your neighbor is dead. His wife our
cousin and her.iii. daughters are dead. Fabius your great friend is dead.
Euander and his children ar dead. Bibulus which red for me in the chair the
last year is also dead. Finally there are so many and so good with all yt be
dead: that it is a great shame and pity to se (at this present,) so many evil
as do live Know ye my children, that all these and many others which ye left
alive full high in rome: are now become worms meat full low under the earth,
and death also does summon me unto the grave. If you (my children) did consider
what shall become of you herafter, truly you will think it better to
weape.1000. years with the dead: then to laugh one hour with those yt be
alive. Remembryng that I ba^e ye in great pain, and have nourished you in
great travel, and that ye came of my proper intrailles: I would have you as
children about me for ye confort and consolation of my pains. But in the end
beholding ye prowesses of those yt are paste, that binds their heirs, I am
content to suffer so long absence your persons, only to the end you may get
honor in chiualrye. For I had rather here tell you should live like knights
in Afrik: the^ to se you utterly lost here in Rome. My children, as you are in
ye wars of Afrike, so I doubt not but yt you desire to se ye pleasurs of
rome: for there is no man in this world so happy, but at his neighbors
prosperity had some envy, envy not ye vicious, nether desire to be among vices:
for truly vices ar of such a condition yt they bring not with the^ so much
pleasure when they com: as they leave sorrow behind the^ when they depart, for yt
true delight is not in ye pleasure which suddenly vanishes: but in ye truth
which evermore remains. I thank ye immortal gods for all these things, first
for yt they made me wise and not folish: for to a woman it is a small matter to
be called so frail, yt in deed she be not folish. The second I thank ye gods,
because in all times of my troubles, they have given me patience to endure the^:
for ye man only in this lif may be called unhappy, to whom ye gods in his
troubles has not given patience. The third, I thank the gods for that
those.lxv. years which I have lived, I never hitherto was defamed: for ye
woman by no reason can complain of her fortune, if in none of her troubles she
has lost her honor. The fourth, I thank the Gods that in this forty years
I have lived in Rome, and remained widow, there was never man nor woman ye
contended with me: for since we women profit little the common wealth, it is
but reason that she which with evil demeanoures has passed her life should
by justice receive her death. The fifth I give the gods tankes, that they gave
me children, the which are better contented to suffer the travails of Affrik:
the^ to enjoy the pleasurs of Rome. Do not count me (my children) for so
unloving a mother, that I would not have you always before my eyes: but
considering that many good men's children have been lost, only for being brought
up in the excessive pleasures of Rome, I do content my self with your absence.
For that man that desires perpetual renown, though he be not banished, he
ought to absent him self from his native country. My dear children, I most
earnestly desire you, that always you acco^panie your selves with the good,
with the most auncientes, and with those which are grave and most expert in
council, and with those that have most seen the world: and do not understand
most of the world, by those that have seen most countries. For the ripe council
proceadeth not from the man that has traueiled in many contreis: but from him
that has felt him self in many dangers. Since the nature of the country
(my children) does knock with the hammer at the gate of the heart of man, I
fear yt if you come and se your friends and parents, you shall always live in
care and pensifnes, and being pensife you shall always live evil contented, and
you shall not do yt which becomes Romain knights to do. And you not being
valiant knights, your enemies shall always rejoice over you, and your desires
shall never take effect: for of those men which are careful and heavy,
proceadeth always services unworthy. I desire you heartily, and by this present
letter I counsel you, yt you will not in any wise seek to come to rome: for as
I have said you shall know few of those that did know you, for either they are
dead or banished, poor or sick, aged or come to naught, sad or evil
contented: so that since you are not able to remedy their grefes, it is best
you should not come hither to se their troubles. For no man comes to Rome but
to weape with the living, and to sigh for the^ that be dead. Truly (my
children) I know not what pleasure is in Rome that should cause any good man to
come hither and to forsake Affrik: for if there you have enemies, here you
shall want friends. If you have the sword that perceth the body, we have that
tongue here that destroys the renown. If you be vexed with the thieves of
Affrike, we are wounded with the traitors, Flatterers, and liers of Italy. If
you lack rest, we have here to much trouble. Finallye seeing that that I do se
in Rome, and hearing that which I hear of Affrik: I commend your war, and
abhor our peace. If you do greatly esteem yt which I have said, esteem much
more that which I shall say, which is, that we always here that you are
conquerours of the Africkans, and you shall here always yt we are conquered by
vices. Therefore if I am a true mother, I had rather se you win a perpetual
memory among strangers: the^ to live with infamy at home in your country.
Peradventure with hope that you shall enherit some goods you will take occasion
to come to Rome. When this thing shall come to your minds, remember (my
children) that your father being alive had not much, and that unto your mother
being a widow many things wanted. And remember that your father bequethed you
nothing but weapons, and know that from me you shall enherite nothing but
books. For I had rather leave my children good doctrine whereby they may live:
them evil riches whereby they may perysh. I am not rich, nor I never travailed
to be rich, and the cause was that I saw many men's children undone, only
through the hope they had to enherite their pare^tes goods, and afterward went
a huntinge after vices. For they seldom times do any worthy feats, which in
their youth enherit great treasurs. This thing therefore being true (as it is in
dead) I do not say only that I would watch, and toil as many do to get riches
and treasurs: but also if I had treasour, before I would give them unto you, I
would (as the philosopher did) cast the^ into the fire. For I had rather have
my children pore and virtuous in Affrike: the^ rich and vicious in Rome. You
know very well my children that there was amongst the Tharentins a law well
observed, that the sons should not inherit any other thing of their fathers
but weapons to fight: and that the daughters should inherit the goods for to
mary them selves with all. Truly this law was very just, for the son that
has always respect to the enheritaunce: will not have to his father any great
confidence. For he ought to be called a valiant Roman knight that with his
life has won honor, and by the sword has gotten riches. Since you are in
straung realms, I pray you heartily that you be conuersaunt with the good (as
good brethren) remembering always that you were my children, and that I gave you
both, suck of mine own propre breasts. And the day that I shall here of
your disagrement, the same day shall be the end of my life. For the discord in
one city of parents does more harm: then a hole army of enemies. It is good
for you (my children) to live in love and concord togethers: but it is more
requisite to keep you with the Roman knights, The which with you, and you
with the^, if you do not love together in ye wars: you shall never have the
upper hand of your enemies. For in great armies, the discordes which rise
amongst the^ do more harm: then the enemies do against who^ they fight. I
think well (my children) that you would be very desirous to know of my estate
(that is to wete) whether I am in health, whether I am sick, whether I am
poor, whether I am pleased, or whether I am miscontented. In this case I know
not why you should desire to know it, since you ought to presuppose that
according to the troubles which I have passed, and the miseries yt with mine
eyes I have seen, I am filled with this world: for wise men after.50. years and
upward, ought rather to apply their minds how to receive death: the^ to seek
pleasurs to prolong life. When man's flesh is weak, it always desires to be
well kept even unto the grave. And as I am of flesh and bone: so I do feale the
troubles of the world, as al mortal men do. But for all this do not think that
to be pore or sick is the greatest misery, neither think yt to be hole and
rich is the chefest felicity: for there is none other felicity of the old
fathers, but for to se their children virtuous. In my opinion it is an honor
to yt country, that the fathers have such children, which will take profit with
their counsel: and contrary wise that the children have such fathers which can
give it them. For the child is happy that has a wise father, and more happy is
the father that has not a folish son. I do write often times unto you my
children, but there is a law that none be so hardy to write to men of war in
the field, except first they inrowle the letters in the senate. Therefore since
I write unto you more letters then they would, they do send less then I
desire. Though this law be painful to mothers which have children: yet we
must confess it is profitable for ye weal publik.

For if a man should write to one in the war, that his family is not well: he
would forsake the wars to remedy it. If a man write unto him that it is
prosperous, he has then a desire to enjoy it. Be not displeased (my children)
though all the letters I do send unto you come not to your hands: For all
that I do not cease to visit the temples for your own health, nor yet to
offer sacrifices to the Gods for your honor. For if we do please the gods, we
have not cause to fear our enemies. I say no more in this case, my children,
but that I beseech the immortal Gods, that if your lives may profit the
common wealth, then they shorten my days and le^gthen your years: but if your
lives should be to the damage of the common wealth, then those immortal gods I
desire that first I may understand the end of your days, before that the
worms should eat my flesh. For rather then by your evil life the glory of
our predecessors should be bleamished: it were much better both your lives were
ended. The grace of the Gods, the good renown amongst men, the good fortune
of the Romans, yt wisdom of the greeks the blessing of Scippio, and of al
other your predecessors be always with you my children.

Of the education and doctrine of children whiles they are young. Wherein the
auctour declares many notable histories. Chap. xxxii.
ALl mortal men which will travel, and see good fruit of their travel,
ought to do as the chief artificer did that painted the world: For ye man that
makes god the head of his works, it is impossible that he should err in the
same. That which we believe, and read by wrytinge, is that the eternal created
the world in short space by his might: but preserved it a long time by his
wisdom. Whereof a man may gather, that the time to do a thing is short: but
the care and thought to preserve it, is long. We see daily, that a valiant
captain assaulteth his enemies: but in the end it is god that gives the
victory, but let us ask the conqueror, what travel it has been unto him,
or wherein he has perceived most danger (that is to wete) either to obtain
the victory of his enemies, or else to preserve them selves amongst the envious
and malicious. I swear, and affirm, that such a knight will swear, that there
is no comparison between the one and the other: for by the bloody sweard in an
hour the victory is obtained: but to keep it with reputation, the sweet of all the life is required Laertius in the book of the life of the philophers
declares, and Plato also hereof makes mention, in the books of his common
wealth, that those of Thebes understanding that the Lacedaemonians had good
laws (for that which they were of the gods favored, and of men greatly
honored) determined to send (by common assent and agreement) a wise
philosopher, the best esteamed amongst them (whose name was Phetonius) to
whom they commanded, that he should ask the laws of the Lacedaemonians, and
that he should be very circumspecte and ware to see what their rules and
customs were.

Those of Thebes were then very noble, valliant, and honest: so that their
principal end was, to come to honor and renown, to erect buildinges, and to
make them selves of immortal memory for being virtuous. For in buildyng they
were very curious: and for virtues they had good Philosophers. The philosopher
Phetonius was more the^ a year in the realm of the Lacedaemonians, beholding
at sundry times all things therein: for simple men do not note things, but
only to satisfye the eyes: but the wise men beholds them, for to know and
understand their secrettes. After that the philosopher had well and plainly
seen and beheld all the things of the Lacedaemonians: he determined to return
home to Thebes, and being arrived, all the people came to see him and here him.
For the vanity of the common people is of such a quality, that it follows
new inventions: and despises ancient customs. All the people therefore
gathered togethers, the good philosopher Phetonius set up in the midst of the
market place a gybet, hoote yrons, a swerd, a whip, and fetters for the feet:
the which thing done, the Thebains were no less as they thought slaundered,
the^ abashed. To the which he spoke these words. You Thebains sent me to the
Lacedaemonians, to the intent I should learn their laws and customs, and in
deed I have been there more then a year, beholding al things very diligentely:
for we Philosophers are bound, not only to note that which is done, but also
to know why it is done know ye Thebains, that this in the answer of my
Imbassage.

That the Lacedaemonians hang upon this Gybet thieves, with this same sword they
behede traitors, with these hoote Irons they torment blasphemers, and liars,
with these rods they whippe vacabondes, and with these Irons do keape the
rebels, and the others are for players, and unthrifts. Finally I say that I do
not bring you the laws written, but I bring you the Instruments wherewith they
are observed.

The Thebains were abashed to se these things, and spoke unto him such words.
Consider Phetonius we have not sent the to the Lacedaemonians, to bring
instruments to take away life: but for the good laws to govern the common
wealth. The philosopher Phetonius replied again, and answered. Thebains, I let
you wete, that if ye know what we philosophers knew, you should see how far your
minds were from the truth: For the Lacedaemonians are not so virtuous, thoroughe
the laws which were made of them that be dead: as for the means they have
sought, to preserve them that be alive. For matters of Justice consiste more in
execution, then in commaundyng or ordeinynge. Laws are easily ordained, but
with difficulty executed: for there are a thousand to make them, but to put
them in execution there is not one. Full little is that which men know that are
present: in respect of that those knew which are past. But yet according to my
little knowledge, I proffer to give as good laws to you Thebains, as ever were
observed among ye Lacedemonia^s. For there is nothing more easy, then to know
the good: and nothing more commen, then to follow the evil. But what profits
it if one will ordeyne, and none understand it: If there be that does understand
the^, there is none that excuteth them. If there be that executes them, there
is none that observes the^. If there be one that observes them, there is a
thousand that reproves them. For without comparison, mo are they that murmr
and grudge at the good, then those which blame and despise the evil. You
Thebains are offended, because I have brought such Instruments but I let you
wete, if you will neither Gybet, nor sword to keep that which shall be ordained,
you shall have your books full of laws, and the common wealth full of vices.

Wherefore I swear unto you, that there are mo Thebains which follow the
deliciousnes of Denis the tyrant: then there are virtuous men that follow the
laws of Lycurgus. If you Thebains do desire greatly to know, with what Laws
the Lacedaemonians: do preserve their common wealth: I will tell you them all
by word, and if you will read them, I will show you them in writing. But it
shall be upon condition, that you shall swear all openly, that once a day you
shall employ your eyes to read them, and your parsonnes to observe them. For
the prince has greater honor, to se one only law to be observed in deed:
then to ordeyne a thousand by writing. You ought not to esteame much to be
virtuous in heart, nor to enquire of the virtue by the mouth, nor to seek it
by labor and trauaille of the feet: but that which you ought greatly to
esteame, is to know what a virtuous law means, and that known, immediately
to execute it, and afterward to keep it. For the chief virtue is not to do
one verteous work: but in swet and trauayl to continue in it. These therefore
were the words that this philosopher Phetonius said to the Thebains. The
which (as Plato says) esteemed more his words that he spoke: then they did
the laws which he brought. Truly in my opinion, those of Thebes are to be
praised and commended: and the philosopher for his words is worthy to be
honored. For the end of those was to search laws to live well, and the end
of the Philosophet was to seek good means for to keep them in virtue. And
therefore he thought it good to show the^, and put before their eyes the gibbet,
and the sword, with the other instruments and torments. For the evil do
refrain from vice more for fear of punyshement, then for any desire they have
of amendment. I was willing to bring in this History, to the end that all
curious and virtuous men may see and know, how litell the auncientes did esteem
the beginnynge, the mean, and the end of virtuous works, in respect of the
perseueraunce and preseruacion of them. Coming therefore to my matter, which my
pen does toss and seek: I ask now presentely, what it profits princes and
great ladies, that God do give them great estates, that they be fortunate in
marriages, that they be all reverenced and honored, that they have great
treasures for their inheritaunces, and above all that they se their wives great
with child, and that afterward in joy they se them delivered: that they se
their mothers giving their children suck, and finally they se them selves
happy in that they have found them good nources, helthful and honest. Truly all this avails little, if to their children (when they are young) they do not give
masters to enstruct the^ in virtues: and also if they do not recomend them to
good guides, to exercise the^ in feats of Chiualry. The fathers which by
syghes penetrat the heaven: by prayers importune the Living god only for to
have children, ought first to think why they will have children: for that
justly to any man may be denayed, which to an evil end is procured. In my
opinion, ye father ought to desire to have a child, for yt in his age he may
sustain his life in honor: and that after his does he may cause his fame to
live. And if a father desires not a son for this cause, at the least he ought
to desire him, to the end in his age he may honor his horye head: and that
after his death he may enheryte his goods, but we see few children do these
things to their fathers in their age: if the fathers have not taught them in
their youth. For the fruit does never grow in the harvest: unless the tree
did bear blosommes in the spryng. I see oftentimes many fathers complain of
their Children, saying that they are disobedient and proud unto them: and
they do not consydre that they them selves are the cause of all those euilles.
For to much abundance and liberty of youth is no other: but a prophecy and
manifest token of disobedience in age. I know not why princes and great lords
do toil, and oppress so much, and scratche to leave their children great
estates, and on the other side we see that in teaching them, they are and show
them selves to negligent: for princes and great lords ought to make account,
that all yt which they leave of their substance to a wicked heir is utterly
lost. The wise men, and those which in their consciences are upright, and of
their honors careful, ought to be very diligent to bring up their children,
and chiefly that they consider whether they be mete to inherit their estates.
And if perchance the fathers se that their children be more given to folly,
then to noblenes and wisdom: then should I be ashamed to se a father that is
wise, travail all the days of his life, to leave much substance to an evil
brought up child after his death. It is a grief to declare, and a monstrous
thing to se, ye cares which the fathers take to gather riches: and the
diligence that children have to spend them. And in this case I say, the son
is fortunate for that he does inherit, and the Father a fool for that he
does bequeth.

In my opinion Fathers ar bound to enstructe their Children well, for two
causes: the one for that they are nearest to them, and also because they ought
to be their heirs. For truly with great greyfe and sorrow I suppose he does
take his death: which leaves to a fool or an unthrift the toil of all his
life.

Hyzearcus the Greek hystorien in the book of his antiquities, and
Sabellyquus in his general history says, that a father and a son came to
complain to the famous philosopher and ancient Solon Solinon: the son
complained of the father, and the father of the son.

First the son informed the quarrel to ye Philosopher, saying these words. I
complain of my father, because he being rich has dysheryted me, and made me
poor, and in my stead has adopted another heir, the which thing my father
ought not, nor cannot do. For sense he gave me so frail flesh, it is reason
he give me his goods to maintain my feebleness. To these words answered the
father. I complain of my son, because he has not been as a gentle son,
but rather as a cruel enemy, for in all things since he was borne, he has
been disobedient to my will, wherefore I thought it good to dysheryte him before
my death. I would I we^e quite of all my substance, so that the gods had
quyte him of his life: for the earth is very cruel that swalloweth not the
child alive, which to his father is dysobedyent. In that he says I have
adopted another child for mine heir, I confess it is true: and for somuche as
he says that I have dysinheryted him, and abiected him from my heritage, he
being begotten of my own body, hereunto I answer.

That I have not disinheryted my son, but I have disinheryted his pleasure,
tothentent he shall not enjoy my travail: for there can be nothing more unjust,
then that the young and vicious son should take his pleasure, of the swette
and drops of the aged father. The son replied to his father, and said. I
confess I have offended my father, and also I confess that I have lived in
pleasures: yet if I may speak the truth, though I were disobedient and
evil, my father ought to bear the blame: and if for this cause he does
dysherite me, I think he does me great iniurye. For the father that enstructed
not his son in virtue in his youth: wrongfullye dysheryteth him, though he
be disobedient in his age. The father again replyeth, and says. It is true
my son, that I brought the up to wantonly in thy youth, but thou know well
that I have taught the sondrye times, and besides that I did correct the when
thou came to some discretion. And if in thy youth I did not instruct the in
learning, it was for that thou in thy tender age dydest want understanding:
but after that thou had age to understand, discrecion to receive, and
strength to exercise it: I began to punyshe the, to teach the, and to
instruct the. For where no understanding is in the child, there in vain they
teach doctrine. Sense thou art old (quoth the son) and I young, sense thou
art my father, and I thy son, for that thou have white here is of thy bearde,
and I none at all: it is but reason that thou be believed, and I condemned. For
in this world we se oftetimes, that the small aucthoryty of the parson, makes
him to lose his great justice. I grant the (my father) that when I was a
child, thou dydst cause me to learn to read: but thou will not deny, that
if I did commit any fault, thou would neauer agree I should be punyshed.
And hereof it came, that thou sufferyng me to do what I would in my youth,
have been dysobedient to the ever since in my age. And I say to the further,
that if in this case I have offended truly me thinks thou can not be
excused: for the fathers in the youth of their children, ought not only to
teach them to dispute of virtues, and what virtue is: but they ought to
enforce them to be virtuous in deed. For it is a good token when youth (before
they know vices) has been accustomed to practice virtues. Both parties thou
diligently hard, the good Philosopher Solon Solinon spoke these words I give
judgment that the father of this child be not buried after his death: and I
command that the son, because in his youth he has not obeyed his father
who is old, should be dysinheryted whiles the father lives from all his
substance, on such condition, that after his death, his sons should
inheryte the heritage, and so return to the heirs of the son and line of
the father. For it were unjust, that the innocence of the son should be
condemned, for the offense of the father. I do command also, that all the
goods be committed unto some faithful parson, to thend they may give the father
meat and drink during his life, and to make a grave for the son after his
death. I have not with out a cause given such judgment, the which
comprehends life and death: for the Gods will not, that for one pleasure the
punyshement be double, but that we chastyse and punyshe the one in the life,
taking from him his honor and goods: and that we punyshe others after there
death, taking from them memory and burial.

Truly the sentence which the Philosopher gave was grave, and would to God we
had him for a judge of this world presentlye: for I swear, that he should
find many children now a days for to disheryte, and mo fathers to punish.
For I cannot tell which is greater, the shame of the children to disobey their
fathers: or the negligence of the fathers in bringing up their children. Sextus
Cheronensis in the second book of the sainges of the Philosophers declares,
that a citezen of Athens said on day to Dyogenes the Philosopher these
words. Tell me Diogenes, what shall I do to be in the favor of the gods, and
not in the hatred of men? for often times among you Philosophers I have hard
say, that there is great difference between that that the Gods will, and that
which men love. Diogenes answered. Thou speak more then thoughtest to
speak, that the gods will one thing, and men another: for the gods are but as
a center of mercy, and men are but as a den of malice, if thou will inioye
rest in thy days, and keape thy life pure and clean: thou must observe these
three things.

The first, honor thy gods devoutly. For the man which does not serve and
honor the gods, in all his enterprises he shall be unfortunate.

The second, be very diligent to bring up thy children well. For the man has
no enemy so troublesome, as his own son, if he be not well brought up.

The third thing, be thankful to thy good benefactours and friends. For the
Oracle of Apollo says, that the man who is unthankful, of all the world
shall be abhorred. And I tell the further my friend, that of these three things
the most profitable (though it be more troblesome) is for a man to teach and
bring up his children well.

This therefore was the answer that the Philosopher Diogenes made to the
demand of the Cytezen. It is great pytie and grief, to see a young child how
the blood does stir him, to se how the flesh does provoke him to accomplish
his desire, to se sensualyte go before, and he himself to come behind, to se
the malicious world to watch him, to se how the devil does tempt him, to se
how vices bind him, and in all that which is spoken, to se how the father is
negligent as if he had no children: where as in deed the old man, by the few
virtues that he has had in his youth: may easily know the infirmites and
vices, wherewith his son is compassed. If the expert had never ben ignorant,
if the fathers had never ben children, if the virtuous had never ben vicious,
if the fine wits had never ben deceived, it were no marvel if the Fathers
were negligent in teaching their children. For the little experience excuses
men of great offenses: but since thou art a father, and that first thou were a
son, since thou art old, and have ben young, and besides all this, since that
pride has enflamed the, lechery has burned the, wrath has wounded the,
negligence has hindered the, covetousness has blinded the, and glotonie
surfeted the, tell me cruel father, since so many vices have reigned in ye:
why have thou not an eye to thy child, whom of thy own blood thou have
begotten? And if thou do it not because he is thy child, thou ought to
do it because he is thy nearest. For it is impossible that the child which with
many vices is assaulted, and not succored: but in the end he should be infamed
and to the dishonor of ye father most wickedly overcome. It is impossible to
keep flesh well favored, unless it be first salted. It is impossible that the
fish should live without water. It is impossible but that the Rose should
wyther, which is of the thorn ouergrowen. So like it is impossible that the
fathers should have any comfort of their children in their age, unless they
have instructed them in virtue in their youth. And to speak further in this
matter I say, that in the Christian catholic religion, where in deed there is
good doctrine, there always is supposed to be a good conscience. Amongst the
writers it is a thing well known, how Eschines, the philosopher was banished
from Athens, and with all his family came to dwell at Rhodes. The occasion was,
because that he and the philosopher Demosthenes were in great contention in the
common wealth. Wherefore the Athenians determined to banish the one, and to
keape the other with them. And truly they did well, for of the contentions and
debates of sages, wars most commonly arise amongst the people. This
philosopher Eschines being at Rhodes banished, amongst others made a solemn
oration, wherein he greatly reproves the Rhodians that they were so negligente
in brynging up their children, saying unto them these words. I let you
understand (Lords of Rhodes) that your predecessors advanced them selves to
discende, and to take their beginning of the Lides: the which above all other
nations were curious and diligent to bring up their children: and hereof came a
law that was among them, which said.

We ordeine and command, that if a father have many children, that the most
virtuous should enherite the goods, and riches: and if there were but one
virtuous, that he alone should inherit the whole. And if perchance the
children were vicious, that then al should be deprived from the heritage. For
the goods gotten with travail of virtuous fathers, ought not by reason to be
inherited with vicious children. These were the words that the philosopher
spoke to the Senate of the Rhodes: and because he said in that Oration many
other things which touch not our matter, I will in this place omit them.
For among excellent writers, the writing loses much authority, when the
author from his purpose digresseth into an other matter. To say the truth, I
do not maruayle that the children of princes and great lords be adulterers,
and belly gods: for that on the one part youth is the mother of Idleness, and
on the other, little experience is the cause of great offenses. And furthermore
the fathers being once dead, the children enherite their goods as quietly,
being laden with vices: as if in deed they were with all virtues endued. If the
young children did know for a certain, that the laws of the Lydes should be
observed (that is to wit) that they should not enherite, unless they be
virtuous: it is impossible but that they would lead a good life, and not in
this wise to run at large in the world. For they do abstain more from
doing evil, fearyng to lose that which they do possess: then for any love
to do that which they ought. I do not denaye, but according as the natures
of the fathers is diverse, so the inclinations of the children are variable. For
so much as some following their good inclination are good, and others not
resisting evil sensualities are evil. But yet in this matter I say, that it
lies much in the father that does bring them up, when as yet they are
young: so that the evil which nature gave, by good bryngyng up is refrayned.
For oftetymes the good custom, does overcome all evil inclination. Princes
and great lords that wylbe diligent in the instruction of their children,
ought to inform their masters and tutors that shall teach them, to what
vices and virtues their children are most inclined: and this ought to be, to
encourage them in that that is good, and contrary to reprove them in all that
is evil. For men are undone for no other cause when they be old: but for that
they had so much pleasures when they are young. Sextus Cheronensis in the
second book of the sayings of the auntientes says, that on a day a
citezen of Athens was byenge things in the market, and for the quality of his
person, the greatest part of them were superfluous and nothing necessary. And
in this case the poor are no less culpable then the rich: and the rich then
the poor. For that is so little, that to sustain man's life is necessary: that
he which has lest, has thereunto superfluous. Therefore at that time, when
Athens and her common wealth was the lantern of all Greece, there was in Athens
a law long used, and of great time accustomed: that nothing should be bought
before a philosopher had set the price. And truly the law was good, and would
to God the same law at this present were observed: for there is nothing that
destroys a common wealth more, then to permit some to sell as tyrauntes,
and others to buy as fools. When the Thebane was buying these things, a
philosopher was there present, who said unto him these words. Tell me I pray
thee, thou man of Thebes, wherefore do thou consume and waste thy money, in
that which is not necessary for thy house, nor profitable for thy person? the
Thebane answered him. I let the know, that I do buy all these things for a
son I have of the age of.xx. years, the which never did thing that seamed
unto me evil, nor I never denayed him any thing that he demanded. This
philosopher answered. O how happy were thou, if as thou art a father, thou
were a son, and that which the father says unto the son, the son would
say unto the father: but I am offended greatly with that thou have told me.
For until the child be.xxv. years old, he ought not to gaynesaye his
father: and the good father ought not to condescende unto the appetites of the
son. Now I call the cursed father, since thou art subject to the will of
thy son: and that thy son is not obedient to the will of his father, so that
thou alterest the order of nature. For so much as the father is son of his
son, and the son is father of his father. But in the end, I swear unto
thee by the immortal Gods, that when thou shall become old, thou shall weape
by thy self at that which with thy son thou did laughe when he was
young. Though the words of this philosopher were few: yet a wise man will
judge the sentences to be many. I conclude therefore, that princes and great
lords ought to reco^mende their children to their masters, to the end they may
teach them to change their appetites, and not to follow their own will: so
that they withdraw them from their own will, and cause them to learn the advice of an other. For the more a man gives a noble man son the bridle, the
more harder it is for them to receive good doctrine.

Princes ought to take heed that their children be not brought up in vain
pleasures and delights. For oftetimes they are so wicked, that the fathers
would not only have them with sharp discipline corrected: but also with bitter
tears buried. Chap. xxxiii.
BY experience we see, that in war (for the defense of men) rampires and
fortes are made according to the quality of the enemies, and those which sail
the dangerous seas, do chose great ships, which may break the waves of
the raging Sea: so that all wise men according to the quality of the danger,
do seek for the same in time some remedy. Oftetymes I muse with my self, and
think if I could find any estate, any age, any land, any nation, any
realm, or any world, wherein there has been any man that has passed this
life, without tasting, what adversity was: for if such a one were found, I
think it should be a monstrous thing throughout all the earth, and by reason
both the dead and living should envy him. In the end, after my count made, I
find that he which yesterdaye was rich, to day is poor: he that was hole,
I see him to day sick: he that yesterdaye laughed, to day I see him weep: he
that had his hearts ease, I see him now sore afflicted: he that was fortunate,
I see him unlucky: finally, him whom we knew alive in the town, now we see
buried in the grave. And to be buried is nothing else, but to be utterly
forgotten: for man's frendshyp is so frail, that when the corpse is covered with
earth, immediately the dead is forgotten. One thing me thinks to all men is
grievous, and to those of understanding no less payneful, which is, that the
miseries of this wicked world are not equally divided, but that oftetymes all
worldly calamities lies in the neck of one man alone. For we are so
unfortunate, that the world gives us pleasures in sight, and troubles in
proof. If a man should ask a sage man now a days, who has lived in mean
estate, and that he would be contented to tell him what he has paste, since
three years that he began to speak, until fifty years that he began to wax
old: what things think you he would tell us, that has chanced unto him?
truly al these that here follow The grefes of his children, the assaults of
his enemies, the importunities of his wife, the wantonness of his daughters,
sickness in his person, great loss of goods, general famine in the city, cruel
plagues in his country, extreme cold in winter, noisome heat in summer,
sorrowful deaths of his friends, and envious prosperities of his enemies:
finally he will say, that he passed such and so many things, that oftimes he
bewailed the woeful life, and desired the sweet death. If the miserable man
has passed such things outwardly, what would he say of those which he has
suffered inwardly? the which though some discrete men may know, yet truly
others dare not tell. For the travails which the body passes in fifty years,
may well be counted in a day: but that which the heart suffers in one day,
cannot be counted in a hundred years. A man cannot denay, but that we would
count him rash, which with a read would mete an other that has a sword: and
him for a fool, that would put of his shoes to walk upon the thorns. But
without comparison we ought to esteame him for the most fool, that with this
tender flesh thinks to prevail against so many evil fortunes: for without
doubt, the man that is of his body delicate, passes his life with much pain.
O how happy may that man be called, which never tasted what pleasure means.
For men which from their infancy have been brought up in pleasures, for want
of wisdom know not how to chose the good, and for lack of force cannot resist
the evil: which is ye cause, that noble men's children ofttimes commit sondrye
heinous offenses. For it is an infallible rule, that the more a man gives him
self to pleasures, the more he is entangled in vices. It is a thing worthy to
be noted, and woeful to see, how politic we be to augmente things of honor,
how bold we be to enterprise them, how fortunate to compass them, how diligent
to keep them, how circumspect to sustain them, and afterward what pity is it
to see, how unfortunate we are to lose all that, which so long time we have
searched for, kept, and possessed. And that which is most to be lamented in
this case is, that the goods and honor are not lost for want of diligence
and travail of the father: but for the abundance of pleasures, and vices of
the son. Finallye let the rich man know, that that which he has won in
labor and toil waking: his son (being evil brought up) shall consume in
pleasures sleaping. One of the greatest vanities that reigns at this day
among the children of vanity is, that the father can not show unto his son
the love which he bears him, but in suffering him to be brought up in the
pleasures and vanities of this life. Truly he that is such a one, ought not to
be called a pitiful father, but a cruel stepfather: for no man will deny me
this, but that where there is youth, liberty, pleasure, and money, there will
all the vices of this world be resident. Lycurgus the great king, geuer of
laws, and sage philosopher, ordained to the Lacedaemonians, that all the
children which were borne in cities, and good towns, should be sent to bring
up in villages till they were.xxv. years of age. As Liuius says that the
Lygures were, which in old time were confederate with those of Capua, and
great enemies to the people of Rome. They had a law amongst them, that none
should take wages in the wars, unless he had been brought up in the fields,
or that he had been a heard man in the mountains: so that through one of these
two ways, their flesh was hardened, their joints accustomed to suffer the
heat and the cold, and their bodies more mete to endure the trauayles of the
wars. In the year of the foundation of Rome, a hundred and forty, the
Romans made cruel wars with the Lygures, against whom was sent Gneus
Fabritius, of the which in the end he triumphed: and the day following this
triumph, he spoke unto the Senate these words. Worthy Senators I have been
these five years against the Ligures, and by the immortal gods I swear unto
you, that in all this time there passed not one weke, but we had either
battle, or some perilous skermiche. And that which a man ought most to
marvel at is, that I never perceived any fear or cowardlynes to be in those
barbarous people, whereby they were constrained to demand peace of the people
of Rome. These Lygures pursued with such fearcenes the wars, that oftetimes
they took away from us all hope to win the victory: for between armies, the
great might of the one, does put always the others in fear. And I will tell
you (fathers conscript) their brynging up, to the end the Roman youth should
take hereby example. When they are young, they are put to be shepeheardes
because they should accustom their flesh in the mountains to endure
travail: by the which custom they are so much masters of them selves (the
country being always full of snow and Ise in the winter, and also noisome
through the extreme heat in the So^mer that I swear by ye god Apollo, in all
this time of five years, of those we have not seen one prease to the fire in ye
winter, nor covet the shadow in ye summer. Do not ye think worthy Senators,
that I was willing to declare unto you these things in the Senate, for any
desire I have that you should esteame any thing the more my triumph: but I do
tell it you to this end, that you may have an eye, and take head to your men
of war, to the end they may always be occupied, and that you suffer them
not to be idle. For it is more perilous for the Roman armies, to be overcome
with vices: then to be disconfited with their enemies. And to talk of these
matters more at large, me thinks they should provide and command, that
rich men should not be so hardy to bring up their children to delicatly: for
in the end, it is impossible that the delicate person should win with his
hands, the honor of many victories. That which moved me to say so much as I
have said (worthy Senators) is to the end you may know, that the Ligures were
not overcome by the power of Rome: but because fortune was against them. And
since in nothing fortune shows her self so variable, as in the things of
war: me thinks that though the Ligures are now vanquished and overcome,
yet notwithstanding you ought to entertain them in love, and to take them for
your confederates. For it is not good council, to hazard that into the hands
of fortune, which a man may compass by friendship. The author of this which
is spoken, is called Iunius Pratus, in the book of the concord of Realms,
and he says in that place, that this captain Gneus Fabritius, was counted no
less sage for that he spoke: then esteamed valiaunte for that he did. In the
old time, those of the Isles Balleares (which now are called Maiorque, and
Minorque) though they were not counted wise: yet at the least in bringing up
their children, they showed them selves not negligent. Because they were
brought up in hardness in their youth, and could not endure all painful
exercises of the wars. Those of Carthage gave five prisoners of Rome, for one
sclaue of Maiorque. Diodorus Siculus says, in those Isles, the mother did not
give the children bread with their own hands: but they did put it on an high
pole, so that they might see the bread with their eyes, but they could not
reach it with their hands. Wherefore when they would eat, they should
first with hurling of stones, or slinges win it, or else fast. Though the
work were of children: yet the invention came of a high wit. And hereof it
came that the Balleares were esteamed for valiant me^, as well in wrestling,
as in slinges for to hurl: for they did hurl with a slinge to hit a white, as
the Lygures shoot now in a cross bow to hitte the prick. Those of great
Britayne, which now we call England, amongst all the Barbarous, were men
most barbarous: but you ought to know, that within the space of few years,
the Romans were vanquished of them many times. For time in all things
brings such change and alteration, that those which once we knew great
lords: within a while after we have seen them sclaues. Herodian in his hystory
of Seuerus Emperor of Rome says, that an Ambassador of Britayne being one
day in Rome (as by chance they gave him a froward answer in the Senate)
spoke stoutely before them all, and said these words. I am sorry you will not
accept peace, nor grant truce: the which thing shall be for the greater
justification of our wars. For afterward none can take, but that which
fortune shall give. For in the end the delicate flesh of Rome shall feel, if
ye bloody swords of Britayne will cut. The English history says, and it is
true, that though the country be very cold, and that the water freseth often:
yet the women had a custom to carry their children where the water was frosen,
and breaking the Ise with a stone, with the same Ise they used to rub the
body of the infant, to the end to harden their flesh, and to make them more
apt er to endure travails. And without doubt they had reason, for I wyshe no
greater penitence to delicate men, then in the winter to see them without fire:
and in the Summer to want fresh shadow. Since this was the custom of the
Britayns, it is but reason we credit Julius Caesar in that he says in his
comentaries, that is to wete, that he passed many dangers before he could
overcome them: for they with as little fear did hyde them selves, and dyued
under the cold water, as a very man would have rested him self in a pleasant
shadow. As Lucanus and Appianus Alexandrinus say, amongst other nations
which came to succor the great Pompei in Pharsalia, were the Messagetes, the
which (as they say) in their youth did suck no other, but the milk of Camels:
and eat bread of Acornes. These barbarous did these things to the end to
harden their bodies, to be able to endure trauail, and to have their legs
lighter for to ro^ne. In this case we can not call them barbarous, but we ought
to call them men of good understanding: for it is impossible for the man that
eats much, to run fast. Viriatus (a Spanyarde) was king of the Lusytaines,
and a great enemy of the Romans, who was so aduenterous in the war, and so
valiant in his person, that the Romans (by the experience of his deeds)
found him invincible. For in the space of.xiii. years they could never have any
victory of him: the which when they saw, they determined to poison him, and
did so in deed. At whose death they more reioysed, then if they had won the
signorie of all Lusitanie. For if Viriatus had not died, they had never brought
the Lusitaines under their subjection. Iunius Rusticus in his epitomie says,
that this Viriatus in his youth was a herd man, and kept cattle by the river
of Guadiana, and after that he waxed older, used to rob, and assault men by
the high ways. And after that he was.xl. years of age, he became king of the
Lusitaines, and not by force, but by election. For when the people saw them
selves enuirouned and assaulted on every side with enemies: they chose rather
stout, strong, and hardy men for their captains, then noble men for their
guydes. If the ancient hystoriographers deceive me not, when Viriatus was a
thief, he led with him always at the least a hundred thieves: the which were
shodde with leaden shoes, so that when they were enforced to run, they put of
their shoes. And thus although all the day they went with leaden shoes, yet
in the night they ran like swyfte buckes: for it is a general rule, that the
loser the joints are, the more swifter shall the legs be to run. In the
book of the iestes of the Lumbardes, Paulus Diaconus says, that in the old
time those of Capua had a law, that until the children were married, the
fathers should give them no bed to sleep on, nor permit them to sit at the
table to eat: but that they should eat their meats in their hands, and take
their rest on the ground. And truly it was a commendable law, for rest was
never invented for the young man which has no bearde: but for the aged,
being lame, impotent, and crooked. Quintus Cincinatus was second Dictator of
Rome, and in deed for his deserts was the first emperor of the earth. This
excellent man was brought up in so great travail, that his hands were found
