thing I say, and not without tears in this senate, openly I do declare it,
which is, that with the tongue every man prayseth virtue: and yet they them
selves with all their lymmes are servants unto vices. Do not think that I say
this only for the Romans which be in Illiria: but for the Senators which I
se here in the Senate. Al you Romans, in your deuyses about your arms, have
this for your word. Romanorum est debellare superbos, and parcere subiectis.
Truly you should better have said: Romanorum, est spoliare innocents, and
reddere subiectos. For you Romans are but destroyers of the people that be
peaceable: and robbers of the swette and labors of strangers.

The vyllayne argues against the Romans, which without cause or reason
conquered their countreye, and proved manifestlye that theye thoroughe
offending of their gods, were vanquished of the Romans. Cap. iiii.
I Ask ye Romans what occasion ye have, that are brought up nigh to the
river of Tyber, against us that live in peace, nigh to the river of Danuby.
Peradventure ye have seen us friends to your foes, or else we have showed our
selves your enemies? peradventure you have hard say, that forsaking our own
land, we should go conquer foreign realms? peradventure ye have been
advertised, yt we rebelling against our own lords, should become obedient to
the crewell barbarous? peradventure ye have sent us some imbassadour to desire
us to be your friends: or else there came some from us to rome, to defye ye as
our enemies? peradventure some king died in our realm, which by his testament
made ye heirs to our realm? whereby you claim your title, and seek to make us
your subjects? peradventure by some ancient law or custom ye have found,
yt the noble and worthy Germany, of necessitye is subject to the proud people
of Rome? peradventure we have destroyed your armies, we have wasted your
fields, sacked your cities, spoiled your subjects, or favored your enemies?
so yt to revenge these injuries ye should destroy our la^d? if we had been your
neighbors, or you ours, it had been no marvel though one should have destroyed
the other. For it chau^seth oftentimes, yt through controversy of a little piece
of ground, tedious wars between people arise. Of a troth none of all these
things which I have named, has chaunsed between ye Romans and us Germans.
For in Germany we felt your tyranny, so sone as we hard of your renown. If
ye be grieved with that I have said, I pray you be not offended with that I
will say, which is: that ye name of Romans, and the cruelty of tyrants,
arrived together in one day upon our people. And what more to say, I know not
Romans, of the little care the gods do take, and of the great audacitie yt
me^ have. For I see yt he which possesses much does oppress him which has
but little: and he that has but little, waieth not him yt has much. So
disordered covetousness strives with secret malice, and secret malice gives
place to open theft, and open robbery no man resists, and thereof comes, yt
the couetice of a malicious man is accomplished, to the prejudice of a whole
state. Harken ye romans, harken, and by the immortal gods I do conjure you,
give ear to that I will say, which is, consider well what you have do^^ for the
gods words be in vain, or else men must have an end, the world in time must
needs fall, or else the world shall be no world. Fortune must needs make sure the
pin of the whele, or else yt shall be seen which never was seen, which is: that
which in.8. years ye have won, ye shall withein.8. days lose. For nothing
can be more just, since ye by force have made your selves tirants: then yt the
gods by justice should make ye slaves. And do not think ye romans though you
have subdued Germany, and be lords thereof, that it was by any warrely
industrye: for ye are no more warlike, no more coragious, nor more hardy, ne
yet more valiau^t the^ we Germans, but sins through our offenses we have
provoked ye gods to wrath, they for ye punishment of our disordinate vices
ordained, yt ye should be a cruel plague and scourge to our persons. Do not
take your selves to be strong, neither repute us to be so weak, yt if the gods
at yt time had favored ye one part, as much as ye other: it might perchance
have happened, ye should not have enioied the spoil. For to say the truth, ye
wan not the victory through ye force of weapons, yt you brought from Rome: but
through the infynyte vices, which ye found in Germany. Therefore since we
wear not overcome for being cowards, neither for being weak, nor yet for
being fearful, but only for being wicked, and not having the gods favorable
unto us: what hope ye Romans to become of you, being as you are vicious, and
having ye gods angry with you? Do not think Romans to be the more victorious,
for yt ye assemble great armies, or yt ye abound in treasures, neither for yt
you have greater gods in your aid, or that ye build greater temples, nor yet
for that ye offer such great sacrifices. For I let you know, if ye do not know
it, yt no man is in more favor with the gods, than he which is at peace with
virtue. If ye triumphs of ye conquerours consists in nothing else but in
subtle wits, politic captains, valiant soldiers, and great armies: without
doubt it would little avail to carry all this to the war, sins afterward we se
by experience, yt men can do no more but give the battles, and the gods the^
selves must give the victories. If I be not deceived, I think that for our
offenses we have sufficientlye satisfied the gods wrath. But truly I believe
that the cruelties which ye have done unto us, and the vnthankefullnesse which
you have showed the gods (though as yet ye have not paid it) that once ye
shall pay it. And hereafter it may chance, that as presentlye ye count us for
slaves: so in time to come ye shall acknowledge us for lords. Since the
trauaylynge by the way, I have seen the high mountains, diverse provinces,
sundry nations, countries so savage, people so barbarous, such and so many
miles as Germany is distaunt from Room, I muse what fond toye came in the
Romans heads: to send to conquer Germany. If covetousness of treasures
caused it, I am sure they spent more money to conquer it, and at this present
do spend to keep it, then the whole revenues of Germany amountethe, or may
amount in many years: and perchance theye may lose it, before they recover
that they spent to conquer it. And if ye say unto me Romans that Germany is
not conquered of Rome for ever, but that only Rome should have the glory to
be mistres of Germanye, this also I say is vanitye and follye. For little
avails it to have the forts and castles of the people: when the hearts of the
inhabitauntes are absente. If ye say that therefore ye conquered Germany, to
amplify and enlarge the limittes and bounds of Rome, also me thinkethe this
as foolish an enterprise. For it is not the point of wise and valiant men to
enlarge their dominyons: and diminishe their honor. If ye say ye sent to
conquer us, to the end we should not be barbarous, nor live like tirauntes,
but that you would we should live after your good laws and customs, if it
be so I am well content. But how is it possible ye should give laws to
strangers, when you break ye laws of your own predecessors? great shame ought
they to have, which take upon the^ to correct others, when they have more need
to be corrected the^ selfs. For the blind man ought not to take upon him to
lead the lame. If this be true (as presently it is) what reason or occasion
had proud Rome, to take and conquer the innocent Germanye? Let us all go
therefore to rob, to kill, to conquer, and to spoil, sins we see the world
so corrupt, and so far from the love of god, that every man (as we may
perceive) takes what he ca^, kylleth whom he will, and that which worst of
all is, that neither those which govern will remedy so many evils as are
committed, neither those which are offended dare complain. Ye chief judges at
this day are so hard to be entreated, ye take so little regard unto the poor
oppressed: yt they think it more quiet to remain in trouble at home, then to
come and put up their complaints before you here at Rome. And the cause
hereof is, that there in their country theye have but one which pursues
the^: and here in this senate theye are evil willed of al, and that is, because
he which complains is poor, and the other which is complained on is rich.
Therefore since fortune would it, and the fatal destinies permit it that the
proud Rome should be mistress of our Germanye, it is but reason ye should
keep us in justice, and maintain us in peace. But you do not so, but rather
those which come thither do take from us our goods, and ye yt are here do rob
us of our good name, saying, yt since we are a people without law, without
reason, and without a king (as unknown barbarous) ye may take us for slaves.
In this case ye Romans are greatly deceived, for me thinks with reason ye can
not call us without reason, since we being such as we are, and as the gods created
us, remain in our proper countries, without desiring to seek or invade
foreine realms. For with more reason we might say, that ye were men without
reason, being not contented with the sweet and fertyle Italye: but that
through shedynge of blood you should desire to conquer all the earth. In yt
ye say we deserve to be slaves, because we have no prince to command us, nor
senate to govern us, nor army to defend us, to this I will answer. That since
we had no enemies, we neded no armies, and since every man is contented with his
lotte and fortune, we had no necessity of a proud senate to govern us, and
we being as we are all equal, it need not we should co^se^t to have any
princes amongst us. For the office of princes is to suppress tyrants, and to
maintain ye people in peace. If ye say further yt we have not in our country
a common wealth, nor policy, but that we live as ye brute bests in ye
mountains, in this also you have but small reason. For we in our country did
suffer noe liars, neither rebels, nor sedicious persons, nor me^ yt brought us
(from strange countries) any apparaile for to be vicious, so yt sith in
apparaile we were honest, and in meat very te^perate, we neded no better
behavior. For although in our country there are noe merchands of Carthage,
oil of Mauritania, marcha^ts of Tire, Steel, of Ca^tabrie, odours of Asia,
gold of Spaigne, silver of Britain, Amber of Sidonie, silk of Damasco, corn
of Scicill, wine of Candy, purple of Arabye: yet for all this we are not
brutishe, neither cease to have a common wealth. For these and such other like
things, give more occasion to stir up many vices: the^ for verteous me^ to live
according to virtue. Blessed, and happy is yt commonwealth, not where great
riches abu^deth, but where virtues are highly co^me^did: not where many light
and angry me^ resort, but where ye pacie^t are reside^t: therefore it follows,
yt of yt co^mo^welth of Rome for being rich, we should have pity: and of ye
common wealth of Germany for being poor, ye ought to have envy. Would to god
that ye conte^tacion we have with our poverty, ye others had ye same with your
riches. For then neither ye had robbed us of our countries, nor we had not
comen hither now to complain in Rome of your tyra^nye. I se romans, that ye
one differs much from the other. For ye others, though ye hear our
opressions, yet thereby ye loase not your pastime but we others can never dry
the tears of our eyes, nor cease to bewail our infinite misfortunes.

The villain concludethe his oration against the judges, which minister not
justice, and declarethe how prejudicial such wicked men are unto the publyke
weal. Cap. v.
YE would think I have said all that I can say, but certainly it is not so.
For there remains many things to speak, which to hear ye will be astonished,
yet be ye assured, that to speak then I will not be afraid, since you others in
doing the^ are not ashamed. For an open offense, deserves not secret
correction. I marvel much at ye Romans, what ye meaned to send us (as you
did) such ignorant judges, ye which by the imortal gods I swear, can neither
declare us your laws, and much less they can understand ours. And ye cause of
all this evil is, yt ye sent not those which be best able to minister to us
justice in Germany, but those which have best frindes with you in Rome:
presuppose yt to those of ye senate, ye give ye office of censourship, more for
importunity, the^ for ability. It is little yt I can say here, in respect they
dare do there. That which ye co^mau^d the^ here, I know not but of yt which
they do there, I am not ignorant, which is. Your judges take all bribes yt are
brought unto the^ openly: and they powle and shave as much as they can
secretly. They grievously punish ye offenses of ye poor, and disse^ble with the
faults of ye rich: they co^se^t to many evils, to have occasion to commit
greater theftes: they forget ye government of the people to take their
pleasure in vice. And being there to mitigate sclaunders, theye are those which
are most sclaunderous: and without goods it auailethe no man to ask justice. And
finally under the color yt they be judges of Rome, they fear not to rob all
the la^d of Germany. What meanethe this ye Romans, shall your pride never
have end in co^ma^ding, nor your couetice in robbing? Say unto us what ye will
in words, but oppres us not so in deeds. If you do it for our children, load
the^ with yro^s and make the^ slaves. For ye ca^ not charge the^ with more the^
they are able to carry but of co^ma^deme^ts and tributs ye give us more the^ we
are either able to carye, or suffer. If you do it for our goods, go thither
and take the^ all. For in our country we do not use as ye Romans do, nor
have such co^dicions as ye have here in Rome. For you desire to live poor,
because ye desire to dye rich. If ye say yt we will rebel, I marvel what you
should mean to think so, since ye have spoiled us, robbed us, and handled us
ill. Assure me ye Romans, yt ye will not unpeople us: and I will assure you we
will not rebel. If our service do not contentye, strike of our heads as to evil
men. For (to tell ye the truth) ye knife shall not be so fearful to our necks,
as your tiranies be abhorred in our hearts. Do ye know what you have done, ye
Romans, ye have caused us of ye miserable realm to swear, never to dwell with
our wives, and to sley our own children, rather then to leave them in the
hands of so wicked and cruel tirants as ye be. For we had rather they should
dye in liberty, the^ live in bondage. As desperate me^ we have determined to
suffer, and e^dure ye beastly mocio^s of ye flesh, during ye time we have to
live, to ye end we will not get our wives with child. For we had rather live
chaste.20. or.30. years, the^ to leave our children perpetual slaves If it be
true yt ye children must endure, yt which ye miserable fathers do suffer? It is
not only good to sley the^, but also it should be better not to agree they
should be borne. Ye ought not to do this Romans, for ye la^d taken by force,
ought ye better to be governed, to ye intent yt ye miserable captives seeing
justice duly administered presently, should thereby forget ye tira^ny passed,
and co^te^t themselves with perpetual servitude. And sith it is true, yt we are
come to co^plain of ye oppressions which your officers do here upon ye river of
Danuby, peradventure ye which are of ye se not will here us, and though you are
now determined to here us, yet ye are slow to remedy us: so yt before ye begin
to refourme an evil custom, ye whole common wealth is all ready undone. I will tell
ye of some things thereof, to the intent you may know the^, and then to refourm
the^. If there come a right poor man to demand justice, having no money to
give, nor wine to present, nor oil to promise, nor frindes to help him, nor
reuenew to succor him, and maynteine him in expe^ces: after he has complained
they satisfy him with words, saying unto him yt spedely he shall have justice.
What will ye I should say, but yt in the mean time they make him spend that
little he has, and give hi^ nothing though he demand much, they give him vain
hope, and they make him wast ye best of his life, every one of the^ does
promise his favor, and afterward they al lay hands upon him to oppress
him. The most of the^ say his right is good, and afterward they give sentence
against him: so that the miserable person which came to complain of one,
returns home complaining of all, cursing his cruel destenies, and criynge
out to the just and merciful gods for reuengement. It chaunseth also, that
often times there comes to complain hear in the Senate, some flattering man
more for malice, then by reason of right, or justice: and ye Senators
crediting his double words, and his fained tears, immediatlye ordein a Ce^sor
to go and give audience on their complaints. Who being go^ne, and returned, ye
seek more to remedy and give ear to the complaints of ye Judge: the^ to the
sclaunders which were among the people. I will declare unto you mye life, O ye
Romans, and thereby ye shall se how they pass their life in my country. I
live by gathering akornes in the winter, and reapinge corn in ye su^mer, some
time I fish as well of necessity, as of pleasure, so that I pass allmoste al
my life alone in the fields, or in the mountains. And if you wot not why,
hear me, and I will show you. I se such tirranny in your judges, and such
robberies as they commit among the poor people, and there are such disse^tions
in that realm, such injuries committed therein, ye poor common wealth is so
spoiled, there are so few that have desire to do good, and also there are so
few that hope for remedy in ye senate: yt I am determined (as most unhappy) to
ba^nishe my self out of mine own house, and to separate my self from my
sweet company, to the end my eyes should not behold so miserable a change. For
I had rather wander solitary in the fields, then to see my neighbors hourly
lament in ye streets. For there the cruel beasts do not offend me, unless I
do assault the^: but ye cursed men, though I do serve them, yet daily they vex
me. Without doubt it is a marvelous pain to suffer an overthrow of fortune:
but it is a greater torment when one felethe it without remedy. And yet
witheoute comparison my greatest grief is, when my loss may be remedied, and
yt he which may, will not: and he yt will, can not by any means remedy it. O
cruel Romans, ye feel nothing yt we feel, inespecially I which speak it, ye
shall se how I feel it, since only to reduce it to memory my eyes do dasell, my
tongue will wax weary, my iointes do sever, my heart does tremble, my entrails
do break, and my flesh consumes, what a woeful thing is it, in my country to
se it with my eyes, to hear it with my ears, and to feel it with mine own
hands? Truly the griefs which ye woeful Germany suffers are such, and so
many: that I believe yet ye mercyful gods will have compassion upon us. I will
not desire ye to think sclander of my words: but only I do beseech ye, you will
understand well what I say. For you ymagining (as you do presume to be
discrete) shall see right well that the troubles which came to us from men, and
among men, with men, and by the hands of men: it is a small mattery we as men
do feel them speaking. For according to the truth, and also with liberty, if I
should declare every other just advertisement which came from the senate, and
all the tyranny which your judges commit in the miserable realm, one of
these.2. things must ensue, either the punishment of me, or ye depriuacion of
your officers if I say true. One thing only comfort me, or whereof I with
other unfortunate people have had experience, in that I think my self happy,
to know that the just plagues proceed not from the just gods, but through ye
just deserts of wicked men: And that our secret fault does waken those, to the
end that they of us may execute open justice. Of one thing only I am sore
troubled, because the gods can not be contented, but for a small fault, they
punish a good man much: and for many faults, they punish evil men nothing at
all, so that the gods do bear with the one, and forgive nothing unto the
other. O secret judgments of god, that as I am bound to praise your works, so
likewise if I had license to condemn them, I durst say, yt ye cause us to
suffer grievous pains, for that ye punish and persecute us by the hands of such
judges, the which (if justice took place in the world) when they chastise us
with their hands, they do not deserve to have their heads on their shoulders.
The cause why now again I do exclame on ye immortal gods, is to se, that in
these 15. days I have been at Rome, I have seen such deeds done in your senate
yt if the least of them had been done at Danuby, the gallows and gibbets had been
hanged thicker of thieves, then the vyneyard is with grapes. I am determined to
see your doings, to speak of your dishonesty in apparel, your little
tempera^ce in eating, and your disorder in affairs, and your pleasures in
living: and on ye other side, I see that when your provision arriueth in our
country, we carry into the temples, and offer it to the gods, we put it on
their heads: so that the one meting with the other, we accomplish that which is
commanded, and accurse those that commanded. And since therefore my heart has
now seen, that which it desires, my mind is at rest, in spitting out the
poison which in it abides. If I have in any thing here offended with my
tongue, I am ready to make recompense with my head. For in good faith I had
rather win honor, in offering my self to death: then ye should have it, in
taking from me my life. And here the villayne ended his talk, immediatlye
after Mar. Aur. said to those which were about him. How think ye my frindes,
what kernel of a nut, what gold of the mine, what corn of straw, what rose
of briars, what mary of bones, and how noble and valiant a man has he showed
him self? What reasons so hye, what words so well couched, what truth so true,
what sentences so well pronounced, and also what open malice has he
discovered? By the faith of a good man I swear, as I may be delivered from
this fever which I have: I saw this villain standing boldly a whole hour on
his feet, and al we beholdinge the earth as amazed, could not answer him
one word. For in deed this villain confuted us with his purpose, and astonished
us, to se the little regard he had of his life. The senate afterward, being
al agreed, the next day following we provided new judges for the river of
Danuby, and commanded the villain to deliver us by writing, all that he had
said by mouth, to the end it might be registered in ye book of good saying of
strangers, which were in the senate. And further it was agreed, yt the said
villain (for the wise words he spoke) should be chosen senator, and of the
free men of Rome he should be one: and that for ever he should be sustained with
the common treasour. For our mother Rome has always been praised and esteemed,
not only to acquit the services which has been done unto her: but also the
good words, which were spoken in the Senate.

That princes and noble men ought to be very circumspect in chosinge judges
and officers, for therein consistethe the profit of the public weal, Cap. vi.
ALexander the great (as the historiographers say) in his youth used hu^ting
very much specially of the mountains: and that which is to be marueiled at, he
would not hunt Dear, goats, hares, nor partriges: but Tigers, Lyberdes,
elephants, cocodrilles, and Lions. So that this mighty prince did not only
show the excellency of his courage, in conqueringe proud princes: but also in
chasing of cruel, and savage beasts. Plutarche in his Apothegmes saiethe: that
the great Alexander had a familiar servant, named Crotherus, to whom often
times he spoke these words. I let the to know Crotherus, that the valya^t
princes ought not only to be upright in their realms which they govern: but
also to be circumspect in pastimes which they use, that the authority which
in the one they have won, in the other they do not lose. When Alexander spoke
these words truly he was of more authority then of years: But in the end
he gave this example, more to be followed, and commanded, then to be reproved or
blamed I say to be followed, not in the huntinge that he exercysed: but in the
great courage which he showed. To the Plebeyans and men of base condition, it
is a little thing yt in one matter they show their might, and in other things
their small power is known: but to princes and great lords it is a
discommendable thing, that in earnest matters any man should accuse them of
pride, and in things of sport, they should count them for light. For the noble
and valiant Prince, in things of importance, ought to show great wisdom,
and in mean things, great stoutnes. The case was such, yt Alexander ye great,
hunting on the wild mountains, by chance met with a cruel Lion, and as the
good Prince would wyn his honor with the Lion, and also the Lion preserve his
own life, they were in griepes the one of the other so fast, that both fell
to the earth, where they striued almost half an hour, but in the end the
lion remained there dead, and the hardye Alexander escaped all bloudye. This
hunting of Alexander and the Lion thoroughe all Greece, was greatly renowned.
I say greatly renowned, because ye grauers and painters drew a pourtrait
forthwith in stone work, of this huntinge, and the grauers hereof were
Lisippus, and Leocarcus, marvelous grauers of anuk works, which they made of
metal, where they lively set forth Alexander and the Lion fighting, and also
a familiar servant of his named Crotherus, being among ye dogs beholding
the^. So that the work seemed not only to represent an ancient thing but that
ye Lion, Alexander, Crotherus, and the dogs, seemed also to be alive in the
same chase. When Alexander fought with the Lion, there came an Embassatour from
Sparthes to Macedonia, who spoke to Alexander these words. Would to god
(immortal prince) that ye force you have used with the Lion, in the mountain,
you had employed against some prince, for to be Lord of the earth. By the
words of the Embassatour, and the deeds of Alexander, may easily by gathered,
that as it is comely for Princes to be honest, valiant, and stout: so to the
contrary it is unseemly for them to be bold, and rash. For though princes of
their goods be lyberall, yet of their life they ought not to be prodigal.
The divine Plato, in the tenth book of his laws says, that ye.2. renowned
Philosophers of Thebes, whose names were Adon, and Clinias fell at variaunce
with them selves, to know in what thing the prince is bound to adventure his
life, Clinias said, that he ought to dye for any thing touching his honor.
Adon said the contrary. That he should not hazard his life, unless it were
for matters touching the affairs of the common wealth. Plato says, those.2.
philosophers had reason in yt they said: but admit that occasion to dye
should be offered the prince, for ye one, or the other: he ought rather to dye
for that thing touching justice, then for the thing touching his honor. For
there is no great difference, to dye more for the one, then for the other.
Applying yt we have spoken, to that we will speak, I say, that we do not
desire, nor we will not, that princes and great lords do destroy them selves
with Lions in the chase, neither adventure their persons in the wars, nor
that they put their lives in peril for the common weal: but we only require
them, that they take some pains and care to provide for things belonging to
justice. For it is a more natural hunting for princes, to hunt out the vicious
of their commonweals: then for to hunt the wild bores, in ye thick woods.
To the end princes accomplish this which we have spoken, we will not ask them
time when they ought to eat, sleep, hunt, sport and recreate the^ selves: but
that of the four and twenty hours that be in the day and night theye take
it for a pleasure and commodity one hour to talk of justice. The government
of the commonweal consists not, in that they should travail until they
sweat, and molest their bodies, shed their blood, shorten their lives, and
lose their pastimes: but all consistethe, in that they should be dylygent to
forsee the domages of their common wealth, and likewise to provide for good
mynysters of justice. We do not demand Princes and great lords, to give us
their goods, nor we forbydde them not to eat, to forsake sleep, to sport,
to hunte, nor to put their lives in danger: but we desire and beseech
them, that theye provide good mynysters of justice for the common wealth.

First they ought to be very dyligente to search them out, and afterward to
be more circu^spect to examine the^: for if we sighe with tears to have good
Princes, we ought much more to pray that we have not evil officers. What
profytethe it the knighte to be nimble, and if the horse be not ready? what
avails it ye owner of ye ship to be sage, and expert, if the Pilot be a fool
and ignorant? What profits the king to be valiant and stout, and the
Captain of the war to be a cowarde? I mean by this I have spoken, what
profits it a Prince to be honest, if those which minister justice be
dissolute? What profits it us yt (...) prince be true, if his officers
beliers? What profits it us yt the prince be sober, if his ministers be
dronkerds? What profits it yt ye prince be gentle, and loving, if his
officers be cruel, and malicious? What profits it us, that ye prince be a
geuer, liberal, and an alms man, if the judge yt ministers justice, be a
bryber, and an open thief? What profits it yt the prince be careful, and
virtuous, if the judge be negligent and vicious? finally I say, that it little
avails that ye prince in his house be secretly just, if adjoining to that, he
trust a tiraunt and open these with the government of the common weal.
Princes and great Lords when they are within their palaces at pleasure,
their minds occupied in high things, do not receive into their secreat
company, but their entier frindes. Another time they will not, but occupy them
selves in pastimes and pleasure: so yt they know not what they have to amend in
their persons, and much less yt which they ought to remedy in their commonweals. I will not be so eger in reproving, neither so satirycal in writing, yt
it should seem I would persuade Princes, that theye live not according to the
highness of their estates: but according to the life of the religious. For
if theye will keep them selves from being tyrauntes, or being outragiouslye
vicious: we cannot denay them some times to take their pleasures. But mye
intention is not, so strayghtelye to command Princes to be just: but only
to show them how theye are bound to do justice. Common wealths are not
lost, for that their Princes live in pleasure: but because they have little
care of justice. In the end people do not murmr when the Prince does
recreat his person: but when he is to slack to cause justice to be executed. I
would to GOD, that Princes took an account with godde, in the things of
their conscience, touching the common wealth: as theye do with men,
touching their rentes and revenues. Plutarche in an Epistle he wrate to
Traiayne the Emperor, sayethe: it pleasethe me very well, most puissaunte
Prince, that the Prince be such one, as all may say that in him there is
nothing worthy of reprehension: butte adding thereunto, it dyspleasethe me
much more that he should have so evil judges, that all should say, in them
were nothing worthy of commendacion. For the faults of Princes very well
may be excused: butte the offenses of the officers, can by noe means be
endured. Many Princes and great Lords deceive them selves, in thinking that
theye do their duty, in that theye be virtuous in their persons, but it
is not so: For it suffysethe not a Prince to draw unto him all virtues, butte
also he is bound to root all vices out of the common wealth.

Admit that Princes will not, or of them selves cannot govern the common
wealth: yet let us desire and admonyshe them, to seek good officers to do it
for them. For the poor Plebeian has noe account to render, but of his good
or evil life: butte the Prince shall render account, of his vicious life
which he has led, and of the little care that he has had of his common
wealth.

Seneca in an epistle he wrote to a frinde of his named Lucilla says. My dear
friend Lucilla, I would gladly thou would come and see me here in Rome: but I
pray thee reco^mend to good judges ye I Will of Scicile. For I would not desire to
enjoy thy sight, if through my occasion yt should leave the common wealth
out of order. And to the intent thou may know what condicio^s they ought to
have, whom thou should chose for governors or judges: I will let thee
understand, that they ought to be grave in their sentences, just in their
words, honest in their works, merciful in their justice, and above all, not
corrupted with bribes. And if I do advertise thee of this, it is because if
thou did take care to govern thy common wealth well, thou should now be
circumspect to examine them, to whom presently thou must recommende the
government thereof. I would say afterward, that all that which the
ancient Philosophers have written in many books, and have left by diverse
sentences, Seneca did rehearse in these few words: the which are so grave,
and necessary, that if Princes retained them in their memory to put them in
execucion, and judges had them before their eyes for to accomplish them, they
would excuse the common wealth of diverse slanders, and theye should also
deliver them selves from a great burdeyn of their conscience.

It is not a thing voluntarye, butte necessary, that the mynysters of justice
be virtuous, well established, and very honest: For to Judges nothing can be
more slanderous, and hurtefull, then when theye should reprove young men of
their youth, others may iustlye reprehende them of their lyghtnes. He which
has a public office in the common wealth, and sytteth openly to judge
therein, ought to observe a good order in his person, least he be noted
dysolute in his doing: For the Judge which is without honestye, and
consideracion, ought to consider with him self, that if he alone have
authority to judge of other men's goods, that there are a thousand which
will judge of his life. It is not only a bourden of conscience, to Princes to
commit the charge of governance of the people to dyssolute persons: but also
it is a great contempt, and dysprayse of Justice. For the sentence geeuen of
him who deserves to be judged, is among the people litel esteemed. Plutarche in
his Apothegmes sayethe, that Phillyppe king of Macedony, father of the great
Alexander, created for judge of a province a freende of his, who after he saw
him self in such office, occupied him self more in kemmynge his head, then
in woorkynge or studyinge his books. King Philyppe being enfourmed of the
vanytye and insolencye of this judge, revoked the power which he had geeuen
him, and when he complained to all of the wrong and grief which was done
unto him, taking his office from him, King Phyllippe said unto him. If I
had given the office to thee, for none other cause but being my friend,
beeleue me that nothing in the world could have suffysed to have taken it
from thee: because I loving thee so entierlye as I did, reason would not I
should have deprived thee of this office, wherewith I honored thee. I gave
thee this office, thinkyng yt thou were virtuous, sage, honest, and also a man
well occupied, and me thynkethe thou rather occupyest thy self in beeholdynge
thye person, then in gouerninge well my common wealth: which thou ought
not to consent unto, and much less do in deed. For the judge ought to be so
occupied, in the administracion of the common wealth: that he should have noe
leisure at any time to keame his head. These words the good king Phillip
spoke unto the judge, whom he dysplaced of his office, for being to fine and
dylygent in keamynge his head, and trymmynge his person. It is not only
decent for ministers of justice, to be grave, and honest: but also it
behouethe them to be true, and faithefull. For to a judge whose office is to
judge the truethe, there can be noe greater infamye: then to be counted a liar.
When two Plebeians be at variaunce togethers for one thing, they come before
the judge for naught else, but that he should judge who has right and
justice thereunto. Therefore if such a judge be not counted true, but a liar,
all take his judgment for false: so that if the plainetife has noe more
power, he will obey justice, yet at the least he will blaspheme him that gave
sentence. There are some judges, that presentlye to get more money, to draw
unto them more friends, and to contynewe also in their offices, use such
shameful shifts with the poor plainetifes, and take so large brybes of the
defe^daunt: that both parties are by him self assured of the sentence in
their favor, before he come unto the bar. Many go to the houses of
judges, some to demand, others to give instructions, other to work deceit,
others to importune them, others to win them, but few go to vysyte them: so
that for those and such se^blables, I do advise, and admonish officers, that
theye be just in their sentences, and vprighte in their words.

The mynysters of justice ought to be such, and so good, that in their life
nothing be woorthye of rebuke: neither in their words, any thing worthy of
reproach. For if herein theye be not very circumspect, oftentimes that shall
happen which the gods would not, which is that to the prejudice of the
justice of another, he shall deny the word of him self. It suffysethe not
judges to be true in their words: butte it is very necessary that theye
be vpryghte in their sentences. That is to wete, that for love theye be not
to large, neither for couetuousnesse theye should be corrupted, nor for fear
drawn back, nor with prayours to be flattered, nor with promysses blinded:
for otherwise, it were a great shame and inconvenience, that the yard which
theye carye in their hands should be streyghte, and the life which theye
lead should be very crooked. To the end justices be vprighte, they ought
much to travail to be lyberall: I mean in things wherein theye ought to
geeue sentence. It is impossible that those which have respect in their
sentence to favor their friends, should not accustomablye use to be
revenged of their enemies. Truly such a judge ought not to be counted just:
but a pryuate Tiraunte. He that with affeccion iudgethe, and passion punishes
is greatly deceived. Those inlyke manner which have authority to govern,
and do think that for borrowynge a little of justice theye should therebye
increase, and multyplye friends in the common wealth, are much abused: for
this act before men is so heinous, and before godde so detestable, that
though for a space he refrain his hands, yet in the end he will extend his
power. For the redemer of the world, only father of truth, will not permit
that such do take upon them the title of justice which in their offices do
show so extreme wrong. Helius Spartianus in ye life of Antonius sayethe, that
the good Emperor going to vysite his Empire (as he was in Capua and there
demau^ding of the state of the Censours, whether they were unjust or rightful,
a man of Capua said in this wise: by the immortal gods, most noble Prince, I
swear, that this judge who presently governs here, is neither just, nor
honest and therefore me think it necessary that we deprive him of his
dignity and I will account unto thee, what befell between him and me. I
besought him yt for my sake he would grant me.4. things, which were al
unjust, and he willingly condescended thereunto: whereof I had no less meruel
in my heart, then vexacion in my body. For when I did desire him, I thought
nothing less then to obtein the^ but only for the co^tentacion of those
which instauntlye desired me to do it. And further this Capuan said. By the
GOD Genius, I swear likewise, that I was not ye more fryndely unto him, for
that he said he did it for mye sake, more then for another: for he that to me
would grant these four, it is to be believed that to others he would grant
four hundredth. For the which thou ought to provide, most noble Prince,
because good judges ought to be pacient to hear, and just to determine. By
this notable example, judges ought to have a great respect, not to those which
do desire them: but to that which theye demand. For in doing their duty,
their enemies will proclaim them just: and contrariwise if they do that they
should not do, their nerest friends will count them tirantes. Judges which
pretend favor to the common wealth, and to be careful of their consciences,
ought not to content them selves simply to do justice: but that of them selves
they should have such an oppinion, that none durst presume to come and require
at their hands, any vile or dishonest thing. For otherwise, if we note the
demander to be unshamefast: we must needs somewhat suspecte the judge in his
justice. Princes ought also to be very circumspect, that the judges be not only
contented to be just, honest, and true: but also in them there ought to
remain no avarice, nor covetousness. For justice, and avarice, can seldom
dwell in one house. Those yt have the charge of the government of ye people,
and to judge causes, ought to take great head, that with bribes and prese^tes
they be not corrupted: for it is impossible but that the same day, yt riches
and treasoures in the houses of judges begin to increase, yt the self same day
the administration of justice, should not decay. Licurgus, Prometheus, and Numa
Pompilius did prohibit nothing in their law so much, neither for any other
cause theye ordained so greauous punishments: but to the intent judges should not
be covetous, nor yet thieves. And of truth they had great co^sideracion, to
fore see and forbid it: for the judge that has received part of the theft,
will not give sentence against the stealers thereof. Let not judges be credyted
for saying they receive no silver, nor gold, neither silks, nor jewels, but
that they take only small presents, as fruits, foul, and other trifles.

For oftentimes it chaunseth, that the judges do eat the fruit, and the
poor suter does feel the morsel. Cicero in the book of laws sayethe that
Cato the Censour being very aged, the Senator said unto him one day in the
Senate. Thou know now Cato, that presentlye we are in the Calendes of
January, wherein we use to divide the offices among the people. Wherefore we
have determined to create Manlius, and Calidanus Censours for this year:
wherefore tell us if they be (as thou think) able and sufficient to supply
that rome. Cato the Censour answered them in this wise. Fathers conscripte, I
let you were that I do not receive the one, nor admit the other. For Manlius
is very rich, and Calidanus the citizeine extreme poor, and truly in both
there is great peril. For we see by experience that the rich officers are to
much subject to pleasures: and the poor officers are to much given to
auaryce. And further he said in this case, me thinks that your Judges whom
ye ought to choose, should not be so extreme poor, that they should want
wherewith to eat: neither so rich, that they should surmount in superfluity,
to geeue them selves to much to pleasures. For men by great abundance,
become vicious: and by great scarsitie become covetous. The Censor Cato being
of such authority, it is but reason that we geeue credit to his words,
since he governed the roman Empire so long space, though indede all the poor
be not covetous, nor all the rich vicious: yet he spoke it for shys intent,
because both those Romans were noted of these ii. vices. For the poor
desire to scrape and scratche: and the rich to enjoy and keep. Which of
those twoe sorts of men princes should chose. I cannot, nor dare not rashely
determine. And therefore I do not counsel them, either to despise the poor
or to choose the rich: but that they give the authority of justice to those,
whom they know to be of good conscience, and not subject to covetousness. For
the judge whose conscience is corrupted, it is impossible he should minister
equal justice. A man may give a shrewed guess of suspicion in that judge,
whether he be of a britell conscience, or no if he see him procure the office
of justice for him self. For that manne which willinglye procures the charge
of conscience of another: commonly little regards the burden of his own.

Of a letter which the emperor Marcus Aurelius wrote to Antigonus his friend,
answering an other which he sent him out of Scicile, wherein he advertised him
of the cruelty of the roman Judges. and this letter is divided into.5.
Chapters Cap. vii.
MArcus Aurelius, companion in the empire, tribune of the people, present lie
being sick, wissheth unto thee Antigonus, health and comfort in thy
banishement. To fly the extreme heat of Rome, and to read some books which
are brought me, from the realm of Palestine, I am come hither to Capua: and
forth haste I made to ride great iourneis, the ague has overtaken me,
which is more troublesome, then perilous. For it takes me with cold, and
plucketh my appetite from me. The.20. day of January I received thy second
letter, and it happened that thy letter and my fever took me both at one
instaunt: but the fever grieved me in such wise, that I could not long endure
to read thy letter. Me thinks we have no stay nor mean, thou being so
brief, and I so long: for my long letter has taken thy greauous sorrows
from the, but thy short letter could not take my fever from me. Now that my
mind is beating of thy travail, the desire which I have to remedy it is
enflamed. I would tell the one thing, and succor thee with some counsel:
but I find that the consolation which thou want, I cannot give the, and
that which I can give the, thou nedest not. In this letter shall not be written
that which was in the first: but herein I will travail the best I can to
answer thee. I will not occupye my self to comfort thee, because I am so out
of course with this disease, yt I have neither will to write, ne yet an^ favor
in any pleasant things. If perhaps this letter be not sauory, so
compendious, neither so comfortable as those which I was woase to write unto
thee: attribute not the blame unto my good will, which desires to serve the,
but to the sickness that gives no place thereunto. For it suffiseth the sick
to be contented with medecynes, without satisfyinge their fryndes. If thy
comfort consisted in writing many letters, and offering the many word: truly
I would not stick to do that for all my fever. But it neither profits the,
nor satisfies me, since I have little, to profer the much. Talkinge now of
this matter, I do remember that the ancient laws of the Rhodians said these
words. We desire and admonish all men, to visit the captives, the
pilgrims, and the comfortless: and further, we ordeine and comaund, that none
in the common wealth be so hardye to give counsel, unless therewith he give
remedy. For to the troubled heart words comfort little, when in them there
is no remedy. Of a truth the law of the Rhodians is good, and the Roman
which shall observe them much better. Assure thy self that I am very desirous
to see thee: and also I know that thou wouldeste as gladlye speak unto me, to
recount me all thy griefs. Truly I do not marvel, because the wounded
heart quieteth him self more, declaring his own griefs, then hearing another
man's consolations. Thou writest unto me of sondrye things in thy letter,
the effect whereof, that thou certifiest me, is that the judges and officers
in that realm be very rygorous, and extreme: and that therefore the
Cicilians are greatly displeased with the Senate.

Hitherto thou have never told me lie, the which moves me to believe all yt
thou writest now in thy letter. Wherefore I take it for a thing most true:
that for as much as all those of Cicil are malicious and enuyous, they give the
judges just occasion to be cruel. For it is a general rule, where men are out
of order, the ministers of justice ought to be rygorous. And though in other
realms it chaunsed not, it is to be believed that it is true in this realm:
where of the ancient proverb says. All those which enhabite the Isles are
evil: but the Cicillians are worste of all. At this day the wicked are so
mighty in their malices, and the good are so much diminished in their
virtues: that if by justice there were not a brydel, the wicked would surmount
all the world, and the good should vanishe immediatlye.

But retourninge to our matter I say, that consideringe with what and how
many euylles we are enuiroined, and to how many miseries we are subject: I
do not marvel at the vanities that men commit, but I am ashamed of the
cruelty which our judges execute. So that we may rather call them tyrauntes,
which kill by violence: then judges which minister by justice. Of one thing I
was greatly astonyed, and almost past my sense, which is, that justice of right
pertains to the gods, and they being offended will be called pitiful: and
we others borowe justice, and not being offended, do glorify our selves to be
called cruel. I know not what manne will hurt an other, since we see that the
gods forgeuing their proper injuries, have attained the renown of merciful,
and we others punishinge the injuries done unto an other, do remain with the
name of tyrauntes. If the punishment of the gods were so severe, as our sins
are filthye, and that they should measure us with this measure: the only
desert of one offense is sufficient to take life from us.

With reason he cannot be called a man amongst men, but a savage amongst
the savages: that forgetting to be of feeble flesh, tormenteth the flesh of his
brother. If a man behold him self from top to toe, he shall find not one
thing in him to move him to cruelty: but he shall see in him many
instruments to exercise mercy. For he has his eyes, wherewith he ought to
behold the neady and indigent: he has feet to go to the church and sermons:
he has hands to help all: he has his tongue to favor the Orphane: he
has a heart to love god: and to conclude, he has understanding to know the
evil: and discretion to follow the good. If men owe much to the gods, for
geuinge them these instruments to be pitiful: truly they are bound no
less unto them, for taking from them all occasions to be cruel. For he has
not given them horns, as to bulls, neither nails as to the catte, nor yet he
has given them poison, as to the serpent: Fynallye, he has not geeuen them so
perilous feet, as to a horse to strike, nor he has geeuen them such bloudye
teethe, as to the Lion to byte. Then since the gods be pitefull, and have
created us pitiful, and commanded us to be pitiful: why do our judges desire
then to be cruel. O how many cruel and severe judges are there at this
day in the Romayne empire, which under the color of good zeal to justice,
adventure to undo the commonwealth. For not for the zeal of justice, but for
the desire to attain to renown: they have been overcome with malice, and
denied their own proper nature. I do not marvel that a Roman censour
should envy my house, will evil to my fryndes, favor mine enemies, despise
my children, with evil eyes behold my daughters, covet my goods, speak evil
of my parsone: But that which I am ashamed of is, that diverse judges are so
gredye to tear men's flesh, as if they were bears, and man's flesh were
noynted with honye.

The Emperor continues still his letter speakinge against cruel judges, and
recites two examples the one of a pitiful king of Cipres, and the other of a
cruel judge of Rome. Cap. viii.
BY the faith of a good manne I swear unto thee friend Antigonus, that I being
young, knew a judge in Rome whose name was Lycaronicus a man of high stature,
his flesh neither to fat, nor to lean, his eyes were some what bloudye and
read, he was of the lynage of the Senators, and on his face he had but a
little bearde, and on his head he had many white hears. This Licaronicus of
long time was judge in Rome, in the roman laws he was well learned, and in
customs and policies very expert, of his own nature he spoke little, and in
the aunswers he gave, he was very resolute. Amongst all those which were in
Rome in his time, he had this excellencye, which was, that to all he
ministered equal justice: and to suitors with great speed he gave brief
expedition, and dispatched them immediatlye. They could never withdraw him by
requests, never corrupt him with gifts, nor begyle him with words, nor fear
him with threatninges, neither would he receive a brybe of any that did offer
it him: And besides this, he was very severe in condition, churlyshe in
words, vnflectible in requests, cruel in punishementes, suspicious in
affairs, and above all, he was hated of many, and feared of all. How much
this Lycaronicus was hated it cannot be reported, and of how many he was
feared, no man can think. For in Rome when any man was iniuried he said: I
pray god that Licaronicus may live long. When the children did cry, the
mothers immediatlye said unto them. Take heed of Lycaronicus, and straight
way they held their peace: so that with the only name of Lycaronicus men
were astonished, and children kept silence. Thou ought also to know
Antigonus, that when any commotyon did arise in a city, or in any other
province, or that any sclaunder rose and increased therein, they were well
assured, and they said that no other should go thither, but only
Lycaronicus. And to say the truth, when he was arrived at that city or
prouynce, the rebels were not only fled: but also diverse innocents were
for fear of his crueltye hyd. For Lycaronicus was so resolute a parsonne, that
some for ill factes, others for consentinge, some for that they favored not
the good right, others for that they kept them secret: none escaped to be
tormented of his parsonne, or punyshed in goods. Think thou Antigonus that
they have been few whom this Judge has caused to be whipte and carted, cast
into wells, beheaded, taken, banished, and put in the stocks, during the time
that the Romans had him with them? By the immortal gods I swear unto thee,
and as Genius the god of nature may help me, that the gallouses and gibbets
were so furnished with feet, hands, and heads of men, as the shambles were
with oxen, sheep, and kyddes. This Lycaronicus was so fleshely to shed humain
blood, that he was never so conversant nor had so merye a countenance: as the
same day he should cause any manne to be drowned in Tyber, hanged in mount
Celio, be headed in the street Salario, tormented or cast into the prison
Marmortina: O cruel, o fyerse, and unspeakable condition that this judge
Lycaronicus had. For it was not possible that he should be brought up
between the delicate arms of the Romans: but in the vile intrailes of you
venomous serpents. I return ones more to say, that it is impossible he
should be norished with the delicate milk of women: but with the cruel
blood of Tigres. If this Licaronicus were cruel, why did they give him such
authority? I curse such authority. If he did it for that he had great
zeal to justice: I curse such zeal of justice. If he did it to win more
honor, I curse that honor: for that man shall be cursed of the gods and hated
of men, which takes life from others, though it be by justice, only to
increase his renown.

The gods are much offended and the people greatly domaged, where the Senate
of Rome calls that Judge gentle which is corrupted: and him that is cruel
just, So that now amongst the Romayne people, those which heal with oil
are not credited: but those only which cure with fire. If any man think it,
at the least I do not thynk it, that when Licaronicus died, all the cruel
judges did end with him: For through all the Romayne Empire there was no more
but one Licaronicus, and at this present there is above.iii. or.iiii. in
every common wealth.

Notwithout tears I speak that which I will speak, which is, that in those
days as all the judges that ministered were pitiful: so was this Lycaronicus
renowned for cruel. But now since all are cruel, we hope in a judge which is
pitefull. In the.xii. year of the foundation of our mother Rome, the first king
thereof was Romulus, who sent a commandment to all the neighbors and
inhabitants there aboutes, to the end that all banished men, all those which
were afflicted, all those which were persecuted, and all those which were in
necessity should come to Rome, for they should be defended from their
enemies, and succored in their necessities. The fame being spread thoroughout
Italy, of the pity and clemency which Romulus showed in Rome (if the Anualles
of the auncientes do not deceive us) Rome was more peopled with inhabitauntes
in.x. years, then Babylon or Carthage, in a hundred. O noble heart of Romulus,
which such things invented: blessed be that tongue, which commanded that the
famous Rome with clemency and pity should be founded. In the original books
which were in the high capitol once I found diverse letters written, to the
sacred senate and romayne people, and in the beginning of the letters the
words said thus. We the king of Parthes in Asya, to the fathers conscripte of
Rome, and to the happy roman people of Italy, and to all those which with
the Romayne senate are confederate, which have the name of Romans, and the
renoume of clemencye, health and tranquillity to your persons we do send
you, and desire the same of the gods for our selves. Behold therefore
Antigonus, what tytles of clemencye had our first Romans, and what example of
clemencye did the Emperor leave for them to come: so that since the barbarous
strangers called them pitiful: it is not to be believed, that to their
subjects or natural country men they were cruel. As the auncientes have
travailed of al to be beloved, so they at this present through their
cruelties, seek nothing but to be feared. If the gods perhaps should reuyue
the dead, and should compare the lyuinge before them in judgment: I suppose
they would say these are not their children, but their enemies, not encresers
of the common wealth, but destroyers of the people.

I being xxxvii. years of age, lay in winter season in an isle called Chetyn,
which now is called Cipres, wherein is a little mountain as yet full of wood,
which is called mount of Archady, where grows an herb called Ilabia,
which the auncientes say, that if it be cut it droppeth blood: and the
nature of it is, that if one rub any manne with the blood thereof hoate
(although he would not) yet he shall love him, and if they annoint him with the
blood that is cold, he shall hate him.

Of this herb we need not doubt any thing at all, for I did prove it, and
noynted one with that blood, who sooner lost his life then the love which he
bare me. There was a king in that I Will of great example of life, and gretlye
renowned of clemencye, though indeed neither by writing nor by words I could
never know his name: but that he was buried under.iiii. pillars in a tomb of
marble, and about the tomb were engraued these greek and ancient letters,
where amongst other things these words were engraven.

THe mighty gods whiles they drew out the length
Of my weak years to pass the flud of life
This rule I had my common wealth to strenght
To norishe peace and stint vain blastes of strife
By virtues way if ought I could obtain
by vices pathe I never sought to get
by dredles peace if I could right attain
by clatering arms blind hasard could not let
By curteis means if I could overcome
By raging threats I heaped up no dread
By secret shifts if I might guide my dome
by open force I nowlde the pain were spread.
By gentle read if I could chastise eke
by sha^pe ways no further proof I sought
In out ward sight I never thought to streeke
before I had to couerte chekes them brought
My free consent could never vainly bear
my tongue to tell one sweet entysinglye
Nor yet my hollow ears would ever hear
Their crooked tales that flatter often awrye.
My schooled heart was always taught to stay
From egre lust of others heaped good
I forced my self his proper wealth to way
And stand content as fortunes judgment stood.
My friends decay, I always watch to aid^
And recked not for bent of enuies bow
In huge expense I never lavish paid
my glittering gold, nor spared yet to low,
For grievous fautes I never punished wight
with mind appeasde but erst I would forgive
my grief did grow when just revenge did high^
And eke I ioyed to pardon men to live.
A mortal man amongst blind heaps of men,
Nature my mother produced me here
And therefore loo enclosed in this den
The egre worms my senseles carcas tere
Amongst the wights that virtue did enhaunce
A virtuous life, I freely passed on
And since that death his kingdom did aduau^ce
my heavenly spirit, to haunt the gods is gone.
HOw think thou Antigonus, what epitaph was this, and what prince ought he
to be, of whom I should say, his life ought to be glorious, and his memory
eternal? I swear unto the, by the law of a good man, and as the gods may
prosper me, I took not so much pleasure in Pompey with his Jerusalem, in
Semiramis with her India, in king Cirus with his Babylon, in Caius Caesar with
his Gawles, in Scippio with his Affrike: as I have in the king of Cipres in
his grave. For more glory has that king there in that sharp mountain being
dead: then others have had in proud Rome being alive.

Marcus Aurelius continues his letter against cruel judges. Of the words
which the emperor Nero spoke concerning justice, and of the instruccion
the emperor Augustus gave to a judge which he sent into Dacya. Cap. ix.
Neither for that which I write in this letter, nor yet for that which king
Cirus had in his grave: my entencion is not to defend the evil, to the end
that for their evil deeds, and outragiousnes, they should not be punished.
For by this means, it should be worse for me to favor them: then for them to
be evil. For they through debilitie do offend: and I by malice do err. But
in this case it seems unto me, and to all others which are of good
judgment, that since frailty in men is natural, and the punishment which
they geeue is voluntarye: Let judges therefore in ministering justice show,
that they do it for the zeal of the common wealth, and not with a mind to
revenge. To the end the faultye may have occasion to amend the faults past,
and not to revenge injuries present, the divine Plato in the books of his
common wealth said, that judges ought to have two things always present
before their eyes, that is to wete, that in judging things touching the goods
of others, they show no covetousness: and in punishing any man, they show no
revenge. For judges have license to chastise the body: but therefore they have
not license to hurt their hearts. Nero the emperor was greatly defamed in
his life, and very cruel in his justice, and with all his crueltyes i^
chanced, that as one on a day brought him a judgment for to subscribe, to
behead certain murderers: He fetching a great syghe said these words, O
how happy were I that I had never learned to write, only to be excused to
subscribe this sentence. Certainly the Emperor Nero, for speking such a
pitiful word at that time, deserved immortal memory: but afterward his so
cruel life, perverted so notable a sentence.

For speaking ye cruche, one evil work suffiseth to deface many good words. O
how many realms and countries have been lost, not so much for the euilles
which in those the wicked have committed: as for the disordinate Justices
which the ministers of justice therein have executed.

For they thinkinge by rigor to correct the dommages past, have raised up
present sclaunder for ever. It is known to al men, who and what the emperor
Augustus has been, who in all his doings was exceadinge good: For he was
noble, valiant, stout, fyerse, and a lover of justice, and above all very
pitiefull. And for so much as in other things he showed his pitye and
clemency, he ordained, that no prince should subscribe judgments of death
with his own hand, neither that he should see iuystce done of any with his
own eyes. Truly the law was pitifullye ordained, and for the cleanness and
pureness of Emperors very necessary.

For it seems better for Princes to defend their land with the sharp
sword: then to subscribe a sentence of death, with the cruel pen. This
good Emperor Augustus was very diligent to choose ministers of justice, and
very careful to teach them how they should behave them selves in the
common wealth: admonishing them not only of that they had to do, but also of
that they ought to fly. For the mynisters of justice, oftentimes sail of
their duty. In Capua there was a governor named Escaurus, who was a just
judge, though he were somewhat severe: whom the Emperor Augustus sent to the
realm of Dace to take charge of that province. And amongst diverse other
things he spoke these words unto him to retain them in his memory. Frynde
Escaurus, I have determined to pluck thee from Capua, and to put into thy
custodye the government of the prouynce of Dace, where thou shall represent
the royal majesty of my person, and thou ought also to consider well,
that as I make thee better in honor and goods: so thou in like case should
make thy self better in life, and more temperate in justice. For hitherto in
justice thou have been a little to rigorous: and in thy life somewhat to rash.
I counsel thee therefore, I do desire thee, and further I command thee,
that thou change thy trade of life, and have great respect to my honor, and
good name.

For thou know right well, that the only profit and honor of the common
wealth of Romayne Princes, consysteth in having good or evil ministers of
their justice. If thou wylt do that I would thou should, I let the
understand, that I do not commyt my honor in thy trust, neither my justice,
to thintente thou should be an enuyer of the innocent, and a scourge of
transgressors: but that only with the one hand thou help to sustanie the
good, and with the other thou healpe to amend the evil.

And if thou will more perticulerly know my entencion, I do send the, to the
end thou should be graundfather to the Orphans, an advocate for the
wydowes, a plaster for the grieved, a staff for the blind, and a father to
all. Let therefore the resolution of all be, to rejoice mine enemies, to
comfort my frindes, to lift up the weke, and to favor the strong: so that thou
be indifferent to all, and parcyall to none, to the end that through thy
upright dealing, mine may rejoice to dwell there, and strangers desire to come
and serve me here. This was the instruccion which the emperor Augustus gave
to the governor Escaurus. And if a man will consider and way his words well, he
shall synde them compendious enough, that I would they were written in our
judges hearts. By thy letter thou declarest that the judges whom the Senate
sent to that I Will, are not very honest, nor yet without some suspicion of
covetousness. O woeful common wealth, where the judges therofare cruel,
dishonest, and covetous: forth cruel judges seek naught else but the blood
of innocents, they covet the goods of the poor, and they sclaunder the good,
to such and so wicked a commonwealth, I would say that it were better to
remain in the mountains among the brute bestes: then by such unjust judges to
be governed in a common wealth. For the firce Lions (which of all beasts are
most cruel) if in his presens the hunter prostrate him self on the earth
before him, the Lion will neither touch him nor his garment. O my frinde
Antigonus, do thou think that if the common wealth be unhappy which has such
judges, that therefore Rome may reioise which provided them? By the faith of a
good man, I swear unto the, that I count the Senators worse which sent them:
than the Judges which went thither. It is a great grief to a noble and stout
heart to demand justice of a man, which neither is true, nor yet observes
Justice: but it is a greater grief to see a Judge, that to many has executed
tyranny, and to many poor men has done sundry wrongs, afterward not with
the life he leads, but with the authority he has, presumes to correct
diverse Judges. He that has the office to punish the vicious, ought him self
to be void of all vices: otherwise, he that has that office, by tyranny
executes justice, and furthermore he is a traitor to the commonwealth. It is
impossible that any Judge should be good, unless he has the authority of
his office for accessory, and his pure life for principal. The end why a
judge is sent in provinces, is to defyne doubtful causes, to refourme their
manners, to favor those which can little, and by vyole^ce to enforce those
which can do much. And for the most part there is no commonwealth so weak,
but may well hang a thief on the gallouse, though there came no Judge from Rome
to give sentence. O how many judges are there now a days in Rome, which have
caused diverse to be hanged, regarding nothing but the first thief: and they
remain free, having robbed all the people. Which ought to think them selves
assured, that though punishment be deferred, yet in the end the fault shall
not be pardoned. For the offenses which men in their life time do dissemble,
the gods after their death do punish. It is much good for the common
wealth, and no less honor for the prince, which has the charge thereof, that
the Judge be honest of parson, and diligent in justice, and that in no vice
(for the which he punishes other) he be either noted or defamed himself. For
much is the office of justice perverted, when one thief hangs another on
the galouse.

The Emperor follows his purpose in his letter against cruel (...)
declares a notable imbassage which came from Iud^a to the (...) to complain
of the judges that governed that Realm. Cap. x.
IN the third year after Pompeius took the cu^e of ^elya, which now is
called Jerusalem: Valerius Gracchus a Romayne borne, was ^ente at that time
into that region for the Romans. This Gracchus was very stout of courage,
subtyle in affairs, and honest in life: but notwithstanding all this, in
conversation he was unbridled, and in the administracion of justice
exceadynge rigorous. When the Jews saw them selves not only subject to the
Romans, but besides that evil handeled: they determined to send their
ambassador to Rome, to the intent to infourme the Senate of the tyrannyes and
oppressions which were committed in the land. And for to accomplish the same,
they sent a very aged manne (as by the hears of his head did well appear)
who was learned in the Hebrew greek and lattine letters. For the Hebrews are
very apt to all sciences, but in weapons great toward. This Hebrew came to
Rome, and spoke to the Senate in this wise. O fathers conscripte, O happy
people, your good fortune and fatal destenies permittinge it, or to say
better, We forsakinge our God, Jerusalem, which of all the cities of Asia was
lady and maystres, and of all the Hebrews in Palestine mother, we see it now
presentlye servant and trybutarye to Rome: whereof we Jews ought not to
marvel, neither ye Romans to be proud. For the highest trees by behement
wyndes are soonest blown down.

Great were the armies which. Pompeius had; whereby we were vanquished:
but greater has our offenses been, since by them we do deserve to be
forsaken of our God. For we Hebrews have a God which does not put us under
the good or evil fortune: but does govern us with his mercy and justice. I
will that ye hear one thing by monthe, but I had rather ye should see it by
experyence, which is: that we have so merciful a God, that though amongst
50. thousand evil, there was of us but.10. thousand good: yet he showed
such tokens of mercy, that both the Egiptians and the Romans might have
seen how our god can do more alone, then all your gods together. We
Hebrews (agreeynge in one faith and unity) have one only God, and in one
God only we put our trust and belief, and him we desire to serve, though
we do not serve him, neither should serve him, on such condycion to offend
him. He is so merciful, that he would not let us prove what his merciful
hand can do, neither would he put our woeful people in captivity as he
has, nor also our God can deceive us, neither our wrytynges cannot lie.

But the greater offenders we be, the greater lords shall ye be over us.
And as long as the wrath of God shall hang over us, so long shall the power
of ye Romans endure. For our unhappy realm has not geeuen ye our realm
for your deserts: nor yet for that you were ryghtfull heirs thereunto, but
to the end ye should be the scourge of our offenses. After the will of our
God shall be fulfilled, after that he has appeysed his wrath and indignacion
against us, and that we shall be purged of our offenses, and that he shall
behold us with the eyes of his clemencye: then we others shall recover that
which we have lost, and you others shall lose that which you have evil won.
And it may so chance, that as presentlye of ye romans we are commanded: so
the time shall come, that of ye others we shall be obeyed. And for as much as in
this case the Hebrews feel one, and ye Romans feel an other: neither ye can
cause me to woorship many gods and much less should I be sufficient to
draw ye to the faith of one only God. I refer all to God, the creator of
all things, by whose might we are created and governed.

Therefore touching the matter of my embassage, know ye now, that in all
times paste until this present, Rome has had peace with Judea and Judea
has had friendship with Rome: so that we did favor ye in the wars and ye
others preserved us in peace. In generallye nothing is more desired then
peace, and nothing more hated then war. And further all this presupposed, we
se it with our eyes, and also do read of our predecessoures: that the world
has been always in contencion, and rest has always been banished. For in
deed if we see many sighe for peace: we see many more employe them selves to
war. If ye other would banishe those from you, which do move you to bear
us evil will, and we others knew those which provoke us to rebel, neither
Rome should be so cruel to Judea, nor yet Judea should so much hate Rome.
The greatest token and sign of peace, is to dyspatche out of the way the
distourbers thereof. For frendshippe oftentimes is lost, not so much for the
interest of the one or of the other, as for the vndiscretenes of the
mediatoures. When one common wealth stryueth against another, it is impossible
that their controversies endure long, if those which come between them (as
indifferent mediatoures) be wise. But if such one which takes upon him those
affairs, be more earnestlye bent then the enemy wherewith the other fyghteth:
we will say, that he more subtylye casts wood on the fire, then he
draws water to quench the hear.

All that which I say (Romans) is because that since the banishment of
Archelaus from Judea (son of the great king Herod) in his place ye sent us
Pomponius, Mareus Rufus, and Valerius to be our Judges: who have been four
plagues, the least whereof suffyseth to poison all Rome.

What greater calamitye could happen to our poor realm of Palestine, then
Judges to be sent from Rome to take evil customs from the evil: and they
them selves to be inuentoures of new vices? What greater inconvenience can
chance to justice, then when the Judges which ought to punish the lyghtnes
of youth, do glorify them selves to be captains of the light in their
age? What greater infamye can be to Rome, then when those which ought to be
just in all justice, and to give example of all virtues: be evil in all
euylles, and inuentoures of all vices? Wherein appears your little care and
much tyranny.

For all said openly in Asia, that the thieves of Rome do hang the thieves of
Iewrye. What will ye I shall say more (Romans) but that we little esteame
the thieves which keep the wooddes, in comparison of the Judges which rob
us in our own houses.

O how woeful were our fatal destenyes, the day that we became subject to
the Romans. We fear no thieves which should rob us in the high way,
we fear no fire which should burn our goods, nor we fear no tyrauntes,
which should make war against us, neither any Assirians which should
spoil our country: we fear not the corrupt air that should infect us,
neither the plague that should take our lives from us: but we fear your
cruel judges, which oppesse us in the common welthe, and robs us of our
good name. I say not without a cause they trouble the common wealth. For that
laid a part which they say, that laid a part which they mean, and that
laid aparte which they rob, immediatelye they write to the Senate to
consent unto them, not of the good which they find in the auncientes: but of
the lightness which they see in the young. And as the Senatoures do hear them
here, and do not see them there: so ye geeue more credit to one that has
been but three months in the province, then to those which have governed
the common wealth.30. years.

Consider Senatoures, that ye have been made and appointed Senators in this
place, for that ye were the wysest, the honestest, the best experimented, and
the most moderate and virtuous.

Therefore in this above all shall be seen if ye be virtuous, in that you do
not believe all. For if those be many and of diverse nations which have to do
with you: much more diverse and variable are their intencions, and ends, for
the which they entreat. I lie if your Judges have not done so many wrongs
in justice, and forsaken their disciplyne: that they have taught the youth of
Judea inuencions of vices, which neither has been heard of our fathers,
neither read in our books, ne yet seen in our time. Ye others Romans,
since ye are noble and mighty, ye disdain to take counsel of men that be
poor: the which ye ought not to do, neither counsel your friends to do
it. For to know, and to have little seldom times goes together. As many
counsayles as Judea has taken of Rome: so many let now Rome take of Judea.
You ought to know, though your Captains have won many realms by
sheddynge blood, yet notwithstanding your judges ought to keep them, not with
rygorous sheddynge of blood, but with clemencye and winnynge their hearts.

O Romans, admonish, command, pray, and aduertyse your Judges whom ye
send to govern strange prouynces: that they imploye them selves more to the
common wealth of the realm, then their hands to number their fynes and
forfettes.

For otherwise they shall sclaunder those which send them: and shall hurt
those whom they govern. Your Judges in just things are not obeyed for any
other cause, but forasmuch as first they have commanded many unjust
things. The just commandments make the humble hearts, and the unjust
commandments do turn and convert the meek and humble men, to severe
and cruel persons. Humayne malice is so geeuen to command, and is so
troublesome to be commanded, that though they command us to do good, we
do obey euylle: the more they commmaund us evil, the worse they be obeyed
in the good.

Believe me (Romans) one thing, and doubt nothing therein, that of the great
lightness of the judges, is sprung the little fear and great shame of the
people. Each Prince which shall give to any judge the charge of justice, who^
he knows not to be able, does it not so much for that he knows well how to
minister justice: but because he is very craftye to augment his goods. Let
him be well assured, that when he least thinks on it, his honor shall be in
most infamye, his credit lost, his goods diminished, and some notable
punyshement light upon his house. And because I have other things to speak in
secreate, I will here conclude that is open, and fynallye I say, that if ye
will preserve us and our realm for the which you have haserded your selves
in many periles: keape us in justice, and we will have you in reverence.
Command as Romans, and we will obey as Hebrews: give a pytefull president,
