and ye shall have all the realm in safegarde.

What will ye I say more, but that if you be not cruel to punish our
weakness, we will be very obedient to your ordinances. Before ye provide for
to command us, think it well to entreat us: for by prayeng with all mekenes,
and not commaundinge with presumpcion, ye shall find in us the love which the
fathers are wont to find in their children: and not the treason which the
lords have accustomed to find in their servants.

The Emperor concludes his letter against the cruel judges, and declares
what the graundfather of king Boco spoke in the Senate. Cap. xi.
ALl that which above I have spoke, the Hebrew said, and not without great
admiracion he was heard of all the Senate. O Rome without rome, which now
haste naught but the walls, and art made a common stews of vices. What
did thou tell me, when a stranger did rebuke and taunte thee, in the
myddest of thy Senate? it is a general rule, where there is corruption of
custom, lyberties are always lost, which seems most true here in Rome.
For the Romans, which in times past went to revenge their injuries into
strange countries: now others come out of strange countries, to assault
them in their own houses. Therefore since the justice of Rome is condemned,
what think thou that I believe of that I Will of Cicil; tell me I pray thee
Antigonus, from whence comes think thou so great offense to the people,
and such corruption to justice in the common wealth? If peradventure thou
know it not, harken and I will tell the. It is an order whereby all goes
without order. Thou ought to know that the counsayloures of princes being
importunate, and the Prince not resistinge them, but suffringe them, they
deceive him, some with covetousness, other with ignorance, geeue from whom
they ought to take, and take from whom they ought to geeue, they honor them
who do dishonor them, they witholde the just, and deliver the covetous, they
despise the wise, and trust the light, fynallye they provide not for the
offices of persons, but for the persons of offices. Hark Antigonus, and I
will tell the more. These miserable judges, after they are provided and invested
in the auctority of their offices (whereof they were unworthy) seeing themselves
of power to co^mau^d, and yt the dygnitie of their offices is much more, then
the desert of their persons: immediatelye they make them selves to be
feared, mynystringe extreme justice. They t^ke upon them the estates of
great lords, they live of the swet of the poor, they supply with malice, that
which they want in discrecion: and that which is worst of all, they myngle
another man's justice, with their own proper profit. Therefore here more what I
will say unto thee, that these cursed judges, saying them selves pestred with
sundry affairs, and that they want the ears of knoweledge, the sails of
virtue, and the ankers of experience not knowing how to remedy such small
evils: they invent others more greater, they disturb the common peace, only
for to augment their own particular profyt. And finally they bewail their
own damage, and are dyspleased with the prosperity of an other. Nothing can
be more just, that since they have fallen into offices not profitable for them,
they do suffer (though they would not) great domages: so yt the one for taking
gifts remain slaundered, and the other forgeuing the^ remains undone. Harken
yet, and I will tell thee more. Thou ought to know, yt the beginnings of
these Judges, are pride and ambition: their means, envy and malice, and their
endinges are death and destruction. For the leaves shall never be grene, where
the roots are dry. If my counsel should take place in this case, such Judges
should not be of counsel with princes, neither yet should theye be defended
of the pryuate, but as suspecte men theye should not only be cast from the
common wealth: butte also theye should suffer death.

It is a great shame to those which demand offices of the Senate, but greater
is the rashness and boldenes of the counsailers, which do procure them: and we
may say, both to the one, and to the other, that neither the fear of god does
withdraw them, nor the power of Princes does bridell them, nor shame does
trouble them, neither the common wealth does accuse them, and fynallye
neither reason commands them, nor the law subdueth the^. But hark, and I
will tell thee more. Thou ought always to know, what the form and manner
is, that the Senators have to divide the offices: for sometimes they give them
to their frindes, in recompense of their frindship, and other times they give
them to their servants, to acquit their services, and sometime also they
give them to solicitours, to the end theye shall not importune them, so that
few offices remain for the virtuous, the which only for being virtuous are
provided. O my frinde Antigonus, I let you to wete, that since Rome did keep
her renown, and the common wealth was well governed, the dylygence which the
Judges used toward the Senate, to the end theye might geeue them offices:
the self same ought the Senate to have to seek virtuous men, to commit such
charge into their hands. For the office of justice ought to be given, not to
him which procurethe it, but to him that best deserves it. In the year of
the foundation of Rome.6. hundredth 42. years, the Roman people had many
wars throughout all the world. To wete Chaius Celius, against those of
Thrace, Gneus Cardon his brother against the Sardes, Iunius Scilla, against ye
Cymbres, Minutius Rufus, against the Daces, Scruilius Scipio against the
Macedonians, and Marius Consul against Iugurtha king of Numidians: and
amongst all these, the war of the Numidians was the most renowned, and also
perylous. For if Rome had many armies against Iugurtha to conquer him Iugurtha
had in Rome good frindes which did favor him King Boco at that time was
king of Mauritanes, who was Iugurthas frinde, and in the end, he was
afterward the occasion that Iugurtha was overthrown, and yt Marius took him.
These two kings Marius the Co^sull brought to Rome, and triumphed of them,
leadinge them before his triumphaunt chariot, their necks laden with yrons,
and their eyes full of tears. The which unlucky fortune, all the Romans which
beheld lamented, and took great pytye of the staungers whom they heard. The
night after the triumph was ended, it was decreed in the Senate, that Iugurtha
should be beheaded, leaving king Boco alive, depryued of his country. And the
occasion thereof was this. The Romans had a custom of long time, to put no
man to execucion, before that first with great dyligence they had looked the
ancient books, to se if any of their predecessoures had done any notable
service to Rome, whereby the poor prisoner might deserve his pardon.

It was found written in a book, which was in the high Capitol, that the
graundefather of king Boco was very sage, and a special friend to the Romayne
people, and that once he came to Rome and made diverse Orations to the Senate,
and amongst other notable sentences, there was found in that book, that he had
spoken these words. Woe be to the that realm where all are such, that neither
the good amongst the evil, nor the evil amongst the good are known. Woe
upon that realm, which is the enterteiner of al fools, and a destroier of
all sages. Woe is that realm where the good are fearful, and the evil to
bold. Woe on that realm where the pacient are despised, and the sedicious
commended. Woe on that realm, which distroie the those that watch for the
good: and crown the those that watch to do evil. Woe to that realm, where
the poor are suffered to be proud: and the rich tiraunts. Woe to that
realm, where all know the evil: and no man does follow ye good. Woe to that
realm, what so many evil vices are openly committed: with in an other
country dare not secretly be mentioned. Woe to that realm, where all procure
that they desire, where all attain to that theye procure, where all think ye
that is evil, where all speak that they think, and finally, where al may do
that which they will. In such, and so unfortunate a realm, where the people
are so wicked, let every man beware he be not inhabitaunt. For in short time,
they shall se upon him, either the ire of the gods, the fury of the men, the
depopulation of the good, or the desolation of the tyrauntes. Diverse other
notable things were contained in those oracions, the which are not (at this
present) touching my letter. But for as much as we thought it was a very just
thing, that they should pardon the follye of the nephewe, for the deserts of
the wise grandfather. Thou shall read this my letter openly to the Pretours,
and Judges which are resydente there, and the case shall be, that when thou
shalt read it, thou shall admonish them, that if they will not amend
secretlye, we will punish them openly. I wrote unto thee the last day, that
as touching thy banyshement I would be thy frinde: and be thou assured, that
for to enjoy thy old friendeshyppe, and to perform mye word, I will not
let to danger mye parsone. I writ unto Panutius my secretary, to succoure
thee with two thousand Sesterses, wherewith thou may relieve thy pouertye:
and from hence I send thee mye letter, wherewithe thou may comfort thy
sorrowful heart. I say no more to thee in this case, but that thoroughe ye
gods thou may have contentacion of all that thou enioyest, health of thy
person and comfort of thy frindes: the bodily euels, the cruel enemies, the
perilous destenies, be far from me. Mark. In the behalf of thy wife Rufa, I
have saluted my wife Faustyne, she and I both have received with joy thy
salutacio^s and with thanks we sent them you again. I desire to see thy
person here in Italye, and wyshe my fever quartene there with thee in Scicile.

An exhortacion of the autcour to Princes and noble men, to embrace peace, and
to eschew the occasions of war. Cap. xij.
OCtauian Augustus, second Emperor of Rome, is commended of all, for that he
was so good of his person, and so well-beloved in all the Romayne Empire.
Suetonius Tranquillus says, that when any man dyed in Rome in his time, they
gave great thanks to the gods for that they took their life from them,
before their Prince knew what death meant. And not contented only with this,
but in their testaments they commanded their heirs, and children, that
yearly they should offer great sacrifices of their propre goods in all the
temples of Rome, to the end the gods should prolong the days of their
prince. That time in deed might be called the golden age, and the blessed
land, where the prince loved so well his subjects, and the subjects so much
obeyed their prince. For seldom times it happens, that one will be content
with the services of all: neither that all will be satisfied with the
government of one. The Romans for none other cause wished for that good
prince (more the^ for the^ selves) life but because he kept the common wealth
in peace. The virtue of this prince deserved much praise, and the good will of
ye people merited no less commendation: he for deserving it to them, and
theye for geuinge it to him. For to say the truethe, there are few in number
that so heartily love others, that for their sakes will hate them selves. There
is no man so humble, but in things of honor will be content to go before,
save only in death, where he can be content to come behind. And this
semethe to be very clear, in that that now dyethe the father, now the
mother, now the husband, now the wife, now the son, and now his
neigheboure, in the end, every man is content with the death of an other,
so that he with his own life may escape him self. A prince which is gentle,
pacient, stout, sober, pure, honest, and true, truly he of right ought to
be commended: but above all, and more then all, the prince which keeps his
common wealth in peace, has great wrong, if he be not of all beloved.
What good can the common wealth have, wherein there is war and discencion?
Let every man say what he will, wytheoute peace noe man can enjoy his own,
noe man can eat wytheoute fear, noe man sleapeth in good rest, noe man
goethe safe by the way, noe man trustethe his neighbor, finallye I say,
that where there is noe peace, there we are threatened daily with death, and
every hour in fear of our life. It is good the prince do scour the realm
of thieves, for there is nothing more unjust, then that which the poor
with toil and labor do get, should with vacabondes in idleness be
wasted. It is good the prince do weed the realm of blasphemers, for it is an
euidente token that those which dare blaspheme the king of heaven, will not
let to speak evil of the princes of the earth. It is good the prince do
clear the common wealth of vacaboundes, and players: for play is so evil a
mote, that it eatethe the new gown, and consumethe the dry wood. It is good
that the prince do forbydde his subjects of prodigal bankettes, and
superfluous apparel: for where men spend much in things superfluous, it
chaunseth afterward that they want of their necessaries. But I ask now what
auailethe it a prince to banishe al vices from his common wealth, if otherwise
he keeps it in war? The end why princes are princes, is to follow the
good, and to eschew the evil. What shall we say therefore, sins that in the
time of war, princes cannot refourme vices, nor correct the vycyous. O if
Princes and noble men knew what damage theye do to their countreye, the day
that they take upon them war, I think and also affirm, that theye would
not only not begin it, nor yet any pryuate person durst scarsely
remember it. And he that does counsel the prince the contrary, ought by
reason to be judged to the common wealth an ennemy. Those which counsel
princes to seek peace, to love peace, to keep peace, without doubt they have
wrong if they be not heard, if they be not beeloued, and if they be not
credited. For the counsailer which for a light occasyon counsayleth his
prince to begin war, I say that unto him either color surmountethe, or else
good conscience wants. It chaunsethe oftentimes that the prince is vexed and
troubled, because one certyfyethe him that a prouynce is rebelled, or some
other prince has invaded his country and as the matter requirethe, the
counsel is assembled. There are some to rash counsailours, which
immediatelye judge peace to be broken as lyghtlye, as others do desire that
wars should not begin. When a prince in such a case asks counsel,
they ought forthewithe not to answer him sodaynely: for things touching
the wars, ought with great wisdom first to be considered, and then
with as much aduisement to be determined. King David never took war in
hand, though he wear very wise, but first he counsayled with Godde. The
good Judas Machabee never e^tred into battle, but first he made his prayer
unto almightye godde. The Greeks and Romans durst never make war against
their enemies, but first they would do sacrifice to the gods, and consulte
also with their Oracles. The matters of justice, the recreacions of his
person, the reward of the good, the punishment of the evil, and the deuydynge
of rewards, a Prince may communicate with any pryuate man: but all matters
of war, he ought first to counsel with God. For the prince shall never
have perfyte vyctorye over his enemies, unless he first commit the quarrel
thereof unto Godde. Those which counsel princes (whyther it be in matters
of war, or in the affairs of peace) ought always to remember this
sentence: that theye geeue him such counsayles always when he is whole in
his chamber, as theye would if theye saw him at the point of death very
sick. For at that instaunte, noe manne dare speak with flatterye, nor burden
his conscience thoroughe bryberye.

Whenne theye entreat of war, theye which move it ought to considre, that
if it came not well to pass, all the blame shall be imputed to their
counsel. And if that his substance be not presently able to recompense the
loss, let him assure him self, that hereafter his soul shall suffer the
pain. Men ought so much to love peace, and so much to abhor war, that I
beeleue that the same preparacion a priest has in his conscience with God
before he presume to receive the holy communion, the same ought a
counsayloure have, before to his Prince he geeueth counsel in war. Since
Princes are men, it is no merueile though they feel injuries as men, and that
theye desire to revenge as men. Therefore, for this cause they ought to have
wise men of their counsel, whereby they should mittigate and assuage their
griefs and troubles. For the counsaylours of princes, ought never to
counsel things they being angry, wherwt after they may justly be displeased,
when they be pacified. Following our matter, in counting the goods which are
lost in loasyng peace, and the euilles which increase in winning wars, I say
that amongst other things the greatest evil is, that in time of war they
lock up closely al virtues, and set at lyberty all vices. During the time that
Princes and great Lords maintain war, though they be lords of their
realms and dominions by right, yet for a truethe theye are not so in deed.
For at that time the lords desire more to content their soldiers, and
subjects: then the souldyers and subjects seek to content the lords. And
this they do, because theye thoroughe power might vanquishe their enemies, and
further thorough the love of their money, relieve their necessities. Either
princes are governed bye that whereunto by sensuality they are moved, or else
by that wherewith reason is contented. If they will follow reason, they have to
much of that they possess: but if they desire to follow the sensual
appetite, there is nothing that will content them. For as it is impossible to
dry up all the water in the sea: so it is hard to satisfye the heart of man
that is couetouse. If princes, take upon the^ wars, saying that their ground
is taken from them, and that thereof theye have a conscience: let them beware
that such conscience be not corrupted. Form the world there is no war
justified, but for the beginning thereof, the princes at one time or an other,
have their conscience burdened. If princes take upon them war for no other
cause, but to augment their state and dygnytye, I say that this is a vain
hope: for theye consume and lose (for the most part) more in one or twoe
years wars, then ever theye get again during their life. If princes
take upon them war, to revenge an iniurye: as well for this also it is a
thing superfluous. For many go to the wars being wronged only with one
thing, and afterward they return iniuried with many. If princes take upon
them war for none other cause but to win honor, me thynkethe also that
that is an unprofitable conqueste. For me thinks that fortune is not a person
so famous, that into her hands a man may commytte his honor, his goods,
and life. If princes take upon them war to leave of them in the world to
come some memory, this no less the^ the other semethe to me vain. For
without doubt, if we examine the histories that be paste, we shall find
those to be more in number, which for beginnynge of wars have been defamed:
then those which for vanquishynge of their enemies have been renowned. If
princes take upon the^ war, supposyng that there are in an other countreye
more pleasures, and delights, then in their own: I say, that to think this,
procedethe of little experyence, and of less conscience. For to a prince there
can be noe greater shame, nor conscience, then to begin wars in strange
realms, to maineteyne his own pleasure and vices at home. Let noe princes
deceive them selves, in thinking that there are in strange countries more
things, then in their own. For in ye end, there is noe land nor nation
in the world, where there is not winter and summer, night and day, sickness
and health, riches and pouertye, myrthe and sadness, friends and enemies,
vicious and virtuous, alive and dead. Fynallye I say, that in all parts all
things agree in one, save only the disposicions of men, which are diverse.
I would ask princes and great lords, the which do and will live at their
pleasures, what theye want in their realms, yea though theye be little? If
theye will hunt, they have mountains and parkes: if theye will fish, theye
have pondes: if theye will walk, theye have rivers: if theye will refreshe
them selves, theye have baynes: if theye will be merye, theye have musicians:
if theye delighte in apparaylinge them selves, theye have cythe clothes: if
theye will geeue, theye have money: if theye desire weomen, theye have wives
if they will take their rest, theye have their gardeines: if winter annoye
them, theye have whote countries: and if theye will eat, theye want no
meats. He that with peace has all these things in his own dominion, why
then with war does he seek them in a strange countreye? Men
oftentimes fly from one countreye to another, not to be more devout, nor
more virtuous: butte to have greater liberty and opportunity to haunte vices.
And afterward whenne theye see the ends of their deeds, theye cannot
refrain their hearts from sighs, since theye might have enjoyed that at
home with peace, which in strange countries they sought with trouble.
There are so few things wherewythe we are contented in the world, that if
perchance a man find in any one place, any one thing wherewithe to
content him, let him beeware that the devil do not deceive him, saying:
that in such another place he may recreate himself better For whyther so
ever we go, we shall find such penurye, and want of true pleasures, and
comfortes, and such coppie and abundaunce of troubles and torments that for
to comfort us in a hundrethe years we scarcelye find one, and to tormente
us, we find at every foot a thousand.

The auctoure recytethe the commodities which come of peace, declaring how
diverse princes upon light occasions have made cruel wars. Cap. xiij.
DImo, an auncyente king of Ponto, said unto a philosopher which was with
him: Tell me philosopher, I have health, I have honor, and I have riches, is
there any thing more to be desired amongst men, or to be geeuen of the
Gods in this life? The philosopher answered him. I see that I never saw,
and I hear that I never heard, For health, riches, and honor, the gods
seldom times do trust in one person, his time is so short that possess
them, that theye have more reason to pray that theye might be quyted of
them, then for to be proud for that theye possess them. And I tell thee
further king Dimo, it little profytethe that the gods have geeuen thee all
these things, if thou do not content thye self therewythe, the which I
think theye have not geeuen thee, nor never will geeue thee. For the gods are
so just in deuydynge their gifts, that to them to whom theye give
contentacion, theye take from them riches: and to those whom theye geeue
riches, they take their contentacion. Plutarche in the first of his pollytike
puttethe this example, and he declares not the name of this philosopher.

O how great a benefyte is that, which the gods geeue to princes and
great lords, in geeuinge them their health, in geeuynge them riches, and in
geuinge them honor, but if besides those he gives them not contentacion, I
say that in geeuynge them the goods, he geuethe them travail and danger.
For if the travail of the poor be greater then the travail of the rich:
wytheoute comparison the discontentacion of the rich, is greater then the
discontentacion of the poor. Men little regarding their health beecome
sick, little esteeminge their riches beecome poor, and because theye know
not what honor is, theye become dishonored? I mean, that the rash princes,
until such time as theye have benne well beaten in the wars, will always
little regard peace. The day that you princes proclayme wars against your
enemies, you set at lybertye all vices to your subjects: Yet you say your
meaning is not theye should be evil. I say it is true. Yet all this joined
togethers, ye geeue them occasion that theye be not good. Let us know what
thing war is, and then we shall see, whyther it be good or evil to follow
it. In wars theye do naught else but kill men, rob the temples, spoil
the people, destroy the innocents, geeue liberty to thieves, separate
friends, and raise strife: all the which things cannot be done wytheoute
great hurt of justice, and scrupulosytie of conscience. The sedycious manne
him self can not denaye us, that if twoe Princes take upon them wars
beetweene them, and that both of them seem to have right, yet the one of
them only has reason. So that the prince which shall fight against
justice, or defend the unjust cause, shall not escape out of that war
justified: Not issuynge out justified, he shall remain condemned: and the
condemnation shall be, that all the losses, murders, burnynges, hangynges, and
robberies which were done in the one or other common wealth, shall remain
upon the account of him, which took upon him the unjust war. Allthoughe
he does not find an other prince, that will demand an accoumpte of him
hear in this life yet he shall have a just judge that will in another place
lay it to his charge. The prince which is virtuous, and presumethe to be a
christian, before he beeginne the war, ought to considre what loss or
profit will ensue thereof. Wherein if the end be not prosperous, he loses
his goods and honor: and if he perchance attain to that he desired,
peradventure his desire was to the damage of the common wealth, and then he
ought not to desire it. For the desire of one, should not hurt the profit of
all. When GOD our lord did create princes for princes, and people accepted
them for their lords, it is to believe that the gods never commanded such
things, nor the men would ever have excepted such, if they had thought ye
princes would not have done that they were bound, but rather that whereunto
they were inclined. For if men follow that whereunto their sensuality
enclinethe them, they do always err. Therefore if they suffer them selves to
be governed by reason, they are always sure. And besides that, princes should
not take upon them wars, for the burdening of their conscience, the
mispendinge of their goods, and the loss of their honor: they ought also to
remember the duty that they owe to the common wealth the which they are bound
to keep in peace and justice. For we others need not governors to search us
enemies but princes which may defend us from the wicked. The divine Plato in
his.4 book de legibus says, that one demanded him why he did exalt the
Lidians so much, and so much dispraise the Lacedaemonians? Plato answered: If
I commend the Lidians, it is for that they never were occupied but in tilling
the field: and if I do reprove here the Lacedaemonians, it is because theye
never knew nothing else but to conquer realms. And therefore I say, that
more happy is that realm, where men have their hands with laboring full of
blysters: then where their arms in fightinge, are wounded with sweordes.
These words which Plato spoke are very true, and would to god that in the
gates and hearts of princes they were written. Plinius in an epistle sayethe,
that it was a proverb much used amongst the Greeks, that he was king which
never saw king. The like may we say, that he only may enjoy peace,
which never knew what war meant. For simple and innocent though a man be,
there is none but will judge him more happy, which occupyeth his
handekerchiefe to dry the sweat of his brows: then he that breakethe it to
wipe the blood of his head. The princes and great lords which are lovers of
war, ought to consider, that they do not only hurt in general all men,
but also specially the good: and the reason is, that allthoughe they of their
own wills do abstain from battle, do not spoil, do not rebel, nor sleye:
yet it is necessary for them to endure the injuries, and to suffer their own
loss and damages. For none are meet for the war, but those which little
esteem their life, and much less their consciences. If the war wear
only with the evil against the evil, and to the hurt and hinderaunce of
the evil little should theye feel which presume to be good. But I am sorry the
good are persecuted, the good are robbed, and the good are slain: For if it
were otherwise (as I have said) the evil against the evil, we would take
little thought both for the vanquishinge of the one, and much less for the
destruction of ye other. I ask now, what fame, what honor, what glory,
what victory, or what riches in that war can be won, wherein so many good
virtuous, and wise men are lost? There is such penurye of the good in the
world, and such need of them in the common wealth, that if it wear in our
power, we with our tears ought to pluck them out of their graves and
geeue them life, and not to lead them into the wars, as to a shambles to be
put toe death. Pliny in one epistle, and Seneca in an other say: that when
theye desired a Romayne captain that with his army he should enter into a
great danger, whereof great honor should ensue unto him, and little
profit to the common wealth: He answered. For nothing would I enter into
that danger if it were not to give life to a romayn citize^. For I desire
rather to go environed with the good in Rome, then to go laden with treasures
into my cou^treye. Comparinge prince to prince, and law to law, and the
christian with the pagan: without comparison the soul of a christian ought
more to be esteemed, then the life of a Romayne. For the good Roman obseruethe
it as a law to dye in the war: but the good christian has this precepte,
to live in peace. Suetonius Tranquillus in the second book of Cesars sayethe.
That among all the Romayne princes there was noe prince so wellbeloued, nor
yet in the wars so fortunate as Augustus was. And the reason hereof is,
because that prince never began any war, unless by great occasyon he
was thereunto provoked. O of how many princes (not ethnicks, but christians) we
have heard and read all contrary to this, which is: that were of such
large conscience, that theye never took upon them any war that was just.
to whom I swear and promise, that since the war which they in this world
beeganne, was unjust: the punishemente which in an other theye shall have is
most righteous. Xerxes king of the Perses being one dayeat dynner, one
brought unto him very fair and sauourye fygges of the province of Athens:
the which beeinge set at the table, he swear by the immortal gods, and by
the bones of his predecessors, that he would never eat fygges of his
countreye but of Athens, which were the best of all Greece. And that which by
word of mouth king Xerxes swear, by valiant deeds with force and shield
he accomplished, and went forthwith to conquer Gretia, for noe other cause,
but for to syll him self with the sygges of that countreye, so that he
began that war not only as a light prince: but also as a vicious man.
Titus Liuius sayethe that when the French men did cast of the wine of Italy,
immediately they put them selves in arms and went to conquer the countreye,
witheout having any other occasion to make war against them: So that the
Frenchemen for the lycorousnes of the pleasant wynes, lost the dear blood
of their own hearts. King Antigonus dreamed one night that he saw king
Methridates with a fyeth in his hand, who like a mower did cut all Italy. And
there fell such fear to king Antigonus, that he determined to kill king
Methridates: so that this wicked prince for credytinge a light dream, set all
the world in an uproar.

The Lumberdes beeinge in Pannonia, herd say that there was in Italy sweet
fruits, sauowry flesh, odoriferous wynes, fair women, good fish, little
cold, and temperate heat: the which news moved them not only to desire
them, but also theye took weapons to go conquer Italye: So that the Lombardes
came not into Italye to revenge them of their enemies, but to be there more
vicious and riotous. The Romans and the Carthagiens were friends of long
time, but after they knew there was in Spain great mines of gold and of
silver, immediatelye arose between them exceadynge cruel wars, so that
those twoe puissaunt realms, for to take each from other their goods,
destroyed their own proper dominions. The authors of the above said, were
Plutarchus, Paulus Diaconus, Berosus, and Titus Liuius. O secret judgments of
god which suffers such things. O mercyful goodness of thee my Lord, yt
permits such things, yt through ye dream of on price in his chamber,
another for to rob the treasures of Spain, another to fly the cold of
Hungary, another to drink the wines of Italy, another to eat figs of Greece,
should put all the country to fire and blood. Let not my pen be cruel against
al princes which have unjust wars. For as Traianus said. Just war is more
worth then feigned peace. I commend, approve, and exalt princes which are
careful and stout, to keep and defend that which their predecessors left
them. For admit that for dispossessing them, hereof comes all the breach with
other Princes. Look how much his enemy offends his conscience for taking it:
so much offends he his common wealth for not defending it. The words which
the divine Plato spoke in the first book of his laws, did satisfye me greatly,
which were these. It is not mete we should be to extreme in commending those
which have peace: nor let us be to vehement in reproving those which have
war. For it may be now, yt if one have war, it is to ye end to attain
peace. And for the contrary, if one have peace, it shall be to the end to make
war. In deed Plato said very true. For it is more worth to desire short
war, for long peace: then short peace for long war. The philosopher Chilo
being demanded whereby a good or evil governor might be known, he au^swered.
There is nothing whereby a good and evil man may be better known, then in
that for the which they strive. For the tyranous Prince offrethe him self to
dye to take from an other: but the virtuous prince trauaileth to defend his
own. When the redemer of this world, departed from this world, he said not I
give ye my war, or leave ye my war: but I leave ye my peace, and geeue you
mye peace. Thereof ensuethe that the good christian is bound to keep the
peace, which Christ so much commanded: then to invent war to revenge his
proper iniurye, which god so much hated. If princes did that they ought to
do, and in this case would believe me: for no temporal thing they should
condescend to shed man's blood, if nothing else, yet at the least the love of
him which on the cross shed his precious blood for us, should from that
clean dissuade us. For the good Christians are commanded to bewail their
own sins: but they have no license to shed the blood of their enemies.
Finally I desire, exhort, and further admonish al princes, and great lords,
that for his sake that is prince of peace, they love peace, procure peace, keep
peace, and live in peace. For in peace they shall be rich, and their people
happy.

The Emperor Marcus Aurelius writes to his friend Cornelius, wherein he
dyscribeth the discomodyties of war, and the vanity of tryumphe. Cap. xiiij.
MArcus Emperor, wysheth to thee Cornelius his faithful friend, health, to thye
person, and good luck against all evil fortune. Withein fiftene days after I
came from the war of Asia, whereof I have triumphed here in Rome, remembrynge
that in times paste thou wear a companyon of my travail, I sent immedyatly to
certyfy thee of my triu^phes. For ye noble hearts do more rejoice of their
fri^ds joy, the^ they do of their own proper delights. If thou will take pains
to come when I se^d to call thee, be thou assured, yt on the one part thou shall
have much pleasure to se ye great abu^da^s of riches, yt I have brought out of
Asia, and to beeholde mye receiuinge into Rome: and on the other, thou can
not keep thy self from weepinge, to se such a sort of captives (the which
entered in before the triu^phant chariotes) bound, and naked, to augment to the
co^querours most glory: and also to them vanquished, to be a greater ignominy.
Seldom times we se the sun shine bright all the day long, but first in the
summer there has been a mist, or if it be in the winter, that has been a frost.
By this parable I mean, that one of the miseries of this world is, that we
shall se few in this world, which now be prosperous: but before have had
fortune, in some cases, very malicious. For we see by experience, some come to
be very poor, and other chance to atteine to great riches: so that thoroughe
the impouerishing of those, the other become rich, and prosperous. The weping
of the one, causes the other to laugh: so that if the bucket that is emptye
above, does not go down: the other which is full beneathe can not come up.
Speaking therefore according to sensuallyty, thou would have been glad yt
day to have seen our triu^phe, with the abundance of riches, ye great number of
captives, ye dyuersitie of beasts, ye valiantnes of the captains, the sharpnes
of wits which we brought from Asia, and e^tred into Rome, whereby thou
might well know the dangers yt we escaped in that war. Wherefore speaking
the truth, the matter between us and our enemies was so debated, that those of
us yt escaped best, had their bodies sore wounded, and their veins also almost
with out blood. I let thee wete, my Cornelius, yt the Parthes are warlike men,
and in dangerous enterprises very hardy and bold. And when theye are at home
in their country every one with a stout heart defends his house, and surely
they do yt like good men, and valiant captains. For if we other romans,
without reason, and through ambition, do go to take another man's: it is mete
and just, that theye by force do defend their own. Let no man through the
abundaunce of malice, or want of wisdom envy the Roman Captain, for any
triumph that is given him by his mother Rome for surely to get this only one
days honor, he adue^tureth his life a M. times in the field. I will not speak
all that I might say of them yt we led forth to the wars, nor of them which
we leave here at home in Rome, which be al cruel judges of our fame: for
their judgment is not upright according to equitye, but rather procedethe of
malice, and envy. Though they take me for a pacient man, and not far out of
order, yet I let thee know my Cornelius, yt there is no patience can suffer,
nor heart dissemble, to see many romans to have such great envy, which
(thorough their malicious tongues) pass not to backebite other men's triumphs.
For it is a old disease of evil men, through malice to backebite that with
their tongue which through their cowardnes, they never durst enterprise with
their hands. Notwithstanding all this ye must know, yt in the war you must
first often hazard your life, and afterward to the discrecion of such tongues
commit your honor. Our follye is so folishe, and the desires of men so vain,
that more for one vain word, then for any profit, we desire rather to get
vain glory with travail: then to seek a good life with rest. And
therefore willinglye we offer our lives now to great travail, and pain
only that among vain men hereafter we may have a name. I swear by the
immortal gods, unto thee mye Cornelius, yt the day of mye triumph, where as
to the seeming of all those of this world I went triumphinge in the chariote
openly: yet I ensure thee my heart wept secreatly. Such is the vanity of men,
that though of reason we be admonished, called, and compelled, yet we fly from
her and contrary, though we be ^^^ked evil handled, and despised of the world,
yet we will serve it. If I be not deceived it is the prosperity of foolish
men, and want of good judgments yt cause the men to enter into others houses
by force rather then to be desiro^^^ be quiet in their own, with a good will.
I mean yt we should in folowinge virtue, sooner be virtuous: then in haunting
vices, be vicious. For speaking the troth, men which in all and for all desire
to please the world, must needs offer them selves to great travail and care.
O Rome, Rome, cursed be thy folly, and cursed be he that in thee brought up so
much pride, and b^ he cursed of men, and hated of gods, which in thee ha^
^uented this pompe^ For very few are they, yt worthily unto it have a^^ ^^d:
but infinite are they, which thorough it have perished. What greater vn^^ ^or
what equal lightness can be, then that a Roman captain, because he ^^h
conquered realms, troubled quiet men, destroyed cities, beaten down castles,
robbed the poor, enriched tiraunts, carried away treasours, shed much blood,
made infinite widows, and taken many noble men's lives, should be afterward
(with great triumph of Rome) received in recompense of all this damage? Will thou now that I tell thee a greater follye, which above al other is greatest? I
let thee wete, infinite are theye that dye in the wars, and one only carries
away the glory thereof: so that these woeful and miserable men, though for
their carcass they have not a grave, yet one captain goes triumphing alone
thorough Rome. By the immortal gods I swear unto thee, and let this pas
secretly, as between frindes, that the day of my triumph, when I was in my
triumphaunt chariot, beholdinge the miserable captives laden with yrons, and
other men cariynge infinite treasures, which we had evil gotten, and to se the
careful widows weep for the death of their husbands, and remembered so many
noble Romans which lost their lives in Affrike: though I seemed to rejoice
outwardly, yet I e^sure thee I did weep drops of blood inwardly. For he is no
man borne in the world, but rather a fury bred up in hell among ye furies, yt
ran at the sorrow of another take any pleasure. I know not in this case, what
reputacion the prince, or captayn should make of him self, that comes from
the war, and desires to enter into Rome, for if he think (as it is reason)
on the wounds he has in his body, or the tresures which he has wasted, on
the places that he has burnt, on the perils yt he has escaped, on the
injuries which he has received, the multitude of men which unjustly are
slain, the frindes which he has lost, the enemies that he has gotten, the
little rest that he has enioied, and the great travail that he has suffered:
in such case I say, yt such a one with sorrowful sighs ought to lament, and with
bitter tears ought to be received. In this case of triumphinge. I neither
commend the Assirians, nor envy the Persians, nor am content with the
Macedonians, nor allow the Caldians, or content me with Greeks. I curse the
Trojans, and condemn the Carthagiens, because yt they proceeded not according
to the zeal of justice: but rather of the rage of pride, to set up triumphs,
endomaged their countries, and left an occasion to undo us, O cursed Rome,
cursed thou have ben, cursed thou art, and cursed thou shall be. For if the
fatal destenies do not lie unto me, and my judgment deceive me, and fortune
fasten not the nail: they shall se of thee Rome in time to come, that which we
others presently se of the realms paste. Thou ought to know, that as thou
by tyranny have made thy self lady of lords: so by justice thou shall return
to be the servant of servants. O unhappy Rome, and unhappy again I return
to call the. Tell me I pray thee, why art thou at this day so dear of
marchaundise, and so chepe of folly? Where are the ancient fathers which
builded thee, and with their virtues honored thee? in whose stead presently
thou magnifyest so many tyrauntes, which with their vices deface thee. Where
are al those noble and virtuous barons which thou have nourished, in whose
steed thou have now so many vicions, and vacabondes? Where are those, which
for thy liberty did shed their blonde, in whose stead now thou have those,
that to bring thee into subieccion, have lost their life? Where are thy valyant
Captains, which with such great travail did endeavor them selves to defend
the walls from enemies, in whose stead have succeeded those that have plucked
them down, and peopled them with vices, and vicious? where are thy great
priests, the which did always pray in the Temples, in whose steed have
succeeded those, which know not but to defile the churches, and with their
wickedness to move the gods to wrath? where are these so many philosophers
and orators, which with their counsels governed the, in whose stead have
now succeeded so many simple, and ignorant, which with their malice do undo
the? O Rome all those auncie^ts have forsaken the, and we succeed those which
now are new, and if thou knew truly the virtue of them, and did
consider the lightness of us: the day that they ended their life, the self
same day not one stone in thee should have been left upon an other. And so
those feldes should have sauoured of the bones of the virtuous: which now
stink of the bodies of the vicious. Peradventure thou art more ancient then
Babylon, more beautiful then Jerusalem, more rich then Carthage, more
strong then Troy, more peopled the Thebes, more in circuit then Corinthe,
more pleasant then Tirus, more fertile then Constantinople, more high then
Camena, more invincible then Aquileia, more priuileged then Gades, more
environed with Towers then Cap^a, and more floryshing then Cantabria. We see
that all those notable cities perished, for all their virtuous defendoures:
and think thou to remain being replenished with so much vice, and peopled
with so many vicious?

O my mother Rome, take one thing for a warning, that the glory which now is
of the, was first of them, and the same destruction that was of them, shall
hereafter light upon the, for such is the world.

For thus goes the world, even as we presentlye see the troubles of them that
be paste: so shall those that be to come, see ours that be present.

Marcus Aurelius goes on with his letter, and declares the order that the
Romans used in setting forth their men of war, and of the outrageous
villanyes which captains and soldiers use in the war. Cap. xv.
I will now declare unto thee, my friend Cornelius, the order which we have to
set forth men of war: and thereby thou shall see the great disorder that is in
Rome. For in the old time there was nothing more looked unto, nor more
corrected, then was the discipline of war. And for the contrary, now a days
there is nothing so dissolute, as are our men of war. News once spread
abrode^ through the empire, how the prince does take upon him any war,
immediatlye diverse oppinions engender amongst the people, and every one
judges dyuerselye upon the war. For as much as the one says it is just,
and the prince that takes it upon him is just. Others say that it is unjust,
and that the prince which began it, is a tyrant. The poor and seditious
persons do allow it, to the end they might go, and take other men's goods by
force. The rich and pacient do condemn it, because they would enjoy their
own in quiet. So that they do not iustifye or condemn war, according to
the zeal of justice: but according to the little or much profit, that shall
follow them of that enterprise. I command which am a Romayne Emperor, war
to be proclaimed, because a city or province has rebelled, and that according
to their custom they do observe the ceremonies of Rome. First you must
understand, the priests must be called to go immediately to pray to the
immortal gods: for the roman people never went to shed the blood of
their enemies in the wars, but first the pristes did shed the tears of
their eyes in the Temples.

Secondly all the sacred Senate does go to the temple of the God Jupiter, and
there they swear all with a solemn oath, that if the enemies (against whom
they go) do require a new confederacion with Rome, or demand pardon of
their faults committed: that (all reuengement laid on side) they shall not
deny them mercy.

Thyrdlye the consul which is appointed for captain of the war, went to
the high capitol, and there he makes a solemn vow to one of the gods,
which lyketh him best, that he will offer him a certain Jewel, if he
return victorious of the same war: and though the jewel which he does
promise be of great value, yet all the people are bound to pay it.

The.4. is, that they set up in the temple of Mars the ensign of the Egle,
which is the ancient roman ensign, and that is, that all the Romans take
it for commandment, that no spectacle nor feast be celebrated in Rome,
during the time that their brethren be in the wars.

The.5. a Praetor mounteth up to the top of the gate of Salaria, and their
he blows the trumpet to muster men of war, and they bring forth the
standers and ensigns to deuyde them among the Captains.

How fearful a thing is it to see, that so soon as the Captain is enuyroned
with thensigne, so soon has he license to commit all euyls, and villanyes. So
that he takes it for a brauerye, to rob the countries whereby he passes:
and to deceive those with whom he practyseth. What lyberty captains and
governors of war have to do evil, and to be evil, it is very manifest
in those whom they lead in their company. For the sons leave their
fathers, the servants their lords, the Scholars their masters, the
officers their offices, the priests their Temples, the amarouse their
loves, and this for none other cause, but that under the color of the
liberties of war, their vices should not be punished by justice. O my friend
Cornelius, I know not how I should begin to say that which I will tell thee.
Thou ought to know, that after our men of war are gone out of Rome they
neither fear the gods, neither honor the temples, they reverence not the
priests, they have no obedience to their fathers, nor shame to the people,
dread of justice, neither compassion of their country, nor remember that they
are children of Rome: and yet very few of them think to end their life, but
that all shame laid aside, they love the condemned ydlenes, and hate ye just
travail. Therefore hark, I will tell thee more, and though it seems much
that I speak, I ensure thee it is but little in respect of that they do, for
so much as some rob temples, others spread rumors, these break the doors,
and those rob the Gods. Somtymes they take the free, somtymes they lose the
bond. The nights they pass in plays, the days in blasphemies, to day they
fight like lions, to morrow they fly like cowardes. Some rebel against the
Captains, and others fly to the enemies. Fynallye, for all good they are
unable, and for all evil they are meet. Therefore to tell the of their
filthynes, I am ashamed to describe them.

They leave their own wives, and take the wives of others, they dishonor the
daughters of the good, and they begile the innocent Virgins, there is no
neighbor but they do covet, neither hostess but yt they do force, they
break their old wedlock, and yearly seek a new marriage: so that they do
all things what they list, and nothing what they ought. Do thou think
presently my friend Cornelius yt there are few evils in Rome, since so many evil
women do go to the war? Here for their sake, men offend the gods, they are
traitors to their country, they deny their parentage, they do come to
extreme poverty, they live in infamy, they rob the goods or others, they
waste their own, they never have quiet life, neither remains any truth in
their mouths: fynallye for the love of them, oftentimes war is moved
again, and many good men lose their lives. Let us leave the reasons, and
come to hystoryes.

Thou know right well, that the greatest part of Asia was conquered and
governed, more with the women Amazones, then with any barbarous people. That
young, noble, and valiant Porro, king of Judea, for want of men, and
aboundans of women, was overcome of the great Alexander. Hanniball the terrible
captain of the Carthagiens was always lord of Italy, until he did permit
women to go to the war. And when he fell in love with a maiden of Capua,
they saw him immediatlye turn his shoulders to Rome. If Scipio the Affricane
had not skoured the Romayne armies of lecherye, the invincible Numantia had
never been won. The Captain Silla in ye wars of Mithridates, and the
courageous Marius, in the war of the Zimbtes, had over their enemies so
many victories, because in their camps they suffered no women. In the time of
Claudius the Emperor, the Tharentines and Capuans were very mortal enemies,
in so much as the one again the other pytched their camp, and by chance
one day in the camp of the Capuans, two Captains fell at varyaunce, because
they both loved one woman, and when the Tharentines perceived their
dissensyon, immediatlye with their power gave them the onset.

Whereof it ensues, that through the naughtynesse of one evil woman, was
lost the liberty of that goodlye city. I had in this war of Parthes 16.
thousand horsemen, and.24. thousand footmen, and.35. thousand women, and the
disorder in this case was so great, that from the host I sent my wife
Faustine, and the wives of diverse other Senators home to their houses, that
they should keep the old and nourishe the young.

Our forefathers led women in the old time to the war, to dress meat for
the whole, and to cure the wounded: but now we lead them to the end
cowardes should have occasyon to be effeminate, and the valiant to be
vicious. And in the end, their enemies do break their heads: but the women
do wound their hearts. I will that thou know other things, my Cornelius,
and they are, that the Gawles, the Vulcanes, the Flaminii, the Regii, the
which are priests of the mother Sibilla, of the god Vulcane, of the god Mars,
and of the god Jupiter, the fear of the gods set aside, leaving their
temples desert, laying of their honest garments, not remembringe their holy
ceremonies, breaking their straight vows, an infinite number of them go to
the camp, where they love more dishonestlye then others: for it is a common
thing, that those which once presume to be solytarye, and shamefaste, after
that they are once fleshed: exceed all other in shame and vice.

It is a dyshonest thing, and also perilous to carye priests to the war:
for their office is to pacifye the gods with tears, and not to threaten men
with weapons. If perchance Princes would say, it is good to carye priests
to the war to offer sacrifices to the gods: To this I answer, that the
temples are buylt to pray, and ye fyeldes for to fight: so that in one place
the gods would be feared, and in an other honored and sacrifyced. In the
year of the foundation of Rome.315. the consul Vietro passed into Asia, and
went against the Palestines, the which there rebelled against ye Romans, and
by the way he passed by the temple of Apollo, in the isle of Delphos, and as
there he made a prayer unto the god Apollo very long, to the end he would
reuele unto him whether he should return victorious from Asia or not. The
oracle answered. O consul Vietro if thou will return victorious from thy
enemies, restore our priests which thou take from our temples. For we
other gods will not: that the man whom we choose for our deuyne service,
ye others should lead to the vices of the world. If it be true (as it is
true in deed) that the god Apollo said unto the consul Vietro, me thinks
it is no just thing to co condescende that priests should go to loose them
selves in the war.

For as thou know my Cornelius, without doubt greater is the offense that
they commit in going to vndooe them selves, then is the service which they
do to princes being desirous to fight.

Let us have the pristes in the Temples to pray, and let us see how the
captains are wont to govern them selves, and in this case thou shall find
that the day that the Senate do appointe a Senator for captain, they prove
him if he can play at the weapons in the Theater.

The Consul leads him to the high capitol with him, the Egle is hanged at
his breast, they cast the purple upon his shoulders, they give him money of the
common treasour, immediatlye he grows into such pride, that forgettinge the
poverty past which he suffered in his country, he thinks one day to
make him emperor of Rome. It is a common thing, that when fortune exalts
men of low estate, to high degree, they presume much, and know little, and
much less what they are woorthe. So that if their feeble force were coequall
to their high mind, one alone should suffice to over come their enemies, and
also to win many realms.

The Captains have taken a custom now in Rome, and they tell me that it is
an invention of Mauritane, that is, that they tease their beardes, they curle
their hears, they clippe their words, they change their garments, they
accompanye with murderers, they go the most part armed, they go very fast
to seem fierce, and to conclude they little esteem to be beloved, and take
it great glory to be feared.

And to thentent thou should know, my Cornelius, how much they would be
feared, I will recyte thee an historye which is, that I standing one day in
Penthapolyn, a captain of mine, I hearing him, and he not seeing me, for so
much as they would not let him do all that he would have done in the
house, he said unto an hostice of his.

Ye other villaynes did never know captains of armies, therefore know it, if
thou do not know it mother, that the earth does never tremble, but when yt
is threatened with a Romayne Captain, and the gods do never suffer the Sun
to shine, but where we others are obeyed.

Sins thou have now hard that he said, hear also the valiauntnes that he
has done. Within short space after, the captain went unto a battle in
Arabia, where he was the first that fled, and left the standerd alone in
the field, the which had almost made me lose the battle. But I in
recompense of his valiant deed, commanded to cut of his great head. For in
giving the onset upon the enemies, the flyenge of one manne does more hurt,
then the fightinge of two thousand does profit. I have often times heard the
emperor Traian my lord say, that the men which in peace seem most
fierce, in wars commonly are most cowardes.

It chances that diverse things are compassed, for having only a good
eloquence, others for having wytche craft, others for being very diligent,
others for opening their purse, and truly this is the most and best mean
that is occupied in Rome. But the affairs of wars do not consiste, in
talkinge many words before their friends: but in fightinge manfullye in the
field against their enemies. For in the end, men most full of words, are for
the most part cowardes in deeds. What will thou I tell the more, my
Cornelius, of the injuries which the captainez do in ye cities whereby they
pass, of the sclaunders which they raise in the provinces where they abide? I
let thee weete, that the little woorme does not so much harm that gnaweth the
wood, the moth to the garments: the spark unto the toae, the locust unto the
corn, neither the wyuell to the garners, as the captains do to the people.
For they leave no beast but they kill, nor orchyarde but they rob, nor wine
but they drink, nor dove house but they clime, nor temple but they spoil, nor
chase but they hunt, no sedicion but they raise, no villainy but that they
commit. And they do more then they ought to do, for they eat without meaning
to pay, and they will not serve unless they be well paid: and the woorst of
all is, that if they have their pay, immediately they change or play it. If
they be not paid, they rob and mutine forthwith: so that with poverty they
are not content, and with riches they wax vicious and insolent. The matter is
now come to such corrupcion, and there is at this day men of war in Rome so
careless, that here no captain seems but an example of murderers, a sturrer
up of sedicious persons, an enuyer of the good, a partaker with all evil, a
thief of thieves, a pirate of rouers, and finally I do not say that they seem
to be: but I do affirm that they are the scourge of your virtuous, and
refuge of the vicious. I would not say this, but yet not withstandyng I ought
to say it, because it is a thing so far out of order, and so much to be
laughed at: that these wicked men though they are our familiar enemies, there
is no prince that rules them, nor Justice that corrects them, nor fear that
does oppesse them, nor law that subdueth them, nor shame that refraineth them,
nor parents that correct them, nor punishment that does abase them, nor yet
death that does end them: but now as men which are without remedy, we let
them eat of all.

Marcus Aurelius Emperor pursues his letter, showing the great damages that
have ensued for the wars begone with strange realms. Cap. xvi.
O Unfortunate Rome, who was not wont to have such evil luck, but the older
thou art, the more unlucky I see thee. For by writings we read, and also with
our eyes we see, that the more fortunat a city or person has been in the
beginning, the more froward fortune is unto him in the endyng. Truly in those
ancient times, and in those glorious worlds, I say when they were peopled with
true Romans, and not as now (they which have no children but bastardes) the
armies were so well taught that came from Rome, as the philosophers which were
in the schools of Greece. If the greek writings do not lie unto me, Phillip
the great king of Macedony, for this is so renowned in histories, and his
son the great Alexander for this was so fortunate in the wars, that they
had their armies so well correct: that it rather seemed a Senate which
governed, then a camp which fought. In that we can gather out of Titus Liuius,
and other writers, from the time of Quintus Cincinnatus dictator, until the
noble Marcus Marcellus, were the most prosperous times of the Romayne empire.
For before kings did trauail, and afterward it was persecuted with tyraunts.
In these so happy times, one of the greatest felicities that Rome had, was to
have the warrelyke discipline well corrected. And then Rome began to fall, when
our armies began to do dommage. For if those of the war have, truce with
vices, the others of the common wealth can not have peace with virtues. O
cursed be thou Asia, and cursed be the day that with thee we had conquest.
For we have not seen the good that have followed us of thy conquest, until
this present, and the loss and dommage which from thee came unto us, shall be
lamented in Rome forever. O cursed Asia, we spent our treasures in thee, and
thou have geeuen to us thy vices. In change of our valyant men, thou have
sent us thy fine mineons, we have won thy cities, and thou tryumphest of our
virtues. We battered thy fortes, and thou have destroyed our manners. We
triumph of thy realms, and thou did cut the throtes of our friends. We
made to thee cruel war, and thou conquerest from us the good peace, With
force thou were ours, and with good will we are yours. We are unjust lords
of thy riches, and just tenauntes of thy vices. Finally thou Asia art a woeful
grave of Rome, and thou Rome art a fylthy sink of Asia. Since our ancient
fathers did content them selves with Rome alone, why should not we their
children content our selves with Rome and Italy? but that we must go to
conquer Asia, where we adventured our honor, and spent our treasure? If those
ancient romans, being as they were, so princely barons in life, and so
valiant in fyghting, and so hardy to command, did content them selves with
this little border: why should not we content our selves not being as they
are, having a realm rich and vicious? I know not what fond toye took us in
the head, to go conquer Asia, and not to content our selves with Rome? Italy
was not so poor of riches, nor so destitute of cities, nor so unpeopled of
people, nor so solitary of beasts, nor so vndecked with buyldinges, nor so
barrayne of good fruits: but that of all these things we had more, then our
fathers wished, and also more then we their children deserved. For me I
would say, that it is for want of judgment or abundance of pride, for us to
seek to exceed our forefathers in seignorie: when we are not coequall unto
them in virtue. I was contented with all things of my forefathers, save only
that they were a little proud, and seditious, and herein we their children do
resemble them well.

For as much as we are not only proud and sedicious, but also covetous and
malycious. So that in virtuous things we go backward, and in unlawful
works we go forward. What is become of the great victories that our
forefathers had in Asia? What is become of the infinite treasure they have
robbed in that country? what is become of ye great number of captives that
they took in the war? what is become of the strange beasts that they sent
into Italy. What is become of the riches which every one brought home to his
house? what is become of the valiant kings which they took in that conquest?
what is become of the feasts and triumphs, wherewyth they entered triumphing
into Rome? What will thou I say more unto thee in this case, (my Cornelius) but
that all they which invented the war are dead, all those which were in Asia
are dead, al those which defended that country are dead, all those which entered
triumphing into Rome are dead, and finally, all the riches and tryumphs which
our fathers brought from Asia, they and those in short space had an end, except
the vices and pleasures whereof we see no end. O if the valiant princes
knew, what a thing it is to invent wars in strange realms, what trauayls
they seek for their persons, what cares in their hearts, what trouble to
their subjects, what waste to their treasors, what poverty to their friends,
what pleasures to their enemies, what destruction of the good, what liberty
of the evil, and what occasion they geeue to strangers to speak, what
universal evil they sow in their natural countries, and what evil poison
they leave to their heirs: I swear by the faith of a good man, that if as I
feel it, princes did feel it, and as I taste it, princes did taste it, and
also as I have proved it, princes did prove it, I do not say that with effusion
of blood I woold take realms by force: but also they offering them to me with
tears, I woold not take the^ willingly. For speaking the truth, it is not the
point of valiant princes for to sustain an other man's, to put their own in
ieoperdye. I ask now, what profit took Rome of the conquest of Asia? I
admit that it durst conquer it, that it was hardye in winning it, obstinate
in fightinge, and happy in taking it: should it therefore be fortunate in
maintaininge it? In this case I say and affirm, and of that I say I do not
repent me: that it is possible to take Asia, but it is but a folly to presume
to maintain it.

Do thou not think it a great folly to presume to maintain Asia, since
there never comes news of a victory, but that it is occasion of an other
battle, and that to sustain war, they rob all Italy? In Asia our money
is spent, our children are perished: In Asia dyed our fathers, for Asia they
make us pay tributes: In Asia the good horses are consumed: Into Asia they
carry all our corn: In Asia all the thieves are nourished: From Asia comes
all the sedicious persons: In Asia all the good do perish: From Asia they
send us all the vices: and fynallye in Asia all our treasures are spent, and
in Asia all our excellent Romans are killed. And since this is the service
that Asia does to Rome, why will Rome continue war with Asia? Other princes
before us have conquered Asia, taken Asia, and possessed Asia: but in the end,
when they saw that it was a country where they feared not the gods, nor
acknowledged subjection to their princes, neither that they were apt to
receive laws, they determined to forsake them: because they found by
experience, that they neither weary their bodies with wars, neither win
their hearts with benefytes. Those Princes not being hardye, nor so bold to
sustain Asia by land, should we others presume to succor it by sea? They
forsake it being neighbors, and will we others maintain it being strangers?
In my oppinion Asia is a country, where all the valiant men have employed
their valauntnes, where all the fools have proved their folly, where all the
proud have showed their pride, where all the princes entered in with might,
where all the tyrauntes have employed their life: but in the end, it neither
profits the one to will it, nor to the others to know it, and yet much
less to vanquishe it.

I know not the man that loves Asia, that wylleth well to Asia, that speaks
well of Asia, or that favors the things of Asia, since she gives us
occasion to speak daily, to sigh nightly, and to weep hourly.

If men atteined to the secret to know the fatal destenies, with ye which
the gods have created Asia, they would not strive so much in the conquest
thereof. For the gods have created it in such a sign, that it should be a
common pasture where all feed, a common market where all sell, a common Inn
where all rest, a common table where all play, a common house where all
dwell, a common country where all remain: and thereof it comes, that Asia
is desired of many, and governed of few. For being as it is a common
country, every manne will make it his own proper.

Peradventure thou wylt think, my friend Cornelius, that I have spoken now
all the euylles of Asia, but harken, yet I will form the a new question
again. For according to the dommages which have followed (from Asia) to our
mother Rome, time shall rather want to write, then matter to declare. Not
without tears I say that which I will say, that there was never any
Romayne Captain that did kylle ten thowsande Asians with the weapons he
brought into Asia; but that he lost a hundredth thousand romans with the
vices they brought to Rome. So that the Asians by the hands of their enemies
died with honor: and left us Romans alive full of their vices with
infamye. I ask now what they were that invented to dyne in common places, to
suppe in secret gardeines, to apparaile the women as men in the theater, to
color the flesh of priests with yellow? to noynt the women as men in the
bathe, the Senators going smellyng to the Senate, Princes to be apparanied
with purple against the ancient decree? to eat twice in the day as the
Tyrant Dennys did, to keep harlottes and concubines as they of Tire do, to
speak blasphemies against the gods which were never heard of before in the
empire? These said vices of Asia, Asia has presently sent to Rome.

At the same time when in those parties of the Orient, the war was kyndeled:
ten valyant capytaynes brought these vices to Rome, whose names my pen
shall pardone to tell, because their vile offenses should not obscure their
valiant deeds. Before that Rome conquered Asia we were rich, we were
pacyent, we were sober, we were wise, we were honest, and above all we
lived contented.

But since that time we have geeuen our selves to forgeat the polycyes of
Rome, and to learn the pleasure of Asia: so that now all vices may be learned
in Rome, as all sciences may be heard in Greece.

By the above rehearsed, all warlyke princes may see, what profit they have
to conquer strange realms. Let us now leave the vices, which in the wars
are recovered, and talk of money which the princes covet and love. And in
this I say, that there is no prince brought into so extreme poverty, as he
which conquereth a strange country.

O Cornelius, thou haste not seen how Princes more of a will then of
necessity do waste their treasoures: how they demand that of another
man's, and how their own does not suffyce them: they take those of
churches, they seek great lones, they invent great tributes, they demand
great subsidies, they geeue strangers occasion to speak, and make them selves
hated of their subjects: fynallye they pray their subjects, and humble
the^ selves to their enemies. Since I have declared the dommages of war, I
will now declare what the original of war is.

For it is impossible that the physician apply unto the sick agreeable
medecyne, if he know not of what humor the sickness does proceed.

Princes since they came of men, are noryshed with men, do counsel with
men, and live with men, and to conclude they are men. Sometime through
pride which abounds in them: sometime through want of counsel, they them
selves imagine, and other flatterers tells, that though they have much in
respect of other princes, yet they can do little. Also they say unto them,
that if their substance be great, their fame ought to be greater. Further
they tell the^, that the good prince ought little to esteem that he has
inherited of his predecessors, in respect of the great deal more he ought to
leave to his successors. Also they tell the^, yt never prince left of him any
great memory, but inue^ting see cruel war against his enemy. Also they tell
the^, yt ye hour that one is chosen emperor of Rome, he may boldly conquer
all the whole earth. These vain reasons being heard of the princes,
afterward as their fortune is base, and their minds high, immediately they
defye their enemies, they open their treasures, they assemble great armies:
and in ye end of all, the gods suffer, that they thinkinge to take an other
man's goods, they waste and lose their own. O princes, I know not who does
deceive ye, that you which by peace may be rich, and by war will be
poor?

O princes, I know not who does deceive you, that you which may be loved do
seek occasions to be hated. O princes, I know not who does begyle ye, that ye
which may enjoy a sure life, do adventure your selves to the mutabilitie of
fortune. O princes, I know not who does deceive you, that you so little
esteem and wey your own haboundaunce, and so greatly set by the want of
others. O princes, I know not who does deceive you, that all having need of
you, you should have need of others. I let thee to wete my Cornelius, though
a prince be more quick and careful then all other his predecessors have
been in Rome: yet it is impossible that all things touching war, should
succeed unto him prosperousely. For in the greatest need of war, either he
wants money, or his subjects do not succor him, or time is contrary unto
him, or he fyndeth perilous passages, he lacks artillarye, or ye Captains
rebel, or else succor comes to his adversaries: so that he sees him self
so miserable, that thoughts do more oppress his heart, then the enemies do
harm his land. Though a prince had no war, but for to suffer men of
war, yet he ought to take upon him no war. I ask thee my Cornelius, what
travail so great to his parsonne, or what greater dommage to his realm can
his enemies do, then that which his own men of war do? The enemies, to
do the worste they can, will but rob our frontiers: but our men of
war do rob all the whole country. The enemies we dare and may resist, but
to ours we cannot, nor dare not speak. The enemies, ye worst they can do, is
once in a month to rob and run their ways: but ours daily do rob, and
remayn still. The enemies fear their enemies only, but ours do fear their
enemies, and have no pity on their frids. The enemies, ye further they go on,
ye more they diminish: but ours ye further they go, ye more they increase. I
know no greater war yt princes can have, then to have men of war in their
realms. For as experience does show us, before ye gods they are culpable, to
princes importunate, and to ye people troublesome: so that they live to the
dommage of all, and to the profit of none. By the God Mars I swear unto thee
(my friend Cornelius) as he may direct my hands in the war, that I have
mo complaints in the Senate, of ye theftes which my captains do commit in
Illiria, then of all the enemies of the Romayne people. Both for that I say,
and for that I keep secret. I am more afraid to create an ensygne of twoe
hundred men of war, then to give a cruel battle to thirtye thousand
men. For that battle, fortune (good or evil) forthwith dispatcheth, but
with these I can be sure no time of all my life. Thou will say unto me
(Cornelius) that since I am Emperor of Rome, I should remedy this since I
know it. For that prince which dissembleth with the fault of another, by
reason he will condemn him, as if it were his own. To this I answer, that
I am not mighty enough to remedy it, except by my remedy there should spring
a greater inconvenience. And since thou have not been a Prince, thou could
not fall into that I have, nor yet understand that which I say. For princes by
their wisdom know many things, the which to remedy they have no power. So
it has been, so it is, so it shall be, so I found it, so I keep it, so will I
leave it them, so I have read it in books, so have I seen it with my eyes, so
I heard it of my predecessors, and finallye I say, so our fathers have
invented it, and so will we their children sustain it, and for this evil,
we will leave it to our heirs. I will tell thee one thing, and imagine that
I err not therein, which is, consideringe the great dommage, and little
profit, which the men of war do bring to our common wealth: I thynk to do
it, and to sustain it, either it is the folly of men, or a scourge given of
the gods. For there can be nothing more just, then for the gods to permit,
that we feel that in our own houses: which we cause others in strange
houses to lament. All those things I have written unto thee, not for that it
skilleth greatly that thou know them: but that my heart is at ease to utter
them: For as Alcibiades said, the chestes, and the hearts, ought always to
be open to their friends. Panutius my secretary, goes in my behalf to
visit that land, and I gave him this letter to give the, with two horses,
wherewith I think thou will be contented, for they are gennettes. The weapons
and riches which I took of the Parthes, I have now divided, notwtstanding I
do send thee.2. Chariottes of them. My wife Faustine greeteth thee, and I
send a rich glass for thy daughter, and a Jewel with stones for thy sister.
No more but I beseech the Gods to geeue thee a good life, and me a good death.

The admonition of the Aucthour to Princes and great Lords to the intent that
the more they grow in years, the more they are bound to refrain from vices.
Cap. xvii.
AVlus Gelius in his book De noctibus Atticis says, that there was an
ancient custom amongst the romans, to honor and have in great reverence
aged men. And this was so inuiolate a law amongst them, that there was none so
noble of blood and lynage, neither so puissaunt in riches, neither so
fortunate in battayles, that should go before the aged men, which were laden
with whit hears: so that they honored them as the gods, and reverenced them
as their fathers. Amongst other the aged men had these preheminences, that
is to wete, that in feasts they sat highest, in the triumphs they went
before, in the temples they did sit down, they spoke to the Senate before
all others, they had their garments surred, they might eat alone in secrat, and
by their only word they were credited as witnesses: Finally I say, that in
all things they served them, and in nothing they annoyed them. After the
people of Rome began war with Asia, they forsook all their good Romayne
customs immediatlye.

And the occasyon hereof was, that since they had no men to sustain the
common wealth, by reason of the great multitude of people which dyed in the
war: they ordained that all the young men should mary, the young maids, the
wydowes, the free, and the bond, and that the honor which had been done
until that time unto the old men, from henceforthe should be done unto the
married men, though they were young. So that the most honored in Rome was
he, not of most years, but he that had most children. This law was made a
little before the first battle of Catthage.

And the custom that the married men were more honored, then the old men,
endured until the time of the Emperor Augustus, which was such a friend of
antiquyties, that he renewed all the walls of Rome with new stones, and
renewed all the ancient customs of the common wealth. Licurgus in the laws
which he gave to the Lacedaemonians ordained that the young men passinge by
the old, should do them great reverence: and when the old did speak, then
the younger should be sylent.

And he ordained also, that if any old man by casualtye did lose his goods and
came into extreme poverty, that he should be sustained of the common wealth:
