and that in such sustentacion they should have respect, not only to succor
him for to sustain him, but further to give him to live competently. Plutarche
in his Apothegmes declares, that Cato the Censoure visitinge the corners of
Rome, found an old manne sittinge at his door weepinge, and sheddinge many
tears from his eyes. And Cato the Censoure demanding him why he was so
evil handeled, and wherefore he wept so bitterlye, the good old manne
answered him.

O Cato, the Gods being the only comfortours, comfort thee in all thy
tribulations, since thou art ready to comfort me at this woeful hour.

As well as thou know that the consolations of the heart are more
necessary, then the phisike of the body: the which being applied sometimes
does heal, and an other time they do harm. Behold my scabbed hands, my
swollen legs, my mouth without teethe, my peeled face, my white beard and my
balde head: for thou being (as thou art,) descreete, should be excused to
ask me why I weep.

For men of my age, though they weep not for the little they feel: yet
they ought to weep for the ouermuche they live. The manne which is laden with
years, tormented with diseases, pursued with enemies, forgotten of his
friends, visited with mishappes, and with evil will and poverty: I know not
why he demands long life? For there can be no sharper reuengeme^t of vices,
which we commit: then to give us long life.

Though now I am aged, I was young, and if any young manne should do me any
iniurye, truly I would not desire the gods to take his life, but that they
would rather prolonge his life. For it is a great pity, to hear the man
(which has lived long) account the troubles which he has endured.

Know thou Cato, if thou do not know it, that I have lived.77. years. And
in this time, I have buried my father, my graundefather, twoe Auntes and.5.
uncles. After that I had buried.9. systers, and.11. Brethren. I have buried
afterward, twoe lawful wyfes, and five bond women, which I have had as
my lemmans.

I have buried also.14. children, and.7. married daughters: and therewith not
contented, I have buried.37. Nephues, and.15. Nieces, and that which greaueth
me most of all is, that I have buried two friends of mine, one wc remained in
Capua, and the other wc was residente here at Rome. The death of whom has
grieved me more, then all those of my aliaunce and parentage. For in the world
there is no like loss to that, where a man loses him whom entierlye he loves
and of whom also he is derelye beloved. The fatal destenies ought to content
them selves, to have annoyed mye house with so many mysfortunes. But after all
this, and above all this, theye have left me a wicked nephewe, which shall
be mine heir, and theye have left unto me that all mye life I shall lament.
O Cato, for that thou owe to the common wealth I do desire thee, and by the
immortal gods I do conjure thee, that since thou art a virtuous Roman,
and censor of the people, that thou provide for one of these two things, that
is to wete, that this mye Nephewe do serve me, or else ordeine that I dye
forthewith. For it is a great crueltye that those do pursue me which are
alive, since it is now 40. years that I ceased not to bewail the dead. Cato
being well enfourmed of that the old man had told him, and since he found
all that true which he spoke, he called unto his presence the young Nephew, and
said unto him these words. If thou were such a child as thou ought to
be, thou should excuse me of pain, and thy self of travail. But since
it is not so, I pray thee take that patiently that I shall command thee:
and be thou assured, that I will not command thee any thing that shall be
against justice. For the vicious yonglinges (as thou art) ought to be more
ashamed of the youthefullnes theye have committed: then for the punishment
which is geeuen unto them.

First I command thou be whipte, because thou art dysobedyent, and
troublesome to thy graundefather,

Secondlye I command that thou be banished the limittes of Rome, because
thou art a vicious young man.

Thyrdly, I command that of all the goods thou have enherited, thou shall be
disenherited: because thou do not obey thy graundfather.

And the cause why I give such severe sentence is, to the end that from
he^sforthe the young shall not disobey the aged, and also that those which have
enheryted great treasours, shall not think that men shall permit them to be
more vicious, then others. Phalaris the tiraunt writing to a friend of his which
was very aged, said these words: the which rather seemed spoken of a
Philosopher then of a tirant. I have meruailed at thee and am offended with the
my friend Vetto, to know as I do, that in years thou art very aged, and in
works very young: and also it greeueth me that thou have lost the credit of
knoweledge in the schools. It greeueth me more, that through thee ye
privilege shoold be lost, which the old men have accustomed to have in Greece:
that is to wete, yt all the thieves, all the perjured, and all the murderers
were more sure, when by white hears theye seemed to be old: when they reteyred
to the aulters of the temples. O what goodness, O what wisdom. what
valyauntnes, and what innocencye ought the aged men to have in the ancient
time: since in Rome theye honored them as gods, and in Greece theye
priuileged those white hears as the temples. Pliny in an epistle he wrote to
Fabatus says, that Pirrus king of the Epirotes, demanded a philosopher which
was the best city of the world? who answered. The best city of the world,
is Molerda, a place of three hundredth fyers in Achaia: because all the walls
are of black stones, and all those which govern it have hoarye heads.

And further he said. Woe be unto thee Rome, Woe be unto thee Carthage, woe
be unto thee Numancia, woe be unto thee Egypt, and woe be unto thee Athens
five cytyes which count them selves for the best of the world, whereof I am
of a contrary oppynion.

For theye auaunte them selves to have white walls, and are not ashamed to
have young Senatoures. This philosopher said very well, and I think noe
manne will say less then I have said. Of this word Senex, is deryued the
name of a Senatoure, for so were the gouernoures of Rome named, because the
first King (that was Romulus) chose a hundred aged men to govern the common
wealth, and commanded, that all the other Romayne youth shoold employe them
selves to the wars.

Since we have spoken of the honor which in the old time was geeuen to the
ancient men, it is reason we know now, from what year they counted men
aged, to the end they shoolde be honored as aged men. For the makers of
laws, when they had established the honors which ought to be done to the
aged: did as well ordeyne, from what day and year, theye shoolde beeginne.
Diverse ancient Philosophers did put syx ages, from the time of the birth of
man, till the hour of death.

That is to wete, chyldehood, which lasts till seven years. Infancy, which
endures until seuentene years. Youth, wc continues till thirty years.
Man's estate, which remains till fyftye and five years. Age which endures
till three score and eyghtene years. Crooked age which remains till death.
And so after man had passed five and fyftye years, they called him aged. Aulus
Gelius in his tenth book, in the xxvii. Chapter says, that Tullius
Hostillius (who was king of the Romans) determined to count all the old and
young, which were amongst the people: and also to know which shoold be
called infaunts, which young, and which old. And there was noe little dyfference
amongst the Romayne Philosophers, and in the end it was decreed by the king,
and the Senate, that men till seventeen years shoold be called infaunts, and
till syx and forty shoold be called young, and from syx and forty vpwardes they
shoold be called old.

If we will observe the law of the Romans, we know from what time we are
bound to call and honor the aged men. But addyng hereunto it is reason that the
old men know, to what prowesses and virtues they are bound, to the end that
with reason, and not with faynyng, they be served. For speaking the truth, if
we compare duty to duty, they old men are more bound to virtue: then the young
to service. We can not denay, but that all states of natyons (great and small,
young and old) are bound to be virtuous: but in this case the one is more to
be blamed, then the other.

For oftentimes if the young do offend, it is for that he wants experience:
but if the old man offend, it is for the abundaunce of malice. Seneca in an
Epistle said these words. I let thee weete my friend Lucillus, that I am
very much offended, and I do complain, not of any friend or foe: but of my
self, and ^^^^e other. And the reason why I thynk thus, is that I see my self
old in years, and young in vices: so that little is that wherein I have served
ye gods, and much less is that I have profyted me^. And Seneca says further,
he which praysethe him self most to be aged, and that would be honored for
being aged: ought to be temperate in eatinge, honest in apparayle, sober in
drinking, soft in words, wise in counsel, and to conclude, he ought to
be very pacient in aduersytye, and far from vices which attempt him. Worthy
of praise is the great Seneca, for these words: but more worthy shall ye
old men be, if they will conform their works according to those words.

For if we see them abandon vices, and give them selves to virtues: we will
both serve them, and honor them.

That princes when they are aged, should be temperate in eating, sober in
drinking, modest in apparel, and above all, true in communicacion. Cap. xviii.
IT is consonaunt to the counsel of Seneca, that the aged should be
temperate in eating, which they ought to do, not only for the reputacion of
their persons: but also for the preseruacion of their lives. For the old men
which are drunk, and amarous, are persecuted with their own diseases, and are
defamed by the tongues of other. That which the ancient men should eat (I
mean those, which are noble, and virtuous) ought to be very clean, and well
dressed, and above all, that theye take it in ceason and time: for otherwise,
to much eatinge of diverse things, causes the young to be sick, and
enforces the old to dye. Young men though they eat dishonestly, very hastily,
and eat speakinge, we can do no less but dissemble with them: but the old
me^ which eat much, and hastelye, of necessity we ought to reprove them. For
men of honor ought to eat at the table with a great gravity: as if they were
in any counsel to determine causes. It is not my intention to persuade the
feeble old men not to eat, but to admonish them to eat no more then is
necessary. We do not prohibit them to eat delicate things, but to beware
of superfluous things. We do not counsale them to leave eatinge having need:
but to withdraw them selves from curiosyties. For though it be lawefull for
aged men to eat sufficient, it is not honest for them to eat to overcome
their stomakes. It is a shame to write it, but more shame ought they to have
which do it, which is, that the goods which theye have won and inheryted
by their predecessors, theye have eaten, and dronken: so that theye have
neither bought house, vine, nor yet married any daughter, but they are naked,
and their poor children go to the Tauernes and Innes: and the miserable
fathers to the Hospitalles, and churches. When any man comes to pouertye,
for that his house is burned, or his ship drowned, or that theye have taken
all from him by law, or that he has spent it in pleadyng against his enemy,
or any other inconvenience is come unto him: me thinks we all are bound
to succoure him, and the heart has compassion to beeholde him: but he that
spends it in apparaile not requysyte, to seek delitious wynes, and to eat
delicate meats, to such one I would say, that the pouertye he suffers is
not sufficient for his deserts. For of all troubles there is none so great,
as to see a man suffer the evil, whereof he himself has been the occasion.
Also according to the counsel of Seneca, the ancients ought to be well
advertised, in that they should not only be temperate in eating, but also they
shoolde be sober in drinking: and this both for the preseruacion of their
health, and also reputacion of their honestye.

For if the old Physicians do not deceive us, human bodies do dry and
corrupt because theye drink superfluously, and eat more then nature
requires. If I should say unto the old men, that theye should drink no
wine: theye might tell me, that it is not the counsel of a Christian. But
presuppose theye ought to drink, and that for noe oppynyon theye should
leave it: yet I admonyshe, exhort, and desire them, that theye drink little,
and that theye drink very temperate.

For the disordynate and immesurate drinking, causes young men to be drunk,
and the old men: both drunk and foolish. O how much authority lost
theye, and what grauytye do honorable and ancient men lose, which in
drynkinge are not sober. Which seems to be true, for as much as the man
beeinge laden with wine, though he were the wysest in ye world he should
be a very fool, that would take counsel of such one in his affairs.
Plutarche in a book which he made of the fortune of the Romans said: that
in the senate of Rome, there was an ancient manne, who made great
exclamacions, that a young man had in such sort dishonored him, that for
the injuries he had spoken, he deserved death.

And when the young manne was called for to answer to that he had said
unto him, he answered. Fathers conscripte, though I seem young unto you, yet
I am not so young, but that I knew the father of this old manne, who was a
virtuous and noble Romayne, and somewhat a kynne to me. And I seeing that his
father had gotten much goods fighting in the wars, and also seeinge this
old manne spending them in eating and drinking: I said unto him one day. I
am very sorye, my lord and uncle, for that I hear of thye honor in the
market place: and am the more sorye for that I see done in thy house, wherein
we saw fyftye men armed before in one hour, and we now see a hundredth knaves
made drunk.

And worse then that, as thye father showed to all those that entered his
house, the ensigns he had won in the wars: so now to those that enter
into thy house, thou show them diverse sorts of wynes. My uncle complained
of me, but in this case I make the plaintiff judge, against me the
defendaunt. And I woolde by the immortal gods, he deserved noe more pain
for his works: then I deserve by my words.

For if he had been wise, he would have accepted the correction which
secretlye I gave him: and had not come openly, to declare his faults in the
Senate. The complaynte of the old manne beeinge heard by the Senate, and the
excuse in like manner of the young man: they gave judgment, that theye shoolde
take all the goods from the old manne, and provide him of a tutour which
should govern him and his house.

And theye commanded the tutoure, that from hence forward he shoolde not
geeue him one cup of wine, since he was noted of drunkenness. Of truth the
sentence which the Senate gave was very just. For the old manne which
geeueth him self to wine, has as much need to have a gouernoure, as an
infaunte, or a fool. Laettius made a book of the feasts of Philosophers, and
declarethe sundry auncyente bankettes, among the which he puts one, where
were assembled many great philosophers. And admit that the meats were mean,
and simple: yet the bidden gestes were sage. And the cause why they did
assemble, was not to eat: but to dispute of some grave doctrines, whereof the
philosophers did somewhat doubt: For in those days, the greater ye Stoikes
and the Peripatetikes were in number: so much the more were the philosophers
divided amongst them selves. When they were so assembled, truly they did not
eat, nor drink out of measure: but some pleasant matter was moved between
the masters and the scollers, between the young and the old, that is to wete,
which of them could declare any secret of phylosophye, or any profound
sentence. O happy were such feasts, and no less happy were they that thither
were bidden.

But I am sorry that those which now bid, and those that are bidden, for a
troth are not as those ancients were. For there are noe feasts now adays of
philosophers, but of gluttons, not to dispute, but to murmour, not to open
doubtful things, but to talk of the vices of others, not to confirm
aunciente amities, but to begin new dissensions, not to learn any
doctrines, but to approve some nouelty. And that which worste of all is, that
the old strive at the table with the young, not on him which has spoken the
most grauest sentence: but of him which has drunk most wine, and has
rinsed most cups. Paulus Diaconus in the historye of the Lumbardes
declarethe, yt four old Lumbardes made a banquet, in the which the one drank
to the others years, and it was in this manner. Theye made defyaunce to drink
two to twoe and after each man had declared how many years old he was: the
one dra^ke as many times as the other was years old, and likewise his
companion pledged him. And one of these four companions had at the least. 58.
years: the second.63 the third.87. the fourth.812. so that a man knowethe
not what they did eat in this banquet, either little or much: but we know that
he that drank least, drank 58. cups of wine.

Of this so evil custom came the Goths to make this law, which of many is
read, and of few understood, where it says. We ordeyn and commau^d on
pain of death, that no old man drink to the others years being at the
table. That was made because they were so much given to wine, that they drank
more often, then they did eat morselles. The Princes and great Lords which
are now old, ought to be very sober in drinking, since theye ought
greatly to be regarded and honored of the young.

For speakinge the truth, and with liberty, when the old man shallbee
overcome with wine, he has more necessity that the young man lead him by the
arm to his house: then that he should take of his cappe unto him or speak
unto him with reverence. Also princes and great lords ought to be very
circumspecte, that whenne theye become aged, theye be not noted for young, in
the apparayle which theye wear: For although that for wearinge a fine and
rich garmente, the prince does not enriche or enpouerishe his common wealth:
yet we cannot deny, but that it does much for the reputacion of his person.
For the vanytie and curiosity of garments, does show great lightness of
mind. According to the varietye of ages, so ought the diversity of apparaile
to be, which semethe to be very clear, in that the young maids are
attyred in one sort, the married women of an other sort, the widows of an
other. And likewise I would say, that the apparayle of children ought to be
of one sort, those of young men of an other, and those of old men of an
other, which ought to be more honester then all.

For men of hoarye heads, ought not to be adourned with precious garments:
but with verteous works. To go cleanlye, to be well apparayled, and to be
well accompanied, we do not forbydde the old, especially those which are
noble, and valiant men: but to go to fine, to go with great traynes, and to
go very curious, we do not allow. Let the old men pardon me, for it is
not the office but of young fools: For the one shows honestye, and the other
lightness. It is a confusion to tell it, but it is greater shame to do it, that
is to weete, that many old men of our time take noe small felicitye, to put
caules on their heads, every manne to wear jewels on their necks, to lay
their cappes with agglettes of gold, to seek out diverse inuencions of
metal to load their fingers with rich ringes, to go perfumed with
odiferous favors, to wear new fashioned apparayle, and fynallye I say,
that though their face be full of wrincles, they can not suffer one wrincle
to be in their gown. All the ancient historiens, accuse Quintus Hottensius
the Romayne, for that every time when he made him self ready, he had a
glass before him: and as much space and time had he to streyghten the
plaites of his gown: as a woman had to trymme the hears of her head. This
Quintus Hortensius being Consul, going by chance one day through Rome, in a
narrow streat met with the other Consul, where through the streightnes of
the passage the plaightes of his gown wear undone: upon which occasion he
complained to the senate of the other Consul, that he had done him a great
iniurye, saying that he deserved to lose his life. The authoure of all this is
Macrobius: in the third book of the Saturnales. I can not tell if I be
deceived, but we may say, that all the curiositye that old men have to go
fine, well appareled, and clean, is for no other thing but to shake of age,
and to pretend right to youth. What a grief is it to see diverse ancient
men, the which as ripe figs do fall: and on the other side it is a wonder to
see how in their age they make them selves young. In this case I say, would
to god we might see them hate vices, and not to complain of the years which
theye have. I pray and exhort princes and great lords, whom our sovereign
lord has permitted to come to age, that theye do not despise to be aged.
For speaking the truth, the man which has envy to seem old, does delight
to live in the lightness of youth. Also man of honor ought to be very
circumspecte, for so much as after theye are beecome aged, theye be not
suspected of their friends, but that both unto their friends and foes, they be
counted faithful. For a lie in a young man's mouth, is but a lie: but in the
mouth of an old manne: it is a heinous blasphemye. Princes and great lords
after they are become aged, of one sort they ought to use them selves to
give, and of the other to speak. For good princes ought to sell words by
weighte, and geeue rewards without measure. The ancient oftentimes
complain, saying, that the young will be not conuersaunt with them: and
truly if there be any fault therein, it is of them selves. And the reason is,
that if sometimes theye do assemble togethers to pass away the time, if the
old man set a talkinge he never makes an end. So that a discrete man had
rather go.xii. miles on foot: then to hear an old man talk three hours. If
with such efficacy we persuade old men, that they be honest in their
apparaile: for a truth we will not give them license to be dissolute in their
words, sins there is a great difference to note some man in his apparaile, or
to accuse him to be malicious or a bablet. For to wear rich apparayle,
iniuryeth few: but injurious words hurt many. Macrobius in the first book
of the dreams of Scipio, declares of a philosopher named Crito, who lived a
hundredth and five years: and till fyltye years he was far out of course:
Butte after he came to be aged, he was so well measured in his eating and
drinking, and so ware in his speech, that they never saw him do any thing
worthy reprehension: nor heard him speak word, but was worthy of notynge. On
this co^dicio^ we would give license to many, ye till fifty years they should
be yo^g: so that from thence forth they would be clothed as old men, speak as
old me^ and they should esteem them selves to be old. But I am sorye that all the spring time does pass in flower, and afterward they fall into the grave
as rotten, before they find any time to pull them out. The old do complain
yt the young do not take their advise: and their excuse herein is, that in
their words theye are to long. For if a man do demand an old man his
opynion in a case, immediatelye he will begin to say, that in the life of
such, and such kings and lords of good memory, this was done, and this was
provided. So that when a young man ask them counsel, how he shall behave
him self with the lyuinge: the old man begins to declare unto him, the
life of those which be dead.

The reason why the old men desire to speak so long is that since for
their age they can not see, nor go, nor eat, nor sleep, they would that al
yt time their members wear occupied to do their duties, all that time their
tongue should be occupied to declare of their times past. All this being
spoken, what more is to say I know not, but that we should content our
selves, that the old men should have their flesh as much punished: as they
have their tongue with talk martired. Though it be very vile for a young man to
speak, and slander to a young manne not to say the truth: yet this vice is
much more to be abhorred in old princes, and other noble and worshipful me^,
which ought not only to think it their duty to speak truth, but also to
punish the enemies thereof. For otherwise the noble and valiant knights
should not lose a little of their authority, if a man saw on their
heads but white hears, and in their mouths found nothing but lies.

Of a letter of the Emperor, Marcus Aurelius, to Claudius and Claudinus,
reprouinge them being old men, for that they lived youthefullye. Cap. xix.
Mark Emperor, borne in mount Celio, desires to you my neighbors,
Claude and Claudine, health of your persons, and amendment of your lives.
I beeinge as I am at the conquest of Asia, and you remaining always in the
pleasures of Rome, we understand your news very late, and I think our
letters arrive there as late. Notwithsta^dynge to all those which go thither,
I geeue aunsweres for you others: and of al those which come hither, I demand
of your health. And do not demand of others, how well, and how much I
love you, but of your own proper hearts: and if your heart say that I am a
feyned friend, then I take my self condemned. If perchance your hearts
does tell you that I love you, being true in deed that I hate you, or if I
tell you that I hate you, beeinge true that I love you: of truth I would
pluck such a heart out of my body, and give it to be eaten of the beasts.
For there is noe greater dysceyte, then that which the man does to him self.
If a stranger begile me, I ought to dissemble it: if an enemy deceive me, I
ought to revenge it: if mye fryend misuse me, I ought to complain of him: but
if I do deceive my self: with whom shall I comfort my self? For there is no
patience that can suffer the heart to deceive him self in any thing, which
he has not deeply considered. Peradventure ye will say that I do not
esteame you, and that I have not written any letter unto you of long time. To
this I answer. That you do not attrybute the fault to mye negligence, but
to the great distaunce of Countries that there is from hence to Rome: and also
to the great affairs of Asia, For amongst other discommodities the war
has this also, that it depriueth us of the sweet conversation of our
country. I have always presumed to be youres, and at this present am at no
man's pleasure, more then at yours. And sins you have always known of me,
what you desired to know, I have espied in you others that, which of force I
must speak. For in the end I have not seen any possess so much, to be worth
so much, to know so much, nor in all things to be so mighty, but that one day
he should need his poor friend. The divine Plato said, and also well,
that the manne which louethe with his heart, neither in absence forgets,
neither in presence becomes negligent, neither in prosperity he is proud,
nor yet in adversity abject, neither he serves for profit, nor yet he loves
for gain: and fynallye he defendethe the case of his friend as his own.
Diverse have been the opinions which the ancients held to affirm for what
end friends were taken, and in the end they were fully resolved, that for.4.
causes we ought to chose frindes. The first we ought to have friends, to
treat and be conversant with all: for according to the troubles of this life,
there is no time so pleasauntlye consumed, as in the conversation of an assured
friend. The second is, we ought to have friends to whom we may disclose the
secrets of our hearts for it is much comfort to the woeful heart, to declare
to his fryende his doubts, if he perceive that he does feel them in deed. The
third, we ought to search and chose friends, to thend they help us in our
adversities. For little profytethe it my heart that with tears the friends do
hear all that I bewail, unless afterward in deed he will take pains to
refourme the same.

The fourth, we ought to seek and preserve frindes to thend they be protectors
of our goods, and likewise judges of our euilles: for the good frinde is no
less bound to withdraw us from the vices, whereby we are sclaundered: then to
deliver us from our enemies, by whom we may be slain. The end why I told
you all this was, if that in this letter you chance to light of any sharp
word, that you take it patiently, considering that the love which I bear
you, does move me to speak, and the faith which I owe unto you, does not
suffer me that I should keep it close. For many things ought to be borne
among friends, though theye tell them in earnest: which ought not to be
suffered of others, though theye speak it in gest. I come therefore to show
the matter, and I beseech the immortal gods that there be noe more then
that which was told me, and that it be less then I suspecte. Gaius Furius
your kinsman and my especial friend, as he went to the realm of Palestyne,
and Jerusalem, came to see me in Antioche, and has told me news of Italy
and Rome, and among others, one above all the residewe I have committed to
memory, at the which I coolde not refrain laughinge, and less to be
troubled after I had thought of it. O how many things do we talk in
gest, the which after we have well considered, geeue occasion to be sorye.
The emperor Adrian mye good lord, had a Iester whose name was Belphus young,
comelye, and stout, allbeeit he was very malicious as such are accustomed
to be: and whiles the imbassadours of German supped with the Emperor in
great joy, the same Belphus beeganne to jest of every one that was present,
according to his accustomed manner with a certain malicious grace. And Adrian
perceiving that some changed color, others murmured, and others wear angrye,
he said unto this Iester, frinde Belphus if thou love me and mye service,
use not these spytefull iestes at our supper, which being considered on, may
turn us to evil rest in our beds. Gaius Furius has told me so many
slanders chanced in Italy, such novelties done in Rome, such alteracion of
our Senate, such contention and strife between our neighbors, such lightness
of you two, that I was astonished to here it, and ashamed to writ it. And it is
nothing to tell after what sort he told the^ unto me, unless you had seen how
earnestly he spoke them, imagining yt as he told the^ without taking any
pain, so did I receive them (as he thought) with out any grief: though in
deed every word that he spoke, seemed a sharp percinge arrowe unto my
heart. For often times some tells us things, as of small importance, the
which do prick our hearts to the quick By the oppynion of all, I understand
that you are very old, and yet in your own fantasies, you seame very young.
And further theye say, that you apparel your selves a new now, as though
presentlye you came into the world: and moreover they say that you are
offended with nothing so much, as when theye call you old, and that in
theaters where comedies are played, and in the fields where the brute beasts
do run, you are not the hindmost, and that there is no sport nor lightness
invented in Rome, but first is registered in your house. And finally they say
that you give your selves so to pleasures, as though you never thought to
receive displeasures. O Claude and Claudine, by the god Jupiter I swear unto
you, that I am a shamed of your unshamefastness, and am greatly abashed of your
manners, and above all, I am excedingly grieved for your great offense. For at
that time that you ought to lift up your hands, you are returned again into
the filth of the world Many things men commyt, which though they seem grave:
yet by moderacion of the person that commits them, they are made light, but
speaking according to the truth, I find one reason, wherebye I might excuse
your lightness, but to the contrary I see ten wherebye I may condemn
your follyes. Solon the philosopher in his laws said to the Athenians, that
if the young offended, he should be gentlye admonished, and grieuouslye
punished, because he was strong: and if the old did err, he should be
lightlye punished, and sharpelye admonished, sith he was weak, and feeble. To
this Licurgus in his laws to the Lacedaemonians said contrary, that if the
young did offend, he should be lightly punished, and grievously admonished,
sins through ignorance he did err: and the old manne which did evil,
should be lightly admonished, and sharply punished, sins through malice he
did offend. These two philosophers being (as theye have been) of such
authority in the world that is paste, and consideringe that their laws and
sentences were of such weighte: it should be much rashenesse in not
admittinge the one of them. Now not receyuyng the one, nor reprouynge the
other, me thinks that there is great excuse to the young for their
ignorance, and great condempnacion oath aged for their experience. Once
again I return to say that you pardone me, mye friends, and you ought not
greatly to weye it, though I am somewhat sharp in condempnation, since you
others are so dissolute in your lives: for of your black life, mye pen
does take ynke. I remember well that I have hard of thee Claude, that thou
haste been lusty and courageous in thye youth: so that thye strength of all
was enuyed, and the beauty of Claudine of all men was desired. I will not write
unto you in this letter, mye frindes and neigheboures, neither reduce to
memory, how thou Claude haste employed thy forces in the service of the
common wealth: and thou Claudine have wo^ne much honor of thy beautye: for
sundry times it chanced, that men of many goodlye gifts, are noted of
grievous offenses. Those which striued with thee are all dead, those whom thou
desiredst are dead, those which served thee Claudine are dead, those which
before thee Claudine sighed, are dead: those which for thee died, are now
dead: and sins all those are dead with their lightness, do not you others
think to dye, and your follyes also? I demand now of thy youth one
thing, and of thy beauty another thing, what do you receive of these
pastimes, of these good interteinmentes, of these abundances, of these great
contentacions, of the pleasures of the world, of the vanytye that is paste,
and what hope you of all these to carye into the narrow grave? O simple,
simple, and ignorant persons, how our life consumes, and we perceive not
how we live therein. For it is no felicity to enjoy a short, or long life:
but to know to employe the same well, or evil. O children of the earth, and
disciples of vanytie, now you know that time flyethe without moving his
wings, the life goes without liftinge up his feet, the world dispatcheth
us not tellinge us the cause, men beegile us not mouinge their lips, our
flesh consumes to us unawares, ye heart dies having no remedy, and finally our
glory decays as if it had never been, and death oppresses us without
knockinge at the door. Though a man be never so simple, or so very a fool:
yet he can not denaye, but it is impossible to make a fire in the botome of the
sea, to make a way in the air, of the thin blood to make roughe sinews,
and of the soft veins to make hard bones. I mean that it is impossible,
that the grene flower of youth, be not one day withered by age.

The Emperor followethe his letter and persuades Claudins and Claudinus
being now old, to give no more credit to the world, nor to any of his
deceytful flatteries. Cap. xx.
THat which I have spoken now, tends more to aduertyse the young, then to
teach the old. For you others have now passed the pryme time of chyldehoode,
the summer of youth, and the harvest of adolescency, and are in the winter of
age, where it seems an uncomely thing, that those youerhoarye hears, shoolde
be accompanied with such vain follyes. Sythens young men know not that they
have to end their youth, it is no maruail that they follow the world: but the
old men which see them selves fall into this gyle, why will they run after
vices again? O world, for that thou art the world, so small is our force, and
so great our debylitie, that thou wylling it, and we not resisting it, thou
do swallow us up in the most perilous goulfe, and in the thorns most sharp
thou do prick us: by the pryuiest ways thou leadest us, and by the most
stony ways thou caryest us. I mean yt thou bring us to the highest favors,
to the end that afterward with a push of thy pike thou myghtest overthrow us.
O world, wherein all is worldly, two and fyfty years have passed since in thee
I was first borne, during which time thou never toldest me one truth: but I
have taken thee with ten thousaund lies. I never demanded the thing but thou
did promise it me, and yet it is nothing at all that ever thou dydst
perform. I never put my trust in thee, but ever thou begildst me. I never
came to thee, but thou dydst undo me, finally never saw I ought in thee
whereby thou deseruest love, but allways hatred. This presupposed, I know not
what is in thee O world, or what we worldlyngs want: for if thou hate us,
we cannot hate the, if thou do us injury, we can dyssemble it, if thou
spurn us with thy feet, we will suffer it, if thou beatest us with a staff, we
will hold our peace, also although thou persecutest us, we will not co^playn,
though thou take ours, we will not demand it of thee, though thou do
beeguyle us, we will not call our selves beeguyled, and the woorst of al is,
that thou do chase us from thy house, yet we will not depart from thence. I
know not what this means, I know not from whence this comes, I wore not who
ought to praise this same, yt we covet to follow ye world, wc will none of us,
and hate ye gods wc love us: often times I make account of my years past,
sometimes also I turn and toss my book to see what I have read, and another
time I desire my friends to geeue me good counsel: and for no other end I do
it, then to attain to that I have spoken, and to know that I will say. I readyng
Rethoryk in Rhodes, Adrian my lord mainteynyng me there, knowing yt I was two
and thyrty years of age, it happened, that in the spryng time I found my self
solytaryly, and solytarines with lyberty smelled the world, and smelling it, I
knew it, and knowing it, I followed it, and followyng it, I attained unto it,
and attaynyng unto it, thereunto I joined my self, and joining my self
therewith, I proved it, and in prouyng it, I tasted it, and in tastyng it me
thought it bitter, and in fyndyng it bitter I hated it, and hatyng it I left
it, and leauyng it is returned, and being returned, I received it again:
finally the world inuytyng me, and I not resistyng it two and fyfty years we
did eat our bread togethers, and in one house we have always remained, will thou know after what sort ye world and I do live in one house togethers, or
better to say, in one heart remain? harken the^, and in one word I will tell it
thee. When I saw the world brave, I served him, when he saw me sad, he
flattered me, when I saw him wealthy, I asked him, when he saw me merye, he
begiled me, when I desired any thing, he help me to atteine to it, and
afterward when the same I best enjoyed, then he took it from me, when he saw
me not pleased, he vysited me, when he saw me, he forgot me, when he saw me
overthrown, he gave me his hand to releue me, when he saw me exalted, he
tripped me again to overthrow me. Finally, when I think that I have somewhat in
the world, I find yt all that I have is a burden. If this which I have spoken
of the world be any thing, more is that a great deal which yet of my self I
will say, which is, that without doubt my follye is greater, then his
malice, since I am begiled so often, and yet allwaies I follow the deceiuer O
world, world, thou have such moodes and fashions in thy procedyng, that thou
leadest us all to perdicion. Of one thing I marvel much, whereof I cannot
be satisfied. Which is, since that we may go upon the bridge, and yet without
any gain we do wade through the water, and where as the shallow is sure, we
seek to run into the golfe, and where the way is dry, we go into the
plashe, where we may eat wholesome meats to norishe the life, we receive
poison to hasten death, we seek to destroy our selves, where as we may be
without danger. Fynallye I say, without profit we commit a fault, though we
see with our eyes the pain to follow. Wise men ought circumspectly to see what
they do, to examine that they speak, to prove that theye take in hand to
beware whose company they use, and above all, to know whom they trust. For our
judgment is so corrupt, that to begile us, one is enough: and to make us not
to be disceiued, ten thosande woolde not suffice. They have so great care of
us, I mean the world to beegile us, and the flesh to flatter us, that the
high way being as it is narrow, the patheway dangerous, and full of
pricks, the journey is long, and the life short: our bodies are never but
laden with vices, and our hearts but full of cares. I have wondered at diverse
things in this world, but that which astonieth me most is, that those yt be
good, we make the^ believe they are evil: and those which are euel, we
persuade others to believe that they are good. So that we shoot at the white
of virtues, and hit the butte of vices. I will confess one thing, the which
being disclosed, I know that infamye will follow me, but paraduenture some
virtuous man will marvel at it, that is, that in those two and fiftye years
of my life, I have proved all the vices of this world, for no other intent,
but for to prove if there be any thing, where in man's malice might be
satisfied. And afterward, all well considered, al examined, and all proved, I
find, that the more I eat, the more I dye for hunger, the more I drink, the
greater thirste I have, the more I rest, the more I am broken, the more I
sleep, the more drousier I am, the more I have, the more I covet, the more I
desire, the more I am tormented, the more I procure, the less I attain.
Finally I never had so great pain through want, but afterward I had more
trouble with excess. It is a great follye to think that as long as a man
lives in this flesh, that he can satisfye the flesh: for at the last cast
she may take from us our life, but we others can not take from her her
disordynate covetousness. If men did speak with the gods, or the gods were
conversant with men, the first thing that I woold ask the^ shoold be, why they
have appointed an end to our woeful days: and will not give us an end of our
wicked desires? O cruel Gods, what is it you do? or what do you suffer us? it
is certain, that we shall not pass one good day of life only, but in tasting
this, and that, life consumes. O intolerable life of man, wherein there are
such malices from ye which we ought to beware, and such perils to fall in, and
also so many things to consider, that then both she and we do end to know our
selves when the hour of death approaches. Let those know that know not, that
the world takes our will, and we others like ignorauntes cannot denay it him,
and afterward having power of our will, does constrain us to that which we
would not: so that many times we would do virtuous works, and for that we are
now put into the worlds hands, we dare not do it. The world uses another
subtiltye with us, that to the end we should not strive with it, it prayseth
the times past, because we should live according to the time present. And the
world says further, that if we others employ our forces in his vices, he
gives us license that we have a good desire of virtue. O would to god in my
days I might see, that the care which the world has to preserve us, the
wordlyngs would take it to withdraw the^ from his vices. I swear that the gods
should then have more servants and the world and the flesh should not have
so many slaves.

The Emperor proceeds in his letter, and proves by good reasons, that sith
the aged persons will be served and honored of the young: they ought to be more
virtuous and honest then the young. Cap. xxi.
I Have spoken all this before rehearsed, for occasion of you Claude, and
Claudine, the which at.3. score and 10. years will not keep out of the prison
of the world: You I say, which have your bodies weak and corrupted, what hope
shale we have of young men which are but.25. years of age? if my memory
deceive me not, when I was there, you had nephews married, and of their
children made sure, and two of the children borne: and since that is true, me
thinks when ye fruit is gathered, the leaf is of no value, and after the
meal is taken from the mylle, evil shall the mil grind.

I mean, that the old man ought to desire, that his days might be shortened in
this world. Do not think my friends, that a man can have his house full of
nephews, and yet say that he is very young? for in lodi^ge ye tree with fruits,
the blossoms immediately fall, or else they become wythered. I have imagined
with my self, what it is that you might do to seem young, and cut of some of
your years: and in the end I know no other reason, but when you married
Alamberta your daughter with Drusus, and your near Sophia the fair, with
Tuscidan, which were so young, that the daughters were scarce, 15. years old,
nor the young me^.20. I suppose because you were ritche of years, and poor of
money, that he gave to every on of them in steed of money for dowrye, 20.
years of yours, hereof a man may gather, that ye money of your nephews have
remained unto you, and you have given unto them of your own years: I
understand my friends, that your desire is to be young, and very young, but I
greatly desire, to see you old, and very old. I do not mean in years, which
in you does surmount: but in discrecion, which in you does want. O Claud and
Claudine, note that which I will say unto you, and bear it always in your
memory. I let you wete, that to maintain youth, to deface age, to live
contented, to be free from trauayles, to lengthen life, and to avoid death:
these things are not in the hands of men which do desire them, but rather
in the hands of those which gives them the which according to their justice,
and not to our covetousness, do give us life by weight, and death without
measure. One thing the old men do, which is cause of slaunderinge many, that
is, that they will speak first in counsels, they wylbe served of the young in
feasts, they will be first placed, in all that they say they will be
believed, in churches they will be higher then the resydue, in distributinge of
offices they will have the most honor, in there opinyons they will not be
gain said, fynallye, they will have the credit of old sage men, and yet they
will lead the life of young dotynge fools. All these premynences and
pryuileges, it is very just that old men should have spent their years in
the service of the common wealth: but with this I do advise and require
them, that the auctority given them with their white hears, be not dyminyshed
by their evil works.

Is it a just thing, that the humble and honest young man do reverence, to
the aged man proud, and dysdaynefull? is it a just thing, that the gentle
and gracious young man do reverence, to the envious, and malycious old man? is
it a just thing, that the virtuous, and pacyent young man do reverence, to the
foolish, and vnpacyente old man? is it a just thing, that the stout and
liberal young man do reverence, to the miserable, and covetous old man? is
it just, that the dylygente and careful young man do reverence, to the
neglygente old man? Is it just that the abstynent and sober young man do
reverence, to the greedye, and gluttonous old man? Is it just, that the
chaste, and contynente young man do reverence, to the lecherous, and dyssolute
old man? Me thinks these things should not be such, that thereby the old
man should be honored: but rather reproved, and punyshed. For old men offend
more, by the euel example they give, then by ye fault which they do commit.
Thou canste not denaye me, my friend Claude, that it is thirtye and three years
sithe we both were at the Theathers to behold a play, when thou came late,
and found no place for thee to sit in, thou sayedst unto me who was set, rise
my son Mark, and since now thou art young, it is but just that thou give
me place which am aged. If it be true, that it is xxxiii. years since thou
askedst place in the theathers as and old man, tell me I pray thee, and also
I conjure thee, with what oyntement have thou anointed thy self, or with what
water have thou washed thy self to become young? O Claude, if thou had
found any medicyne, or dyscouered any herb, where with thou could take
white hears from men's heads and from women the wrincles of their face: I
swear unto thee and also I do assure thee, that thou shooldest be more
vysyted and served in Rome, then the god Apollo is in his Temple at Ephesus.
Thou should well remember Annius priscus the old man, which was our
neighbor, and somewhat a kin to thee, the which when I told him that I
could not be filled with his good words, and to behold his ancient white
hears, he said unto me. O my soon Mark, it appears well yt thou have not been
aged because you talkest as a young man: for if white hears do honor ye person,
they greatly hurt the heart. For at that hour when they se us aged, the
strangers do hate us, and ours do not love us. And he told me more, I let the
wete my son Mark, that many times my wife, and I talking of the years of
another perticularly, when she beholds me, and that I seem unto her so
aged, I say unto her, and swear that I am yet yo^ge, and that the white hears
came unto me by great travails, and the age by sickness. I do remember also,
that this Annius Priscus was senator one year: and because he would not
seem aged, but desired that men should judge him too be young: he shaued his
bearde and his head, which was not accustomed among the senators nor
Censours of Rome. And as one day amongst the other Senators he entered into
the high Capitolle, one said unto him. Tell me man, from whence come thou?
What will thou? and why come thou hither? how durst thou being no senator
enter into the Senate? he answered. I am Annius priscus the aged, how
chau^ceth it that now you have not known me? they replied unto him, if thou
werte Annius Priscus thou would not come thus shaven. For in this sacred
senate can none enter to govern the common wealth: unless his parso^ be
endued with virtues, and his head with white hears, and therefore thou art
banished and deprived of thy office. For the old which live as ye young, ought
to be punished. Thou know well Claude, and Claudine, yt that which I have
spoken, is not the faynyng of Homere, neither a fable of Ouide, but that you
your selves saw it with your eyes, and in his banishment I did help him with
money, and more over he was banished another time for the lightness he did
commit in the night in the city, and I marvel not hereof: for we see by
experyence, that old men which are fleashed in vices, are more obstinate to
correct then the young. O what evil fortune have the old men, which suffered
them selves too wax old in vices: for more dangerous is the fire in an old
house, then in a new, and a great cut of a sword is not so perilous, as a
rotten fistule. Though old men were not honest and virtuous, for the service of
the gods and the common wealth, for the saying of ye people, nor for the
example of the young: yet he ought to be honest, if it wear but for the
reverence of their years. If the pore old man have noe teeth, how shall he
eat? If he have no heat in his stomach, how can he dysgest? If he have no
taste, how can he drink? if he be not strong, how can he be an adulterer? If
he have no feet, how can he go? If he have the palsy, how can he speak?
if he have the gout in his hands how can he play. Finally, such like
wordlye and vicyous men, have employed their forces being young, desirous to
prove al these vices: and when they are old it greueth them extreamelye that
they can not as yet acco^pplishe their desiers.

Amongst all the faults in old men (in my opinion) this is the chefest, that
since they have proved al things, that they shoold still remain in their
obstinat folly. There is no part but they have travailed, no villainy but they
have assayed, no fortune but they have proved, no good but they have
persecuted, no evil but has chanced unto the^, nor there is any vice but they
have attempted. These unhappy men which in this sort have spent all their
youth, have in ye end their combs cut with infirmities, and diseases: yet they
are not so much grieved with the vices (which in them do abound) to hinder them
from virtues, as they are tormented for want of corporal courage, to further
them in their lusts. O if we were gods, or that they would geeue us license to
know the thoughts of the old, as we see with our eyes the deeds of the young I
swear: to ye God Mars, and also to the mother Berecinthe, that without
comparison, we woold punish more the wicked desiers which the aged have to be
wicked: then the light deeds of the young. Tell me Claude, and you Claudine, do
you think though you behave your selves as young, you shall not seem to be old?
know you not that our nature is the corruption of our body, and that our body
hinders our understandings, and that the vnderstandyngs are kept of our
soul, and yt our soul is ye mother of desiers and yt our desiers are ye
scourge of our youth, and that our youth, is ye ensign of our age and age the
spy of death, and that death in the end is the house where life takes his
herber, and from whence youth flies a foot, and from whence age can not escape
a horsback? I woold rejoice that you Claude, and Claudine, woolde tell me what
you find in life that somuche therewith you should be contented: since now you
have passed four score years of life, during the which time either you have
been wicked in the world, or else you have been good. If you have been good, you
ought to think it long until you be with the good gods: if you have been evil,
it is just you dye, to the end you be no worse. For speaking the truth, those
which in.3. score and 10 years have been wicked in woorks, leave small hope of
their ame^dment of life. Adrian my lord, being at Nola in Campania, one brought
unto him a nephew of his from the study, where as the young child had not
profyted a little: for he became a great Gretian and latinest, and more over he
was fair, gracious, wise and honest. And this Emperor Adrian loved his nephew
so much, yt he said unto him these words My nephew, I know not whither I
ought to say unto thee, yt thou art good, or evil: for if thou be evil, life
shall be evil imployd on thee, and if thou be good, thou ought to die
imediatly, and because I am woors the^ all, I live longer then all. These
words which Adrian my lord said, do plainly declare and express, that in
short space ye pale and cruel death does assault the good, and le^gthneth life
a great while to the evil. The opinion of a philosopher was, that the gods are
so profound in their secrets, high in their misteryes, and so just in their
woorks, that to men which least profit the common wealth, they lengthen life
longest: and though he had not said it, we others see it by experience. For the
man which is good, and that bears great zeal and friendship to the common
wealth, either the gods take him from us, or the enemies do sley him, or the
dangers do cast him away, or the the travails do finish him. When great
Pompeius and Julius Caesar became enemies, and from that enmite came to cruel
wars, the cronicles of that time declare, that the kings and people of the
occidental part became in the favor of Julius Caesar, and the mightiest and
most puisaunte of all the oriental parts, came in the aid of great Pompeius,
because these two Princes were loved of few, and served and feared of al.
Amongst the diversity and sundry nations of people, which came out of the
oriental part, into the host of the great Pompeius, one nation came marvelous
cruel and barbarous, which said they dwelled in the other side of the mountayns
Riphees, which go unto India. And these barbarous had a custom, not to live no
longer then fifty years: and therefore when they came to yt age, they made a
greater fire and were burned therein alive, and of their own wills they
sacrificed them selves to the gods. Let no man be astoined at that we have
spoken but rather let them marvel of that we will speak (that is to say) that
the same day that any man had accomplished fifty years, immediately he cast him
self quick in to the fire, and the parents, children, and his friends, made a
great feast. And the feast was, that they did eat the fleash of the dead half
burned, and drank in wine and water the ashes of his bones: so that the stomak
of the children being alive, was the grave of the fathers being dead. All
this that I have spoken with my tongue, Pompeius has seen with his eyes for
that some being in ye camp did accomplish fifty years, and because ye case was
strange, he declared it often times in the Senate. Let every man judge in this
case what he will, and condemn the barbarous at his pleasure, yet I will not
cease too say what I think. O golden world, which had such men. O blessed
people, of whom in the world to come shall be a perpetual memory. What contempt
of world? what forgetfulness of him self? what stroke of fortune? what whip for
the flesh? what litell regard of life? O what bridell for the veruous? O what
confusion for those that love life? O how great example have they left us, not
to fear death? Since those heeare have wyllingly despised their own lives,
it is not to be thought that they died to take the goods of others, neither to
think that our life shoold never have end, nor our covetousness in like manner. O
glorious people, and.10. thousand sold happy, that the proper sensuallyty
being forsaken, has overcome the natural appetyte to desire to live, not
beeleeuing in that they saw, and that having faith in that they never saw, they
striued with the fatal destines. By the way they assalted fortune they,
changed life for death, they offered the body to death, and above al have won
honor with the gods, not for that they should hasten death, but because they
should take away that wc is superfluus of life. Archagent a surgio^ of Rome,
and Anthonius Musus, a physician of the Emperor Augustus, and Esculapius father
of the physic, shoold get litel money in that country. He that the^ shoold
have sent to ye barbarous to have done as the Romans at that time did, that
is to wete, to take siroppes in the mornings, pylls at night, to drynk mylk in
the morning, to noynt them selves with gromelsede, to be let blood to day, and
purged to morrow, to eat of one thing, and to abstein from many: a man ought to
think, that he which willingly seeks death will not give money to lengthen
life.

The Emperor concludes his letter, and shows what perilles those old men
live in which dissolutely like young children pass their days, and geeueth unto
them wholesome counsel for the remedy thereof. Cap. xxii.
But returning now to thee Claude, and to thee Claudine me thinks, that
these barbarous being fifty years of age, and you others having above three
score and 10. it should be just, that since you were elder in years you were
equal in virtue, and though (as they) you will not accept death patiently: yet
at the least you ought to amend your euel lives willingly. I do remember, that
it is many years since that Fabritius the young, son of Fabritius the old,
had ordained to have deceived me, of the which if you had not told me, great
inconveniences had happened: and since that you did me so great a benefit, I
woold now requite you the same with an other like. For amongst friends there is
no equal benifit, then to deceive the deceyuer. I let you know, if you do not
know it, that you are poor aged folks, your eyes are soonk into your heads,
the nostrels are shutt, the hears are white, the hearing is lost, the tongue
faltreth, the teeth fall, the face is wrincled, the feet swollen, and the stomak
cold. Finally I say, that if the grave could speak, as unto his subjects, by
justice he might command you to inhabit his house. It is great pity of the
young men, and of their youthful ignorante, for then unto such their eyes are
not opened, to know the mishaps of this miserable life, when cruel death does
end their days, and adiorneth the^ to the grave. Plato in his book of the
common wealth said, that in vain we geeue good counsels, to fond and light
yongmen. For youth is without experience of that it knows, suspicious of that
it hears, incredible of that is told him, despising the counsayl of an other,
and very poor of his own. For So Much as this is true that I tell you Claude,
and Claudine, that without comparison, the ignorance which the young have of the
good is not so much: but the obstinacion which the old has in the euel is
more. For the mortal gods many times do dissemble with a.1000. offeces
committed by ignorance, but they never forgeeue the offense perpetrated by
malice. O Claude, and Claudine, I do not meruel that you do forget the gods
(as you do) which created you, and your fathers, which beegot you and your
parents, which have loved you and your friends, which have honored you: but that
which most I marvel at is, that you forget your selves. For you never consider
what you ought to be, until such time as you be there where you would not
be, and yt without power to return back again. Awake, awake, since you are
drowned in your dreams, open your eyes since you sleep so much, accustom your
selves to trauells, since you are vacabonds, learn that which beehoueth you
since now you are so old. I mean, that in time convenient you agree with
death, before he make execution of life.52. yers have I known the things of
the world, and yet I never saw a woman so aged through years, nor old man with
members so feeble, that for want of strength could not (if they list) do good:
nor yet for the same occasion shoold leave to be euel if they list to be
euel. It is a marvelous thing to see, and worthy to note that all the corporal
members of man waxes old, but the inward heart, and the outward tongue: for the
heart is always green to invent evils, and ye tongue is alwais able to tell lies.
My opinion should be that the pleasant somer being past, you shoold prepare
your selves for the intemperate winter which is at hand. And if you have but few
days to co^tinew, you shoold make have to take up your lodging. I mean that
since you have passed the days of your life with travel, you shoold prepare your
selves against the night of death, to be in the haven of rest. Let mockries
pass as mockries, and accept truth as truth, that is to weete, that it were a
very just thing, and also for your honor necessary, that al those which in
times past have seen you yo^g and foolish, shoold now in your age, se you
grave and sage. For there is nothing that so much forgets the lightness and
folly of the youth, as does gravity and constancy in age. When the knight
ronneth his carire, they blame him not for that the horse mayn is not finely
commed: but at the end of his race he shoold see his horse amended and looked
to* what greater confusion can be to any parson, or greater sclau^der to our
mother Rome, then to see that which now adays therein we see yt is to weete,
the old which can scarcely creap through the streats, to beehold the plays and
games as young men, which search naught else but pomp and vanity. It greeueth me
to speak it, but I am much more ashamed to see, yt ye old Romans do daily
cause the white hears to be plucked out of their heads because they would not
seem old, to make their berd small to seem young, wearing their hosen very
close, their sherts open before, ye gown of the senator imbrodred, the Romayn
sign richly enameled, the collar of gold at the neck, as those of Dace.
Fringes in their gowns, as those of Sapphire, hoopes in their hatts, as the
Greeks, and perles on their fingers, as those of India. What will thou I tell
thee more, then I have told thee, but that they wear their gowns long and
large, as those of Tharenthe, and they wear them of the color as men of war,
and every week they have change as players, and the woorst of all is, that
they show them selves as doting in love now in their age, as others have done
hertofore in their youth. That old men are ouercom by young desires, I do not
meruel, for that brutish lust is as natural, as the daily food: but the old
men (being old men) should be so dissolute, heerewith men justly ought to be
offended. For the old men covetous, and of flesh vicious, both offend the gods,
and sclaunder the common wealth. O how many I have known in Rome, who in their
youth have been highly praised and: esteamed and afterward through geeuing
the^ self to very much lightness in their age, have been of all abhorred. And
the woorst of al is, that they have lost al their credit, their parents, their
favor, and their poor innocent children their profit. For many times the gods
permit, that the fathers committing thoffence, the pain shoold fall upon their
own children. The renowned Gaguino Cato, who descended from the high lignage
of the sage Catoes, was five years Flamen priest, and administrator to the
vestal virgins, three years praetor, two years Censor, one year dictator, and
five times Co^sull, being.75. years old, he gave him self to follow, serve, and
to desire Rosana, the daughter of Gneus Cursius, a lady of troth very young and
fair, and of many desired, and much made of: time afterward passing away, and
god Cupide doing his office, the love was so kindled inwardly in the heart of
this old man, that he rann almost mad: So yt after he had consumed all his
goods in serving her daily he sighed, and nightely he wept, only for to see
her. It chanced that the said Rosana ^el sick of a burning ague, wherewith she
was so diste^pered, that she could eat no meat but desired greatly to eat
grapes: and since there were none ripe at Rome, Gaguino Cato sent to the
river of Rheyn to fetch some being far and many miles distant from thence.
And when the thing was spread through Rome, and that all the people knew it and
the senate understanding the folly of him: the fathers commanded that Rosana
should be locked up with the vestal virgins, and the old man banished Rome for
ever, to ye end that to the^ it shoold be a punishment, and to others an
example. Truly it grieved me sore to see it, and also I had great payns in
writi^g it. For I saw ye father die in i^famy, and his children live in
poverty, I believe yt al those wc shall hear this example. and al those wc shall
read this writing, shall find the fact of this amorous old man, both vile and
filthy, and they will allow ye sentence of ye senate which they gave against him
for good and just. I swear that if Gaguino Cato had had as many young men in his
banishment as he left old men lovers that followed his example in Rome, there
shoold not be cast away so many men, neither so many women evil married. It
chances often times, that when the old men (specially being noble, and
valyant) are aduertysed of their servants, are rebuked of their parents, are
prayed of their friends, and accused of their enemies to be dishonest in such a
place they answer, that they are not in love, but in jest. When I was very
young no less in wisdom, the^ in age, one night in the Capitol I met with a
neighbor of mine, the which was so old, that he might have taken me for his
nephiew, to whom I said these words. Lord Fabricus, are you also in love? he
answered me. You see yt my age suffers me not that I shoold be a lover if
I shoold be, it is but in sport.

Truly I marueiled to meet him at that hour, and I was ashamed to have such an
answer. In old men of great age, and gravity, such request can not be called
love, but grief, not pastime, but loss of time, not mockry, but villainy: for
of love in jest, ensues infamy in deed. I ask you Claude, and Claudine, what
a thing is it to see an old man to be in love? Truly it is no other, but as a
garland before the tauern doors, where al men think yt there is wine, and they
sell naught else but vinegar. They are eggs white without, and rotten within,
they are golden pills, the taste whereof are very bitter, and as e^pty boxes in
shops, which have new writings on them, or as a new gate, and with in the house
is full of filth and cobwebs: finally the old lover is a knight of Exchetes,
which helps to lose money, and can deliver no man from peril. Let this word
be noted, and always in your memory committed, that the old man which is
vicious, is but as a leeke which has the head white, and the tail green. Me
thinks that you ought to break the wings of time, since that you have
feathers to fly withal. Deceive not your self nor your friends and neighbors,
saying that there is time for all. For the amendment is in your hands, but time
is in the hands of god to dispose. Let us come now to remedy this great damage,
do what you can by the day of youth, and deferr it not until the night of age:
for ill cutteth the knife, when the edge thereof is dulled, and ill can he know
the bones which is accustomed to eat the flesh. I tell you, and advertise you
that when the old and rotten houses beeginneth to fall, under set not them with
rotten wood, but with hard timber. I mean, with the upright thoughts of
accounts, which we ought to give to the gods of our life, and to me^ of our
renoume. Forth I say, that if the vine be gathered of our virtues, we ought
to graffe again the amendment: and if ye shreds of our gatherings be dry and
withered, through our peruers woorks, we ought to set them again with new
mould and good desires. The gods are so gentle to serve, and so good to
content, that if for all the services we ow them, and for the gifts which they
geeue us, we can not pay them in good woorks: they demand no more in payment
but good wills. Finally I say, that if thou Claude, and Claudine, have offered
the meal of youth to the world, offer now the blood of age to the gods. I have
written longer then I had thought to do. Salute all my neighbors specially
Drusio the patrician, and noble Romayne widow. I remember that Gobrine your
niece did me a pleasure, the day of the feast of the mother Berecinthia,
wherefore I se^d 2. thou sand Sesterces, one thousand to help to mary her: and
the other thousand, to help to reliue your poverty. My wife Faustine is sick,
and I send you another.1000. Sesterces to geeue to the vestal virgins, to pray
to the gods for her. My wife sends to thee Claudine a cofer, by the immortal
gods I swear unto thee, I can not tell what is in it, I beeseech the godds,
since you are aged, to give you a good death, and to me and Faustine, they
suffer us to lead a good life. Marcus of mount Celio with his own hand writes
this.

Princes ought to take heed that they be not noted of avarice, for that the
coueious man is both of god and man hated. Cap. xxiii
THe great Alexander king of Macedony, and Darius the unfortunate king of the
Persyes, were not only contrary in wars and conquests, which they made but
also in the conditions and inclinations which they had. For Alexander naturally
loved to geeue and spend: and Darius to the contrary, to heap, lock, and
keep. When ye fame of Alexander was spread abroad through out all the world, to
be a prince of honor, and not covetous, his own loved him entierly, and
strangers desired to serve him faithfully, The miserable king Darius, as he
was noted of great avarice and of small liberality, so his did disobey him, and
strangers hated him. Whereof may be gathered that princes and great lords by
geeuing, do make them selves rich: and in keeping, they make them selves
poor. Plutarche in his apothegmes declares, yt after king Darius was, dead
and Alexander had triumphed over all the oriental parts, a man of Thebes being
in the market place of Athenes setting forth the fortune of Alexander, for the
sundry countries which he had conquered: and describing the euel fortune of
Darius, for the great number of men which he had lost, a philosopher with a
loud voice said. O man of Thebes thou art greatly deceived, to think that one
prince loses many seignories: and that the other Prince wins many realms.
For Alexander the great wanne naught but stones, and couerings of cities: for
with his liberality he had alredie gotten the good wills of the cite sins, And
to the contrary, the unfortunate Darius did not lose but stones, and the
couertures of cities, for with his covetousness and avarice he had now lost all the hearts of those of Asia. And farther this philosopher said unto him, that
princes which will enlarge their estates, and amplify their realms in their
conquests, ought first to win ye hearts, and to be noble, and liberal: and
afterward to send their armies to conquer the forts, and walls, for otherwise
litel avails it to win ye stones if the hearts do rebel. Whereby a man may
gather, that that which Alexander wan, he wan by liberalitye and stoutnes: and
that which king Darius lost, he lost for beeinge miserable, and covetous. And
let us not meruail hereat, for the princes and great lords wc are overcome
with avarice, I doubt whither they ever shall see them selves co^querors of
many realms. The vice of avarice is so detestable, so euel, so odious, and so
perilous, yt if a man shoold e^ploy hi^ self to write al ye disco^modites
theru^to belongi^g, my pen should do naught else, then to presume to dry up
all the water in ye sea: For the stomach where avarice enters, causes a man
to serve vices, and worship Idolles. If a virtuous man would prepare him
self to think on the great travail, and litell rest that this cursed vice
bears with him, I think that none would be vicious therein. Though the
covetous man had no other travail, but always to go to bed with danger, and
to rise up with care: Me thinks it is a trouble sufficient for such one when
he goes to bed, thinks that he should be killed in his bed, or that sleping
his cofers should be rifled: and from that time he rises, he is always
tormented with fear to lose that which he has won, and careful to augme^t
that litel in to much. The divine Plato in the first book of his commonwealth
said these words, the men be made rich, because they never learned to be
rich: for he which continually, and truly will become rich, first ought to
abhor covetousness, before he begin to occupy him self to lock up goods.
For the man which sets no bond to his desire shall always have little
though he see himself lord of the world. Truly this sentence was worthilye
spoken of such a man. The sentence of ye Stoyckes does satisfy my mind much,
whereof Aristotel in his pollitikes makes mention, where he says, that unto
great affairs, are always required great riches: and there is no extreme
poverty, but where there has been great abundance. Thereof ensues, that
to princes and great lords which have much, they want much, because to men
which have had litel, they can not want but litel. If we admonish wordlings
not to be vicious, they will always have excuses to excuse them selves,
declaring why they have been vicious: the vice of avarice excepted, to whom and
with whom they have no excuse. For if one vain reason be ready to excuse
then, there are.2000. to condemn them. Let us put example in all the
principal vices, and we shall se how this only of avarice, remains
condemned, and not excused. If we reason why a prince or great lord is haulty
and proud, he will answer that he has great occasion. For the natural
disposition of men is, rather to desire to commau^d with travail, then to
serve with rest. If we reprove any man that is furious, and given to anger: he
will answer us, that we marvel not, since we marvel not of the proud:
For the enemy has no more auctority to trouble any man, then the other to take
revenge of him. If we blame him for yt he is fleshly and vicious, he will
answer us, that he can not absteyne from that sin: for if any man can eschew
ye acts he fights continually with unclean thoughts. If we say that any man
is negligent, he will answer us, that he deserves not to be blamed: for the
vileness of our nature is such, that if we do travail it, immediately it is
weary and if we rest it, immediately it rejoices: If we rebuke any man that is
a glutton, he will answer us, that without eatinge and drinkinge we can not
live in the world: for the divine word has not forbidden man to eat with
the mouth, but the unclean thoughts which come from the heart. As of these
few vices we have declared, so may we excuse all the reasidue: but to the vice
of covetousness, none can give a reasonable excuse. For with money put into ye
cofer, the soul cannot profit, nor ye body rejoice. Boethius in his book of
consolation said, yt money is good, not when we have it in possession, but when
we want it, and in very deed ye sentence of Boethius is very profound: for when
man spends money, he attayneth to that he will, but having it with him, it
profits him nothing. We may say of rich and covetous men, that if they
heap and keep, they say it is but for dear and dry years, and to releue
their parents and friends. We may answer them, that they do not heap up to
remedy the poor in such like necessities, but rather to bring the
commonwealth to greter pouertye. For then they sell al things dear, and put
out their money to great usury: so that this covetous man does more harm with
that he does lend them, then the dry year does with that it has taken from
them. The noble and virtuous men ought not to cease to do well, for fear of
dry years: for in the end if one dear year come it makes all dear, and at
such a time, and in such a case, he only may be called happy, which for being
free and liberal in alms, shall rejoice that his table should be costlye. Let
covetous me^ beware, that for keaping of much goods, they give not to the
deuel their souls: for it may be that before the dear year comes to sell
their corn, their bodies shall be laid in the grave. O what good does god to
the noble men, giving them liberal hearts: and what ill luck have covetous men
(having as they have) their hearts so hard laced. For if covetous men did taste
how sweet and necessary a thing it is to give: they could keep little for them
selves. Now since the miserable and covetous men have not the heart to give
to their friends, too depart to their parents, to succor the poor, to lend
to their neighbors, nor to sustain the orphans, it is to be thought yt they
will spend it on them selves. Truly I say no more, for there are men so
miserable, and so hard of that they have, that they think that as evil spent,
which among them selves they spend: as that which one robs from them of
their goods. How will the covetous and miserable wretch give a garme^te to a
naked man, which dare not make him self a cote? How will he give to eat to the
poor famylyar, wc as a poor slave eats the bread of branne, and sellethe
the flower of meal? How shall the pilgrims lodge in his house, who, for pure
miserye dare not enter? and how does he visit the hospital, and reliue the
sick, that often times hasardeth his own health and life, for that he will not
give one penye to the physician? how shall he succor secretly the poor and
neady, which makes his own children go barefoote, and naked? how can he help
to marye the poor maids being orphans, when he suffers his own daughters
to wax old in his house? how will he give of his goods to the poor captives,
which will not pay his own men their wages? how will he give to eat to the
children of poor gentelmen, which always grudgeth at that his own spend?
how should we believe that he will apparel a widow, hwich will not give his own
