wife a hoode? how does he daily give alms, which goes not to the church on
the Sunday because he will not offer one penny? how shall the covetous man rejoice
the heart, since for spending of one penny, often times he goes supperles to bed?
And finally I say, that he will never give us of his own proper goods, which
weapeth always for the goods of an other.

The auctor follows his matter, and with great reasons discommendeth the vices
of covetous men. Cap. xxiiii.
ONe of the things wherein the divine providence shows, yt we do not
understand the manner of her government, is to see that she gives understanding
too a man too know the riches, she gives him force too seek them, subtiltye
too gather them, virtue too sustain them, courage too defend them, and also
long life to possess them. And with all this she gives him not license to
enjoy them, but rather suffers him, that as without reason he has made him
self lord of an another man's, of right he should be made sclaue of his
own: thereby a man may know, of how greater excellencye virtuous pouertye
is, then the outrageous covetousness: for so much as to the poor, god does give
contentation of that litell he has, and from the rich man he takes
contentacion of the great deal he possesses. So that to the covetous man we
se troubles increase hourly: and the gain comes unto him but monthly. Let
us compare the rich and covetous man to the pore potter, and we shall se who
shall profit most, either the potter with his pottes that he makes of earth,
or else the covetous with the money which he has in the earth. Though I make no
answer to this, yet answer herein has been alredye made, that the one is
much better at ease with the earth, then the other is with the good. For the
potter gets his living by selling pottes, and the covetous man loses his
soul by keeping riches. I humblye require ye high princes, and also I beseech ye
great lords, and further I admonish the other nobles, and Plebeiens, always
to have this word in memory, I say, and affirm that the more strongly the
man keapeth, and locketh his treasures: the more strongly, and privily is he
kept: for if he put two keys to keape his treasure he puts seven to his
heart not to spend them. Let the noble and valiant men beware, yt they give
not their minds to heap up treasoures: for if once their hearts be kindled with
covetousness, for fear of spendinge a halfpeny, they will daily suffer them
selves to fall into a thousand miseries. The Plebeiens wc are very rich may
say, yt they have not heaped up much treasures, since they can not behold a
hundred, or two hundred duccates. To this I answer that the estates
considered, ten duccates do as much harm to a treasurer, as to others ten
thousand. For the fault consists not in keaping, or hidi^g (much or litel)
riches: but for so much as in keapinge them, we cease to do many good works.
To me it is a strange matter, that nigardlines has greater force to ye
covetous, then conscience has in others. For there are many, which
notwithstanding conscience, do profit with the goods of others: and the
covetous having more misery then conscience, cannot yet profit with their
own. With much care and no small dilygence the covetous men do provide that
the myllers do not rob the meal, that their beasts make no wastes that the
hunters run not through the corn, that their wine perish not, that those
which owe them any thing, do not go and make them selves bank routes, that
wynetts do not eat their corn, and that thieves rob not their goods: but in
the end they watch none so well, as them selves. For all the others (erely, or
late) have always oportunitye to rob from them somewhat: but the covetous
has never the heart to change a duccate. Men ought to take great pity of a
covetous man, who by his own will, and not of necessity, wears his gown al
to torn, his shoes out, his points without aggletes an evil favored girdle,
his cote rent, his hatte old, his hose seame rent, his cappe greasy, and his
sherte lowsy: finally I say, that diverse of these mysers feign that they have a
great sum to pay, and it is for no other thing, but for not wearyng a good
garment. What can the covetous do more, then for keeping a penny in his pursse,
he will go two months and not trim his beard? Since it is true that
these pynchpenies do behave their persons so evil, do ye thynk they have
their houses any thing the better furnished? I say no, but you shall see their
chambers full of cobwebbes, the doors out of the hingels, the windows riuen,
the glasses broken, the planches lose, the couertures of the house without
gutters, the stools broken, the beds woorme eaten, and chimnies ready to fall:
so that to herber a friend or kinsman of theirs, they are constrained to lodge
him in their neighbors house, or else to send to borrow all that they want. And
passing over the garments they wear, and the housen wherein they dwell, let us
see what table they keep^ for of their gardens they eat no fruit, but that
that falls of the tree, of their vines, but rotten grapes, of their sheep,
the sickest, of their corn, ye wettest, of wine that which has taken wind, of
lard that is yelow, of milk, that is turned: and finally I say, the felicity
that glottons have in eating, the self same have they in keeping. O unhappy are
the glottons, and much more are the covetous: for the taste of one consists
only in the throat, and the felicity of the other consists in that he may
lock up in his chest. We have now seen how ye covetous were simple apparayl,
keep a poor table, and dwell in a filthy house: and yet they less regard
those things that touch their honor.

For if they had their ears as open to here, as they have their hearts bent at
each hour to gather, and heap up: they should hear how they are called mysers,
vserers, nygards, pinchepenies, oppressors, cruel, unthankful, and
unfortunate. Finally I say, that in the commonwealth they are so hated, that all
men had rather lay hands upon their bodies to kill them, then tongues on their
renowm to defame them. The covetous man is of all other most unlucky. For if
we fall at strief with any, he shall find no one friend that will come to
visit him in his house: but he shall have a hundred thieves which will rob
him of his goods. For to revenge a covetous enemy, a man need desire naught
else but that he live long: for he is more tormented in his life with his own
covetousness, then he can be otherwise with any penance. If rych men woold
say unto me, that they do not rejoice to have fair houses, since they may
have them, neither of curious aparel, since they may were it, nor of deinty
meats, since they may eat them, and that that which they do, is not to be
covetous, but for that they are good christians: In so just a thing, reason
woold my pen shoold cease: but I am sorry, they so little esteem things
touching their honor, and much less the matters touching their conscience. If
ye auaricious say he keeps goods to do alms, I do not believe it: for
daily we see that if a poor man ask him alms, he answers them immediately,
god help you, for he has neither purse nor penny. The covetous uses this,
that he never geeueth any alms in his house, but fatt meat, and resty baken,
rotten cheese, and hoar bread: so that it seems rather that they make clean
their house, then geeue alms to the poor. If the covetous man woold tell us,
that that which they have, is to discharge some dets of their predecessors
wherewith they are burdened, I say it is a vain excuse: since we see that the
wills of their fathers, of their mothers, and of their graundfathers, be not
as yet performed, neither will they think to perform them, which seems to
be very true. For since the hour that they laid their fathers in the grave,
they never had any one thought of their dead fathers. He which of pure
covetousness and misery, suffers him self to dye for hunger and cold: I think
he has small devotion to geeue alms, and much less to do any man good. If
the covetous man say unto us, that that which he keeps, is for no other
cause but to buyld a sumptuous chapel, and to leave of them some memory, to
this I answer. That if such one does it with his own proper swet, and makes
restitucion of all the evil that he has done, it shall be sanctified, and of
all good men commended: but if the covetous will that many live in great
poverty, only to make a rich tomb, god does not command that, neither does the
church admit it: for sacrifice done to god with the cries and swet of others,
is not acceptable. If the covetous tell us, that though they heap treasures, it
is not but at their death to distribute it to the poor, and to be brought
honestly to the ground: I say that I commend this purpose, so his intent be
accordingly performed: but I am sorry ye couetouse man shoold think hereby to
merit, and that he shoold thus discharge the wickedness of his life, for the
distribution of a little money after his death.

I woold think it more sure, that princes and great lords shoold spend their
goods, to mary poor maidens, being orphans in their life, then to command
money to be dealt after their death. For often times the heirs or their
executors, the body interred, do little perform the will of the testator: and
much less observe the legacyes beequethed, though it be to ye utter undoing
of the poor orphans. O what guerdon and commendacion deserves he that justly
and truly discharges the legacies of the dead, and of the surplus (if any
be) or with their own, relieve the orphans and mary the poor maidens, keeping
them from the vices of this world. Suppose that a covetous man chances to
traffic at Medine in Spain, at Lions in France, at Lisbone in Portingal, at
London in England, at Andwarp in Flaunders, at Millain in Lombardy, at Florence
in Italy, at Palermo in Scicil, at Prage in Boeme, and at Buda in Hungary:
finally with his eyes he has seen all Europe, and by trafique he has
knowledge of all Asia. Admit now that in every place he has gotten goods, and
that which he has gotten, was not with whole conscience, but according to the
companies, so has the offenses been diverse.

In this case, if at the hour of death, when the covetous man deuydeth his
money beetweene the children, he might also deuyd his offenses, so that he
dispossessing him self of the goods, might thereby be free from the offenses,
then it were well. But alas it is not so, for the wicked children live
tryumphing on the earth with the goods: and the miserable father goes weepyng
to hell with his sins.

Of a letter which the Emperor Marcus Aurelius wrote to his friend Cincinatus who
being a Romayn knight became a merchant of Capua, wherein he touches those
gentlemen which take upon them the trade of merchandise against their vocation.
It is divided into.iii. Chapters. Cap. xxv.
MArck the Emperor, with his brother Annius Verus, fellow in the Empire,
wishes to thee Cincinatus of Capua, health to thy person, and grace against
thy evil fortune. From the feast of our mother Berecinthe, I have seen
neither servant of thy house, nor read any letter of thy hand, which thing
makes me suspect greatly, that thy health is in danger, or that thou
mistrustest our friendship: for earnest friendship, requires daily
communication, or visitation: I pray thee be not so careless from henceforth,
and do not forget us in such wise, I mean, that thou will come and see us, or
at the least that thou will write unto us often: for ye letters of faithful
friends, though utterly they do not take from us the desire of the presence:
yet at the least they make us hope for a meeting. I know that thou may answer
me, that in the common wealth of Capua thou art so busyed, that it is
impossible thou shooldst write unto me: heereto I answer thee: That in no
affairs thou can be so occupied, that it be a lawful let, not to
communicate, or write unto thy friend. For we may well call the time which we
live, to be well employed, which is spent in the service of god, and in the
conversation of our friends. All the residue that we wast in talking,
traueling, sleeping, eating and resting, we ought not to write it in the book
of life, but in the register of death. For all be it that in such semblable
woorks the body is refreshed: yet therewith the heart cannot be comforted. I
swear unto thee therefore (my friend) that it is impossible ye man take any
contentation of any worldly thing, where the heart is not at rest: for our
comfort is not in the sinnues, or in the bones of the body, but in the lively
power of the soul. It is long since that you and I have known togethers, it
is long time likewise that I loved thee, and thou me: and since we are so true
old friends, it is but reason that with good woorks we do renew our friendship.
For falsely they vsurp the name of friendship, which are not co^uersant one with
the other, no more then if they were strangers. The man wc speaks not to me,
wc writes not to me, wc sees me not, wc visits me not, wc geeueth me
not, and to whom I geeue not, I woold not he were my enemy: but it little
avails me that he call me friend, for particular friendship consists not
in abundance, but that friends do open their hearts, and talk with their
persons. Peradventure thou will say, that the great distaunce which is from
Rome to that country, has been occasion to deminish our friendship: for the
noble hearts are on fire with the presence of that they love, and have great
pain with the absence of that they desire. I answer, that the farther the
delicious wines are sent, from the place where they grow: the greater strength
they have. I mean, that herein true friends are known, when their persons are
furthest severed: for then are their wills most conioined. Tell me I pray
thee Cincinnatus, since always thou have found me a diligent friend in thy
service, why do thou mistrust my faithful good will? The green leaves
outwardly do show, that ye tree inwardly is not dry. I mean, that the good
woorks outwardly do declare ye feruentnes of ye heart inwardly. If thou
Cincinnatus presumest to be a true friend of thy friend, I will thou know this
rule of friendship, which is: Where perfect love is not, there wa^teth always
faithful service: and for the contrary he ye perfectly loves, assuredly
shall be served. I have been, am, and will be thine, therefore thou shall do me
great injury, if thou art not mine.

The Emperor proceeds in his letter and declares what virtues men ought to
use, and the vices which they ought to eschew. Cap. xxvi.
IN times past I being young, and thou old, I did succor thee with money, and
thou me with good counsel: but now the world is otherwise changed, in that
thy white hears do judge thee to be old, and thy woorks do cause thee to be
young. Therefore necessity compels me, that we change our style, which is:
that I succor thee with good counsel, though thou geeue me no money therefore:
for I count thy covetousness to be such, that for all ye good counsel, and
cou^selers of Rome, ye wilt not vouchsafe to geeue one quatrine of Capua. Now
for ye good that I wish thee, and for that which I owe to ye law of friendship,
I will presently geeue thee a counsel, whereby thou may know what a good man
ought to do, to be loved of god, and feared and loved of me^. If ye wilt
quietly lead thy life in this miserable world, retain this well in memory which
I write unto thee. First ye good deeds thou have received of any, those shall
thou remember: and ye wrongs thou have sustained, them shall thou forget.
Secondarely, esteem much thy own little: and way not the much of an other.

Thirdly, the company of the good always covet: and the conversation of ye
evil daily fly. Fourthly, to the great show thy self grave: and to the small
more conversant. Fifthly, to those which are present, do always good woorks:
and of those that be absent, always speak good words. Sixthly, way little ye
loss of fortune, and esteem much things of honor. The seventh, to win one
thing, never adventure thou many: nor for many things doubtful, do not thou
adventure any one thing certain. Finally and lastly, I pray thee and advertise
thee that thou have no enemy: and that thou keep but one friend. He which
among the good wilbee counted for good, none of these things he ought to want.
I know well that thou will have great pleasure to see these my counsels well
written: But I ensure thee I shall have greater pleasure, to see them in thy
deeds well observed. For by writing to geeue good counsel, it is easy: but by
woorks to follow ye same, is marvelous hard. My faithful friendship to thee
plighted, and thy great ability considered, caused me always for thee in Rome
to procure honorable offices, and by my suyt thou have been Edite and tribune,
and master of the horses, wherein thou behauedst thy self with such wisdom, that
all ye senate therefore yielded me most hearty thanks, I procuring them for thee,
and thou for thy self winning such perpetual renowm. One thing of thee I
understand, which with good will I woold not have known, and much less that
any such thing by thee shoold have been committed: that is to weet, that thou
leaving thy office of the pretorship in the war by land, have taken upon thee
traffike of a marcha^t by sea: so that those which in Rome knew thee a knight
do see thee now in Capua a merchant. My pen indyting this my letter, for a
time stood in suspense, for no other cause, but only to see what thing in thee
first I might best blame: either ye noble office which thou did forsake, or
the vile and base estate wc thou have chosen. And though thou be so much
bereued of thy senses, yet call to mind thy ancient predecessors which dyed in
the wars, only to leave their children, and nephews armed knights: and that
thou presently seek to lose that liberty through thy covetousness, which they
wanne by their valyauntnes. I think I am not deceived, that if thy predecessors
were revived, as they were ambicious of honor, so woold they be greedy to eat
thee in morsels, sinnues, bones and all. For the children which unjustly take
honor from their fathers, of reason ought to lose their lives.

The castles, towns, housen, mountains, woods, beasts, Jewels, and silver,
which our predecessors have left us, in the end by long continuance do perish:
and that which causes us to have perpetual memory of them, is the good renowm
of their life. And therefore if this be true, it is great shame for the parents
to have such children, in whom the renowm of their predecessors does end. In
the flourishing time of Cicero the orator, when by his counsel the whole
common wealth was governed, he being then of power, both in knowledge and of
money: Salust said unto him in his inuectiue, that he was of base stock:
whereunto he answered. Great cause have I too render thanks unto the gods,
that I am not as thou art, by whom thy high lineage is ended: but my poor stock
by me does now begin too rise. It is great pity to see, how many good, noble,
and valiant men are dead: but it is more greef to see presently their children
vicious, and unthrifts. So that there remains as much memory of their infamy,
as there does of the others honesty. Thou makst me ashamed, that thou have
forsaken to conquer the enemies as a romain knight, and that thou art become a
merchant, as a poor plebeian. Thou make me to muse a littel, my friend
Cincinnatus that thou will harm thy familiars, and suffer strangers to live
in peace. Thou seek to procure death, to those which geeue us life: and to
deliver from death those, which take our life To rebels thou geeuest rest, and
to the peace makers thou geeuest anoyaunce. To those which take from us our own
thou will geeue: and to those which geeueth us of theirs thou will take. Thou
condemnest the innocent, and the condemned thou will deliver. A defender of thy
country thou will not be, but a tirant of thy commonwealth. To al these
things aduentureth he which leaves weapons, and fauleth to merchandise. With
my self often times I have mused, what occasion should move thee to forsake
chiualry, wherein thou had such honor: and to take in hand merchandise,
whereof follows such infamy. I say, that it is as much shame for thee to have
gone from the wars as it is honor for those which are born unto office in the
commonwealth. My friend Cincinnatus, my end tends not to condemn merchandise
nor marchaunds, nor to speak evil of those which traffic, by the trade of
bying and selling. For as without the valiant knights, war cannot be
atchyued: so likewise without ye diligent merchants, the common wealth cannot
be maintained. I cannot imagine for what other cause thou shooldst forsake ye
war, and traffic merchandise, unless it were, because thou now being old,
and want force to assault men openly in the straits: shooldst with more ease
sitting in thy chayer rob secretly in the market place. O poor Cincinnatus,
since thou byest cheap and sellest dear, promisest much and performest
little: thou byest by one measure and sellest by an other, thou watchest that
none deceive thee, and playest therein as other merchants accustom. And to
conclude I swear, that the measure wherewith the gods shall measure thy life,
shall be much iuster then that of thy merits. Thou have taken on thee an office,
wherewith, that wc thy co^paignions in many days have robbed, thou in one hour
by disceit do get, and afterward the time shall come, when all the goods wc
thou have gotten, both by truth, and falshod, shall be lost, not only in an hour
which is long: but in a moment which is but short. Whether we geeue much, we
have much, we may do much, or we live much: yet in the end the gods are so
just, that all ye evil we do commit shall be punished, and for all the good
we woork, we shall be rewarded, so that ye gods oftentimes permit, that one
alone shall scourge many, and afterward the long time punishes all.

The Emperor concludes his letter and persuades his friend Cincinnatus to
despise the vanities of the world, and shows though a man be never so wise,
yet he shall have need of an other man's counsel. Cap. xxvii.
IF I knew thy wisdom esteemed the world, and vanities thereof, so much as ye
world does possess thee, and thy days, as by thy white hears most manyfestly
does appear: I need not take the payns to persuade thee, nor thou shooldst
be annoied in hearing me: Notwithstanding thou being at the gate of great
care, reason woold that some shoold take the clapper to knock thereat, with some
good counsel: for though the raser be sharp, it needs sometimes to be
whet. I mean though man's understanding be never so clear: yet from time to
time it needs counsel. Virtuous men often times do err, not because they woold
fail, but for that ye things are so evil of digestio^, that the virtue they
have, suffiseth not to tell them what thing is necessary for their profit. For
the which cause it is necessary, that his will be brydled, his wit fined, his
oppinion changed, his memory sharpened, and above all, now and then that he
forsake his own advise, and cleave unto the counsel of an other. Men which
covet to make high, sumptuous, fair, and large buildings, have great care that
the foundation thereof be surely laid: for where the foundacions are not sure,
there the whole buyldings are in great danger. The manners and conditions of
this world (that is to weete) the prosperous estates whereupon the children of
vanity are set, are founded of quick sand: in that sort, that be they never so
valiant, prosperous, and mighty, a little blast of wynd does stir them, a
little heat of prosperity does open them, a shower of adversity does wet them,
and unawares death strikes them all flatt to the ground. Men seeing they cannot
be perpetual, do procure to continue the^ selves, in raising up proud
buyldings, and leaving to their children great estates: wherein I count them
fools, no less then in things superfluous. For admit the pillars be of gold,
the beams of silver, and that those which ioyn them be kings, and those which
buyld them are noble, and in that mining they consume a thousand years before
they can have it out of the ground, or that they can come to the bottoms: I
swear unto them, that they shall find no stedy rock, nor lively mountain, where
they may buyld their house sure, nor to cause their memory to be perpetual.
The immortal gods have participated all things to the mortal men, immortality
only reserved: and therefore they are called immortal, for so much as they
never dye, and we others are called mortal, because daily we vanish away. O
my friend Cincinnatus, men have an end, and thou think that gods never ought
to end. Now green, now ripe, now rotten, fruit is severed from this life, from
the tree of the miserable flesh, and esteem this as nothing, for so much as death
is natural. But often times in ye leaf or flower of youth, ye frost of some
disease, or ye peril of some mishap does take us away: so that when we think
to be alive in ye morning we are dead in the night. It is a tedious and long
woork to weue a cloth: yet when in many days it is wouen, in one moment it is
cut. I mean that it is much folly to see a man with what toil he enricheth him
self, and into what peril he puts him self, to win a state of honor: and
afterward when we think little we see him perish in his estate, leaving of
him no memory. O my friend Cincinnatus, for the love that is between us I desire
thee, and by ye immortal gods I conjure thee, yt thou geeue no credit to the
world which has this condition, to hide much copper under little gold, under
the color of one truth, he tells us a thousand lies, and with one short
pleasure, he mingleth ten thousand displesures. He beegyleth those to whom
he pretends most love, and procures great domages to them, to whom he
geeueth most goods, he recompenseth them greatly which serve him in jest, and
to those which truly love him, he geeueth mocks for goods. Finally I say,
that when we sleep most sure, he waketh us with greatest peril. Either thou
know the world with his deceyt, or not: if thou know him not, why do
thou serve him? if thou do know him, why do thou follow him? Tell me I
pray thee, wooldst not ye take that thief for a fool, which woold buy the rope
wherewith he shoold be hanged, and the murderer that woold make the sword,
wherewith he shoold be beheaded? and the robber by the high way, that woold
show the well wherein he shoold be cast? and the traitor yt shoold offer him
self in place for to be quartered? the rebel that shoold disclose him self to
be stoned? Then I swear unto thee, yt thou art much more a fool, wc know
the world, and will follow it, and serve it. One thing I will tell thee, which is
such, that you ought never to forget it: that is to weete, yt we have
greater need of faith, not to beliue ye vanities wc we see, then to beeleue ye
great malices, wc with our ears we here. I retorn to advise thee, to read and
consider this word which I have spoken, for it is a sentence of profound
mystery. Do thou think Cincinnatus, that rych men have little care to get
great riches? I let thee weet, that ye goods of this world are of such
condition, that before the poor man does lock up in his chests a.100.
crowns: he feels a thousand greefes and cares in his heart. Our predecessors
have seen it, we see it presently, and our successors shall see it: that ye
money wc we have gotten, is in a certain number, but ye cares and trauails wc
it brings are infinite. We have few painted houses, and few noble estats in
Rome, ye wtin a little time have not great cares i^ their hearts, cruel enmities
with their neighbors, much evil will of their heirs, disordinat importunities of
their friends, perilous malices of their enemies, and above al in ye Senate they
have innumerable process, and often times to lock a little good in their chests,
they make ten thousand blots in their honor. O how many have I known in Rome,
to whom it has chanced, that all that they have gotten in Rome to leave unto
their best beeloued child: an other heir (with little care) of whom they thought
not, has enjoyed it. There can be nothing more just, then that al those which
have beegyled others with disceits in their life, shoold be found disceiued in
their vayn immaginacions after their death. Injurious shoold the gods be, if
in all the evil that the evil propound to do, they shoold geeue them time and
place convenient to accomplish the same. But the gods are so just and wise,
that they dissemble with the evil, to thend they shoold beegin, and follow the
things according to their own wills and fantasies: and afterward at the best
time, they cut of their lives, to leave them in greter torment. The gods shoold
be very cruel, and to them it shoold be great grief to suffer, yt that
which the evil have gathered, to the prejudice of many good: they shoold enjoy
in peace for many years. Me thinks it is great folly, to know that we are
borne weeping, and to see that we dysighing, and yet for all this that we
dare live laughing. I woold ask the world and his worldlyngs, since that we
enter into the world weeping, and go out of the world sighing, why we shoold
live laughing? for the rule to measure all parts, ought to be equal. O
Cincinnatus, who has beegyled thee, to the end that for one bottel of water of
the Sea of this world for thy pleasure, thou will blister thy hand with the
rope of cares, and broose thy body in thanker of troubles: and above all to
adventure thine own honor, for a glass of water of an other man.

By the faith of a good man I swear unto thee, that for all the great quantity
of water thou drawest, for the great deal of money thou have, thou remainest
as much dead for thrist, drinking of that water: as when thou were without water
in the cup. Consider now thy years, if my counsel thou will accept, thou shall
demand death of the gods to rest thee as a virtuous man: and not riches to
live as a fool. With the tears of my eyes I have beewayled many in Rome, when
I saw them depart out of this world, and thee I have beewayled, and do
beewaile (my friend Cincinnatus) with drops of blood, to see thee retorn into
the world. The credit thou had in the senate, the blood of thy predecessors,
my frenship, the aucthority of thy parson, the honor of thy parentage, the
sclaunder of thy comonwealth, ought to withdraw thee from so great covetousness.
O poor Cincinnatus, consider the white honored hears which do fall, ought to
be occupied in the noble armies: sithe^s thou art noble of blood, valyant in
parson, ancient of years, and not evil willed in the common wealth. For thou
ought to consider, that more worth is reason, for the path way of men which
are good: then the common opinion, which is the large high way of the evil.
For if it be narrow to go on the one side, there is no dust wherewith the eyes
be blinded as in the other.

I will geeue thee a counsel, and if thou feel thy self euel, never count
thou me for friend. Lust no more after ye greasy fatt of temporal goods, sins
thou have short life: for we see daily many, before they come to thy age dye,
but we see few after thy age live. After this counsel I will geeue thee an
advise, that thou never trust present prosperity: for then always thou art in
danger of some evil fortune. If thou art mounted into such pricking thorns as
a fool: me thinks thou oughts to descend as a sage. And in this sort all
will say amongst the people, that Cincinnatus is descended, but not fallen. My
letter I will conclude, and the conclusion thereof see well thou note, that is
to weete, that thou and thy trade shall be cursed, where you other merchants will
live poor, to die rich. Once again I retorn to curse you, for that the
covetousness of an evil man is alwais accomplished, to the prejudice of many
good.

My wife Faustinc does salute thee, and she was not a little troubled when
she knew thou were a merchant, and that thou keep a shop in Capua. I send
thee a horse to ride upon, and one of ye most richest arras of Tripoli to ha^g
thy house withal, a precious ring, and a pommel of a sword of Alexandrie: and
all these things I do not send thee, for that I know thou have need thereof:
but rather not to forget the good custom I have to geeue. Pamphil^ thy aunt,
and my neighbor is dead. And I can tell thee, that in Rome dyed not a woman of
long time, which of her left such renowm: for so much as she forgot all
enmities, she succored the poor, she visited the banished, she entertained
friends, and also I heard say that she alone did light all the temples.
Prestilla thy cousin has the health of body, though for the death of her mother
her heart is heavy. And without doubt she had reason: for the only sorows which
the mothers suffer to bring us forth, though with drops of blood we shoold
beewayl them, yet we cannot recompense them.

The gods be in thy custody, and preserve me, with my wife Faustine from all
evil fortune. Mark of mount Celio with his own hand

The aucthor persuades princes and great Lords to fly covetousness and avarice,
and to beecome bowntifull and liberal, which virtue is ever pertinent to the
royal parson. Cap. xxviii.
PIsistratus the renowned tyrant among the Atheniens, sins his friends coold
not endure the cruelties that he committed, each one returned to his own
house, and utterly forsook him. The which when the tyrant saw, he laid all
his treasure and garments on a heap togethers, and went to visit his friends,
to whom with bitter tears he spoke these words. All my apparel and money
here I bring you, with determination, that if you will use my company, we
will go all to my house, and if you will not come into my company, I am
determined to dwell in yours. For if you be weary to follow me, I have great
desire to serve you: since you know that they cannot be called faithful
friends, where the one cannot bear with the other. Plutarchus in his Apothegmes
says, that this tyrant Pisistratus was very rych, and extreme covetous, so
that they write of him, that the gold and silver which once came into his
possession, never man saw it afterward, but if he had necessity to buy any
thing, if they woold not present it unto him willingly, he woold have it by
force. When he was dead, the Atheniens determined to wey him and his treasure:
the case was marvelous, that the gold and silver he had, weyd more then his
dead body.6. times. At that time in Athens there was a philosopher called Lido,
of whom the Atheniens demanded, what they shoold do with the treasure and
dead body? me thinks (quod this philosopher) that if those which are living,
did know any silver or gold which the tyrant took from them, it shoold be
restored again immediately: and do not meruell, that I do not require it to
be put in the common treasure. For god will not permit, that the commonwealth
be enriched with the theft of Tyraunts: but with the swet of the inhabitants.
If any goods remayn which do not appear from whom they have been taken, me
thinks that they ought to be distributed among the poor, for nothing can
be more just, then that which the goods wherewyth the tyrant has
enpouerished many, with the self same we shoold enrich some.

As touching his burial, me thinks he ought to be cast out to the (...) to
be eaten, and to the dogs to be gnawen. And let no man thynk this sentence to
be cruel: for we are bound to do no more for him at his death, then he did
for him self in his life, who being so overcome with auaryce, that he woold
never disburse so much money, as shoold buy him seven foot of earth, wherein
his grave shoold be made. And I will you know, that the gods have done a great
good to all Greece, to take life from this tyrant. First it is good, because
much goods are dispersed, which heretofore lay hid, and served to no purpose.
Secondly, that many tongues shall rest, for the treasours of this tirant, made
great want in the commonwealth, and our tongues the greatest part of the day
were occupied, to speak evil of his parson. Me thinks this philosopher has
touched two things, which the covetous man does in the common wealth, that is
to wete, that drawing much gold and silver to the hid treasure, he robs ye
merchandise wherewith the people do live: The other dommage is, that as he is
hated of all, so he causes rancour and malice in the hearts of all: for he
makes the rych to murmour, and the poor to blasphem. One thing I read in the
laws of ye Lombards worthy (of truth) to be noted and known, and no less to
be followed, which is: that all those which shoold have gold, silver, money,
silks, and clothes, every year they shoold be registered in the place of
justice. And this was to the end, not to consent nor permit them to heap much:
but that they shoold have to buy, to sell, and to trafik, whereby ye goods were
occupied among the people. So that he which did spend the money to the profit
of his house, it was taken for good of the common wealth. If christians woold
do that now adays which the Lombardes did, there shoold not be so many
treasures hid, nor so many covetous men in the commonwealth: for nothing can
be more unjust, then that one rych man shoold heap up that, which woold
suffice ten thousand to live with all. We can not deny but that the cursed
avarice, and disordinat couetise to al states of men is as prejudicial, as the
moth which eats all garments.

Therefore speaking the truth and with lyberty, there is no house that it does
not defyle: for it is more perilous to have a clod of earth fall into a man's
eye, then a beam upon his foot. Agesilaus the renowned king of the
Lacedaemonians, being asked of a man of Thebes what word was most odible to
be spoken to a king, and what word that was that coold honor him most? he
answered. The prince with nothing so much ought to be annoied, as to say unto
him that he is rich, and of nothing he ought so much to rejoice, as to be
called poor. For the glory of ye good prince consists not in that he has
great treasures: but in that he has geeuen great recompenses. This word
without doubt, of all the world was one of the most royallest, and worthiest to
be committed unto memory. Alexander, Pirrhus, Nicanor, Ptolomeus, Pompeius,
Julius Caesar, Scipio, Hanniball, Marcus Portius, Augustus, Cato, Traian,
Theodose, Marcus Aurelius, all these princes have been very valiant and
virtuous: but addyng heereunto also, the writers which have written ye deeds
that they did in their lives, have mentioned also the poverty which they had at
their death. So that they are no less exalted, for the riches they have spent:
then for the prowesses they have done. Admit that men of mean state be
auaricious, and princes and great lords also covetous: ye fault of the one is
not equal with ye vice of the other, though in ye end all are culpable.

For if the poor man keep, it is for that he woold not want, but if the
knight hoord, it is because he has to much. And in this case I woold say,
that cursed be the knight which trauaileth, to ye end that goods abound, and
does not care that between two bows his renowmsall to the ground. Since
princes and great lords will that men do count them noble, virtuous, and
valiant, I woold know what occasion they have to be nigards and hard.

If they say that that which they keep is to eat, herein there is no reason:
for in the end, where the rich eats least at his table, there are many that
had rather have that which remains, then that which they provide to eat in
their houses. If they say that that which they keep is to apparel them, here
in also they have as little reason: for the greatness of lords consists not, in
that they shoold be sumptuously appareled, but that they provide that their
servant go not rent, nor torn. If they say it is to have in their chambers
precious jewels, in their halles rich Tapestry, as little woold I admit this
answer: for all those which enter into princes palaces, do beehold more if
those that haunt their chambers be virtuous, then that the tapestries be rych.

If they say that it is to compass their cities with walls, or to make
fortresses on their fronters: so likewise is this answer amongst the others
very cold. For good princes ought not to travel but to be well willed, and if
in their realms they be welbeeloued, in the world they can have no walls so
strong as the hearts of their subjects. If they tell us that that they keep is
to mary their children, as little reason is that: for since princes and great
lords have great inheritaunces, they need not heap much. For if their children
be good, they shall increase that shall be left them: and if by mishap they be
evil, they shall as well lose that that shall be geeuen them. If they say unto
us that that which they heap is for the wars in like manner, that is no just
excuse: For if such war be not just, the prince ought not to take it in
hand, nor the people thereunto to condescend: but if it be just, the common
wealth then, and not the prince shall bear the charges thereof. For in just
wars it is not sufficient that they geeue the prince all their goods: but
also they must them selves in parson hazard their lives. If they tell us that
that they keep is to geeue and dispose for their souls, at their dying day: I
say it is not only want of wisdom, but extreme folly. For at the hour of
death, princes ought more to rejoice for that they have geeuen: then for that
at that time he geeueth. O how princes and great lords are evil counseled,
since they suffer them selves to be slaundered for being covetous, only to
heap a little cursed treasure. For experience teaches us, no man can be
covetous of goods, but needs he must be prodigal of honor, and abandon
liberty. Plutarche in the book which he made of the fortune of Alexander,
says that Alexander the great had a private servant called Perdyca, the which
seeing that Alexander liberally gave all that which by great travel he
attained, on a day he said unto him. Tell me, most noble prince, since thou
geeuest all that thou have to others, what will thou have for thy self?
Alexander answered. The glory remains unto me, of that I have won and
gotten: and ye hope of that wc I will geeue and win. And further he said unto
him, I will tell thee true Perdyca: If I knew that men thought, that all that
which I take were for covetousness, I swear unto thee by the god Mars that I
woold not beat down one corner in a town: and to win all the world I woold
not go one days journey. My intention is to take the glory to my self, and to
deuyde ye goods amongst others. These words so high, were worthy of a valyant
and virtuous prince, as of Alexander which spoke the^. If that which I have
read in books do not begyle me, and that which with these eyes I have seen:
to become rych, it is necessary that a man geeue: for ye princes and great
lords which naturally are geeuen to be liberal, are always fortunat to have.
It chances often times, that some man geeuing a little, is counted liberal:
and an other geeuing much, is counted a nigard. The which proceeds of this
that they know not, that liberality and nigardnes consists not in geeuing
much, or little: but to know well how to geeue. For the rewards and recompenses,
which out of time are distributed, do another profit them which receive them,
neither agree to him which geeueth them. A covetous man geeueth more at one
time, then a noble and free heart does in.20. thus says the common proverb, it
is good coming to a niggards feast. The difference beetwene the liberality of
the one, and the mysery of the other is, that ye noble and virtuous does geeue
that he geeueth to many: but the nigard geeueth yt he geeueth to one only.
Of the which vnaduisement princes ought greatly to beware. For if in such case
one man alone shoold be found, which woold comme^d his liberality: there are
ten thousand which woold condemn his covetousness.

It happens often times to princes and great lords, that in deed they are free
to recompense, but in geeuing they are very unfortunate. And the cause is, yt
they geeue it not to virtuous persons and well co^dicioned, but to those which
are unthankful, and do not acknowledge the benefit received. So that in
geeuing to some, they have not made them their friends: and in not geeuing to
others, they have made them their enemies. It suffyseth not to princes and
great lords, to have great desire to geeue: but to know when, how, or where,
and to whom they ought to geeue. For if they be accused otherwise to heap up
treasures, they ought also to be condemned for that they do geeue. When a man
has lost all that he has in play, in whoors, in bankets, and other semblable
vices, it is but reason they be ashamed: but when they have spent it like
noble, stout and liberal men, they ought not to be discontented, for the wise
man ought to take no displesure for that he loses: but for that he evil
spends: and he ought to take no pleasure for that he geeueth, but for that
he geeueth not well. Dion the grecian in the life of ye Emperor Seuerus says,
that one day in the feast of the God Ianus, when he had geeuen diverse rewards
and sundry gifts, as well to his own servant, as to strangers, and that he
was greatly commended of all the Romans, he said unto them.

Do you think now (Romans) that I am very glad for the gifts, rewards, and
recompenses which I have bestowed: and that I am very glorious for ye praises
you have geeuen me? by the god Mars I swear unto ye, and let the god Ianus be
so merciful unto us all this year, that ye pleasure I have is not so great,
for ye I have geeuen: as ye grief is for yt I have no more to geeue.

The auctour follows his intencion and persuades gentlemen, and those that
profess arms, not to abase them selves for gains sake, to take upon them any
vile function or office. Cap. xix.
PLutarche in his Apothemes declares, that king Ptolomeus the first, was a
prince of so good a nature, and so gentle in conversation, that often times he
went to supper to the houses of his familiar frinds, and many nights he
remained there to sleap. And truly in this case he showed him self to be
welbeeloued of his. For speaking according to the truth a prince on whose life
depends the hole state of the common wealth, ought to credit few was the
table, and also fewer in the bed. Another thing this Ptolomeus did, which was,
when he invited his friends to dinner or supper, or other strangers, of soome
he desired to borow stools, of thothers napkins, and of others cups, and so
of other things, for he was a prodygall prince. For all that his servant in
the morning had bought, before the night following he gave it away. One day all the nobles of his realm of Egypt assembled togethers, and desired him very
earnestly, that he woold be more moderat in geeuing: for they said, through
his prodygality, the hole realm was impouerished. The king answered. You
others of Egypt are marvelously deceived, to think that the poor and needy
prince is troubled. In this case I dare say unto you, that the poor and needy
prince ought to think him self happy, for good princes ought more to seek to
enrich others, then to heap up treasures for them selves. O happy is the common
wealth which deserves to have such a prince, and happy is that tongue, which
coold pronounce such a sentence. Certainly this prince to all princes gave good
example and counsel, that is to weete, that for the^ it was more honor, and
also more profit, to make others rich: the^ to be rich them selves. For if
they have much, they shall want no crauers, and if they have little, they shall
never want servant to serve them. Suetonius Tranquillus in the book of
Cesars says, that Titus the Emperor one night after supper, from the bottom
of his heart fetched a heavy sigh, and he being demanded of those which were
at his table why he sighed so sore, he answered. We have lost at this day,
my friends. By the which words the emperor meant, that he counted not that day
amongst those of life: wherein he had geeuen no reward nor gift. Truly this
noble prince was valiant, and mighty, since he sighed and had displeasure,
not for that which in many days he had geeuen: but because that one day he
had failed to geeue any thing. Pelopa of Thebes, was a man in his time, very
valiant and also rich: and since he was fortunat in getting, and liberal in
spe^ding, one asked him why he was so prodigal to geeue? he answered. If to
thee it seems yt I geeue much, to me it seems yet I shoold give more:
since the goods ought to serve me, and not I to honor them. Therefore I will
that they call me the spender of the goods: and not ye steward of the house.
Plutarche in his apothemes says, yt king Darius floutyng at king Alexander
for being poor, sent to know where his treasures were for such great armies,
to who^ Alexander the great au^swered. Tell king Darius, yt he keeps in his
cofers his treasures of metal: and yt I have no other treasures then the hearts
of my frinds. And further tell him, yt one man alone can rob al his treasures:
but he and all the world can not take my treasures from me, which are my
frinds. I durst say, affirming yt Alexander said, that he cannot be called
poor, wc is rich of frinds: neither can he be called rich, wc is poor of
frinds. For we saw by experience, Alexander with his frinds took king Darius
treasures from him: and king Darius with all his treasures, was not puissau^t
enough to take Alexanders friends from him. Those which of their natural
inclinacion are shamefast, and in estate noble, they ought above all things to
fly ye slander of covetousness: for without doubt greater is the honor which is
lost, then ye goods that are gotten. If princes and great lords of their own
natural dispositions be lyberal, let the^ follow their nature: but if
perchance of their own nature they are inclined to covetousness, let them
enforce their will. And if they will not do it, I tell them which are present, yt
a day shall come when they shall repent: for it is a general rule, that the
disordinat covetousness do raise against them selves al venomous tongues. Think
that when you watch to take men's goods, the others watch in like manner to take
your honor. And if in such case you hazard your honor, I do not think yt your
life ca^ be sure: for there is no law that does ordein, nor patience that can
suffer, to see my neighbor live in quiet, by the swet of my brows. A poor man
esteems as much a cloak, as the rich man does his delicious life. Therefore it
is a good consequent, yt if the rich man take the gown from ye poor: the poor
man ought to take life from the rich Phocion amongst the Greeks was greatly
renowned, and this not so much for that he was sage, as for that he did
despise al worldly riches, unto whom when Alexander ye great (king of Macedony)
had sent him a hundredth marks of silver, he said unto those yt brought it. Why
does Alexander se^d this money unto me, rather then to other philosophers of
Greece? they au^swered him. He does send it unto thee, for yt thou art the
least covetous, and most virtuous. Then answered this philosopher. Tell
Alexander yt though he knows not what belongs to a prince, yet I know well
what pertains to a philosopher. For ye estate and office of philosophers, is
to despise the treasures of princes: and the office of princes is to ask
counsel of philosophers. And further Phocion said, you shall say also to
Alexander, yt in that he has sent me, he has not showed him self a pitiful
friend, but a cruel enemy: for esteeming me an honest man (such as he thought
I was) he shoold have helped me to have been such. These words were worthy
of a wise man. It is great pity, to see valya^t and noble men to be defamed of
covetousness, and only for to get a few goods, he abaseth him self to vile
offices: wc appertein rather to mean parsons, then to noble men, and valiant
knights. Whereof ensues, yt they live infamed, and al their friends slau^dered.
Declaring further I say, yt it seems great lightness, that a knight shoold
leave ye honorable state of chiualry, to exercise the handycraft of husbandry:
and yt the horse shoold be changed into oxen, the speres to mattocks, and ye
weapons into plows. Finally, they do desire to toil in the field: and refuse
to fight in the frontiers. O how much some knights of our time have
degenerated, from yt their fathers have been in times past: for their
predecessors did advance them selves of the infidels, wc in the fields they
slew, and their children brag of the corn and sheep they have in their
grounds. Our ancient knights were not wont to sigh, but when they saw the^
selves in great distres: and their successors weep now, for that it rained not
in ye month of May. Their fathers did strive, which of them could furnish most
men, have most weapons, and keep most horses: but their children now adays
contend, who has the finest wit, who can heap up greatest treasour and who
can keep most sheep. The ancients stryued who should keep most men: but
these worldlings at this day strive, who can have greatest revenues. Wherefore
I say, since the one does desire as much to have great rents, as the other did
delyght to have many weapons: it is as though fathers shoold take the sweord by
the pomell, and the children by the scaberd. All the good arts are perverted,
and the art of chyualry above all others is despised: and not without cause I
called it an art, for the ancient philosophers consumed a great time, to write
the laws that the knights ought to keep. And as now ye order of the
Carthagians seems to be most straight: so in times past the order of
knighthod was the streightest. To whom I swear, that if they observed the order
of chiualry, as good and gentill knights: there remained no time vacant for
them in life to be vicious, nor we should accuse them at their death as evil
christians. The true and not feigned knight, ought not to be proud, malicious,
furious, a glutton, coward, prodigal, nigard, a liar, a blasphemer, nor
negligent. Finally I say, that all those ought not to be judged as knights,
which have golden spurs: unless he has there with an honest life. O if it
pleased the king of heaven, that princes would now adays examine as straightly
those, which have cure of souls: as the Romans did those which had but charge
of armies. In old time they never doubbed any man knight, unless he were of
noble blood, proper of person, moderat in speech, exercised in the war,
courageous of heart, happy in Arms, and honest in life: finally, of all he
ought to be beeloued for his virtue, and of none hated for his vice. The
knights in whom these virtues shyned bright in Rome had diverse lyberties, that
is to weete, that they only might wear ryngs, ride on horsback thorough the
streats, they might have a shylde, shit their gates at dynner, they might drynk
in cups of silver, speak to the senate, and make defyaunces, they might
demand the ensign, wear weapons, take ye charge of imbassage, and ward at
the gates of Rome. The auctour hereof, is Blondus in the book of De Italia
illustrata. If Pliny deceive us not in an Epistle, and Plutarche in his
pollitiks, Seneca in a tragedy, and Cicero in his paradoxes, there was nothing
wherein the ancients were more circumspect, then in electing of their knights.
Now it is not so, but that one having money to buy a lordshyp, immediately he is
made knight: and that which is woorst, when he is made a knight, it is not to
fight against the enemies in the field, but more freely to commit vices, and
oppress the poor in the towns. To the end he may be a good christian, he
ought to think upon Jesus crucyfyed: and to be a good knight, he ought always
to beehold the arms of his shyeld, the which his graundfather, or great
graundfather wanne. For they shall see, that they wanne them not being vicious
in their houses: but in sheding the blood of their enemies in the frontiers.

Of a letter which the emperor wrote to Mercurius his neighbor a merchant of
Samia, wherein men may learn the dangers of those which traffyck by sea, and
also see the covetousness of them that travail by land. Cap. xxx.
MArcus Aurelius Emperor of Rome, borne in mount Celio, wysheth to thee
Mercurius his special frind, health and consolation in the gods the only
comforters. It seems well, that we are friends, sythe^s we do the woorks of
charyty. For I understanding here thy mishap, immedyatly sent a messenger to
comfort thee: and in hearing my disease, thou se^dell a friend of thine to visit
me. Wherefore men may perceive, if thou had me in mind, I did not forget
thee. I understand yt the messenger yt went, and the other that came, met in
Capua: the one carried my desire for thee, and the other brought thy letter for
me. And if as diligently thou had read mine, as I attentively have hard
thine: thou shooldst thereby plainly know, yt my heart was as full of sorrow as
thy spyrit was full of pain. I was very glad, and great thanks I yield thee, for
yt thou did send to comfort me in my fever tertian: and thy visitacion and
comfort came at the same hour, that it left me. But if ye gods did leave this
fact in my hands, even as they thought it good to fix the fever in my bones: I
woold not leave thee without comfort nor geeue place to the fever to retourn
again. O how great is our pride, and the misery of man's life. I speak this,
because I do presume to take many realms from other, and yet I have not the
power to pluck ye fever out of my own bones. Tell me I pray thee (Mercurius)
what profit is it to us to desire much, to procure much, to attain much, and to
presume much, since our days are so brief, and our persons so frayl? It is long
time since we have been bound togethers in friendship, and many years have
passed sithe^s we have known the one the other: and ye day yt thy friendship
trusted my faith, immediately my faith was bound, yt thy evils shoold be mine,
and my goods thine: for as ye divine Plato said, yt only is true friendship,
where the bodies are.2. and the wills but one. I count yt suspicious
friendship, where the hearts are so divided, as ye wills are severed: for there
are diverse in Rome great friends in words, wc dwell but ten houses in sunder,
and have their hearts ten thousand miles distant. When thou wenst from Rome, and
I came from Samia, thou know the agreement wc we made in Capua, whereof I
trust thou will not deceive me now, but that I am another thou here, and that
thou shooldst be another I there: so that my abse^ce with thy presence, and
thy presence with mine absence be always together. By relacion of thy
messenger, I understood that thou had lost much goods: but as by thy letter
I was informed, yt anguish of thy parson was much greater. As we understand
here thou did send a ship laden with merchandise to Greece, and the mariners and
factours desiring more to profit by their wisdom, then to accomplish thy
covetousness: did cast the merchandise into the Sea, and only they travailed to
save their persons. In deed in so straight and perilous a case, thou have no
reason to accuse them, nor yet they are bound to satisfy thee: for no man can
commit greater folly, then for the goods of others to hazard his own propre
life. Pardon me (Mercury) I pray thee for that I have spoken, and also for
that I will say, wc is, that for so much as the mariners and factours were not
thy children, nor thy kinsmen, nor thy friends: so that thy merchandise might
have come to the haue^ safe, thou had little passed if they had al been
drowned in ye deep goulf of the sea. Further I say, though I woold not say it,
and thou much less here it, yt according to the little care which you other
covetous men have, of the children and factors of others, and according to the
disordinat love wc you have to your proper goods; where as thou weepest
bitterly for the loss of thy goods, though thou had seen all the mariners
drowned, thou wooldst not have shed one tear. For Romain merchants weep
rather for ten crowns lost, wc they can not recover: then for ten men dying,
the which ten crowns woold have saved. Me thinks it is neither just, nor
honest, yt thou do that which they tell me thou do, to complain of thy
factours, and accuse the maryners: only to recover of the poor men by land, yt
which the fish have in their possession in the Sea. For as thou know, no man
is bound to change health, life, nor the renowm of their parsons, for the
recovery of goods. Alas, what pyty have I on thee Mercury, in that the ship was
laden with thy merchandise: and the woorst of all is, that according to my
understanding, and thy feelyng, the Pirates have not cast such fardels into the
sea, as thoughts has burdened and oppressed thy heart. I never saw man of such
condition as thou art, for that thou see that the ship (until such time) as
they cast that merchandise over ye board could not sail safely: and yet thou
do lode thy self with riches to go to thy grave. O grievous and cursed
riches, with the which neither in ye deep seas, neither yet in the main land,
our parsons are in safeguard. Knowing thy property, I woold rather bind my self
to seek thy lead and tin: the^ thy heart so wounded. For in the end, thy lead
is together in some place in the bottom of the sea: but thy covetousness is
scattered through all the whole earth. If perhaps thou shooldst dye, and the
surgions with the sharp raser should open thy stomach, I swear unto thee, by
the mother Berecinthe, (which is the mother of all the gods of Rome) that they
shoold rather find thy heart drowned wc the lead: then in life with thy body.
Now thou can not be sick of the fever tertian as I am, for the heat with in
thy body, and the pain in thy head, woold cause thee to have a double quartain:
and of such disease thou can not be healed in thy bed, but in the ship, not
in land, but in the sea, not with physicians, but with pirates. For ye
phisicions woold carry away the money, and the pirates woold show thee where thy
lead fell. Trouble not thy self so much Mercury, for though thou have not thy
lead with thee in the land, it has thee with it in the sea, and thou ought
enough to comfort thy self: for where as before thou had it in thy cofers,
thou have it presently in thy intrailes. For there thy life is drowned, where
thy lead is cast. O Mercury now thou know, that the day that thou did
recommend thy goods to the unknown rocks, and thy ship to the ragyng seas, and
thy outrageous avarice to the furious wynds, how much that thy factors went
desyryng thy profyt, and gayn: so much the more thou might have been assured
of thy loss. If thou had had this consyderacion, and had used this
diligence: thy desire had been drowned, and thy goods escaped. For men that
dare adventure their goods on the sea, they ought not to be heavy for that
that is lost: but they ought to rejoice for that that is escaped. Socrates, the
ancient and great Philosopher determined to teach us, not by word, but by
woork, in what estimacion a man ought to have ye goods of this world: for he
cast in the sea not lead, but gold, not little, but much, not of another man's,
but of his own, not by force, but willingly, not by fortune, but by wisdom.
Finally in this worthy fact he showed so great courage, that no covetous man
woold have rejoiced, to have found so much in the land: as this philosopher did
delyght, to have cast in the sea. That which Socrates did was much, but greater
ought we to esteem that he said, which was: O ye disceytfull goods, I will
drown you, rather then you shoold drown me. Since Socrates feared, and drowned
his own proper goods: why do not the covetous fear to rob the goods of
other? This wise Philosopher woold not trust the fine gold: and thou do
trust the hard lead. Draw you two lottes, Socrates of Athens, and thou of
Samia. See which of you two have erred or done well: he to carry gold from the
land to the Sea, or thou by the Sea, to bring gold to the land. I am assured,
that the ancient Romans woold say that it is he: but the covetous of this
present world would say, that it is thou. That which in this case I thynk is,
that thou in praysyng yt, do disprayse thy self: and Socrates in dyspraysyng
it, of all is praised and esteemed.

The Emperor follows his matter and concludes his letter, greatly reproving
his friend Mercurius for that he took thought for the loss of his goods. He
shows him the nature of fortune, and describes the conditions of the
covetous man. Cap. xxxi.
THis messenger told me, that thou art very sad, that thou cryest out in the
night, and importunest ye gods, wakest thy neighbors, and above all, that thou
complainest of fortune which has used thee so evil. I am sorry for thy grief:
for grief is a friend of solytude, enemy of company, a lover of darkness,
strange in conversation, and heir of desperacion. I am sorry thou cryest in
the night, for it is a sign of folly, a token of small patience, the point of
no wise man, and a great proof of ignorance: for at the hour when all the world
is covered with darkness, thou alone do discover thy heart with exclamacions.
I am sorry that thou art vexed with the gods, saying that they are cruel. For
so much as if they have taken any thing from thee for thy pride, they shoold
restore it again unto thee for thy humility. For as much as we offend the gods
through the offense, so much do we appease them with patience. O my friend
Mercurius, know thou not that the patience which the gods have in dissembling
our faults is greater, then that which men have in suffering their
chastisements? for we others unjustly do offend them, and they justly do
punysh us. I am sorry, that with thy exclamations and complaints thou
slau^derest thy neighbors: for as thou know, one neighbor, always enuyeth
another, in especially the poor, the rych. And according to my counsel, thou
shooldst dyssemble thy pain, and take all things in good part: for if perhaps
thy riches have caused thy sorrow, thy patience will move them to compassion. I
am sorry thou complainest of thy fortune: For fortune (since she is known of
al) does not suffer her self to be defamed of one: and it is better to thynk
with fortune how thou may remedy it, then to thynk with what grief to
co^playn. For they are diverse men, which to publish their pain are very
careful: but to seek remedy, are as negligent. O poor innocent Mercurius,
after so long forgetfullnesse, art thou more aduysed to complayn of fortune
again? and datest thou defye fortune, with whom all we have peace? We unbend
our bows, and thou wilt charge thy lances: thou know not what war
means, and yet thou will win the victory: all are deceived, and wilt thou
alone go safe? What wilt thou more I say unto thee, since I see thee commyt thy
self to fortune? Do thou know, that it is she that beats down the high
walls, and defends the town dyches: know thou not, that it is she that
peopleth the uninhabitable deserts, and dyspeopleth the peopled Cities? Know
thou not, that it is she that of enemies makes friends, and of friends enemies?
Know thou not, that it is she that conquereth the conquerors? Know thou
not, that it is she that of traitors makes faithful, and of faithful
suspicious? finally I will thou know, that fortune is she which turns realms,
breaks armies, abassheth kings, raises tirants, geeueth life to the dead,
and berieth the living. Do thou not remember, that the second king of ye
Lacedaemonians had over his gates such words.

The palace here beehold, where men do strive, by fruitles toil, to conquer
what they can. And fortune ^cke that princes fancies riue, by his unbridled
will, that always wan.
Certainly these words were high, and proceeded of a high understanding. And
if in this case. I may be beeleeued, they ought to be well noted of wise men,
and not written before the gates, but imprinted within the hearts. Better knew
he fortune then thou, since he took him self for one disherited, and not as
heir: and when he lost any thing as thou, he knew that he received it by
loan, and not that it was his own. Men in this life are not so much deceived
for any thing, as to thynk yt the temperall goods shoold remayn with them
during life. Now that god does suffer it, now that our woeful fortune does
deserve it, I see no greater myshaps fall unto any, then unto them which have
the greatest estates and riches: so that truly we may boldly say, that he
alone which is shut in the grave, is in safeguard from the inconstancy of
fortune. Thy messenger has told me further, that this summer thou preparedst
thy self to Rome, and now that it is winter thou wylt sail to Alexandria. O
thou unhappy Mercury, tell me I pray thee how long it is, sythens thou lost
thy sensis? forasmuch as when this life does end, thy auaryce beeginneth a
new? Thou foundest two cities very meet for thy traffyck, that is to weete,
Rome, which is the scourge of all virtues: and Alexandria which is the chiefest
of all vices. And if thou love greatly these two cities, here I pray thee
what marchaundise are sold therein. In Rome, thou shall lode thy body with
vices: and in Alexandria, thou shall swell thy heart with cares. By the faith of
a good man I swear unto thee, that if perchance thou buyest any thing of that
that is there, or sellest ought of that thou bring from thence: thou shall
have greater hunger of that thou shall leave, then contentacion of that thou
shall bring. Thou do not remember that we are in winter, and that thou must
pass the sea, in the which if the Pirates do not deceive me, the surest
tranquyllyty, is a sign of the greatest torment. Thou myghtst tell me, that
thy ships should retourn without frayt, and therefore they shall sail more
surely. To this I answer thee, that thou shall send them more laden with
covetousness: then they shall return laden with silks. O what a good change
shoold it be, if ye avarice of Italy coold be changed, for the silk of
Alexandry. I swear unto thee, that in such case thy sylk woold frayght a ship:
and our couetyse woold lode a whole navy. That covetousness is great, which the
shame of the world does not oppress: neither the fear of death does cause
to cease. And this I say for thee, that sythens in this dangerous time thou
durst sail, either wisdom wants, or else auaryce and covetousness
surmounteth. To satisfy me, and to excuse thee with those which speak to me
of thee, I can not tell what to say unto them, but that GOD has forgotten
thee, and the seas do know thee. I pray thee what go thou to seek, since
thou leauest the governance of thy house, and saylest in Alexandrie?
Peradventure thou go to the goulph Arpyn, where the maryners cast in thy
lead?

Take heed Mercury, and consider well what thou do, for peradventure where
as thou think to take from the fysh the hard lead, thou may leave unto
them thy soft flesh. I have known many in Rome, which for to recover one part
of that that they have lost, have lost all that which was left unto them. O my
friend Mercury, note, note, note well this last word, whereby thou shall know
what it is that you covetous men gape for in this life. Thou seek care for
thy self, envy for ye neighbors, spurs for strangers, a bayt for thieves,
troubles for thy body, damnacion for thy renowm, unquietness for thy life,
annoyance for thy friends, and occasion for thy ennemies. Finally thou searchest
maledictions for thy heirs: and long suits for thy children: I can not write
any more unto thee, because the fever does so behemently vex me. I pray
thee, pray to the gods of Samia for me: for medecines littel profits, if the
gods be angry with us. My wife Faustine saluteth thee, and she says that
she is sorry for thy loss: she sends thee a rich jewel for Fabilla thy
daughter, and I send thee a commission to thend they shall geeue thee a ship in
recompense of thy lead. If thou saylest with it, come not by Rhodes, for we
have taken it from their pirates. The gods be in thy custody, and geeue me and
Faustine a good life with ours, and a good name among strangers. I do not
write unto thee with mine own hand, for that my sickness does not permit it.

That Princes and noble men ought to consider the mysery of man's nature, and
that brute beasts are in some points (reason set a part) to be preferred unto
man. Cap. xxxij.
MYdas the ancient king of Phrigia, was in his government a cruel tyrant, and
contented not him self to play the tiraunt in his own proper country, but also
maintained rouers on the sea, and thieves in the la^d to rob strangers. This
king Mydas was well known in ye realms of orient, and in such sort, that a
friend of his of Thebes said unto him these words. I let thee to weete king
Mydas, that all those of thy own realm do hate thee, and all the other realms
of Asia do fear thee: and this not for that thou can do much, but for the
crafts and subtilties which thou use. By reason where of, all strangers, and
all thine own have made a vow to god, never to laugh during the time of thy
life: nor yet to weep after thy death. Plutarche in the book of pollitiques
says, that when this king Mydas was born, the ants brought corn into his
cradel, and into his mouth: and when the nurse woold have taken it from him, he
shut his mouth, and woold not suffer any parson to take it from him. They
being all amazed with this strange sight, demanded the oracle what this
beetokened. Who answered, that the child should be marvelous rych, and with
that exceeding covetous: which the ants did beetoken in fylling his mouth with
corn. And afterward he woold not geeue them one only grayn and even so it
chanced, that king Mydas was exceedyng rych, and also very covetous: for he
woold never geeue any thing, but that which by force was taken from him, or by
subtelty robbed. In the schools of Athens at that time flourished a philosopher
called Sylenus, who in letters and pureness of life, was highly renowned. And as
king Mydas was known of many, to have great treasures: so this philosopher
Silenus, was no less noted for despysyng them. This philosopher Silenus
trauaylyng by the borders of Phrigia, was taken by the thieves which robbed the
country: and being brought before king Mydas, the king said unto him. Thou
art a philosopher, and I am a king: thou art my prisoner, and I am thy lord: I
will that immedyatly thou tell me, what ransom thou can geeue me to
redeem thy parson: for I let thee to weete that I am not contented any
phlosopher shoold perysh in my country, because you other philosophers say,
that you will willyngly renounce the goods of the world, sith you can not have
it. The philosopher Silenus answered him. Me thinks (king Mydas) that thou
can better execut tyranny, then to talk of philosophy: for we make no
account that our bodies be taken, but that our wills be at lyberty. Thy
demand is very simple, to demand ransom of me for my parson, whether thou
take me for a philosopher or no. If I be not a philosopher, what moves
thee to fear to keep me in thy realm? for sooner shooldst thou make me a
tyrant, then I thee a philosopher. If thou take me for a philosopher, why
do thou demand money of me? sins thou know I am a philosopher, I am a
craftesman, I am a poet, and also a musicion. So that the time that thou in
heapyng up riches have consumed: ye selfsame time have I in learning sciences
spent. Of a philosopher to demand either gold or silver for ransom of his
parson, is either a word in mockery, or else an invention of tyranny, For
since I was borne in the world, riches never came into my hands, nor after
them has my heart lusted. If thou (king Mydas) wooldst geeue me audience and
in the faith of a prince beeleeue me, I woold tell thee what is the greatest
thing, and next unto that the second, that the gods may geeue in this life: and
it may be, that it shall be so pleasant unto thee to here, and so profitable
for thy life, that thou will pluck me from my enemies, and I may diswade thee
from tirannies. When king Mydas hard these words, he gave him license to say
these two things, swearing unto him to hear him with as much pacyence as was
possible. The philosopher Silenus, having license to speak freely, taking an
instrument in his hands, beeganne to play and sing in this wise.

The senate of the gods when they forethought
On earthly wights to still some ryall grace,
the chiefest gift the heavenly powers had wrought
had been to sow his seed in barrayne place.
But when by steps of such divine constraint,
they forced man perforce to fyxe his line,
The highest good to help his bootles plaint
had been to slyp, his race of slender twine.
For then the tender babes both want to know
the dear delight that life does after hale
And eke the dread, that griefly death does show
Er Charons bote, to Stigeanshore does sal^
THese two things the philosopher proved with so high and natural reasons,
that it was a marvelous matter to see with what vehemence Sylenas the
philosopher sang them: and with what bitterness Mydas the tirant wept. Without
doubt the sentences were marvelous profound, which ye philosopher spoke: and
great reason had that king to esteem it so much. For if we do prepare our
selves to consider whereof we are, and what we shall be, that is to weete,
that we are of earth, and that we shall retourn to earth: We woold not cease
to weep nor sygh.

One of the greatest vanities which I find among the children of vanity is,
that they employ them selves to consider the influences of the stars, the
nature of the planets, the motion of the heavens, and they will not consider
them selves of which consyderacion they shoold take some profyt.

For man geeuing his mind to think on strange things, comes to forget his
own propre. O if we woold consider the corruption whereof we are made, the
fylth whereof we are engendered, the infinite travail wherewt we are borne, ye
long tediousnes wherewt we are norished, the great necessities and suspicions
wherein we live, and above all, the great peril where in we dye: I swear,
and affirm that in such consideracion we find a thousand occasions to wysh
death, and not one to desire life. The children of vanyty are occupied many
years in the schools to learn rethoryk, they exercise them selves in
philosophy, they here Aristottel, they learn Homere without book, they study
Cicero, they are occupied in Xenophon, they harken Titus Liuius, they forget
not Aulus Gelius and they know Ouide: yet for all this I say, that we can not
say that the man knows little, which does know him self. Eschines the
philosopher said well, that it is not the least, but the chiefest part of
philosophy to know man, and wherefore he was made: for if man woold deeply
consider what man is, he shoold find mo things in him, which woold move him to
humble him self, then to stir him to be proud. If we do beeholdyt without
passion, and if we do examine it with reason, I know not what there is in man.
O miserable and frail nature of man, the which taken by it self is littel
worth: and compared with an other thing is much less. For man sees in brute
beasts many things which he does e^uy: and the beasts do see much more in
me^, whereo^ if they had reason, they woold have compassion. The excellency of
the soul laid aside, and the hope which we have of eternal life, if man do
compare the captyuyty of men to the lyberty of beasts, with reason we may see,
that the beasts do live a peacible life: and that which men do lead, is but a
long death. If we prepare our selves to consider, from the time that both man
and beast come into this world, until such time as they both die, and in how
many things the beasts are better then men: with reason we may say, that
nature like a pitiful mother has showed her self to beasts, and yt she does
handle us as an iniust stepmother. Let us beeginne therefore to declare more
particularly the original of the one, and the beginning of the other: and we
shall see how much better the brute beasts are endowed, and how ye miserable
men are disherited.

The auctour follows his purpose, and excellently compares the mysery of
men, with the lyberty of beasts. Cap. xxxiij.
WE ought deeply to consider, that no wild nor tame beast is so long before
