he come to his shape, as the miserable man is: who with corruption of blood
and vile matter, is nine months hyd in the womb of his mother. We see the
beast when she is great (if need require) does labor all exercises of
husbandry: so that she is as ready to labor when she is great, as if she
were empty. The contrary happens to women, which when they are big with
child, are weary with going, troubled to be laid, they ride in chariots
through ye market places, they eat little, they brook not that they have eaten,
they hate that which is profitable, and love that which does the^ harm: Finally
a woman with child is contented with nothing, and she fretteth and vexes
with her self. Since therefore it is true, that we are noisome and
troublesome to our mothers, when they bear us in their wombs: why do not we
geeue them some safe conduct, when they are in their delivering? O miserable
state of man, since the brute beasts are borne without destroying their mothers:
but the miserable men before they are born, are troublesome and careful, and
in the time of their birth, are both perilous to them selves, and dangerous
to their mothers. Which seems to be very manifest: for the preparacion that
man makes when he will die, yt self same aught the woman to do, when she is
ready to be delivered. We must also consider, that though a beast has but
two feet, as the birds have, he can go, move, and run, immediately when it
comes forth: but when man is born, he can not go, nor move, and much less
run. So that a popingey ought more to be esteemed, which has no hands: then
the man which has both hands and feet. That which they do to the little babe,
is not but a prognostication of that which he ought to suffer in the progress
of his life: that is to weete. That as they are not contented to put ye evil
dooer in prison, but they lode his hands with yrons, and set his feet in the
stocks: so in like manner to the miserable man, when he enters into the
charter of his life, immediately they bind both his hands and his feet, and lay
him in ye cradel. So that the innocent babe is first bound and rolled, before
he be embraced, or have suck of the mother. We must note also, yt the hour
wherein the beast is brought forth, though it know not ye Sier which begat it,
at ye least it knows ye damme which brought it forth: which is apparent, for
so much as if the mother have milk, the yongling forth with does suck her
teats: and if perchance she have no milk, they go afterward to hide the^
selves under her wings: Of ye miserable man it is not so, but ye day that he
is born, he knows not the nurse that geeueth him suck, neither the father
which has beegotten him, the mother which has born him, nor yet the midwife
which has received him: moreover he can not see with his eyes, hear with his
ears nor judge with the taste, and knows neither what it is to touch, or
smell: so that we see him, to whom ye seygnory over al brute beasts and other
things (that are created) parteineth, to be born the most unable of all other
creatures. We must also consider, that though the beast be never so little,
yet it can seek for ye teates of his mother to suck, or to wa^der in ye fields
to feed, or to scrape ye du^ghilles to eat, or else it goes to ye fou^tayns
and rivers to drink, and yt he lerneth not by ye discourse of time, or yt any
other beast has taught it, but as soon as it is born, so sone does it know
what thing is necessary for it. The miserable man is not borne with so many
present commodities, he can not eat, drynk, nor go, make him self ready, ask,
nor yet complayn, and that which is more, he knows not scarcely how to suck,
for the mothers often times woold geeue to their children (if they could) the
blood of their heart: and yet they can not cause them to take the mylk of their
breasts. O great mysery of man's nature, for so much as the brute beasts as soon
as they are come forth of their mothers womb, can know and seek: but when yt
is offered unto man, he can not know it. We must note also, that to brute
beasts nature has geeuen clothing, wherewyth they may keep them selves from
the heat of Summer, and defend them selves from the cold of winter: which is
manifest, for that to lambs and sheep she has geeuen wool, to byrds
feathers, to hoggs bristels, to horses hear, to fysh scales, and to snayles
shells. Finally I say, there is no beast which has need with his hands to
make any garment, nor yet to borow it of another. Of all this the miserable man
is depryued, who is borne all naked, and dies all naked, not carrying with him
one only garment: and if in the time of his life he will use any garment, he
must demand of the beasts, both leather and wool: and thereunto he must also
put his whole labor and industry.

I woold ask princes, and great lords, if when they are borne, they bring with
them any apparel: and when they die, if they carry with them any treasour? To
this I answer no: but they die as they are borne, as well the rych as the
poor, and the poor as the rich. And admit that in this life fortune does make
difference beetweene us in estates, yet nature in time of our birth, and death,
does make us all equal. We must also think and consider, that for so much as
nature has provided the beasts of garments, she has also taken from them the
care of what they ought to eat: for there is no beast that does either plow,
sow, or labor, but does content her self, and passes her life either with the
little flies of the air, with the corn that she fyndeth in ye highways, with
the herbs in the fyelds, with the ants of the earth, with the grapes of the
vine, or with the fruits which are fallen. Finally I say, that without care all
beasts take their rest, as if the next day followyng they shoold have no need
to eat. O what a great benefit shoold god do to the miserable man, if he had
taken from him the travail to apparel him self, and the care to search for
things to eat. But what shall the poor miserable man do, that before he
eats, he must till, sow, he must reap, and thresh the corn, he must
cleanse it, griend it, paste it, and bake it, and it can not be provided
without care of mind, nor be done without the propre swet of the brows. And if
perchance any man did provide for him self with the swet of others, yet shall
he live with his own offenses. Also in other things the beasts do excel us:
for in the flowers, in the leaves, in the herbs, in the straw, in the otes, in
the bread, in the flesh, or in the fruit which they eat, or in the water which
they drink, they feel no pain, although it be not sweet: nor take any
displeasure, though their meats be not sauory. Finally, such as nature has
provided them, without disgysing or making them selves better, they are
contented to eat. Man coold lose nothing, if in this point he agreed with
beasts: but I am very sorry, yt there are many vicious and proud men, to who^
nothing wants either to apparail, or eat: but they have to much to maintein
them selves, and here with not contended, they are such dronkardes to taste of
diverse wines, and such Epicures to eat of sundry sorts of meats: that often
times they spend more to dress them, then they did cost the bying. Now when
the beasts are brought forth, they have knowledge both of that that is
profitable, and also of that that is hurtful for them. For we see this, that
the sheep flies the wolf, the catt flies the dog, the ratt flies the catt,
and the chicken the kyte: so that the beasts in opening the eyes, do
immediately know the friends who^ they ought to follow, and the enemies whom they
ought to fly. To the miserable man, was utterly denied this so great privilege.
For in the world there has been many beastly men, who has not only attained
that, which they ought to know whiles they lived: but also even as like beasts
they passed their days in this life, so they were infamed at the time of their
death. O miserable creatures yt we are, which live in this wicked world, for
we know not what is hurtful for us, what we ought to eat, from what we
ought to abstain, nor yet whom we shoold hate: we do not agree with those
whom we ought to love, we know not in whom to put our trust, from whom we
ought to fly, nor what it is we ought too choose, nor yet what we ought to
forsake. Finally I say, that when we think often times to enter into a sure
haven, within.3. steps afterward we fall headlong into the deep sea. We
ought also to consider, that both to wild and tame beasts, nature has geeuen
arms, or weapons to defend them selves, and to assault their enemies, as it
appears, for that to birds she has geeuen wings, to the hearts swiftfeete,
to the Elephants, tushes, to the serpents scales, to the Eagle tallons, to the
Faucon a beak, to ye lions teeth, to the bulls horns, and to ye bears paws,
Finally I say, that she has geeuen to the Foxes subtilty to know how to hyde
them selves in the earth, and to the fishes little finnes how to swim in the
water. Admit that ye wretched men have few enemies, yet in this they are none
otherwise priuileged then the beasts: for we see (without tears it cannot be
told) that the beasts which for the service of men were created, with the self
same beasts, men are now adays troubled, and offended. And to the end it seem
not we should talk of pleasure, let every man think with him self, what it is
that we suffer with the beasts of this life: For the Lions do fear us, the
wolfes devour our sheep, the dogs do bite us, the cattes scratche us, the
Bear does tear us, the serpents poyso^ us, the Bulls hurt us, with their
horns, the birds do ouerfly us, the ratts do trouble us, the spiders do annoy
us, and the woorst of all is, yt a litel fly sucketh our blood in ye day, and
the poor flea does let us from sleep in the night. O poor and miserable man
who for to sustein this wretched life, is enforced to beg al things that he
needs of the beasts. For the beasts do geeue him wool, the beast do draw him
water, the beasts do carry him him from place to place, ye beasts do plough the
land, and carries the corn into their barnes. Finally I say, that if the man
receive any good, he has not wherewith to make recompense: and if they do him
any evil, he has naught but the tongue to revenge. We must note also that
though a man lode a best with stripes, beat her, drive her by the foul ways
though he takes her meat from her, yea though her yonglings dye: yet for none
of all these things she is sad, or sorrowful, and much less does weep, and
though she should weep, she cannot. For beasts little esteame their life,
and much less fear death. It is not so of the unhappy and wretched man, which
can not but bewail the unthankfulness of their friends, ye death of their
children, the want which they have of necessityes, the case of adversity which
do succeed them, the false witness which is brought against them, and a
thousand calamities whice do torment their hearts. Finally I say, that the
greatest comfort that men have in this life, is to make a river of water with
the tears of their eyes. Let us inquire of princes and great lords, what they
can do when they are borne, whether they can speak as orators, if they can
run as posts, if they can govern them selves as kings, if they can fight
as men of war, if they can labor as laborers, if they can woork as the
masons, if they knew to teach as masters, these litell children would answer,
that they are not only ignorant of all that we demand of them, but also
that they can not understand it. Let us return to ask them what is that they
know, since they know nothing of that we have demanded them? they will answer
that they can do none other thing, but weep at their birth, and sorrow at
their death. Though al those (which sail in this so perilous sea) do rejoice
and take pleasure, and seem too sleap soundly: yet at the last there comes ye
wind of adversity, which makes them al to know their folly. For if I be not
deceived, and if I know any thing of this world: those which I have seen at
the time of their birth take shipp weeping: I doubt whether they will take land
in ye grave laughing. O unhappy life (I shoold say rather death) which the
mortals take for life, wherein afterward we must consume a great time, to
learn all arts, sciences, and offices: and yet notwithstanding, that whereof
we are ignorante, is more the^ that which we know. We forget the greatest
part save only that of weeping, which no man needs to learn: for we are
borne, and live weeping, and until this present we have seen none dye enjoy.
We must note also that the beasts do live and dye, with the inclinations
where with they were borne: that is to weete, that the wolf follows the
sheep, and not the birds: the hounds follow the hares, and not the ratts: the
sparrow flies at the birds, and not at the fish: the spider eats the flies,
and not the herbs. Finally I say, that if we let the beast search his meat
quietly, we shall not see him geeuen to any other thing.

The contrary of all this happens to men, ye which though nature has created
feeble, yet Gods inte^tio^ was not they should be malicious: but I am sorry,
since they cannot avoid debilyty, that they turn it into malice. The
presumption which they have to be good, they turn to pride: and the desire
they have to be innocent, they turn into envy. The fury which they should
take against malice, they turn into anger: and the liberality they ought to
have with thee good, they convert into auaryce. The necessity they have to eat,
they turn into gluttony: and the care they ought to have of their conscience,
they turn into negligence. Finally I say, that the more strength beasts have,
the more they serve: and the less men are worth, so much the more thanks have
they of god. The innocence of the brute beast considered, and the malice of the
malicious man marked: without comparison, the company of the brute beast is
less hurtful, then the conversation of evil men.

For in ye end, if ye be conversant with a beast, ye have not but to beeware
of her: but if ye be in company with a man, there is nothing where in ye
ought to trust him. We must note also, that it was neither seen, or read,
that there was any beast that took care for the grave: but the beasts being
dead, some ore torn in pieces with Lions, other dysmembred by the bears,
others gnawn with dogs, other remain in the fylds, other are eaten of men, and
other by the ants. Finally, the intralles of the one, are the graves of others.
It is not so of the miserable man, the which consumes no small treasure to
make his tomb, which is the most vaynest thing that is in this miserable life
for there is no greater vanity, nor lyghtnes in man, then to be esteemed for
his goodli and su^ptuous sepulture, and little to way a good life. I will
swear, that at this day all the dead do swear, that they care little if their
bodies be buried in the deep Seas, or in the golden tombs, or that the cruel
beasts have eaten them, or that they remain in the fields without a grave: so
that their souls may be among the celestial companies. Speaking after the
law of a christian, I durst say that it profits little the body to be among
ye painted and carved stones: when the miserable soul is burning, in the fyrye
flames of hell. O miserable creatures, have not we suffycient where with to
seek in this life, to procure, to travail, to accomplish, to sygh, and also
what to beewayle, with out having such care and anguysh, to know where they
shall be buried? Is there any man so vain, that he does not care that other
menn shoold condempn his evil life: so that they praise his rych Tomb? To
those yt are living I speak and say of those that are dead: that if a man gave
them leave to return in to the world, they would be occupied more to correct
their excess, and offenses: then to adourne and repair their graves and
tombs, though they found them fallen down. I cannot tell what to say, more in
this case, but to admonysh men that it is great folly to make any great
account of the graves.

The Emperor Marcus Aurelius writes this letter to Domitius a citezin of Capua
to comfort him in his exile, being banished for a quarrel beetwixt him and an
other about the running of a horse, very comfortable to those that have been in
favor and now fallen in disgrace. Cap. xxxiiii.
Mark the Romain Emperor, borne at mount Celio, to thee Domitius of Capua,
wysheth health, and consolation from Gods the only comforters. The bitter
winter in these parts, have reised boisterus wynds, and the winds have caused
much rayn, and the much rayn has caused great moystures: the which engenders
in me sundry dyseases. Among the which the gowt of my hands is one, and the
Siatica in my leg is another. Eschines the philosopher said, that the liberty
of the soul and the health of the bodi, cannot be esteemed to much and much
less also be bought for money. Tell me I pray thee, what can he do or what
is he worth, yt has neither lyberti, nor health? The divine Plato in his
books of his common wealth, recites three things.

The first, that the man which owes nothing, cannot say that he is poor. For
the day that I ow money to another, another and not my self is lord of mine
own. The second, the man which is no servant, nor captive, has not reason to
say that any thing may make him unhappy. For fortune in nothing shows her
self so cruel, as to take from us the liberty of this life.

The third which Plato said, is that among all temporal goods there is none
more greater, nor greater felicity, then the treasure of health. For the man
which is persecuted with sickness, with riches can have no contentacion. In the
time of our old fathers, when Rome was well corrected, they did not only
ordeine the things of their common wealth: but also they provided for that
which touched the health of every person. So that they watched to cure the
body, and they were circumspect to destroy vices. In the time of Gneus
Patroclus, and Julius Albus, they say that the city of Rome was ordinarily
vysyted with sickness. Wherefore first they did forbid, that in the month of
July, and Augustus, there should be no stews for women. For the blood of the
young, was corrupted in venerial acts.

The second, that no man should bring any fruit from Salon, nor Campania, to
sell during these.2. months in Rome. For the delicate ladies of Rome for
extreme heat, and the poor for their poverty, did not eat in summer but
fruyts: and so the market places were full of fruyts, and the houses full of
agues. The third, they did defend that no inhabitaunt should be so hardy, to
walk after the sunn were set. For the young men, thorough the lightness they used
in the nights, took dyseases which vexed them in the days.

The fourth, they did prohibit that no man should be so hardy, to sell openly
in Rome wine of Candie, or Spain. For in the great heat of the summer, as the
sun is very whot, so the wine as poison does kill young men.

The fifth, that they shoold purge the priuyes, and make clean the streats and
houses. For of the corruption of the air, is engendered the plague among the
people. When Rome was rych, when Rome prospered, all these things were observed
in the common wealth. But since Catilina the Tyrant did rebel, since Scilla
and Marius did slander it, since Caesar and Pompeius did play the tiraunts,
since Octauius Augustus and Marcus Antonius did robb it, since Calligula and
Nero did defame it, they cared litel whither they entered into Rome, to sell the
wine of Spain or Candia. For they feared more the knife of the enemies: then
the heat of the summer. Great reason had the ancients to forbid those things
in Rome, for, to say the troth they are not healthful. When I was young in
Rome, my head did not ache with talking in the night, nor I did feel my blood
chafed with drinkyng wine. Then I was not troubled to iette in the heat in the
summer, nor I was annoyed to goo bare legged in the winter.

But now that I am old, there is no heat but offends me, nor cold but
perseth me. For men through much evil rule in their youth, come to greauous
dyseases in their age. O if mortal men, after that they be old could at any
time woork with the gods, that they shoold beecome young again: I swear unto
thee, by the faith of a good man, that they woold beehaue them selves so well,
that the world should not again deceive them. Since men have been vicious in
their youth, I do not meruell though they are full of dyseases when they are
old. For how can he love his health, which hates virtue? All that which I have
spoken here before is to the end you may know and beeleeue that I am sick,
and that I cannot write unto the so long as I would, and as thou desire: so
that hereof it follows, that I shall bewail thy pain, and thou shall be
grieved with my gowte. I understood here how at ye feast of the god Ianus,
through ye running of a horse, great strife is risen beetweene thee and thy
neighbor Patricius: And the brute was such, that they have confiscated thy
goods, battered thy house, banished thy children, and deprived thee from the
Senate for x. years.

And further, they banished thee out of Capua for ever, and have put thy fellow
in the prison Mamortine: so that by this little fury, thou have cause to lament
all the days of thy life. All those which come from thens do tell us, that
thou art so woeful in thy heart, and so changed in thy parson: that thou do
not forget thy heavy chances, nor receiuest consolation of thy faithful
friends.

Think not that I speak this, that thou should be offended: for according
to the often chaunges which fortune has showed in me, it is long since I knew
what sorrow meant. For truly the man which is sorrowful, sigheth in the day,
watches, in the night, delyteth not in company, and with only care he
rests. The light he hates, the darkness he loves, with bitter tears he
waters the earth, with heavy sighs he perceth the heavens, with infinite
sorows he remembers that that is past, and forseeth nothing that that to come
is. He is displeased with him that does comfort him, and he takes rest to
express his sorrows. Finally, the unfortunate man is contented with nothing,
and with him self continually he does chafe. Beeleue me Domitius, that if I
have well touched the conditions of the sorrowful man, it is for no other
cause, but for that my evil fortune has made me taste them all. And hereof it
comes, that I can so well dyscribe them: for in the end, in things which
touch the sorrows of the spirit, and the troubles of the body, there is great
dyffere^ce from him that has read them, and from him that has felt them. If
thou dydst feel it there, as I do feel it here, it is suffycient to geeue
thee and thy friends great dolor, to think that for so small a trifle thou
should undo thee, and all thy parentage. And speaking with the troth, I am
very sorry to see thee cast away: but much more it greeueth me, to see thee
drowned in so little a water. When men are noble, and keep their hearts high,
they ought to take their enemies agreeable to their estates. I mean, that when
a noble man shall adventure to hazard his person, and his goods, he ought to do
it for a matter of great importance. For in the end, more defamed is he that
overcomes a laborer, then he which is overcome with a knight. O how variable
is fortune, and in how short space does happen an evil fortune? in that which
now I will speak, I do condemn my self, and accuse thee. I complain to the
Gods, I reclayme the dead, and I call the living, to the end they may see, how
that before our eyes we suffer the greeses, and know them not, with the hands
we touch them, and perceue them not, we go over the^ and see them not, they
sound in our ears, and we hear them not, daily they do admonysh us, and we
do not beeleue them: finally we feel the peril, where there is no remedy of
our grief. For as experyence does teach us, with a little blast of wind the
fruit do fall, with a little spark of fire the house is kyndled, with a little
rock the shipp is broken, at a little stone the foot does stumble, with a
little hook they take great fysh, and with a little wound dies a great person.

For all that I have spoken, I mean, that our life is so frayl and fortune so
fykcle, that in that part where we are surest harnessed, we are soonest
wounded. Seneca writing to his mother Albina, wc was banished from Rome, said.

Thou Albina art my mother and I thy son, thou art aged and I am not young, I
never beeleued in fortune, though she woold promise to be in peace with me.
And further he said, all that which is in me, I count it at the dysposition of
fortune, as well of riches, as of prosperitye: and: I keep them in such a
place, that at any hour in the night when she lists, she may carye them
away, and never wake me. So ye though she carry those out of my cofers yet
she should not rob me of this in my intrails. With out doubt such words were
merueylous pythy, and very decent for such a wise man.

The Emperor Adryan my Lord, did wear a ring of gold on his finger which he
said was of the good Drusius Germanicus, and the word about the ring in latin
letters said thus. Illis est grauis fortuna, quibus est repentina. Fortune to
them is most cruel, whom suddenly she assaulteth. We see oftentimes by
experience, that in the fystula which is stopped, and not in that which is
open, the Surgion makes doubt. In the shallow water, and not in the deep
seas, the Pilot despayreth. The good man of arms is more afraid of the
secreate ambushment, then in the open battle. I mean, that the valiant man
ought to beware, not of strangers, but of his own, not of enemies but of
friends, not of the the cruel war, but of the feigned peace, not of the
manifest damage, but of the pryuy peril. O how many we have seen, whom the
myshaps of fortune coold never change, and yet afterward having no care she
has made them fall. I ask now, what hope can man have, which will never trust
to the prosperity of fortune? Since for so light a thing, we have seen such
trouble in Capua, and so great loss of thy person and goods? If we knew
fortune, we woold not make so great complaynt of her.

For speaking the troth, as she is for all, and would content all, though in
the end she mock all, she geeueth and shows us all her goods, and we others
take them for inherytaunce. That which she lends us, we take it for
perpetual, that which in jest she geeueth us, we take it in good earnest, and
in the end, as she is the mocker of all, so she goes mockyng of us, thinking
that she geeueth us another man's, and she takes our own proper. I let thee
wete, that knowing that of fortune which I know, I fear not the turmoyles of
her traueyles neither does her lightnings or thu^ders astony me, nor yet will
I not esteem the pleasantnes, of her goodly fair flatteryes. I will not trust
her sweet reioysings, neither will I make account of her frendshyps, nor I
will join my self with her enemies, nor I will take any pleasure of ye she
gives me, neither grief of yt she takes from me, nor I will have respect
when she tells me truth, nor I do not regard it, though she tell me a lie.

Finally, I will not laugh for that she asks me, nor I will weep for yt
she sends me. I will now tell thee (my friend Domitius) one thing, and
heartily I desire thee to keep it in memory. Our, life is so doubtful, and
fortune so sudden yt when she thretneth, she stryketh not always, neither
does she threaten always when she stryketh. The man which presumes to be
sage, and in all things well provided, goes not so fast, yt at every step
he is in danger of falling, nor so softly, that in long time he cannot aryue
at his journeys end. For the false fortune gauleth in steed of strikyng, and in
steed of gauling strikes:

Therefore since in years I am older then thou, and have more experience of
affairs: if thou have marked that I have told thee, thou wylt remember well that
which I will say unto thee, which is: that that part of thy life is
troublesome, which unto the seems to be most sure. wylt thou that by example
I tell thee all that, which by words I have spoken? Behold Hercules of Thebes,
who escaped so many dangers, both by sea and by land, and afterward came to
die in the arms of a harlotte. Agamemnon the great Captain of Greeks in the
x. years which he warred against Troy, never had any peril: and afterward in
the night, they killed him entering into his own house.

The vnuincyble Alexander the great, in all the conquests of Asia did not dye,
and afterward with a little poison, ended his life in Babylon. Pompeius the
great, dyed not in the conquest of his enemies: and afterward his friend
Ptholomeus slew him. The couragyus Julius Caesar, in.lii. battles could not be
ouercom: and afterward in the Senate, they slew him with xxiii. wounds.

Hannibal, the terryble captain of Carthage, slew him self in one moment
(which the Romans could not do, in xvii. years) only because he would
not com into ye hands of his enemies. Asclipius medius, brother of great
Pompeius, in xx. years that he was a rouer on ye seas, never was in any peril:
afterward drawyng water out of a well, was drowned therein. Ten Captains,
who^ Scipio had chosen in the conquest of Affrike, jesting on a bridge, fell
into the water, and there were drowned. The good Bibulus going triu^phing in his
chariot at Rome, a tile fell on his head: so that his vain glory was the end of
his good life. What wylt thou more I say unto thee, but that Lucia my sister
having a needel on her breast, and her child between her arms: the child
layeng his hand upon the needell, and thrust it into her breast, whereby the
mother dyed. Gneus Ruffirius: Which was a very wise man, and also my kinseman,
one day keamyng his white hears, struck a tooth of the comb in his head,
wherewith he gave him self a mortal wound: so that in short space after his
life had end, but not his doctrine, nor memory. How think thou Domitius: by
the immortal gods I swear unto thee, that as I have declared to thee this small
number, so I coold recite thee other infinyte. What mishap is this after so
many fortunes? what reproach after such glory? What peril after such surety?
what evil luck, after such good success? What dark night after so clear a day?
What so evil enterteinment, after so great labor? What sentence so cruel,
after so long process? O what inconvenience of death, after so good beginning of
life? Being in their stead, I can not tell what I would but I had rather choose
unfortunate life and honorable death: then an infamous death, and honorable
life. That man which will be counted for a good man and not noted for a brute
beast, ought greatly to travail to live well, and much more to dye better. For
the evil death makes men doubt that the life has not been good, and the good
death is the excuse of an evil life. At the beeginnyng of my letter I wrate
unto thee, how that the gowt troubles me evil in my hand. I say it were to
much to write any le^ger, and though the letter be not of mine own hand,
these two days the love that I bear thee, and the grief that holds me, have
stryued together. My will desires to write, and my fingers cannot hold the
pen. The remedy hereof is that since I have no power to do what I would as
thine, thou oughtst to accept what I can as mine. I say no more herein, but as
they tell me thou buildest now a house in Rhodes: wherefore I send thee a
thousand sexterces to accomplysh the same. My wife Faustine saluteth thee, who
for thy pain is sore dyseased. They tell us thou have been hurt, wherefore she
sends thee a weight of the balm of Palestyne. Heal thy face therewith, to
the end the scarres of that wound do not appear. If thou find green
almonds, and new nutts, Faustine desires thee that thou will send her some. By
another man she sends a gown for thee, and a kirtell for thy wife. I
conclude, and do beeseech thee immortal Gods to geeue thee all that I desire
for thee, and that they geeue me all that thou wyshest me. Though by the
hands of others I write unto thee, yet with my heart I love thee.

That Princes and noble men ought to be advocates for widows, fathers of
orphans, and helpers of all those which are comfortles. Cap. xxxv.
MAcrobius in the third book of the Saturnalles says, that in the noble cyty
af Athens, there was a temple called Misericordia, which the Athenians kept so
well watched, and locked, that without leave and license of the Senate no man
might enter in. There were the Images of pitiful princes only, and none
entered in there to pray but pitefull men.

The Atheniens abhorred always severe and cruel deeds, because they would not
be noted cruel. And thereof comes this manner of saying, that the greatest
injury they could say unto a man was, that he had never entered into the scoole
of the philosophers to learn, nor in to the temple of Misericordia to pray. So
that in the one, they noted him for simple: and in the other they accused him
for cruel. The historiographers say that the most noble lineage that was at
that time, was of a king of Athens, the which was exceeding rych and lyberall
in geeuing: and above all very pitiful in pardoning. Of whom it is written,
that after the great treasours which he had offered in the temples, and the
great riches he had distributed to the poor: he took upon him to bring up
all the orphans in Athens, and to feed all the widows. O how much more did
that statut of the said pytyfull king shine in that temple, who norished the
orphans, then the ensigns which are set up in the Temples of the captains,
which had robbed the wydows. All the ancient princes, I say those that have
been noble and valiant, and that have not had the name of tiraunts, though in
some things they were noted: yet they always have been praised, esteemed, and
commended to be gentle and merciful: so that they recompensed the fiersnes
and cruelty which they show to their enemies, with the mercy and clemency which
they used to the orphans. Plutarch in his politikes says: that the Romans
among them selves ordained, that all that which remained of bankettes and
feasts, which were made at marriages and triumphs, shoold be geeuen to wydows,
and orphans. And this custom was brought to so good an order that if any rich
man would use his profit of that which remained, yt orphans might justly have
an accion of felony against him as a thing robbed from them. Aristides ye
philosopher in an oration he made of ye excellency of Rome says that ye
princes of Persia had this custom, never to dyne nor sup, but first ye trumpets
shoold blow at their gates: the wc were more loud, then armonious. And it was
to this end, that all the widows and orphans shoold come thither: for it was a
law amongst them, that all yt which was left at the royal tables, should be
for the poor and indigent persons. Phalaris ye tyrant writing to a friend of
his, said these words. I have receued thy brieef letter, with ye rebuke likewise
wc thou gave me therein, more bitter the^ tedyous. And admit yt for ye time
it grieved me, yet after I came to my self, I received thereby great comfort.
For in the end, one loving rebuke of his friend is more worth: then a feigned
flattery of his enemy. Amongst the things whereof thou accusest me, thou say
yt they take me for a great tiraunt, because I disobey the gods, spoil the
temples, kill the priests, pursue the innocents, rob the people: and the woorst
of all yt I do not suffer me to be entreted, nor permit yt any man be
conuersau^t with me. To that they say I disobey the gods, in very deed they
say true. For if I did all that ye gods would, I shoold do little of that men
do ask me. For as much as they say I robb the temples, thereunto also I
grant: For the immortal gods do demand rather of us pure hearts, then that
we shoold buyld their temples. For that they say I kill priests, I confess also
that it is true. For they are so dissolute, that I think I do more services to
the gods, to put them to death: then they do in doing their sacrifices whiles
they live. For that they say I rob the temples, I also confess it: for I
defending it as I do from enemies, it is but meet and reasonable they find
me and my servants. For yt they say I suffer me not to be entreated, it is
true. For daily and hourly they ask me so many unjust, and unreasonable
things, yt for them and for me it is better to denay them: then for to grant
them. For that they say that I am not conversant with any, I confess it is
true. For ever when they come into my palace, it is not so much to do me
service, as to ask me some particular thing for their profit. For that they
say I am not pitefull amongst the miserable, and will not hear the wydows, and
orphans, in no wise to that I will agree: For I swear unto thee, by the
immortal gods, that my gates were never shutt to widowees, and orphans. Pulio
in the life of the Emperor Claudius says, that ons a poor widow came before
Claudius the Emperor with weeping eyes, to desire him of justice. The good
prince being moved with compassion, did not only weep as she: but with his
own hands dried her tears. And as there was about ye emperor many noble
Romans, one amongst them said unto him. For ye authority and grauitye of
Romayn princes, to hear their subjects in justice, suffiseth only: though
they dry not ye tears of their faces. This emperor Claudius au^swered. Good
princes ought not to be contented, to do no more than just judges: but in
doing justice, a man must know yt they are pitefull. For oftentimes those wc
come before princes, do return more contented with the love they show them:
then with the justice they minister unto them. And further he said. For as much
as you say yt it is of small aucthoryty, and also of less gravity, that a
prince do weep with a widow, and with his hands wype her eyes, I answer: thee
that I desire rather to be partaker of the griefs with my subjects, then to
give them occasion to have their eyes full of tears.

Certeynly these words are worthy to be noted, and no less followed.

Admit that clemency in all things deserves to be praised, yet much more
ought it to be commended, when it is executed on weemen. And if generally in
all, much more in those which are void of health, and comfort. For weeme^ are
quickly troubled, and with greater difficulty comforted.

Plutatche, and Quintus Curtius say, the good intertainment which Alexander
the great, showed unto the wife and children of king Darius (after he was
utterly vanquished) exalted his clemency: in such sort, that they gave rather
more glory to Alexander, for the pity and honesty which he used with the
children, then for the victory he had of the father. And when the unhappy king
Darius knew the clemency and pity, which the good Alexander used to his wife,
and his children, he sent unto him his ambassadors, to the end yt on his
beehalf they shoold thank him for yt yt is past, and shoold desire him that
he would continue so in time to come: saing, that it might chance, that the
Gods and fortune would mitigat their wrath against him.

Alexander answered to the imbassadours these words, Ye shall say in my
beehalf to your king Darius, that he geeue me no thanks for the good and
piteful woork that I have done to his captyue weemen, since he is certain I
did it not for that he was my friend: and I would not cease to do it, for yt
he is mine enemy. But I have done it, for that a gentle Prince is bound to do
in such a case. For I ought to employ my clemency to weemen, which can do
naught but weep: and my puissaunte power Princes shall feel, wc can do naught
else but wage battle. Truly these words were worthy of such a prince, Many
have envy at ye surname of Alexander, wc is great. And he is caled Alexander
ye great, because if his heart was great in ye e^terprises he took upon him,
his courage was much more greter in cities and realms wc he gave. Many have
e^uy at yt renown which they geeue Pompeius, because they call him great, for
this excellent Romayn made him self co^queror of.22. realms, and in times past
has been accompanied with 25. kings. Many have envy at the renown of Scipio
the Affrica^, who was caled Affricane, because he overcame and conquered the
great and renowned city of Carthage: the which city in riches was greater then
Rome, in arms and power it surmounted all Europe. Many have envy at Scipio the
Asian, who was called Asian, because he subdued the proud Asia: the which
until his time was not but as a church yard of Romans. Many have great envy
at the imortall name of Charles, who was called Charles the great, because
being as he was (a little king) he did not only vanquish and triumph over
many kings, and strange realms: but also forsake the royal sea of his own
realm.

I do not maruayl, that the proud princes have envy against the virtuous and
valiant princes: but if I were as they, I would have more envy at the renown
of Antonius the emperor, then of the name and renown of all the princes in the
world. If other princes have attained such proud names, it has been for that
they robbed many countries, spoiled many temples, committed much tyranny,
dissembled with many tyraunts, persecuted diverse innocents, and because they
have taken, from diverse good me^, not only their goods but also their lives:
For the world has such an euel property, yt to exalt ye name of one only, he
puts down, 500. Neither in such e^terprises, nor with such titles, wa^ the
emperor Anthonius Pius his name, and renown. But if they call him Anotonius the
pitefull, it is because he knew not but to be father of Orphans: and was not
praised, but because he was advocate of wydows. Of this most excellent prince
is read, that he himself did here, and judge the complaints and process in
Rome of the orphans: And for the poor, and wydows, the gates of his palace
were always open? So that the porters which he kept within his palace, were
not for to let the enter of the poor: but for to let and keep back the rich.
The historiographers oftentimes say, that this good prince said, that the good
and virtuous princes, ought always to have their hearts open for the poor, and
to remedy the wydows, and never to shut the gates against them. The god Apollo
says, that the prince which will not speedely judge the causes of the poor,
the gods will never permit that he be well obeyed of the rich. O high and
worthy words, that it pleased not ye god Apollo, but our living god, that
they were written in the hearts of princes. For nothing can be more unjust or
dishonest, then that in the palace of princes and great lords, the rich and
fools shoold be dispatched: and the widows and orphans frinds should have no
audience, Happy, and not once, but a hundredth times happy is he, that will
remember the poor afflicted, and open his hand too comfort them, and does not
shut his cofers from helping them, unto him I assure and promise, that at the
straight day of judgment, the process of his life shall be judged with mercy
and pity.

That the troubles griefs, and sorows of widows are much greater, then those
of widdowers: where fore princes and noble men ought to have more compassion
upon the weemen: then on men. Cap. xxxvi.
IT is great pity to see a noble and virtuous man sorrowful, alone and a
widower, if especially he lived contented when he was married. For if he will
not mary, he has lost his sweet company: and if he think to mary an other,
let him be assured he shall scarcely agree with his second wife. There is
much sorrow in that house, where the woman that governed it is dead: For
immediately ye husband forsakes him self, the children do lose their
obedience, the servants beecome neglygent, the hand maids beecome wanto^, the
friends are forgotten, the house decays, the goods wast, the apparel is lost:
and finally in the widowers house there are many to rob and few to labor.
Heavy and lamentable are the thoughts of ye widower: for if he thinks to
mary, it greueth him to geeue his children a stepmother. If he can not be
married, he feels greater pain, seeing him al ye day to remain alone: so
that ye poor miserable man sigheth for his wife he has lost, and weepeth for
her whom he desires to have. Admit yt this be true, there is great
difference from ye cares and sorows of weemen, to yt of men. A thing very
clear, for so much as the widower lawfully may go out of his house, he may
go to ye fields, he may talk with his neigbours, he may be occupied with his
friends, he may follow his suits and also he may be conversant, and refresh
him self in honest places. For commonly men are not so sorrowful in taking ye
death of their wives, as ye wives are, in taking the death of their husbands.
All this is not spoken in ye disfavor of wise and sage men, whom we see make
small streams, with ye tears of their eyes for ye death of their wives: But
for many other vain and light men: wc (the 9. days of the funeral past) a man
does see without any shame to go through ought the strets, beeholding the ladies
and damsells which are in the windows. Truly the woeful women, which are
honest, use not such lightness. For whiles they are widows, it is not lawful
for them to wander abroad, to go out of the house, nor speak with strangers,
nor practice with her own, nor be conversant with her neighbors, nor plead
with their creditours, but agreeable to their woeful estate, to hide and
withdraw them selves in their houses, and to lock them selves in their
chambers: and they think it their duty, to water their pla^ts with tears, and
importune the heavens with sighs. O how woeful? o how grievous? o how sorrowful
is the state of wydowes? for so much as if a widow go out of her house, they
take her for dishonest. If she will not come out of the house, she loses her
goods: If she laugh a litel they count her light, If she laugh not, they call
her an hipocrit. If she go to the church, they note her for a gadder. If she
go not to the church, they say she is unthankful to her late husband. If
she go il apparayled they count her to be a nigard. If she go clenly and
handsome they say nowshee would have a new husband. If she do mainteyne her
self honestly, they note her to be presumptuous. If she keep company,
immediately they suspect her house.

Finally I say, that the poor miserable widows shall find a thousand which
judge their lives, and they have not one that will remedy their pains. Much
loses the woman, who loses her mother which has borne her or her sisters
which she loves, or the fri^des which she knows, or the goods which she
has heaped up: but I say and affirm, that there is no greater loss in ye
world unto a woman, then the loss of a good husband. For in other losses there
is but one only loss: but in that of the husband, al are lost together.
After that the wife does see her loving husband in the grave, I woold ask her
what good could remain with her in her house? Since we know, that if her
husband were good, he was the haue^ of al her trobles, the remedy of al her
necessitys, the inuentour of all her pleasours, the true love of her heart, the
true lord of her parson, and the idol whom she honored: finally he was the
faithful steward of her house, and the good father of her children and
familye. Whether family remains or not, whyther children remains or not, in
the one and in the other, trouble and vexation remains most assuredly to the
poor widow. If perchance she remain poor, and have no goods, let every man
imagine what her life can be. For the poor miserable unhappy woman, either
will adventure her parson to get, or will lose her honesty to demand. An honest
woman, a noble and worthy woman, a delicat woman a sweet woman, a woman of
renown, a woman that ought to maynteyne children, and family, ought to have
great reason to be full of anguishe and sorrow: to see, that if she will
mainteyne her self wc the needle she shall not have sufficiently to find her
self bread and water. If she gain with her body she loses her soul. If
she must demand others, she is sahamed. If she fulfill the testament of her
husband, she must sell her gowns If she will not pay his detts, they cause
her to be brought before the judge. As women naturaly are tender, what heart
will suffer them to suffer such inconuenie^ces? and what eyes can abstain to
shed infinite tears? If perchance goods do remain to the miserable widow,
she has no litel care to keep the^? She is at great charges and expenses, to
sustain, and maintayn her self in long suit about her lands, much trouble to
augment them, and in the end, much sorrow to depart from them.

For all her children, and heirs, do occupy them selves more to think, how
they might inherit: then in what sort they ought to serve her. When I came to
this passage, a great while I kept my pen in suspense, to see whither I ought
to touch this matter or no, that is to weete, that oftentimes the poor wydows
put openly the demand of their goods: and the judges do secretly demand the
possession of their parson. So that first they do injury to her honor, before
they do minister justice to her demands. Though perchance she has no child,
yet therefore she remains not without any comfort, and for that the parents
of her husband do spoil her of her goods. For in this case their heirs often
times are so disordered, that for a worn cloak, or for a broken shirt, they
trouble and sore vex the poor wydow. If perchance the miserable wydow have
children, I say that in this case she has double sorrow. For if they are young,
she endures much pain to bring them up: so that each hour and moment, their
mothers live in great sorows, to think only of the life, and health of their
children. If perhaps the children are old, truly the griefs which remayn unto
them are no less. For so much as the greatest part of them are either proud,
disobedient, malycious, negligent, adulterers, gluttons, blasphemers, false
liars, dull headed, wanting wit, or sickly.

So that the joy of the woeful mothers is to beewayl the death of their
welbeeloued husbands, and to remedy the discords of their youthful children.
If the troubles which remain to the mothers with the sons be great: I say
that those which they have with their daughters, be much more. For if the
daughter be quick of wit, ye mother thinks yt she shall be undone. If she
be simple, she thinks that every man will deceive her. If she be faier,
she has enough to do to keep her. If she be deformed: she cannot mary
her. If she be well manered, she will not let her go from her. If she be
evil manered, she cannot endure her. If she be to solitary, she has not
wherewith to remedy her. If she be dissolute, she will not suffer her to be
punished. Finally, if she put her from her, she fears she shall be
sclaundeted. If she leave her in her house, she is afraid she shall be
stolen. What shall the woeful poor wydow do, seeing her self burdened with
daughters, and environed with sons, and neither of them of such sufficient
age, that there is any time to remedy them: nor substance to maintein them?
Admit that she mary one of her sons, and one daughter, I demand therefore if
the poor widow will leave her care, and anguish? Truly I say no, though she
choose rich personages, and well disposed, she cannot escape, but the day that
she replenisheth her self with daughters in law, the same day she charge
her heart with sorows, travels, and cares. O poor wydows, deceive not your
selves, and do not immagin that having married your sons, and daughters, from
that time forward ye shall live more joyful and contented. For that laid aside,
which their nephews do demand them, and that their sons in law do rob
them: when the poor old woman thinks to be most surest, ye young man shall
make a claym to her goods. What daughter in law is there in this world, who
faithfully loves her stepmother? And what son in law is there in the world,
ye desires not to be heir to his father in law? Suppose a poor widow to be
fallen sick, the which has in her house a son in law, and that a man ask him
upon his oath, which of these two things he had rather have: either to govern
his mother in law, with hope to heal her: or to bury her, with hope to inherit
her goods. I swear that such woold swear, that he coold rejoice more to geeue
a ducket for the grave: then a penny to the physician, to purge and heal her.
Seneca in an epistle says, that the fathers in law naturally love their
daughters in law, and the sons in law are loved of their mothers in law. And
for the contrary he says, that naturally the sons in law do hate their
mothers in law: But I take it not for a general rule, for there are mothers in
law which deserve to be woorshipped, and there are sons in law which are not
worthy to be beeloued. Other troobles chance daily to these poor wydows,
which is, that when one of them has one only son, whom she has in the
steed of a husband, in steed of a brother, in steed of a son, she shall see
him dye: whom since she had his life in such great love, she cannot though
she woold, take his death with patience: So that as they bury the dead body of
the innocent child, they bury the lively heart of the woeful mother. Let us omit
the sorows which the mothers have when their children dye, and let us ask the
mothers what they feel when they are sick? They will answer us, that always
and as often times as their children be sick, the death of their husbands then
is renewed, imagining that it will happen so unto them, as it has done unto
others. And to say the truth, it is not marvel if they do fear. For the vine
is in greater peril, when it is budded, then when the grapes are ripe. Other
troubles oftentimes increase to the poor widows, the which amongst others this
is not the least: that is to weete, the little regard of the friends of her
husband, and the unthankfulness of those which have been brought up with him.
The which since he was laid in his grave, never entered into the gates of his
house: but to demand recompense of their old services, and to renew and beegin
new suits. I woold have declared (or to say better, breefly touched) the
travels of wydows, to persuade princes that they remedy them, and to admonish
judges to hear them, and to desire all virtuous men to comfort them. For the
woork of it self is so godly, that he deserves more which remedyeth ye
troubles of one only: then I which write their miseries all together.

Of a letter which the Emperor Marcus Aurelius wrote to a Romayn Lady named
Lauinia, comforting her for the death of her husband. Cap. xxxvii.
MArcus of mount Celio, Emperor of Rome, cheef consul, tribune of the people,
high Bishop, appointed against the Daces, wishes health and comfort to thee
Lauinia, noble, and worthy Romayn matron, the late wife of the good Claudinus.
According to that thy person deserves, to that which unto thy husband I ought,
I think well that thou will suspect that I way thee little: for yt unto thy
great sorows, complaints, and lamentacions, are now aryued my negligent
consolacio^s. When I remember thy merits, wc can not fail, and imagine that ye
wilt remember my good will, wherewith always I have desired to serve thee: I am
assured, yt if thy suspision accuse me, thy virtue and wisdom will defend
me. For speaking the truth, though I am ye last to comfort thee: yet I was
the first to feel thy sorows. As ignorance is the cruel scourge of virtues,
and spur to all vices: so it chances often times, yt over much knowledge,
puts wise men in doubt, and sclaundereth ye innocent. For as much as we see
by experience, the most presumptuous in wisdom, are those which fall into
most perilous vices. We find the latins much better with the ignorance of
vices: then the Greeks with the knowledge of virtues. And the reason hereof
is, for that of things which we are ignorant we have no pain to attayn unto
them: and less grief also to lose them. My intention to tell thee this was,
because I knew that, which I woold not have known, and have hard that, which I
woold not have hard: that is to weete, yt the days and troubles of Claudinus
thy husband are ended, and now thy sorows ( Lauinia his wife) do begin. It is
now a good while, that I have known of the death of ye good Claudinus my friend,
and thy husband, though I did dissemble it. And by the god Mars I swear unto
thee, that it was not for that I woold not beewayl him, but because I woold not
disco^fort thee. For it were extreme cruelty, that she wc was so comfortless,
and sorrowful, for the absence of so long time: shoold be killed with my hand,
through ye knowledge of the death of her so desired husband. It were to unkind
and unseemly a thing, that she, of whom I have received so many good woorks:
shoold receive of me so evil news. The ancients of Carthage held for an
inviolable law, that if the father did tell ye death of his son, or ye son
the death of the father, or ye woman ye death of her husband, or the husband
the death of his wife, or any other semblable woeful, and lamentable death: that
he shoold be cast into the prison, among them wc were condemned to dye. It
seemed to those of Carthage, that he wc said unto an other, that his brother,
kinsman, or friend, was dead, immediately they shoold kill him, or he ought to
dye, or at the least he shoold never be seen in his presence. If in this
case the law of the Carthagians was just: then I ought to be excused, though I
have not told thee this heavy news. For as often as we see him, who has brought
us any evil tidings: our sorows by his sight is renewed again. Since Claudinus
thy husband dyed, I have not had one hour of rest, for to pass thy time away:
for fear lest such woeful and sorrowful news, shoold come to thy knowledge. But
now that I know thou know it, I feel double pain. For now I feel his death,
my care, and thy want of consolation: and the damage by his death shall follow to
the romayn Empire. Thou have lost a noble Romayn, valyant in blood, moderat in
prosperityes, pacient in adversities, coragious in dangers, diligent in
affairs, wise in counsels, faithful to his friends, subtle and ware of his
enemies, a lover of the common wealth, and very honest in his person: and above
all, and whereof I have most envy is, that he never offended man in his life,
nor hurt any with his tongue. We find seldom times, so many virtues assembled in
one man.

For saying the truth, if a man did narowly examine ye vices of many, which
presume to be very virtuous: I swear that he shoold find more to reprove,
then to praise. Since you have lost so good a husband, and I so faithful a
friend: we are bound, thou to beewayl so great a loss, and I to sigh for so
good a companion. And this I do not desire for Claudine, who now rests among
ye gods: but for us others, wc remayn in danger of so many evils. For ye dead
do rest, as in the sure haven: and we others do sail, as yet in raging sea.
O thou heavy heart, how do I see thee, beetweene the bell and the clappers,
that is to weete, that thou want the company of ye good: and art environed
with the flock of evil. For the wc occasion, I doubt often times, whether I may
first bewaill the evil which live: or ye good wc are dead, because in the end
ye evil men do offend us more, wc we find: then does the good men which we
lose. It is a great pity, to see the good and virtuous men dye: but I take it
to be more sorrow, to see the evil and vicious men live. As the divine Plato
says, the gods to kill the good wc serve them, and to geeue long life to the
evil wc offend them, is a mystery so profound, that daily we do lament it,
and yet we can never attayn to the secrets thereof. Tell me I pray thee
Lauinia, know thou not now, that the gods are so merciful, with whom we go
when we dye, and that men are so wicked, with whom we be whiles we live:
that as ye evil were born to dye, so the good dye to live? for the good man
though he dye, lives: and the evil man though he live, dies. I swear unto
thee by the mother Berecinthia, and so the god Jupiter do preserve me, that I
speak not this which I will speak fainedly: which is, that considering the
reast that the dead have with the gods, and seeing the sorows and troubles we
have here with the living: I say, and affirm once again, that they have greater
compassion of our life, then we others have sorrow of their death. Though the
death of men were as ye death of beasts, that is to weet, yt there were no
furies, nor devils, wc shoold torment the evil, and that the gods shoold not
reward ye good: yet we ought to be comforted, to see our friends dye, if it
were for no other, but to see the^ delivered from ye thraldo^ of this miserable
world. The pleasure yt the Pilot has to be in sure haven, the glory yt the
captain has to see the day of victory, the rest that the traueler has to see
his journey ended, the contentation that the woork man has to see his woork
come to perfeccion, all ye same have the dead, seeing them selves out of this
miserable life. If men were born always to live, it were reason to lament them,
when we see them dye: but since it is troth that they are borne to dye, I
woold say, since needs dye we must, that we ought not to lament those which
dye quickly, but those which live long. I am assured, that Claudine thy
husband, remembering that which in this life he has passed, and suffered, and
seeing the rest that he has in the other: though the Gods woold make him
emperor of Rome, he woold not be one day out of his grave. For returning to
the world, he shoold dye again: but being with the gods, he hops to live
perpetually. Lady Lauinia, most earnestly I desire thee, so vehemently not to
perse the heavens with thy so heavy sighs, ne yet to wete the earth, with thy
so bitter tears: since thou know, that Claudine thy husband is in place,
where there is no sorrow, but mirth, where there is no pain, but rest: where he
weepeth not, but laugheth, where he sigheth not, but sings, where he has
no sorows, but pleasures, where he fears not cruel death, but enjoys
perpetual life. Since therefore this is true, it is but reason the wydow
appease her anguish, considering that her husband endures no pain.

Often times with my self I have thought, what the widows ought to immagin,
when they see them selves in such cares and distress.

And after my count made, I find that they ought not to thynk of the company
past, nor woeful solitarynes wherein they are presently, and much less they
ought to think on the pleasures of this world: but rather to remember the rest
in the world to come. For the true widow ought to have her conversation among
the living, and her desire to be with the dead. If til this present thou had
pain, and trouble, to look for thy husband to come home: have thou now joy,
that he looks for thee in heaven, wherein I swear unto thee, that there thou
shall be better used of ye gods, then he was here of me^. For in this world
we know not what glory means, and there they know not what payns are.
Licinius and Posthumous thy uncles, told me that thou art so sorrowful, that
thou will receive no comfort: but in this case I think not, that thou bewailest
so much for Claudinus, that thou alone do think you have lost him. For since
we did rejoice togethers in his life: we are bound to weep togethers at his
death. The heavy and sorrowful hearts, in this world feel no greater greef: then
to see others rejoice at their sorows. And the contrary hereof is, that the
woeful and afflicted heart feels no greater joy, nor rest in extreme mishaps
of fortune, then to think that others have sorrow and greef of their pain. When
I am heavy and comfortles, I greatly joy to have my friend by me: and my heart
does tell me, that what I feel, he feels: So that all which my friend with
his eyes does beewail, and all that which of my greefes he feels, the more
therewith he burdeneth him self, and the more thereof he discharges me. The
Emperor Octauian Augustus (the histories say) on the river of Danuby, found a
kind of people which had this strange custom, that with eyes was never seen,
nor in books at any time ever read, which was: that two friends assembled, and
went to the aultars of the temples, and there one friend confederat with an
other: so that their hearts were married, as man and wife are married touching
their bodies, swering, and promysing there to the gods, never to weep, nor to
take sorrow, for any mishap that shoold come to their persons. So that my friend
shoold come to lament, and remedy my troubles, as if they had been his own: and
I shoold lament, and remedy his, as if they had been mine. O glorious world, O
age most happy, O people of eternal memory, wherein men are so gentle, and
frendz so faithful: that their own trauails they forgot, and the sorows of
strangers they beewayled. O Rome without rome, O time evil spent, O life to us
others evil employed, O wretch that always art careless, now adays ye stomach
and intrailes are so severed from the good, and the hearts so joined with the
evil: that men forgetting them selves to be men, beecome more cruel then
wyld beasts. I labor to geeue thee life: and thou seek to procure my death.
Thou weepest to see me laugh: and I laugh to see thee weep. I procure that
thou do not mount: and thou seek that I might fall. Finally without the
profit of any, we cast our selves away: and without gayn, we do rejoice to
end our lives. By the faith of a good man I swear unto thee (Lady Lauinia) that
if thy remedy were in my hands, as thy grief is in my heart: I woold not be
sorry for thy sorows, neither thou so tormented for the death of thy husband.
But alas, though I miserable man have the heart to feel thy anguysh: yet I want
power to remedy thy sorows.

The Emperor proceeds in his letter, and persuades wydowes to put their
wills to the will of god, and exhorts them to live honestly. Cap. xxxviii.
SInce thy remedy, and my desire cannot be accomplished, because it is a
thing impossible to receive, and speak with the dead: and not having power, me
think that thou and I shoold refer it to the gods, who can geeue much better
then we can ask. O lady Lauinia, I desire thee earnestly, and as a friend I
counsel and admonish thee, and with all my heart I require thee, that thou
esteem that for well done, which the gods have done, that thou conform thy self
to the will of ye gods, and that thou will naught else, but as ye gods will. For
they only know they err not, wherefore they have assaulted thy husband with so
sodein death: and to thee his wife, have lent so long life. The gods being as
they are, so mighty, and so sage, what is he that can be judge of their
profound iugements. The gods know right well those which serve them, and those
which offend them: those that love them, and those wc hate them: those that
praise them, and those that blaspheme them: those that yield them thanks, and
those which are unthankful. And I tell thee further, that oftentimes the gods
are served more with them which are buried in the graves: then with those which
go weeping through the temples. Will thou now enter into account with the gods?
thou oughtst to note and consider, that they have left thee children to comfort
thy self, they have left thee goods wherewith thou may avoid poverty, they
have left thee friends by whom thou shall be favored, they have left thee
parentz of whom thou art beeloued, they have left thee a good name for to be
esteemed, and health wherewith thou may live: Finally I say, that small is
that which the gods take from us, in respect of yt they leave us. After one
sort we ought to beehaue our selves with men, and after an other we ought to
serve the gods. For to men some times it is requisite, to show a countenance
for to humble them: but to the gods it is necessary, to lie flat on the ground
with thy stomach to honor them. And if the Oracle of Apollo do not deceive us,
ye gods are sooner with humility (wherewith we woorship them) appeased: then
with presumptuous sacrifices (wc we offer unto them) contented. Since thou art
wydow (Lady Lauinia) and art a wise and virtuous woman, beesech the gods to
preserve thy children, to defend thy renowm, and not to sever thy friends from
thee, and that thou scatter not thy goods, to preserve thy person in health,
and above all, to be in their, favor. Thou can not win, nor lose so much
in all thy life: as the gods can geeue, or take from thee in one hour. Woold
to god the wydow knew, how little she wins among men, and how much she
loses among the Gods, when she is not pacient in adversity: for impacience
oftentimes, provoke the gods to wrath. We see it in man's body by experience,
that there are sundry dyseases, which are not cured with words spoken: but with
the herbs thereunto applied. And in other diseases the contrary is seen, which
are not cured with costly medicynes: but with comfortable words.

The end of this comparison tends to this effect, that all the afflicted
hearts shoold know, that sometimes the heart is more comforted with one benefyte
which they do: then with a hundred words which they speak. And at an other
time, the sorrowful heart is better lyghtned, with one word of his friends
mouth: then with all the service of others in the world. O wretch that I am,
for as in the one, and in the other I am destitut: So in all I do want. For
considering thy greatness, and waying my little knowledge, I see my self very
unable. For that to comfort thee, I want science: and for to help thee I need
riches. But I cease not to have great sorrow, if sorrow in payment may be
received. That wc with my person I can do, neither with paper or ynk I will
requite. For the man wc with word only comforts (in effect being able to
remedy) declares him self to have been a feigned friend in times past: and
shows that a man ought not to take him for a faithful friend in time to come.
That which the Romans with the wydows of Rome have accustomed to do, I will
not presently do with thee (Lady Lauinia) that is to weete: that thy husband
being dead, all go to visit the widow, all comfort the wydow, and all weep
with the wydow: and within a few days after, if the woeful wydow have need of
any small favor with the Senate, they withdraw them selves togeether, as if they
had never known her husband, nor seen her. The renowm of ye Romayn wydows, is
very daynty: for of their honesty, or dishonesty, depends the good renowm of
their person, the honor of their parents, the credit of their children, and the
memory of the dead. For this therefore, it is healthful counsayl, for wise men
to speak few words to wydows, and to do infinite good woorks. What avails
it woeful wydows, to have their coffers filled with letters and promyses, and
their ears stuffed with words, and flatteries? If hitherto thou have taken
me for thy neighbor, and parent of thy husband, I beeseech thee henceforth
that thou take me for a husband in love, for father in counsel, for brother
in service, and for aduocat in the Senate. And all this so truly shall be
accomplished, that I hope thou will say: that which in many I have lost, in
Marcus Aurelius alone I have found. I know well (as thou do in like manner)
that when the hearts with sorows are over whelmed, the spirits are troubled, the
memory is dulled, the flesh does tremble, the spirit does change, and reason
is withdrawn. And since that presently sorrow and care, in thy house do
remayn: let the gods forsake me, if I abandone thee, let them forget me, if I
remember thee not. But as Claudine remained thine, wholly till the hour of
death: so Marcus Aurelius will evermore be thine, during his life.

Since I love thee so intierly, and thou trustest me so faithfully, and that
thou with sorrows art so replenished, and my heart with care so oppressed: let
us admit, that thou Lady Lauinia, have the auctority to command me in thy
affayrs, and I license to counsel and aduertyse thee of things, touching thy
honor, and person. For often times the wydows have more need of a mean remedy,
then of a good counsel: I earnestly desire thee to leave the lamentacion of
the Romayn wydows, that is to weete: to shutt the gates to tear their hears, to
cut their garments, to go bare legged, to paynt the vysage, to eat solitarily,
to weep on the graves, to chyd her Chamberlayns, to pour out water with
tears, to put Acorns on the graves, and to byte their nayls with the teeth: For
these things, and such other semblable lightness, beehoueth not the gravity of
Romayn Matrons, either to see the^ or else to know them. Since there is no
extremity but thereunto vice is annexed: I let thee weete (lady Lauinia) if thou
be ignorant thereof, that the widows which are so extreme, do torment them
selfs, do trouble their friends, do offend the gods, do forsake theirs, and
in the end they profit not the dead: and to the envious people, they geeue
occasion to talk. I woold think and me seems, that the women which are
matrons, and widows, ought to take upon them such garment, and estate, the day
that the gods take life from their husbands: as they entend to wear during
their life. What avails it that a wydow be one month shut up in her house,
and that afterward within a year she is met in every place of Rome? what
avails it, that for few days she hydeth her self from her parents, and
friends: and afterward she is found the first at the theaters? what profits
it, that widows at the first do morn, and go evil attired: and afterward
they dispute, and co^plain of the beauty of the romayn wives? what forces it,
that widows for a certain time do keep their gates shutt: and afterward
their housen are more frequented then others? What skilleth it, that a man see
the widows weep much for their husbands, and afterward they see them laugh
more for their pastymes? Finally I say, that it little avails ye woman, to
seem to suffer much openly for the death of her husband: if secretly she has
an other husband all ready found? For the virtuous, and honest wydow,
immediately as she sees an other man alive: she renueth her sorrow for her
husband that is dead. I will show thee (Lady Lauinia) a thing that beefell in
Rome, to the end thou think not I talk at pleasure. In the old time, in Rome
there was a noble and worthy Romayn Lady, wife of the noble Marcus Marcellus,
whose name was Fuluia. And it happened so, that this woman seeing her husband
buried in the field of Mars, for the great greef she had, she scratched her
face, she ruffled her hear, she tore her gown, and fell down to the earth in
a found, by the reason whereof two Senators kept her in their arms, to thend
she shoold torment her self no more. To whom Gneus Flauius the Censour said.
Let Fuluia go out of your hands, she will this day do all the penance of
wydows. Speaking the truth, I know not, whether this Romain spoke with the
Oracle, or that he were a divine: but I am assured that al he spoke came to
pass. For that this Fuluia was the wife of so excellent a Romayn, as the good
Marcus Marcellus was: I woold that so unlucky a chance had not happened unto
her, which was: that whiles the bones of her husband were a burning, she
agreed to be married to an other: and which was more, to one of the Senators
that lyfted her up by the arms, she gave her hand, as a Romayn to a Romayn,
in token of a faithful marriage. The case was so abominable, that of all men
it was dispraised that were present: and gave occasion that they never credit
wydows afterward. I do not speak it (Lady Lauinia) for that I think thou will
do so. For by the faith of a good man, I swear unto thee, that my heart neither
suspecteth it, nor yet the auctority of so grave a Romayn does demand it: for
to thee only ye fault shoold remain, and to me the wonder. Heartily I commend
unto thee thy honesty, which to thy self thou ought, and the care which
beehoueth so worthy and noble a wydow. For if thou art tormented, with the
absence of the dead: thou oughtst to comfort thee, with the reputacion of the
living. At this present I will say no more to thee, but that thy renowm among
the present be such, and that they speak of thee so in absence: that to the
evil, thou geeue the brydell to be silent, and to the good, spurs to come
and serve thee. For the widow of evil renowm, ought to be buried quick. Other
things to write to thee I have none. Secret matters are dangerous to trust,
considering that thy heart is not presently disposed to here news. It is reason
thou know that I with thy parents and friends have spoken to the Senate, which
have geeuen the office that thy husband had in Constantinople, to thy son.
And truly thou oughtst no less to rejoice of that, which they have said of
thee: then for that they have geeuen him. For they say, though thy husband had
never been citizen of Rome: yet they ought to have geeuen more then this, only
for thy honest beehauiour. My wife Faustine saluteth thee, and I will say I
never saw her weep for any thing in the world so much, as she has wept for
thy mishap. For she felt thy loss, which was very great: and my sorrow, which
was not little. I send thee.iiii. thousand sexterces in money, supposing that
thou have wherewith to occupy them, as well for thy necessaries, as to
discharge thy debts. For the complaints, demands, and processes, which they
minister to the Romayn matrons are greater: then are the goods that their
husbands do leave them. The gods which have geeuen rest to thy husband O
Claudine, geeue also comfort to thee his wife Lauinia, Marcus of mount Celio,
with his own hand.

That Princes and noble men ought to despise the world, for that there is
nothing in the world but plain disceit. Cap. xxxix.
PLato, Aristotle, Pithagoras, Empedocles, Democrites, Selcucus, Epicurus,
Diogenes, Thales, and Methrodorus, had among them so great contention to
describe the world, his beginning, and property: that in maintaining every one
his oppinion, they made greater wars with their pens: then their enemies
have done with their lances. Pithagoras said, that that which we call the
world is one thing, and that which we call the universal is an other. The
philosopher Thales said, that there was no more but one world: and to the
contrary, Methrodorus the astronomer affirmed, there were infinite worlds.
Diogenes said, that the world was everlasting. Seleucus said, that it was not
true: but that it had an end. Aristotle seemed to say that the world was
eternal. But Plato said clearly, that the world has had beginning, and shall
also have endyng. Epicurus said, that it was round as a ball. Empidocles said,
that is was not as a bowl: but as an egg. Chilo the philosopher (in the high
mount Olimpus) disputed, that the world was as me^ are: that is to weete, that
he had an intellectible and sensible soul. Socrates in his school says, and
in his doctrine wrote that after.37. thousand years, all things shoold return
as they had been before. That is to weet, that he him self shoold be born a
new, and shoold be norished, and shoold read in Athens. And Dennis ye tyra^t
shoold return to play ye tyra^t in Siracuse, Julius Caesar to rule Rome,
Hanniball to conquer Italy: and Scipio to make war against Carthage,
Alexander to fight against king Darius, and so forth in all others past. In
such and other vayn questions, and speculations, the ancient philosophers
consumed many years. They in writing many books have troubled their spirits,
consumed long time, trauayled many countries, and suffered innumerable dangers:
and in the end they have set forth few trueths, and many lies. For the least
part of that they knew not, was much greater: then all that which they ever
knew. When I took my pen in my hand to write the vanity of the world: my
entention was not, to reprove this material world, the which of the four
elements is compounded. That is to weete, of the earth that is cold and dry: of
the water that is moist and cold: of the air, that is whot and moist: of fire
that is dry and whot: So that taking the world in this sort, there is no reason
why we shoold complayn and lament of it, since that without him we cannot
live corporally. When the paynter of the world came into the world, it is not
