to be beeleeued that he reproved the water which bare him, when he went
upon it: nor the air that ceased to blow in the sea, nor the earth that
trembled at his death, nor the light which seized to light, nor the stones
which brake in sonder, nor the fish which suffered them selves to be taken, nor
the trees which suffered them selves to be dry, nor the monuments that
suffered them selves to be opened. For the creature knowledged in his creator
omnipotency, and the creator founded in the creature due obedience. Oftentimes
and of many parsons we here say, o woeful world, o miserable world, o subtyl
world, o world unstable and unconstant. And therefore it is reason we know what
the world is, whereof the world is, from whence this world is, whereof this
world is made, and who is lord of this world: since in it all things are
unstable, all things are miserable, all disceitfull, and all things are
malicious which can not be understood of this material world. For in the
fire, in the air, in the earth, and in the water, in the light, in the
planets, in the stones, and in the trees, there are no sorows, there are no
miseries, there are no disceit, nor yet any malice. The world wherein we are
born, where we live, and where we dye, differs much from the world, whereof
we do complayn: for the world against whom we fight, suffers us not to be
in quiet one hour in the day. To declare therefore my entencion, this wicked
world is no other thing, but the evil life of the worldlings, where the earth
is the desire, the fire the couetice, the water the inconstancy, the air the
folly, the stones are the pride, the flowers of the trees the thoughts, the
deep sea the heart. Finally I say, that the son of this world, is the
prosperity: and the moon is the continual change. The prince of this so
evil a world is the devil, of whom Jesus Christ said. The prince of this
world shall now be cast out: and this the redeemer of the world says. For
he called the worldlings and their worldly lives the world. For since they be
servant of sin, of necessity they must be subjects of the devil. The
pride, the auaryce, the envy, the blasphemy, the pleasures, the lechery, the
negligence, the glottony, the ire, the malice, the vanity, and the folly.

This is the world against which we fight al our life, and where the good are
princes of vices, and the vices are lords of the vicious.

Let us compare the travels which we suffer of the elements, with those which
we endure of the vices, and we shall see, that little is the peril we have
on the sea, and the land, in respect of that which increases of our evil
life. Is not he in more danger, that falls through malice into pride: then
he which by chance falls from a high rock? Is not he who with envy is
persecuted, in more danger: than he that with a stone is wounded? Are not
they in more peril, that live among vicious men: than others that live among
bruit and cruel beasts? Do not those which are tormented with the fire of
covetousness suffer greater danger, then those which live under the mount
Ethna? Finally I say, that they be in greater perils, which with high
immaginations are blinded: then the trees which with the importunat wyndes are
shaken. And afterward this world is our cruel enemy, it is a deceitful
friend, it is that which always keeps us in travel, it is that which takes
from us our rest, it is that that robs us of our treasor, it is that which
makes him self to be feared of the good, and that which is greatly beeloued
of the evil. It is that which of the goods of other is prodigal, and of his
own very miserable. He is the inuenter of all vices, and the scourge of all
virtues. It is he which entertaineth al his in flattery and fair speech. This
is he which brings men to dissension, that robs the renowm of those that
be dead, and puts to sack the good name of those that be alive. Finally I
say, that this cursed world is he, which to all ought to render account, and
of whom none dare ask account. O vanity of vanity, where all walk in vanity,
where all think vanity, where all cleue to vanity, where all seems vanity:
and yet this is little to seem vanity, but that in deed it is vanity. For as
false witness shoold he bear, that woold say that in this world there is any
thing assured, healthful, and true: as he that woold say that in heaven there
is any unconstant, variable, or false thing. Let therefore vayn princes see, how
vayn their thoughts be, and let us desire a vayn prince to tell us how he
has governed him with the vanities of the world. For if he beeleeue not that
which my pen writes, let him beeleeue that which his parson proves. The
words written in the book of Ecclesiastes are such.

I David's son that swaies the kingly seat
with hungry thurst, have thrown amid my breast
A vayn desire to prove what pleasures great
In flying life have stable foot to rest.
To taste the sweet that might suffice my will
with rayned course to shun the deeper way
whose streams of his delight, shoold so distill
as might content my restles though to stay
For lo, queen follies imps through vayn beelief
So proudly shape their search of tickle retch
that though desert auailes the wave of grief
to science top their claimming will does stretch
And so to draw some nice delighting end
Of fancies toil that feasted thus my thought
I largely wayed my wasted bounds to bend
to swelling realms as wisedoms dyall wrought.
I ryall courts have reached from the soil
to serve lodge my huge attending trayn
Each pleasant house that might be heapt with toy^
I reared up to weeld my wanton rayn.
I causd to plant the long unused vynes
to smooth my taste with treasure of the grape
I sipped have the sweet in flaming wynes
old rust of care by hidd delight to skape.
Fresh arbors I had closed to the skies
A shrouded space to use my fickle feet
rich gardens I had dasing still mine eyes
A pleasant plot when dainty food was meet.
High shaking trees by art I strove to set
to freight desire with fruit of leeking taste
When broyling flame of summers sun did hett
the blossomd bows his shooting beams did wast.
From rocky hills I forced to be brought
Cold silver springs to bayne my fruitful ground
Large thrown out ponds I labord to be wrought
where numbers huge of swimming fish were found.
Great compast parkes I gloried long to plant
And wild forests where swarmed herds of dear
thousands of sheep no cattal could not want
with new increase to store the wasted year.
Whole rowts I kept of servile wights to sarue
Defauts of princely courts with yrkesom toil
whose skilful hand from conning coold not swerve
their sway was most to deck my daynty soil
The learned wights of musikes curious art
I trained up, to please me with their play
whose sugared tunes so sailed to my heart
As flowing greef, agreed to ebb away.
The tender maids, whose stalk of growing years
yet reached not to age his second rayn
whose royal fames, were swalowed in no cares
But burnt by love as beauties lot does gayn
Lo I enjoyed to feed my dulled spirit
with strayned voice of sweet alluring song
but yet to mount the stage of more delight
I ioyed to see their comely daunces long.
The hills of massy gold that I vpheapt
So hugie were by hoord of long excess,
That clottered clay, with prouder price was kept
In sundry realms, when ruthful need did press.
In some I say, my bodies roling guide
did gase for naught, but subject lay to sight
My judge of sounds, wished nothing to abide
but was instild to kindle more delight.
The clother of my corpse yet never felt
that pleased him ought, but ay it touched again
my sycher of savors, if ought be smelt
that might content, his woold was never vayn.
The greedy sighs of my devoured breast
Travailed in thought to conquer no delight
but yielded straight as wire to the wrest
to office such, as wanton will be hight.
But when the doors of my abused eyes
were hoysed up with looks and looks again
And that my egre hands, did ay enclyne
to touch the sweet, that seasond still their pain,
When wanton taste, was fed with each conceit
That strange devise brought forth from flowing wit
when restless will was ballast with the weight,
of princely reach, that did my compass fit,
I saw by search, the sorry unstable bloome
the blasted fruit, the flitting still delight
The fyckle joy, the often abused doom
the slipper stay, the short contented sight
Of such as set their heaven of lingering life
In pleasures lap, that laughes at their abuse
whose froward wheel, with frowning turn is rise
to drown their bliss, that blyndly slept with use.
For lo, the course of my delighting years
that was embraste in arms of fancies past
when wisdoms son, through follies clouds aperes
does blush to here, the count that pleasure cast.
So now I see the mass of huge delight
with flattering face does promise but decay
whose flitting foot, entysed once to flight
his restles wings, do seek to sore away.
Lo thus he slips, reclaimd with endless pain
Possessed a while, departing soon again.
This says the sage Solomon, talking of the things of the world: the which as
he spoke of the world, so had he proved it in deed in his parson. Crediting,
as it is reason to such high doctrine, I cannot tell what my pen can write more
in this case, since he says, that after he had all proved, experimented,
possessed, and tasted, he found that all that we procure and have in this
world is vanity. O princes, and great lords, I beesech ye, and in the name of
Jesus christ I exhort you, with great discretion to enter into this deep seas:
since this order is so disordered, that it brings all disorders, and evil
customs. For all those which shall trauail by ye way, when they shall think to
go most sure in ye midst of their journey, they shall find them selves to be
lost. None ought to agree with the world, for that he might live sure in his
house: for day and night, to all worldlings he has his gate open, making
their entry large and sure. But let us beeware we enter not, and much more
that we lode not our selves with his vices, and be delighted with his
pleasures. For since we do wax worse, and that we are entered therein,
though we do repent, by no way we find the sure coming out, but ye first
we must well pay for our lodging. I marvel not though the worldlings at every
moment be deceived, sins superfyciously they beehold ye world with their eyes,
and love it profou^dly with their hearts. But if they desired as profoundly to
consider it, as they do vaynly follow it, they shoold see very plain that ye
world did not flatter them with prosperity, but threaten them with adversity. So yt
under the greatest point of the dye, which is the vi. is hyd ye least which is
the ase, I woold counsel princes, and great lords, that they woold not
beeleeue the world nor his flatteries, and much less beeleeue them selves nor
their vayn ymaginacions. The which for the most part do think that after they
have travailed and heaped up great treasure, they shall enjoy but their own
trauail, without the trouble of any man, or that any man do go again them. O
how vayn is such thought, and how often does it change contrary. The world is
of such an evil condition, that if he let us rest our first sleep, as well
us, as that which we have gotten, immediately in the morning, yea oftentimes an
hour from thence, he waketh us with a new care, and now he has prepared for
us some mean, to occupy our selves about some other trouble.

The autour follows his intencion, and speaks vehemently against the
dysceyts of the world. Cap. xl.
THemperor Traian said one day to his master (which was Plutarche the great
philosopher) tell me master, why there are commonly more evil then good? and
why without comparison there are mo which follow vices, than those which
embrace virtue? The great Plutarche answered. As our natural inclinacion is
more geeuen to lasciuiousnes and negligence then to chastity and abstinence: so
the men which do enforce them selves to follow virtue are few, and those which
geeue slack ye reyns to vices are many. And know thou, if thou know it not
(most noble Prince) that all this evil proceeds, that men do follow men,
and that they suffer not reason to follow reason. Feeble, and miserable is our
nature, but in the end we ca^ not den^y, that for all our travails we may
find remedy in it, which seems to be true. For so much as if the sun does
annoy us, we do retire to ye shadow. If we are grieved going on foot, we
do remedy it going on horseback. If the sea be dangerous, we sail with
shyps, If the cold do vex us, we approach near the fire. If thurst does
trouble us, we do quench it with drink, If rayn does wet us, we go into
houses. If the plague be in one place, we fly into another. If we have
enemies, we comfort our selves with our friends. Finally I say, that there is
no sorrow, nor travail, but that a man has found some rest and remedy. This
presupposed to be true (as it is troth in deed) now I ask all the
worldlings, if they have found any remedy against the troubles and disceits of
this world? If I be not deceived, and if I understand any thing of this world,
the remedy which the world geeueth for the troubles, certainly are greater
travails, then the travails them selves: so that they are salues that do not
heal our wounds, but rather burn our flesh. When the diseases are not very old
rooted, nor dangerous, it profits more oftentimes to abide a gentle fever:
then to take a sharp purgacion. I mean, that ye world is such a deceyuer, and
so double, that he does contrary to that he punishes. That is to weete,
that if he do persuade us to revenge an injury: it is to the end that in
revenging that one, we shoold receive a thousand inco^ueniences. And where as
we think it takes from us, it increases infynite. So that this cursed guide,
making us to beeleeue it leads us upon the dry land among our friends: causes
us to fall into the imbushment of our enemies. Princes and great lords, in the
thoughts they have, and in the words that they speak, are greatly esteemed:
and afterward in the woorks which they do, and in the affairs they travail,
are as little regarded. The contrary of all this does the wicked world, who
with all those he companieth, in his promises he is very gentle: and
afterward in his deeds, he is very proud. For speaking the troth, it
costeth us dear: and we others do sell it good chepe. I say much, in saying
that we sell it good chepe: but in manner I shoold say better, that we geeue
it willingly. For few are those in number which carry away wages of the world:
and infinite are those, which do serve it only for a vayn hope. O princes,
and great lords, I counsel and require you, that you do not trust the world,
neither in word, deed, nor promise, though he swear and swear again, that
he will keep all he has promised with you. Suppose that the world does
honor you much, flatter you much, visit you often, offer you great treasures, and
geeue you much: yet it is not because he will geeue it ye by little and little,
but that afterward he might take it all from ye again in one day. For it is
the old custom of the world, that those which above all men he has set
before: now at a turn, they are furdest beehinde. What may we have in the
world and in his flatteries, since we do know, that one day we shall see our
selves depryued thereof? and that which is more, he uses such craft and
subtilty with the one and the other, that in old men whom reason woold shoold
not be vicious, he (the more to torment their parsons) has kyndled a greater
fire in their hearts, so that this malicious world puts into old riches, a
new covetousness: and in the aged, engenders cruel auaryce, and that in that
time, when it is out of time. We ought greatly to consider, how by the world
we are deceived: but much more we ought to heed, that we be not by it
distroyed. For where as we thynk to be in open lyberty: he keeps us secret
in prison. We thynk we are whole, and he geeueth us sickness. We thynk we
have all things: yet we have nothing. We thynk that for many years long
shall be our life, when yt at every corner we are assaulted of death. We think
yt it counts us for me^ yt be wise, when he keeps us bond like unto
fools. We think yt it increases our good, when yt in deed it burdeneth our
co^sciens. Finally I say, that by the way where we thynk to continue our
renown, and life: we lose without recovery, both life and fame. O filthy
world, that when thou do receive us, thou do cast us of: when thou do
assemble us, thou do seperat us: when thou seem to rejoice us, thou
make us sad: when you please us: how thou displeasest us: when thou exaltest
us, how thou hu^blest us: and when thou do chastise us, how thou reioicest.
Finally I say, yt thou have thy drynks so impoysoned, that we are without
thee, with thee, and having the thief within the house, we go out of the
doors to seek him. Though men be diverse in gestures: yet much more are they
variable in their appetites. And since ye world has experience of so many
years, it has appetites prepared for all kind of people. For the presumptuous
he procures honors, to the auaricious he procures riches, and to those
which are gluttons, he presents diverse meats. The fleshly he blinds with
women, and the negligent he lets rest: and the end why he does all these
things, is that after he has fed them as fysh, he casts upon them the
nets of all vices. Note princes, and great lords, note noble men, though a
prince do see him self lord of all the world, he ought to thynk that of no
value is the seignory, onles he him self be virtuous. For little it profits
that he be lord of the vicious: which is him self the servant of all vices.
Many say that the world does beeguile them: and other say that they have no
power against ye world. To who^ we may answer. That if at the first
temptacions we woold have resisted the world: it is impossible yt so
oftentimes it durst assault us. For of our small resistaunce, comes his so
great audacity. I can not tell if I shall dissemble, I shall hold my peace, or
whither I shall say that I woold say, since it greeueth my heart so much, only
to think of it. For I feel my eyes redyer to lament it, then my fingers able
to write it. It is so, that every man suffers himself to be governed so of
the world: as if god were not in heaven, and he had not promised to be a good
christian here in earth. For all that he will, we will, that which he
follows, we follow, and that which he chooses we choose. And that which
is greatest sorrow of all, if we do refrayn our selves from adversity, it is
not for that of our own nature we woold cease from it: but because the world
will not command us to do it. Little is that which I have spoken, in respect
of that I will speak: which is, that the world has made us now so ready to his
law, that from one hour to another, it changes the whole state of this life.
So that to day he makes us hate that, which yesterday we loved, he makes us
complayn of that, which we commended: he makes us to be offended now with
that, which before we did desire: he makes us to have mortal enemies of
those, which before were our special friends. Finally I say, that the world
makes us to love that in our life, which afterward we beewaile at the hour
of death. If the world did geeue unto his minyons, any perfect and accomplished
thing: it were somewhat that for a time a man should remayn in the service of
his house: But since that in the world all things are granted not during life,
but as lendyng, which ought to be rendered the day following: I know not what
man is so very a fool, that in the world does hope for any perpetual thing?
For all that he geeueth, he geeueth with such condition, that they shall
render it unto him when he shall demand it: and not at the dyscrecion of him
that does possess it. Peradventure ye world can geeue us perpetual life? I
say certainly no. For in the sweetest time of all our life, then suddenly we
are assaulted of cruel death. Peradventure the world can geeue us temporal
goods in abundaunce? I say certainly no. For no man at any time had so much
riches: but that which he wanted was more, then that he possessed.

Peradventure the world can geeue us perpetual joy? I say certainly no.

For exemptyng those days which we have to lament, and also the hours which
we have to sygh: there remains not for us one moment to laugh. Peradventure
he can geeue us perpetual health? I say certainly no. For to men of long
life, without comparison the diseases are more which they suffer: then the
years are which they live. Peradventure the world can geeue us perpetual rest?
I say certainly no. For if the days be few, wherein we see the elements
without clouds: fewer are the hours, which we feale our hearts without cares.
Therefore since that in this miserable world there is no health perpetual, nor
life perpetual, nor riches perpetual, nor joy perpetual, I woold know what
it is that the worldlyngs woold of the world, since they know that it has no
good thing to geeue them, but only by lendyng, or by usury? If it be usury,
there is no gayn of money: but rather retourn, with restitucion of vices. O
children of vanyty, O masters of lyghtnes, since it is so, that ye now
determyne to follow and serve the world: look not of the world to have any
thing, but things of the world. In it is nothing but pride, envy, leachery,
hate, ire, blasphemy, auaryce, and folly. And if ye ask if he have in his
governance any virtuous thing, he will answer you that he does never sell
such marchaundyse in his shop. Let no man thynk that the world can geeue us
that, which it has not for it self. And if we will change any thing with it,
and it with us: he is so subtle to sell, and so curious to buy, yt that which
he takes shall be of great measure, and that which he sells us, shall want
much weight.

Of a letter the Emperor Marcus Aurelius wrote to his friend Torquatus to
comfort him in his banishment, which is notable for all men to learn the
vanities of this world. Cap. xli.
MArcus Emperor of Rome companion in the empire, with his brother Annius Verus,
to thee Torquatus of ye city of Gayetta wishes health to thy parson, and
strength against thy evil fortune. I being in the Temple of the vestal virgins,
about three months hence, I received a letter of thine: the which was in such
sort, that neither mine eyes for that time could make an end to read it, nor
since I have had the heart to answer it. For in the inconveniences of our
friends, if we have no faculty nor might for to remedy it, at the least we are
bound to beewaile it. Thy sorrow makes me so heavy, thy pain does trouble me
so much, I am so careful of thy anguish, so tormented with thy grief, that if
the gods had geeuen power to woeful men to depart their sorows, as they have
geeuen to rych men to depart their goods: by the faith I owe to god, I swear,
that as I am the greatest of thy friends, I woold be he which shoold take the
most part of thy griefs. I know right well, and as well as he that has
proved it, that as much difference as there is beetween the bark and the tree,
the mary and the bone, the corn and the straw, the gold and the dross, the
truth and the dreams: so much is there to here the travails of another, and
to taste his own. Notwithstanding comfort thy self my friend Torquatus: for where
the friends be true, the goods and the evils are common beetwyxt them.
Oftentimes with my self I have marueiled, to what end, or intencion, the
immortal Gods have geeuen travail, and torments to men, since it is in their
power to make us to live without them. I see no other thing, why the myshaps
ought pacyently to be suffered: but because in those, we know who are our
faithful friends. In battle the valiant man is known, in tempesteous
weather the Pilot is known, by the touch stone gold is tried, and in aduersyty
the friend is known.

For my friend does not enough to make me merry, unless also he does take
part of my sorrow. I have heard say here, and now by thy letter I have seen,
how they have banished thee from Rome, and confyscated thy goods, and that for
pure sorrow thou art sick in thy bed: whereof I marvel not that thou art sick,
but to be as thou art alive. For saying to thee the truth, where the heart is
sore wounded, in short space it has accustomed to yield up unto the body. I
see well that thou complaynest, and thou have reason to complayn, to see thy
self banyshed from Rome, and thy goods confiscate, to see thy self out of thy
country, without any parentage: yet therefore thy sorrow ought not to be so
extreme, that thou shooldst put thy life in hazard. For he alone ought to
have license, and also is bound to hate life, which does not remember that
he has served the Gods, nor has done any profyt to men. If the affairs of
the Empire did not occupy me, and the emperyall majesty did not wythdraw me:
I woold immedyatly have to come to comfort thy person, where thou shooldst have
seen by experience, with what grief I feel thy trouble. And therefore if thou
take me for thy friend, thou oughtst to beeleeue of me that, which in this
case I woold of thee: which is, that as thou have been the most entyer friend
which I had in Rome: so is this the thing that most I have felt in this life.
Tell me my friend Torquatus, what is it thou suffrest there, that I do not
lament here? It may be that sometime thou laughest, but I allways weep:
sometimes thou comfortest thy self, but I am allways sad. It may be that thou
lightnest thy pain: but I am in sighyng. It may be that sometimes thou castest
from thee sorrow: but for me I cannot receive consolation. It may be that thou
hopest remedy of longlyfe: but for me I find no remedy more healthful, then
present death. Finally I say, that here I feel all that thou feel there,
and furthermore I suffer all that, which as a friend I ought to suffer here: so
that both our pains are made one most cruel sorrow, wherewyth my woeful life
is tormented. I woold greatly desire to come and see thee, and to help to
dysburthen thee of this charge. And since it is impossible for me, I send thee
this letter, wherein perchance thou shall find some comfortable words. For
thou know, that if the true friends cannot do that which they ought: yet they
do accomplish it, in dooyng that they can. If my memory deceive me not, it is
well two and thirty years since we two have known togethers in Rome, during
the which, fortune has made here beetween us diverse alteracions, in the which
time I never saw thee one day contented. For if thou were sad, nothing did make
thee merry, but were as a man without taste: and if thou were joyful, thou
esteemedst it little, as a man being troubled. Therefore if the truth be so
(as in deed it is) that in trauayles thou were laden with sorows, and in
prosperities thou were evil content, so that of nothing in the world thou
take any taste: why is it (my friend Torquatus) that now again thou art in
dyspaire, as if thou cammest new into this world? Thou dydst rejoice thy
self.xxxii. years, with the tryumphs and prosperyty of Rome: and thou
complainest only of three months, that fortune has been contrary unto thee.
O Torquatus, Torquatus, do thou know that the wise men (in whom wisdom
reigns) have more fear of two unhappy days in this life: then of two
hundredth of prosperous fortune? O how many have I seen go out of their
prosperyties, with the charges of another man, and their own proper vices? so
that the vayn glory and the failing prosperity endured few days: but the grief
of that they have lost, and the enmyties which they have recovered, endure many
years. The contrary of all this comes to infortunat men, which escape out of
their tribulacions spoiled of vices, enuyronned with virtues: persecutours of
evil, zelers of good: friends of all, and enemies of none: contented with
theirs, and not desyryng others: finally they are escaped wisely from the snare,
and have gathered the rose, not hurting them selves with the pricks. What wylt
thou that I say more unto thee, but that the most fortunat are vanquyshed in
peace: and the unfortunate are conquerers in war? One of the sentences which
most have contented me, of those which the auncyents have spoken, is this, of
the divine Plato. That those wc are in prosperyty, have no less need of good
counsel: then the unhappy have of remedy. For no less do they travail,
which go always in the plain way: then those which mount on the sharp craggy
mountayn. According to that I have gathered of thy letter, me seems that
when we hope most rest, greatest travail has succeeded to thee. And hereof I
do not marvel, nor thou oughtst not to be offended. For as experience
teaches us, when the trees have the blossoms, then they are most subject to
the frost. And when glasses are drawn out of the furnace, they break. The
captayns having won the victory, do dye. When they will put the key in the
door, the house does fall. The pirates perish, withyn the kenning of land. By
that I have spoken I mean, that when we thynk to have made peace with fortune,
then she has a new demand ready forged. All new chaunges of fortune, causes
allway new pain to the parson: but oftentimes it is cause of more great
fortress. For the tree bears not so much fruit, where it first grew, as
there where it is again planted: and the sauors are more odiferous, when they
are most chafed. I mean, that men of hye thoughts, the more they are wrapped in
ye frownings of fortune, the more valiant and stout they show them selves. The
man utterly is foolysh, or has great want of understanding, who hops at any
time to have perfect rest, immaginyng that the world will geeue no assault
upon him: but that the time shall come, wherein he shallbee without care and
fear. This miserable life is of such condition, that daily our years do
diminish, and our troubles increase. O Torquatus, by the immortal gods I do
desire thee, and in the faith of a friend I do require thee, thou being born
in the world, nouryshyng thy self in the world, living in the world, being
conuersaunt in the world, being a child of the world, and following the world,
what dydst thou hope of the world, but things of the world? Peradventure thou
alone wilt eat the fleash without bones, geeue battle without peril,
travail without pain, and sail by the sea without danger. I mean, that it is
impossible for mortal men to live in the world, unless they will beecome
subject to the sorows of the world. The world has allways been the world, and
now the world shallbee after us, and as a world shall handell the worldlyngs,

The wise men, and those which of their estates are careful, are not contented
to see, nor superfycially to know the things: but rather way them profoundly. I
say this, because if thou knewst thy debylyty, and knewst fortune, and her
change, if thou knewst the men, and their malyces, if thou knewst the world,
and his flatteryes: thou shooldst win no little honor, where as otherwise thou
may chance to get infamy. We are now come to so great folly, yt we will not
serve the Gods, wc have created us: nor abstain from the world, wc persecuteth
us. And the best is, yt he not wyllyng us (but rather reiectyng us) we say yt
of our own wills we will love and serve him: and yet knowing that those which
longest have served the world, do go out of his house most bytterly
lamentyng. Oftentimes I stay to thynk, that according to the multitude of men
which follow the world, being allways evil handled of the world) if the world
did pray them, as he does annoy them, if he did comfort them, as he does
torment them, if he kept them, as he banysheth them, if he exalted them, as
he abuses them, if he received them, as he expels them, if he did
contynew them, as he consumes them: I thynk that the Gods should not be
honored in heaven, nor the Temples woorshypped in the earth. O Torquatus my
friend that which now I will say of thee, thou may say of me. That is to
weete, how much we put our confydence in fortune, how lewdly we pass our
days, and how much we are blinded in the world: yet for all that we credyt
his word as much, as though he had never mocked any.

Marcus Aurelius goes on with his letter and by strong and high reasons
persuades all that live in the world, not to trust the world, nor any thing
therein. Cap. xlij.
TEll me I pray thee Torquatus, what wylt thou hear more? What will thou see
more? and what wylt thou know more, to know the world? seeing how until this
present thou have been handled of the world? thou demaundest rest, and he
has geeuen thee trouble. Thou demaundest honor, and he has geeuen thee
infamy. Thou demaundest riches, and he has geeuen thee poverty. Thou
demaundest joy, and he has geeuen thee sorrow. Thou demaundest to be his,
and he has geeuen thee his hand. Thou demau^dest life, and he has geeuen
thee death. Therefore if it be true, that ye world has handled thee in this
wise, why do thou weep to return again to his wicked house? O fylthy world,
how far art thou from just: and how far ought they to be from thee, which
desire to be just. For naturally thou art a friend of novelties, and enemy of
virtues. One of ye lessons which the world reads to his children is this: yt
to be true worldlings, they shoold not be very true. The which experience
plainly shows us, for the man which medleth much with the world, leaves
always suspicion of him that he is not true. The world is an imbassadour of
the evil, a scourge of the good, cheifest of vices, a tyrant of the verteous,
a breaker of peace, a friend of war, a sweet water of vices, the gawle of the
virtuous, a defender of lies, an inuenter of novelties, a trauailer of the
ignorant, a hammer for the malicious, a table of gluttons, and a furnace of
concupyscence: finally, it is the peril of Charibde, where the hearts do
perish: and the danger of Scilla, where the thoughts do wast. Presuppose that
these be the conditions of the world. The troth is, yt if there be any
worldlyng who complains to be evil content with the world shall he therefore
change his style? Truly no, and the reason is, that if perchance one
worldling shoold go out of the house of the world, there are ten thousand
vanities at his gate. I know not what wise man will live in the world with such
conditions, since the vices wherewith we do rejoice our selves are very few,
in respect of the torments which we suffer. I say not that we do hear it by
hear say, and read them in books: but we see with our own eyes, the one to
consume and wast the goods, others by mysfortune to fall, and lose their
credyt, others to fall and lose their honor, and others to lose their life, and
all these myseries seen, yet nevertheless every man thinks to be free by
privilege, where there is none priuileged: O my friend Torquatus, of one thing
I assure thee, which is, that the men which are borne of women are so evil a
generation, and so cruel is the world where in we live, and fortune so
empoysoned with whom we frequent: that we cannot escape without being
spurned with his feet, bytten with his teeth, torn with his nails, or
impoysoned with his venym. Peradventure thou may say unto me that thou have
seen some in Rome, which have lived long time, fortune never being against
him? To this I answer thee, that thou oughtst rather to have pyty upon him,
then envy: for it is not for his profyt, but for his great hynderaunce. For the
world is so malycious, that when it seems to be most our friend, then it
woorketh us most dyspleasure. The healthful men dye rather of a short disease
in few days: then the dry and feeble men do, with a disease of many years.
By this comparison I mean, that since man cannot escape, nor live without
travail: it is much better, that by little and little he tastes them, then
they enter all at one time into his house. O how much ought the man to be
hated of the immortal gods, who knows not what travail means in this
world? For he only ought to fear fortune, who knows not fortunes force.
Since the gods woold permyt, and thy myshap has been such, that thou have
found more danger, where thou thoughtst most surety as a man evil fortuned:
it is reason that we apply unto thee some new ware, to the end thou lose not
thy good renown, since thou have lost thy evil goods,

Tell me I pray thee (Torquatus) why do thou complayn as a man sick? why
cryest thou as a fool? why syghest thou as a man in dyspayre? and why do
thou weep as a child? Thou art come out of the way.

And thou complainest to have lost thy way. Thou sailest by the broiling seas:
and thou wonderest that ye waves do assault thee. Thou have ascended ye
steep, and craggy mountayns: and thou complaynest that thou art weary. Thou
walk by the thorns: and wylt not that thy gown be torn.

Dydst thou thynk in the top of the high mountayn to live most sure? By that I
have spoken, I will ask what dyligent service thou have done to the world,
that thou wooldst the gods of heaven shoold recompense thee? Wooldest thou of
fortune a safe conduct, she being (as she is) enemy of many, nature being
not able to geeue it, the which is mother of all? O my friend Torquatus, that
which the pytyfull nature cannot promise thee, dydst thou thynk that fortune
(which is the just stepmother) should geeue? It is impossible that the Sea
should always promise us suerty, and the heaven clerenesse, the summer dews,
and the winter frosts. Mark well, mark my friend Torquatus, that all natural
things are subject to change every year: but all the worldlyngs ought to
endure to eclypse every moment.

Since the natural goods cannot always be in one man's custody, being
necessary, it is just that the goods of fortune perysh, since they are
superfluous. Unjust shoold the Gods be, if that which is to the damage of so
many, they had made perpetual: and that which is to the profyt of all, they
had made mortal. I will no more reduce to thy memory, the prosperyty wc thou
have had in times past: before yt we treat how fortune handles thee at this
present. The deceytfull fortune, when at thy gate she sold her marchaundyse,
knowing that she sold unto thee, and thou being ignorant of that thou
boughtst: she gave thee fruitful ground, and afterward made it unto thee
paynfull. She has geeuen thee sower for sweet: and the sweet she has
returned to the sower. She has geeuen thee the evil for the good: and where
that thou have sold her good: she returned unto thee evil. Finally she has
beeguyled thee in the just pryse: thou not supposyng that thou had received
any damage. We can do no less in this case but to have compassyon upon
thee: yet though they condemn malicyous fortune for sellyng, they will note
thee simple in buying. For in the shop of fortune, all marchaundyse are
suspycious. O unhappy that we are, I say those which meddle with the world:
for in his market they see naught but lies, and we do not trust but in the
ouerthrows of our renown: which are not paid, but with the cost of our life.
And the factours of that fair, geeue us nothing by weight, or measure: for
they are a sort of vacabounds, and the woorst of all is, knowing that they
ought to lose with fortune, all seek to buy at her shop. Geeue thy self to the
world, love the world much, serve the world well, follow the world well, and
feel the world well: for in the end of the journey, the world requires thee
to be like unto his inconstancy. I woold enter into count, not with the world,
which in the end is the world: but with the worldlyngs, which are in love with
the world. For in the end, either it is good or evil. If the world be good
for them, whereof do they complain? If he be evil, why do they follow
him? They can not (though they woold) deny one of the two errors wherein the
worldlyngs fall: that is to weete, that they serve an evil master, or that
they murmour of a good lord. Tell me my friend Torquatus what dydst thou hope,
since thou made so long time a countenance to the world? two and thyrty
years thou have served the world, and have been in his favor: wherefore it
were now hye time that between thee and him were some dyscord. For beetweene
the graundfathers and the nephews, beetween the father and the children,
beetween the uncles and the nephews, daily we see great strifes: and did
thou think, that beetween thee and fortune, perpetual peace shoold be? She
gave not to Belus king of the Assirians but.ix years of prosperity. To the
Queen Semiramis six only. To Label king of the Lacedaemonians. five. To the
king of Chaldeans. four. To the great Alexander. four. To the great Amilcar
king of Carthage two. To our Julius Caesar one, and to infinite others she gave
not one. If the world were pacyent he shoold be no world, if the world were
constant, he shoold be no world, if the world were sober, he shoold be no
world, if the world were true, he shoold be no world, if the world were
corrigible, he shoold be no world: finally I say, that for naught else the
world is world, but because there is nothing in him worthy to be beeloued:
and many things in it that deserves to be reproved. If thou were wise, and
knewst any thing of the world, in all the discourse of those.xxxii. years, thou
had not eaten without care, nor had gone without guyles, and had not
spoken without suspicion, nor slept without assault, nor trusted any friend. For
the war men do thynk always, wherein their enemies may beeguile them,
wherein they them selves may fail, and wherein fortune may let them. I know
not if it be that the world of him self be happy, or that the worldlings are
fools. For if one stranger, one neighbor, or our proper brother does envy
us, we will never (though he do require us) pardon him, and we cease not to
follow the world, though we know he presecuteth us. So that we draw our
sweords against flies: and will kill the elephants with needles. There is no
greater ill in the world, then to thynk all things in the world are in
extremyty. For if we be abased, we sigh always to mount: and if we be
high, we weep allways for fear of falling. Such ouerthrows has the world,
and his snares are so secret: that we are no sooner shipped, but we see both
our hands and feet entangled in vices: by the which our lyberty is brought
into such extreme and cruel captivity, that we beewayle our mishaps with
roaryng voice as brute beasts: but as men we dare not once utter them. I know
not whereof this comes, for some I see which willingly fall, and other I see
which woold recover them selves. I see diverse that woold be remedyed, and I
see all do complain: but in the end I see no man that does amend. These
things I have written unto thee, for no other thing, but because from hence
forth thou shooldst live more circumspectly: for as thou know, I say
nothing, whereof I have not had long experyence. The colt which thou have sent
me is proved very good, especyally for that he leapeth very well, and for
the caryer he is exceedyng ready, and has a comely grace. I send thee two
thowsa^d sexterces, wherewt thou may relieve thy necessityes. Fyndyng
opportunity, as touching thy banishment, I will speak to the senate in thy
beehalf. I say no more to thee, but that the consolacion of the gods, and the
love of the gods be with thee Torquatus. The malice of the evil, and the ire
of ye furies, be absent from me Marcus, My wife Faustine saluteth thee. And
in her beehalf, and mine, recommend us to thy fair daughter in law Solophonia,
and thy daughter Amilda. Mark of mount Celio, writes to thee Torquate, with
his own hand.

Princes and noble men ought not to bear with iugglers, iesters, parasytes,
and common players, nor with any such kind of raskals, and loyterers. And of
the laws which the Romans made in this beehalf. Cap. xliij.
LIcurgus, Promotheus, Solon, and Numa Pompilius, famous inuenters, and
ordeyners of laws, showed the subtilty of their wits, and the zeal which
they had to their people, in ordeining many laws which they taught: not only
what they ought to do: but that which they ought to fly. For the good and
expert phisicions do deserve more praise to preserve us before we are sick:
then to heal us after we are diseased Plutarche in his apothegmes never
cease to exalt the Lacedaemonians, saying: that when they did observe their
laws, they were the most esteemed of all the greeks: and after that they brake
them, they were the most vylest subjects, which ever the Romans had. The
felicity or infelicity of realms, does not consist to have good or evil laws:
but to have good or evil princes. For little profyteth us the law to be just,
if ye king be wicked., Sextus Cheronensis in the life of Nerua says, when the
romans and the Greeks had wars togethers, and that the imbassadours of
these two nations were at controversy, which of them shoold have the Rhodiens
to be their friends: the Greek ambassador said to the Romayn. Ye ought not
to make your selves egall, O Romans, with the Greeks, sins the troth is, that
ye came from Rome to Greece to seek laws. The romain ambassador answered
him, I grant thee, that from Rome we sent to seek laws in Greece: but thou will not denay, that from Greece you have brought the vices to Rome. I say unto
thee the troth, that without comparison, greater damage have the vices done
unto us: then your laws has profyted us. Plutarche in an epistle he wrate to
Traiane, said these words. Thou writest unto me, most noble prince, that thou
art occupied in ordeyning new laws: but in my oppinion it had been much better,
that thou had kept, and caused to be kept the old. For little profyteth it to
have the books full of good laws, and that the common wealth be full of evil
customs. I have seen very few Princes, but to make laws they had hability
sufficient and to keep them, they have felt in them selves great debylity and
weakness. Hereof we have example. For Nero was he which made the best laws
in Rome: and that afterward of life was most corrupt. For the gods oftentimes
permit, that by the hands of some evil men, the others shoold be constrained
to be good. Plutarche says further. If thou wilt (noble Prince) trust thine
own understanding, in my poor counsayl, in few words I woold recite unto thee
al ye ancient laws. I will send thee very brief and sweet laws, not to thend
thou shooldst publysh them in Rome: but to the end thou keep them in thy
house. For since thou have made laws for all. I will make laws for thee. The
first law is, that thou beehaue thy self in such sort, that thou be not noted
of any notable vice: For if the prince be virtuous in his palace, none dare
be dyssolute in his house.

The second law is, that equally thou keep justice, as well to him which
lives far of, as to him which is near about thee: for it is much better yt
thou depart of thy goods to thy servants, then that thou shooldst geeue that
justice, which apperteineth to others. The third law is, that thou delyght in
word and deed to be true, and that they take thee not in this default to
speak too much. For princes which in their words are uncertain, and in their
promyses doubtful, shall be hated of their friends, and mocked of their enemies.

The fourth law is, that thou be very gentle of condition, and not forgetful
of services done. For unthankful princes are hated of god, and despised of me^.

The fifth law is, that as a pestilence thou chase from thee flatterers. For
such with their evil life, do disturb a whole common wealth: and with their
flatteries, do darken thy renown. If thou (most noble prince) wilt observe
these.v. laws, thou shall need to make no more laws: For there is no need of
other law in the common wealth, but to see that the prince be of good life.
This wrote Plutarche to Traian, and every virtuous man ought to have them
written in his heart. I was willing to touch this history only to show the
profyt of this last law, where it says, that princes admit into their
conversation no flatterers, of whom it is reason we talk of now: For so much
as there are diverse men, with whom they lose their time, and spend their goods.
When Rome was well ordered, two officers were greatly esteemed to the Romans.
The one was the masters of fence, which were as men that fought and turned,
and many times in that fight they were slain. And the cause to invent this
play, was to ye end young men (not expert in war) shoold see the swords
drawn, sharp speres, shootyng of crossebows, to geeue blows with their sword,
to shed blood, to geeue cruel wounds, and to sley men: For in this sort they
lost fear, and in going to the war they recovered courage. The man which
has once past a fourd in the water though it be in the night, dare pas it
again. But he which has never passed it over though it be in the day, dare
not adventure it. I mean, that the Romans were very sage, to show unto their
children the dangers, before they did put them therein. For this is the
difference beetwene the fearful heart, and the courageous stomach, in that the
one flies from a distaffe, and the other is not afraid of a sweord.

The second office which was esteemed in Rome was, that of the iugglers,
iesters, comediants, and of such others, which invented plays, and pastimes:
and the romans devised these sports, to rejoice the people: and in especially
men of war, whom they feasted at their going forth, and much more at their
coming home. For the Romans thinking that they shoold be with such glory
received, went with determinacion either to win the victory, or to dye in
battle. The ancient and true Romans had such care for the common wealth of
their people, that they consented that iesters shoold jest, iugglers shoold
iuggle, and the players of enterludes shoold play: But this was not through
abundaunce of vanyty, nor for want of gravity, but to take from the Plebeians
occasion of idleness, and to keep them occupied in other particular plays:
they woold that all the pleasures shoold be taken togethers. Not without cause
I say, that the pleasures were taken in commen, that is to weete, that no
romayn could play any plays particularly, make any bankets, represent
comedies, nor make any feasts beeside those, which they made to rejoice the
whole people, so that in Rome they trauayled severally, and rejoiced togethers.
I would to god that such and so excellent a romain custom were observed in our
christian common wealth.

But I am very sorry that indifferently rich, and poor, great and small, do
play comedyes, roune the bulls, make just ordein bankets, wear devises, feast
the ladies spend in bankets and invent feasts. The which things altogether do
redound to the damage of the common wealth, to the wast of the goods, and to
the corrupcion of the manners: for the particular pastimes do increase new
vices to breed in me. These players did serve in rome to make pastime at the
great feasts of their Gods: For since Romans were great worshippers of their
gods, and so careful of their temples, they sought to feast them all the ways
they could invent. Truly this was done by the divine sufferance, for their gods
being laughing stocks (as in deed they were) the living god would they should
be served, honored, and feasted by iestures, and mocks. Blondus in the third
book de Roma triumphante mencioneth the which I have have spoken, and says.
That the Romans were no less curious to give laws to the iudglers, and
iesters, which went mocking up and down Rome: then to the captayns which were
fighting in the war. For though they did permit iesters, players and iuglers,
to exercise their offices: yet they did command them that their lives might
be upright and just. Amongst others, such were the laws, which the romans
ordained for these iesters, iuglers, players, and tomblers.

The first law was, they commanded that they should all be known, and
examined, to see if they were honest men, wise, and sage. For the more their
offices were vain, so much the more they provided, that they were geeuen to
wise men. The second law commanded to examine them, to see if they were able,
and comely to exercise their offices: and in deed in this case, as well as in
the other, they had reason, as very a fool is he wc for harkneth to a fool
not pleasant, as the fool him self.

The third law was that they did not permit any Roman iugler to exercise such
feats, oneles he had some other craft. So that if they occupied the holy days
to play and show pastyme in the streats, the other days they should woork at
home at their houses. The fourth law was, that no iugler nor vice should be so
hardy in his ostentacions to speak any malices: and in deed it was a law very
necessary. For often times they are few which do rejoice at their mockryes:
and many which complain of their malices.

The fifth law was that no iugler or iester, should be so bold to make any
pastimes in any particular houses, but in open places. For otherwise, those
which spoke them beecame hardy, and those which heard them were vicious.

The Romans not contented to have made these laws, ordained that the iuglers
for no pastimes showed, or any other thing spoken should be so bold as to
receive any money. And to avoid their complaynts, and to satisfy their pains,
they allowed every one of them a thousand sexterces yearly out of the common
treasure. We ought greatly to praise the providence of ye Romans, which have
prescribed a kind of life for the iesters to live: eue^ as they did to other
men of rome, and to the captains of war. And in this place no less tha^ in an
other grave thing, they showed their wisdom. For a governor of a common
wealth trauaileth more to correct fools, the^ to govern ye sage.

How some iesters were punished by the ancients, and of the iesters and
loyterers of our time. Cap. xliiii.
IVlius Capitolinus in the book of the manners of the ancients says, that in
times past, the iesters, and iugglers were greatly esteemed. And we will not
deny but that they had reason, sins with them they honored the gods they
took their pleasures, the rejoiced their feasts, they were very quick men,
nor importunate, nor covetous. The iester has no grace, unless immediately a
man puts his hand to the purse. We find so^e fragments of an oration which
Cicero made in the senate, greatly reproving the Senators, and all the people,
because they so willingly gave ear to this iester, who stirred up sedition
among the commons, his name was Roscio, who was so greatly esteemed in rome
that the Romans did more willingly hear that which he said in his jests,
than that which Cicero spoke in good earnest: This iester Roscio and Cicero
stryued which of them both were of greater wit, Roscio for prese^ting a thing
with diverse jests, or Cicero pronouncing waity matters in earnest. When I read
in Julius Capitolinus that which I have spoken, I will not cease to confess
mine innocence, for that I could not then keep my self from laughing to see
that Roscio, being Prince of folly: did presume to dispute with Cicero, which
was father of eloquence. Since all these things are unstable in one, so from one
day to another we see them change. The romans did greatly esteem the
policy of the common wealth, the discipline of war, the nurture of children,
the exercise of the young, and the honesty of the players, and iuglers: the
which in time came to be dissolute, that very often they were occasion of great
slander among ye people. The which by the Romans seen, and considered, and
that the iesters which were wont to show them pleasures, were cause of
discension (and where all they commanded them to be resydente in their
offices, they were vacabonds, and that using them as sages, they lived as
loyterers and fools, not contented with that yt they gave them of the common
treasure, but they went begging of every man) the Senate of rome determined
among them selves to banish all the iuglers, and iesters, out of the common
wealth. On this execution of these loyterers, sprang dyues dyssentions among
the people. For the Princes which were good, cast them out: and those which
were evil, called them in. So that one of the tokens which were in Rome to
know a virtuous, or vicious prince was to see if he maintained iesters,
iuglers, or vacabonds, among the people. Plutarch in his Apothegmes says,
that the Lacedaemonians did never permit any iugler or iester to be in the
common wealth. And when one did demand a Lacedemonian, by an imbassador of
Rhodes, what was the occasion to make such a law, since the the iesters, and
players, showed pleasure to the people, and the people lost naught but laughed
at their folly: the Lacedemonian answered. Lycurgus saw, hard, felt, or red
some great damage the iesters, iuglers or players, might do in the commonwealth, since against them he made this so straight a law. But that which I
know is yt we Greeks are better, weeping with our sages: then are the Romans
laughing at their fools. Dio in the life of Traian declares, that there came
a iugler to Rome from Affricke, whose conueyance was so clean, that it was a
wonderful thing to see what seats he did, and to hear what words he spoke.
And when they prayed the good Emperor Traian, that it would please him to hear
him, he answered. It is not for the authority of a grave and virtuous prince,
that in his presence any such vain thing should be showed. For in such a
case, he shoold be no les noted of lightness, then the other accused of folly.
And further he said. Before princes a man should not be so hardy to speak
dishonest words, nor show light representacions. And in such case as much
pain deserve they which move him thereto: as those which do represent them.
For a man ought not to put before princes things which should allure them to
vices: but things wc shoold move them to virtues. Certainly these words were
worthy of such a personage. Suetonius Tranquillus in the life of Augustus
declares, yt in Rome there was a iester very pleasant and of an excellent wit
caled Epifanius who one day upon a holyday to show the Emperor so^e pleasure
and hoping to have a good reward, went to ye palace at one time in ye attire
of a page, and another time i^ ye habit of a Romayn matron: and so truly
counterfeted every thing that it seemed not to be him, but the self same
parson he represented. The Emperor Augustus was greatly displesed with that
the iester had done, and commanded forth with that he shoold be whipped iii.
tyms about the theater. And when he complained, that the Emperor commanded
vacabonds to be whipped once, and he thrice, the Emperor Augustus answered.
Once they shall whip thee, for the injury thou did to the Romayn matron, whom
thou did represent. The second time they shall whip thee, for the presumption
that thou have to represe^t it before my parso^. The third for ye time thou
have made diverse lose, for beeholding and hearing thee. For iesters do not
deserve so much punishment, in the iestes and mockries they do say: as for the
time which they lose, and cause others to lose. Certainly the punishment which
was geeuen to the iester, was very just: and exceading good were the words,
which Augustus said. There was an other in the time of Augustus whose name was
Pilas. And when the Emperor had banyshed all the iesters, and iuglers from
Rome, this Pilas was so pleasant, and merry with all persons, that with great
instau^ce they be sought ye Emperor to revoke yt sentence. And ye request in
deed was so great as if it had been for a Philosopher, they could have done no
more. For dayn, and light me^, employ rather yt they have, on him who brings
unto them some folly: then on one, which teaches and corrects their life.
The Emperor condescended to the request of the people, on such condition, that
they should geeue a master and tutor to Pilas, that shoold chastise and
correct him as a fool. Saying, yt since sages took fools to be their
masters, that ye fools also shoold have sages for masters. The case was that
one day he that had the charge of Pilas, did rebuke him for certain lightness
that he had done, or for some dishonesty that he had said: whereat Pilas was
exceading wrath with him. The which the emperor vndesta^ding, commanded he
should be whipped and banished for ever. When Augustus gave this sentence they
say he said these words. Rome has been mighty, and puisaunt enough, to make
her enemies stoop: and now she is not able to banish iesters, and fools. And
that that is worse of al, they have presumption to vex us, and we have not
courage to reprove them. The Lacedaemonians had great reason and also the
Romans, to ryd their common wealth of iesters. For they are idel, vicious,
dishonest, malycious, and preiudyciall to the common wealth. These iesters and
iuglers are idell, seeing that more then others, they eat the swette of others.
They are vicious, for they can not exercise their offices but in vices, and in
treatyng with vicious men. They are dishonest, for they get not to eat by
doing good woorks: but by speaking dyshonest words. They are malicious, for
they have accustomed when they love not a man, immediately to speak evil of
him. They are unprofitable for the common wealth, for they mock us and sell us
vain words: and we pay them good money. The world is come to so great folly,
and corruption, that eue^ as grave and wise men think it great inconvenience,
to be conuersaunt with vain, and fond men: so the Lords of estate think it an
honor, to have in their house, some foolysh iesters, yea better to say (with
reverence of speech) raylyng knaves, which speak not to please and show
pastyme, but to offend the present, and rayl at the absent, as well of the high,
as ye low, and that that is more yet then this, is that they are not contentyd
to have given this enterteinment and welcome to the noble men and Ientlemen
that are at their lords board: but they must needs have a cast at my lord him
self to chere him with all: which intolerable abuse ought not only not to
be suffered, but with most sharp correction punished. But what shall we say,
that for the most part the lords are so vain and the iesters so presumptuous
and arrogant: that the Lords have more care to content them, then they have to
please the lords. In the house of a lord, a fool at the end of the year will
ask more, then any other of those which are most ancient, so that the follyes
of one are more acceptable, then the seruyces of all. It is shame to speak it,
and no less to write it, that the Children of vanity are so vain, that they
brybe a fool or a iester no less in these days, to the intent he may be a
mean for them unto the Prince: then they did in times past desire Cicero, to
make an oration for them before the Senate. It is for want of understanding,
and through the vilety of person oppression of the heart, and disprayse of
renown, to be desirous by the mean of fools, too attain to any thing. For
he can have no great wysedo^e, which puts his hope in the favor of a fool.
What remains for me to say, when I have said that which I will say? And it
is, that if a iester or fool say openly to some lord, God save your life my
good lord. Oh he is a noble man in deed he will not stick to geeue him a
gown of silk: and entering into a church, he would not geeue a poor man a
halpeny.

O what negligence is there of princes? O what vanity of Lords? since they
forsake the poor and wise, to enrych the iesters and fools. They have enough
for the world, and not for Ihesus Christ: they geeue to those that ask for his
lovers sake, and not to those which ask for the health of the soul. He ought
not to do so: for the knight which is a Christian, and not a worldlyng, ought
rather to will that the poor do pray for him at the hour of death: then that
the fools, and iesters should praise him in his life.

What does it profit the soul, or the body, that the iesters do praise thee
for a cote thou have geeuen them: and that the poor accuse thee, for the bread
thou have denayed them? Peradventure it will profyt thee as much, that a fool or
a flaterer, go before a Prince apparayled with a new lyuery of thine: as the
poor men shall do thee damage before God, to whom thou have denied a poor
ragged shirt? All gentlemen, and noble parsonages, in the name of our savior
Jesus Christ I admonysh, exhort, and humbly require, that they consider well
what they spend, and to whom they geeue, for the good Princes, ought to have
more respect of the necessityes of the poor: then of the follyes of
counterfayts. Geeue as ye will, divide as ye list, for at the hour of death,
as much as ye have laughed with the fools, for that ye have geeuen them, so
much shall ye weep with the poor, for that ye have denayed them. At the hour
of death it shall be grievous pains to him that dies, to see the flesh of the
orphans all naked, and to beehold counterfaite fools laden with their
garments. Of one thing I am amassed, that indifferently every man may beecome a
fool, and no man let him: and the woorst of al is, if once a fool beecome
covetous, all the world afterward cannot make him to to be in his right
senses. Truly such one which has no reason to be a fool, at the least he
has good occasion: since he gets more to eat playeng, the^ the others do
woorking. O what negligence of the princes, and what small respect of the
governors of the common wealth is this? that a young man, whole, stout, strong,
and valiant, should be suffered to go from house to house from table to
table, and only for babbling vain words, and telling shameful lies, he
should be counted a man of an excellent tongue? Another folly there is in this
case, that their words are not so foolish, as their deeds are wicked. And
though they have a good, or euel grace: yet in the end, they be counted in the
common wealth, as loyterers and fools. I know not whether in this case is
greater, either their folly, or our lyghtnes: for they use as fools, in
telling us lies, and we pay them good money. The Romans did not permit in
their common wealths, old stale iesters: nor we Christyans ought to retain
into our houses, idel loyterers. Ye ought to know that more offends he which
sins with a defourme woman: then he which sins with a beautiful lady.
And he which is drunk with sower ale offends more then he which is drunk
with sweet wine. And so in like manner greater offense commit they which lose
their times with fools that have no grace: then with iesters, which have good
wits. For it may be permitted sometime, that the sage man for the recreation
of his spyrits, do frequent the company of some pleasant man.

Of a letter which ye Emperor wrote to Lambertus his friend, governor of
Helespont certifying him that he had banished from Rome all fools and
loytering plaiers and is divided into.3. chapters, a notable letter for those
that keep counterfeit fools in their howses. Cap. xlv.
MArcus Aurelius only Emperor of Rome, lord of Asia, confederate with Europe,
friends of Affricke, and enemy of the wars, wishes health to thee Lambert,
governor of the I Will of Helespont. With the furs which thou did send me. I
have caused my gown to be furred, and am girded with the girdel which thou
did present me, and am greatly contented with thy hounds. For all is so
good, that the body does rejoice to possess it, and the eyes to beehold it,
and also the heart to render thanks for it. Where I did ask a few things of thee
in jest, thou have sent me many in ernest, wherein not as a servant, but as a
friend thou have showed thy self. For the office of noble and worthyharts, is
to offer to their friends, not only that which they demand: but that also which
they think they will demand. Truly thou have better measured thy services, by
thy noblenes: then I thee demand by my covetousness. For if thou do
remember, I did demand of thee only.xii. skins: and thou have sent me.12.
dosen. I told thee that I desired.6. hounds for to hunt: and thou have sent
me.12. of ye best that can be found in the I Will. In such sort, that I have had
honor: and thou have wonn renown. For in the litel I have demanded, they
shall see my little covetousness: and in the much thou have sent me, they shall
perceive thy great lyberalyty. I esteem highly that which thou have sent me:
and I beeseech the gods send thee good luck. For thou know, we may render
thanks for ye benefits received: but we have not the power to requite the
gentleness showed. For the man which dare receive of an other any gift, does
bynd him self to be his slave. I can not be thy slave, for I am thy friend:
and thereof thou oughst to rejoice, more then an other. For being a servant,
I should serve thee with fear: but being thy friend, I will profit thee with
friendship. Therefore to declare the chief occasion wherefore I write unto thee
at this present, I say, I send thee.3. ships laden with iesters and iuglers,
loyterers, vacabonds, and fools: and yet I do not send unto thee all the
vacabonds which are in Rome, for the^ thy I Will should be peopled with
strangers. The office that they had, was that soom of the^ iested and rayled
at the table, soome sang sundry malicious songs at marriages, others told lies
and news for their dinners at the gates, other played common plays in the
streats, other enterteined the roman matrones with foolish nouells and tales,
others set forth vain and light books of rymes and ballets: and yet I swear
unto thee by the god Hercules, these loiterers wanted no fools to here them. I
let thee weete, my friend Lambert, that these loyterers are such, and their
scolers in number so many that though the masters may be in.3. ships carried:
yet the scholars could not be in an hundred transported. Of one thing I
meruell much, and also I affirm, that the Gods be offended, since earthquakes
overthrew the houses, the great waters carry away the bridges, the frost freese
the vines, the corrupt air infecteth the wise men: and yet is there no plague
that consumes the fools? O how unhappy art thou Rome, unto him that shall
well beehold thee, and dilygently search thee. For in thee wants valyant
captayns, honest Senators, just Ce^sors, faithful officers, and virtuous
Princes: and only there abounds fools, iesters, plaiers, dysers, loyterers,
and vacabo^ds. O what service thou should do to the gods, and profit to our
mother Rome, if for.3. ships of fools, thou did send us one bark only of
wise men? I would not say (but I will not cease to say) that I have seen
fools, that I have heard many folys: but I never saw so great fools, nor hard
such extreme folly, as that of some noble romans, and Italyens, who think it a
great act to keep a fool in their house. I judge him to be a greater fool,
that so desires to keep a fool: then the fool him self. For a fool has a
semblaunce of the sage, after that he accompanies with a sage: but the sage
shows him self a fool, after he accompanies with a fool. Why do men
seek things of mockry? since all that is in the world is mockry? Why seek
we fools? Since all that we say, is nothing but folly? Why do we rejoice
with those which flatter us? since there are none, that say one only truth?
Why do we seek fained fools: Since that all, or the most part of us all,
are very fools? I see diverse in Rome, the which though they company with
honest men, are dissolute, companyeng with sages they are simple, treating with
wise men, they are without consideracion, and being conversant with fools,
they think to be sage. If we keep company with pitefull, we shall be
pityfull.

If we be conversant with the cruel, we shall be^e cruel. If we comunicate
with liars, we shall be liars. If we haunt the true, we shall be true: and if
we desire the foolish, we shall be fools. For according to the masters and
doctrines we have: such shall be the sciences which we shall learn, and the
woorks which we shall follow. The famous tirant Dionisius the Siracusane, which
was in Scicil, said unto the philosopher Diogenes. Tell me Diogenes, what
kind of me^ ought we to have in our houses, and with what persons ought we
to divide our goods? Diogenes answered him. The wise man which will live in
peace with the common wealth, and that will not see his goods evil employed,
ought not to geeue to eat, nor to accompany with any, but with the aged persons
which should counsel them, and with the young which should serve them, with
friends which should favor them, and with the poor, to the end they should
praise them. Denis the tiraunt greatly commended that, which Diogenes the
philosopher told him: but he could never profyt with that counsel. For as
he showed him self a tirant in robbing: so he showed him self also
indiscreet in spending. Presuppose that that which Diogenes the philosopher
spoke were true, that is to weete, that we ought to feed the aged, servants,
friends, and poor: we see by this answer, it is not just to geeue to eat,
either to iesters, minstrels, parasites, flaterers, loiterers or fools. First
me seems, that a man ought not to think that fools are capable to geeue
counsel, since they have it not for them selves: for it should be great folly
to use men as sages, which of their own will have made them selves fools. The
second, me seems that it is a vain thing to think, that the iesters should
serve as servants: for these unhappy people, to fly travail only, have taken
upon them this office so sclaunderous.

Thirdly it seems to be a shamefast thing, and of great inconuenyence, that
any noble and sage? man should determine, to have any flatterer, or iester for
his famylyar friend: for such ought not, nor cannot be counted among ye true
friends, since they love us not for ye virtue we possess, but for the goods
which we have. Fourthly me thinks it a vain thing to think, that under the
color of poverty it should be just, to geeue meat to iesters, or loyterers:
for we cannot say ye such are poor for that they want riches, but that folly
abounds in them. Since therefore a man is defamed to have such iesters,
flatterers, and loyterers for friends, and that for being servants they are
unable, and with out wit to ask them counsel: me thinks it is a great
folly, to spend his goods on such loyterers. For as their intencions to the
gods only are manifest, and to men secret: so their is nothing wherein the good
do approve and manifest their intencions to be good, or evil, more then in
the words which they speak, and in the companies which they keep.

Marcus Aurelius goes forward with his letter and declares how he found the
sepulchers of many learned Philosophers in Helespont, whereunto he sent all
these loyterers. Cap. xlvi.
I will thou know Lambert, that thy I Will is consecrated with the bones of many
excellent men, the which were banyshed by sundry tirannous Princes of Rome. The
ancients greatly commend that I Will, because there are therein stones caled
Amatistes, tame dear, fair women, familiar wolfes, swift dogs of foot, and
pleasant fountains.

Yet notwithstanding I will not cease to commend these things which rejoice
those that be present, and also comfort those that be to come. For I esteem
more the bones, which the earth do cover: then the riches, which grows
thereon. If thou have not lost the sense of smelling, as that I Will does sauoure
unto me of sages: so does Rome stynk of fools. For, for the time it is less
pain, to endure the stink of the beast: then to hear the words of a fool.
When the wars of Asia were ended, I returned home by that isle, wherein I
visited all the living people, and all the graves of the dead philosophers. And
for, a truth, I tell thee Lambert, ye that journey was very trublesome unto
me: for here in my person endured much pain, on the land I suffered diverse
dangers, and on the sea I saw my self in sundry perils. In the city of
Corinthe (where thou art resident at this present) in the midst of the market
place, thou shall find the grave of the philosopher Panimio, to whom the
straight friendship auayled litel, which he had with Ouide: but the enmity
greatly endomaged him which he had with Augustus the emperor. Two miles from
Theadfonte at the foot of the mountains Arpines thou shall find the grave of
the famous orator Armeno, who was by the co^sul Scilla unjustly banished, And
of troth, as here was much blood lost, because Scilla should not enter into
Rome: so there were not few tears shed in Italye, for the banishment of this
philosopher. In the gate of Argonata, hard by the water, in the top of a high
rock, thou shall find the bones of Celliodorus the Philosopher, who observed
all the ancient laws: and was a great enemy of those, which brought in new
customs, and statutes.

This good Philosopher was banyshed, in ye prosperitye and fury of ye Marians:
nor for the evils they found in him, but for the vices he reproved in them. In
the fyldes Heliny, there was a great tomb, within the which were the bones of
Selleno the philosopher, who was as well learned in the.vii. lyberall arts: as
if he himself had first invented them.

And he was banished by ye Emperor Nero, for because he persuaded this cruel
Emperor, to be merciful, and pyteful. In ye same fyeldes Heliny out of the
woods toward the west part, you shall find the grave of ye philosopher
Vulturnus a man in Astrology profoundly learned wc little auayled him in his
banishment

For he was banished by Marcus Antonius, not for that Marcus Antonius would
have banished him (for he was not offended by him) but because his love
Cleopatra hated him, as her mortal enemy.

For women of an evil life, revenge commonly their angry hearts, with the death
of their especial friends. Diverse other tombs in that I Will I saw, the names
whereof though in writing I have them: yet at this present I cannot call them to
memory. Well, by the faith of an honest man I swear unto thee, that thou shall
find al true which I have told thee. Now I tell thee Lambert, that I visiting
those graves, their disciples did not bear them greater obedience, when they
were alive: then I did reverence now they are dead. And it is true also, that
in all that time my eyes were as much wet with water, as their bones were
covered with earth. These philosophers were not banyshed, for myscheues by
their persons committed, nor for sclaunders they had done in the common
wealths: but because the deeds of our fathers deserved, that they shoold be
taken from their company, and we their children were not worthy, to have the
bones of so famous, and renowned sages in our custody. I cannot tell, if the
envy I have to that I Will be greater, or the pyty I have of this miserable Rome:
for the one is immortal by the graves of the dead, and the other is defamed
with the life of the living.

I desire thee heartily as a friend, and do command thee as a servant, that
thou keep ye pryuyleges which I geeue to that I Will, without breakyng any one.
For it is very just, that such cities peopled with such dead, should be
priuileged of ye living. By this Centurion, thou shall know al things which are
chanced amongst the prisoners.

For if I should write all the whole matter unto thee as it was done: I e^sure
thee, unto me it would be much pain to write it, and to thee great trouble
to read it. It suffyceth presently to say that the day of the great solempnitie
of the mother Berecinthe a sclaunderer arose in Rome by the occasion of these
iesters, scoffers, and loyterers: and by the faith of a good man, I swear unto
thee, that the blood which was shed through the places, surmounted the wine
which was drunk at the feast. And think not that which I say to be little that
the blood which was shed, surmounted the wine that was drunk.

For as thou now know, the Citezins are come to so great folly: that he
which was on that day most drunk, they said that he had offered unto the Gods
greatest sacrifyces. I am yet afraid, to remember the crueltyes which that day
I saw with my own eyes: but I am much more ashamed of that which they talk of
us in strange realms. For the noble and worthy hearts, do not count it so
much to receive a great wound: as to take it of a cowardly man. There is great
dyfference beetweene the netts, where with they take brydes, and no less is
there beetwene the hooks, wherewith they take fysh. I mean that the knife which
