cutteth the flesh, dyffereth much from the knife which hurts the heart. For
the hurts of the body, with surgions may be healed: but the gods only are the
phisicions of the peryls of the heart.

I saw Rome which was never vanquyshed by valiant men at that day overcome by
loyterers. Rome which could never be wonn by those of Carthage, is now wonn by
iesters, players, and vacabonds. Rome which triu^phed of all the realms, is
now vanquished of the loyterers, iesters, and idel persons.

Finally, we saw that Rome which in times past gave laws to the Barbarous, is
now beecome ye slave of fools: in this case I have been so troubled, that I
cannot tell what to say, and less what I write unto thee. One thing comforts
me, that since Rome and her Romans do not rejoice them selves but with
fools: that she and her children be not punyshed, but by the hands of
fools. I think not that in this case ye Gods do any wrong, if Rome which
laughed through mockry at the players: do weep one day with the loyterers in
good earnest. Thou might demand me Lambert, since we other Princes are
bound to maintain equal justice with al: wherefore we do dissemble many
offenses which others have done in earnest: and yet we will not pardon those
iesters, since all that they have invented, was for mirth and pastyme? I promise
thee, though their offenses were great in deed: yet I do not banish them so
much for the blood they have shed, as for the good orders which they have
perverted. Once again I retourn to say unto thee, yt I have not banyshed them
so much for because they were occasion of murders: as to be teachers of all
lies. Without co^paryson, greater is the offense to the gods, and greater is
the damage to the common wealth to take away (as these loyterers have done) the
senses of wise men: then that which the murderers do, to take life from their
enemies. The end of these iesters, scoffers, iuglers, idell men, and those kind
of rascalles, is always to persuade men yt they speak continually in mockries,
treat continually in mockries, and to rid them of their sorows, and all this
is but to deceive them of their goods. In the which case I say, and so pleased
it the gods, that they shoold content them selves with the goods, without
robbing us of our wisdom. When Scipio the Affrican had ended the wars of
Affrike, he went through Rome accompanied not with valiant captains: but
with the plaiers, iesters, and iuglers. The which a philosopher seeing, said
unto him these words. O Scipio, according to the much they have talked of thee,
and the little I see in thee, it had been better thou had dyed in Affricke,
then to come to Rome. For thy high acts, in thy absence did astony us: and thy
light nesse in thy presence does offend us. To thee it is great infamy, and to
the sacred senate little honesty, that thou having conquered so mighty princes in
affricke, should go accompanied with fools, and madd men in Rome. I let thee
weete Scipio, that thy life had not then so much peril among thy enemies: as
thy honor has at this present among fools. These words were very good,
though they were evil received, of humayne malice. For by reason of these
words the poor aged philosopher was banished (by the friends of Scipio) out of
Italy and sent to the I Will of Helesponte.

The Emperor ends his letter, and shows the cause and time why and when
these iesters, and iuglers were admitted into Rome. Cap. xlvii.
AFter that these loyterers and vacabounds shall la^d in thy I Will, thou shall let
them go at liberty and shall take none of their goods: but you shall advertise
them that they be not so hardy, to exercise their crafts nor feats. For if
they do the contrary thou may make them lose their life in thy I Will, wc I
have condicionally pardoned here in Rome. One thing I command thee, and I
beesech thee forget it not, that is to wete: that thou compel them to labor,
and that in no means thou suffer them to be idle.

For Idleness is the mother of al vices in the parson, and the causer of al
sclau^ders which arise in the common wealth. Since we know not but to labor,
and the loyterers know not but to loyter, I would say, that with more reason
they might say that we were not sage: then we might say that they are fools.
For wrongfully are they called fools, which by craft eat the swette of others:
Seeing the little regard we have to these loyterers, and considering how much
we presume: by the faith of a good man I swear unto thee Lamberte, that with
greater reason they should mock our woorks: then we others should laugh at
their words. For they profit more with our goods, then we do of their
folly. In the, CCxli. of the foundation of Rome a sore plague came into Italy.
The which being ended, they determined to tell not the thousands of menn that
were dead: but the small number of those which remained alive. Rome afterward
being so solitary, and Italy so desolate, only to rejoice the people, and to
the end the cities should not remayn uninhabited, the first theathers were
invented, and then first were these players received. For until that time the
Romans knew no other thing, but to offer sacrifice to their gods in the
temples: and to fight against their enemies in the feeldes. O lamentable thing
to hear, that this plague lasted only.xxiiii. months, and the rage and folly
of these players, and idel men, has endured more then.iiii. years. Would to
the immortal gods, that yt plague had ended those few which remayn: before
this cursed generation had brought so abominable customs into Rome. For much
better had it been for our mother Rome, that she had wanted inhabiters, than
such raskals should have come and dwelled therein. I know well (Lambert) yt
these parsons do greatly complain of me, and that the complaynts which they
do in the beeginning, shall not have an end there: but I care not much for the
complaints of the euel wc do serve for no other thing but to reprove ye
justices which are ministered unto them by the good. The princes in that they
command, and the judges in that they execute, ought not much to esteem the
complaynts of al those which say they have wrong: Provided that the cause be
justified, and that under the color of justice they do no wrong in deed. In
the flatteries which they tell us concerning our glory, and in the sclaunders wc
they speak of us concerning our reproach, wise men ought well to note the
nature of ye parson which speaks it, whether that be true which he
speaks, and what moves him to tell it, For as it is a shame for to be
rebuked of a man which is honest: so it is no small infamy to be praised of
those which are evil.

Since the time I was borne, I never saw any thing less profitable in the
common wealth, nor more vain, neither worse inuencions, nor colder recreations
then these are, which these iesters, players, and iuglers do invent.

What thing can be more monstrous, then to see the folly of a fool bring
diverse wise men out of their wits? What greater mockry can there be, then
that al do think that the jests of a fool ought to be rejoiced at, with the
laughter of the sage? What greater sclaunder can there be, the^ that in the
offices of the noble and worthy Romans, the gates should always be open for
fools: and the wise men should find them always shutt? What greater cruelty
can there be in Rome, then that the senators and rich men geeue more to a
player, for a song which he sings in one hour, then they do to the
servant for serving them a whole year? What greater theft can there be than
this, that the garrisons which are in Illiria want: and players, iesters
iuglers, flatterers, and loyterers, in Rome have to much? What greater sha^e
can Rome receive then this, when it shall be said in time to come, that
iuglers, players, parasites, iesters, and flatterers, have won more with
their iugling, playing, jesting and flattering: then diverse captayns with their
wepons, and triumphs? Beehold therefore Lambert, what difference there is
beetwene captayns, and loyterers. For when the one went through Rome, sowing
their follyes from gate to gate: the others went from realm to realm consuming
their goods, aduenturing their lives, fighting against the barbarous people,
and shedding their own proper blood.

And in the hindermost part of Spain, when those of Seuill had war with the
Gaditanes, it chanced that even in the midst of the time those of Seuil
wanted money, and, ii. parasites offered them selves for.ii. years to sustain
the wars, with their own proper goods: so that with the riches of two fools:
many wise men were overcome. When the Amazones were ladies of Asia, then they
buylt the great temple of the goddess Diana. And as the histories account,
only with that they took away from a player, was buylt this noble temple. If
the histories of the Egiptians do not deceive me, king Cadmus, who with
a.100. gates buylt the great city of Thebes, for such a buylding, so high and
monstrous a city, all his subjects together gave him not so much, as two
parasits did alone. When the good emperor Augustus renewed the walls of Rome,
and made them of hard stone, which before that time were only of earth and
brick, toward such a costly woork, he had more of two parasites which were
drowned, then of all the city beeside. I being in the city of Corinthe, saw an
ancient tomb, wherein the Corinthians say their first king was buried. And the
historiographers say that this king was a great wrostler, other say he was a
parasite, others say he was a iugler, but how so ever it was, he was first a
iester, and obtained a realm in earnest. Beehold therefore La^bert, how they
are neglected of the gods, and favored of fortune, and in how little estimacion
the goods of this life ought to be esteemed: sins some by counterfayting the
fools, leave of them as great a memory of their folly, as the others do by
their wisdom. There is one thing only of these loyterers that pleseth me,
that is to weete, that in presence they make every man laugh with the follyes
they speak: and after that they are gone, al remain sad for the money they
carry away. Truly it is a just sentence of the gods, that those which have taken
vanie pleasures togethers, do weep after wards for their losses severally. At
this present I will write no more unto thee, but that I send thee this letter
written in Greek, to the end thou may read it to all those of that isle. And
thou shall immediately dispatch the ships, to the end they carry the provisions
to the men of war in Illiria. Peace be with thee Lambert, health and good
fortune to me Mark.

The senate saluteth thee, and do send thee the prorogation of the gouerme^t
for the next year. In the calends of January thou shall say Gaude felix. my
wife Faustine comme^deth her to thee, and sends thee for thy daughter a rich
girdel. In payment of thy seruyces, I send thee.ii. rich jewels, ii. light
horses, and one laden with.4000. sexterces. Marcus of mount Celio, with his own
hand writes unto thee.

That princes and noble men ought to remember that they are mortal, and must
dye, where are sundry notable consolations against the fear of death. Cap.
xlviii.
CLeobolus and Biton were the sons of a renowned woman, the which was Nun
to the goddess Juno: and when the day of that solemn feast was celebrated,
her children prepared a chariot, wherein their mother shoold go to the temple.
For the Greeks had this custom, the day that the priests went to offer any
sacrifyces, either they were carried on men's arms, or in chariots. They
adourned their temples so well, they esteemed their sacrifices so much, and did
so much honor their priests: that if any priest did set his foot on the
ground, that day they did not permit him to offer any sacrifices to the gods.
It chanced as this Nun went in her charyot, and her children Cleobolus and
Biton with her, the beasts which drew the chariot, suddenly fell down dead.x.
miles from the temple of the goddess Juno. The children seeing the beasts
dead, and that ye mother coold not go a foot, and that the chariot was al
ready, and that there were no beasts to draw it: they (as loving children)
determined to yoke them selves, and draw the chariot as if they had been dome
beasts. And as ye mother carried the^.ix. months in her womb, so did they draw
her in the chariot.x. miles. Now for that they passed through infinite nomberz
of men, to the great feast of the goddess Juno: every man seeing Cleobolus and
Biton yoked in the chariot like beasts, were greatly amazed, saying that these
two children deserved with great rewards to be recompensed. And truly they
said justly, and so the deserved it. For they deserved as much to be praised
for the example which they showed to all children to reverence their parents:
as for carrying their mother in ye chariot to the temple. So after that the
feast was ended, ye mother not knowing how to requite the benefit of her
children, with many tears beesought the goddess Juno, that she with ye other
gods woold be contented, to geeue her.ii. children the best thing that the
gods coold geeue to their friends. The goddess Juno answered her, that she
was contented to require the other gods, and that they woold do it. And the
reward was, that for this noble fact the gods ordained, that Cleobolus and
Biton shoold sleep one day well, and in the morning when they shoold wake,
they shoold dye. The mother pitifully beewayling the death of her children: and
complaining of the gods, the goddess Juno said unto her. Thou have no cause
why to complayn, sins we have geeuen thee that thou have demanded: and have
demanded that which we have geeuen thee. I am a goddess, and thou art my
servant and therefore the gods have geeuen to thy children the thing, which
they count most dear, which is death. For the greatest revenge which amongst
us gods we can take of our enemies, is to let them live long: and the best
thing that we keep for our friends, is to make them dye quickly.

The auctor of this history is called Hisearchus in his politikes, and Cicero
in his first book of his Tusculanes. In ye I Will of Delphos, where ye Oracle of
ye god Apollo was, there was a sumptuous temple, the which for want of
reparacion fell down to the ground as often times it chances to high and
sumptuous buyldings, which from time to time are not repaired. For if ye
walls, dungeons, castles, and strong houses coold speak, as well woold they
complayn for that they do not renew them, as the old men do for that we do
not cherish them. Triphon, and Agamendo, were two noble personages of Greece,
and counted for sage and rich men: the which went unto the temple of Apollo,
and buylt it new again, as well with the labor of their persons, as with the
great expenses of their goods. When the buylding was atchiued, ye god Apollo
said unto them, that he remembered well their good service, wherefore he woold
they shoold demand him any thing in reward of their trauail, and with a good
will it shoold be granted. For the gods use, for a little service, to geeue a
great reward. Triphon, and Agamendo, answered unto the god Apollo, that for
their good will, for their travel, and for their expenses, they demanded no
other reward: but that it woold please him to geeue them the best thing that
might be geeuen unto man, and that unto them were most profit: saying, that
the miserable men have not the power to eschew the evil, nor wisdom to choose
the good. The god Apollo answered, that he was contented to pay them their
service which they had done, and to grant them that which they had demanded.
By reason whereof, Triphon, and Agamendo having dyned, sodeinly at the gates of
the temple fell down dead. So that the reward of their travel, was to pluck
them out of their misery. The end to declare these two examples is to thend
that al mortal men may know, that there is nothing so good in this world as to
have an end of this life: and though to lose it there be no savor, yet at the
least there is profit. For we woold reprove a traueler of great foolishnes, if
sweating by the way he woold sing: and after at his journeys end he shoold
beegin to weep. Is not he simple, which is sorry for that he is comen into
the haven? is not he simple, that geeueth the battle, and fights for that
he has got the victory? Is not he stubbern, which is in great distress, and
is angry to be succored? Therefore, more foolish, simple, and stubbern is he,
which traueleth to dye, and is loath to meet with death. For death is the true
refuge, the perfect health, the sure haven, the whole victory, the flesh
without bones, fysh without scales, and corn without straw: Finally after
death we have nothing to beewail, and much less to desire.

In the time of Adrian the emperor, a philosopher called Secundus (being
marueilously learned) made an oration at the funeral of a noble Romayn matrone
(a kinswoman of the emperors) who spoke exceeding much evil of life, and
marvelous much good of death. And when the emperor demanded him what death
was, the philosopher answered: Death is an eternal sleep, a dissolucion of the
body, a terror of the rich, a desire of the poor, a thing inheritable, a
pilgrymage uncertain, a thief of men, a kind of sleaping, a shadow of life, a
seperacion of the living, a company of the dead, a resolution of all a rest of
travels, and the end of all idle desires. Finally death is the scourge of all
evil, and the cheef reward of the good.

Truly this philosopher spoke very well, and he shoold not do evil, which
profoundly woold consider that he had spoken. Seneca in an epistle declares,
of a philosopher whose name was Bassus, to whom when they demanded what evil a
man can have in death, since men fear it so much, he answered. If any damage
or fear is in him who dies, it is not for the fear of death: but for the vice
of him which dies. We may agree to that the philosopher said, that even as
the deaf can not judge harmony, nor the blind colors: so likewise they cannot
say evil of death, in especially he which never tasted it. For of all those
which are dead, none returned again to complayn of death: and of these few that
live, all complayn of life. If any of the dead returned hither to speak with
the living, and as they have proved it, so they woold tell us. If there were any
harm in secret death, it were reason to have some fear of death? But though a
man that never saw, hard, felt, nor tasted death, does speak evil of death,
shoold we therefore fear death? Those ought to have done some evil in their
life, which do fear and speak evil of death. For in the last hour, in the
straight judgment, the good shall be known, and the evil discovered. There is
no prince nor knight, rich nor poor, whole nor sick, lucky nor unlucky, which
I see with their vocacions to be contented, save only the dead: which in their
graves are in peace and rest, and are neither covetous, proud, negligent, vayn,
ambitious, nor dissolute. So that the state of the dead ought to be best,
since we see none therein to be evil contented. And since therefore those
which are poor, do seek wherewith to enrich them selves, those which are
sad, do seek whereby to rejoice, and those which are sick, do seek to be
healed, why is it, that those which have such fear of death, do seek some
remedy against that fear? In this case I woold say, that he which will not
fear to dye, let him use him self well to live. For the giltles takes away
fear from death. The divine Plato demanded Socrates how he beehaued him self
in life, and how he woold beehaue him self in death, he answered. I let thee
weete, that in youth I have traueled to live well, and in age I have studied to
dye well: and since my life has been honest, I hope my death shall be joyful.
And though I have had sorrow to live, I am sure I shall have no pain to dye.
Truly these words were worthy of such a man. Men of stout hearts suffer
maruelously, when ye swet of their travel is not rewarded, when they are
faithful, and their reward answers nothing to their true service: when for
their good services, their friends beecome unthankful to them, when they are
worthy honor, and that they prefer them to honorable rome and office. For
the noble and valyant hearts, do not esteem to lose the reward of their labor:
but think much unkindness, when a man does not acknowledge their travel. O
happy are they that dye: For without inconvenience and without pain every man
is, in his grave. For in this tribunal, justice to all is so equally observed:
that in the same place where we have deserved life, in ye same place we
merited death. There was never nor never shall be judge so just, nor in
justice so vpryght, that geeueth reward by weight, and pain by measure: but
sometimes they chastise the innocent, and absolve the gylty, they vex the
faultlesse, and dissemble with the culpable. For little avails it the plaintiff
to have good justice: if conscience want to the judge that shoold minister.
Truly it is not so in death, but all ought to count them selves happy. For he
wc shall have good justice, shall be sure on his part to have the sentence. When
great Cato was censor in Rome, a famous Romayn dyed, who showed at his death a
merueylous courage: and when the Romans praised him for that he had so great
virtue, and for the words he had spoken, Cato the Censour laughed at that they
said, for that they praised him. And he being demanded the cause of his
laughter, answered. Ye marvel at that I laugh, and I laugh at that you
marvel. For the perils and travels considered wherein we live, and ye safety
wherein we dye. I say, yt it is no more needful to have virtue and strength to
live, then courage to dye. The aucthor hereof is Plutarch in his Apothegmes.
We cannot say but that Cato the Censour spoke as a wise man, since daily we
see, shamefast and virtuous persons suffer hunger, cold, thrist, travel,
poverty, inconvenience, sorows, enmities, and mishaps: of the wc things we
were better to see the end in one day, then to suffer them every hour.

For it is less evil to suffer an honest death: then to endure a miserable
life. O how small consideration have men to think, that they ought to dye but
once. Since the truth is, that the day when we are born, and comen in to the
world is the beeginning of our death: and the last day is when we do cease to
live. If death be no other but an ending of life, then reason persuades us to
think, that our infancy dies, our chyldhod dies, our manhod dies, and our
age shall dye: whereof we may consequently conclude, that we dye every year,
every day, every hour, and every moment. So that thinking to lead a sure life,
we taste a new death. I know not why men fear so much to dye, since that from
the time of their birth, they seek none other thing but death. For time never
wanted to any man to dye, neither I knew any man that ever failed of this way.
Seneca in an epistle declares that as a Romain woman lamented the death of a
child of hers, a philosopher said unto her: Woman why beewaylest thou thy
child? she answered I weep because he has lived.xxv. years, and I woold
he shoold have lived till fyfty. For amongst us mothers, we love our children
so heartily, that we never cease to beehold them, nor yet end to beewayl them.
Then the Philosopher said. Tell me I pray thee woman, why do thou not
complayn of the gods, because they created not thy son many years before
he was born: as well as thou complaynest that they have not let him live.l.
years? Thou weepest, that he is dead so soon: and thou do not lament that
he is borne so late. I tell thee true woman, that as thou do not lament for
the one, no more thou oughtst to be sorry for the other. For without the
determination of the gods, we can not shorten death: and much less lengthen
life. So Pliny said in an epistle, that the cheifest law which the gods have
geeuen to humayn nature was, that none shoold have perpetual life. For with
disordinat desire to live long, we shoold never rejoice to go out of this
pain. Two philosophers disputyng before the great Emperor Theodose, the one
said that it was good to procure death: and the other likewise said, it was a
necessary thing to hate life. The good Theodose taking him by the hand said.
All we mortalles are so extreem in hatyng, and loving: that under the color
to love, and hate life, we lead an evil life. For we suffer so many travels
for to preserve it, that sometimes it were much better to lose it. And further
he said, diverse vayn men are come into so great follies, that for fear of
death, they procure to hasten death. And having consideration to this, me
seems that we ought not greatly to love life, nor with desperation to seek
death. For the strong and valiant men, ought not to hate life so long as it
lasts: nor to be displeased with death, when he comes. All commended that
which Theodose spoke, as Paulus Diaconus says in his life. Let every man speak
what he will, and let the philosophers counsel what they list, in my poor
judgment, he alone shall receive death without pain: who long before is
prepared to receive the same. For sodayn death is not only bitter to him which
tastes it: but also it fears him that hates it. Lactantius said, that in
such sort man ought to live, as if from hence an hour after he shoold dye.

For those men which will have death before their eyes, it is impossible that
they geeue place to vain thoughts. In my oppinion, and also by the advise of
Apuleius, it is as much folly to fly from that which we cannot avoid: as to
desire that we cannot attain. And this is spoken for those, that woold fly
the vyage of death which is necessary: and desire to come again which is
impossible. Those that travel by long ways, if they want any thing, they borow
it of their company. If they have forgotten ought, they return to seek it at
their lodging, or else they write unto their friends a letter. But I am sorry that
if we once dye, they will not let us return again, we cannot speak, and they
will not agree we shall write: but such as they shall find us, so shall we
be judged. And that which is most fearful of all, the execucion and sentence
is geeue^ in one day. Let princes and great lords beeleeue me in this. Let
them not leave that undone till after their death: which they may do during
their life. And let them not trust in that they command: but in that whiles
they live they do. Let them not trust in ye woorks of an other: but in their
own good deeds. For in the end, one sigh shall be more worth, then all the
friends of the world. I counsel, pray, and exhort all wise and virtuous men, and
also my self with them, that in such sort we live, that at the hour of death,
we may say we live. For we cannot say that we live, when we live not well.
For all that time which without profit we shall live, shall be counted unto
us for nothing.

Of the death of Marcus Aurelius the Emperor, and how there are few friends
which dare say the truth to sick men. Cap. xlix.
THe good Emperor Marcus Aurelius now being aged, not only for the great years
he had: but also for the great travels he had in the wars endured: It
chanced, that in the.xviii. year of his Empire, and.lxxii. years from the day
of his birth, and of the foundation of Rome.v. hundredth xliii. being in the
war of Pannony (which at this time is called Hungary) beeseeging a famous
city called Vendeliona, suddenly a disease of the palsy took him, which was
such, that he lost his life, and Rome her Prince, the best of life that ever
was born therein. Among the heathen princes some had more force then he, other
possessed more riches then he, others were as aduenturous as he, and some
have known as much as he: but none has been of so excellent and virtuous a
life, nor so modest as he. For his life being examined to the uttermost,
there are many princely virtues to follow, and few vices to reprove. The
occasion of his death was, that going one night about his camp, sodeinly the
disease of the palsy took him in his arm: so that from thence forward he
coold not put on his gown, nor draw his sword, and much less carry a staff.
The good emperor being so laden with years, and no less with cares, the sharp
winter approaching more and more, great abundance of water and snow fell about
the tenis: so that an other disease fell upon him, called Litargie, the which
thing much abated his courage, and in his host caused great sorrow. For he was
so beeloued of all, as if they had been his own children. After that he had
proved all medicines and remedies that coold be found, and all other things,
which unto so great and mighty princes were accustomed to be done, he
perceived in the end, that all remedy was past. And the reason hereof was,
because his sickness was exceeding vehement, and he him self very aged, ye air
unwholesome, and above al, because sorows and cares oppressed his heart. Without
doubt, greater is the disease that proceeds of sorrow, then that which
proceeds of the fever quartain. And thereof ensues, that more easily is he
cured, wc of corrupt humors is full: then he wc with profound thoughts is
oppressed. The emperor then being sick in his chamber, and in such sort that
he coold not exercise ye feats of arms: as his men ran out of their camp to
scirmidge, and the Hungarions in like manner to defend, the fight on both parts
was so cruel, through the great effution of blood, that neither the hungarion
had cause to rejoice, nor yet ye romayn to be merry. Understanding the evil
order of his, and specially that.v. of his captains were slain in the conflict,
and that he for his disease coold not be there in person: such sorows persed
his heart, that although he desired forthwith to have dyed, yet he remained
two days and three nights, without that he woold see light, or speak unto any
man of his. So that ye heat was much, the rest was small, the sighs were
continual, and the thirst very great: the meat little, and the sleep less,
and above all his face wrynkled, and his lips very black. Sometimes he cast up
his eyes, and another time he wrong his hands: always he was sylent, and
continually he sighed. His tongue was swollen, that he coold not spit: and his
eyes very hollow with weeping. So that it was a great pity, to see his death:
and no less compassion, to see the confusion of his palace, and the
hinderaunce of the war. Many valiant captains, many noble Romans, many
faithful servant, and many old friends, at all these heaviness were present.
But none of them durst speak to the Emperor Mark, partly for that they took
him to be so sage, that they knew not what counsel to geeue him: and partly
for that they were so sorrowful, that they coold not refrayn their heavy tears.
For the loving and true friends, in their life ought to be beeloued: and at
their death to be beewailed. Great compassion ought men to have of those which
dye, not for that we see them dye: but because there are none that tells
them what they ought to do. Princes and great lords are in greater peril when
they dye: then the Plebeyans. For the counsaylour dare not tell unto his Lord
at the hour of death, that which he knows: and much less he will tell him
how he ought to dye, and what things he ought to discharge whiles he is
alive. Many go to visit the sick, that I woold to god they went some other
where. And the cause hereof is, that they see the sick man's eyes hollow, the
flesh dried, the arms without flesh, ye color enflamed, the ague continual,
the pain great, the tongue swollen, nature consumed, and beesydes all this, the
house destroyed: and yet they say unto the sick man, be of good cheer, I
warrant you, you shall live. As young men naturally desire to live, and as death
to all old men is dreadful: so though they see them selves in that dystresse,
yet they refuse no medicine, as though there were great hope of life. And
thereof ensues oftentimes, that the miserable creatures depart the world,
without confessing unto god, and making restitutions unto men.

O if those which do this, knew what evil they do. For to take away my goods,
to trouble my person, to blemish my good name, to sclaunder my parentage, and
to reprove my life, these woorks are of cruel enemies: but to be occasion to
lose my soul, it is the work of the devil of hell. Certainly he is a
devil, which deceives the sick with flatteries: and that in steed to healp
him to dye well, puts him in vayn hope of long life.

Herein he that says it, wins little: and he that beeleeueth it,
aduentureth much. To mortal men it is more meet, to geeue counsels to reform
their consciences with the truth: then to hasard their houses with lies. With
our friends we are shameless in their life, and also bashful at their death.
The which ought not to be so. For if our fathers were not dead, and that we
did not daily see these that are present dye: me thinks it were a shame and
also a fear, to say to the sick that he alone shoold dye. But since thou
know as well as he, and he knows as well as thou, that all do travel in
this perilous iurney: what shame have thou to say unto thy friend, that he is
now at the last point? If the dead shoold now reuyue, how woold they complayn
of their friends? And this for no other cause, but for that they woold not geeue
them good counsel at their death. For if the sick man be my friend, and that I
see peradventure he will dye: why shall not I counsel him to prepare him self
to dye? Certainly oftentimes we see by experyence, that those which are
prepared, and are ready for to dye, do escape: and those which think to live
do perish. What shoold they do which go to vysit the sick? persuade them
that they make their testaments, that they confess their sins, that they
discharge their conscience, that they receive the Communion, and that they do
reconcile them selves to their enemies.

Certainly, all these things charge not the lance of death, nor cut not the
thread of life. I never saw blyndnes so blind, nor ignorance so ignorant, as
to be ashamed to counsel the sick, that they are bound to do when they are
whole. As we have said here above, Princes and great Lords, are those above
all other that live and dye most abusedly. And the cause is, that as their
servant have no hearts to persuade them when they are merry: so have they no
audacity to tell them truth, when they are in peril. For such servant care
little, so that their masters beequeath them any thing in their wills, whether
they dye well, or live evil.

O what misery, and pity is it, to see a Prince, a Lord, a gentleman, and a
rych person dye, if they have no faithful friend about them, to help them to
pass that pain? And not without a cause I say, that he ought to be a
faithful friend. For many in our life do gape after our goods, and few at our
deaths are sorry for our offenses. The wise and sage men, before nature
compels them to dye, of their own will ought to dye. That is to weete, that
before they see them selves in the pangues of death, they have their
consciences ready prepared. For if we count him a fool, which will pass the
sea without a ship: truly we will not count him wise, which takes his
death without any preparacion before. What loses a wise man to have his will
well ordained? in what adventure of honor is any man before death, to
reconsile him self to his enemies: and to those whom he has born hate and
malice? What loses he of his credit, who in his life time restores that,
which at his death they will command him to render? wherein may a man show him
self to be more wise, then when willingly he has discharged that, which
afterward by process they will take from him? O how many princes, and great
lords are there, which only not for spending one day about their testament,
have caused their children, and heirs, all the days of their life to be in
trauerse in the law? So that they supposing to have left their children welthy:
have not left them, but for atturneis and counselers of the law. The true and
unfeigned Christian, ought every morning so to dyspose his goods, and correct
his life: as if he shoold dye the same night. And at night in like manner he
ought so to commit him self to god, as if he hoped for no life until morning.
For to say the truth, to sustein life, there are infinite travels: but to meet
death, there is but one way. If they will credit my words, I woold counsel no
man in such estate to live: that for any thing in the world, he shoold undo
him self. The rich and the poor, the great and the small, the gentlemen and
the Plebeians, all say and swear, that of death they are exceeding fearful. To
whom I say and affirm, that he alone fears death, in whom we see amendment
of life. Princes and great lords, ought also to be perfect before they be
perfect, to end before they end, to dye before they dye, and to be mortified
before they be mortified. If they do this with them selves, they shall as
easily leave their life: as if they changed from one house to an other. For the
most part of men delight to talk with leisure, to drink with leisure, to eat with
leisure, and to sleep with leisure: but they dye in haste. Not without cause I
say they dye in haste, since we see the^ receive the sacrament of ye supper of
ye lord in haste, make their wills by force, and with speed to confess and
receive. So that they take it, and demand it so late, and so without reason:
that often times they have lost their senses, and are ready to geeue up the
spirit, when they bring it unto them.

What avails the ship master, after the ship is sonk? what do weapons
auayl, after the battle is lost? What avails pleasures after men are dead?
By that I have spoken, I will demand, what it avails the sick, being heavy
with sleep, and beereft of their senses, to call confessors, to whom they
confess their sins? Evil shall he be confessed, which has no
understanding to repent him self. What avails it to call the confessor, to
understand the secret of his conscience: when the sick man has lost his
speech? Let us not deceive our selves, saying in our age, we will amend
hereafter: and make restitution at our death. For in mine oppinion, it is not
the point of wise men, nor of good christians, to desire so much time to
offend: and they will never espy any to amend. Woold to god, that the third part
of time which men occupy in sin, were employed about the meditations of
death: and ye cares which they have to accomplish their fleshly lusts, were
spent in beewayling their filthy sins. I am very sorry at my heart, that they
so wickedly pass their life, in vices and pleasures as if there were no God,
to whom they shoold render account for their offenses. All worldlings willingly
do sin, upon hope only in age to amend, and at death to repent: but I woold
demand him, that in this hope sinned, what certeinty he has in age of
amendment, and what assurance he has to have long warning before he dye.
Since we see by experience, there are mo in number which dye young, then old:
it is no reason we shoold commit so many sins in one day, that we shoold
have cause to lament afterward all the rest of our life. And afterward to
beewail the sins of our long life, we desire no more but one space of an
hour. Considering the omnipotency of the divine mercy it suffiseth, ye and I
say, that the space of an hour is to much, to repent us of our wicked life: but
yet I woold counsel all, since the sinner for to repent takes but one hour,
that that be not the last hour. For the sighs and repentance, which proceed
from the bottom of the heart, penetrate ye high heavens: but those which come of
necessity, does not perse the seeling of the house. I allow and commend, that
those that visit the sick, do counsel them to examine their conscienses, to
receive the communion, to pray unto god, to forgeeue their enemiez, and to
recommend them selves to the devout prayers of the people, and to repent their
sins, finally I say, that it is very good to do all this: but yet I say it
is better, to have done it before. For the diligent and careful Pirate,
prepares for the tempest, when the sea is calm. He that deeply woold
consider, how little the goods of this life are to be esteemed: let him go to
see a rich man when he dies, and what he does in his bed. And he shall
find that the wife demands of the poor husband her dower, the daughter the
third part, the other the fifth, the child the pre-eminence of age, the son in
law his marriage, the physician his duity, the slave his liberty, the servants
their wages, the creditors their debts, and the woorst of all is, that none of
those yt ought to enherit his goods, will geeue him one glass of water. Those
that shall here or read this, ought to consider, that that which they have
seen done at the death of their neighbors: the same shall come to them, when
they shall be sick at the point of death. For so soon as the rych shuts his
eyes, forthwith there is great strife beetweene the children for his goods.
And this strife is not to unburden his soul: but which of them shall inherit
most of his possessions. In this case, I will not my pen travel any further,
since both rich and poor, daily see the experience hereof. And in things very
manifest, it suffyseth only for wise men to be put in memory, without wasting
any more time to persuade them. Now the Emperor Marcus Aurelius had a secretary
very wise, and virtuous, through whose hands the affairs of the Empire passed.
And when this secretary saw his lord, and master, so sick, and almost at the
hour of death, and that none of his parents nor friends durst speak unto him:
he plainly determined to do his duity, wherein he showed very well the
profound knowledge he had in wisdom, and the great good will he bare to his
lord. This secretary was called Panutius, the virtues and life of whom, Sextus
Cheronensis in the life of Marcus Aurelius declares.

Of the comfortable words, which the Secretary Panutius spoke to the Emperor
Marcus Aurelius at the hour of his death. Cap. l.
O My lord, and master, my tongue cannot keep silence, mine eyes cannot refrayn
from bitter tears, nor my heart leave from fetching sighs, ne yet reason can
use his duity. For my blood boyleth, my sinnews are dried, my pores be open,
my heart does faint, and my spirit is troubled. And the occasion of all this
is, to see that the wholesome counsels which thou geeuest to others: either thou
can not, or will not take for thy self. I see thee dye my lord, and I dye for
that I cannot remedy thee. For if the gods woold have granted me my request,
for the lengthning of thy life one day: I woold geeue willingly my whole life.
Whether the sorrow be true, or fained, it needs not I declare unto thee with
words, since thou may manyfestly discern it by my countenance. For my eyes
with tears are wet, and my heart with sighs is very heavy. I feel much the want
of thy company. I feel much the damage which (of thy death) to the whole
common wealth shall ensue. I feel much thy sorrow which in thy palace shall
remain, I feel much for that Rome this day is undone: but that which above al
things does most torment my heart, is to have seen thee live as wise, and now
to see thee dye as simple. Tell me I pray thee, my lord, why do men learn
the Greek tongue, travel to understand the hebrew, sweat in the latin, change so
many masters, turn so many books, and in study consume so much money and so
many years: if it were not to know how to pass life with honor, and take death
with patience? The end why men ought to study, is to learn to live well. For
there is no truer science in man, then to know how to order his life well. What
profits it me to know much, if thereby I take no profit? what profits me
to know strange languages, if I refrain not my tongue from other men's matters?
what profits it to study many books, if I study not but to begyle my friends?
what profits it to know the influence of ye stars, and the course of the
elements: if I cannot keep my self from vices? Finally I say, that it little
avails to be a master of the sage: if secretly he be reported to be a
follower of fools. The cheef of all philosophy consists to serve god, and not
to offend men. I ask thee, most noble prince, what avails it the Pilot to
know the art of sailing: and after in a tempest by negligence to perish? What
avails it the valiant captayn, to talk much of war: and afterward he
knows not how to geeue the battayl? What avails it the guide, to tell the
nearest way: and afterward in the midst to lose him self.

All this wc I have spoken, is said for thee my Lord. For what avails it that
thou being in health, shooldst sigh for death: since now when he does
approach, thou weepest because thou wooldst not leave life? One of the things
wherein the wise man shows his wisdom, is to know how to love, and how to
hate. For it is great lightness (I shoold rather say folly) to day to love him,
whom yesterday we hated: and to morrow to sclaunder him whom this day we
honored. What Prince so high, or what Plebeyan so base has there been, or in
the world shall ever be, the which has so little (as thou) regarded life: and
so hyghly commended death? What things have I written (being thy Secretary)
with my own hand, to diverse prouynces of the world: where thou speak so much
good of death, that sometimes you made me to hate life? What was it to see
that letter which thou wrotest to the noble Romayn Claudines wydow, comforting
her of the death of her husband, which dyed in ye wars? Wherein she
answered: That she thought her trouble comfort, to deserve that thou shooldst
write her such a letter.

What a pitiful and sauory letter have thou written to Antigonus, on the death
of thy child Verissimus thy son so much desired? Whose death thou tookest so,
that thou exceedest the limits of philosophy: but in ye end, with thy princely
virtues, thou did qualify thy woeful sorows. What sentences so profound, what
words so well couched did thou write in that book entytuled The remedy of
the sorrowful. the which thou did send from the war of Asia, to the
Senators of Rome: and that was to comfort them after a sore plague. And how
much profit has thy doctrine done since? with what new kind of consolation
have thou comforted Helius Fabatus the Sensour, when his son was drowned in
the river? where I do remember, that when we entered into his house, we found
him weeping: and when we went from thence, we left him laughing. I do
remember, that when thou wentst to visit Gneus Rusticus in his last disease,
thou spakest unto him so effectuously, that with the vehemence of thy words,
thou made the tears to run down his cheeks. And I demanding him the
occasions of his lamentacions, he said. The emperor my lord has told me so
much evils that I have won, and of so much good that I have lost, that if I
weep, I weep not for life which is short, but for death which is long. The
man whom above all thou have loved, was Torquatus, whom thou did obey as thy
father, and seruedst as thy master. This thy faithful friend being ready to
die, and desyring yet to live, thou sendst to offer sacrifices to the gods, not
for that they shoold grant him life: but that they shoold hasten his death.
Herewith I being astonished, thy nobleness to satisfy my ignorance, said unto
me in secret these words.

Marvel not Panutius, to see me offer sacrifyces to hasten my friends death:
and not to prolong his life. For there is nothing that the faithful friend
ought so much to desire to his true friend: as to see him rid from the travels
of this earth, and to enjoy the pleasures of heaven. Why think thou most
noble prince, that I reduce all these things to thy memory, but for to demand
thee how it is possible, that I which have hard thee speak so well of death,
do presently see thee so unwilling to leave life? since the gods command it,
thy age wills it, thy disease does cause it, thy feeble nature does permit
it, the sinful Rome does deserve it, and the fickle fortune agrees, that for
our great misery thou shooldst dye. Why therefore sighest thou so much for to
dye? The travels which of necessity must needs come, with stout heart ought to
be received. The cowardly heart falls before he is beaten down: but the
stout and valiant stomach in greatest peril, recouereth most strength. Thou
art one man, and not two, thou oughtst one death to the gods, and not two: why
will thou therefore being but one, pay for two? and for one only life, take
two deaths?

I mean that before thou endest life, thou dyest for pure sorrow. After that
thou have sailed, and in the sailing thou have passed such peril, when the
gods do render thee in the safe haven, once again thou will run in to ye
raging sea, where thou scapest the victory of life, and thou dyest with the
ambushements of death. Lxii. years have thou fought in the field, and never
turned thy back: and fear thou now being enclosed in the grave? have thou
not passed the pykes, and briars, wherein thou have been enclosed: and now thou
tremblest, being in the sure way? Thou know what dommage it is long to
live, and now thou doutest of the profit of death which ensues. It is now many
years, since death and thou have been at defiaunce, as mortal enemies: and now
to lay thy hands on thy weapons, thou flyest and turnest thy back. Lxii. years
are past, since thou were bent against fortune: and now thou closest thy eyes,
when thou oughtst over her to triumph. By that I have told thee I mean, that
since we do not see thee take death willyngly at this present: we do
suspect that thy life has not in times past been very good. For the man which
has no desire to appear before the gods: it is a token he is laden with
vices. What meanest thou, most noble prince, why weepest thou as an infant, and
complainest as a man in despair? If thou weepest because thou die, I
answer thee, that thou laughedst as much when thou liuedst. For of too much
laughing in ye life, proceeds much wayling at the death. Who has always for
his heritage, appropriated the places being in the common wealth? The
inconstancy of the mind, who shall be so hardy to make steady? I mean that all
are dead, all dye, and al shall dye: and among all will thou alone live? Will thou obtayn of the gods, that which makes them gods? That is to weete, that
they make thee immortal, as them selves? Will thou alone have by privilege,
that which the gods have by nature? My youth demands thy age what thing is
best, or to say better, which is less evil: to dye well, or to live evil. I
doubt that any man may attayn to the means to live well, according to the
continual and variable troubles which daily we have accustomed to carry
beetweene our hands, always suffering hunger, cold, thirst, care, displeasures,
temptacions, persecucions, evil fortunes, ouerthrows, and diseases.

This cannot be called life, but a long death: and with reason we will call
this life death, since a thousand times we hate life. If an ancient man did
make a show of his life, from time he is come out of the intrailes of his
mother, until the time he enters into the bowels of the earth, and that the
body woold declare all the sorows that he has passed, and the heart discover
all the ouerthrows of fortune, which he has suffered: I immagin the gods
woold marvel, and men woold wonder at the body which has endured so much, and
the heart which has so greatly dissembled.

I take the Greeks to be more wise, which weep when their children be
borne, and laugh when the aged dye: then the Romans which sing when the
children are borne, and weep when the old men dye. We have much reason to
laugh, when the old men dye, since they dye to laugh: and with greater reason
we ought to weep, when the children are borne, since they are borne to weep.

Pannatius the secretary continues his exhortation admonishing al men
willingly to accept death, and utterly to forsake the world and all his
vanities. Cap. li.
SIns life is now condemned for evil, there remains naught else, but to
approve death to be good. O if it pleased the immortal gods, that as I
oftentimes have hard the disputacions of this matter: so now that thou cooldst
therewith profit. But I am sorry that to the sage, and wise man, counsel
sometimes (or for the most part) wants. None ought to cleue so much to his
own opinion, but sometimes he shoold follow the counsel of the third parson.
For the man which in all things will follow his own advise, ought well to be
assured, that in all, or the most part, he shall err. O my lord Mark, since
thou art sage, lively of spirit, of great experience and ancient, did not
thou think, that as thou had buried many, so like wise some should bury
thee? What imaginacions were thine to think, that seeing the end of their days,
others should not see the end of thy years? Since thou die rych, honorably
accompanied, old, and above all, seeing thou die in the service of the common
wealth, why fear thou to enter into thy grave? Thou have always been a
friend as much to know things past: as those which were hid and kept secret.
Sins thou have proved what honors, and dishonors do deserve, riches and
poverty, prosperity and adversity, joy and sorrow, love and fear, vices and
pleasures: me seems that nothing remains to know, but that it is
necessary to know what death is. And also I swear unto thee (most noble lord)
yt thou shall learn more in one hour, what death is: then in a hundredth years
what life means. Since thou art good, and presumest to be good, and have
lived as good, is it not better that thou dye, and go with so many good: then
that thou escape, and live amongst so many evil? That thou feel death, I
marvel nothing at all, for thou art a man: but I do maruail that thou
dissemblest it not, since thou art discrete. Many things do the sage men
feel, which inwardly do oppress their heart: but outwardly they dissemble
them, for the more honor. If all the poison which in the sorrowful heart is
wrapped, were in small pieces in the feeble flesh scattered: then the walls
woold not suffice to rub, neither the nails to scratch us. What other thing
is death, but a trap or door where with to shut the shop, wherein all the
miseries of this woeful life are vendible? What wrong or prejudice do the gods
unto us, when they call us before them: but from an old decayed house, to
change us to a new builded palace? And what other thing is the grave, but a
strong fort, wherein we shut our selves from the assaults of life, and broils
of fortune? Truly, we ought to be more desirous of that we find in death,
then of that we leave in life. If Helia Fabricia thy wife do grieve thee, for
that thou leauest her young, do not care. For she presently has little care of
the peril, wherein thy life depends. And in the end, when she shall know of
thy death, she will be nothing grieved. Trouble not thy self for that she is
left widow. For young women (as she is) which are married with old men (as thou)
when their husbands dye: they have their eyes on that they can rob, and their
hearts on them whom they desire to mary. And speaking with due respect, when
with their eyes they outwardly seem most for to beewaile: then with their
hearts inwardly do they most rejoice. Deceive not thy self in thinking that the
empress thy wife is young, and that she shall find none other Emperor with whom
again she may mary. For such, and the like, will change the cloth of gold,
for gowns of skynnes. I mean, that they woold rather the young shepeheard in
the field: then the old emperor in his royal palace. If thou take sorrow
for the children whom thou leauest, I know not why thou shooldst do so? For
truly if it grieve thee now, for that thou dyest: they are more displeased,
for that thou lyuest. The son that desires not the death of his father, may
be counted the only Phoenix of this world, for if ye father be poor, he
wishes him dead for yt he is not maintained, and if he be rich, he
desires his death to enherit ye sooner. Sins therefore it is true (as in deed
it is) it seems not wisdom that they sing, and thou weep. If it grieve thee
to leave these goodly palaces, and these su^ptuous buildings, deceive not thy
self therein. For by ye god Jupiter I swear unto thee, that since that death
does finish thee, at ye end of.lxii. years: time shall consume these su^ptuous
buildings in less then xl. If it grieve thee to forsake the company of thy
friends, and neighbors, for them also take as little thought, sins for thee they
will not take any at all. For amongst the other compassions yt they ought to
have of the dead, this is true, that scarcely they are buried, but of their
friends and neighbors they are forgotten. If thou take great thought for that
thou will not dye, as the other emperors of Rome are dead: me seems that
thou oughtst also to cast this sorrow from thee. For thou know right well,
that Rome has accustomed to be so unthankful to those wc serve her: yt the
great Scipio also, woold not be buried therein. If it grieve thee to dye, to
leave so great a seignory, as to leave the empire: I can not think that such
vanity be in thy head. For temperat, and reposed men, when they escape from
semblable offices, do not think that they lose honor: but yt they be free, of
a troblesome charge. Therefore if none of al these things move thee to desire
life, what should let thee yt through thy gates enter not death? it greeueth
men to dye for one of these two things, either for the love of those they leave
beehynd them, or for the fear of that they hope. Sins therefore there is
nothing in this life worthy of love, nor any things in death why we shoold
fear: why do me^ fear to dye? According to ye heavy sighs you fetchest, ye
bitter tears thou she dest, and according also to the great pain thou show,
for my part I think: that the thing in thy thought most forgotten was, yt the
gods shoold command thee to pay this debt. For admit yt al think yt their life
shall end, yet no man thinks yt death will come so soon. For that men think
never to dye, they never beeginne their faults to amend: so that both life and
fault have end in the grave togethers. Know not thou (most noble prince) that
after the long night, comes ye moist morning? Do thou not know yt after
the moist morning, there comes yt clear sun? Know not thou, yt after the
clear sun, comes the cloudy element? Do thou not know, yt after the
dark mist, there comes extreme heat? And that after the heat, comes the
horrible thunders? and after the thunders, the sodeyn lightnings? and that
after the perilous lightnings, comes the terrible hayle? Finally I say, that
after the tempesteous and troublesome time, commonly comes clear and fair
weather. The order that time has, to make him self cruel, and gentill: the
self same ought men to have to live and dye. For after the infancy, comes
chyldhod, after chyldhod comes youth, after youth comes age, and after age,
comes ye fearful death: Finally after ye fearful death, comes ye sure
life. Oftentimes I have read, and of thee not seldom hard, yt the gods only
wc had no beginning, shall have also no endyng. Therefore me thinks (most
noble prince) that sage men ought not to desire to live long: For men which
desire to live much, either it is for that they have not felt the travails
past, because they have been fools: or for that they desire more time, to
geeue them selves to vices. Thou might not complayn of that, sins they have
not cut thee in the flower of the herb, nor taken thee green from ye tree, nor
cut in thee in the spring tide, and much less eat the eager, before thou were
ripe. By that I have spoken, I mean, if death had called thee when thy life was
sweetest: though thou had not had reason to have complained, yet thou might
have desired to have altered it. For it is a great grief, to say unto a young
man that he must dye, and forsake the world. What is this (my lord) now that
the wall is decayed ready to fall, the flower is withered, the grape does
rotte, the teeth are loose, the gown is worn, the lance is blunt the knife is
dull, and do thou desire to return into the world, as if thou had never
known the world? These lxii. years thou have lived in ye prison of this body,
and will thou, now ye iron fetters have rot thy legs, desire yet to length
thy days, in this so woeful prison? They yt will not be contented to live lx.
years and five in this death, or to dye in this life: will not desire to dye in
lx. thousand years. The Emperor Augustus octauian said. That after men had
lived.l. years, either of their own will they ought to dye: or else by force
they shoold cause them selves to be killed. For at that time, all those which
have had any humain felicity, are at the best. Those wc live above that age,
pass their days in grievous torments. As in the death of children, in ye loss
of goods, and importunity of son in laws, in mainteining processes, in
discharging debts, in sighing for that is past, in bewailing yt that is
present, in disse^bling injuries, in hearing woeful news, and in other infinite
trauails. So yt it were much better, to have their eyes shut in the grave: then
their hearts and bodies alive, to suffer so much in this miserable life. He
whom the gods take from this miserable life at ye end of 50. years, is quited
from al these miseries of life. For after that time he is not weak, but
crooked, he goes not, but rouleth, he stumbleth not but falls. O my lord
Mark, know thou not, yt by the same way whereby goes death, death comes?
Know not thou in like manner, that it is 52. years that life has fled from
death: and that there is an other time as much, that death goes seeking thy
life? and death going from Illiria where he left a great plague, and thou
departing from thy pallayce ye.ii. now have met in Hungary? know not thou,
that where thou leapedst out of thy mothers intrails to govern the land,
immediately death leaped out of his grave to seek thy life? Thou have always
presumed, not only to be honored: but also to be honorable, if it be so,
since thou honoredst the Imbassadours of Princes which did send them the more
for their profyt, then for thy service, why do thou not honor thy messenger,
whom the gods send more for thy profyt, then for their services? Do thou not
remember well, when Vulcane my son in law poisoned me, more for the
covetousness of my goods, then any desire he had of my life? thou lord did
come to comfort me in my chamber, and toldst me that the gods were cruel to
slay the young: and were pytiful to take the old from this world. And thou
saydst further these words. Comfort thee Panutius: For if thou were born to
dye, now thou die to live. Sins therefore (noble prince) that I tell thee
that which thou toldst me, and counsel thee the same which thou cou^sayledst
me: I render to thee that which thou have geeuen me. Finally, of these vines
I have gathered these clusters of grapes.

The answer of the emperor Marcus to Panutius his secretory, wherein he
declares that he took no thought to forsake the world: but all his sorrow was
to leave beehynd him an unhappy child to enheryt the Empire. Cap. lij.
PAnutius blessed be the milk thou have sucked in Dacia, the bread which thou
have eaten in Rome, the learning which thou have learned in Greece and the
bringing up which thou have had in my palace. For thou have served as a good
servant in life: and geeuest me counsayl as a trusty friend at death. I
command Commodus my son to recompense thy service, and I beseech the
immortal gods, that they acquit thy good counsayls. And not without good cause
I charge my son with ye one, and require the gods of the other. For the
payment of many services, one man alone may do: but to pay one good counsayl,
it is requisyt to have all the gods. The greatest good that a friend can do to
his friend, is in great and wayghty affairs, to geeue him good and wholesome
counsayl. And not without cause I say wholesome. For commonly it chances, that
those which think with their counsayl to remedy us: do put us oftentimes in
greatest perils. All the trauayles of life are hard: but that of death is the
most hard and terrible. Al are great, but this is the greatest. All are
perilous, but this is most perilous. All in death have end except the trauayl
of death, whereof we know no end. That which I say now, no man perfectly can
know: but only he which sees him self, as I see my self now at the point of
death. Certainly Panutius, thou have spoken unto me as a wise man: but for
that thou know not my grief, thou could not cure my disease, for my sore is
not there, where thou have laid the plaster. The fistula is not there where
thou have cut ye flesh. The opilation is not there, where thou have laid the
ointments. There were not the right vayns, where thou dydst let me blood. Thou
have not yet touched the wound, which is the cause of all my grief. I mean that
thou oughtst to have entered further with me, to have known my grief better.
The sighs which the heart fetches (I say those which come from the heart) let
not every man thynk which hears the^, that he can immediately understand them.
For as men can not remedy the anguishes of the spirit: so the gods likewise
woold not that they shoold know the secrets of the heart. Without fear or shame
many dare say, that they know the thought of others, wherein they show them
selves to be more fools, then wise. For since there are many things in me,
wherein I my self doubt: how can a stranger have any certain knowledge
therein? Thou accusest me Panutius, that I fear death greatly, the which I
deny: but to fear it as man, I do confess. For to deny that I fear not
death, shoold be to deny that I am not of flesh. We see by experience, that
the elephants do fear the Lion, the Bear the Elephant, the woolf the Bear,
the lamb the woolf, the ratte the catte, the catte the dog, and the dog the
man: finally the one and the other do fear for no other thing, but for fear
that one kylleth not the other. Then since brute beasts refuse death, the which
though they dye, fear not to fight with the furies, nor hope not to rest with
the gods: so much the more ought we to fear death, which dye in doubt,
whither the furies will tear us in pieces with their torments, or the gods
will receive us into their houses with joy. Think thou Panutius, that I do
not see well that my vine is gathered, and that it is not hyd unto me, that my
palace falls in decay? I know well, that I have not but the kirnel of the
raison, and the skin: and that I have not but one sygh of all my life, until
this time. There was great difference beetweene me and thee: and now there is
great difference beetwixt me and my self. For about the ensign, thou do
place the army. In the ryuers, thou castest thy nets, within the parks, thou
huntest the bulls. In the shadow thou take cold. By this I mean, that thou
talkest so much of death: because that thou art sure of thy life. O miserable
man that I am, for in short space, of all that in this life I have possessed:
with me I shall carry nothing, but only my wynding sheet. Alas now shall I
enter into the field, not where of the fierce beasts I shall be assaulted: but
of the hungry woorms devoured. Alas I see my self in that dystresse, from
whence my frayl flesh cannot escape. And if any hope remayn, it is in thee o
death. When I am sick, I woold not that he that is whole shoold comfort me.
When I am sorrowful, I woold not that he which is merry shoold comfort me.
When I am banished I woold not that he which is in prosperity shoold comfort
me. When I am at the hour of death, I woold not that he shoold comfort me,
which is not in some suspicion of life. But I woold that the poor shoold
comfort me in my poverty, the sorrowful in my sorows, the banyshed in my
banishment, and he which is in as great danger of his life, as I am now at
the point of death. For there is no counsel so healthful, nor true: as that
of the man which is in sorrow, when he counsayleth an other, which is likewise
tormented him self. If thou consyderest well this sentence, thou shall find
that I have spoken a thing very profound, wherein notwithstanding my tongue is
appeased. For in my oppinion evil shall he be comforted, which is weeping
with him, that continually laugheth. I say this to the end thou know, that I
know it: and that thou perceive that I perceive it. And because thou shall not
live deceived, as to my friend I will disclose the secret: and thou shall see,
that small is the sorrow which I have, in respect of the great, which I have
cause to have. For if reason had not stryued with sensuality, the sighs had
ended my life, and in a pond of tears, they had made my grave. The things
which in me thou have seen, which are to abhor meat, to banysh sleep, to
love care, to be annoyed with company, to take rest in sighs, and to take
pleasure in tears: may easily declare unto thee, what torment is in the sea of
my heart, when such tremblings do appear in ye earth of my body. Let us now
come to the purpose, and we shall see, why my body is without consolation, and
my heart so overcome with sorows: for my feelyng, greatly exceeds my
complaynyng, because the body is so delycat, that in scratchyng it, it
complayneth: and the heart is so stout and valiant, that though it be hurt,
yet it dyssembleth. O Panutius, I let thee weete, that the occasion why I take
death so grievously, is because I leave my son Commodus in this life: who
lives in this age most perilous for him, and no less dangerous for the
Empire. By the flowers are the fruits known, by the grapes the vines are
known, and by the face men are known: by the colt the horse is judged, and by
the infant, youth is known.

This I say by the Prince my son, for that he has been evil in my life, I
do ymagyn that he will be worse after my death. Since thou (as well as I)
know the evil conditions of my son, why do thou marvel at the thoughts
and sorows of the father? My son Commodus in years is young, and in
understanding younger. He has an evil inclynation, and yet he will not
enforce him self against the same, he governs him self by his own sense, and
in matters of wisdom he knows little: of that he shoold be ignorant, he
knows too much: and that which is woorst of all, he is of no man esteemed.
He knows nothing of things past, nor occupyeth him about any thing present.
Finally, for that which with mine eyes I have seen, I say, and that which with
in my heart I have suspected I judge: that shortly the person of my son
shallbee in hazard, and the memory of his father perysh. O how unkindly have
the Gods used them selves toward us, to command us to leave our honor in the
hands of our children? for it shoold suffice, that we shoold leave them our
goods: and that to our friends we shoold commyt our honor. But yet I am sorry,
for that they consume the goods in vices: and lose the honor, for to be
vicious. The gods being pityful as they are, since they geeue us the authoryty
to deuyde our goods: why do they not geeue us leave, to make our wills of the
honor? My sons name being Commodus, in the Romayn tongue, is as much to say,
as profyt: but as he is, we will be content to be without the little profyt,
which he may do to some, so that we may be excused of the great damage,
which he is lykely to do to all. For I suppose he will be the scourge of
men, and the wrath of Gods. He enters now into the pathway of youth, alone
without a guide. And for that he has to pass, by the high and dangerous
places: I fear lest he be lost, in the wood of vices. For the children of
Princes, and great Lords, for so much as they are brought up in lyberty, and
wantonness, do easily fall into vices, and voluptuousnes: and are most stubborn
to be wythdrawen from their folly. O Panutius, give attentive ear to that I
say unto thee. See thou not, that Commodus my son is at lyberty, is rych,
is young, and is alone? By the faith of a good man, I swear unto thee, that the
least of these wynds woold overthrow, not only a young tender ash: but also a
mighty strong oak. Riches, youth, pride, and lyberty, are four plagues which
poison the prince, replenysh the common wealth with filth, kill, the living,
and defame the dead. Let the old men beeleeue me, and the young men mark well
what I say, that where ye gods have geeuen many gyfts: it is necessary they
have many virtues to susteyn them. The gentle, the peaceable the cou^terfait,
the simple, and the fearful, do not trouble the common wealth: but those who^
nature has geeuen most gyfts. For as experience teaches us, with the fairest
weomen the stews are furnyshed, the most proper personages are unshamefast, the
most stout and valiant are murderers, the most subtle are thieves, and men of
clearest understanding, often times beecome most fools. I say and say again. I
affirm, and affirm again, I swear, and swear again, that if two men which are
adorned with natural gyfts, do want requisyt virtues: such have a knife in
their hands, wherewith they do strike and wound them selves, a fire on their
shoulders wherewith they burn them selves, a rope at their necks to hang them
selves, a dagger at their breast wherewyth they kill them selves, a thorn in
their foot wherewith they prick them selves, and stones whereat they stumble:
so that stumbling they fall, and falling they find them selves with death whom
they hate, and without life which so much they loved. Note well Panutius, note,
that the man which from his infancy has always the fear of the gods before
his eyes, and the shame of men, says troth to all, and lives in prejudice
to none: and to such a tree, though evil fortune do cleave, the flower of his
youth do wither, the leaves of their favors dry, they gather the fruits of
his travails, they cut the bough of his offices, they bow the highest of his
branches downwards, yet in the end, though of the winds he be beaten, he
shall never be overcome, O happy are those fathers, to whom the Gods have
geeuen quick children, wise, fair, able, light, and valiant: but all these
gifts are but means to make them vicious. And in such case, if the fathers
woold be governed by my counsayl, I woold rather desire that members shoold
want in them: then that vices shoold abound. Of the most fairest children which
are born in the Empire, my son Commodus the Prince is one. But I woold to the
immortal gods, that in face he resemble ye blackest of Ethiope: and in manners,
the greatest philosopher of Greece. For the glory of the father is not, nor
ought not to be, in that his child is fair of complexion, and handsome of
person: but that in his life he be very vpryght. We will not call him a
pytifull father, but a great enemy, who exalts forth his child, for that
he is fair: and does not correct him, though he be vicious. I durst say,
that the father which has a child endued with many goodly gyfts, and that he
does employ them all to vices: such a child ought not to be born in ye world,
and if perchance he were born, he ought immediately to be buried.

The Emperor Marcus Aurelius concludes his matter, and shows that sundry
young princes for being vicious, have undone them selves, and impoueryshed
their Realms. Cap. liij.
O What great pyty is it, to see how the father buyeth his child of ye gods
with sighs, how the mother deliver them with pain, how they both nourish them
with travails, how they watch to susteyn them, how they labor to remedy them,
and afterward they have so rebelled, and be so vicious that the miserable
fathers oftentimes do dye not for age, but for the greeues wherewith their
children torment the^. I do remember, yt the prince Co^modus my son being
young, and I aged (as I am) with great payns we kept him from vices: but I fear,
yt after my death he will hate virtues. I remember many young princes, wc of his
age have enherited the^pire of Rome, who have been of so wicked a life: that
they have deserved to lose both honor, and life. I remember Dennis the famous
tyrant of Scicil, of whom is said, that as great reward he gave to those
that invented vices: as our mother Rome did to those wc conquered realms. Such
woork could not be but of a Tyrant, to take them for most famyliar, which are
most vicious. I remember four young princes, which governed the empire, but not
with such valyauntnes, as the great Alexander: that is to weete, Alexander,
Antiochus, Siluius, and Ptholomeus, to whom for their vanyty and lightness, as
they called Alexander the great, Emperor in Greece: so likewise do they call
these young men, tiraunts in Asia. Very happy was Alexander in life, and they
unhappy after his death. For all that which with glorious triumphs he wanne,
with vile vices they lost. So that Alexander divided between them four the
world, and afterward it came into the hands of mo then four hundredth. I do
remember, that king Antigonus little exteemed that, which cost his lord
Alexander much. He was so light in the beehauior of his person, and so defamed
in the affairs of the common wealth: that for mockry and contempt, in the
steed of a crown of gold, he bare a garland, in the steed of a scepter, he
carried neitels in his hand, and of this sort and manner he sat to judge among
his counsailours, and used to talk with strangers. This young prince does
offend me much, for ye lightness he committed: but much more I marueyl at the
gravity of the sages of Greece, wc suffered him. It is but meet he be
partaker of the pain, which condescended to the fault. I do remember
Calligulus the fowerth Emperor of Rome, who was so young and foolysh, that I
doubt of these two things, which was greatest in his time. That is to weete,
the dysobedyence which the people bear to their lord: or the hate which the
lord bear to his people. For that unhappy creature was so dysordered in his
manners, that if all the Romans had not watched to take life from him: he
woold have watched to take life from them. This Caligula ware a brooche of gold
in his cap, where in were written these words. Vtinam omnis populus vnam
precise ceruicem haberet, vt vno ictu omnes necarem. Which is to say: woold to
god all the people had but one neck, to the end I might kill them all at a
stroke. I remember the Emperor Tiberius, thadoptiue son of the good Caesar
Augustus, which was called Augustus, because he greatly augmented the empire.
But the good Emperor did not so much augment the state of his common wealth,
during his life: as Tiberius did dymynish it, after his death. The hate and
mallyce which the Romayn people bare to Tiberius in his life, was manyfestly
dyscouered after the time of his death. For the day that Tiberius dyed (or
better to say, when they killed him) the Romayn people made great processyons,
and the Senators offered great presents to the Temples, and the priests gave
great sacrifyces to their Gods: and all to ye end their Gods shoold not receive
the soul of this tiraunt amongst them, but that they woold send it to be kept
among the furies of hell. I remember Patrocles (second king of Corinthe)
inheryted the realm at two and twenty years of his age, who was so dysordered
of his flesh, so vndyscreete in his doings, so covetous of goods, and such a
coward of his person, that where his father had possessed the realm forty
years, the son did not possess it thyrty months. I remember Tarquine the
proud, who though among eight knyghts of Rome was the last, and comlyest of
gesture, valiant in arms, noblest of blood, and in geeuyng most lyberall: yet
he employed all his gyfts and graces which the Gods had geeuen him, evil. For
he employed his bewty to riot, and his forces to tyranny. For through the
treason, and vyllany, which he committed with the Romayn Lucretia, he did not
only lose the realm, and flying saved his life: but also for ever was
banyshed, and all his lynage likewise. I remember the cruel emperor Nero, who
lived, enherited, and dyed young: and not without a cause I say, that he lived,
and dyed young. For in him was graffed the stock of the noble and worthy Cesars:
and in him was renewed, the memory of those Tyraunts. To whom think thou
Panutius, this tiraunt woold have geeuen life, since he with his own hands
gave his mother her death? Tell me I pray thee, who think thou has made
