that cursed heart, who slew his mother, out of whose womb he came? opened her
breasts, which gave him suck? shed the blood, whereof he was born? tore the
arms in wc he was carried? and saw the intrails, wherein he was formed? The
day yt the emperor Nero slew his mother, an orator said in ye senate.

Iure interficienda erat Agrippina que tale portentum peperit in populo romano.
Which is to say, justly deserved Agrippina to be put to death, which brought
forth so strange a monster amongst the Romayn people.

Thou oughtst not therefore to marueil (Panutius) at the novelties which thou
have seen in me: for in these three days that I have been troubled in my
mind, and altered in my understanding, all these things are offered unto me,
and from the botom of my heart I have digested them. For the careful men are
not blinded, but with their own ymaginacions. All these evil conditions which
these Princes had scattered amongst them (of whom I have spoken) do meet
togethers in my son Commodus.

For if they were young, he is young. If they were rych, he is rych. If they
were free, he is free. If they were bold, he is bold. If they were wild, he
is wild. If they were evil, certainly I do not think that he is good. For
we see many young princes, which have been well brought up, and well taught:
yet when they have inherited, and come to their lands, they beecome immediately
vicious, and dissolute. What hope have we of those, which from their infancy
are dissolute and evil inclined? of good wine, I have made often times strong
vinegar: but of pure vinegar, I have never seen good wine. This child keeps
me, beetwene the sails of fear, and the anchor of hope: hopyng he shall be
good, since I have taught him well, and fearing he shallbee evil, because his
mother Faustine has norished him evil. And that which is the woorst, yt the
young child of his own nature is inclined to al evil. I am moved to say this
much, for that I see his natural inclinacion increase: and that which was
taught him dimynish, for the which occasyon, I doubt that after my death, my
son shall return to that, wherein his mother has norished him: and not to
that, wherein I have taught him. O how happy had I been, if never I had had
child, for not to be bound to leave him thempire: for I woold chose then,
among the children of the good fathers: and woold not be bound to such a one,
whom the gods have geeuen me. One thing I ask thee Panutius, whom wooldst thou
call most fortunat? Vespasian, wc was natural father of Domitius, or Nerua, the
adopted father of the good Traiane? both those two ( Vespasian, and Nerua) were
good princes, but of children. Domitian was ye head of al mischief: and Traiane
was the mirror of al goodness. So yt Vespasian in that he had children, was
unhappy: and Nerua in that he had none, was most fortunat. One thing I will tell
thee Panutius, the which by thee considered, thou wylt little esteem life, and
shall lose the fear of death. I have lived lxii. years, wherein I have read
much, hard much, seen, desired, attained, possessed, suffered and I have much
reioysed my self. And in the end of all this, I see my self now to dye, and I
must want my pleasures, and my self also. Of all that I have had, possessed,
attained, and whereof I have enjoyed, I have only two things: to weete, pain
for that I have offended the gods, and sorrow for the time which I have wasted
in vices. There is great difference beetweene the rych and the poor in death,
and more in life. For the poor dies to rest, but if the rich dye it is to
their great pain. So that the gods take from the one, that which he had: and
puts the other in possession, of that he desired. Great care has the heart
to seek the goods, and they pass great troubles to heap up them togethers,
and great diligence must be had in keeping them, and also much wit to increase
them: but without comparison, it is greater grief to depart from them. O what
pain intolerable and grief it is to the wise man, seeing him self at the point
of death, to leave the swet of his famyly, the majesty of his empire, the honor
of his present, the love of his friends, the payment of his debts, the deserts
of his servant, and the memory of his predecessors, in the power of so evil
a child, the which neither deserves it, nor yet will deserve it. In their table
of our ancient laws, were written these words. We ordeyn and command, that
the father which shall be good according to the oppinion of all, may disheryt
his son, who according to the opinion of all is evil. The law said further.
The child which has dysobeyed his father, robbed any holy Temple, iniuryed any
wyddow, fled from any battle, and committed any treason to a stranger, that
he shoold be banished from Rome, and dysenherited from his fathers goods.
Truly the law was good, though by our offenses it be forgotten. If my breath
failed me not as it does fail me (for of troth I am greatly payned) I
woold declare unto thee how many Parthes, Medians, Egiptians, Assirians,
Caldeans, Indians, Hebrews, Greeks, and Romans, have left their children
poor being able to have left them rych, for no other cause, but for that they
were vicious. And to the contrary, other being poor, have left them rych, for
that they were virtuous. By the immortal Gods I swear unto thee, that when
they came from the war of Parthia, and triumphed in Rome, and confirmed the
Empire to my son, if then these not not had not withstoode me, I had left
Commodus my son poor with his vices: and woold have made heir of all my
realms, some virtuous man. I let thee to weete Panutius, that five things
oppress my heart sore, to the which I woold rather see remedy my self, then to
command other to remedy it.

The first, for that in my life time I can not determyn the process, that the
virtuous wydow, Drusia has with the senate. Because since she is poor, and
deformed, there is no man that will geeue her justice. The second, because I
dye not in Rome. And this for none other cause, then that with the sound of the
trumpet shoold be proclaimed, that all those which have any quarrel, or debt
against me, and my famyly, should come thither to be paid, or satisfied of
their debts, and demands. The third, that as I made four tyraunts to be put
to execucion, which committed tyranny in Asia and Italy: so it grieved me that
I have not also punished certain Pirates, which roued on the seas. The fowerth,
for that I have not caused the Temple to be fynished which I did beegynne for
all the gods. For I might have said unto them after my death, that since for
all them I have made one house: it were not much that any of them shoold
receive one into his, which pass this life in the favor of gods, and without
the hatred of men. For dying after this sort, men shall susteyn our honors: and
the gods shall provide for our souls.

The fyfth, for that I leave in life for my only heir, Commodus the prince,
yet not so much for the destruction which shall come to my house: as for the
great damage which shall succeed in the common wealth. For the true princes
ought to take the domages of their persons light, and the domages of the common
wealth for the most grievous. O Panutius, let therefore this be the last word
which I will say unto thee, that is to weete, that the greatest good that the
Gods may geeue to the man that is not covetous, but virtuous, is to geeue him
good renown in life: and afterward a good heir at our death. Finally I say,
that if I have anything to do with the gods, I require, and beeseech them,
that if they should be offended, Rome slaundered, my renown defamed, and my
house demynished, for that my son be of an evil life: that they will take
from him life, before they geeue me death.

Of the words which the Emperor Marcus Aurelius spoke unto his son Commodus
at the hour of death, necessary for all young gentlemen to understand. Cap.
liiij.
SInce the disease of Marcus Aurelius was so extreme, that in every hour of
his life he was assaulted with death: after he had talked a long time with
Panutius his secretary, he commanded his son Commodus to be wakened, who as
a young man slept soundly in his bed. And being come before his presence, al
those which were there, were moved immediately with compassion, to see the eyes
of the father all swollen with weeping: and the eyes of the child, closed with
overmuch sleep. They could not waken the child, he was so careless: and they
could not cause the goodfather sleep, he took so great thought. All those
which were there, seeing how the father desired the good life of the son, and
how little the son wayed the death of his father: had compassion of the old
man, and bare hate to the wicked child. Then the good Emperor casting his
eyes on high, and directing his words to his son said. When thou were a
child, I told thy masters how they ought to bring thee up: and after that
thou dydst wax greater, I told thy governors how they shoold counsel thee:
And now will I tell thee, how thou with them which are few, and they with thee,
being one, ought to govern and maintayn the common wealth. If thou esteem
much that which I will say unto thee my son: know thou, that I will esteem it
much more that thou wilt beeleue me. For more easily do we old men, suffer
your iniuryes: then ye other young, do receive our counsels. Wisdom
wants to you for to beeleeue us, yet ye want not boldness to dishonor us.
And that which is woorst, the aged (in Rome) were wont to have a chayr of
wisdom, and sagenes: but now a days the young men count it a shame and folly.
The world at this day is so changed, from that it was wont to be in times
past: that all have the audacity to geeue counsel, and few have the wisdom
to receive it, so that they are a thowsaund, which sell counsels: and there
is not one, yt buyeth wisdom. I believe well my son, yt according to my fatal
destinies, and thy evil manners, little shall yt avail which I shall tell thee.
For since thou wooldst not credyt these words, which I spoke unto thee in my
life: I am sure that thou will little regard them after my death. But I do this
more to satisfy my desire, and to accomplish that which I owe unto the common
wealth: than for that I hope for any amendment of thy life. For there is no
grief that so much hurts a person, as when he him self is cause of his own
pain. If any man does me an injury, if I lay my hands upon him, or speak
injurious words unto him, my heart is forthwith satisfied: but if I do injury
to my self, I am he wc wrongeth, and am wro^ged, for that I have none on whom
I may revenge my wrong, and I vex and chafe with my self. If thou my son be
evil, after yt thou have enheryted the empire: my mother Rome will complain of
ye gods, which have geeuen thee so many evil inclinacions. She will co^playn of
Faustine thy mother which has brought thee up so wantonly, she will complayn
of thee wc have no will to resist vice: but she shall have no cause to
complayn of the old man thy father, who has not geeuen thee good counsels.
For if thou had beeleeued that, which I told thee: men woold rejoice to have
thee for their lord, and the gods to use thee as their minister. I cannot tell
my son if I be deceived, but I see thee so deprived of understanding, so
uncertain in thy words, so dissolute in thy manners, so unjust in justice, in
that thou desire so hardy, and in thy duty so negligent: that if thou change
and alter not thy manners, men will hate thee, and the gods will forsake thee. O
if thou knewst my son what thing it is to have men for enemies, and to be
forsaken of the gods, by the faith of a good man I swear unto thee, that thou
wooldst not only hate the seignory of Rome, but with thy hands also thou
wooldst destroy thy self. For men which have not the gods merciful, and the
men friendly, do eat the bread of grief, and drink ye tears of sorrow. I am sure
thy sorrow is not so great to see that the night does end my life: as is the
pleasure which thou have, to see that in short space thou shall be emperor of
Rome. And I do not marvel hereat. For where sensuality reigns, reason is
banished and constrained to fly. Many love diverse things, because of troth
they know them not: the which if they did know, without doubt they woold hate
them. Though men love in mockry, the gods and men hate us in earnest. In all
things we are so doubtful, and in all our woorks so dysordered, that at some
time our understanding is dull, and loses the edge: and an other time, it is
more sharp then it is necessary. Thereby I mean, that the good we will not
here, and much less we will learn it, but of the evil we know, more then
beehoueth us, or necessity requires. I will counsel thee my son by words,
that which in lxii. years I have learned by science and experience. And since
thou art as yet so young, it is reason that thou believe him which is aged. For
since we princes are the mirror of all, every man does beehold us, and we
other do not beehold ourselves. This day, or to morrow, thou shall enherit ye
Romain empire, and think that inheriting the same, thou shall be lord of the
world. Yet if thou knewst how many cares and perilles, commanding brings
with it, I swear unto thee, that thou wooldst rather chose to obey all, then
to command one. Thou think my son, that I leave thee a great lord, for to
leave thee the empire, which is not so. For all they have need but of thee,
and thou alone have need of all. Thou think that I leave thee much
treasure, leaving thee the great reuenews of the empire, the which also is as
little. For though a prince have treasures in abundance, yet if he want
friends, he has great want of tresures. Thou think also my son, that I
leave thee that thou be obeyed of all, and that none dare gayn say thee.

Truly it ought not to be so. For it is more meet for the prince (which
desires to preserve his life, and augment his honor) to be conformable to the
will of all: then to desire that all shoold be agreeable to him. For thou my
son, that know not what truth is, lies will not grieve thee. For as much as
thou know not what rest is, the broyls and mocions of the people shall not
vex thee. For that thou know not what friends mean, thou shall esteem it
little to have enemies. For if thou were pacient, reposed, true, and a loving
man: thou would not only refuse ye empire of Rome, but also ye wooldst curse
the father which woold leave thee such inheritance. I will thou know if thou
know it not, that in leaving thee the empire, I leave thee not riches, but
poverty: not rest, but travail: not peace, but war: not friends, but enemies:
not pleasures but displeasures: finally in place I leave thee, where always
thou shall have somewhat to beewayle. And though thou would, thou shall not
laugh. I advertise, admonish, and also exhort thee my son, to think that all
that which I leave thee, is vanity, lightness, and folly, and a disgised mockry.
And if thou beeleuest it is in mockry, from hensforth I know thou art deceived.
I have lived longer then thou, I have read more than thou, and with great pain
have gone further than thou. And sins that with all these aduertisements, in
the end I find my self mocked: hopest thou to live surely, and escape without
fraud or guyle? When thou shall think to have the empire in rest, then shall
there arise a province in Africa, or in Asia, the loss of the which should
come to a great inconvenience: and for to recover it, great charges would
ensue. When thou think to recover friends, then shall strange enemies invade
thee. So that in flattering, and rejoicing our friends, we can not keep them:
and in flying, and rejecting them, we can not defend our selves. When thou
shall think to be in gretest joy, then shall some care oppress thy heart. For
princes which have, and possess much the news which geeue them pleasure, are
very seldom: but the things which annoy them, come hourly. When thou shall
think to have liberty, to do what thou will: then shall thou be most
restrained.

For the good and well ordered princes, ought not to go whither their wanton
desires moves them: but where it is most lawful, and decent for the honor of
their estates. When thou shall think that none dare reprove thee, for that thou
art emperor, then oughtst ye most to beeware. For if they dare not threaten
evil princes with words, they have the hardines to sell them by treason. If
they dare not punish them, they dare murmour at them: and these which can not
be their friends, do procure to be their enemies: finally, if they lay not
hands on their persons, they let their tongue run at large to prate of their
renoune. When thou shall thynk to have satisfied thy servants, then will they
demand recompense for their services. For it is an old custom among
courtyers, to spend freely, and covet greedily. Therefore if thou do credit
these things, I know not who is so foolish, that for his enherytaunce desires
such sorrow. For admit that any man come to the empire, without comparison the
rest is more worth, which ye empire takes from him: then the pleasures which
it geeueth him? If the empire of Rome were as well corrected and ordered, as in
old time it was accustomed to be: though it were great pain to govern it,
yet it were more honor to keep it, but it is so rooted in vices, and so many
tira^ts are entered therein, that I woold tak the^ more wise to judge it a
mockry, then those which embrase it as an honor. If thou knewst what Rome is
worth, what Rome has, what Rome may, and what Rome is, I swear unto thee,
that thou would not labor much to be lord thereof. For though Rome with walls
be strongly compassed: yet of virtuous Citezins it is greatly unprovided. If
the inhabitants be great, the vices are without number. Finally I say, that ye
stones which are in the buyldings, in one day may be counted: but the evils
which are therein, in a.1000. years can not be declared. By the faith of a good
man I swear unto thee, my son, that when I beegan to reygne, in 3. years I
repaired the decayed walls that were of Rome fallen: and one only street to
live well, in xx. yers I could not refourme. The divine Plato said very well:
That much more ought the great cities to glorify, to have virtuous citezins:
then to have proud and sumptuous buildings. Beeware, beeware my son, that the
inconstancy of youth, and the liberty which you have to possess, and govern
the empire, cause thee not to undo thy self. For he is not counted free, with
in liberty is borne: but he that dies in liberty. O of how many I have red,
hard, and also seen which are borne slaves, and afterward have dyed free: and
this for that they were virtuous. And how many I have seen die slaves, being
bornfree only for being vicious: so that there liberty remains, where
noblenes is resident. Princes which have great realms, of necessity shall have
occasions to punish many excesses: wherefore it is requisite, that they be
courageous. And beeleue me my son, yt they ought not to take corrage upon
them, because they be mighty, and puissaunt: but because they are virtuous.
For to punish these excesses of others, ye good life is more requisite: then is
the great auctority of the empire. A virtuous prince ought to leave no vice
unpunished, for the good, to follow good, and the evil for fear of his
correction, dare not commit any offense in the common wealth. He that lives
like a wise man, is hardy to geeue punishment: but he that lives in fear,
dare not almost speak. For the man which dare be so hardy to punish an other,
for the self same fault for the which he deserves to be punished: of the
gods he is justly hated, and of men despised. Let princes take it for an
assured thing, that they shall never have the love of the people, the liberty of
the common wealth, the order of their house, the contentation of their friends,
the subjection of their enemies, and ye obedience of their people: but with
many tears shed on the earth, and with many prowesses done of his person. To a
virtuous prince, all do render: and against the vicious prince, all the earth
does rebel. If thou will be virtuous hear what thing virtue is. Virtue is a
castle which never is taken, a river wc is not passed over, a sea which is not
sailed, a fire that never is quenched, a tresure that never is wasted, an army
yt never is overthrown, a change which never wearieth, a spy wc always
returns, a sign which beegilesh no man, a way very straight, a friend that
succoureth al necessities, a surgion that immediately heals, and a renown
which never perishes. If thou knew, my son, what thing it is to be good,
thou would be the best of the world. For the more vicious a man is, so much
the more he is entangled in vices: and how much more a man is virtuous, so
much more to virtues he cleaves. If thou will be virtuous, thou shall do
service to the gods, thou shall geeue good renown to thy predecessors, and for
thy self thou shall prepare a perpetual memory. Thou shall do pleasures to
strangers, and get ye favor of thine own people. Finally, ye good will honor
thee with love: and the evil will serve thee with fear. In the histories of the
wars of the Charentines, I found ye renowned Pirrus (king of Epirotes) did
wear in a ring these words written. It is too little punishment for a vicious
man, to take his life from him: and it is too small a reward for a virtuous man,
to geeue him the seignory of the whole earth. Truly these words were worthy
of such a man. What thing can be beegon of a virtuous man, whereof we hope not
to see the end, and come to good proof? I am deceived, if I have not seen in
my days many me^, which were base borne, unfit for sciences, void of vices in
ye common wealth, poor of goods and unknown of birth, wc with all these base
conditions have learned so many virtues, that it seemed great rashness to beegin
them: and afterward for being virtuous only, they have found the effects such
as they thought it. By the immortal gods I swear unto thee, and so the god
Jupiter take me into his holy house and confirm thee my son in mine: if I
have not known a gardner and a potter in Rome, which for being virtuous, were
occasion to cast five rich senators out of the senate. And ye cause to make
the one to gain, and the other to loose, was that to ye one they would not pay
ye pots, and to ye other his appels For at that time more was he punished, wc
took an apple from a poor man, then he wc bet down a rich man's house. All
this I have told thee my son, because vice abaseth the hardy prince: and
virtue geeueth courage to the bashful. From.ii. things I have always kept my
self. That is to weete, not to strive against open justice, nor to contend
with a virtuous person.

The Emperor Marcus Aurelius follows his purpose, and among other wholesome
counsels exhorts his son to keep wise and sage men about him, for to
geeue him counsel in all his affairs. Cap. lv.
HItherto I have spoken to thee in generally, but now I will speak unto the
particulerly, and by the immortal gods I conjure thee, that thou be very
attentive to that I will say: For talking to thee as an aged father it is
reason thou hear me as an obedient child. If thou will enjoy long life,
observe well my doctrine: For the gods will not condescend to thy hearts
desires, oneles thou receyuest my wholesome counsayles. The disobedience and
unfaithfulness, wc children have to their fathers, is al their undoing. For
oftentimes the gods do pardon the offenses, that are done unto them: and do
not pardon the disobediences wc the children bear to their fathers. I do not
require thee my son: that thou geeue me money, sins thou art poor. I do not
demand that thou travail, sins thou art tender. I do not demand ye
reuengement of mine enemies, since I have none. I do not demand that thou
serve me, sins I dye. I do not demand the empire, sins I leave it unto thee.
Only I do demand, that thou govern thy self well in the common wealth: and
that the memory of my house be not lost through thee. If thou esteem much
that I leave unto thee so many realms, I think it better to leave thee many
good counsayls, wherewith thou may preserve thy selue, sustain thy parson,
and maintain thine honor. For if thou have presumption not to profit with my
counsel, but to trust to thine own mind: before my flesh be eaten with
worms, thou shall be ouerco^e with thy enemies. My son, I have been young,
light, bold, unshamefast, proud envious, covetous an aduoulterer, furious, a
glutton, slouthful, and ambicious, and for that I have fallen into so great
excesses, therefore I geeue thee such good advise. For the man wc in his youth
has been very worldly, from him in age proceeds ripe counsel. That wc
until this time I have cou^sailed thee and that which to my death I will
counsel the. I desire that ons at the least you prove it: And if it do thee
harm, leave it, and if it do thee good, use it. For there is no medecin so
bitter, that the sick does refuse to take: if there by he think he may be
healed. I pray thee, I exhort thee, and I advise thee my son, that thy youth
beeleue mine age, thy ignorancy beeleue my knowledge, thy sleep beeleue my
watch, the dimnes of thy eyes, beeleue the clearnes of my sight, thy
imaginacio^ beeleue my virtue, and thy suspicion beeleue my experience. For
otherwise, one day thou shall see thy self in so^e distress, where small time
you shall have to repent, and none to find remedy. Thou may say unto me (my
son) that sins I have been young, I let thee to be young: and that when thou
shall be aged, thou will amend: I answer thee, that if thou will live as young:
yet at the least govern thy self as old. In a prince which governs his
common wealth well, mani myseries are dissembled of his parson. Even as for
mighty affairs, ripe cou^sayles are necessary: so to endure the troubles of
the empire, the person needs some recreacion. For the bow string wc always
is stretched, either it lengthneth, or it breaks. Whether princes be young or
old, there can be nothing more just then for the recreacio^ of them selves, to
seek some honest pastimes. And not without a cause I say that they be honest.
For sometimes they accompany with so dishonest persons, and so unthrifty: that:
they spend their goods, they loose their honor, and weary their persons more,
than if they were occupied in the affairs of the common wealth. For thy youth,
I leave thee children of great lords, with whom thou may past the time away.
And not without cause I have provided that with thee they have been brought up
from thy infancy. For after thou came to man's estate, enheriting my goods,
if perchance thou wooldst accompany thy self with young men, thou should find
them well learned. For thy wars, I leave thee valiant captains, though
(indeed) things of war are beegoon by wisdom: yet in the end, the issue
faleth out by fortune. For stuards of thy treasures, I leave thee faithful men.
And not without cause, I say they are faithful. For oftentimes greater are the
thieves wc are receyuers, and tresorers, then are they that do rob among the
people. I leave thee (my son) expert and ancient men, of whom thou may
take counsel, and with whom ye may co^municat thy trobles. For there can be
fourmed no honest thing in a prince, unless he has in his company ancient
men: for such geeue gravity to his parso^ and auctority to his palace. To
inue^t theaters, to fish ponds: to chase wild beasts in ye forests, to run
in ye fyelds, to let thy hawks fly, and to exercise weapons, al these things
we can deny thee, as to a young man, and ye being young, may rejoice thy self
in all these. Thou oughtst also to have respect, yt to ordeine armies, inue^t
wars, follow victories, accept truces, co^firm peace raise brutes, to make
laws, to promote ye one, and put down the others, to punish the evil, and
first to reward the good, the counsel of al these things ought to be taken,
of clear judgments, of persons of experience, and of white heads. Think
thou not, that it is possible to pass ye time with the young, and to counsel
with the old? The wise and discreet princes, for all things have time enough,
if they know well how to measure it. Be ware my son, that they note thee not
to use great extremities. For the end and occasion why I speak it, is because
thou should know (if thou know not) that it is as indecent a thing for a
prince, under the color of gravity, to be ruled and governed wholly by old
men: as under semblaunce of pastime, always to accompany him self with the
young. It is no general rule, that all young men are light, nor all old men sage.
And thou must according to my advise, in such case use it thus: if any old man
lose the gravity of his age, expulse him from the: if yt find any young men
sage, despise not their counsel. For the bees do draw more honey out of the
tender flowers: then of ye hard leaves. I do not condemn the aged, nor I do
commend the young, but it shall be well done, that always thou choose of both
the most virtuous. For of troth, there is no company in the world so evil
ordered, but yt there is mean to live with it, without any suspicion: so that
if the young are evil with folly, ye old are worse through covetousness. Ons
again I return to advertise thee (my son) that in no wise thou use
extremity. For if thou beeleeue none but young, they will corrupt thy manners
with lightness: and if you beeleeue none but ye old, they will deprave thy
justice through covetousness. What thing can be more monstrous, then yt the
prince which commands all, should suffer him to be commanded of one alone?
Beeleeue me son in this case, yt the governments of many, are seldom times
governed well by the head of one alone. The prince which has to rule and
govern many, ought to take the advice and counsel of many. It is a great
inconvenience, that thou being lord of many realms, should have but one
gate, wherein all do enter into, to do their business with thee. For if
perchance he which shall be thy familiar, be of his own nature good, and
be not mine enemy: yet I would be afraid of him, because he is a friend of
mine enemies. And though for hate they do me no evil: yet I am afraid yt for
ye love of an other, he will cease to do me good. I remember that in the
annalles of Pompeius, I found a little book of memoryes, wc the great Pompeius
bare about him, wherein were many things that he had read, and other good
counsayles, wc in diverse parts of the world he had learned: and among other
words, there were these. The governor of the common wealth, wc commits all the government to old men, deserves very little: and he that trusts al young,
is light. He that governs it by him self alone, is beeyonde him self: and
he wc by him self and others do govern it, is a wise prince. I know not
whither these sentences are of the same Pompeius, or that he gathered them out
of soome book, or that any philosopher had told him them, or some friend of
his had geeuen him them. I mean, that I had them written with his hands and
truly they deserved to be written in letters of gold. When thy affairs shall
be weighty, see thou dispatche them always by counsel. For when the
affairs be determined by the counsel of many, the fault shall be divided
among them all. Thou shall find it for a truth (my son) that if thou take
counsel of many, the one will tell the inconvenience, the other the peril,
other the fear the other the damage, the other the profit, and the other the
remedy, finally, they will so debate thy affairs, that plainly thou shall know
ye good and see the danger thereof. I advertise thee (my son) that when thou
takst counsel, you beehold with thy eyes ye inconvenience, as well as ye remedies
wc they shall offer unto thee. For ye true counsel consists not, to tell what
they ought to do, but to declare what thereof is like to succeed. When yt
shall enter prise (my son) great and weighty affairs, as much oughtst you to
regard ye little damages for to cut the^ of in time: as ye great mishaps, to
remedy them. For oftentimes it chances, that for the negligence of taking up
a gutter, ye whole house falls to the ground. Notwithstanding I tell thee
thou take counsayl. I mean not, that thou oughtst to be so curious, as for
every trifle to call thy counsel. For there are many things of such quality,
yt they would be immediately put in execution: and they do endomage
themselves, attending for counsel. That which by thine own aucthority thou
may dispatch with out the damage of the common wealth, refer it to no other
person: and here in thou shall be just, and shall do justice confourmable.
For considering that thy service depends only of them, the reward which they
ought to have, ought to depend only on thee. I remember, that when Marius ye
Co^sul came from the wars of Numidia, he divided all the treasour he
brought amongst his souldyers, not putting one jewel into the common treasour.
And when here of he was accused, for that he had not demanded license of
the senate: he answered them. It is not just I take counsel with others, for
to geeue recompense to those: which have not taken ye opinions of others, to
serve me. Thou shall find (my son) a kind of me^, which are very hard of
money, and exceeding prodigal of counsel. There are also diverse lenders,
which without demau^ding them, do offer to give it. With such like men, thou
shall have this counsel, never look thou for good counsel at that man,
whose counsel tends to the prejudice of another. For he offreth words to
thy service, and trauaileth thy business to his own profyt. As ye gods gave me
long life, of these things have I had great experience, wherein I let thee know,
that for the space of.xv years I was consul, Senator, Censor, Praetor,
Questor, Edil, and Tribune: and after all this, I have been.18. years emperor
of Rome, wherein al those wc have spoken most against me, touched the profit or
damage of another. The chief intencion of those wc follow the courts of Princes
are to procure to augment their houses. And if they cannot com to that, they
seek to dimynish ye of another, not for that any profit should follow unto them
thereof, be it never so little: but because man's malice is of such condition,
that it esteems the profit of another, his own damage. They ought to have
great compassion of the Prince, for the most that follow him, serve him not for
that they love him but for the gyfts and rewards wc they hope to have of him.
And this seems to be true, for the day that Princes shall cease to geeue
the^: the self same day beegyn they to hate him. So that such servant, we
cannot call friends of our persons: but covetous of our goods. That thou love
(my son) the one above ye other, thou may right well: but I aduertyse thee
that thou, nor they do make any semblaunce, in such sort that al do know it.
For if thou do otherwise: they will murmr at thee, and will all persecute
thee. He incurreth into no small peril, nor has no little trouble, which is
above al of the Prince beeloued. and of the people hated. For then he is
hated, and persecuted of all. And yet more damage ensues unto him, of the
enmyty of al: then does of the love of the prince alone, For sometimes (the
gods permitting it, and his beehauiour deserving it) the Prince does cease to
love him: and therewith his enemies beegyn to persecute him. From the time I
knew what meaned to govern a common weal, I have always determined, never to
keep man in my house one day, after I know him to be an enemy to the common
wealth. In the year of the foundation of Rome, 649. Lucius Lucullus the
Senator going to the wars against Mithridate, by chance found a tablet of
copper, in the city called Triganie, the which was at the gate of the king of
that prouynce. And on that same was engraven certain Caldean letters, the
which in effect said these words. The prince is not sage, who will put in
hazard the state of his common wealth, for the only commoditye of one alone:
For the service of one, cannot avail against the love of al. The prince is not
sage, ye for to enrich one alone, seeks to empouerish all: For it is a thing
intolerable, that the one do labor the fyelds, and the other do gather the
fruit.

The Prince is not just, which will satisfy the covetousness of one more then the
service of all: for there is mean to pay the services of the good, and there
is no riches to satisfy the covetousness of the evil. The Prince is a fool that
despyseth the counsel of all, and trusts in the opinyon of one. For though
there be in a great ship but one Pilot, yet it needs many Marryners. Bold
is the Prince, which to love one only, wylbee hated of al: for noble Princes
ought to think it much profyt to be beeloued, and much more displeasure to be
hated. These were the words which were written in that tablet, worthy of
eternal memory. And I will tell thee further in this case that Lucullus the
Senator sent on the one part the tablet of copper, where these words were: and
on the other part, the coffers where in he had brought the riches, to the end
the senate should choose one, and leave the other. The senate despysing the
riches and treasours, choose the tablet of counsayles.

The Emperor follows his matter and exhorts his son unto certain
particular things worthy to be engraued in the hearts of men. Cap. lvi.
Until now, I have spoken as a father to his son, that which touches thy
profit. Now I will tell thee what thou shall do after my death for my service.
And if thou will be the true son of thy father, ye things wc I have loved in
my life, shall be of thee esteemed after my death. do not rese^ble many
children, wc after their fathers have closed their eyes, do remember them no
more. For in such case, though in deed ye fathers be dead and buried: yet they
are always living, to complain to ye Gods of their children, Though it
seems not to be sclaunderous, yet it is more perilus, to contend with ye dead:
then to iniure ye living. And ye reason is for yt the living may revenge, and
are for to answer: but ye dead cannot make answer, and much less they can
be revenged. And in such case ye Gods do take their cause in protection: and
some times they execute such cruel punishment of those that live, yt rather
the^ they would endure it, they wysh to be dead. Thou oughtst to think (my
son) that I have beegot thee, I have nouryshed thee, I have taught thee, I
have trymmed thee, I have chastised thee, and I have exalted thee. And for this
consyderation, though by death I am absent, it is not reason yt thou ever
forget me. For the true, and not unthankful child, ought ye same day to bury
his father in his tender heart: when others have laid him in the hard grave. One
of the visible chastisements wc the gods geeue to men in this world is, that
the children obey not their fathers in their life. For the self same fathers
did not remember, their own fathers after their death. Let not young Princes
think, after they have inherited, after they see their father dead, and after
they are past correction of their masters, that al things ought to be done as
they the^ selves will it, for it will not be so. For if they want the favor of
the Gods, and have maledyction of their fathers: they live in trouble, and dye
in danger. I require naught else of thee (my son) but that such a father as I
have been to thee in my life, such a son thou be to me after my death. I
commend unto thee (my son) the veneracion of the gods, and this cheefely
above al thing. For the prince with makes account of the gods, need not to
fear any storm of fortune. Love the gods, and thou shall be beeloued. Serve
them, and thou shall be served. Fear them, and thou shall be feared. Honor
them, and thou shall be honored. Do their commau^dements and they will geeue
thee thy hearts desire. For the gods are so good, that they do not only
receive in account, that wc we do: but also that wc we desire to do. I
commend unto thee (my son) the reverence of the Temples, that is to weete,
that they be not in discord, that they be clean and renewed, that they
offer therein ye sacrifices accustomed. For we do not this honor, to ye
substance wherewith the temples are made: but to the Gods, to whom they are
consecrated. I commend unto thee the veneration of priests: and I pray thee,
though they be covetous, auaricious, dissolute, impatient, negligent, and
vicious: yet yt they be not dishonored. For to us others it apperteineth, not
to judge of the life they lead as me^: but we must consider, that they are
mediators beetwene the gods and us. Beehold my son, that to serve the gods,
honor the temples, and reverence the priests, it is not a thing voluntary, but
very necessary for Princes: For so long endured ye glory of the Greeks, as
they were worshippers of their Gods, and careful of their Temples. The vnhappi
realm of Catthage was nothing more cowardly, nor less rych, then that of the
Romans, but in the end, of the Romans, they were overcome, because they
were great lovers of their treasours, and little worshippers of their Temples. I
commend unto thee (my son) Helia thy stepe mother: and remember, though she
be not thy mother, yet she has been my wife. That wc to thy mother Faustine
thou oughtst for bringing thee into the world: the self same thou oughtst to
Helia, for the good entertainme^t which she has showed thee. And in deed,
often times I being offended with the she maintained thee, and caused me to
forget: so yt she by her good words did win again that, wc thou by thy
evil woorks did loose. Thou shall have my curse, if thou use her evil:
and thou shall fall into their of the gods, if yt agreest that other do not
use her well. For all the damage which she shall feel, shall not be, but for
the inconvenience of my death, and injury of thy person. For her dowrye I leave
her the tributes of Hostia, and the orchyardes of Vulcanus, which I have made
to be planted for her recreation. Be thou not so hardy to take them from her:
for in taking them from her, thou shall show thy wickedness, and in leaving
them her, thy obedyence, and in geeuing her more, thy bounty and liberalyty.
Remember (my son) yt she is a Roman woman young, and a wydow, and of the
house of Traiane my lord, and that she is thy mother adoptatiue, and my
natural wife: and above al, for that I leave her recommended unto thee, I
commend unto thee my son in laws, whom I will thou use as parents and
friends. And beeware, that thou be not of those wc are brethern in words, and
cousins in woorks. Be thou assured that I have willed so much good to my
daughters, that the best which were in all the countries, I have chosen for
their persons. And they have been so good, that if in geeuing them my
daughters, they were my son in laws: in love. I loved them as children. I
commend unto thee my Systers, and daughters, whom I leave thee al married: not
with strange kings, but with natural senators. So that al dwell in Rome where
they may do thee services: and thou may give them rewards and gifts. Thy
sisters have greatly inheryted the beauty of thy mother Faustine: and have
taken little nature of their father Mark. But I swear unto thee, that I have
geeuen them such husbands, and to their husbands, such and so profitable
counsels: that they would rather loose their life then agree to any thing
touching their dishonor. Use thy sisters in such sort that they be not out of
favor, for that their aged father is dead and that they beecome not proud, for
to see their brother Emperor. Women are of a very tender condition: for of
small occasion they do complain, and of less they wax proud. Thou shall
keep them and preserve them after my death, as I did in my life. For
otherwise, their conversation to the people shall be very noisome: and to thee
very importunate. I comend unto thee, Lipula thy youngest Sister wc is enclosed
with in the virgin, vestalles, who was daughter of thy mother Faustine, whom
so derely I have loved in life, and whose death I have beewailed until my
death. Every year I gave to thy sister, six thousand Sexterces for her
necessyties: and in deed I had married her also, if she had not fallen into
the fire, and burnt her face. For though she were my last, I loved her with
all my heart. All have esteemed her fall into ye fire for evil luck: but I do
count the evil luck for good fortune. For her face was not so burned with coals
as her renown suffered peril among evil tongs. I swear unto thee (my son)
that for the service of the gods, and for the renown of men: she is more sure
in ye Temple with the vestal Virgins, then ye art in the Senate with thy Senators.
I suppose now, that at the end of the journey, she shall find her self better
to be enclosed, then thou at liberty. I leave unto her (in the prouynce of
Lucania) every year six thousand sexterces. Travail to augme^t them for her,
and not to dymynish them. I commend unto thee Drusia the Romain wydow, who has
a process in ye Senate. For in ye times of the co^motions past her husband was
banished and proclaimed traitor. I have great pyety of so noble, and worthy a
widow: for it is now.iii. months since she has put up her complaint and for
ye great wars I could not show her justice. Thou shall find (my son) that
in.xxxv. years I have governed in Rome, I never agreed that any widow should
have any suit before me, above.viii. days. Be careful to favor, and
dispatch the orphans, and wydows. For the needy wydows, in what place so ever
they be, do encurre into great danger. Not wc out cause I advertise thee, yt
ye travail to dispatch the^ so sone as ye may: and to administer justice
unto the^. For through ye prolo^ging of beautiful wome^s suites, their honor
and credit is diminished. So yt their business being prolo^ged, they shall not
recover so much of their goods as they shall lose of their renowm. I co^me^d
unto thee (my son) my old servant, which with my long years, and my cruel
wars, with my great necessityes, with the combrance of my body, and my long
disease, have had great trouble: and as faithful servant, oftentimes to ease
me, have annoyed them selves. It is convenient since I have prevailed of their
life, that they should not loose by my death. Of one thing I assure thee, that
though my body remain with the worms in the grave: yet before the gods I
will remember them. And heerin thou shall show thy self to be a good child,
when thou shall recompense those wc have served thy father well. Al princes
which shall do justice, shall get enemies in the excucion thereof. And since it
is done by the hands of those, which are near him the more familiare they are
with the prince, the more are they hated of the people: al in generally do
love justice, but none do rejoice that they execute it in his house. And
therefore after the Prince ends his life, the people will take revenge of
those, which have been ministers thereof. It were great infamy to the empire,
offense to the gods, injury to me, unthankfulness to thee, having found the
arms of my servants, ready xviii. years, that thy gates should be shut
against them one day. Keep, keep these things (my son) in thy memory: and
since particulerly I do remember them at my death, consider how heartily I
loved them in my life.

The good Marcus Aurelius, Emperor of Rome, ends his purpose and life. And of
the last words which he spoke to his son Commodus, and of the table of
counsels which he gave him. Cap. lvii.
WHen the Emperor had ended his particular recommendacions, unto his son
Commodus, as the dawning of the day beegan to appear: so his eyes beegan to
close, his tongue to faulter, and his hands to tremble, as it does accustom to
those, which are at the point of death. The prince perceiving then little life
to remain, commanded his secretory Panutius to go to the coffer of his books,
and to bring one of the coffers before his presence: out of the which he
took a table of.iii. foot of breadth, and ii. of length, the wc was of Eban,
bordered al about with unicorn. And it was closed with.2. lyds, very fine of red
wood, wc they call rasing, of a tree where the Phoenix (as they say) breeds, wc
did grow in Arabia, And as there is but one only Phoenix, so in the world is
there but one only tree of that sort. On the uttermost part of the table, was
graven the God Jupiter, and on the other ye goddess Venus: and in the other
was drawn the God Mars, and the goddess Diana. In the uppermost part of ye
table was carved a bull: and in ye neythermost part was drawn a king. And they
said the paynter of so famous and renowned a woork, was called Apelles. The
Emperor taking the table in his hands, casting his eyes unto his son, said
these words. Thou see my son, how from the turmoyls of fortune I have
escaped, and how I into miserable destenies of death do enter, where by
experience I shall know what there is after this life. I mean not now to
blaspheme the gods: but to repent my sins. But I would willingly declare why
ye gods have created us, since there is such trouble in life, and such pain in
death. Not understanding why the gods have used so great cruelti with creatures,
I see it now, in that after.lxii. years I have sailed in ye danger and peril
of this life: now they command me to land, and harbor in ye grave of death.
Now approaches ye hour wherein ye band of matrimoni is losed, the thread of life
untwined, the key does lock, the sleep is wakened, my life does end, and I go
out of this troublesome pain. Remembering me of yt I have done in my life, I
desire no more to live: but for yt I know not whyther I am carried by death, I
fear and refuse his darts. Alas what shall I do, since ye gods tell me not
what I shall do? what cou^sail shall I take of any man, since no man will
accompany me in this journey? O what great disceite, o what manifest blindness
is this, to love one thing al ye days of his life, and to call nothing with us
after our death? Because I desired to be rych, they let me die poor. Because
I desired to live with company, they let me die alone. For such shortness of life,
I know not what he is yt will have a house, since the narow grave is our
certain mansio^ place? beeleeue me, my son, that many things past do grieve
me sore: but with nothing so much I am troubled, as to come so late to ye
knowledge of this life. For if I could perfectly beeleeue this, neither should
men have cause to reprove me, neither yet I now such occasion to lament me. O
how certain a thing is it, that men when they come to the point of death, do
promise the gods, that if they proroge their death, they will amend their life?
but notwithstanding, I am sorry that we see them delivered from death, without
any manner of amendment of life. They have obtained that, which of the gods they
have desired: and have not performed that, wc they have promised. They ought
assuredly to think, that in the sweetest time of their life, they shall be
constreyned to accept death. For admit that the punishment of ingrate persons
be deferred: yet therefore the fault is not pardoned. Be thou assured my
son, that I have seen enough, hard, felt, tasted, desired, possessed, eaten,
slept, spoken, and also lived enough. For vices geeue as great trouble, to
those which follow them much: as they do great desire, to those which never
proved them. I confess to the immortal Gods, that I have no desire to live:
yet I ensure thee, I would not dye. For life is so troublesome that it wears
us: and death is so doubtful, that it fears us. If the gods deferred my
death, I doubt whyther I should reform my life. And if I do not amend my
life, nor serve the Gods better, nor profit the common wealth more, and if that
every time I am sick, it should grieve me to die: I say it is much better for
me now to accept death, then, to wysh the lengthning of my life. I say the
life is so troublesome, so fyckle, so suspicious, so uncertain, and so
importunat (finally I say, it is a life whithout life) that he is an obstinat
fool, wc so much desires it. Come yt that may come: for finally, not
withstanding yt I have spoken, I willingly commit my self into the hands of ye
Gods, since of necessity I am thereunto constreined. For it proceeds not of a
little wisdom, to receive that willingly, which to do we are constrained of
necessity. I will not recommend my self to the priests, nor cause the oracles
to be visited, nor promise any thing to ye temples, nor offer sacrifices to
the gods, to the end they should warrant me from death, and restore me to
life: but I will demand, and require them, that if they have created me for
any good thing, I may not loose it for my evil life. So wise and sage are the
gods in that they say, so just and true in that they promise, that if they
geeue us not that which we others would: it is not for that they will not, but
because we deserve it not. For we are so evil, and worth so litel, and we
may do so little, that for many good woorks we deserve no meryt: and yet with
an evil work, we be made unworthy of al. Since therefore I have put my self
in to ye hands of the Gods, let them do with me what they will for their
service: for in the end, the woorst that they will do is much better then the
world will do. For all that the world has geeuen me, has been but mockry,
and deceyte: but that which the gods have geeuen me, I have governed, and
possessed without suspicion. For this last hour (my son) I have kept the
best, the most noble, and riches jewel that I have possessed in my life time.
And I do protest unto the immortal gods, that if as they do commau^d me to
dye, they would geeue me license to read in the grave: I would command it to
be buried with me. Thou shall know my son, that in the.x. year of my
Empire, a great war arose against the unruly people of Persia, where by evil
luck it was appointed for me, in person to geeue the battle: the which
won, and al their country destroyed, I returned by the old city of Thebes in
Aegipte, to see if I could find any antiquity of those in times past. In the
house of an Egiptian pryest, I found a litel table, which they hanged at the
gate of the kings palace the day of his coronatio^. And this poor pristes
told me, that that which was in this table, was written by a king of Egypt,
named Ptholomeus Arsasides. I beeseech the immortal Gods, my son, that such
be thy woorks, as the words of this table require. As emperor, I leave thee
heir of many realms: and as a father, I geeue thee this table of counsayles.
The words which the fathers do teach unto the children at the last hour, the
children ought to keep continually in their memory. Let this therefore be my
last word, with the Empire thou shall be feared through out all the world:
and with the counsayles of this table, thou shall be loved of al nations. This
talk being ended, and the table geeuen, the Emperor turned his eyes, lost his
senses, and for the space of a quarter of an hour lay languishing in extreme
pain, and within a while after yielded up the ghost. In this table wear
certain greek letters which were in meeter and in our tongue signify thus.

ON honors stall I do no tirant heave,
nor yet the poor suppress if he wear just
For riches rule I nould to pardon cleave,
For want of wealth nor follow rigours lust.
For naked love I never spent reward,
nor would correct for only enuies heat,
Of virtues imps I always had regard
and mischifs mates have plagd with torment great.
To others doom I never would commit
of open right the quarrel to decide
ne yet of doubtful strifes in trust of wit
The final end alone I would divide.
To them that sought for justice equal sway
her golden rule I never did deny
ne yet to such for whom desert would lay
Their sclender fautes might well be slipped by
To feel the grife that waued in my mind
With others smart I never could sustain
nor yet rewards my princely words would bind
When sweet delight had chifest joy to rain.
In high estate when most blind fortune smild
A reckles life I restles ran not on
nor yet when change those happy days beegyld
to cold despaier my quiet mind was gone.
By boiling heat of malice endeles fire
to vices train I cast no egre eye
ne yet for lust of pining welthes desire
Unlawful facts I rechles would apply.
The traitors breast I never could embrace
nor lend mine ears to swalow flattring talk
of vices slaves I wayed not the grace
nor left unsought good will in virtues walk.
Poor Irus band for that I did reliue
Whose needy state does stoop in Cresus swaie
the greatest gods whose heavenly warck does griue
the proudest crowns was aymy present state,
FINIS.
The fourth book of the Dyall of Princes Compyled by the right reverend father
in god, Antony of Gueuara, Bishop of Mondogueto, preacher, Chronicler, and
counceller to Charles the fifth Emperor of Rome: Containing many instructions
and rules, for the favored of the Court, being once in favor, easily to keep
and continue them selves in favor still. Right necessary and profitable for all
princes, and noble men, and gentlemen courtiers that seek to continue them
selves in honor and estimacion.

The Epistle to the Reader.
WHat detracting tongues report of me and my first travel in the translation
of this Dyall, enlarging them at pleasure to woork my defame, disabling my
doing herein, by brute yt was no woork of mine, but the fruit of others
labor: I need not much force, since by daily proof we see, that ill disposed
mynds can never frame an honest tongue in head. For my object, and reproof of
this their sclaunderous and malignant speech, I can allege (courteous reader)
two principal causes, which thou reading and judging with indifferency, may
easily approve, if I shoold seem to gloss with thee. First, the baseness of my
style, the plain and humble words couched in the same, the mean, rude, and ill
contryued sentences laid before thee, togeether with the simple handelyng of
the whole: plainly shows to thee whence they are, and easily acquainteth thee
with the curious translator. Who protests to god, and confesses to the
world, that he more rashely then wisely plonged him self into so grave and
deep a matter, and whose young years and unskillful head, might both then and
now have excused his fond enterprise herein. For the second and last, I must
needs appeal to all the woorshipfull, and my beeloued compaignyons, and fellow
students of our house of Lyncolnes Inn at that time, from whence my poor
english Dyall took his light. To whose just and true reports (for thy
undoubted satisfaction, and discharge of my poor honesty) I refer thee, and
wholly yield me. These recyted causes, for purgacion of my suspected fame, as
also for established assurance of the like, and thy further doubt of me
hereafter, I thought good (gentle reader) to denounce unto thee. I might well
have spared this second and last labor of mine taken, in the reformacion and
correction of this Dyall, enlarging my self further once again, with the
translation of the late and new come favored courtier (and which I found
annexed to the Dyall for the fourth and last book) If my preceding travel
taken in the setting forth of the first three books, and the respect of mine
honesty in accomplyshing of the same, had not incyted me (unwilling) to
continue my first begone attempt, to bring the same to his perfyt and desired
end: which whole woork is now complete by this last book, entitled the
favored courtyer. Which first and last volume, wholly as yt lies, I prostrate
to the judgment of the grave and wise Reader, subiecting my self and yt, to
the reformation and correction of his learned head, whom I beeseech to judge of
me with favor and equity: and not with malice to persecute my same, and honest
intent, having for thy benefit, (to my little skill and knowledge) employed my
simple talent, crauyng no other guerdon of thee, but thy good report, and
courteous acceptaunce hereof. Which dooyng thou shall make me double bound to
thee. First, to be thankful for thy good will. Secondly, to be considerate
how hereafter I take upon me so great a charge. Thirdly, thou shall encourage
me to study to increase my talent.

Fourthly, and lastly, most freely to beestow thincrease thereof on thee, and
for the benefit of my country and common weal, whereto duty byndeth me:
Observing the sage and prudent saying of the renowned orator and famous Cicero:
with which I end, and thereto leave thee. Non nobis solum nati sumus, ortusque
nostri partem patria vendicat, partem parents, partem amici. In defense and
preservation whereof (good reader) we ought not alone to employ our whole
wits and able senses, but necessity enforcing us, to sacrifice our selves
also for benefit thereof. From my lord Norths house nere London the.10. day of
May. 1568.

Thine that accepts me. Th. North.

The prolog of this present woork shows what one true friend ought to do for
an other: Addressed to the right honorable the lord Fraunces Conos, great
commander of Lion.
THe famous Philosopher Plato, beesought of al his disciples to tell the^, why
he iornyed so often from Athens to Scicille, being the way he traveled (in
deed) very long, and the sea he passed very dangerous: answered them thus.
The cause that moves me to go from Athens to Scicille, is only to see
Phocion, a man iustinal that he does, and wise in all that he speaks: and
because he is my very friend, and enemy of Denis, I go also willingly to him,
to aid him in that I may, and to council him in all ye I know: and told them
further. I do you to weete my disciples, that a good philosopher, to visit and
help his friend, and to accompany with a good man, shoold think the journey
short, and no whit paynfull, though he shoold sulk the whole seas, and pace
the compase of the earth. Appolonius Thianeus departed from Rome, went through
all Asia, sailed over the great flud Nile, endured the bitter cold of mount
Caucasus, suffered the parching heat of the mountayns Riphei, passed the land
of Nassagera, and entered into the great India: And this long pilgrimage took
he upon him, in no other respect, but to see Hyarcus the philosopher, his
great and old friend. Agesilaus also among the Greeks accounted a worthy
Captayn, understanding that the king Hycarius had an other captayn (his very
friend) captyue: leaving all his own affairs apart, traueling through diverse
countries, went to the place where he was, and arrived there, presented him
self unto the king, and said thus to him. I humbly beeseech thee O puissant
king, thou deigne to pardon Minotus, my sole and only friend, and thy subject
now: for what thou shall do to him, make thy account thou have done it to me.
For in deed thou can never alone punish his body, but thou shall therewith
also crucify my heart.

King Herod after Augustus had overcome Mark Antony, came to Rome, and laying
his crown at ye Imperial feet, with stout courage spoke these words unto him.
Know thou (mighty Augustus) if thou know it not, that if Mark Antony had
beeleeued me, and not his accursed love Cleopatra, thou shooldst then have
proved how bitter an enemy I woold have been to thee, and he have found how
true a friend I was, and yet am to him. But he, as a man rather geeuen over to
the rule of a woman's will, then guyded by reasons skill, took of me but money
only, and of Cleopatra counsel. And proceeding further said: Lo here my
kingdom, my person, and royal crown laid at thy princely feet, all which I
freely offer to thee, to dispose of at thy will and pleasure, pleasing thee so
to accept it, but yet with this condition (inuict Augustus) that thou command
me not to here nor speak ill of Mark Antony my lord and friend, yea although
he were now dead. For know thou, sacred prince, that true friends, neither for
death ought to be had in obliuio^, nor for absens to be forsaken. Julius
Caesar last dictator and first emperor of Rome, did so entierly love Cornelius
Fabatus the consul, that traueling togethers through the alps of France and
being beenighted, far from any town or harber, save that only of a hollow
cave, which happily they lighted on: And Cornelius the consul even then not
well at ease, Julius Caesar left him the whole cave to thend he might be more
at rest, and he him self lay abroad in the cold and snow. By these goodly
examples we have resited, and by diverse others we coold resite, may be
considered, what faithful friendship ought to be beetwixt true and perfect
friends, and into how many dangers one friend ought to put him self for an
other. For it is not enough that one friend be sorry for the troubles of an
other, but he is bound (if need were) to go and dye joyfully with him. He
only deservedly may be counted a true friend, that unasked, and before he be
called, goes with his goods and person to help and relieve his friend. But in
this our iron age alas there is no such kind of amity as that we have spoken
of. More then this, that there is no friend will part with any thing of his to
relieve his friend, much less that takes care to favor him in his trobles: but
if there be any such that will help his friend, yt is even then when time
serves rather to pity and lament him, then to aid or succor him. It is a thing
worth the knowledge, that to make a true and perpetual friendship, we may not
offer to many persons, but according to Seneca his saying, who says. My friend
Lucillus, I council thee that thou be a true friend to one alone, and enemy to
none: for nombers of friends brings great encumbrance, which seems somewhat to
diminish friendship. For who that considers the liberty of the heart, it is
impossible that one shoold frame and agree with the conditions of many, and
much less that many shoold content them with the desiers and affections of
one. Tully and Salust were two famous orators amongst the Romans, and great
enemies beetwene them selves, and during this emulation beetweene them, Tully
had purchased all the Senators friendship, and Salust only had no other friend in
all Rome, but Mark Anthony alone. And so these two great Orators being one day
at words togeethers, Tully in great anger said to Salust: what force or power
art thou of, or what can thou do or attempt against me? since thou know
that in all Rome thou have but one only friend, Mark Antony, and I no enemy but
one, and that is he? To whom Salust answered. Thou gloriest (O Tully) that
thou have no mo but one only enemy, and afterward jests at me, that I have no
more friends but only one: but I hope in the immortal Gods, that this only
enemy thou have, shall be able enough utterly to undo thee: and this my sole
friend that I have, shall be sufficient to protect and defend me in all my
causes. And shortly after these words passed beetween them, Mark Antony showed
the friendship he bare to the one, and the enimity he had to the other, for
he caused Tully to be put to death, and raised Salust to great honor. A friend
may well impart to the other all his own, as bread, wine, money, time,
conversation, and such like, but he cannot notwithstanding geeue him part of
his heart, for that suffers it not to be parted nor divided, because it can
be geeuen but to one alone. This granted to be true, as needs it must
doubtless, that the heart can not be divided but only geeuen to one, then is it
of necessity, that he that will seek to have many friends, must needs repair
to the shambels to provide him of many hearts. Many vaunt them selves, and think
it a glory to have nombers of friends, but let such well consider to what use
that legendary of friends do serve them, they shall then easily find they stand
them in no other steed, but to eat, to drink, to walk, to babble, and to
murmr togeethers, and not one to help the other with their goods, favor, and
credit at their need, nor friendly to reprove them of their faults and vices,
which doubtless ought not to be so. For where true and perfect friendship
raygneth, neither I wish my friend, nor he with me shoold dissemble any fault
or vice. Ouide says in his book de art amandi, that the law of true and
unfeigned love is so straight, that no friendship but mine in thy heart shoold
herber, and in mine shoold lodge none others love but thine, for love is none
other thing but one heart living in two bodies, and two bodies obeying one heart.
In this world there is no treasure co^parable to a true and sure friend, sith to
a faith full friend a man may safely discover ye secrets of his heart, beewray
unto him his gryping greeues, trusting him with his honor, comitting to his
guyd and custody all his goods, he shall succor him in his misery, counsel
him in peril, rejoice at his prosperity, and mourn at his adversity: and in
fine I conclude, such a friend never werieth to serve him in his life, nor to
lament him after his death. I grant that gold and silver is good, kynsfolks
are good, and money is good, but true friends exceed them all without
comparison. For all these things cannot warrant us from necessity (if synister
fortune plunge us into it) but rather increase our torment and extremity: Also
they do not rejoice us, but rather heap further greefes upon us, neither do
they succor us, but rather each hour geeue us cause to complayn, much less do
they remember and advise us of that that is good, but still do deceive us, not
dyrectyng us the right way, but still bringing us out of our way, and when they
have lead us awry out of the high way, they bring us into desert woods, and
high and dangerous mountayns, whereof necessity we must fall down hedlong. A
true friend is no partaker of these conditions, but rather he is sorry for the
lest trouble that happens to his friend, he fears not, neither spares his
goods, nor the danger of his person, he cares not to take upon him any
painful journey, quarrels, or suits, nor yet to put his life in every hasard of
death. And yet that that is most of all to be esteemed is, that like as the
heart and bowels ever burn with pure and sincere love, so does he wish and
desire with gladsome mind, to bear the burden of all his friends mishaps, yea
more then yet spoken of. Alexander the great offered great presents to the
Philosopher Zenocrates, who woold not vouchsafe to receive them, much less to
beehold them. And being demanded of Alexander why he woold not receive them,
having poor kinsfolks and parents to beestow them on: he answered him thus.
Truly I have both brothers and sisters (O Alexander) yet I have no kinsman but
him that is my friend, and one only friend I have, who has no need of any gyfts
to be geeuen him. For the only cause why I choose him to be my sole and only
friend, was for that I ever saw him despise these worldly things. Truly the
sentence of this good philosopher Zenocrates is of no small efficacy, for him
that will aduysedly consider of it, since that not seeldom but many times it
happens, that the great troubles, the sundry dangers, and the continual
necessities and miseries we suffer in this vale of misery, have for the most
part proceeded from our parents, and afterward by our friends have been
mediated and redressed. Therefore since we have thought it good and necessary
to choose a friend, and that he be but one only, each man must be wise lest in
such choice he be deceived. For often times it happens, that those that take
little regard herein, grant their friendship to such one as is to covetous,
impacient, a great babbler, seditious, and presumptuous, and of such conditions
that sometime it shoold be less evil for us to have him our enemy, then to
account of him as of our dear friend. Him whom we will choose for our faithful
friend, amongst other manners and conditions he must chiefly and before all
be endued with these, that he be courteous of nature, faier spoken, hard and
stout to endure pain, pacient in troubles, sober in diet, moderate in his
words, grave and ripe in his counsels, and above all steadfast in friendship,
and faithful in secrets. And whom we shall find with these laudable virtues
and conditions adorned, him may we safely take and accept for our friend. But
if we see any of these parts wanting in him, we ought to shon him as from the
plague, knowing for certeinty, that the friendship of a feigned and fantastical
friend is much worse and perilous, then the enmity of a known and open enemy.
For to the hands of one we commit our heart, and faith: and from the deceipts
and treasons of the other, we defendour selves with our whole force and power.
Seneca writing to his dear and faithful friend Lucillus says unto him. I pray
thee (O Lucillus) that thou order and determyne thine affaiers by thaduise and
counsel of thy friend, but also I do remember thee, that first thou see well
what manner of friend thou have chosen thee, for there is no merchandise in the
world this day that men are so soon beegyled in, as they are in the choice of
friends. Therefore the grave sentence of Seneca wisely wayed, we shoold assent
with him in oppinion, that since no man byeth a horse but he first causes him
to be ridden, nor bread but first he sees and handles it, nor wine but he
tastes it, nor flesh but first he wayeth it, nor corn but he sees a
sample, nor house but that he does first value it, nor Instrument but first
he plays on it, and judges of his sound: yt is but reason he shoold be so
much the more circumspect before he choose his friend to examine his life and
condition, since all the other things we have spoken of may be put in diverse
houses and corners, but our friend we lodge and keep dearly in our proper
bowels. Those that write of the emperor Augustus say, that he was very
strange and scrupulous in accepting friends, but after he had once received
the^ into his friendship, he was very constant and circu^spect to keep them.
For he never had any friend, but first he had some proof and trial of him,
neither woold he ever after forsake him for any displeasure done to him.
Therefore yt shoold always be so, that true friends shoold bear one to an other
such love and affection that the one being in prosperity, should not have
occasion to complayn of him self in that he did not reliue his friends
necessity being in adversity: nor the other being poor and needy, shoold
grudge or lament for that his friend being rich and welthy, woold not succor
him with all that he might have done for him. For to say the truth, where
perfect frendshyp is, there ought no excuse to be made to do what possible is
the one for the other. The friendship of young men comes commonly, (or for the
most part at ye least) by being companyons in vice and folly: and such of
right ought rather to be called vacabonds, then once to deserve the name of
true friends. For that cannot be called true friendship, that is continued to
the preiudyce or derogation of virtue. Seneca writing again to Lucillus says
these words. I woold not have thee think, nor once mistrust, O my Lucillus,
that in all the Romayn empire I have any greater friend then thou: but with all
assure thy self, that our friendship is not so straight beetwene us, that I
woold take upon me at any time to do for thee otherwise then honesty shoold
lead me. For though the love I bear thee has made thee lord of my lyberty:
yet reason also has left me virtue free.

The aucthor proceeds on.
Applyeng that we have spoken to that we will now declare, I say I will not
acknowledge my self your servant, for so shoold I be compelled to fear you
more then love you: much less will I vaunt my self to be your kinsman, for so
I shoold importune and displease you: and I will not brag that heretofore we
have been of familier acquaintance, for that I woold not make any demonstration
I made so little account of you, and less then I am bound to do: neither will
I bost my self that I am at this present your famyliar and welbeeloued, for in
deed I shoold then show my self to be to bold and arrogant: but that that I
will confess shall be, that I love you as a friend, and you me as a kinsman, al
be it this friendship has succeeded dyuersly till now. For you being noble as
you are, have bountifully showed your friendship to me, in large and ample
gyfts: but I poor, and of base estate, have only made you sure of mine in
words. Plutarche in his Polytikes said: That it were far better to sell to
our friends our woorks and good deeds, (whether they were in prosperity,
adversity, or necessity) then to feed them with vayn flattering words for
nothing. Yet is it not so general a rule, but that sometimes it happens that
the high words on the one side are so profitable, and the woorks so few and
feeble on the other side, that one shall be better pleased and delighted with
hearing the sweet and courteous words of the one, then he shall be to be served
with the cold service and woorks of the other, of small profyt and value.
Plutarch also in his book De animalibus tells us, that Denis the tyrant
being one day at the table reasoning of diverse and sundry matters with
Chrisippus the philosopher, it chanced, that as he was at diner, one brought
him a present of certain sugar cakes, wherefore Chrisippus cesing his former
discourse fell to persuade Denis to fall to his cakes. To whom Denis answered,
on with your matter Chrisippus, and leave not of so: For my heart is better
contented with thy sweet and sugared words, then my tongue is pleased with the
delycate taste of these mountayn cakes. For as thou know, these cakes are
heavy of digestion, and do greatly annoy the stomach: but good words do
maruelously rejoice and comfort the heart. For this cause Alexander the great
had the poet Homer in greater veneration, being dead, then all the other that
were alive in his time: not for that Homer ever did him service, or that he
knew him, but only because of his learned books he wrote and compyled, and
for the grave sentences he found therein. And therefore he bare about him in
the day time the book of the famous deeds of Troy (called the Illiades)
hanged at his neck within his bosom: and in the night he laid it under his
bolster, at his beds head where he slept. In recompense therefore (sir) of
the many good turns I have received at your hands, I was also willing to
compyle and dedicate this my little treatise to you, the which I present you
with all my desires, my studyes, my watches, my swett, and my troubles, holding
my self fully satisfied for all the payns I have taken, so that this my simple
travel be grateful to you (to whom I offer yt) and to the publyke weal
profitable. Being well assured, if it please you to trust me and credyte my
writing, you shall manifestly know how freely I speak to you, and like a friend,
and not deceive you as a flatterer. For if the beeloued and favored of princes
chance to be cast out of favor, it is because every man flattereth him and
seeks to please him and no man goes about to tell him troth, nor that that
is for his honor, and fittest for him. Salust in his book of the wars of
Iugurtha says, that the high heroycall facts and noble deeds were of no less
glory to the historiographer that wrote them, then they were to the captayn
that did them. For it happens many times that the Captayn dying in the
battle he has woone, lives afterward notwythstandyng by the fame of his
noble attempt, and this proceeds not only of the valiant deeds of arms he
was seen do; but also for that we read of him in worthy authors which have
amply written thereof. We may well say therefore touching this matter, that
as well may we take him for a true friend, that geeueth good counsel: as he
which does us great pleasure, and service. For according to the oppinion of
the good Marcus Aurelius, who said to his secretary Panutius, that a man with
one pay, may make full satisfaccion and recompense of many pleasures and good
turns showed: but to requyte a good counsel, diverse thanks and infinite
services are requisite. If we will credit the ancient historiographers we
shall find it true, that the virtuous emperors, the fortunate kings, and the
valiant Captains, when they shoold enterprise to go conquer their enemies,
either they sought for some philosopher, or they choose some other honest
learned man, of whom they took council touching all their affayrs, before
they pressed any soldiers. Comparing the times past, with the times present, we
