think (that have read some what) that the time past was as pure grayn, and this
now as chafe and straw: the one as ye time calm and still in the sea, and
this as wavering and tempesteous: that then the fine and pure metal, and this
now the dross thereof: The other the marie, and this the bones: the one the
clear day, and the other the dark night: For in these days in princes courts,
and noble men's houses, they glory more to have a scoffing knave or iester to
make them laugh, then they reckon of a grave and wise man to geeue them
counsel. Alexander the great in all his wars woold always be accompanied
with the wise Aristotle. Cyrus king of Persia, with the philosopher Chilo: King
Ptolomie with Pithinus the philosopher: Pirrhus king of Epyre, with Zatirus:
Augustus themperor with Symonides: Scipio thaffrican with Sophocles: Traian
themperor with Plutarche, and Antonius themperor with Gorgias: now all these
famous princes carried not with the^ so many learned philosophers, to fight in
battle with armed weapon in hand like other their soldiers, but only to use
their counsel and advice. So that the great battles they overthrew, and the
worthy victories they wanne, with the noble tryumphs done, was as much by the
grave counsel of these good and wise Philosophers, as by the force of their
army, and prowes of their Captayns. The greatest good turn and benefit one
friend can do for an other, is to know to geeue good counsel to his friend, in
his greatest need: and not without cause I say to know to geeue counsel. For
it happens often times, that those that thought to have geeuen us good remedy
by their counsel, (wanting in deed discrecion and judgment in the same) have
caused us to run into further dangers. And therefore Seneca being once
demanded of themperor Nero, what he thought of Scipio thaffrican, and Cato
the censor, answered him in this manner. I think it was as necessary that Cato
was born for ye common wealth, as Scipio for ye wars, for the good Cato with
his prudent counsel expelled vice out of the wealth public, and the other
with his noble courage and great armies did ever wythstand the force of the
enemies. According to the saying of Seneca, let us also say after him, that he
is very arrogant that presumes to geeue an other counsel, but with all we say
again: that if the counsel be found good he has geeuen to his friend in his
need and necessity, as much praise deserves he that gave it, as he that knew
how to take it. Now after thexample of the ancient philosophers, which went to
the wars not to fight, but only to geeue counsel, I will (sir) for those
things that pertayn to your service, and profit, take upon me the office of a
philosopher, and for the first doctrine of my philosophy I say, that if it
please you, to receive these counsels which my pen does write to you, at
this present, I promise you, and by the faith of a christian man I swear, that
they shall be such excellent helps to you, for the preservation of your credyt
and favor you are now in, as you may be enriched by the true and diligent
service of your servant. For if a man woold with an oath ask the truth of
Plato, Socrates, Pithagoras, Diogenes, Licurgus, Chilo, Pittachus, and of
Apolonius, and also of all the university and company of the other
philosophers, they woold swear and affirm that the felicity of man consists
not in great might, in great aucthority, and possessions: but only in deserving
much. For the honor, favor, and dignityes of this mortal life, are more to be
praised and had in veneratio^ when they are placed in a condign and worthy
person: then they are being possessed of an unworthy and graceles man,
allotted to him not by virtue, but by fortune. And therefore your aucthority
being great at this present, exalted thereto by gods divine will and
prouydence, and now in the highest degree of prosperity: I woold wish you my
good lord, less then any other courtier to trust to fortunes impery. For if
the earthquakes sooner bring to ground the proud and stately Palaces, then the
mean and low howses: if ofter fall on the highest mountayns, the dreadful
lightnings and tempests, then on the lowest hills: if among the greater
multitude of people the plagues be rifer, then amongst the fewer number: if
they use rather to spread their netts, and lay the byrdlyme on the green and
thickst bows, then on the dry and wythered sticks, to snare the sely byrds
withal: If always the stillest seas do foreshew to us a greater tempest
following: and if that long health be a watch unto a great and dangerous
sickness ensuyng: by this also I will infer, that those that are atchiued to
sublime estate and high degree are commonly more subject to fall, then those of
mean and baser sort. The emperor Augustus on a time demanded of the Poet
Virgill, that he woold teach him how he might conserve him self in thempire,
and always be acceptable to the public weal. To whom Virgill answered. I
think, O mighty Caesar, that to reign long in thempire, thou must consideratly
look into thy self, examining thy life and doings: and how much thou shall
see thy self excel and exceed all those (of thy empire) in dignity: So much
more must thou endeavor thy self to surmount all others, in virtue, and we
orthynes. For he is unworthy to rule a multitude, that is not chief himself
in all virtues. Those therefore that in court of princes bear office, and
aucthority, ought earnestly to desire and endeavor them selves to avoid the
fylthy sink of vice, and to seek the clear spring of virtue. For otherwise,
they shall be more defamed for one vice or defect found in them, then honored
for their office and authority they have.

The aucthor concludes.
According to the saying of the poet Virgill to the Emperor Augustus, I am also
of oppinion (my Lord) that you ought to be very circumspect and well advised,
in looking into your self who you are, what power you are of, what you are
worth, and what you possess: and dooyng thus, you shall find that among your
wise counselors you are the greatest, among the rich, among the best esteemed,
among the most fortunat, among your secretories, among the rulers, amongst all
those of your realm and subjects, you are ever ye greatest. And therefore as
you are greatst, and supreme above them all: so you ought the more to force to
be the most virtuous of them all. For else it were against all reason, being
the greatest, to be the least and most inferior of all. For truly none ought
to be praised for good, for yt he is of power, force, possessions, wealth,
much worth, in favor, of dignity, neither for any nobility that is in him, if
these natural gifts be not accompagnied with virtue and good woorks. The
ancient historiographers do highly commend the greatness of Alexander, the
knowledge of Ptholomie, the justice of Numa Pompilius, the clemency of Julius
Caesar, the patience of Augustus, the truth of Traian, the pity of Antonius,
the temperancy of Constantius, the continency of Scipio, and the humanity of
Theodosius: so that we may say these so great and noble princes have won
more honor by their virtues, then they have atchyued by tryumphant victories.
Albeeit a man be never so dishonest, vicious, and lascivious, and that he be
rooted in all ydlenes, let us say and avouch it for a truth, that it is
impossible (if he may return to look back on him self, and that he may call
to mind what manner of man he has been, what he is at this present, and to
what end he may come) but that the remembrance of his forepassed faults and
deeds, shoold be more grievous and yrksom to him, then the great delight his
body shoold take of the present pleasures. For neither the woorms in the vynes,
nor the locusts in the corn, nor the moths in the garments, nor the little
woorms in the wood are so hurtful and dommageable, as sins are of power to
make a man sorrowful. For to say truly, the pleasure we receive when we
commyt them is not so great, as is the displeasure we feel after we remember
them. The which I considering, my lord, yt causes me to look over mine old
memorials, to examyne my memory, to strengthen my judgment, and to seek a new
kind of study, to no other end, but to find out sweet words, diverse doctryns,
and strange historyes, by means whereof I might withdraw you from vayn and
worldly delights, to cause you to walk in the right path, and to affect things
virtuous and honest, though I have always known them as acceptable to you, as
they have been familier. For princes servant, the more they are busied with
affairs, the less they know them selves. And therefore great pain suffers
he, and with over venymous poison is he infected, that with others, and for
other occupyeth all his time, and for his own sowl health cannot spare a moment
of time. O what comfort and quiet were it unto my heart, if it were assured it
had taken the right way, in the doctrine which I write to you, and that I had
not erryd in the counsels I geeue you: so that in readyng my book you might
acquire profit thereby, and I of my travel therein reap my full contentation.
And to the end, my Lord, we may better express the matter, search the wound,
and stop the vayns, that we may leave no part uncured or dreggs of
infection, if heetherto I have used playnesse, I will now speak more plainly to
you, and yet as one friend uses to an other. And therefore may it please you to
accept these small written preposes in this book, among all the residue,
proceeding from the hands of one that rather desires ye health of your sowl,
then the gayn and satisfaction of your affects and desires.

All you that be princes familiers, and beeloued Courtiers: observe and retayn
with you these few precepts and counsels.
1 Never tell (my lord) to any all that you think. Show not all that you have.
Neither take all that you desire: Tell not all that you know.

Much less never do all that you may. For the right path way to bring the
favored courtier into his Princes disgrace, is to be addicted to his sensual
appetytes and vain humors, and not to be guyded with reason and discrecion.

2 Beware also you trust not, nor commit to the hasard of fortunes ticklenes
such things, as touch and conserve your parson, honor, goods and conscience.
For the wise courtier that lives in his princes grace, will not rashly put him
self in danger, in hope to save him self harmles, at all times when he
lists.

3 Although every man offer his service to you, and seem to be at your
commandment when you shall need him: yet I tell you (sir) I woold not wish
you had either need of them, or of me: For many of those line and curious
courtiers which are the first that offer them selves to draw on your side, and
to stand by you if need be, are commonly (at the very pinch) the first and
redyest to throw stones at our faces.

4 In other men's matters busy not your self to much: and in your own, strive
not with time, but take leisure. For living after this rule, you shall long
keep your self in the good and quiet estate you are in, and otherwise some
inconvenience might lightly fall upon you, that shoold make you remember what
you were wont to be.

5 The imminent peril and danger those are in, which are mounted to the top
of some high thing, or to the cliffe of some high and rocky mountayn, where
they have no other way to descend, but to fall, is much like to that of the
famyliars of Princes. And therefore my lord, I woold wysh you woold procure you
such faythfulll friends about you, that they having regard and care of your
person, shoold always hold you by the gown for falling. And not such as after
they had let you fall, woold then lend you their hands to help you up again.

6 All be it the things of the sowl shoold be preferred before all others of
this worldly life, yet nevertheless I will be content, so that you have as
great care and consideration of your conscience, as you have of your honor. All
which I was willing to tell you (sir) to the end you may better understand,
that those that are in estimation with the prince, though they may benefit by
time (in taking their time) yet time does never benefyt by them at all.

7 You must ever do good to your uttermost power, and never do dyspleasure to
any, though it lie in your power, and that you have just cause. For the tears
of the poor that are iniuryed, and the lamentable cries and playnts of the
oppressed, may possibly one day ascend to the presence of the tribunal seat
(where god shall sit in his majesty) demaundyng justice and vengeance against
you: and also come to the ears of the prince, to cause you to be hated of him
for ever.

8 Touching the favor you will show to any, either in offices, or other
benefits you will beestow on any man, take heed you always rather prefer
honest and true Christians, then your own near kynsmen or friends.

For a man may lawfully make his friend partaker of his goods, but not of his
conscience.

9 In your councels you geeue, in any wise be not to much affectioned in them,
neither scorn with those that contrary your oppinion. Be not proud and severe
to those you do command, neither do any thing without good aduyce and
consideration. For all beeit in princes courts every man does admire and
beehold the excellency and woorthynes of the person, yet are those always that
are most in favor of the Prince, more noted, regarded, and sooner accused then
others.

10 If you will not err in the counseils you shall geeue, nor fayl in those
things you enterprise: Embrace those that tell you the truth, and reject and
hate those, whom you know to be flatterers and dissemblers. For you shoold
rather desire to be admonished of the thing present, then counseled after the
damage received.

Although we suppose assuredly all these things above written are not lykely
to happen, nor come even so to pass as I have spoken: yet may yt please you
(sir) to remember they are not therefore impossible. For spiteful fortune
permits often times, that the sails which the lyghtnyng and boisterous
tempests could not break and tear in pieces, are afterward upon a soden,
(even in the sweet of the mornings sleep, each man taking his rest, leaving
the seas before in quiet calm) all to shyuered, and torn a sunder. He that
means to geeue another a blow also, the more he draws back his arm, with
greater force he strikes. And even so (neither more nor less) says fortune
with those, on whom for a time she smyleth. For the longer a man remains in
her love and favor, the more cruel and bitter she shows her self to him in
the end. And therefore I woold advise every wise and sage person, that when
fortune seems best of all to favor him, and to do most for him, that then he
should stand most in fear of her, and least trust her deceipts. Therefore
(Sir) make no small account of this my book, little though it be. For you
know, that doubtless (as experience teaches us) of greater price and value is a
little spark of a Dyamond, then a greater ballasse. It forces little that the
book be of small or great volume, sith thexcellency thereof consysteth not in
the number of leaves, more or less, but only in the good and grave sentences
that are amply written therein. For every author that writes, to make his
book of great price and show, ought to be brief in his words, and sweet and
pleasant in his matter he treats of, the better to satisfy ye mind of the
reader, and also not to be tedious to ye hearer. And (Sir) I speak not without
cause that you shoold not a little esteem this small treatise of mine, since
you are most assured, that with time al your things shall have end, your friends
shall leave you, your goods shall be divided, your self shall dye, your favor
and credyt shall dimynish, and those that succeed you, shall forget you, you
not knowing to whom your goods and patrimony shall come: and above all, you
shall not know what conditions your heirs and children shallbee of. But for
this I write in your Royal history and Chronicle of your lawdable virtues and
perfections, and for that also I serve you as I do with this my present woork,
the memory of you shall remain eternized to your Successors for ever. Chilo the
philosopher being demanded whether there were any thing in the world that
fortune had not power to bring to naught, answered in this sort. Two things
only there are, which neither time can consume, nor fortune distroy, and that
is: the renown of man written in books, and the verity that is hidden. For
allthough troth for a time lie interred, yet yt resurgeth again and receives
life, appearing manyfestly to all. And even so in like case the virtues we
find written of a man, do cause us at this present to have him in as great
veneration, as those had in his time that best knew him. Read therefore (Sir)
at times I beeseech you these wrytyngs of mine, allbeeit I fear me you can
scant borrow a moment of time with leisure once to look upon yt, being (as I
know you are) allways occupied in affairs of great importance, wherein me
thinks you shoold not so surcharge your self, but that you might for your
commodyty and recreacion of your spirits reserve some pryuat hours to your
self. For sage and wise men should not so burden them selves with care of
others toil, that they should not spend one hour of the day at the least (at
their pleasure) to look on their estate and condition. As recou^teth Suctonius
Tranquillus of Julius Caesar who notwythstandyng his quotydian wars he had,
never let slypt one day but that he read, or wrote some thing. So that being
in his Pauyllyon in the camp in the one hand he held his lance to assault his
enemy, and in the other the pen to write with all, with which he wrote his
worthy comentaries. The reasonable man therefore calling to mind the straight
account yt he must render of him self and of the time he has lost, shall
always be more careful that he lose not his time, then he shall be to keep
his treasure. For the well employed time is a mean and help to his salvation:
and the evil gotten good a cause of his eternal damnation. More over yet, what
toil and trauayl is it to the body of the man, and how much more peril to the
living soul, when he consumes his hole days and life in wordly broile: and
yet seely man he can not absent him self from that vile drudgery, till death
does sommon him to yield up his account of his lief and doings. And now to
conclude my prologue, I say this book is divided into two parts: yt is to
weete: in the first ten chapters is declared how the new come courtier shall
beehaue him self in the princes court to win favor and credit with the
prince: and the surplus of the woork treats, when he has atcheeued to his
princes favor, and acquired the credyt of a worthy courtier: how he shall then
continue the same to his further aduau^cement. And I doubt no whit, but that my
lords and gentlemen of court will take pleasure to read it, and namely such as
are princes familiars and beeloued of court shall mostly reap profyt thereby,
putting the good lessons and aduertisements they find heretofore written, in
execucion. For, to the young courtiers it shows them what they have to do:
and puts in remembrance also the old favored courtier (living in his
princes grace) of that he has to be circu^spect of. And finally I conclude
(sir) that of all the treasors, riches, gyfts, favors, prosperities, pleasures,
services, greatness, and power, that you have and possess in this mortal and
transitory life, and by ye faith of a christian I swear unto you also yt you
shall carry no more with you, then ye only time wc you have well and virtuously
employed, during this your pilgrimage.

The Argument of the book entitled the favored courtier, wheare the author
shows the intent of his woork, exhorting all men to read and study good and
virtuous books utterly reiectyng fables and vayn trifflyng stories of small
doctrine and erudicion.
AVlus Gelius in his book De noctibus atticis says, that after the death of
the great poet Homer, seven famous Cities of Greece were in great controversy
one with the other, each one of them affirmyng, that by reason the bones of the
said poet was theirs, and only apperteined to them, all seven taking their
oaths, that he was not only born, but also norished and brought up in every
one of them. And this they did, supposing that they never had so great honor in
any thing, but that this was far greater, to have educated so excellent and
rare a man as he was. Euripides also the philosopher, born and brought up in
Athens, trauayling in the realm of Macedonia, was suddenly stricken with death,
which woeful news no sooner came to the Athenians ears, (declared for a
troth) but with all expedicion they depeached an honorable imbasy, only to
entreat the Lacedaemonians to be contented to deliver them the bones of the
said philosopher, protesting to them, that if they woold franckly grant them,
they woold regratify that pleasure done them: and if they woold deny them, they
should assure them selves they woold come to demand them with sweord in hand.
King Demetrius held Rhodes beesyged long time (which at length he wanne by
force of arms) and the Rhodians being so stubborn that they would not yield
by composition, nor trust to his princely clemency, he commanded to strike of
all the Rhodians heads, and to raze the cyty to the hard foundacions. But when
he was let understand that there was even then in the cyty Prothogenes, a
philosopher and paynter, doutyng least in executyng others, he also unknown
might be put to the sweord, revoked his cruel sentence, and gave straight
commandment forthwith they should cease to spoil and deface the town
further, and also to stay the slaughter of the rest of the Rhodiens. The divine
Plato being in Athens, advertised that in the cyty of Damasco (in the realm
of Palestine) were certain books of great antiquity, which a philosopher born
of that country left beehynd him there: when he understood it to be true,
went thither immediately, led with the great desire he had to see them, and
purposely (if they did like him) afterward to buy them. And when he saw that
neither at his suit, nor at the requests of others he could obtein them, but
that he must buy them at a great price, Plato went and sold all his patrimony
to recover them: and his own not being sufficient, he was fayn to borrow upon
interest of the common treasory to help him. So that notwithstanding he was so
profound and rare a philosopher (as in deed he was) yet he woold sell all
that small substance he had, only to see (as he thought) some pretty new
thing more of philosophy. As Ptholomeus Philadelphus king of Egypt, not
contented to be so wise in all sciences as he was, nor to have in his
library.8000. books as he had, nor to study at the least.4. hours in the
day, nor ordinaryly to dispute at his meals with philosophers, sent
nevertheless an imbassage of noble men to the Ebrews, to desire them they woold
be contented to send him some of the best learned and wisest men among them, to
teach him the Ebrew tongue, and to read to him the books of their laws. When
Alexander the great was born, his father king Phillippe wrote a notable letter
immediately to Aristottle, and among other matters he wrote there were these. I
do thee to weete, O greatest philosopher Aristotle (if thou know it not)
that Olimpias my wife is brought to bed of a son, for wc incessantly I geeue
the gods immortal thanks: not so much yt I have a son, as for that they have
geeuen him me in thy time. For I am assured he shall profit more with the
doctrine thou shall teach him: the^ he shall preuail with the kingdoms I shall
leave him after me. Now by the examples above recited, and by many more we
coold allege, we may easly consider, with what reverence and honor the ancient
kings used the learned and virtuous men of their time. And we may also more
plainly see it, sith then they held in greater price and estimacion the bones
of a dead philosopher, then they do now the doctrine of the best learned of
our time. And not without just occasion did these famous and heroycal princes
joy, to have at home in their houses, and abroad with them in the feeld, such
wise and learned men whilst they lived, and after they were dead to honor their
bones and carcases: and in doing this they erred not a jot. For who so ever
accompanies continually with grave and wise men, enjoys this benefit and
privilege before others, that he shall never be counted ignorant of any.
Therefore continuing still our first purpose, let us say, that who so ever will
profess the company of sober and wise men, yt can not otherwise be, but he
must maruelously profyt by their comapny. For being in their company they will
put all vain and dishonest thoughts from him, they will teach him to subdue and
resyst all sodein passions and motions moved of choler: by them they shall
win good friends, and learn also never to be troublesome or enemy to any,
they will make him forsake all sin and vice, declaring to him what good
woorks he shall follow, and what he shall most fly and eschew: they will let
him understand how he shall humble and beehaue him self in prosperity, and
they will also comfort him in his adversity, to keep him from all sorrow and
despair. For though a man be never so careful and circumspect, yet has he
always need of the council of an other in his affairs, if therefore such
person have not about him good virtuous, and sage men, how can it otherways be
but that he must stumble often, and fall down right on his face, having no man
to aid or help him. Paulus Diaconus says, that albeeit the Affricans were
wild and brutish people, yet had they withstandyng a law amongst them, that
the senators amongst them coold choose no other senator, if at the election
there were not present a philosopher. So it happened one day amongst the rest,
that of many philosophers they had in Carthage, amongst them was one named
Apolonius: Who ruled for the space of three score and two years all their senate
with great quiet, and to the contentacion of all the senators: which to show
them selves thankful to him, erected in the market place so many images of
him, as he had governed their common weal years, to the end the fame and
memory of him should be immortal: and yet they did dedycate to their famous
Anniball but only one image, and to this philosopher they set up above three
score. Alexander ye great when he was most bent to bluddy wars, went to see
and speak with Diogenes the philosoper, offering him great presents, and
discoursyng with him of diverse matters. So that we may justly say, this good
prince of him self took payns to seek out wise men to accompany him, electing
by others choice and advise all such, as he made his captayns to serve him in
the wars: It is manifest to all, that Dionisius the Siracusan was the
greatest tyrant in the world, and yet notwithstanding his tyranny, it is a
wonder to see the sage and wise men he had continually in his court with him:
and that, that makes us yet more to wonder of him is, that he had them not
about him to serve him, or to profyt one jot by their doctrine and council:
but only for his honor, and their profyt, which enforces me to say,
concurring with this example, that sith tyrants did glory to have about them
wise, and worthy men: much more shoold those rejoice, that in their woorks and
deeds are noble, and free hearted. And this they ought to do, not only to be
honored with them openly, but also to be helped with their doctrine and
councels secretly. And if to some this shoold seem a hard thing to follow, we
will say: that worthy men not being of ability and power to mainteyn such
wise men, ought yet at least to use to read at times, good and virtuous books.
For by readyng of books, they reap infynyt profyt, as for example, by readyng
as I say these good authors, the desire is satisfied, their judgment is
quickened idleness is put away, the heart is disburdened, the time is well
employed, and they lead their life virtuously, not being bound to render
account of so many faults, as in that time they might have committed. And to
conclude, it is so good an exercise, as it geeueth good examples to the
neyghbor, profyt to him self, and health to the soul. We see by experience,
after a man takes upon him once the study of holy scriptures, and that he
frames him self to be a divine, he will never wyllyngly thencefoorth deal
in other studies, and all because he will not forgo the great pleasure he
receives to read those holly sayyngs. And that causes, that we see so many
learned and wise men (for the more part) subject to diverse diseases, and full
of melancoly humors. For so sweet is the delight they take in their books,
that they forget and leave al other bodily pleasure: And therefore Plutarke
writes, that certain Philosophers being one day met at the lodgyng of Plato
to see him, and demau^dyng him what exercise he had at that time: Plato
answered them thus. Truly my brethern I let you know, that even now my only
exercise was to see what the great poet Homer said. And this he told them,
because they took him even then readyng of some of Homers books, and to say
truly, his answer was such, as they shoold all look for of him. For to read a
good book in effect is nothing else, but to hear a wise man speak. And if this
our judgment and advise seem good unto you, we would yet say more, that you
shoold profyt more to read one of these books, then you should to hear speak,
or to have conference with the author him self that made yt. For it is without
doubt, that all writers have more care and respect in that their pen does
write, then they have in yt their tongue does utter. And to the end you should
not thynk we can not prove that true that we have spoken, I do you to wit,
that every author that will write, to publysh his dooyng in prynt, to lay yt to
the show and judgment of the world, and that desires thereby to acquire honor
and fame, and to eternyse the memory of him, turns many books, conferreth
with other wise and learned men, addycteth him self wholly to his book
indeuoureth to understand well, often refuses sleep, meat and drynk, quyckneth
his spyrits, dooyng that he puts in writing exactly with long advise, and
consideracion: which he does not, when he does but only speak and utter
them, though often in deed (by reason of his great knowledge) in speech unawares
there falls out of his mouth, many goodly and wise sentences. And therefore
god has geeuen him a goodly gift that can read, and him much more that has a
desire to studdy, knowing how to choose the good books from the evil. For to
say the troth, there is not in this world any state or exercise more honorable,
and profitable then the study of good books. And we are much bound to those
that read, more to those that study, and much more to those that write any
thing, but mostly doubtless to those that make and compile goodly books, and
those of great and hye doctrine. For there are many vayn and fond books, that
rather deserve to be thrown in the fire, then once to be read or looked on.
For they do not only show us the way to mock the^, but also ye ready mean to
offend us, to see them occupy their brayns and best wits they have to write
foolish and vayn things, of no good subject or erudicion. And yt that is woorst
of al yet, they are occasion that diverse others spend as much time in readyng
their jests, and mockries, as they woold otherwise have employed in doctrine,
of great profyt and edifying, the which to excuse and defend their error, say
they did not write them for men to take profyt thereby, but only to delight
and please the readers, to pass the time away meryly. Whom we may rightly
answer thus: that the readyng of ill and vayn books can not be called a
pastime, but aptly a very loss of time. And therefore Aulus Gellius in the
fyfteenth of his book writes, that after the romans understood the orators
and poets of Rome did geeue them selves to write, vain, voluptuous, and
dishonest books, causing enterludes, and poetical commedies to be played,
they did not only banysh them from Rome, but also out of al ye parts of Italy.
For yt he seemed not the Romayn grauyty, neither was it decent for the weal
publyk, to suffer such naughty books among them, and much less to bear with
vicious and lascivious governors. And if the Romain paynyms left us this for
example, how much more ought we that are christians to continue and follow yt,
since they had no other books to read save only histories, and we now a days
have both histories and holy scriptures to read which were granted us by the
church, to the end by the one we might take some honest pleasure and
recreation, and with the other procure the health of our souls. O how far is
the common wealth now a days dygressed from ye we write and counsel, sense we
see plainly, that men occupy them selves at this present, in readyng a number
of books, the which only to name I am ashamed. And therefore said Aulus
Gellius in his forteenth book, that there was a certain philosopher wrote a
book of hye and eloquent style, but the subject very hard and dyffuse to
understand, the which Socrates and other philosophers hearing of, commaundid
immediately the book to be burned, and the author to be banyshed, by which
example we may well perceive, that in that so perfyt and reformed vniuersyty
they woold not only suffer any lascivious or vicious book, but also they
woold not bear with those, that were to hawty and vayn glorious in their
styles, and whose matter were not profitable and benefyciall to the publyk
weal. That man therefore that walloweth in idleness lap, and that vouchsafes
not to spend one hour of the day to read a grave sentence of some good book,
we may rather deservedly call him a brute beast, then a reasonable creature.
For every wise man ought to glory more of the knowledge he has, then of the
abundance of goods he possesses. And it can not be denied but that those
which read virtuous books, are ever had in better favor and estimacion then
others. For they learn to speak, they pass the time without trouble, they know
many pleasant things which they after tell to other, they have audacyty to
reprove others: and every man delyteth to hear them, and in what place or
company so ever they come, they are always reverenced and honored above others:
every man desires their knowledge and acquaintance, and are glad to ask them
council. And that, that is yet of greater credyt to them is, that they are not
few in number, that trusts them with their body and goods. And moreover I
say, that the wise and learned man which professes study, shall know very well
how to council his friend, and to comfort him self at all times when need does
serve, which the foolysh ignorant person can not do, for he can not only
tell how to comfort the afflycted in adversity, but also he can not help him
self in his own proper affairs, nor take council of him self what is best to
do. But retorning again to our purpose, we say, because we woold not be
reproved of that we rebuke others of, we have been very cyrcumspect and
advised, and taken great care and payns in our studdy, that al our books and
works we have publyshed and compiled, should be so exactly done, that the
readers might not find any ill doctrine, nor also any thing worthy reproof.
For the dishonest books made by lascivious persons do geeue (deservedly)
evident token to the readers to suspect the autors, and troubles the
judgments of those that geeue attentyue ear unto them. And therefore I
council, and admonish him that will enterprise and take upon him to be a
writer, and setter forth of books, that he be wise in his matter he
shows, and compe^dious in the words he writes: and not to be like to
diverse writers, whose woorks are of such a frase and style, as we shall read
many times to the midst of the book, ere we find one good and notable
sentence, so that a man may say, that all the fruit those reap for their pain,
watches, and trauayl, is no other, but only a mere toy and mockry, they
being derided of every man that sees their woorks. That author that
undertakes to write, and afterward prostrateth to common judgment the thing
he writes, may be assured that he sets his wits to great traueyl and
study, and hasardeth his honor to present peril. For the judgment of men
being varyable, and diverse (as they are in deed) many times they do meddle
and enter into judgment of those things, whereof they are not only not
capable to understand, but also less skylfull to read them. Now in the book
we have set out of ye dyal of princes, and in that other we have translated
of the life of the romayn emperors, and in this we have now set forth of the
favored courtier, the readers may be assured they shall find in the^ goodly and
grave sentences, whereby they may greatly profyt, and they shall not read any
words superfluous, to comber or weery them at all. For we did not once
license our pen to dare to write any word, that was not first waied in true
balance, and meat by just measure. And God can testify with us, that without
doubt we have had more pain to be brief in the words of our books we have
hitherto made, then we have had to gather out the invention and grave
sentences thereof. For to speak good words, and to have good matter and wise
purposes, is the poperty of one that naturally is modest, and grave in his
actions: but to write breefely, he must have a deep understanding. When at
the font of the printers foorme we first baptized the book of Marcus
Aurelius, we there entitled it the Dyal of princes, and this therefore that
we have now made and added to yt, we will call yt (for more breefenesse) the
favored courtier: which portendeth the whetstone and instructyon of a courtier.
For if they will vouchsafe to read, and take the fruitful counsels they find
written herein, they may assure them selves they shall awake out of the
vanyties they have long slept in, and shall also open their eyes, to see the
better that thing wherein they live so long deceived. And allbeeyt in deed
this present woork shows to you but a few contrived lines, yet god him self
does know, the payns we have taken herein has been exceedyng great, and this
for two causes: the one for that the matter is very strange and diverse from
others, the other, to thynk that assuredly it should be hated of those, that
want the taste of good discypline. And therefore we have taken great care, it
should come out of our hands well refoormed, and corrected: to the end that
courtiers might find out many sentences in yt profitable for the^, and not one
word to trouble them. Those noble men or gentlemen that will from henceforth
have their children brought up in princes courts, shall find in this kooke all
things they shall need to provide them of, those also that have been long
courtiers, shall find all that they ought to do in court, And such also as are
the best favored of princes, and carry greatest reputacion of honor with them,
shall find likewise excellent good counsels, by mean whereof they may always
maynteyn, and continue them selves, in the cheifest greatness of their credit
and favor: so that it may well be called a mitridatical electuary, recuering
and healing all malignaunt opilations. Of all the books I have hitherto
compyled, I have dedicated some of them to the Imperial majesty, and others to
those of best favor and credit with him: where ye readers may see, yt I rather
glory to be a satire, then a flatterer, for that in all my sentences they can
not find one cloked word, to enlarge and imbetter my credit and estate. But to
the contrary, they may read an infynyt number of others, where I do exhort
them to govern their persons discreetly and honorably, and to amend their lives
thencefoorth. When I imprinted the Dyal of princes, together with Marcus
Aurelius, and brought them to light, I wanted not backbyters and detracters
that beeganne forthwith to tear me in pieces, neither shall I want at this
present (as I beeleeue) such as will not spare with venomus tongues to poison
my woork. But like as then I little wayd their sclaunderous speeches of me,
even so much less do I now force what they can say against me, being
assured they shall find in the end, they have ill spoken of me, and my poor
woorks, proceedyng from them rather of a certain envy that gnaweth their heart,
then of any default they find in my doctrine: comforting my self yet in the
assurance I have, yt al their spite shall one day have an end, and my woorks
shall ever be found good and perdurable.

Here ends the Argument.
The fourth book of the Dyall of Princes, Compiled by the Lord Antony Gueuara,
Bishop of Mondogueto.
That it is more necessary for the courtyer (abydyng in court) to be of lively
spirit and audacity, then it is for the souldior, that goes to serve in the
wars. Cap. i.
PLutarch, Pliny, and Titus Liuius declare, that king Agiges one day requested
the oracle of Appollo to tell him, who was the happiest man in the world, to
whom answer was made that it was a man they called Aglaon, be known of the
gods, and unknown of men. This king Agiges making then search for this man
thorough all Greece, who was called Aglaon, found at length that it was a poor
gardyner dwelling in Archadia, who being of the age of three score years and
two, never went above a mile from his house, keepyng him self and his famyly
contynually with his only labor and tyllage of his gardeyn. Now all be it
there were in the world of better parentage and lynage then he, better
accompanied of servant and tenaunts, better provided of goods and riches,
higher in dygnyty, and of greater authoryty then he: yet for all this, was
this Aglaon the happyest of the world. And this was, for that he never haunted
Princes courts, neither by envy to be overthrown, nor yet by auaryce to be
overcome. For many times it chances to men, that when they would least geeue
them selves to acquayntaunce, then come they most to be known, and when they
make least account of them selves, then comes there an occasyon to make them
to be most reputed of. For they win more honor, that dispyse these goods,
honors, and riches of this world: then those do, that continually gape, and
seek after the same. And therefore we should more envy Aglaon with his little
gardeyn, then Alexander the great with his mighty Asia. For true contentacion
consysteth not in having abundance, but in being contented with that little
he has. Yt is a mockry, and woorthely he deserves to be laughed at, that
thinks contentacion lies in having much, or in being of great authoryty:
for such ways are redyer to make us stumble, yea and many times to fall down
right, then safly to assure us to go on our way.

The punishment that God gave to Cain for murderyng of his brother Abel was,
that his body contynually trembled, and he ever after wandered thorough the
world: so that he never found ground wheare he might enhabyt, nor house where
he might herber. And albeeit this malediction of Cain was the first that ever
god ordained, I durst affirm notwythstandyng that it remains as yet until
this present day amongst courtyers, sith we see them daily traueyle and run
into strange countries, daily chaungyng and seeking new lodgyngs. Which makes
me once again to say, yt Aglaon was counted happy, and for yt only he never
romed far from his house. For to say truly, there is no mysery comparable to
that of the courtier, that is bound daily to lie in others howses, having none
of his own to go too. And he only may be called happy, that puts not him
self in danger to serve others. Julius Caesar being councelled to wayt upon
the consul Silla, to the end that by seruyng or being about him he might do
him self great good, and yt might be very profitable to him, answered thus. I
swear by the immortal gods I will never serve any, on hope to be more
worth, and greater then I am. For this I am suer of, that where lyberty is
exiled, there might nor power can prevail.

He that forsakes his own country where he lived at ease, and in health,
and the place where he was known and beeloued, the neyghbors of whom he was
visyted, the friends of whom he was served, the parents of whom he was
honored, the goods wherewith he mayntayned him self, his wife and children (of
whom he had a thousand pleasures and consolations) and that comes to serve
and dye in the court: I can not say otherwise of him, but that he is a very
fool, or that he comes to do penance for some notable crime he has
committed. And therefore not without great cause was this name of court (which
in our tongue sygnyfyeth short) adhibited to the palace of princes, where all
things in deed are short, only envy and malice excepted, which continue long.
He only desires to be a courtier, that as yet has not tasted the sweetenes
and pleasure of his own house, nor has yet proved and seen the troubles and
payns of the court. For he yt knows them, sygheth when he is called to the
court, and weepeth when he is kept long there. I have studied in times past in
the universities, preached in the court, praying in relygion: and now I dwell
upon my byshopryck, teaching and Instructyng my dyocessans: but I dare say, of
all these four states recyted, there is none so straight, and paynfull, as is
to follow the court. If I studied at the vniuersyty, I did yt of free will to
be wyser: but only in the court I spent my time, to be more worth then I
was. But the greatest time I consumed in religyon, was to say my prayers, and
to beewayle my grievous sins. In the court I only gave my self to suspect my
neyghbor, and invented to buyld great castells of wynd (with thought) in the
air. And therefore I retorn once again to say, that it is a greater trouble to
beecome a courtier, then to be a relygious person. For in religion it
suffices to obey one: but in the court he must serve all. And in relygion
also they are appareled with less cost and charges, and to the greater
contentacion of the person, then they are in the court. For a poor gentleman
courtyer is bound to have more change and suits of apparel, then the falcon
feathers. The religious persons go allways to dynner, and find their meat on
the table ready prepared for them, without any thought taken of their part what
they shall have: but fine courtiers many times rise out of their bed, without
ever a penny in their purse. And allbeeit relygious persons all their life take
great payns in rysyng at mydnyght to serve god: yet have they great hope after
their death, of the heavenly rest and comfort: but poor courtyers, alas what
should I say, hard is their life, and more peryllous their death, into greater
danger truly puts he him self that beecommeth a courtyer, then did Nasica
when he was with the serpent, then king David with the Phylistiens, then the
Southsayers with Euah, then Hercules with Antheon, then Theseus with the
Minotawre, then king Menelaus with the wild bore, then Corebus with the
monster of the marysh, and then Perseus with the monsterous whale of the sea.
For every one of these valiant men were not afraid but of one: but the
miserable courtyer stands in fear of all. For what is he in court, yt
seeing his near kynsman or dearest friend, more in favor or credyt then him
self, or rycher then he, that wysheth not his friends death, or at the least
procures by all means he can, he shall not equal, nor go even with him in
credyt or reputacyon. One of the woorst things I consider and see in courtyers
is, that they lose much time, and profyt little: For the thing wherein they
spend their days, and beestow the nights for the more part is, to speak ill of
those that are their betters, or excel them in virtues: and to undo those
that are their equals and compaignyons: to flatter the beeloued, and among the
inferior sort to murmr one against an other, and allways to lament and sygh
for the times past.

And there is nothing that provoke courtyers more to complayn, then the daily
desire they have to see sundry and new alteracions of time. For they little way
the ruyn of ye common weal, so they may enlarge and exalt their own estates.
Also it is a thing of course in court, that the rejected and fauorlesse
couctyers shole togethers, murmuryng at their princes, and backbytyng their
councellers and officers, saying they undo the realm, and bring all to
naught. And all this presupposed, for that they are not in the like favor and
estimacion that they be in, which bears office and rule in the common weal.
And therefore when it comes in questyon for a courtyer to advance him self,
and to come in credyt in the court, one courtyer can scarsly ever trust an
other. On the other side, me thinks that the life of the court is not the very
life in deed, but rather an open penance. And therefore in my oppinion, we
should not reckon courtyers alive, but rather dead, buried in their life. For
then the courtier ever fyndeth him self panged with deaths extreme passions,
when he perceyueth an other to be preferred and called before him. Alas,
what great pyty it is to see a hapless and unfortunate courtier, for he seely
soul awaketh a thousand times in the night, tosseth from side to side of his
bed, sometime upright he lies, lamentyng his Iron hap, now he sigheth for
his native soil, and sorroweth then for his lost honor: so that in manner he
spends the whole night in watch and cares, imaginyng with him self all ways
he can, to come in credyt and favor again, that he may attain to wealth and
prefarment before others, wc makes me think, yt it is not a pain, but a
cruel torment: no service but tribut: and not once only, but ever: that the
body of the poor miserable courtier abides and that (in despyte of him) his
wretched heart does bear. By the law of the court, every courtyer is bound to
serve the king, to accompany the beeloued of court, to visit noble men, to wayt
upon those that are at the princes elbow, to geeue to the ushers, to present
the auditors, to entertaigne the wardens and captayns of the ports, to currey
favor with the herbingers, to flatter the treasorers, to trauayl and speak for
their friends, and to dyssemble amongst their enemies. What legs are able to
do all these things? what force sufficient to abide these brunts? what heart
able to endure them? and more over what purse great enough to supply all these
deuyses? I am of opinion there was never any so foolysh, nor merchant so
covetous, that has sold him self in any fair, or corst him self for any other
marchaundise, but only the unhappy courtier, who goes to the court to sell
his lyberty, for a little wynd and vayn smoke of the court. I grant that a
courtier may have in the court plenty of gold and silver, sumptuous apparel,
favor, credyt, and authority: yet with all this abundaunce ye can not deny me,
but he is as poor of lyberty, as rych of substance or credyt. And therefore
I dare boldly say this word again, that for one time the courtier has his
desire in court, a thousand times they will enforce him to accomplish others
desires, which neither please nor like him. Surely it comes of a base and
vile mind, and no less cowardly, for any man lightly to esteem his lyberty,
and fondly to embrace bondage and subjection, being at others commandment.
And if the courtier woold answer me to this, that though he serve, yet at
least he is in his princes favor. I woold reply thus, though he be in favor
with the prince, yet is he notwithstanding slave to all his other officers.
For if ye courtyer will sell his horse, his moyle, his cloak, his sweord, or
any other such like whatsoever he shall have ready money for all, saving for his
lyberty, which he lyberally bestows on all for nothing. So that he seems
to make more estimate of his sweord, or apparel he sells, then he does of
his lyberty which he geeueth. For a man is not bound to trauail at all, (to
make him self master of others) more then pleases him: but to recover lyberty,
or to mayntayn it, he is bound to dye a thousand deaths. I speak not these
things for that I have read them in my books, but because I have seen them
all with mine eyes: and not by science, but by experience: and I never knew
courtyer yet content in court, much less enjoying any jot of his lyberty,
which I so much esteem, that if al men were sufficient to know it, and knew
well how to use it, he woold never for any treasure on earth forgo yt, neither
for any gage lend yt, were it never so precious. Yet is there in court beesides
this an other kind of trouble I have not yet touched, and that is not small.
For often times thither comes of our friends which be strangers, whom of
necessyty, and for honesties sake, the courtier must lodge with him at home, ye
court being all ready full pestered. And this happens often in such a time,
when the poor courtier has neither lodging of his own, to lodge them in: nor
happily six pence in his purse to welcome them with all. I woold you woold tell
me also, what grief and sorrow the poor courtier feels at his heart, when
he lodges in a blind narrow lane, eats at a borrowed table, sleeps in a
hiered bed, his chamber having no door to it, yea and forth more part his
apparel and armor, even to the very sweord in gage. Then when any friend of his
comes out of the country to lie with him he being so poor, and also a
stranger in another man's house: how is it possible he shoold accept into his
company any others, and perhaps as nedie as he? Sometimes he were better, and
had rather bear his friends costs, and charges (being altogether unable) yea
and find him al his necessaries (what shift so ever he made) then he should
suffer his friend or stranger to come home to his house to know and see the
mysery he lives in. For more is the honest heart and good nature ashamed and
grieved to discover his mysery, then yt is to suffer and abide yt. Commonly the
courtier being alone is content with a little couch, one mattresse or quilt,
one flockbed, with one pillow, and one payr of sheets, with one couerlet, with
one frieng pan, one gridyerne, one spitt, one kettel one basen, with one
candelstick, and with one pott, which he can not do, if any stranger or
friend of his come to him, for then he must for his reputacion sake hang his
chamber, dress up his bed, and furnish yt better, and must also provide for a
thousand other such trifles he stands in need of. And if it fall out his
host and goodman of the house will not lend him these things, or that perhaps
he has them not (as it chances often) he shall be compelled to borow upon a
gage, or to hier of others: whereas if he were alone with his own people, he
would right well be contented with his small ordinary. And when a stranger
comes to seee him, he must be at greater cost and charges: so that he shall
spend more at one dinner, or supper, then he had done before in three days.
And therefore dowtles the courtiers are at more charges with their friends yt come
to see them, then they are with them selves. For the honorable and worthy
courtiers had rather fast an other time, the^ to show him self at this pinch
needy and hard, and to be mocked of his acquaintance. O, how many men are
there in the world that spend in one day all that they have traueled to get
togethers in many? not for yt they esteem not their goods, and desire not to
keep then: but only for a little vain glory, to get the^ ye name of a free
hearted and liberal man, dealing honestly among his friends. Also as great is ye
troble to ye poor courtier when ye court remoueth often from place to place. For
the^ he must trusse up his bagage, lode ye moyls, and hier carts to carry yt,
afterward pray the cofferer to pay him, the harbingers to prepare him a
lodging, and then he must first send one of his men to see if the lodging be
meet for him: furthermore courtiers have occasion oftymes to be angry with
the carters and muletters, for loding to much or to little, and for coming too
late to the lodging, and many times also they must tide at noone days, and in
the greatist heat and somtymes in rain, dew, tempest, or in other ill
weather (what so ever yt be) for that the carters and cariers will not lose
their iorny. And admit that all this may be easily carried, is it therefore
reasonable, or meet, the poor courtier should spend at one vyage or removing
of the court, all the profit and spare he has made in sir months before?
And what shall we say also, of the stuff and moueables that the poor courtier
of necessity must buy in every place where the court remains, as chaiers,
tables, forms, stools, water potts, platters, disshes, and other small
trasshery that would cost more the carriage, then the buyng of them a new. and
to conclude, al things pertaining to court are paynfull, unpleasant, and
chargeable for the poor courtier. For if he should carry always with him, al
such things as be necessary, and that he should need: in carriage they are
broken or mard, or being left beehind, they are in hasard to be stolen or
lost. For he that will be a continual courtier, must be of a bold and stowt
courage. For he shalbeee forced howerly to leave of his own desiers, to
please and content others, changing and shifting to diverse places and
strange lodgings, and ofttymes, of servants and new family, daily increasing
his charge and expense. And truly if that which is gotten and gained in court
be worth much: much more does that exceed that is spent in court, and these
expenses are rather lauishe, then moderat: disordered, then well spent, for in
effect courtiers spend more, with strangers they receive into their lodgings,
then they do with their ordinary servants they keep. Albeeit that, that
courtiers lose and leave beehind them at every removing of the court be but of
small account or importance, yet is it notwithstanding both grief, and
displeasure to them. For in deed there is no house so richly furnished, and
replenished with moueables, but that the lord or master of the house will chase
to see a disshe or glass broken, or spoiled. Yet there is an other discomodity
in removing of the court, for some courtiers there are that be so poor, that
for want they can hardli follow the court, and others also that are rych, are
compelled to bear many of their charges with whom they are in company with by
the way: and some of those are so rude, and ill brought up, that they had
rather bear their charge al their iourny, then once again to have them in
their company. But a godsname what shall we say yet of the wretched courtier
whose coffers, and horse are arrested at his departing for his debts? Truly I
ly not, for once I saw a courtiers moyle sold for her prouinder she had
eaten, and that money not sufficient to pay the host: the courtier remaining yet
detter of an overplus, the poor man was stripped even of his cappe and gloves
for satisfaction of the rest. Also there is an other sort of needy courtiers,
so troblesome, and importune, that they never cease to troble their friends, to
borow money of their acquayntance, soome to find themselves, soome to apparel
them selves, others to pay their dets, others to play, and others to geeue
presents so that at the removing day, when they have nothing wherewith to pay
nor content their crediters, then are they sued in law, and arrested in their
lodging, and the credyters many times are not satisfied with their goods, but
take execution also of their bodies, laying them in fast prison, till they be
paid and satisfied of their whole dett. O what a folly may be thought in
those, that cannot moderat their expenses according to their ability? For to
say uprightly, he should cut his garments according to his cloth, and measure
his expenses with his revenues, and not followyng his affection and desire. For
the gentleman, or courtier, in the end has not the mean nor commodity to
spend as the contry man has, that lives at home at ease in his contry, and
spe^deth such commodityes as he brings into his house, but the courtier
consumes in court not his own alone, but also that of others. And therefore in
court or else where, let every wise man be diligent to bring his affairs to
end: but yet let him so moderate and use his expenses, as he shall not need,
nor be driven to morgage and gage that he has. For he that feasteth, and
rowteth with others purse of that that is lent him, cannot choose but in the
end he must break, and deceive his crediters. Therefore all worthy men that
love their honor, and fear reproach, ought rather to suffer honger, cold,
thirst, care, pain and sorrow: then to be had in the check roll, of riotous
and prodigal spenders, trustles of their promise, and suspected of their
words. There is yet an other great troble in the court of princes, and that is
the exceeding derth of vittels, the unreasonable want of howses, and the great
price of horses, for many times they spend more for straw, and litter for their
horse, then they do in other places for hey, otes, and bread. And further if
the courtier be a poor gentillman, and that he would feast and bancket his
friends or companions, he shall spend at one dinner or supper so much that he
shall be constrained to fast a hole week after. Therefore if the courtier will be
well used in following of the court, he must not only know, and speak too, but
also love, and inuit at times the bouchers, vittlers, fruterers, keepers, and
softers, Fishmongers, and poulterers, and other purueiers of the same, of who^e
he shall always have as much need of his provision, as he shall have of the
judges, to show him Justice when he shall need it. For meat, bread, wine,
wood hey, otes, and straw, are como^ly very dear in court: For few of al
these things are to be bought in court, but of others infinite things to be
sold, to profit and gain the poor courtiers, that else had no shyft to live.
And yet is there a little more trouble in court, and that is, that continually
letters are sent to the courtier from his friends, to obtain of the prince or
his counsel his dispatch in his private affairs, or for his servants or
tenants, or other his friends. And many times these suits are so ill welcome to
the courtier, that he had rather have pleasured his friend with a piece of
money, then they should have laid upon him so weighty a matter. And beesides
this there is yet an other troble, that the bringet of the letter must needs
ly at the courtiers house attending his dispatch, so that the courtier delaiyng
his friends business, augmenteth his grief, and keeping the messenger there,
increases his charge. And if perchanse his business be not dispatched, and the
suit obtained, those that wrote to him will not think he left it of, for that
be would not do it or take pains therein: but for that he wanted favor and
credit, or at least were very negligent in following their cause. And that that
vexes them thoroughly yet is, that their parents and friends ween (which are in
the contry far from court) that this courtier has all the courtiers at his
commandment, that he may say, and do what he will there. And therefore his
friends, when they have occasion to imploie him in court, and that they write to
him touching their affairs, and that he has now taken upon him the charge
and burden of the same, seeing him self after unable to discharge that he
has enterprised, and can not as he would satisfy his friends expectacion:
then he faleth to despair, and wissheth he had been dead when he first
took upon him this matter, and that he made them beeleeue he could go
thorough with that they had committed to him, being impossible for him, having
small credit and estimation amongst the nobility and councellers.

Therefore I would never council him that has brethern, friends, or other
near kynsfolks in court, to go seek them out there, albeeyt they had matters
of great weight and importance, on hope to be dispatched the sooner by their
credit, favor, and suit: and for this cause, for that in court there is ever
more privy malice, and Envy then in other places: wherefore they can not be
revenged one of the other, but must tarry a time, and then when they see
opportunity, they set in foot to overthrow, and secretly to put back their
enemies suit. Now lo, these things, and other infinite plagues do light on
these poor unfortunate courtiers, incredible happily to any but the old and
experienced courtier. If the old and wise courtier would count all the favors
and mischances, the derth and abundance, the frendships and enmities, the
contentation and displeasures, and the honor and infamy he has endured in the
court, I beeleeue assuredly we should not be a little sorry for that body that
had suffryd so much, but much more for that heart that had abidden al those
storms and broyls. When the courtier sees that he is not hard of the prince,
nor spoken to of the beloved and favored of the court, and that the tresorer
does not dispatch him, and ye coferer keep back his wages, it is a misery to
see him, and on the other side a pleasure and pastime to here what he says,
cursing the wretched life of this world. And even then in his heat and rage he
teareth and blasphemeth god, and swears accursedly, that thenceforth he will
forsake the vain abuses of court, and leave also the trompries of ye deceitful
world, auowing to enclose him self in precinct of religious wales, and to take
upon him also religious habit. Alas if I fetched as mani sighs for my sins,
as courtiers do for their mishaps and disgraces: what a number would they come
to? For a courtier, incontinent that he feels him self sick, that he is
alone, and rejected of his friends in court, he beecometh so heavy and
pensive, that with his deep sighs he priceth the heavens on hye: and with his
flowing tears he moysteth the earth beelowe: So that a man might more easily
number the trobles of the stowt and harby Hercules, then those which the
courtier daily suffers. And beesides those many we have recited, yet
further, these also we can recite, that their servants rob them, their
purseberers consume their money, iesters and counterfeit knaves ly ever upon
their reward, woomen pick their purses, and strompets and bawds spoil them of
all. But what shall I say more to you. If the poor courtier be full of
feathers, every man plumes him: but if he want whings, there is no man hasty
to plume him: and to conclude, in princes court you shall find no such trade of
life, whereby you may satisfy every man. For if the courtier speak litel, they
will say he is but a fool, and if he be to large of tongue, they will say he
is a glorious fool, if he be free in expenses, they will say he is a
prodigal fool, if he be scarce of his purse, they will say he is a
covetous miser, if he be alone, and solitary at home, they will account him
an hypocrite: and if he visit others often, they will say he is a bold and
troblesome man, if he have any train of men following on him, they will say
he is a proud man: and if he go without company, that he is poor, and
miserable. So that of court, this may rightly be said. That it is a very
theather, wheare one mocketh and grinneth at an other, and yet in the end they
(al in manner) find them selves scorned and deceived. Now discursing also of
sleep, does the courtier alweys sleep as much as he will? no suer, but as much
as he may. And touching his meat, has he always that he lyketh? no truly:
but he is forced to be contented with that he has. And as for his apparel,
is he clothed according to his wise no no: but according to others fancies. O
unhappy courtier, that spendith the most part of his miserable life, in coming
his head, washing his beard, wearing fair and brave hose, varnishing his sword
and dagger, blacking his boots, providing him of clokes, bying him cappes,
furring him gowns, and sitting him self with other small and needful
trifles: wasting in them all his own goods, and that of his friends. I am not
of that mind and opinion that others are, that say there are none in so great
liberty as courtiers be, which should not be said, and much less credited,
since we see by daily proof: if they be in service, they are as sclaues. If
they be not in service with the king, or other nobleman, they live in poor
estate. Now let every man say what he will: wheare poverty reigns, there
liberty can have no place. And there is nothing in ye world herer, the^ that
we buy with entreaty and not with many. And therefore we must confess, that
princes courts are meeter to exercise the youth, then for the aged to live
there without rest. For young men have more hardines, to away with the pains
and trobles of the court: then they have years, to seek the greefes and
displeasures they receive thereby. Now go to the court that list, procure
office and auctority that will: for hither to I never met or spoke with man that
was contentid with the court. For if he be crept in favor he fears every
hour to fall, and lose his credit, if ever he be once out of favor, and in
disgrase, he dispayreth he shall never return again into favor, and if he
that goes to the sea commits him self first to god before he take
ship: much more ought he to do yt that goes to dwell in court: For in the
sea, of a C, ships there do not perish te^ne: but in ye court, of a.1000.
courtiers, there comes not three in favor.

Of courtiers brawles and quarells with the harbingers for ill lodging. Cap. ii.
AFter Lucullus the roman his return from Asia, in an oration he made before
the senate, he said thus: I swear unto you by ye Imortal gods (fathers
conscript) that in all this my journey I felt no pain, nor troble, nether for
the conduct and government of mine army, nor for the rebellion of the people,
nor for the absence of my friends, nor for the war of ye enemies, nether for
the long time, nor yet for the peril of my life. For all these things are
incident to soldiors and men of war, and common to rulers in peace. But if you
be desirous to know what was my troble, and that that grieved me most, yt was
on the remembrance of the quiet rest I had at home. For as you know right well
(sacred senate) during ye time a man lodges in other men's howses he is never
at liberty. And this word of Lucullus me thinks every courtier might well
apply to him self, for that he is always bound to do service to the master
of the house wheare he lodges, yea although he receive a 1000. injuries of
him, yet therefore it is not lawful for him to anger or displease him in any
thing. Therefore in very il and unlucky hour is the courtier arrived, when he
must take his journey in stead of rest, travail for quietness, mysery for
abundance, bondage for liberty, and pain for pleasor, and albeeit courtiers
abide many pains and trobles, yet this me thinks is the greatist, and lest
tolerable, when they must be lodged: resoning of the pains, displeasures,
fortunes, and mishappes that me^ suffer, litell is that my pen does write
heerin, and much less that my tongue does speak in comparison of that the
woeful heart does bide. O how many things are there, that are felt even as the
very bottom of the heart, and yet dare not the tongue once utter them? Truly how
poor a house so ever the courtier has in the contry, he should more esteem
yt, then the best lodging that ever he met with in court, or else wheare. For
at home, he does and comaundeth all that he will: But in an other man's house,
he must take that is geeue^ him. A pilgrim or traueler shall come into a
city, wheare he shall see fair and goodly churches; stately buyldinges, rich
gates, high walls, pauid streates, large market places, provision enough,
abundance of vittells, and nombers of strangers, and when he has seen all
this, he does so little esteem of the^, that to return again to his poor
home, he trauelleth though it be all the night. And therefore we should not
wonder at those, that do not greatly stray from their house, and that are but
seldom in many places: but we might well have him in suspicion, that
continually wandreth through strange contries and howses. For notwithstanding
the great wonders he sees, and the great conversation of amity that he has
or can find, yet in ye end they are only the eyes that are fed with the sight
of others things, and not the heart that is contented with his own, and also
to see in princes courts great treasure and riches brings us commonly more
grief then delight. And ye more his eye is fed with view of the fair dames
of court and princely pomp thereof, the greater sorrow assaulteth his heart, he
may not still enjoy ye same. And therefore ye Renoumed Focion, ye Athenian
captain, answered once certain men yt said there were to be sold in ye
markett place of Athens goodly stones, and rich Ieweles woorthi ye sight,
howbeeit hard to be bought, being held at so hie a price by ye merchant that
sold the^. From my first youth (said this philosopher) I made an oath: never to
go see any city, onles it were to conquer yt, and yield yt subject to me: nor
to go see Jewels, that I could not buy. The great emperor Traian was much
commended, for that he never took toy in his head to go see any thing, but for
one of these three causes, to weete: either to imitate that he saw, to bye yt,
or else clearly to conquer yt. O worthy words of Focion, and Traian, and very
meet to be noted and retained. Now to speak more particularly of the trobles
daily heaped on their necks that follow court, and that are to be lodged in
diverse places, and strange howses, I say: that if ye poor courtier do depart
at night from the court to repair to his lodging, he fyndeth often times the
host of his house, and other his guestes at home, already in their beds, and
fast asleep: so that it happens sometimes, he is feign to go seek his bed in
an other place for that night. And also if he should rise early in the morning
to follow his matters, or to wait upon his lord our master, his host perhaps
and his howsehold are not yet awake, nor slurring to open him the door. And
further if his host be angry and displeased, and out of time: who shall let
him to lock his doors, the day once shutt in? and who should compel him to
open his doors before broad day? Truly it is a great happ to be well lodged
about the court, and much more to meet with an honest host. For it happens
often, that the great pleasure and contentacion we receive, being lodged in a
faier lodging is lightly taken from us, by the hard entreaty and straight
usage of the host of the same, And in this is apparent, the vanity, fondnes,
and lightness of some courtiers, that rather desire, and seek for a fair and
pleasant lodging: then for a good, and profitable. The ambition of the courtier
is now grown to so great a soly, that he desires rather a fair lodging for
his pleasure, then a comodious or profitable for his family. For admit the
harbinger do geeue them a good and comodious lodging, if yt be not sightly to
the eye, and stand comodiously, they can not like of yt by no means. So that
to content them, the fouriers must needs provide them of a fair lodging to the
eye, though litel handsome to lodge in: and yet somtymes they will hard and
sca^t be pleased with that. And if the courtier be of reputacio^, and
beeloued in court, I pray you what pain and troble shall the poor harbinger
have to content his mind, and to continue in his favor? For beefor master
courtier wilbee resolved which of the.ii. lodgings he will take, the fair and
most honorable, or the mean and most profitable, he bleedeth at the nose for
anger, and his heart beats and leapes a thousand times in his body. For his
person would have the good, and comodious lodging: and his folly, the pleasant,
and fair. I never saw dead man complain of his grave, nor courtier content
with his lodging. For if they geeue him a hall, he will say it wants a
chimny, if they geeue him a chamber, he will say yt lacks an inner chamber,
if they geeue him a kitchen, he will say it is to low, and smoky, and that yt
wants a larder, if they geeue him a stable, that it wants a spence or
storehowse, if they geeue him the best: and cheifest parts of the house, yet
he says he wants small and litell houses of office, and if he have
access to the well, he must also have the comodity of the base court. And in
fine, if they geeue him a low paued hall, to cool and refreshe him in summer,
he will also have a high boorded chamber for the winter, and possible he shall
not have so many rooms at home in his own house, as he will demand in his
lodging abroad. And therefore many things suffers the courtier in his own
house, that he will not bear with all in an inn or an other man's house. And it
may be also, that the harbingers have provided them of a fair and goodly
lodging, wheare he shall comaund, both master, Stuff, and al other things in
the house, and yet the courtier shall mislike of it, fynding fault it is to
far from the court, and reputeth yt half a dishonor and impayr of his
credit to be lodged so far of, since others that are beeloued, and in favor
in court in deed, lie hard adioining to the court, or at the least not far
of. For this is an old said troth, the nearest lodged to ye court como^ly ye
best esteemed of the prince. I have seen many courtiers offer large gifts, and
rewards, to entreat the harbingers to lodge the^ near ye court: but I never
saw any that desired to be lodged near ye church, and this comes, for yt
they rather glory to be right courtiers, the^ good christians. And therefore
Blondus recites in his book De declinatione imperii yt a gretian called
Narsetes, (a captain of Justinian ye great) was wo^t to say often, that he
never remembered he went to ye sea, nor e^tred into ye palace, nor beega^ any
battle, nor cou^celed of wars nor mounted a horse back, but that first he
went to the church and seruid god. And therefore by the doings and saiyngs of
Narsetes we may gather that every good man ought rather to incline to be a
good christien, the^ to geeue him self to arms and chiualry to be a right
courtier. It happens many times, that after the courtier be come to his
lodging, he lyketh of yt well, and is well pleased with all: but when he has
been in others lodgins, and has looked upon them, straight way he falls out
of liking of his own, and thinks him self il lodged to others. And this
misliking grows not of his ill lodging, but of an inward malice and spite
he has, to see his enemy preferred to a better then his own. For such is the
secret hate, and envy, in princes court, (a thing common to courtiers) that they
disdain not only to thank the harbingers for their care taken of them, in
placing them in good lodgings: but they must also complain, and speak ill of
them, for the good lodgings they have geeuen to their adversaries, and
compaignions, better then that of theirs. There is also a foul disorder in
court among the harbingers, in appointing lodgings: and litell modesty beesides
in courtiers in asking them. For such there are, that many times, nether they,
nor their parents have any such lodgings at home in their own howses, as they
will demand only for their horskeepers, and servants. But the great pain of
the court is yet, that such nouels as come newly to court, they say they are of
great estimation in the contry, rich, and of an ancient house, and his father
of great authority and estimation, and when the troth is known, his fathers
authority and first estimation was, of good laborers, and husbandmen, their only
rents and revenues consisting in that they gat, by the daily swet and labor of
their persons: and their power and ability, in the rents of an other man's
goods: and their liberty, in service and subjection of those that gave them
wages, and hired them by the day. And I would to god their blood were not
tainted with some other notable blot. There is a plague also in the court,
which always dureeth, and never leaves court, and that is: that those that
are always least worth, and of least calling, do presume and take upon them
most, and also are woorst to please of al others. And this they do (their
power being small) that they would supply that in words and countenance,
