which they want in deeds and effects. I ly, if I saw not once in the county of
Aragone, a gentilma^ that hired a whole house, wheare him self and his famely
were very well lodged and comodiously: and after that I remembered I met with
him in Castilla, wheare he could not content him self with the change of
eight howses, beesides his first he was appointed to: and the occasion was,
for that in Aragon he paid for that house he had, and for these he paid
nothing. So of others purse every man coueteth to show his magnificence, and
to declare his follyes: but when they deffray their own charge, they are hard
as flynt, and go as near to work as may be. It is very true, that if there
be any disorder and troble to be lodged in the court, it comes also for the
most part of the harbingers, without whom the courtiers could never be well
lodged, although the prince had commanded they should be lodged, near him.
Albeeit in the court a man may easiy exempte him self from the princes council,
and justice of the same, having no suits there, and from the council and
affairs of wars being no captain: From the sinode of the spiritualty,
being no ecclesiastical person: and from that of the Indians, going to no
Magicians: from the conuention of marcha^ts, keeping safely their merchandise:
and from ye correction of the lord high marshal of ye court, not being foolish
and insole^t: yet nevertheless there is no courtier (be he never so high or
great in favor) yt can avoid him self from ye harbingers authority, but he
must needs come under his lee, being in their power to dispose ye lodgis as
they think good: to lodge the^ honorably or meanly, to please or displease
the^, to lodge or dislodge them. And if the courtier happen at any time to
quarrel or fall out wc the^: I warrant him he shall be remembered of ye harbingers
in his lodging, and possibly a horskeeper, (yea perhapps his enemy) shall be
better lodged then he, or else he may seek his lodging in the streats where
he shall. For all other iniuryes or offenses done in court, whatsoever, the
courtier may easily redress them by Justice, but for those he receives of
the harbinger, he must take them quietly, and be contented with them. For
otherwise we should not only offend them, but iniure our selves, and make
them to provide us of no lodging: so heerby we should utterly be dislodged,
and unprovided. And therefore they do bear with many things in that office,
which they would not do in any other office: as for example. Those kind of
officers must be much made of, of others well intreted, accompanied, feasted,
flattered, followed, yea and many times served and waited upon. I mean in
serving their turn, anointing their hands, and always inritching their gloves
with some piece of gold and silver, and alas, the seely courtier that has not
such sovereign ointment in his box, to cure these above recited sores, but
only to serve his own turn: if he be not his kynseman, or near allied, let
him yet at least get acquaynted with him, and make him his friend, an esye thing
to bring to pass, if he do not vex him nor geeue him thwart language, and
somtymes he must inuit him to dinner and supper. For in ye court there is no
goodness gotten, neither by ye king, by ye beloved, by the noble men, by the
honorable of his council, treasorers, nor yet by the harbingers, but in
suffering them, and doing them always good and acceptable service. And if
percase the harbingers wrong you, and do you displeasure, or that they should
say you were troblesome and importunat: yet be you wife to bear with them in
any case, and seem not to here them. For what loses the courtier, if he
bare now and then with a few crooked words at the harbingers hands? mary by
forbearing them, he happily comes to be lodged the better. Suppose the
courtier be not always lodged to his mind and desire, should he imediatly
complain of them or murmur at them? no suer, he should but so doing show
him self of small education. For what skylleth yt though among many pounds of
good meat, the boucher sometime myngle a morsel of liver, longes, or lights
of the beast. And therefore a man should not blame the poor harbingers so much
as they does. For they are not commanded of the king to buyld new lodgings,
but such as they are, to divide them amongst the train of his court: So that
they lodge courtiers in such as they find, and not in those they would, adding
thereto yt they have regard to their estates and demerits, and not to ye
affections and wills of ye persons they lodge. For it were more reason, they
should appoint ye greatist and best lodgings, to ye noblest personages and ye
oldest servants of court, then to the late and new come ^ourtier: whose youth
can better away with an ill nights lodging, the^ ye gray hears of ye old
courtier. Otherwise, ye service of ye old courtier that has spent his young
years in princes court (to ye great pain and troble of their persons) and in
his service, should for gwerdon beee paid with ingratitude, if he should not
be preferred to ye best comodious lodging for his ease and also ye first to
be advanced by the prince before ye young seruiture. Now if it be honest and
reasonable that ye harbinger have great consideration to ye merits of him that
he lodges, even so it is fit the courtier should way the press of the court,
and incomodious place wheare the harbingers are constrained to lodge them:
knowing that to day the court remoueth to such a place where there are happily
six thousand houses: and to morrow perhaps there are not a thousand, therefore
if in such a place he find but narrow fustien to make him a dublet: let him
take patiens till such time they remove to an other place, where they shall
find broad cloth enough, to make them large clokes.

How the courtier should entreat his host or master of the house where he
lies. Cap. iii.
THe good and civil courtier must also entreat his host well where he lies:
for else if he come in to his lodging braling and thretning, it may be, that
besides he he will keep his heart and good cheer secret from him, he will
not not also open his chamber doors to him. There are in the court such hare
brains, and indiscreet persons, that have so litell regard and respect to
their honest hosts, that they do nothing in their lodgings, but revel and
keep il rule, and do even what they list, as though the house were theirs to
command, and not given them only for lodging. Whereof springs two exceeding
evils, the one that they offend god: and the other that the prince is also ill
served. For the house is not geeuen them to command, but only appointed for
them to lodge in. We read in the life of the emperor Seuerus that he
ordained in Rome, that if the owner of the house did entreat his gest and
stranger ill, or that he did him hurt or displeasure, the stranger should
accuse him before the justice, but in no wise brawle nor quarrel with him in
his own house. Plutarke in his politikes also resiteth, that in the temples of
the gods, in the realm of Dace, there was no liberty or safty for malefactors,
save in their own proper howses, which served them for their only refuge and
inviolable assurance, for they thought that within the entry and gates of the
same, none other but the lords and masters of the house might pretend any
jurisdiction or seignory. Now if among the Daces no officer or justice could
lay hold or punish any man, so long as he kept his house: me thinks it is
against all reason, and humanity, that the courtier should once offer his host
an injurious or unseemly word. Plato being one day reproved of his friends,
for that he would not rebuke his host Denis the Siracusan, who at the first
received him very courteously, and afterward used him ill, answered the^ thus.
My friends, to be angry with fools that show us pleasure, to take revenge of
children whom we have brought up, to beat a woman with whom we must be
familiar, and to brave and braule with those in whose howses we are lodged,
nether the philosophers of Greece ought to council him, nor the noble heart
once to think to do yt. I can not deny, but that there are some hosts very
rude and uncivil, that it is in manner an impossible thing to bring him to any
honesty or ciuility. Howbeeit notwithstanding I would wish the noble and worthy
courtier to take in jest, all the wrongs and injuries done or said to him by
his host, or at the least to seem as though he hard them not all: otherwise,
from that day the courtier falls out with him, he may even withal think
presently to depart his house, and to seek him a new lodging: for he can
never be quiet in his lodging, where the goodman of the house and he cannot
agree. And where so ever the fine courtier shall lodge, let him never stick at
the charges of a lock to his chamber door a hatch to the window, a degree
or.ii. to the stairs, a rope for the well, a harth to the chimny, nor for a
casement to the wyndowe, for these are but trifles, and they cost little, though
he leave the^ to the house: yet with those trifles he byndeth his host, and
makes him beeholding to him. Also he may not forget sometime to send home
cates to his host, and to inuit him to dinner to him: and likewise if his host
did present him with any thing, he must accept it in very good part, and thank
him much for yt. For other while, by small presents, great frendshipp is
obtained. The discreet courtier must also forbid his pages and servants to
come into his hosts gardeyn, to spoil his fruit, or to gather his flowers, to
steal his hens, or to break any thing of his: That they pull not up the
pauements of the house, paynt his walls with coals or chalk, that they rob
not his done house, nor make any noise to steal his coneys, to break his
glass windows, and to hurt or mar any thing about his house: For if many
times they refuse to lodge strangers in their howses, it is, not for want of
lodging, or that the masters should comber them: but for the displesures, and
shrewd turns they receive by their pages and servants daily. Yt shall chance
many times that a cittezin that has a fair new house, goodly whyt walls,
and trimly painted, shall have a courtier come to lodge in his house, that
shall have such a train with him of servants, young children and their neuews,
which are so foolish, proud and so rechles, that they break the forms, throw
down tables, paint and beedawb ye walls, beat down doors, run thorough
the feelings, steal the byrds, and do a thousand other mischefes and unhappy
turns, so that the poor owner of the house had rather lodge an other time
Egiptians and beggars: then such rude and harmefull courtiers. And therefore I
have seen in the court, by reso^ of the servants disorder and ill rule, the
masters commonly ill lodged, lodgings denied them, or after they had them to be
quite taken from them. One of the necessariest things a courtier should have,
is to keep quiet and well conditioned servants: otherwise it is to be thought
(as in deed the common saying is) the house to be ill governed, where the
family and servants are so ill conditioned and disordered. And touching this
matter Aulus Gellius De noctibus atticis says, yt when Cornelius Gracchus was
returned to Rome, after he had been co^sul a great while in the Isles Baleares,
he said these words before all the senate. You know (fathers conscript) I
have been chief Justice, and consul, xiii. years. during all which time I
swear to you by the imortal gods, that to my knowledge I never did wrong to
any man, nether any servant of mine displeasure to any, nor done any thing
that was not lawful to be done in the house where I lay. Phalaris the
tyrant when he received any displeasure of the Agrigentines, he caused his
servants to lodge in their howses with them, for the one and the other were so
wicked, so unthrifty, such quarellers, and brawlers, that he could not work
them a greater spyght nor displeasure, then to lodge them here and there in
their howses. There be also in the court some courtiers, that are esteemed of
every man to be of so evil beehauiour and demeanor, their servants and
famyly of such lewd and nawghty condicyons, that their hosts are thoroughly
resoluyd, either not to receive them into their howses, or if they be compelled
to yt, to absent the^ selves for the time of their being there: rather then to
suffer such iniuryes and wrongs, as they are suer they must take at their
hands. The courtier must consider that sometimes he has need of a bottel of
water to drink, a broom to swepe his chamber, a platter or dish to serve him
withal, of a table cloth and napkins, and of a towell for his hands and his
face, of a stool to sit on and of soome kettle for the kytchin: and in such
case, he should charge his servant courteously to ask these things of his
host, and not to take them parforce and unasked. Every man desiereth to be
master in his own house, and be he brother, cosen, or friend, he will not
suffer him to bear as much rule in his own house, as him self. So that he
will be less offended, with the hurt and loss of those things that he has
lent, and were gently asked him: then with those, which unknowing to him, by
force, and against his will they have taken from him, yea though they bring
them afterward hole and sound again. And this our liberty is so much set by,
that we shall see sometimes a man for his pleasure, play and lose a.c.
Crowns of gold, and say never a word: and on the other side, if one break
the least glass in his house, he will cry, and rage to the heavens. I
remember when I was a courtier, and went to visit an other courtier a friend of
mine, that was sick in his lodging, I fell a chiding and rebuking the host, for
that I found him exclaymyng and criyng out of the pages, which plaiyng at the
bal had broken him a little lamp of glass, and he answered me thus. I cry
not (sir) for the loss of my lamp which is a halfpeny matter, nor for the oil
that they spylt worth a farthing, but only for the liberty they rob me of,
and for the small account they make of me. The good and wise courtier may not
be to familiar with his host his wief, nor suffer his servants to be busy
with the mayds of the house, more then to speak to them for their necessaries,
for in this case, they should less hurt the master of the house, to ransake
and spoil his house, and all that he had in yt: then to take from him his
honor and good name. To cast the bedds on the flower, to break the doors and
windows, to vnpaue the stones, to paint and black the walls, or to make any
noise in the house, are all of them things: yet sometimes tolerable though not
honest nor civil: but to take his wief, and to abuse her, it is nether lawful
nor possible to dissemble yt, much less to suffer it. For it were too much
shame, and reproach to the husband to abide yt, and high treason and crime
abominable for the courtier to do yt. Now since men are frail, and that
they can not, nor will not subdue their passions and filthy motions of the
flesh, there wants not notwithstanding women in princes courts, whose love
and frendships they may easily embrace: which though they were al commanded to
avoid the court, and ye vierge of ye court, yet it could not be chose^, but
some might secretly continue still in court to enterteine the courtly courtiers.
For if in the court there be kept a table of play.ii. months only in the
year, all the year long beesides they find the streats full stored of common
woomen. when the year is most plentiful and fruitful of all things, yet still
there lacks soome provision of vittailes in the court: but of such women
there is never no want but rather to many. And therefore we have not said
without great reason, that it were to much treason and dishonesty for the
courtier to fall in love with his hostess: for in doing yt, he should do
her husband too much wrong, disfame the wife, and offend his friends and
neighbors, and utterly undo him self. For Suetonius Tranquillus resyteth that
Julius Caesar caused a Captayn of his to be beeheaded only for sclaundering and
defaming of his hostess, the which he did not, tarying for the complaint of
her husband, nor ye accusation of any other. And ye Emperor Aurelianus seeing
one of his men at a window one day pulling his hostess by ye sleeue, caused
his hand to be stricken of immediately, although both his hostess and he swear
he did it but in jest, and to no other intent. Plutarch in his book De
matrimonio says, that there was a law among the Licaoniens, that if any
stranger did but only talk with his hostess, his tongue shoold be cut out of
his head, and if he had passed further, that he shoold then lose his head.
Macrobius also in his Saturnaller recites, that amongst ye Romans it was
reputed a great infamy, if any man came, and praised the beawty and manners of
the mistress of the house where he lodged, for in praising her, he let them
understand he knew her, and knowing her he spoke to her, and speaking to her,
he opened his heart to her, and this doing, he plainly defamed her, and made
her to be euel reported of. Aulus Gelius writes that the like punishment was
geeuen to him that had carnal participacion with any vestall virgin, the self
same was also executed on him that procured any infamy to his hostess where
he lay.

Which punishment was, either to be cut in the mids, and quartered in four
parts, or else to be stoned to death alive. The good courtier must also have an
other great regard, and that is, to comaund his servants to look well to his
ryding apparel, and such as are lent him of courtiers to wear otherwhile, to
see that it be kept clean and well brusshed, and above all safely delivered
where it was borrowed, For commonly the horskeepers have their horses lowsing
clothes and their masters footecloth more nete and clenly, then the grooms
and pages of the chamber have his apparel: and this proceeds of their great
sloth and negligence. And truly this passes the bounds of shamefast degree,
yea and comes much to charge the courtiers conscience, the small account he
has, so to let his garments and apparel, and other his mouables to be
spoiled and lost. And this happens very often by the negligence of their pages
and servant, which now throws them about the chambers, dragges them upon
the grownd, now sweeps the house with the^, now they are full of dust, then
tattered and torn in pieces, here their hose seam rent, there their shoes
broken: so that if a poor man come afterward to buy them to sell again, it
will rather pity those that see them, then geeue them any courage to buy them.
Wherefore the courtier ought not to be so careless, but rather to think upon
his own things and to have an eye unto them: For if he go once a day to his
stable to see his horses how they are kept and looked to, he may likewise take
an other day in the week when he may find leisure to see his wardroppe, how
his apparel lies. But what paciens must a poor man take, that lends his
implements and apparel to the courtiers? that never lays them abroad a
sunning, to beat out the dust of them, nor never layth them in water, to wash
and white them, be they never so fowl. And al be it the beds and other
implements lent to the courtier, be not of any great value, yet it is not fit
they shoold be thrown at their tail and kept filthyly: For as charely and
dayntily does a poor laboring and husband man keep his woollen couerlet, and
sets as much by it, as does the jolly courtier by his quilt or couerpane of
silk. And it chances often times also, that though at a need the poor man's
bed costeth him less money, then the rich man's bed costeth him, yet does it
serve him better, then the rich and costly bed serves the gentleman or
nobleman. And this to be true, we see it by experience, that ye poor
husbandman or citizen slepeth commonly more quietly, and at his ease, in his
poor bed and cabean with his sheets of tow: then does the lord or rich
courtier, lying in his hanged chamber, and bed of silk, wrapped in his fynest
holland shetes, who still sigheth and co^playneth. And finally we conclude,
that then when ye court remoueth, and that ye courtier departs from his
lodging where he lay, he must with all curtesy thank the good man and good
wife of ye house for his good lodging, and courteous intertainment he has had
of them, and must not stick also to geeue them somewhat for a remembrance of
him, and beesides, geeue certain rewards among the maids and men servants of
the house according to their ability, that he may recompense them for that is
past, and win their favor for that is to come.

What the courtier must do to win the Princes favor. Cap. iiij.
DIodorus Siculus says, that the honor and reverence the Egiptians used
ordinarily to their Princes was so great, that they seemed rather to woorship
them, then to serve them; for they coold never speak to them, but they must
first have license geeuen them. When it happened any subject of Egypt to have a
suit to their prince, or to put up a supplication to the^, kneeling to them
they said these words. Sovereign lord and mighty prince, if it may stand with
your highness favor and pleasure, I will boldly speak: if not, I will presume no
further, but hold my peace. And the self reverence and custom had toward god
Moses, Aaron, Thobias, David, Solomon, and other fathers of Egypt, making like
intercession when they spoke with god, saying. Domine mi rex, Si inueni gratiam
in oculis tuis, loquar ad dominum meum. O my lord and king, if I have found
favor in thy sight, I will speak unto thee: if not, I will keep perpetual
silence. For there is no service ill, when yt is grateful and acceptable to
him, to whom it is done: as to the contrary none good, when it pleases not ye
party that is served. For if he yt serves, be not in his masters favor he
serves, he may well take pains to his vndooyng, without further hope of his
good will or recompense. Wherefore touching that I have said, I infer, that
he that goes to dwell and abide in the court, must above all indeuer him self
all he can to obtayn the princes favor, and obtaining it, he must study to
keep him in his favor. For it shoold little prevail the courtier to be
beeloued of all others, and of the prince only to be mislyked. And therefore
Alcamidas the Grecian, being once advertised by a friend of his, that the
Athenians did greatly thirst for his death, and the Thebans desired his life:
he answered him thus. If those of Athens thirst for my death, and them of
Thebes likewise desyring my life, I can but be sorry and lament. How be it
yet, if King Phillip my sovereign lord and master hold me still in his grace
and favor, and repute me for one of his beeloued, I care not if all Greece
hate and dysloue me, yea and lie in wayt for me.

In deed it is a great thing to get into the princes favor, but when he has
gotten it, doubtless it is a harder matter to know how to keep it. For to make
them love us, and to win their favor, we must do a thousand manner of
seruyces: but to cause them to hate and dislyke of us, the least dyspleasure in
the world suffyseth. And therefore the pain and trouble of him that is in favor
in the court is great, if he once offend, or be in displeasure.

For albeeit the prince do pardon him his fault, yet he never after returns
into his favor again. So that to conclude, he that once only incurreth his
indignation, he may make just reckening never after, or marvelous hardly to
be received again into favor. Therefore says the divine Plato in his books
De republica: that to be a king and to reign, to serve and to be in favor,
to fight and to overcome, are three impossible things, which neither by man's
knowledge, nor by any diligence can be obtained: only remaining in the hands
and disposing of fickle fortune, which does diuyde and geeue them where it
pleases her, and to whom she favors best.

And truly Plato had reason in his saying, for to serve, and to be beeloued,
is rather happ and good fortune, then industry or diligence. Since we see often
times that in the court of princes, those that have served but three years
only, shall be sooner preferred and advanced, then such one as has served
perhaps.xx. or.xxx. years, or possible al his life time. And further he
shall be both displaced, and put out of service, by means of the other. And this
proceeds not through his long and faithful service he has done, but only by
reason of the good hap that follows him. Although Plato tells, that to get
realms and seignories, to overcome battles, and to be favored and beeloued of
princes, be things granted to us rather by hasard, and fortune, then by
force, of good woorks, and laudable acts, or by long toylyng in painful
service: yet the noble and stout heart therefore shoold not cesse at any time to
enterprise, and manfully to execute in every occasion presented to him, to
achyue to fame and honor: neither for any pain and labor to lose the hope to
obteyn his pretensed purpose. For men so^etymes lose many things, rather
through timorousnes, and want of audacitie, then for that they lack good hap or
fortune. To see in the court of princes some to be richer, more honored, more
noble, more esteemed, better beeloued, more waited upon, better served, and
better welcome then others, and more feared then others: we may by these
tokens know, that fortune has not used to reward those with such favors and
preferrements, which live at home ydlely, and much less courtiers, who live in
court with all pleasure and delicacy, wherewith they are never weryed.

Let no man be so fond to think, that fortune is so bountiful and liberal,
that for his authority, or only thought, she wilbee once moved to lift him out
of misery, to exalt him to higher place and dignity, without some secret and
private respect had to his virtue. For when she many times upon a sodein
raises any to high and great estate, it comes by the merits of him that is
exalted, or through the displeasure of him that is thrown down: in whose rome
she has placed an other in favor with her. As we read of Julius Emilius, for
a time high in favor, and afterward in great disgrace with the emperor
Constantius, in whose place and rome succeeded afterward an other named
Alexander, who being one day reproved by some of his friends of ingratitude
toward them, (that said they were causers and furderers of his honor and
preferrement) answered them in this manner. Masters, if I am comen into such
favor with themperor, my good and gracious lord, succeeding in the place of
Emilius, truly it was more by reason of his deserved fall, then by your
obtained means or requests: Fortune and his heavy destiny having so willed and
ordained it, more to overthrow and displace him of his room and credit he was
in, then to advance and prefer me to the same. The which I say, to advise
the citizen and gentleman that goes to the court to be a courtier, to thend
he be not fickle headed, and light of beelief, to think that immediately he
shall come to such aucthority, that he may easily comaund all that he will:
neither that he shoold so much despair, and be hopeles, but that by time (in
serving well) he might come to be in as great favor, as any other about the
prince. We see daily such change and alterations in the common weal, and
fortune to turn her unstable wheel so often, that many times ye administration
of ye common weal is in his hands and rule, of whom before they made little or
none account. And therefore I say to you, and again return to tell you, that
the courtier yt seeks to come into his princes favor, and to be beeloued of
him, and that coueteth to be well reputed of in court must endeavor him self to
be very honest, and as near as may be fautles of life: and true and faithful
in his charge or office he takes upon him. For the good oppinion that men
have of a man, is ever the first degree to attain to the princes favor. For
there is no man in the world, of whatsoever state or condition he be, so
vicious and lascivious, but at the least he desires to have an honest and
virtuous man in his house: so that a man may say, that the good and godly life
is the redyest mean and way (where ever the person be) to bring him soonest
into the princes favor, and to make him to be beeloued generally. Wherefore
Phalaris the tyrant, writing to an emulator of his, said these words unto
him. I confess thou art an honest man, but thou wilt not deny me also, that
al those thou keep in thy house, be wicked persons and of ill life: a thing
which in my house thou shall find all contrary. For although I am a tyrant, at
least yet I love, that no ill disposed person eat bread in my house: So that
though I am laden with many vices, yet am I accompanied also with many wise and
learned men. The divine Plato came from Greece into Scicilia, only to see
Dionisius the Siracusan, and not Plato him self alone, but also diverse other
philosophers in company with him: whom he did not only honor and entreat well,
but also saw they wanted nothing fit or necessary for them. Many times
Dyonisius was wont to say these words. I am captain of the Rhodians, sith I
defend them from the Affricans: and king of the Affricans, because I govern
them: and friend of the Italians, because I offend them not: and father of the
philosophers, because I help to relieve them in all their necessities: and the
Scicilians call me a tyrant, because they see I leave not to punish them, and
keep them under. By these two examples we may gather, that the tyrants being
friends to virtuous and honest men, much more and of necessity ought the good
and just princes to be. Also the courtier must take great heed he be not
arrogant, and a liar, a flatterer, and dissembler: for those, and such like
faults, are rather woodz and by paths, vttlerly to lose a man: then a plain
hie way to bring him into favor and credit. And although by chance there have
been some, that with all these faults have notwithstanding crept into favor:
yet we will show them a hundred, that only for those vices have been cast out
of favor and credit both. For commonly, all those that by the favor of wicked
princes beeginne to be great, and of some honor, and that study by all
dishonest and unlawful means to continue and keep them selves in credit,
and: favor Albeeit for a time we see them reign and flourish in prosperity:
yet that lasts not long, nether is it perpetual, but a time comes again,
when we see them fall, and quite cast of, to their great shame and utter
undoing. There are many that knows and understands the princes court but
meanly, or not at all, which beeleue, that for being well spoken, and being
careful and diligent in their buysines and affairs, they should the sooner for
that come in favor and credit before others: but in the end their hope and
imagination is nothing, not answering any thing their desire: for as there are
in court many green heads, and graceles couertures, which are of no
reputacion, nor any thing set by, nether deserving to be well thought of: So
are there many wise heads and beeloued courtiers greatly esteemed and reputed
of. And this for their own good demerits, and by means also of the others
wicked abuse and disorder. Suetonius tranquillus recites, that Scilla the
consul, being mortal enemy of the Marians, (of which faction was also Julius
Caesar) said: that from Cesars infancy his wisdom made him more to be feared
and wondered at: then ever his stout and valiant courage he showed. Plutarke
writing to Traian said. I assure thee (Sovereign prince) I do more esteem
and honor thy parson, then I do care for all thy empire beesyds. For I have
seen thee do a thousand good things to deserve yt, but I never saw thee once
desirous to have yt. And suer in my opinion I think there is no better alchemye
in court, to grow to sodeyne wealth, and to acquire the princes favor: the^
that the same of his good life should rather resound his praise to the prince,
thereby to make him known unto him: then the respect of his noble house or
progenye.

That courtier also that craves his princes grace, must take heed in any wise
he be not consorte or companion with rash and hasty persons, whose unstable
heads mislike of every state, still deprauing all others virtues.

Such fellow mates, and compagnions, the wise courtier must in any case refuse
to be conversant with. I must advise him also he beeware he be not rash of
speech, nor that he speak ill of any man: For it is a right kind of treso^ to
detrect and backbyte our friends, and much more the prince, to whom we wholly
owe our duty and allegiance. And therefore the wise and virtuous courtier must
fly from this company as far as he can, that are possessed with such vain
humors, and passions of mind: For such kind of me^, will never council us to
sarue well, nor to beeware of liberal speaking, but will rather infect us, and
bring us to their naughty vain humor, and make us to be demed as bad as them
selves (though we be not so) only for keeping them company. Like as in commonweals there are seditious heads, wc move and stir the poor commons to
rebellion: even so in princes courts there are the like factious heads, that
seek to win good will of courtiers, and so to stir up their mynds also to
tumult and sedition: which, because they have no way to come up, and grow in
favor, do detract and speak ill of those, that are in favor and authority. One
of these abiects, and inferior sort, shall go to ye house of an other, (in
like disgrace and discredit that him self is in,) and there these companions
shall open their throtes against the prince, and his court saying, the king
cares not for his subjects, talking of the high minds and countenances of the
beeloued and favored of court, of the affections of the counsel, of the
parciality and enmyty of the court, of the want of munition for wars, and of
the fall and decay of the common wealth: and thus with theys lewd and uncomely
discorses, they spend the long and doleful nights of winter season, and there
withal also the long and whot sunny days of summers time. Adrian the emperor
being once informed, that there met and assembled togethers daily, at the
house of one Lucius Turbon, a number of the seditious and factious sort of
Rome, which were offended with him, and conspired against him: to prevent them
of insurrection, proclaimed presently through Rome and enacted yt for a law,
that all courtiers that assembled there, should lose their heads, and all the
Romans should be banished. All this we have spoken, to banish vice from
princes courts if yt may be: for now a days, as there are many houses of
ordinary tables, and nombers of disyng houses for all manner of play: so is
there also in the court, beesides the groom porters, other chambers where they
meet to murmr at each man's doings. And as there are some that say, gowe let
us go to such a man's house, and there we shall find play enowgh, and good
fellowshipp to pass the time away as we will: even so these others say, gow,
we will go to such a chamber, and there we shall meet with our compaignions
and good fellows, wheare we may talk liberally and at our pleasure, without
check or control of any. Infamous be that house, wheare there is no other
exercise, but play and riot: and accursed be that, wheare they can not occupy
them selves, but in defamyng and backbiting their breethern and neighbors. For
to conclude, it were less euel to play and lose their money, then to robb and
spoil his neyghbor of his good name. Now to get into the princes favor, it
helps much to consider, wherein the prince takethe chief delyght, and whereto
he is best affected: whether to music, hunting, fliyng, riding of horses, or
fishing, running, or leaping, or any other actiuity what so ever it be. And
his affect and desire once known, and observed: he must geeue him self wholly
to love that the prince loves, and to follow that that he follows. And as
princes commonly are geeuen to their wills, to leeke soome pastymes better then
others: so do they show them selves more favorable and gracious to soome of
their servants, then others: and rather to those whom only they see conform
and agreeable with their affections, then to such as are alwey most dilygent
and paynefull about them, to do them the best service they can. The curious
courtier may account him self happy, if he can frame him self to comend that
the prince allows, and likewise to dissalow of that the prince mislyketh: and
though perhaps he were many times of the contrary opinyon, he may well
think and beeleeue to him self what he lyketh best, but in no case to utter
that he thinks, nor to make any countenance to the contrary. The emperor
Aurelius never drank other then redd wine, and because he was infourmed that
Torquatus the Roman, for his sake did not only refrain from drinkyng white
wine, but did also plant all his vynes with red grapes, he made him censor of
Rome, and gave him the ward of the gate Salaria in the said city. In eating
and drinking, in hunting, and tilting, in peace, and in war, in youthful
sportes, and grave matters, the wise courtier must alweyes follow the steps
and will of the prince, and imitate him in the same the best he can. And if yt
be beneficial for the courtier to have the princes favor and to be esteemed
of him: let him in no wise enterprise to talk too much to him. For by
continual frequenting the prince yt can not otherwise fall out, but he shall
both troble him, and be thought a proud, arrogant, and an importunat fool of
him. And if the courtier has no grave and weyghty matters to move the prince
in, to what purpose does he seem to molest and importune the king? We say
in weighty matters to communicate with him. For to talk with the prince, and
to troble his ears with tryfles and matters of small moment, he should be
reputed of the hearers a rash man, and of the king him self a witless fool.
Let us consider a little what is fit for the courtier to do, and what
beecometh him best, and whether it be lawful for him to conferr with the
prince, and then we shall come to know, if yt be decent for him to speak often
to the prince. Therefore to go to the king to speak ill of any man, I think no
wise man will offer to do yt: and if it be to geeue him secret intelligence
of any thing, he must first dout whether the king will beeleeue him or no:
and to think to counsel him, it is a token of a light head: and to presume to
sleyt with the prince, and to beemery with him, to pass the time away, let
every man beeware he run not into that error, nor that he once prease to
do it. To send to reprove a prince, I know not what he is that would be so
foolish hardy once ^o dare to open his lips against him: and to flatter him,
if the prince be wise, he will understand him: and if he find him once, it
is enough to turn the flatterer to great displeasure, yea and to put him
quite out of favor wish him. And therefore to live in suerty and avoid these
dangers, me thinks it is best to speak but seldom to him. Lucullus was a
great friend to Seneca and was also gouerner of Sicilia, and demanding one day
of Seneca what he might do that might be acceptable to the emperor Nero his
lord and master, Seneca answered him thus. If thou desire to be acceptable to
princes, do them many services, and geeue them few words. And so like wise
the divine Plato said in his books De repub. that those that have to move the
prince in any thing, in any case be brief: for in dilating to much, they
should both comber the prince, and make him also not geeue attentive ear,
nether could he have leisure to hear them, nor pacyens to tarry them. And he
said further. Those matters and subjects they treat with princes in, and that
are used to be told them, ought to be grave, and sententious: either tendyng
to comodyty of the weal publyke, to his honor or profit, or to the service of
the king, to whom he speaks. These counsels and aduertysements of Plato
and Seneca (in my poor opinion) deserve to be noted and had in memory: And
notwithstanding all that I have spoken, I say yet further to you, that there is
nothing disposes ye prince better to love and favor his servants, then to see
them diligent in service, and slow in speaking. For to reward him that only
seeks it by means of his tongue and by words, it is in our free wills to do
it: but to recompense him that by his diligent service only craves a good
turn and not in words, we are in conscience bound to yt: And hereof
springs the vulgar proverb: The good service is demand sufficient, though
the tongue be silent.

What manners and gestures beecome the courtier when he speaks to the prince.
Cap. v.
WHen the courtier determines to speak to the prince, he must first show
him self unto him with great reverence, before he come at him, and if the
king be set, he must knele to him upon one knee, with his cappe in his left
hand, holding yet nether to far nor to near his body, but rather downwards
toward his knee, with a good grace and comely fashion, not to lustely, nor to
much boldly, but with a set shamefast gravity, putting him self on the left
hand of the prince to speak with him, whether he be sitting or standing. For
placing our selves on the left hand, we leave the king on the right, as duty
wills us: For the right hand beelongeth ever to the best person. Plutarke
says, that in the bankets the kings of Persia made, they sat him, whom they
loved, and made most account of, cheek by cheek, and on the left hand of the
prince, where the heart lies: saying, that those whom they loved with their
heart, should be set down also on that side the heart lay, and in no other
place. Blondus says to the contrary, that the Romans did honor the right
hand so much, that when ye Emperor entered ted into the senate, no man durst ever
put him self on his right hand. And he says more over, that if a young man
were perchanse found sitting on the right hand of an old man, or the servant on
the upper hand of his master, the son on the right hand of his father, or any
page, prentise or serving man, on the upper hand of a burgeis or cytesin: they
were no less punished by Justice for that fault and offense, then if they had
done any notable crime or delicte. Who so ever will speak to the prince, must
speak with a soft voice and not to hastily. For if he speak to loud, those
that stand by shall hear what he says to the king: and in speaking to fast,
the king shall not easily understand what he says. And he must alsoere he
speak to the prince premeditate long before what he will say to him, and put
into him good words and aptly placed: for wise men are more careful what
words their tongues should utter, then what their hands should do. There is
great difference beetwixt speaking well, and doing well: for in the end the
hand can but strike and offend: but the tongue can both offend and defame. Even
when ye courtier is telling his tale to ye prince, let him be advised in all
his actions and gestures, and that he play not with his cappe from one hand to
an other, much less that he beehold ye prince to earnestly in the face. For
in the one he shoold be taken for a fool, and esteemed in the other for a
simple courtier. He must take great heed also that he spitt not, coffe, nor
hawk, when he speaks to him, and if it be so he be constrained by nature
to it: then let him hold down his head, or at least turn at one side that he
breath not in the kings face. Pliny writing to Fabatus says, that the kings
of India never suffered any man (in speaking to them) to approach so near them,
that their breath might come to their face. And they had reason to do it, to
avoid strong and unsavory breths, growing rather of the indisposition of the
stomak, or of the putrefaction of the lungs, or of the corruption of the brayn.
And if the courtier have to speak with the king after dinner or supper, let him
beeware he eat no garlyke, nor onyons, nor drink wine without water. For if
he savor of garlyk or onyons, the king may think he lacks discretion to
come with those sents to his presence: or if his breath were strong of wine,
that he were a drunkard. He must be very circumspect also that when he
speaks to the king, he speak not with his head, as well as with his tongue,
nor that he play not with his hands, nor his feet, nor yt he stroke his
beard, nor wynk with his eyes: for such fond countenaunces, and gestures, do
rather beecome a fool or iester, then a civil or honest courtier.

And in his discourse with the Prince, that he exceed not in superfluous
words, more then shall only be needful and touching his matter, and not to
seem in his presence to deprave or detract any man. He may honestly allege,
(and that without reproach) the service he has done him: but not to lay
before him others faults and imperfections. For at such a time it is not
lawful for him to speak ill of any man, but only to communicate with him of
his own affayrs. And he may not go so far also, as to remember him with too
great affection, the blood spent by his ancestors in his service, nor the
great acts of his parents: for this only word said to ye prince, I did this,
better pleases and lyketh the Prince, then to tell him a hundred other words
of that that his predecessors had done. It pertayneth only to women, and they
may justly crave recompense of the prince for the lives of their husbands lost
in the princes wars: but the valiant, and worthy courtier, ought not to
demand recompense, but for that he only has done, by persyng lance, and
bloody sword. He must beeware also that he show no countenance to the king
of insatisfaccion, neither to be passioned in casting his service in the
princes teeth, saying all others have been recompensed save only him, whom the
Prince has clean forgotten. For princes will not that we only serve them, but
that we also (at their wills and pleasures) tarry for recompense, and not to
have it when we gape, or are importune for yt. Howbeeit it is lawful
notwithstanding, humbly and lowly, without cholor or passion, to put the Prince
in remembrance of all that we have done for him, and of the long time we
have spent in seruyng him. Also the curious courtier shall not show him self to
dyslike at all of the prince, neither by heaping of many words, to induce him
to bear him the better good will. For men's hearts are so prone to ill, that for
one only unpleasant or overthwart word spoken to them, they lightly forgeat a
thousand seruyces done them.

Socrates being one day demanded what he thought of ye princes of Greece,
answered. There is no other difference beetwene the names and properties of
the gods, and that of princes, but that the Gods were immortal, and these
mortal. For these mortal princes use in manner the like aucthority here in
earth, that the gods immortal do in heaven above. Saying further also, that I
always was, am, and wilbee of that mind, that my mother Greece remayn a common
weal. But since it is determined to be governed by princely monarchy, I wish
them in all, and for all, to acknowledge their obedyence and allegiance to
their king and sovereign. For when they woold otherwise use it, they may be
assured they shall not only go against mortal princes, but also against the
eternal god. Suetonius Tranquillus says, that Titus the emperor being
advertised that the consuls woold kill him, and vsurp his empire, answered
thus wisely. Even as without the divine will and providence I coold never have
possessed the imperial crown, so without their permission and sufferaunce, it
lies in no man's power to deprive me of it.

For to us men it pertains only to keep the imperial iurisdiccion, and to
the gods alone to geeue and defend it: Which we have spoken, to thend no man
presume to be revenged of his prince, neither in word nor deed: for to speak
ill of him, we shoold rather purchase us their high indignation and
displeasure, then procure us any cause or suggestion to be revenged of him.
Let the good courtier be also aduysed, that in talking with the prince he be
not to obstinate, to contend with the prince, or any other in the princes
presence: For this name of arrogant, and self willed, beecommeth not the person
of a wise courtier. For we know that in sport, and argument every man desires
to overcome, how tryfling so ever the matter be.

And therefore we read in the life of the emperor Seuerus, that Publius the
consul iested one day with Fabritius his compagnion, and told him he was in
love. Whom Fabritius answered: I confess it is a fault to be in love, but
yet it is a greater fault for thee to be so obstinate as thou art. For love
proceeds of wit and discretion: but obstinacy, comes of folly and great
ygnoraunce. If perchance the king ask the courtiers opinion in those matters
they discoursed, if he know his opinion to agree with the princes, let him
tell it him hardely: but if it be contrary, let him hold his peace, and not
contend against him, framyng some honest excuse to concele his oppinon. But if
perhaps the king were obstinate, and bent to his oppinion in any thing, and
that through his self will and obstinacy, he woold do any thing unreasonable,
or prejudicial to his common wealth, and that great detryment might come
thereby: yet for all this, in such case the beeloued courtier shoold not at
that instant be to plain with him, to let him understand his error, neither
yet shoold he suffer him altogeether to pass his way untouched, but in some
fine manner and proper words (as may beecome the place best) to geeue him to
understand the troth. But to use it with more discretion, he shall not need
before them all to open his whole mind, but to keep his oppynion secret,
expecting a more apter time, when the king shall be apart in his privy
chamber, and then frankly to tell him his hole mind, with all humylity and
reverence, and to show him the plain troth, without keeping any one thing from
his knowledge. For otherwise in tellyng the king openly, he shoold make him
ashamed: and in dyssemblyng his fault also privily, he shoold not be
admonished of his error committed. Now therefore let our conclusion be, that
the courtier that proceeds in his matters, rather with oppinion and obstinacy,
then discretion and judgment: shall never be in favor with the Prince, nor
yet beeloued in the court. For it is as necessary for the courtier, that will
seek the favor of the prince and love of the court, to impose his tongue to
silence: as it is to dyspose his body to all manner of service. I know there are
some such rash, indiscreet, and arrogant fools, that as much do bost and
rejoice to have spoken indiscreetly to the king, and without respect of his
princely majesty: as if they had done some marvelous thankful service, with
whom truly no man ought to be greatly offended, for such fond bostes and
vaunts as they make, and much less also with that that happens to them
afterward. The courtier also must be well aduysed, that albeeit the king for
his pleasure do privily play with his hands, or jest with his tongue with the
courtier, and that he take great pleasure in it: yet that he in no case
presume to do the like, (yea though he were assured the kings majesty woold
take it well:) but let him modestly beehaue him self, and show by his words
and countenance that he thinks the prince does honor him, in pleasing his
majesty to use those pastymes and pleasant deuyses, with so unworthy a person
as he is. For the prince may lawfully play, and sport him self with his lords
and gentlemen: but so may not they again with him. For so doing, they might
be counted very fond and light. With a man's compagnions and coequals it is
lawful for every man to be merry and play with all. But with the prince, let
no man so hardy once presume further, more then to serve, honor, and obey him.
So that the wise courtier, must endeavor him self always to come in favor by
his wisdom, and courtly beehauiour, in matters of weight and importance: and
by great modesty and gravity, in things of sport and pass time. Therefore
Plutarch in his Apothegmes says, that Alcibiades, amongst the Greeks a
worthy captayn, and a man of his own nature disposed to much mirth and
pleasure, being asked once by some of his familiar friends why he never
laughed in theaters, bankers, and other common plays where he was, answered
them thus. Where others eat, I fast: where others take pain and play, I rest
me and am quiet: where other speak I am silent: where they laugh, I am
courteous, and jest not. For wise men are never known but among fools, and
light persons. When ye courtier shall understand, or here tell of pleasant
things to be laughed at, let him in any case (if he can) fly from those great
laughters and foolries? that he be not perhaps moved too much with such toys,
to laugh to loud, to clap his hands, or to do other gestures of the body, or
admirations to vehement, accompanied rather with a rude and barbarous manner of
beehauiour, then with a civil and modest noblenes. For over great and
excessive laughter was never engendered of wisdom, neither shall he ever be
counted wise of others that uses it. There are also an other sort of courtiers
that speak so coldly, and laugh so dryly, and with so ill a grace, that it were
more pleasure to see them weep, then to laugh. Also to nouel or to tell tales
to delyght others, and to make them laugh, you must be as brief as you can,
that you weary not, and comber not the auditory: pleasant and not biting nor
odyous. Else it chances often times, that wanting any of these conditions, from
jesting they come many times to good earnest. Elius Spartianus in the life of
the Emperor Seuerus says that the said Emperor had in his court a pleasant
fool, and he seeing the fool one day in his domps and cogitacions, asked him
what he ayled to be so sadd? The fool made answer. I am deuysing with
myself what I shoold do to make thee merry. And I swear to thee (my lord
Seuerus) that for as much as I way thy life dear, possible I study more in ye
nights for the tales I shall tell thee in the morrow after, then do thy
Senators touching that they must decree on the next day. And I tell thee
further (my lord Seuerus) that to be pleasant and delighting to the prince,
he must neither be a very fool, nor altogeether wise. But though he be a
fool, yet he must smatter somewhat of a wise man: and if he be wise, he
must take a little of the fool for his pleasure. And by these examples we may
gather, that the courtier must needs have a certain modesty and comely grace,
as well in speaking, as he must have a soft and sweet voice in singing. There
are also some in court, that spare not to go to noble men's bords to repast,
which being in deed, the unseemly grace it self, yet in their words and
talk at the board they woold seem to have a marvelous good grace, wherein they
are often deceived. For if at times the Lords and gentlemen laugh at them, it is
not for any pleasure they take in their talk, but for the ill grace, and uncomely
gestures they use in their talk. In the bankets and feasts courtyers make some
times in the summer, there are very often such men in their company, that if the
wine they drank took their condition, yt shoold be drunk either colder, or
whotter then it is.

How the Courtier shoold beehaue him self to know, and to visit the noble men
and gentlemen, that be great with the Prince and continuing still in court.
Cap. vi.
THe courtier that comes newly to the court to serve there, must immediately
learn to know those that are in aucthority, and favor in the court, and that
are the princes officers. For if he do otherwise, neither shoold he be
acquainted with any noble man or gentleman, or any other of the princes
servant, neither woold they also geeue him place, or let him in when he
woold. For we be not conversant with him we know not, and not being
conversant with him, we trust him not, and distrusting him, we commit no
secrets to him: So that he that will come in favor in the court, must make him
self known, and be friend to all in general. And he must take heed that he
begin not to suddenly to be a busy suter in his own private affairs, or for
his friend, for so he shall be soon reputed for a busy soliciter, rather then a
wise courtier. Therefore he that will purchase favor and credit in the court,
must not be to careful to prefer men's causes, and to entermedle in many
matters. For the nature of princes is, rather to commit their affairs in the
hands and trust of grave and reposed men, then to busy and importunate
soliters. The courtier also may not be negligent to visyt the prelates,
gentelmen, and the favored of the court, nor to make any difference beetween
the one and the other: and not only to vysyt their parents and friends, but his
enemies also. For the good courtier ought to endeavor him self the best he can
to accept all those for his friends at least, that he can not have for parents
and kinsfolks. For amongst good and virtuous courtiers, there should never be
such bloody hate, that they should therefore leave one to company with an
other, and to be courteous one to another. Those that be of base mind, do
show their cankred hearts by forbearing to speak, but those that be of noble
blood and valiant courage, beegynne first to fight, ere they leave to speak
togethers. There is also an other sort of courtiers, which being sometimes at
the table of noble men, or else where when they hear of some quarrel or private
dyspleasure, they show them selves in offer like fyerce lions, but if
afterward their help be craved in any thing, and that they must needs stand
by their friend and draw on his side: then they show them selves as still as
lambs, and gentle enough to be entreated. Amongst others the new come courtier
has to be acquainted withal, he must learn to know those the prince
favors, and loves best, on whom he must attend and wayt upon, and do all
the service he can, without grudge and disdaigne. For there is no king, but
far of on him, has an other king, that still contrarieth his mind, and
preuenteth him of his intent and pleasure: And ever near unto him some, whom
he loves and favors, that may dispose of the prince as he lysteth.
Plutarke writing to Traian said these words. I have (O Traian) great pytty on
thee, for the first day thou tookest upon thee the Imperial crown of the
Romayn Empire, of a free man thou thraldst thy self to bondage. For only you
other princes have authority to geeue lyberty to all others, but never to grant
it to your selves, saying more over, that under the color of royal lyberty,
you shall remayn more subject, then your own subjects that ere obey you. For if
you command many in their houses, also one alone after commands you in
your own court. Now although many commanded the prince, or that he would
follow the counsel but of a few, or that he loved one above an other, or that
he consented one alone should govern him, thee good courtyer need not once
open his mouth to reason of the matter. For so it might easily fall out, he
should beegynne out of hand to feel in the court, of what importance yt were
to enter into such discourse of the prince, and afterward to go home to his
own house, to end yt with bitter tears. First to purchase the high indygnation
of the prince, secondly to be dysdeigned of the court, thirdly to be cast
quyte out of favor, fourthly to be exyled and banished the verge of the court,
and fyftly and lastly to end the rest of his woeful days in vile and miserable
place. Now if it be hard to compass to get into the princes favor, I thynk yt
no very ill counsel yt at least he seek to be in favor with him that is in
the princes favor. For often times there comes as much displeasure to us, being
ill willed of those ye prince does esteem and favor: as there does by ye
princes own indygnacion, that reigns over us. For that we talk of princes,
comes not all to his ears (and but seldom) unless the matter be
sclaunderous and offensive to his majesty. But to the contrary, we no sooner
speak of those that be in favor, and beeloued of the prince, but they are not
only with speed advertised what was spoken of them: but they further dyuine
what we thought of them. Therefore my friend courtier, sith it lies not in
thee to diminish or impair his credit, that is in favor with ye prince, and
beeloued in ye court: neither to displace his matters and suyts he takes in
hand, and yt thou have no authority to reform and govern the common weal, nor
to redress and amend the wrongs and injuries received, I would wish thee to
follow my counsel. If thou spy the fauts and imperfections of the court, that
thou rather suffer and abide them, in keepyng them secret: the^ to seem to
reprove them openly, when thou see princes the^ selves contented to dissemble
and cover them privily. It is therefore the sounder counsel, to follow and
serve those that are in favor and credit, then to pursue them in word or
deed. And therefore ye courtier must be very choice with whom he is
familiar, to whom he speaks, whom he trusts, who hears him, and of whom
he receives all his intellygence. For there is great difference beetweene the
words that are spoken, and the intent and meaning with which they were spoken.
For the bowels and intrails of courtiers are so damnable, and their hearts so
crooked, and diuerted from the right path way of bounty and goodness, that the
new and ignorant courtier shall think him self much profited by their aduices,
and admonitions, when in deed they shall but deceive him: and shall think he
was well counseled, when he shall find him self the most deceived in the
world, and in greater anger then before. There are some also so little
contented with ye prince, and so ill recompensed for their saruice, that they
are not only not his friends, but they practyse secretly to purchase him more
enemies. And when the courtier sees, that he that is in favor and credyt,
does in deed styck close with him unfeignedly, what need he care then,
though all the rest be his enemies. And the good courtier must consider, that
he goes not to the court to revenge iniuryes, but only to purchase honor and
profyt. To whom also I geeue counsel, that he be not enemy to him that is in
favor, nor friend to his enemy: and yet it shall be best for him to be friend
to all, and enemy to none, if he can possible. Who so ever desires to be
well thought of in the court, and to be beeloued of courtyers, it is better
for him to suffer injuries done him, then he him self to be a procurer of
them to others. And for the injuries, detractyons, and mutynyngs that they
shall raise against the favored of the court, no man ought to trust any other
person then him self: sith that for the most part whom they do trust, (when
he shall have need of the good report, and credit of him that is in favor
with the prince, thinkyng to do him a piece of great saruice) he shall not
care to unfold to him even the bottom of his friends secrets, which were
committed to him in great secresy. He must also consider that he can not
possibly in a short time grow in favor with the prince, nor come also to be
accepted for a friend of him that is in favor about the prince: but the sooner
to hasten his good fortune, he must acquaint him self thoroughly with the
officers and servants of the beeloued, and do them a thousand pleasures daily,
as well in courteous words, as in seruyng their turns also with money or jewels,
presenting them ever with some pretty small token from them, to have them in mind,
and to remember them to their masters. For the true order of this disorder, is
in effect to be rather friend to their servants, then familiar or beeloued with
their masters, that are in so great favor: he must also be informed, which of
his servants (that is in estimacion with the prince) is in best credit with his
master, and him he must seek to make his friend above al other his fellows.
For even as the prince has a servant whom he loves, that leads him
altogether: even so likewise has the favored courtier, a servant about him, yt
commands him. There is no will so free and lyberal, neither any lord so high
and absolute, nor judge so upright a iusticer, but in ye end he geeueth more
trust and credit to one, then to an other. And hereof proceeds most commonly,
that we love not those we ought to love, but those whom we fansy most. Now
therefore following our intent, touching the visitacion of courtiers, he must
lay watch, and consider well to procure knowledge, first, if any such noble men,
or other his friends, (which he has devotion to visyt) be occupied, or
withdrawn to their bed cha^bers, for some private busynes of theirs, for if it
were so, they woold rather think he came to trouble them, the^ to visit them.
And therefore he that is wise (in visiting his friends) may not be too
importune upon them to prease into their bed chamber, neither to be too
tedious and unpleasant in his words. There are some so solitary, yt woold
never be vysyted, and others that desires to be visited every day, others
there be yt woold the visitacion shoold be short, others that take such
pleasure to hear a long discourse, that he woold his tale shoold never be
ended. So that the courtier must look into the natures of men, and so to frame
his visitacions, according to the conditions of their mind: and to remember his
visitations to great, and grave men, be not so often and daily, that they be
troublesome to him: nor so seldom, that they may think them strangers, and
that they had forgotten him. That only deserves the name of a true visitacion,
where the person visyted may not be troubled with importunacy, nor the visyter
may dymynish any part of his credyt and estimacion, and also that he prejudice
not his own commodyty in his affairs. I speak it for some that are so
troublesome in their visytacions, and so foolish and tedious in their words,
not knowing how to make an end, that we may better call them troublesome,
envious, and impudent, then honest vysiters, and faithful friends. And
therefore we should leave them so contented we vysyt, that they shoold rather
be angry to leave our company, then that they should complayn of our
importunity: geeuing them rather occasyon to meet us with a pleasant
countenance, when we enter into their house, then to make them hyde them
selves, or fly from us, when they see us, and to say they are not within. And
me thinks in deed where we have not great and straight friendship, or else
some affairs of great importance that touches us much, it should be
sufficient to vysyt our friends and acquaintance, once in a month: and where
they would see us more oftener, let us carry till they complayn, and find fault,
and send to us to let us understand it, and not that we be so ready to come
to offer and present our selves unto them, unless the necessity of our cause
do urge us. There are some persons so indiscreet in being vysited, that when
others come to see them, either they make the gates to be shut upon them,
or they cause their servants to say they are not within, or else they get them
out at the backdore, or they fayn that they are a little a^rafed, only to avoid
and fly from these troublesome and babbling visyters* So that they had rather
see a seriant enter into his house to arrest them for debt, then to be cumbred
with these loathsome and pratyng vysyters. Also yt is not fyt to go see their
friends at unlawful hours, as about dynner or supper time: for those that are
vysyted, will rather thynk they come to dyne or suppe with them, then of
curtesy and good will to see them. It happens sometimes, that many are brave
and rytch in apparel, that keep but a poor and mean ordynary at their table,
sparyng from their mouth to lay yt upon their backs: and therefore they are
very loath, and offended, that any of their friends or famylyars should take them
at meals to judge of them: for they thynk yt less pain to fast from meat
secretly, then that their scarcety should openly be discovered. Also the laws
of honesty, and ciuylity, do not permit any man to enter into the house, hall,
or chamber of an other, without knockyng, or calling first at the door. For
that only pryuyledge to come into the house suddenly, and speak never a word,
beelongeth to the husband or masters of the house. Also it is not good to go
see his friend when he is at play, for if he be a loser, it can not be but
he will chafe and be in choler (in his mind) with his friend, to come then to
trouble him, and to let him of his play: And if happily he were a wynner before
his friend came to see him, and afterward chance to be a loser again: he
will lay thoccasyon of his loss upon his friend that came of good will to see
him, and say that he turned his good luck away from him, and that he came but
to trouble him, taking it rather for an offense and injury done him, then for
any good love or duty showed him. If our friend in like manner whom we go to
vysyt, come out of his chamber to receive us, not byddyng us come into the
camber, nor to sit down, but standing to talk with us without any other
curtesy or enterteynment, we may easily perceive by this his manner of
interteynment that he geeueth us good and honest leave to depart when we
will. The wise, and fine courtyer, will as easily find and understand him by
his signs, as he will do sometimes by his words. Also the courtier must
take great heed that inseemyng to use curtesy, he happen not to make some
foolish countenance in pulling of his cap, in making curtesy, coming into the
hall, or taking a stool to sit down, lest he be therefore marked and mocked of
the standers by, or noted for proud or presu^ptuous, for to stay or let at
these triffles, a man rather gets the name of a glorious, light, and proud:
then of a grave and sober man. All things touching conscience, ciuility, and
honor, the good courtier should always have in memory, and before his eyes,
when he shall discourse with his lord, or vysyt his friend. And for the first
beeginning of his discourse, and talk with him (after they are set down
togethers) he must ask him how his body does, and whether all his house be
meery and in good health: for yt is the thing that we must first procure for
our own private commodity, and secondly desire yt for our friends. Also in the
courtyers vysitacions he may not be too curious or inquisytiue of news,
nether over beesy to tell news: for after his friend were once advertised of the
troth, it might be lightly, he woold thank him for his coming and comend him
for his curtesy: and notwtstanding blame him for his news, and count him a
liar. And if it happen we find the party whom we visyt, sad, comfortles, and
in some necessity, although he were not our friend, yet for that he is a
chrystyan, we ought to comfort him in words, and to seek also to help and
relieve him with some what. Licurgus in his laws he made ordained, that it
should not be lawful for any man to come to see a prisoner, but he should
held to deliver him: nor any poor man, but he shoold relieve him: nor any
sick or diseased parson, but he should help and comfort him to his able power.
And truly me thinks Licurgus had great reason to make this law, since we see
that in experience, that a man's mind, for one only thing that is geeuen him,
is better contented and satisfied: then with a thousand words that they can
speak to him. And if his house whom they go to vysyt, and where he dwells,
be his own inheritance, and fee simple, or that he has it by lease or
purchase, or that he buylt it out of the ground, or if he have repaired or
new coated yt, the courtier must pray him to let him see yt, and when he has
seen yt he must greatly commend it to him: for all mortal men have this
common fault and humor, that we must be praised of our doings and not
reproved for our faults. Further if they vysyt any sick person, they must
remember they speak but little to him, and that softly, and pleasant matters:
for otherwise yt should seem (and they will also beeleeue) he came to see him,
rather to aggrauat his sickness more, then to comfort him. We must ever make
short visytacions, not only with the sick and dyseased, but the whole and
sound. And then the good courtier must take his leave of them, when he is even
in his most pleasant discourse, to thend they may entreat him to tarry longer:
and not to tarry till they seem to license him by outward signs and
ceremonies: and he that shall go visyt an other, let him take heed he be
not so long, and tedious in his talk, that the parson whom he visyteth do
rise before him. For it were too plain a token he were weery of his company
and long tariyng, sith he rose before him to geeue him occasion to depart. If
his wife whom he visits, be not a sister or kynswomen of the courtiers yt
visyts him, or that they be not of very familyar acquaintance togethers, he
should not once seem to ask for her, much less to desire to see her. For as
Scipio says, a man should not trust any to see his wife, nor to prove his
sweord. It is also a custom used among courtiers, yt when they go to any man's
house to see him, before they light of on their horse, they send to know
whether he be within or no. And when the courtier takes his leave of him he
has visyted, he must not suffer the gentilman to bring him out of his chamber
to accompany him, much less to come down the staiers with him: which if he
use in this manner, the other shallbee bound to thank him for his coming, and
shall commend him for his ciuility. And if it happen when we go to vysyt some
noble man, or other beeloued of ye court at his lodging, and yt at our coming
he is ready to come out of his house to ride abroad in the fields to take air,
or to ride to ye court to solicyte some of his affairs, or to ride abroad into
the town for his pleasure, the dylygent courtyer must willyngly accompany him,
and offer him all the service he can: and so he shall deserve double thanks of
him, the one for his coming, and the other for his gentle offer and company. To
visyt the princes servants, it is not ye manner (for that they are always
occupied in the princes service) neither shall they have such time of leisure as
other have. And because they have no time comodious to see the^ at home at
their own houses, yet at the least the good courtier must needs accompany them
at times when they go abroad. For there is more reason the esteemed courtier
should make more of him that accompanies him, then of ye other that is too
importunat and toublesome to him.

Of the good countenance and modesty the courtier should have, in beehauyng
him self at the prince or noble man's table in the time of his meal. Cap. vii.
THose that are abiding still in princes court, must in any case go seldom, or
not at al, abroad to others tables, but always to keep their own. For that
courtier that runs from table to table, to eat of there is cost, to have his
meat free, is not so sparing of his purse, as he is too prodygall and lavish
of his good reputacion. Therefore Eschines the philosopher being demanded one
day, what a man should do to be counted good, he answered thus. To beecome
a parfyt Greek, he must go to the church willingly, and of good devotion,
and to the wars of necessity: but to feasts and bankets, neither of will, nor
of necessity, unless it be to do them honor and pleasure that do inuit
thee. Suetonius Tranquillus writes, that themperor Augustus prohibyted in
Rome, that no man should conuite each other, to feast, or banquet with an other,
but if his friend woold do him ye honor to come to his feast, that then he
should send him home to his house, of that meat he should have had at the
feast and banquet with them at their houses. And when he was asked of certain
of his friends what he meant to make this law: he gave them this answer. The
cause that moved me, good friends, to forbid plays, and bankets in Rome was:
because in play, no man can keep him self from swearing, and terrible
blaspheming the name of god: and in bankets every man is geeuen to detect and
defame his neighbor. Cicero reconteth of Cato the Censor, that he lying in his
death bed, at the mercy of god, should say these words. Four things I
remember I have done in my life, wherein I have rather showed my self a
voluptuous and negligent Barbarian, then a wise and good Romain citisin, for
the wc I find my self sore grieved.

The first is this. For that I spent a whole day and forgot to serve the gods,
and did not profyt my common weal in any thing, wc I should never have done.
For it is as great a dishonor for a philosopher to be counted an idle and
neglygent person: as it is for a noble heart, to be counted a rank coward.

The second is for that safly I might once have gone by land, and perilously I
hasarded my self upon the water. A thing wc I shoold well have let alone. For
never no wise man should ever have put him self into peril, onles yt were only
for the service of the gods, for the increase of his honor, or for the defense
of his country.

The third is, yt I opened once a great secret, and matter of importance to a
woman, wc I ought less to have done then all the rest. For in grave matters,
and things of counsel, there is no woman capable to geeue counsel, and much
less to take it, and least of all to keep it secret.

The fowerth was, that an other time I was contented to be overcome by a friend
of mine that earnestly inuyted me to his house to dinner, and thereupon I went
with him, wc I shoold not have done. For to say the troth, there was never
famous nor worthy person that went to eat in an other man's house, but yt he
diminished his liberty, hasardyng also his grauyty and reputacion to the rumor
and brute of others. The wc words being so wisely spoken by the prudent Cato,
were well worthy to be noted and carried away, and so much the more, yt being
now drawing to his last home, and even in his last breathing hour he only
spoke of these four things and no more, whereof, although he were a Romain,
yet he showed to us a repenting mind. But woe is me, yt albeeit I bear the
name of a christian, yea and that I am so in deed, yet in that last day when
nature sommons me, I fear me, and beeleeue assuredly I shall have cause to
repent me of more then four things. Now by these things heretofore recyted
we may easily conjecture, that albeeit we are contented to be entreated and
requested in many things, yet in this only to go to others tables to feast.
and in strange houses we shoold not be entreated, but rather compelled and
against our wills. And where the courtier is forced by importunancy to accept
the bidding, without offering him self before, he deserves as great thanks of
the bidder for his coming, as the other did in bidding him. For if it should
not be so, it should seem rather a dynner for strangers that travels by the
way, then for noble men and gentelmen that comes from the court. For that day
the courtier grants to dine with any man, the same day he byndeth him self
to be beeholding to him that bids him: for although he come to him of good
will, yet to acquit his curtesy done him, he is bound of necessity. Also it
is a small reputacion (and worthy great reproach) that a courtier make his
boste he has eaten at all the tables and officers boords in the court, and yt
no man can say he has once been at dinner or supper with him at his own house.
And truly I remember I knew once a courtier yt might dispe^d above two
hundredth ducats by year, who told me, and assured me he never bought stick
of wood to warm him with in his chamber, nor pot to sees his meat in, neither
spyt to roast with all, nor that ever he had any cater for his provision, save
only yt he had made a register of many noble men's boords, amongst who^ he
equally divided his dyners and suppers. By means whereof he saved al his
charges, save only his men's board wages. But what vileness or discurtesy coold
equal the misery and shame of this careless courtier? Suer not that of ye
meanest and poorest slave of the world, ye lives only by his hyer: no it
deserves not to be compared unto it. For to what end desire we the goods of
