this world, but yt by them we may be honored, relieve our parents and
kinsmen, and thereby also win us new friends? what state or condition so ever
he be of, yt has enough and abundance, we are not bound to esteem ye more
of him for that, nor to do him the more honor, but only for that he spends
it well, and woorshipfully, and for his honor, if he be honorable. And this we
speak of gentleman as of cytisyn. And he that in court makes profession to
dine at other men's tables, I dare undertake if they dine betimes on ye holly
day, he will rather lose saruice in the morning, then dinner at noone. And if
any friend come to lie with these sort of courtiers, and that he be but newly
come to the court, straight ways he will have him with him to dinner, and bring
him to salute ye gentleman where he dines that day, saying that he was bold
to bring his kinsman and friend with him to salute him, and all this is not so
much to bring him acquainted with him, as it is to spare his meat at home for
both. And yet they have an other knack of court fyner the^ this. They flatter
ye pages and servants, because they should ever geeue the^ of the best wine at
ye table, and with certain familiar noddes and sweet words they entertain the
lords, shewers, and caruers, and make much of them, yt they should set before
them full dyshes and of ye best and deintiest meat. There are also some of
these courtiers that to be well waited upon at the table, and to make them his
friends, do sometimes present the steward with a velvet cap, the shewers with a
pair of washed or perfume gloves, the pages with a sweord girdel, and the
butlers or cooberd keepers with some other pretty reward or devise. And it
chances often times in noble men's houses that there are so many gests to dyne
and sup with him daily, that many times the board will not hold the^ al by a
great number: wc when they once perceive, to see how quickly and with what
speed the courtiers take their places to set them down and to be suer of a
room, it is a world to see it. But oh I woold to god they were so happy and
dilygent to go to the church and hear a sermon, as they are busy to get them
stools to sit at the table. And if perhaps a courtier come late, and yt the
table be all ready full, and the lurch out, yet he will not be ashamed to
eat his meat nevertheless. For albeeit he can not be placed at his ease yet he
is so bold and shameless, that rather then fail he will sit of half a buttock,
or beehynd one at the table. I remember I saw once at a noble man's board three
courtiers set upon one stool, like the four sons of Amon, and when I
rebuked them for it, and told them it was a shame for them, they answered me
merely again, that they did it not for that there wanted stools, but to prove
if need were if one stool woold bear them three. Such may well be called
greedy gluttons, and shameless prowlers, without respect or honesty, that when
they are dead, would be buried in the highest place of the church: and when
they are alive, little force at whose table they sit, or how they sit, litel
regarding their honor or estate. Truly for him that is poor and needy, to
seek his meat and drink where he may come by it best it is but meet: but for
the gorgeous courtyer, be decked with gold, be buttoned and be iewelled,
ietting in his veluets and silks, to beg and seek his dinner daily at every
man's board, being nobly and honorably enterteined of the prince, and able to
bear his countenance: what reproach, defame, and dishonor is it to him? He
that uses daily to run to other men's tables, is often times forced to sit
lowest at ye board upon a broken stool, and to be served with a rusty knyfe,
to eat in foul dishes, and to drink for a change whot water, and wine more
then half full of water, and to eat hoar bread, and that yt of all others yet
is worst of all, every one of the servants looks over ye shoulders on him, and
are angry with him in their mynds. Truly he that with these conditions goes
abroad to seek his dinner, were better in my opinion to fast with bread and
water at home, then to fill his belly abroad. But such men's reward, that haunts
men's houses in this manner, is this in the end, that ye noble men to whose
houses they come to, are offended with them, the stewards of the house murmr
at them, the pages and servants mocks them, and laughs the^ to scorn, the
tasters and cup bearers chafe with them in their mynds, the cubberd keepers
wonder at them, ye clarks of the kychyn thinks them importunat and shameless
creatures. Wherefore it follows (who soever will observe it) yt so soon as
the servants see him once come into the dyning chamber, some of them hydes ye
stool where he woold sit down, others set before him the woorst meat of the
board and the filthiest dishes they have, and therefore he yt may have at home
at his house his poor little pyttance well dressed, a fair white table cloth, a
bright knife, new and white bread, wood and candel in the winter, and other
necessaries: if he like better to go from table to table, from kychyn to
kychyn, and from one buttery to an other, I will suppose he does it for great
spare and hardness, or for want of honesty and good manners. Now he that keeps
an ordinary house, and remayns always at home, may dine if it be in the somer
season, in his shyrt if he list, he may sit when he will, and where it
please him, he drinks his wine fresh, and has the flies driven from his table
with the ventola, he disdaigneth the court and noble men's boords, keeping his
own as frank and as sparing as he list, and no man to gayn say him: yea and
after meat he is at lyberty to sit still, and take his ease, or to walk abroad
in the shade as he will. And in winter if perhaps he be were, he straight
shifts him, and changes all his clothes, gets him a furred night gown on the
back of him, and a pair of warm slyppers to heat his cold feet with all, he
eats his meat warm and smoking whot, and takes yt he likes best, he drinks
white wine, red wine or claret wine as he thinks good, and need never to care
for them that beehold him. And therefore so great privileges as those be of
lyberty, the courtier should never refuse to buy them for his money, much less
for the gayn of a meals meat he should leave to enjoy them. But if the
courtier will needs determyn to vysyt noble men's boords, he must be very
ware, yt in coming to a noble man's table, he do not so much commend his fare
and ordinary, that he complayn of other men 3 tables where he has fed. For
it is a kind of treason to defame and sclauader those, whose houses they are
wont to visyt often. And when he is set at the table, the courtier must beehaue
him self modestly, he must eat temperatly, and fynely, he must delay his wine
with water, and speak but little: so that those that are present can not but
praise him for his temperancy and sober diet, but also for his wisdom and
moderat speech. To feed mannerly is to be understand, not to blow his nose in
his napkyn, nor to lean his arms upon the table, not to eat to leave nothing
in the dysh, not to find faults with the cooks, saying the meat is not enough,
or not well dressed. For yt were a great shame for the courtier to be noted of
the wayters, to be a belly gut and to be counted a gross feeder. There are
some also that make them selves so familiar and homly in the house, that they
are not contented with that is served them in the dysh, but shamefully they pluck
that to them that is left in other dyshes, so that they are esteemed for
Iesters, no less sawsy and malepert in their order, then insatiable in their
beastly eating. The good courtier must also take heed he lay not his arms to
fair on the table, nor that he make any noise with his teeth or his tongue,
nor smack with his mouth when he eats, and that he drink not with both his
hands on the cup, nor cast his eyes too much upon the best dishes, that he
know, nor tear his bread with his teeth, that he lick not his fyngers, nor
adoone eating before others, nor to have too greedy an appetite to the meat or
sauce he eats, and that in drynkyng he gulp not with his throat. For such
manner of feedyng, rather beecommeth an alehouse, then a noble man's table. And
although the courtyer can not go over all the dyshes that comes to the board,
yet at least let him prove a little of every one, and then he must praise the
good cookry and fine dressyng of them al. For commonly the noble men and
gentlemen that inuit any to their board, take it discourteously, and are ashamed
if the inuyted praise not their meat and drink they geeue them, and not only
the noble men are ashamed of yt, but also the other officers that have the
charge to see yt well dressed, and in good order. Always he that eats at an
other man's table, to do as he ought, shoold praise the woorthines of him that
bad him (yea though perhaps he made a lie) and commend the great care and
diligence of his officers in furnishing his table with so good meats, and in
setting on yt forth in so good order. I say not without a cause that sometime
a praise with a lie may well stand togethers, sense we see some noble men's
tables so sclender furnyshed, and that his ordinary should seem rather a
preparatiue supper and diet for a sick man that means to take physic in the
next morning, then an ordynary, or dinner for Easter day. And therefore I say,
that of right the lords and masters are pleased, when they here their officers
and servants commendid. For they choose most commonly such a steward, as they
knew to be wise, and courteous of nature: a treasorer, true and faithful: a
purueier, expert and diligent: a butler, hasty and melancony: the groom of his
chamber, paynfull and trusty: his secretary, wise and secret: his chappleyn
simple, and his cook fine and curious. For many think it more glory to have an
excellent cook in their house, then to have a valiant captayn, to keep a
strong piece, or hold. They are contented in court that noble men's chappleins
be rather simple then over wise, or well learned. For if he read but little,
he has the sooner say service, and therewith also is more fyt to drudge and
do service about the house. Now therefore continuing our beegoonne purpose, the
courtier that eats at other men's tables, must see he drink little, and that
his wine be well delayed with water. For wine tempered with water, brings
two commodityes: the one, it makes him sober that drinks it, and shall not be
ouerseen: the other, he shall not dystemper him self, that the wayters have any
occasyon to laugh at him. If yt should hap sometimes that he found the wine
well watered before, that yt had stood a pawlyng long, or that yt were some
what sharp or sower, or that the water were to whot: the good courtier shoold
not therefore immedyatly complain and find fault at the table, for so he
shoold shame the servants, and make them angry with him, and also displease
their master. Truly it is a grief to suffer yt, to see that he that has
nothing at home in his own house, either to eat or drynk, will yet look to be
well used at an other man's house, and is never satisfied. I speak yt for
certain indiscreet courtiers, and wanting judgment, that being at any man's
board, (without any shame) dare dispraise the cooks, and speak ill of them, if
perhaps the taste of their porage and meat myslyke them, and that it be not
good, and according to their appetit: and of the butlers, if the wine be not
cold and fresh: of those that weight above, if every thing they call for, be
not done at a beck and quickly: of the stewards of the house, if they be not
served immediately: and of the boys and pages, if they geeue them not drink
sodeinly: of the caruers, if they carue them not to their lyking: and also with
the clarks of the kychyn, if they see them not served with meat enough, that
there be enough lest upon the table. So that the noble men's officers (for the
more part) have more trouble and displeasure, by the discontentacion of those
that come to their masters table, then they have by the evil words their
masters speaks to them. And for this respect therefore no man ought to be so
bold as once to open his lyps to complayn of any want in an other man's house,
as if they serve him with claret wine, rather then with white: or with white,
then claret. For a right and parfect courtier, shoold not set his appetit in ye
taste nor variety of wynes, or meats in an others house. I grant that it is
very fit, and lawful for young courtiers, to run well, to leap far, to
throw the bar of Iron, to dance well, to ride a horse well to manedge and
geeue him his carere well, and to turn well, to handle his weapon well, and to
break a staff well, and otherwise to help him self with all manner of weapons:
but for one to defye an other in drinking, it shoold be a great sacrilege of
the courtier. The Scithiens, as ratifieth Trogus Pompeius, were so sober and
modest in eating and drinking at their meats, that it was a foul fault among
them to break wynd, or belch. And therefore now a days we find few Scithiens,
but many drinkers, which depart from the feast so full freight, as immediately
when they are come home, they unload their charged stomach, and lay open all that they have eaten and dronken. Wherefore he yt uses to drink clean, and
pure water, is at more liberty, then those that drink wine simply, without
compou^d. For excessive drinking of wine, does not alonly troble and distemper
the brain and judgment of the drinker: but further discovers to you, great
and horrible vices. Therefore yet touching our matter, I say once again, that it
is a fond dispute, and argument, to prove which of the wines were best,
pleasant, and most swetest, and which is oldest or newest, sharp or hard, soft
or sweet, clearest or darkest, or of best taste or quickest savor. For to judge
of the taste of wynes, and to know the goodness and perfection of it, rather (to
say truly) beelongeth to a Tauerner or vintner, then rightly to an honest
courtier. And it is fitter, and more decent also for him, to talk of arms and
chivalry, then to deal in discourse of Bacchus feasts. What a mockry, and
foolish nicety is it of him, that not only drinks water alone, but also cannot
drink it in that cup, where there has been wine filled before. He shall also
be very circumspect that is bidden to a strangers house, that he drink not
so deep at a draught, that he leave nothing in the cup, neither that he
drink so long as he has breath, and the water stand in his eyes again. For
the grave and sober courtier shoold never drink, till he might no more, nor
till there were none left. Also when he is at the table, he shoold not enter
in argument and dispute with any, neither shoold he be obstinat in oppinion,
and much less use filthy or uncomely talk: and he must also bridle nature
much, that he cry not out in laughyng as some do. For like as yt sounds to
his reproach, to be noted a glutton, and drunkerd: it is in like case far
worse, to be accounted a fool, and a iester.

Also it preuayleth little that a courtier be moderate, and honest in eating,
if he be dishonest, and insolent in his talk. For many times it happens at
noble men's boords, that they take more pleasure in some, then in other some:
not to see them eat and drink well, but to hear them tell lies, and to be
pleasant at the board. Therefore as we have said, the wise courtyer shoold
praise and commend all that he sees served at an other man's table, and it is
not lawful for him to dislyke or dispraise it. And further because he is
fedd at an other man's charge, he must of necessity take all in worth that is
geeuen him, and set before him, and not to look to have that that he
desires. And when there is any question moved at the table of the best and
most delicat dishes, and of the fynest cooks, and of ye new kinds of broths
and sawces, and from whence the fattest capons come, it shall not be fit for
ye wise courtier to say in that al yt he knows and understands. For how
much honor it is for him to be able to talk in martial feats, or chiualry: so
much more dishonor and reproach it is to him, to be skillful in dressing of
meats, and all to fill the belly. I remember that being one day at a bishops
board, I hard a knight make great bost and vaunt, that he coold make vii.
manner of fricasies, iiii. kinds of pyes, xii. sorts of sawces, and x. of fruit
tarts, and xii. diverse ways to dress eggs: but to hear him tell these things
was not to be accounted of so much, as the gestures and countenance he made
in telling them. For he did lively show with his hands the present making of
them, the eating of them, and the right tasting of them with his tongue. And
because it happens many times that in some noble man's house there is not
like fare and entertainment that an other has, the cyuill courtier shoold not
be so dishonest, as to make report he leaves that noble man's table, to go
to an others that is better served. For the worthy courtier shoold not haunt
that table where he fares best, but where he fyndeth him self best welcome,
and esteemed. Ah how many noble men and knyghts sons are there, that spare
not to go to any man's board for his meat and drink, yea though it fall out
they be their fathers enemies: and they do it not in respect to reconcile
them, and their fathers togeethers, but rather for a good meals meat, or more
aptly to say, to fill their bellyes with dainties.

What company the courtier shoold keep, and how he shoold apparel him self.
Cap. viij.
THe wise Courtier, both in court and out of court, and in all places where he
comes, must take great regard he accompany with none, but with wise, and
virtuous men. For if he do not, he can not win nor acquire such honor by
his well doing, as he shall lose his credit, by keeping ill company. And
therefore he shall enforce him self always to be in the presens and company
of virtuous and noble men, and shall confer with the most grave, wise, and
honest gentlemen of the court: For using this way, he shall bynd them to him,
by reason of his daily access to them: and he shall purchase him self a good
oppinion of them, besides the good example he shall leave to others to tread
his steps, and follow his coorse. For what is more true, then when a young
gentleman comes newly to the court, you shall see immediately a company of
other young fools, a company of amarous squires, light and idle persons, a
company of troublesome iesters, and covetous praters, besides other young fry in
court, that when they know a new come courtier (namely being of great living)
They will seek to attend upon him, and trayn him to the luer of their affects
and manner, bringing him to like of their qualities and conditions. Wherefore
conningly to shake of the rout of these needy greedy retayners, he must
altogether feed them with fair words, and show them good countenance, and
yet notwithstanding seek by all policy he can to fly their fellowship and
company. Noble men's sons knights sons, and gentleme^s sons, may not think
their friends sends the^ to ye court, to learn new vices, and wicked
practices, but to win them new friends, and obtain the acquaintance of noble
men whose credit and estimation, with the prince may honor and countenance
them, and by their virtues and means, may after a time be brought into the
princes favor also, and daily to rise in credit and reputation amongst others.
Therefore such fathers as will send their children to the court, onles they do
first admonish them well how they ought to beehaue them selves, ere that they
recomend them to to the charge and oversight of some dear and especial friend
of theirs, that will reprove them of their faults when they do amiss. I say
they were better to lay irons on there feet, and send them to. Bedlem or such
other like house where madd men be kept. For if they be bound there in irons,
it is but to bring them to their wits again, and to make them wise: but to
send them to the court lose, and at lyberty without guide, it is the next way
to make them fools, and worse then mad men, assuring you, no greater danger
nor injury can be done to a young man, the^ to be sent to the court, and not
committed to the charge of some one that should take care of him, and look
straightly to him. For otherwise, it were impossible he should be there many
days, but he must needs run into exces and foul disorder, by means whereof
he should utterly cast him self away, and heap upon their parents heads
(continual curses, and greefes, during their lives. And therefore their
fathers) supposing after they have once placed their sons in the court, that
they should no more carke nor care for them, nor reckon to instruct them to be
wise and vrrtuous) find when they come home to them again, that they are laden
with vices, ill complexioned, worse aparelled, their clothes al tottered and
torn, having vainly and fondly spent and played away their money, and worst of
al forsaken their masters, leaving them displeasid with their saruice. And of
these I would admonish the young courtier, because he must of necessity
accompaigny with other young men, that in no case he acquaynte him self with
vicious and ill disposed persons, but with the honest, wise, and courteous:
amongst whom he shall put upon him a certain grave and stayed modesty,
fitting him self only to there companies, being also apt and disposed to all
honest and virtuous exercices, decent for a right gentilman, and virtuous
courtier, shunning with his best policy, the light, foolish, and vain toys
of others. And yet notwithstanding these, my intent and meaning is not to seem
to persuade or teach him to beecome an hippocrite, but only to be courteous,
honest, and well beeloued of other young gentlemen: winning this reputation
withal, to be esteemed for the most virtuous and honestist among them,
gallant and lively in his disportes and pastimes, of few words, and small
conversation amongst bosters and backbyters, or other wicked and naughty
persons: not to be sad among those that are merry, nor dumme among, those yt
talk wisely, and of grave matters: nor to believe he should be accounted a
trim courtier, to take his book in his hands to pray, when others will take
the ball to play, or go about some other honest recreation or pastime for
exercise of the body. For so doing, they would rather take him for a fool and
an Ippocrite, then for a virtuous and honest young man.

Being good reason the child should use the pleasures and pastimes of a child,
young men, disportes and acts of youth: and old men also grave and wise
recreacions fyt for them. For in the end do the best we can, we can not fly
the motions of the flesh, wherein we are borne into this world. These young
gentilmen courtiers must take heed that they become not troblesome,
importunate, nor quarelers, that they be no filchers liers, vacabonds, and
sclaunderers, nor any way geeuen to vice. As for other things, I would not
seem to take from them their pastyme and pleasure, but that they may use them
at their own pleasure. And in all other things lawful and irreprouable,
observing time and hours convenient, and therewithal to accompaigny them
selves with their fellows and compaignions. Also the young courtier that comes
newly to the court, must of necessity be very well apparelled, according to
his degree and calling, and his servants that follow him well appointed. For in
court men regard not only the house and family he comes of, but mark also
his apparel and servants that follow him. And I mislike one thing very much,
that about the court they do rather honor and reverence a man brave and
sumptuous in apparel being vicious, then they do a man that is grave, wise,
and virtuous. And yet nevertheless the courtier may assure him self of this,
that few will esteem of him, either for yt he is virtuous or nobly borne, if
he be not al so sumptuously apparelled and well accompanied, for then only
will every man account and esteem of him. Wherefore I durst take upon me to
swear, if yt were possible to take oath of our bodies, that they would swear
they needed them not, much less desire so large compassed gowns, that every
puff of wynd might swell them as the sails of a ship, nether so long that
trailyng on the ground they gather dust, and cast it into our eyes. Howbeeit I
think now adays these fine men wear then large and wide, and women long with
traynes upon the ground: because in the court and else where, no man makes
reckning of him that spends but orderly, and only upon necessaries to go
clenly withal: but him they set by, that is prodigal, excessive and
superfluous. And who that in his doings and apparel is moderate, and
proceeds wisely: they hold him in court for a miserable and covetous man: and
contrarily, he that is prodigal and lavish in expense, him they count a noble
and worthy person. Albeeit the courtier come of a noble house, and that he be
young of years, rich, and welthy, yet would I like better he should use
rather a certain mean and measure in his apparel (wering that that is comely
and gentilman like) then others of most cost and worship. For like as they
would count him a fool for wering that he could not pay for: So they likewise
would think him simple, if he ware not that that become him, and that he
might easily come by. His apparel should be agreeable with his years, that is
to say, on the holly days some more richer and brauer then on the woorkydayes:
and in the winter of the whottest furrs: in the somer light garments of satin
and damask: and to ride with, some others of lesser price and more durable. For
as the wisdom of man is known by his speaking: so is his dyscretyon decerned
by his apparel. Let not the poor courtyer studdy to wear or deuyse any new
or strange fashioned garment, for if he be of that humor, he shall quickly
undo him self, and geeue others occasion also to follow his light and vain
invention. There are now adays found out so many strange ways to dress meat,
and so many fasshions and paterns of apparel, that now they have universities
of taylers and cooks. What more greater vanity and lightness can there be then
this? that they will not suffer the mothers gowns to be made fyt for their
daughters: saying that they are old and out of fashion, and that they use now a
new kind of apparel and attire far from the old manner. And not withstanding
these gowns be it in manner new, good, hole, clean, rich, and well made, and
without weme, yet their daughters must needs have new gowns at their
mariadge. So that we may aptly say, that a new folly, seeks always a new
gown, namely when they are light persons, without wit and discretion. And I
pray you is it not a goodly sight in ye court, to see a foolish courtier wear
a demie cappe, scant to cover his crown of his head, to have his bearde
marquizottyd, a payr of parfumed gloves on his hands, his shoes cut after the
best fasshion, a litel cutted cape, his hose fair pulled out, his dublet
sleues bravely cut and pinct, his rapier and his dagger guilted by his side:
and then on the other side the pestilens of penny he has in his purse to
bless him with, and beesides he is deep in the marchaunts book for all
those things he has taken up of credit of him.

Their nagges foot clothes would not be so litell and narrow, that should
seem a friars hoode, nether so great and large as the foot clothes of
bisshops moyles. Also the courtier must see that his footecloth be good and
hole, clean, and without spot, not tattered and seame rent. This we speak
because there are soome miserable courtiers that have their foot clothes
thread bare, broken and seame rent, foul and durty narro and all dug full of
holes with their spurs. And therefore no man deseruith to be called a right
courtier, onles he be fine and nete in his apparel he wears, and also
courteous and civil in his words and enterteinment. And yet touching ye rest
of the furniture of their horse, or gelding, their harnes and trappers must be
kept black and clean, and they must look that the reins of the bridel be
not broken nor unsown, wc I speak not without cause: for there are a number
of courtiers that at primero will not stick to set up a jest of a.100. or.200.
crowns, and yet will think much to geeue their poor horskeepers twelve pence
to by them a payr of raynes. And truly the courtier (in my judgment) that is
content to tie his hose with vntagged points, to see his fire smoke when he
should warm him, to ride with broken reins, and to cut his meat at the table
with a rusty knife, I would think him base borne, and rudely brought up. When
the courtier will ride his horse, let him look ever before he take his back,
that he have all his furniture fyt for him, his main and tail fynely comed,
his styrrops bright glistering, his stirrup leathers strong, and his sadell
well stuffed, and above all let him sit upright in his seat, and carry his
boddy even, swaruing of nether side, holding his legs still and keep his
stirrope. For this name to be called Chiuallier (signifies in our tongue a
rider of a horse) came first because he could ride and manedge his horse well,
And when he would stir his legs to spur his horse, let him beeware he
stoop not forwards with his boddy, and when he does spur his horse, let
him not spur him low but hye in the flanckes, and whether he will run or
stand still with his horse, let him always have his eye upon ye raines, that
in no case the raines, go out of his hand. And in geeuing his horse a carere,
let him not writh his body, nor be to busy in beating or spurring his horse
often. For in his carrire, to know when to spur him, when to geeue him head,
or to pull him back again, and to stop him, I have seen many take yt upon
them, but few in deed that ever were skillfull and could do yt well. Now the
courtyer being mounted on horse or moile, without his rapier by his side,
seems rather a physician that goth to visit his sick pacients, then a
gentilman of the court that for his pleasure and disport rides abroad through
the streates.

And if he were by chance intreatid by some noble man to accompany him or to
ride beehind him of pleasure through the streates, every honest courtier ought
not only to do it, but unasked to be ready to offer him self to wait upon
him and go with him willingly. And let the fine courtier beeware, that in
geeuing his hand to a gentilwoman he be not gloued, and if she be a
horsback, that he talk with her bare headed, to do her the more honor, and
if she ride beehind him, and they chance to discourse togethers, let him
never look back upon her to beehold her, for that is a rude manner and a token
of ill education. And one common courtesy there is among courtyers, that when
they are in talk with ladies and gentilwomen and enterteining of them, they
suffer them to do with them what they will, to reign over them, and to be
ouercomed in argument of them, and they hold yt good manner to do them
service, when they have any occasion offered to serve them. And when he shall
accompany any gentylwoman to go a visitation with her, or to walk abroad for
their pleasure through the streates, he must ride fair and softly, and if she
should happen to keep him so long in talk till she should light, the good
courtier must bear yt courteously, and make a good countenance as though it
grieved him nothing, sith we know very well, that when women beeginne once to
talk, it is impossible for them to make an end, onles they be overtaken with
night, or prevented by some other accident. He that wilbee a courtier, must
wear his shoes black and clean, his hose straight to his legs, and his
garments without plight or wrincle, his sword fair varnished, his sherts
fynely wrought, and his capp standing with a good grace. For the chefest thing
of court is, that noble me^ be rich in apparel, and the right courtyers fine
and cleanly. It is not decent for a man to wear his slippers so long that the
cork be seen, nor his garments till they be torn, nor furre til yt be
bare before, nor shertes till they be worn out, nor his cappe till the
turffe be greasy, nor his coat till yt be threde bare, nor his girdell till
yt be half broken. For the courtier may not only wear his garments to
content himself, but also to like others that shall beehold yt. And after that
he is once determined to go to the court, he must suppose to go thither well
apparrelled, else they will not suer account him to be a right courtier. For in
this case, excuse of poverty may not be alleged, for they will think them
rather miserable, then poor courtiers. The good courtier may not spare in
court, to spend afterward at home: but he must pinche at home to be liberal
afterward in the court.

And yet once again I return to recite, that for a courtier to come into the
princes favor, he may not any way be sparing or miserable, but rather
honestly liberal, and bountiful. For seeldome times concur these two things
together, to be miserable, and yet with his mysery to attain to the princes
favor. I remember I saw a friend of mine once in the court were a ierkin faced
at the collar with martyrns, and they were all bare and greasy, and there was a
certain portugal in the court (a pleasant compaignion) that came to this
gentleman, and asked him properly, what fair Furrs they were he ware about his
neck: and this gentillman auswered him martirns: marterns sir says the
portingall, me thinks they are rather like furrs of Ashwednesday, then of
Shrouetewsday. And finely this portingall compared Mardi (that is tewsday) to
his martrin surrs: and so likewise his martrin furs to Mardi. And sure he
had great reason not to praise them, but greatly to rebuke him for them. For it
had been more for his honor and worshipp, to have had the collar of his ierking
lined with fair new white lamine, then with those old, stale, durty and swety
marterns. The brooches that our courtier must were in his capp must be very
rich, and excelently wrought, and his devise or word that he will have about
yt such, that though every man may read yt, yet few shall understand what yt
means. For such devises are ever lightly grounded of vain and fond toys, and
therefore they should be so much more secret and obscure. For suer the fault is
great enough in a man to deuiseyt, though he do not beewray yt. Also his
servants that waits upon him must needs go handsomely apparelled, and syne and
nete in their apparel. For it is small honor for the master to be well
apparellyd, if he let his servants go beggarly. There are many courtiers that
have their men following on them with threede bare clokes, torn coats, foul
shertes, broken hose, and rent shoos. So that these poor seruingmen, if ^or
one month they were that their master gives them, for three other months
after they were their own proper flesh. It is no wise man's part, but a mere
folly to keep a greater train then he is able. For that courtier that has
always many servants waiting on him, and they going tottered and torn, having
no good thing to put on their backs, (or at least that they have is but mean
and simple) shall sooner win the name of a broker, that prefarreth other men to
saruice, then of a master that keeps servants him self. The good courtier
must geeue unto all his servants that serve him, either apparel, or wages: for
that servant that serves only in house for bare meat and drink, shall never
serve truly while he does serve. And therefore let the courtier look well to
yt, that he enterteigne no man into his saruice, but that first he agree with
bim for standing wages: onles yt be that he be some neuew, or kynsman, or
some of his dear friends: else in the end, if he be a noble man (unless he do
so) he shall find that at the years end he shall spend him more, than if he
gave him ordinary wages, and beesids they will not be contented with him,
although yt be to his greater charge. Also let him consider well, if yt happen
that (when he has need of servants to wayre upon him) some brother or
neighbors child be offerid to him, whether he shall receive him or no. For
after he has him in his house, either he shallbee compelled to bear with his
faults, and disorders he shall do, or else desirous to rebuke and reform him,
or to send him home again, he shall but win anger and displeasure of his
father, or his proper kinsfolks. Suerly such courtiers as take those kind of
men into their service, have a great deal of pain and troble with them. And
truly it is too great a cruelty, that the courtier should be driven to bear
the dishonesty of his man ye serves him, when his own father could not away
with his conditions. Some fathers there are so blinded, and sotted with
fatherly affection, and difficulte besides to please, that they are not
contented that the courtier has received their son into his saruice, and
that he entreat him as if he were his own kynsman: but further they would
have the courtier his master bear withal his dishonesty and lewdnes: and if
they ran not frame the young man to their mind as they would have them, yet at
lest they would have his master to pity him, for that he is but young and has
no knowledge, and for a while to winck at all his faults, in hope of a better
amendment.

The courtier may not only see that his men be well in apparel, but he must
provide also that they have meat enough to put in their bellyes. For the
servants that are starued for meat, are wont to do small service, and besyds
that to complain much. Let him beware also he do not take into his saruice
any lewd persons busy bodies, and unquiet men, cutpurses, Ruffians, quarellers
or hooremongers: if he find that he have any such in his house, let him turn
him out of saruice straight: for by keeping such mates in his house, his house
shall never be well ordered, there shall ever be quarelling and swering
amongst them, and besyds that, the neighbors and common people shallbee
offended. Let the good courtier forsee that he have no cards nor dyce in his
house to occupy the servants. For these thriftles servants that are geeuen to
play, begin first to play, and afterward they learn to steal. Let the
courtier be well advised also when he chideth with his servants that he be
not too loud; that his voice may be hard abroad, as all the hosts and
Inkeepers are. For in being too loud he should be more dishonored, then
blamed, for the ill words he geeueth his man. Let him take heed also that he
do not call his servants dronkards, thieves, villeins, Jews, nor other such
like names of reproach. For these and such other like vncourteus words are of
small correction, and yet they bring displeasure and disdaigne enough. And if
the courtier can not geeue bountifully, and pleasure his officers and servants
that are about him, yet at least (how so ever the world go) let him not be
behynd with them in paiyng them their whole wages due to them: for so yt might
lightly happen, that the servants would begin to make complaynts of him, and
that unhappily in the end he might come to die with mysery in his enemies hands.

There is no enemy in the world so cruel, nor so much to be feared, as the
servant that is not contented with his master, for as he is the thief of the
house, so knows he very well what piece of his masters harnes is wanting for
his boddy to set on him, when he would in that place have an arrow for his
token. Therefore soon so as yt comes to the courtyers ears that any of his
servants complaigne of him, either let him geeue him all that he would have, or
put him out of his house imediatly. For if he do yt not, let him be assured
that that servant will never leave till he have him put in discord with his
friends, and defame with others. And above all things we have spoken of yet,
the courtier must chiefly look what his man is he trusts with his honor:
for in this case many are wont not only to be deceived, but also many times
scorned. And there are many that will put their goods into the hands and trust
of a man, but their honor, and things of gretest weight and importance, they
will sooner commit to the trust of a young foolish, and simple page, then of a
wise and stayed man. And therefore how much more his business is of weight and
importance, so much less should yt be reveled to the secrecy of a boy. And if
he do otherwise, I can assure him he shall sooner be spoken of of every man,
then he shall have his buysines dispatched. The courtier must also have his
chamber well hanged, and fynely kept, and clean, and his house and famyly all
in good order, and every man quiet. For the cleanes of the house, and ciuility
of the servants, are a great token and witness of the nobility of the master. In
the courtyers chamber wheare he lies, the bed must first of all be made, and
the cloth before the door let down, the chamber swept, the hangings and other
stuff that is there in good order, with some parfumes or other sweet odours,
so that it should laugh upon a man that comes into yt: for there are some in
the court so filthy and so il furnished of hangings and other stuff, that if
any man come to see their chambers, they seem rather sheep coats, then
courtiers chambers.

Of the wise manner the courtier should have to serve and honor the ladies and
gentil women, and also to satisfy and please the ushers and porters of the
kings house. Cap. ix.
LEt the good courtier be always circumspect that he seek not any favor at
the Justices hands, but that that is lawful. For if either he be denied, he
shall return with shame: or being granted, he shall leave his conscience to
gage. In suits and controversies between men of relygion in the spiritual
court, let him in no case deal. For at the first show they seem very easy to
the Judge, but when they come to vnripping of the matter, to judge of them,
then they are matters of great charge and conscience.

There were many towers in Iherusalem, to any of which the devil might have
brought Ihesus christ to have persuaded and tempted him to have thrown him
self down: howbeit he would not bring him but to the pinnacle of the church,
to let us under stand thereby, that he took more pleasure in one sin done
in the church, or of holy persons then of ten committed in the world, and
of wordlings. And notwithstanding the courtier do not see that the reason is
of his side that is recomended to him, he need never pass for that, to
entreat for him, or to charge his own proper conscience: as for example. If
any man entreat him to speak to ye judge, or to write him a letter. For many
times we see ye Judges make much more account of one only word or letter from
him that is in favor and estimation with ye prince, the^ they will of ye
religion and Justice of an other man. And alweyes write in this form. Right
worshipful or honorable, ye letters of favor that shall be requested of you.
etc. that by those words the judge may know, that for yt they were requested
and beesought and not that yt should seem you write for affection, for doing
otherwise, that that you shall write to him to satisfy others in, he will think
that you do it, because either for reason or duty he should perform your
letters. The like consideration and modesty a good prince should have in that
he does command: the like and self same should the esteemed and favored of
the court observe in his requests he makes. For many times the requests of
the beeloued in court are with more celerity performed, then the comissions of
the prince are accomplished. Let the courtier always have in his mind also,
that if he meet with any nobleman or Knight by the way, he do in any
condition return with him, and keep him compaigny, although the nobleman or
Knight strive with him, not to have him go back with him, yet let him not
suffer him self to be overcome, to let all men know, that notwithstanding the
noble man or Knight pass him in degree or apparel, yet he shall not exceed
him in curtesy and ciuility. This compaigny is to be understood to be
offered the knight when he rydeth in to the city of pleasure, and not wha^ he
goth alone, and shows by his forehead an unpleasant countenance trobled in
his mind. Yet the courtyer nevertheless must offer him self to accompaigne
him, which if he do accept, he may not then importune or withstand him to
do yt: For wheare he should think to be accounted courteous, they would
repute him a troblesom man. When the courtier shall accompaigny any noble man
of the court, let him not then seem to contend with other courtiers for place,
and honor in his presence, who should be before, or behynd an other. For this
strife coming to the noble man's ears whom they accompaginy, it might easily
happen, that that compaigne, that came to wait upon him, and to do him honor
and service, should then seem to dishonor and offend him. Little knows he
what honor means, when in these trifles he seeks it. For the wise and
courteous courtier, has not only to seek honor with them, with whom he
rydeth cheek by cheek: but also with those that are beeloued of the prince.
Now when the noble man is accompaignyed and that he is come hard by the court,
you courtyers, be ready to light of your horse quickly before him, and when
he shall likewise take his horse again, be as ready to take your horse back
before him. For doing thus, you shall be nere about him when he lights of on
his horse, and afterward help him when he mounteth on his horse again. If
perhapps at the coming in of a chamber, the lords servants want consideration,
or that they remember not to hold open the cloth over the door, the good and
dilygent courtyer should suddenly put him self before him, to lift and hold
yt up. For many times yt is as great an honor for a courtier to be accounted
one of good manner and bringing up in the court, as out of the court it is to
be reputed a great and famous captain in wars. And seence the courtier is
determined to accompaigne some noble man to the court, he is also bound by
the laws of the court to wait upon him home again, which if he do, the
noble man shall be more beeholding to him for the attendance he has geeuen
upon him, then for his compaigne to ride with him. If any came to speak with
the courtier that were equal with him in degree or meaner of calling or
condition then him self, yt is one of the first and cheifest points of
ciuility and good manner, not to suffer him to open his lips to speak to him,
before he have his cappe on his head, for one to talk commonly with the other
with his cappe in his hand, is of great authority and reverence, as from the
duty of the subject to the prince, or that of the servant to the master. The
good courtier must ever speak again to him that speaks to him, do him
reverence that does him reuerens, put of his cappe to him that puts of his,
and this he must do without any respect that he is his friend or foe. For in
the effects of good manner, no man ought to be so much an enemy, that the
enmity should break the bounds of curtesy and humanity. It is rather fyt for
common persons, then for courtlike gentlemen, in so mean things to show their
e^mitt. For to say truly, the good courtier should not show the enmity of his
heart, by putting on or pulling of his cappe, but by taking sword in hand to
revenge his quarrel. And if the courtier were in the church, court, or in the
chapel of the prince, and set, and an other gentilman happily comes in the
same place wheare he is, he must do him the curtesy to geeue him his place
and seat and to pray him to sit down, yea and if there were no other place
fyt for ye gentilma^ to sit in, and that of courtesy also he would not offer
him that injury to accept yt: yet at the least let the courtier do what he
may to make him take a piece of his stool, that parting with him his seat,
the other may also come to part with him his heart. If those that were set hard
by the courtier beegonne to talk in secret togethers, he should rise from
thence, or go a litell aside from them. For in the court they will say he is
ill taught and brought up, and wants ciuility and good manners that will seem
to harken to any bodies tale or secrets. The courtiers must have frendshipp
also with the porters to open him the court gates that are kept fast cheyned
in, that they be contented to suffer their moyle or foot cloth nagge to enter
into the utter court. And the like must be practiced with the gentlemen
ushers of the chamber, and captain of the guard, to whom he must do a
thousand pleasures that they may respect his person, and let him come in when
he will. And the next way to win this frendshipp, and to contynew them
friends and to be welcome of them, is to feast them otherwhile, sometime with
a dinner, some time with a bancket, but especially not to sail them of a new
years gift on neweyears day, what trifle or present so ever it be. That
courtier that is not acquainted with the ushers, and does them no pleasures,
may be well assured that those above in the hall, will make him tarry in the
utter court: and those that stand at the gate of the cheyne, they will make him
light in the myer. With the ushers of the privy chamber, he must needs deal
honorably withal as to come and see them somtymes, and to do them much honor,
in giuyng them some fair jewel or presentyng them with a gown or coat
cloth of silk or velvet. And thus he shallbee assured they will not only let
him into the privy chamber, but they will also procure him to speak with the
prince even at his best leisure. To make the yemen of the guard also that
makes gentlemen geeue place, and stand alofe of from the prince, yet can not
be but very profitable for the courtier to have them his friends. For many
times they may help us to a fit place to talk with the King. yt is such a
troble and charge to get to speak with the prince, that if we have not great
frendshipp with these we have spoken of, and that we do them some pleasures
before we come to the court, they will shut the doors against us, and we
shall come home ashamed of our selves. For a courtier to be acquainted with
the ladies and gentlemen of the court, it is rather of pleasure then of
necessity, albeeit it be true, that the young courtier that serves not some
lady or dame in court shall be rather blamed of his shamefastnes and cowardly
heart, then approved for his modesty and gravity. In deed for a young gentilman
that is rich, noble, and free hearted, it is an honest and comely enterteinment
to be come some ladies servant of the court: But for him that is poor, living
in disgrace, and out of favor, let him utterly fly the love of courtly dames,
and slick to the poor frendshippe of devout nonnes. For the property of
courtly mystresses is to empty their servants purses, and ye manner of religious
nonnes to beg always of him that visites her. The courtier that offerith him
self to serve any lady a or gentilwoma^ in court does bynd him self to a
straight religion: For some times he must kneel by her of one knee, sometimes
he must stand upon his feet before her, and always he must have his cappe
in his hand, and he may not speak to her unless she command him first, and
if she ask any thing of him, he is bound to geeue yt her straight if he
can, and though she frown upon him, yet he may not be angry with her, so
that the courtier must needs employ his hole person, and goods, in serving of
her that he loves. For the courtier that is married, sure it is not fyt for him
to love any other woman then his wife, nether is it honest for the woman to be
seruid with any married courtier. For these manner of loves are to no other end,
but for him to be merry with her, and for her to get somewhat of him. Let the
courtier be very wise that he do not love and serve such a gentil woman,
whom he can not obtain to his wife, for otherwise it should be a great
grief to him, and a more shame, to see an other before his eyes enjoy her and
eat of that fruit, which he had to his great cost and charges made now a
fruitful orchard. And if it happen that his mistress whom he sarueth be
nobly borne, very fair of complexion, pleasant of condition, of good grace and
beehauiour in her conversation, very wise and fine in her doings: he may be
well assured he shall never forget this grief and sorrow, and so much more if
he did love her withal his heart and unfeignedly. There is great difference
beetwene that we lose, and that we have: For if the heart lament for the loss
of that we have: yt beewayleth bitterly to lose that we love. Also the
courtier must be advised that he tell not to any that his wife has told him,
or any thing that has passed secretly beetweene them: For women are of such a
quality, that for any thing they do, they would never hear of yt again
willingly, and those secrets that an other comits to them of trust, they can
never keep them secret. There is a law common beetwen women and their lovers:
For if they go abroad, their lovers must attend upon their persons: and if they
buy any thing in the streate as they go, they are bound to pay for yt: And if
they be to late abroad, they must provide the^ of torches to bring them home
with, and when the court remoueth from place to place, theyrs is the chardge to
defraud their expenses by the way: and if any do them injury, they are bound
to revenge their quarrel: if they fall syck, they must do them a thousand
pleasures and saruices: if any challenge be made in court of tilt, torney, or
barriers, they must be the first and best mounted and armed above others (if
they may possible) withal not forgetting their Ladies colors and devise,
offering them selves nobly to perform the challenge, geeuing them to
understand, that for their sakes, they nether fear to adventure their lives,
nor spare for any chardge to do them all honor and service. With out dout we
may speak yt truly, that he puts him self to great peril and danger
(what so ever he be) that serves women. But when the wise courtier is now
become a servant to any lady in court, he must beware in any case he
enterteigne or serve any other then his mistress: For if he did otherwise,
he should raise a mortal hate and discord between those women: by reason
whereof many sclaunders and broils might ensue. It is a natural thing to all
women, that to hate any man, a hundred will come to agree in one opinyon: but
to love him you shall not find two of one mind. The good courtier must covet
the best he can to be always at the making ready of the King, and at his
meat, and for two causes: The one for that he may be ready to do him
saruice, and the other, for that at such a time they shall have an apt time to
treat with the prince in any thing he will, if he have any occasion of
business with him. And when the king is either at his meat, or that he be
putting on his apparel, let the good courtier be circumspect he come not to
near the table where he sits, nor that he touch the kings apparel he
wears on. For no man ought once presume to be so hardy to meddle with his
meat, or his apparel, unless he be shewer, or chamberlayne.

And if in this time of repast, or making him ready, there were present any
iesters or fools, that said or did any thing to make them laugh: The good
courtier must take heed that he laugh not to loud, as in such cases many are
wont to do. For in such a case the prince would be better plesed at the
modesty of the courtier, then at the knavery or folly of the fool.

The honest courtier must not have a fool his friend nor his enemy: for to make
him his friend, he is to dishonest, and too be his enemy, he is to vile and
cowardly. I wish the courtier not to be angry with him, what so ever he
does: for many times yt happens, that the frendshipp of a wise man does not
so much benefit or pleasure: as the enmity and displeasure of one of these
fools does hurt. And if he will geeue them any thing (as he must needs)
let him beeware he geeue him not occasyon to condemn his conscience, and that
he stop their mouths: For the courtier that is a christyan, should geeue
as much more to the poor to pray to god for him, as he should geeue to others
to speak well of him to the King.

When the King sneyses, and that the courtyer be present, he must straight
put of his capp, and bow him self in manner to the ground, but for all that
he must take heed he say not christ help you, or god bless you, or such
other like. For to do do any manner of curtesy or honor, is only pertynent to
courtiers: But to say christ help, or god bless you, is the country manner.
And if the King by chance should have any hear, or feather, or flee upon his
clothes, or any other filthy thing about him: none but the chamberlein only
should take it away, and none other courtier should once presume to take any
thing from his back, or to touch his garment, nether any other person, unless it
were in case to defend him. When the King is set at the table, the courtier may
not come into the kitchen, nor much less lean upon the surueying boorde. For
though he did yt perhaps but to see the order of the survey and service of the
prince: yet yt may be suspected of some, he meant some worser matter, and
thereby they should judge ill of him. If the prince have a felicity in hawking,
the courtier must endeavor him self to keep a cast or two of good fawlcons:
and if in hu^ting, then he must have good greyhounds. And when he is eather a
hawking or hu^ting with ye king, he must seek to serve him so diligently that
day, that he may both find him game to sport with, and procure for him self
also favor at the princes hand. Many times princes are so earnest of their
game, and so desirous to kill that they hunt, that they are wont boldly to
chase the beasts they hunt, and pursue them so, that oftymes they lose the
sight of all the rest. In such a case the good courtier must ever have his eyes
upon him, and rather seek to follow the king, then to take pleasure in hunting
of other beasts. For in that case yt shallbee a better hunting for him, to
find out the king, and to be with him: then he should take pleasure in being
alone with the heart. Yt may happen lightly, that the King gallopping his horse
upon the rockye stones, he might stumble at such a stone, as both the king and
his horse should come to the ground: and at that time it could not be but very
profitable for the courtier to be present. For yt might so happen, that by
means of the princes fall, (he being ready to help him) he might thenceforth
beeginne to grow in favor and credit with the prince. The most part of those
that delyght to go a hunting, are wont commonly to eat their meat greedely,
and drink out of measure, and beesids to shoute and make a wonderful noise as
they were out of their wits: which things the grave and wise courtier should
not do: for they are rather fit for vacabonds, and Idle persons, that sets
not by their honesty: then they are for the honest courtier, that only desires
and indeuoureth by modest and wise be hauiour to beecome great, and in favor.

Of the great pains and trobles the courtier has that is toild in suits of
law, and how he must suffer, and beehaue him self with the judges. Cap. x.
THere are in the court also diverse kynds of men, that be not courtiers, and
princes servants, but only are courtiers of necessity, by reason of suits they
have with the council. And these manner of courtyers have as much need of
council, as of help: for he that has his goods in hasard, has also his
life in ieopardy.

To speak of the diverse and subtle ways of suffering, it is no matter worthy to
be written with black ynk, but only with lively blood. For in deed if every
one of these suitors, were forced to abide for his faith and believe those
pains, troubles, and sorows, that he does to recover his goods: as much
cruelty as tortures shoold Vagliadoti, and Grauata have, as ever had Rome in
times past. In my oppinion, I think it a hell to continue a long suter. And
surely we may believe, yea and swear to, that the martirs executed in old time
in the primitive church (which were many in number) did not suffer so much,
neither felt such grief to lose their life, as does now a days an honest man
to see him self deprived of all his faculties. It is a great trouble and charge
to recover any thing, but in the end of these two effects, a wise man suffers
and feels more the displeasures he receives, then he does the goods he
spends. And in my judgment to strive and contend is nothing else, but to
bring matter to the heart to sigh and lament, to the eyes to weep, to the feet
to go, to the tongue to complain, to the hands to spend, to entreat his friends
to favor his cause, and to command his servant to be careful and diligent,
and his body to labor continually. He that understands not the conditions of
contention I will let him know they are these. Of a rych man, beecome poor: of
a merry man, to be made melancholy: of a free man, a bond man: of a liberal
man, a covetous man: of a quiet man, an unquiet person: and of a hateful, a
desperate person. How is it otherwise possible, but the haples suter must
beecome desperate? seeing the judge look upon him with frowning cheer, his
goods to be demanded of him wrongfully, and that now it is so long a time he
has not been at home, and knows not yet whether sentence shall be geeuen
with him or against him, and besides all this, that the poor man in his
lingering suite has spent so much, that he has not left him six pence in his
purse. If any of these troubles be enough to bring a man to his end, much more
shall they be to make the poor man desperate, and weary of his life. So diverse
are theffects, and success seen in matters of suite, that many times there is
no wit able to direct them, nor goods to bring them to end. Nay we may boldly
and truly say, that the laws are so many, and diffuse of them selves, and men's
judgments so simple to understand them, that at this day there is no suite in
the world so clear, but there is found an other law to put that in doubt, and
make it void. And therefore the good and ill of the suter, consists not so
much in the reason he has, as in the law which the Judge chooses to geeue
judgment of. It is well that the suter believe and think that he has right,
but the cheifest thing of importance is, that the judge also desire yt he have
his right. For that Judge that favors my cause, and desires to do me
justice, he will labor and study to seek out some law, that shall serve my
turn to restore me again to my right. To contend, is so profound a science,
that neither Socrates to the Athenians, nor Solon to the Greeks, nor Numa
Pompilius to the Romans, nor Prometheus to ye Egiptians, nor Licurgus to the
Lacedaemonians, nor Plato to his disciples, nor Apolonius to the poets of
Nemsis, nor Hiarcus to the Indians, coold ever tech it them, and much less
coold they tell how to find any way to write it in their books of common
wealth. The cause why these famous men did not find it, was because this
science coold not be learned by studying of diverse books, nor by traueling
through diverse countries, but only by framing great suites and processes, and
by infinite charge and expense of money. Happy, yea truly most happy were
those ages, in which they neither knew, nor coold tell, what strife or
contentionment. For in deed from that time hitherto, the world has fallen to
decay, and cheefely since men have grown to quarrel and contend each other with
his neighbor.

Plato was wont to say, that in that common weal where there were found many
Physicians, it was also an euydent token that there were many vicyous people:
and likewise we may say that in the city where there are many suitors, it is to
be thought it folowes also, that there are many ill disposed people. That only
may be called a blessed and fortunat common weal, where men live quietly, and
have not to do with Justices nor judges. For it is a true rule, when
physicians are much freque^ted, and judges much occupied, that amongst that
people there is little health, and less quiet. But to return to the troubles
of our suitors, I say that the disciples of the famous Philosopher Socrates were
not bound to be sylent in Athens above two years, but the unfortunate suitors
were bound to hold their peace ten years if their suits did continue so long.
For albeeit the Judge do them open injury, yet they may not seem to complayn,
but rather say he thinks he has done him the best justice in the world.
And if for his mishapp, or plague of his offenses, he woold not so approve and
speak them, let him be assured the Judge will perceive it by his countenance,
and afterward let him know it by his judgment. Some suitors say they are
great sinners, and I say they are saints. For of the seven dedly sins that
are committed, only of three they are but to be accused. For in the other
iiii. (although they woold) they do not geeue him time nor leave to offend.
How can the suter ever offend in Pride, since he must poor man go from house
to house with his capp in his hand, and all humility to solicit his cause? How
can he ever offend in Avarice, sith he has not many times a penny in his
purse to by him his dyuer, nor to pay for the infinite draughts and coppyes
proceeding out of the Chauncery? How can he offend in Sloth and ydlenes, since
he consumes the long nights only in sighs and complaynts, and the whole day
in trotting and trudging up and down? How can he offend in Gluttony since he
woold be content to have only to suffyse nature, and not to desire pyes, nor
breakfastes, nor to lay the table every day? That sin they most easily and
commonly offend in, is Ire, and in deed I never saw suter pacie^t: and
although he be angry, we may not marvel at yt a whit. For if ever once in
the end of half a year he happen to have any thing that pleases him, I dare
be bound every week after he shall not want infinite troubles to torment and
vex him. These men also offend much in envy, for in deed there is no man that
pleades but is envious, and this proceeds many times to see an other man, by
favor dispatched of his suit, that has not continued only two months in court
a suter: and of his that has continued above two years since yt began, not a
word spoken. They offend also in the sin of backbyting, and murmuryng
against their neyghbors. For they never cease complaining of the partiality of
the Judges, of the slouthfulnes and tymorousnes of his Counselor, that pleades
his cause at the bar: of the little consideration of ye attorney, of the
payments of the notary, and of the small courtesies (or rather rudenes) of the
officers of the Judge.

So that it may well be said, that to strive in law, and to murmr, are nere
kinsfolks togeethers. The Egiptians were in time past plaged only with ten
plagues, but these miserable and woeful suitors are daily plaged with a thousand
torments. And the difference beetwixt their plague and these, is that the
Egiptians came from the divine prouydence, and these (of our poor suitors) from
the invention of man's malice. And it is not without cause we say that it is
man's invention, and not divine. For to frame inditements, to geene delays to
the party, to allege accions, to deny the demand, to accept ye proof, to
examine witnesses, to take out process, to note the declaration, to prolong the
cause, alleging well, or proving ill, to refuse the judge for suspect, to make
intercession to take out the copy of the plea, and to call upon it again with
a 1500. dudles: Surely all these are things that neither god commands in the
old testament, neither Ihesus Christ our savior does allow in his holy
Gospel. The writings of Egypt, although they were to the great loss and
detriment of ye seignory of the Egiptians, yet were they nevertheless very
profitable for the liberty of the Egiptians. But the miserable playntifes are
yet in an other greater extremity. for notwithstanding the plagues and miseries
the poor wretches suffer daily, yet do they leave their souls buried in the
courts of Chauncery, and cannot notwithstanding have their goods at liberty.
And if the plague of the Egiptians was by ryuers of blood, froggs, horse flies,
death of cattle, tempests, leprosy, locusts, mists, flies, and by the death of
the first borne children: The plague of the plaintifes is to serve the
presidents to bear with the auditors, to entreat the notaries, to make much of
their clarks, to please the counselors, to follow their heels that must open
their cause, to pray the ushers, to borow money, to go from house to house to
solicit their attorneys, all these things are easy to tell, but very hard to
suffer: For after they are once proved and tried by experience, they are
enough to make a wise man contented, rather to lose a piece of his right, then
to seek to recover it by any such extremity. For he may be well assured,
that he shall never want fair countenance, sugared words, and large
promyses: but for good doings it is a marvelous wonder if ever they meet
togeethers. And therefore before all other things it is necessary he pray to
God for his own health and preservation, and next to him, for the preseruacion
and long continuance of the Judge, if he will obteyn his suite. Therefore I
advise him that has not the Judge for his friend, to beeware (as from the
devil) he do not commence any suite before him. For to dispatch him the
better, either he will find the means to make his case very dark, or at least
he will prolong his suite as long as it please. It skilleth not much whether
the judges be old, or young men, for both with the one and the other the poor
playntife has enough to do. If they be old men a man shall travel long ere
he will hear his cause. If they be young men, he shall wayt long also ere
he can inform them of the very points of his case. An other great
discommodity yet follows these old Judges, that being ever sickly and of weak
nature, they never have strength nor time in manner to examyn their cases. And
as those that have lost now a great piece of their memory, only trusting in
forepassed expenses, they presume to dispatch their suits as lightly (without
further looking into them, or thoroughly examining them) as if they had already
advisedly studied them. And peradventure their case is of such importance,
that if they had looked upon it very well, they coold scantly have told what
to have said in it. And I woold not that when my case shoold be determined,
and judgment geeuen upon my matter, that the Judge shoold benefit him self
only, with that he had seen or read before. For although experience be a
great help for the Judge, to geeue the better Judgment upon the matter, yet
notwithstanding he is to study a new to understand the merits of the cause.

It is also a great trouble, and dangerous, for a man to practice with new
Judges, and to putt their matters into their hands, who only were called to the
place of a Judge, being thought learned and fit for yt, and so brought to
rule as a magistrate. For many times these young Judges, and new physicians
although they want not possibly knowledge, yet they may lack a great deal of
practyse and experience: which is cause that the one sort makes many lose
their lives before they come to rise infame: and the other undo many a man,
in making him spend all that ever he has.

There is yet besides an other apparaunt danger, to have to do with these new
and young experienced judges, for when they come to sit newly in judgment, with
their other brethren the Judges, having the law in their mouth to serve all
turns, they do but only desire and study to win fame and reputation amongst
men, and thereby to be the better reputed of his brethren. And for this cause
only when they are assembled together in place of justice to geeue judgment of
the plees laid before them, they do then only enlarge them selves, in
alleging many and diverse oppinions of great learned men, and book cases: So
that the heerers of them may rather think they have studied to show their
eloquence and learning, then to open the decision and judgment of the cases
they have before them.

And for fynall resolution I say, that touching plees and suits. I am of
oppinion, they shoold neither trust the experience of the old Judge, nor the
learning and knowledge of the young. But rather I reckon that man wise, that
seeks by little and little to grow to an honest end and agreement with his
adversary, and that taryeth not many years to have a long, yea (and possible)
an uncertain end. Also I woold exhort the poor pleyntyfe, not to be over
curious to understand the qualityes of the Judge, as a man woold say. If he
be old, or young, if he be learned or priuileged, if he be well studied or
but little, if he be a man of few or many words, if he be affected or
passioned, tractable or self willed, for possibly being to inquisitiue to
demand of any of these things, it might happen though he did it vnwarrs, yet
he shoold find them afterward all heaped togeethers in ye parson of ye Judge,
to his hynderance and damage in decydyng his cause. The wise suter shoold not
only not seek to be inquisitiue of ye Judge or his conditions, but also if
any man woold seem to tell him of him, he shoold geeue no ear to him at all.
For if it come to the judges ears he inquireth after his manner of living, and
condition, he will not only be angry with him in his mind, but wilbee also
unwilling to geeue judgment in his favor. The poor suter shall also meet with
terrible judges, severe, intractable, collerick, incommunicable, and
inexorable, and yet for all this he may not look upon his nature, nor
condition, but only regard his good conscience. For what need he care if the
Judge be of severe and sharp condition, as long as he may be assertained he
is of good conscience. It is as needful for the upright, and good Judge, to
have a good and pure conscience: as it is to have a skylfull head, and
judgment in the laws. For if he have this without the other, he may offend
in mallyce: and if he have that without the other, he may offend also in
ygnoraunce. And if the suter come to speak with the Judge, and he by chance
find him a sleep, he must tarry till he awake, and if then he will not, or
he cannot geeue ear unto him, he must be contented. And if he caused his
man to say he were not within (notwythstanding the suter saw him) he must
dissemble yt, yea if the servant geeue him an ill answer, he must take it
in good woorthe: For the ware and politic suter must not be offended at any
thing that is done or said to him, till he see the diffinitiue sentence geeuen
with him or against him.

It is a marvelous trouble also to the suter to choose his Counselor. For many
times he shall choose one that shall want both law and conscience. And some
others shall choose one that though on the one side he lack not law, yet on
the other he shall be without both soul and conscience. And this is apparently
seen, that sometime for the gayn of twenty nobles he shall as willingly deny
the troth, and go against his own conscience, as at an other time he will
seek to mayntain Justice. It is true there are many other counselors also
that are both wise and learned, and yet notwithstanding they know the law, they
can by no means frame it to his clyents case, wanting deuyse and conueyaunce to
ioyn them togeether. And so yt happens many times, that to compare it to his
clyants case, he conueyth him so unfitly, as of a plain case it was before,
it is now made altogeether a fold of infinite doubts. I grant it is a great
furtheraunce to the clyants, to have a good and wise counselor, but it is a
great deal more for their profit, if they can geeue a sound and profound
judgment of his case. For yt is not enough for the counselor to be able to
expound the law, but it is beehouefull for him to apply yt to his purpose and
to apt it to time and place, according to the necessity of his cause. I have
known counselors my self, that in their chayers and readyngs in their halles,
have seemed Egles, they have flowen so high in their doctrine and
interpretations: but afterward at ye bar where they plead, and in the face
of the court, where they shoold best show them selves, there they have proved
them selves very capons. And the only cause of this is, because they have
gotten by force of long travel and continual study, a knowledge to know to
moote, and read ordinaryly their book cases in their chayers, by common
practyse, and putting of them each to other.

But when they are taken out of that common trade and high beaten way, and
brought to a little path way strayghted to a counselors room at the bar, to
plead his clyants strange and unknown case (much contrary to their book
cases before recyted) then stripped of their common knowledge, and easy seat in
chayer, they stand now naked on their feet before the judgment seat, like
senceles creatures void of reason and experyence. But now to supply these
imperfeccions of our raw counselors, and to further also our Clyents cause the
better: we will that the Clyent be liberal, and bountiful to his
counselor, (thereby the better to whet his wytt and to make him also take
payns to study his case thoroughly) being true, that the counselor geeueth
law, as he has reward. And that the counselor also be careful of his
Clyants cause, and to go through with that he takes upon him, and truly to
deserve that he takes of every man. For else they will say (and who can blame
the poor souls) they are better takers, then good dispatchers: A foul blott
to so great a virtue. But well, we will compare them to their brothers the
physicians, who deal with their sick pacients, as the lawiers with their poor
clyants. For if you geeue him not a piece of gold or two in his hand, at each
time of his visitation, to restore the languishing body: he cares as little
for the preservation of his health, whether he live or dye: as the lawier
does for his claynts case, whether it go with him or against him. More over
my pen cease not to write of the great troubles, displeasures, journeys,
expenses, and travels, that the poor suitors have with their counselors daily
(as with their atturneys, Soliciters, clarks, officers, registers, and sealers)
for want of matters to write on: but only for that they are so odious matters,
and so foul examples, that they deserve rather to be remedied then written.
Therefore leaving this law discurse, and returning again to the pryuate
affaiers of the courtier, abiding still in court, I say: That the courtier must
learn to know the noble men and cheef officers of the Prince. As the lord
chaunceller, The lord Treasorer, The lord marshall, The lord Steward, The lord
Chamberlain, The lord Privy seal, The Treasorer, The Controller, The master of
the horse, The vice Chamberlayn, the Secretary, the captayn of the guard, and
the Coferer. And he need not force to wey their stock and family, whether they
were rich or poor, humble or proud, stout or fearful, nor regard their
qualities and complexions, much less their persons, save only their aucthority
and office they have. And to say truly it cannot be chosen, but we must come
before these Judges and officers sometimes to beseech and pray them, now for
our own private causes, then for the mysrule and offense of our servant, and
also for the importunancy of our friends in their matters, to labor them for
justice and favor. And for this cause me thinks it is a wise part of the
courtier to get into favor with the counsel, and other officers of Justice,
and to obtain their good wills with continual attendaunce of them, in doing
them service at a need, and also to entertayn them wythsome small presents to
continue their favor.

First before we beeginne to trouble them, we must be acquainted with them,
vysit them, and present them with somewhat: For indeed it is a cold and unfit
thing to crave favor at a Judges hands, whom we never knew, nor did any
service to.

The wise courtyer must beeware also not to importune the noble men and his
friends so much, yt for every tryflyng thing he woould have them go to the
judges, to solicit and entreat for him, which I speak, because I know there
