are some such indiscreat persons, that daily do importune the judges so much,
and for such trifles, that afterward with shame they are repulsed, and denied,
in matters of great weight and importance. And there are some also that
solicit their matter with gravity, and others with importunyty, to whom I
wyllbee so bold to say, and tell them of it also, that importunacy shows the
simplicity of the suter, and gravity, the honesty of the worthy knyghts and
gentleman courtier. It is but well done and meet for the courtier that is a
suter, to be diligent to solicit his cause, and to follow yt thoroughly, but
yet without troubling or importuning too often the judges. For if once the judges
know him for an importunate and cumbersome suter, they will not only not speak
with him when he comes, but also they will not let him come in at the gate
when they see him coming to them. And if he happen to go home to the judges
house, and that he tell his tale to him standing, let him not in no wise care
to sit down, and that his words he speak to him be few, and his memorial
he geeues him brief. For obseruyng this order he shall at that time be
easily, yea willingly and courteously hard of him, and shall make him think
that hereafter also he will use the like order with him. When he sees that
the judge is troubled, and that his head is occupied, let him in no case at
that present offer to trouble him, or to speak to him in his matter. For admit
he were contented to hear you quyetly (though half unwilling) and to suffer
you to tell your tale, yet is it impossyble he should wholly understand your
case, his head being otherwise occupied. And it is needful also to show you,
that though the judge seem to be a little melancony, or collerick, yet the
suyter need not let for that to speak to him, to open his case, yea and to
seek to hold in with him still: For many times we see the melancony and ill
disposed natures, appeased and overcome with the courteous and gentle
conversation. I remember touching this matter, I went once to the court, to
solicit the judge, to pray him to dispatch my friends matter, and that he
might have justice. And took my friend with me. And the judge answered us
both, that withal his heart he would dispatch him, and swear and swear again
to him that he should have justice, and that with right good will he woould
keep his right all he could. Nay sir said my friend to him whom the case
touched, I thank you sir very much that you will dispatch me quickly, but
wheare you say that you have a great desire to keep my right and justice, I
utterly appeal from that sentence. For I come not sir, and if it please you,
to follow your heels and to wait upon you to solicit my cause, to the end you
should keep my right, and deteigne if from me: but that you shoold geeue yt
to me. For I promis you this sir, if you once geeue it me, I mean never to
trouble your woorship hereafter with the keeping of it again, but will discharge
you quite. And now after al these things we have spoken, I conclude yt who so
ever curses his enemy, and seeks revenge of an injury done him, let him not
desire to see him poor and miserable, neither hated nor ill willed of any
other, dead nor banished, but let him only beeseech god to plague him with
some ill suit. For a man cannot devise to take a greater revenge of his enemy,
the^ to see him entangled in a vile suit to follow the court, or to attend in
chauncery.

The auctor changes his matter, and speaks to the beeloued of the court,
admonishyng them to be pacient in their troubles, and that they be not
partial in thaffaires of the common weal. Cap. xi.
THe courtier shall do well and wisely, (and cheefely if he be noble, and
beeloued to pass over the injuries done him, and to bear them pacyently, and
never to geeue any words to any that shall offend him. For the officers of
princes can by no other means so well assuer their offices and authority they
have, as by dooyng good continually to some, and to suffer others, no way
making any countenance of displeasure for the injuries done him by others.
And if yt happen (as many times yt does) that a follower and hanger on of the
court, (having spent all that he has, and driven now to seek a new banck)
chance to speak dyshonest words, and frame great quarells against the kings
officers: in this case the courtier, and wise offycer, should never answer him
with anger and displeasure, and much less speak to him in choler. For a man
of honor, and respect, wyllbee more grieved with a dishonest word that is
spoken against him, then he wilbee for the denial of that he asks. Those
that are beeloued, and beelyked of princes above all other things ought to be
very pacient, courteous and gentle in all things. For all that the followers of
the court, and suitors, can not obteyn in the court, let them not lay the fault
to the prince that denied yt them, but only to the favored of the prince, and
those about him, for that they never moved yt to the kings majesty: nor once
thought of the matter, as the poor suitors supposed they had. The payns and
troubles of court are infynyt and insupportable. For how quiet so ever the
courtier be, they will trouble and molest him, if he be pacyent, they
willbee impacyent and in storms, saying that such a man spoke ill of him, and
seeks contynually to defame him. Which things we will the courtyer hear with
paciens, and dissemble with wisdom. For the wise courtyer should not be
angry for the ill words they speak of him, but only for the vile and wicked
acts they do to him. Let not the courtyer and beelyked of the prince be
deceived, in thynkyng that dooyng for this man, and for that man, and in
showing them favor: that for all he can bynd or stay their tongues that they
speak not ill of him, and their hearts that they hate them not extremely. For
the enemy receives not so much pleasure of that the courtyer geeueth him, as
he does greef and dyspleasure, for that that is beehynd yet in the courtiers
hands to geeue him. Now in the palace of princes it is a natural thing, for
each man to desire to aspire, and to creep into the princes favor, to be able
to do much, and to be more worth then others, and to command also: and as
there are many that desire it, so are they very few in number that by their
virtues and demeryts obteyn that favor. It is a thing most suer and undoubted,
that one alone enjoying his princes grace and favor, shall be hated in manner of
the most part of the people. The more they be rych, noble, and of great power,
that are beeloued and accepted of princes, so much the more ought they to be
circumspect, and to live in fear and doubt of such disgraces and mysfortunes
that may happen to them, sith every man's eye is upon them, and that they are
enuyed for that they can do much, and desire also to take from them that
authority and credit they have, and to spoil them of such treasure as they
possess, or have gotten by the princes favor. And in this case the beelyked of
the court must not trust in the pleasures he has done them, neither in the
favor he has showed them, much less in the feigned frendshyp they seem to
bear him, and that he thinks he has gotten of them, neither must he must
to much his friends, neighbors, and kynsfolks, no nor his own brethren: But let
him be assured, that all those that are not in like favor and estimation that
he is, (be he of what degree or parentage he willbee, yea and as near a
kynne as may be) they will all be in that his very mortal foes. Authoryty to
command, being the cheef and highest point of honor, and whereto every man
seeks to aspire, and which was cause that Pompey beecame the deadly enemy of
Julius Caesar his father in law, Absalon of David his natural father, Romulus
of his brother Remus, Allexander of Darius, who showed him self to fore a
father in love in bryngyng on him up, and Mark Antony of Augustus Caesar his
great friend. So that I say, yt may well be said, that after dysdaigne and
cankered Ire have once possessed the delycat breast of man, only concerning honor
and commandment, it is never thencefoorth recured of that infested sore,
neither by gyfts and promises, and much less by prayers and requests. It is
true the accepted of the prince may well be free from all thirst and hunger,
cold and heet, wars, plague, and poverty, and from all other calamytyes and
troubles of this our wretched life, but he shall never be free from
detractions of venomous and wicked tongues, and from spyghtfull and enuyous
persons. For no less is envy joined to favor, then is thirst to a burning
ague. In this case yt is impossible but that the courtier should receive many
times displeasure and disgraces in the court, but not to geeue ear to these
detracters, and ill speakers of men. To remedy these things, the courtier must
needs seem to let them know by his looks and aunswers, that he is more
offended with them, that come and tell him these lewd tales: then with those that
indeed did truly report the^ of him. This counsel would I geeue ye courtier,
yt what ill so ever he hears spoken of him, I woold wish him not seem to
know it, and much less to be a^gry with al, nor once to give a dishonest word
to ye reporters thereof. For his choler over past, the euel words he has
spoken to them in his anger may tourn him to more displeasure, then he has
done him hurt that caused him speak these words. And therefore surely to
bridel the tongue, is rather a divine then humayn virtue: and cheefely in that
instant, when the heart, is mastered and subdued with cholorick passions. For
afterward yt happens many times, that being quiet again in our mynds, we
are sorry for that we have spoken in our anger, yea against them that have
angered us. If the courtier should way every word that is spoken against him,
and esteem every thing that is done to him, he should purchase him self a
continual and sorrowful life, yea and out of measure a troblesome and
unpleasant, sith princes courts are ever full of serpent tongues, and venomous
hearts, and that it lies not in man's power to let, that the hearts of men hate
us not, and that their tongues speak not ill of us, I would advise the courtier
to take all the ill that is spoken of him, in sport and mirth, and not in
anger. Seneca said (and that wisely spoken) that there is no greater revenge to
punish an injurious word, then to seem to laugh at yt. For it is a thing more
natural and proper to weomen, then men to desire to take revenge of words,
with the like words again: sith the noble heart that esteem his honor, must
not have his hands in his tongue, but his tongue in his hands. O how many have
we seen, both out of court and in court, the wc for no other respect but to
revenge one only seely word, yt touched them not much, would put the^ selves,
their goods, and fame in peril: and yet in the end had not that revenge
neither they desired, but rather redoubled it gaynst them selves, in losyng
their fond and vayn attempt. Therefore to conclude those that wylbee great in
favor and estimacion in the princes court, and those also that are now in favor
and credit with the prince, and that desire to continue and persevere in his
favor still, must not make account of any words spoken to him, or offenses
done him: for all that are in favor have need to suffer, and no occasion to
revenge. Till this present day I never saw any that received any hurt or
detriment by being pacient: but being impacient I have seen numbers cast
them selves away, you must also know, that in all places, wheare troop and
company of people be, there is always ever discord and diversities in
oppynions and judgments of men. So that it happens many times in a common
weal, yea and yt meets sometimes in one house, that all shallbee of one
blood and kynred, yet in pryuat wills and affections mortal enemies. And
therefore, suer yt is a thing worthy to be noted, and no less to be wondered
at, to see the father with the sons, the uncles with the neuews, the
graundfathers with the children, the son in laws with their father in laws,
and brothers with their brothers, and systers, the one to be as far
different from the other as white and black, and as much friends as the dog
and the catte. And all this is caused only, for that they are rather wedded to
a self will and oppinion they have, then they are addicted to love and affect
that that nature byndeth them to. We see also many young courtiers, that though
they be virtuous and noble (having inherited and succeeded in nobility of
blood their ancestors) by means whereof they are honored and reverenced: and
possessyng also the greatness, and abundance of their goods, and riches (which
makes them wealthy, and mayntayns them honorably) enjoying the noble parentage
for which they are regarded, having many friends and servant that do them
great service and pleasure. And all in respect of their noble auncetors: and
yet notwithstanding all these great things we have spoken, they follow their
own inventions and imaginations, which their auncetors knowing would have fled:
and hate and myslyke that, that they doubtless being alive woold have followed.
And therefore it is rather a token of lightness then of good will, for one to
leave to help and relieve his own friends and kynsfolks, to succor and do good
to strangers, or others, whom he never knew, nor can tell what they are. For
I assure you, that one of the greatst losses and myshaps that can come to a
noble house, is to have new frendshyp, and partialyty, with strangers and men
unknown. That gentelman that geeueth him self to follow such one as pleases
his fantasy best, and that leaves to lean to those whom his ancestors
heretofore both loved and lyked: shall see those old friends not only leave and
forsake him, but clean geeue him over to his will, and shortly after shall find
his substance and faculty consume and wast away, beesydes, the honor of his
house to be brought to utter decay and oblyuion. And this we have spoken,
only to advise the princes officers, and such as have credyt and aucthority,
that they do not with favor support and aid any partial sect, namely that
that concerns the state and body of common weal. For the esteemed of the
prince, more easly, and with less occasion do undo them selves, and lose the
credyt they have woone: by reason of their partialities, and factions they
mayntayn, then they do for the daily benefyts and suyts they importune the
prince in. Wherefore the servant and officers of the kings house, although
they be in good favor with the prince, and that it please him to like well of
them, yet they may not so hardyly support any to do hurt to others, and so
absolutely, as if they were the lords and princes them selves. For albeeyt yt
pleases the king to call them to honor, and to enrych them with goods and
possessions, yet the king can not, nor will not like that they shallbee
suborners of factions, and quarells, amongst their subjects in the common
wealth. And yet nevertheless it happens many times, that those that see them
selves only in favor above others, will presume to do vyolence and wrong to
others, trustyng to their great credyt and favor they are in, that that shall
suffice to cloak and hide any fault they shall commyt, which they never ought
to think nor yet for any respect in the world to do. For such vnhaply might
be the crime they commyt, that although it be in the princes power to do
great things for them, yet he could not at that time with his honor excuse
their offense, nor seem to protect the^ in their lewdnes, without great murmur
and discontentacion of his subjects. I know very well, that in court the
minds, affections, and oppynions of courtiers are so diverse, and va^iable,
that notwithstanding the beloved of the prince endeavor him self al he can
possible to please and content every man in court, yet of all impossibylities
it is a thing most impossyble ever to attayn to it, to win all men's good
wylles. Nevertheless he must so trimly and wisely beehaue him self in all his
doings, that those at least, whom he can not with all his policy and devise
make his friends have not yet any just occasion geeuen them to be his enemies.
I see there is no mean, no reason, no devise or pollycy of man, favor nor
dilygence, that can defend the honored and esteemed of court from detraction
and envy. Therefore I will boldly geeue him this advise with him that in
matters of justice and other public affairs he bear him self so upright,
that notwithstanding they repine at his authority and credit: yet that they have
no cause offered to complayn of him. The courtier is forced to complayn when
his own familiar companions and fellow servants of the prince, in his matters
of contention or quarrel step beetween them, not to part them, but rather to
the contrary to contend with them and join in demand of that they strive for:
which the lucles courtier is very apt to know, although he dare not discover
yt, For many times he supposes yt less evil to suffer the persecucion of
the enemy, then to fall into the disgrace of the beeloued and esteemed about
the prince. For ye reputed of the prince commonly think they do much for the
common weal in bearing and favoring some, and in punishing and persecuting
others. For those of great authority, professing honor and reputacio^, and that
fear shame: would rather them selves to be defamed and rejected, then to see
their enemies advanced, or preferred to the favor of the prince or of them
that be in favor and credit with the prince. And the beeliked or officers of
the prince may not think, that the favor they geeue to one against an other,
can be kept secret, and that it cannot come to light: for in so doing they are
deceived. For in deed there is no thing so manifest or known in the common
weal, then the doings and practices of those that are in favor and authority,
yea even to the very words they speak. Those that are aggreeued, and have to
complayn of some injury done them, or also those that are even the familiars
of the favored, and that do but aspire daily to grow in greater credit with
their prince then others, do not see any thing said or done to others, yt are
in better credit then them selves: (be it in eating, drinking, watching,
sleeping, in play, being quiet or buysy,) but they sodeinly go and report it,
and tell it to some other that is in favor, to enter and to increase always
into greater favor and trust with them. If there happen any discention or enmity
amongst the people in the common weal, or realm, the esteemed of the court
must beeware in any case they put in their hand: and if they do at all, that
it be but to pacify them, and to make the^ good friends again, and not to
discover them worse then they were before. For if he do otherwise, all
these quarrels in the end shall cease, (they being reconciled togethers, and now
made parfet friends) and to him they will all show them selves open enemies. And
therefore it beehooueth the favored of princes to be have them seleus so
wisely toward them that are at discord and variaunce togethers, that both the
one side and the other shoold be glad and well pleased, to make him arbitrer
beetweene them to decide both their causes: without any suspicion that they
have of him (be it never so litel) of parciality of either part. The same day
that the favored of the court shall take upon him to bear any private
affection to any of the common weal, and that he rather lean to one party or
to an other: the self same day and hour he shall put in great hasard his
person, and not without great danger to lose his goods) together with the
favor and credit of his prince. And the secret enemies he has (through the
envy they bear him) should suffice him, yea rather to much, by reason of his
favor and credit) without seeking any new enemies, for that he says or does.
Such as are great with the prince, and ye fly the passions affections, and
partialities, of the common weal may be assured they shallbee beeloued,
served, and honored of all: but if they shall do the contrary, they may trust
to yt likewise, yt their enemies will be revenged of them, because they did
pursue them: And their friends also will complayn of them, because they did not
favor their cause as they ought. Therefore let not the beelyked thynk, if he
dare beeleeue me, that by having only the favor of the person of the prince,
it is enough for him to govern and rule the whole realm at his pleasure. For
although yt can not be denied, that to have so great a friend as the person of
a king, it is a great advantage and commodity, and that he may do much: yet
we must grant also, that many enemies, are able to hurt us, and do us great
injury. And therefore my advise should be, that every wise man, having one a
friend: should be ware to have an other enemy.

That the officers and beeloued of the court shoold be very dyligent, and
careful in the dispatch of the affairs of the prince and common weal, and in
correcting and reforming their servants, they shoold also be very circumspect
and aduysed. Cap. xii.
SVrely it is a great servitude and trouble to live in court contynually, but
it is a far greater when it is enforced of necessity (by reason of suytes and
troubles) and yet greatest and most intolerable, when they can not obteyn a
short and breef dispatch according to their desire. For weying well the manner
and conditions of the court, that suitor may reckon him self happily
dispatched, every time yt he is quicly dispatched, although his dispatch be
not according to his mind. And I speak it not without a cause, that he may
reckon him self well dispatched when he has his answer. For without
comparyson it is less ill of both, for the poor suyter that attends on the
court, to be presently denied his suyt, then to continue him long with delays
as they do now a days, the more is the pity. If the poor suitors (tgat go
to the court) did know certainly that the delay made in their suyts were for no
other occasion, but for to dispatch them well, according to their desire:
although it were not so reasonable, yet were yt tolerable the payns and
trouble that they abide. But if the poor miserable and wretched creatures have
great trouble in traversing the law, and abiding their orders: obteyning it
nevertheless in the end with great labor and toil, yea and contrary to their
expectacion: have they not yet matter enough trow ye to complayn of? yes suer,
enough to make them despair. What so ever he be therefore that goes to the
court to be a suyter for any matter of import, let him determyn and think with
him self he shall not obteyn his suyt even as he woold have it. For if he
shall feed him self with certain promises, made in private (a thing common to
courtiers, to promis much, and perform nothing) and with other vayn and
foolish thoughts: the great hope he shall conceive of their smokes of court,
must needs geeue him afterward occasion to despair when he sees ye promis
unperformed. The court is a sea so deep, a pilgrimage so uncertain, yt there
we daily see naught else, but lambs swymme with safty in ye deepest chanel, and
elephants drown in the shalowest foord. To go sue, to serve, to trauayl, and to
solicit in the court of princes, may aptly be likened and compared to those
that put in many rych jewels to the lottery in open market: in wc it happens
very often, that he that has put in a.100. lottes shall not happen perhaps of
one, and an other that only has put in one, fortune shall so favor him, that
he shall ever after be made a rych man. The like we may say to him that has
lived so long in court, that he has not only got him a beard, but it is also
now beecome a gray beard: and yet in all this long time of his service he has
not gotten him any certainty, or stay of living to live honesty withal, to
mayntayn his aged years in quiet: and he may well say, that all the lottes
have been unfortunate to him which he put in adventure. It is true, that to be
called a good and virtuous man, it suffyceth to have a sharp wit and good
head: but to beecome rych, he must only have good fortune. And this is
plainly seen in the court, that some in four months will grow great like a
Melone, and some other in forty years will never bear but little fruit, like a
palm tree. We have told you all these things to this end, only to remember
those that go to the court of princes to follow any suyt, or to continue a
courtier still, that in any case they carry a purse with them full of money, and
a heart armed with paciens. O what pyty is it every way to see him that is a
suter in the court, to be long haled with a tedious suit, and in the end not
to obteyn any part of his desire, without a little pleasyng wynd of court. For
if he will have his suit go forward, and take good success, and have it
speedely granted, he must first buy it of god with bitter tears, and
afterward of the king with humble intercession, of the secretaryes with
promysses, and of the ushers with presents, and of the beeloued and in
authority with infynit service: So that to conclude, far greater is the reward
they crave, then the value, of the favor or benefyt they beestow. If I have
discoursed to you sufficiently what the unlucky suitors have done and do: you
shall further know what they think and do imagyn, as it falls out true. The
seely souls they pass the nights in watch, devising continually, not in what
church the next day they may hear divine service, but only what means they
may procure to come to the speech of the favored of the court, to speak one
word unto them. The poor suter (unskillful of courtly practice) believes,
that when he has once exhibited a bill or memorial of his suyt to the
master of requests, or that he has spoken a word or two to any one in favor
with the prince, that straight without further delay he shallbee dispatched of
his suit, and that he shall not need to sue any more. But alas they are
deceived, and prevented of their expectacion. For the unhappy suter shall be no
sooner out of his sight, but they presently forget all that has been said to
them, yea and peradventure his mind so occupied, that his byll of memorial is
also torn in pieces, and his suyt and bill committed to flying air.
Thaffaires of the wars are done by force and necessity, and those of friends
by good will, but those of the miserable suyters of the court, by money or
great importunity. So that it follows that hardly any man obteyneth the end
of his suyt (be his right never so good) without great dyligence and paynfull
toil. And many times the poor suter of the court departs from his own
house, and goes to the court, on hope and deliberacyon to be dispatched in
two months: and afterward the poor miserable man shall spend above six
months there without dispatche. But all this is nothing to the greese and
displeasure he shall felt in the end, if with better judgment he measure and
consider, the pleasure and felicity he might have had at home, with the
troubles and displeasures he abides in the court. For making account with his
purse, he shall perhaps find all his money spent, ere his suyt in manner be
begoon. I told you but of a little wonder, to tell you that al his ill
consisted in the empting of the purse. For in deed I shoold have said better,
and more truly, tellyng you that he had sold his nagge, laid his sweord in
gage, baratted his cote and cloak, and of two shirts he brought, the one he
sold: so that the seely man has no more left to chop, nor sell. And yet more
over me thinks I tell you little, If I show you not also, that after he has
consumed all his money he brought in his purse, sold, chopped, and laid to
gage all the apparel that he had, he is notwithstanding all this enforced
for debt to gage to his host all that that remayns behynd, to satisfy him for
his lodging. So that when he comes home to his house, he may say truly,
that he comes home weary, ashamed, consumed, and all that he has at gage.
He that determines to be a suter at the court, is wont before he go from
home, to make account what he will spend every day ordynaryly: but what he
shall spend extraordinaryly, against his will, that he never reckens of. And
therefore I woold counsel him for the best, if he put ten crowns in his
purse for ordinary charges, let him also put ten more for extraordinary. For
it is impossible he should ever keep an order and measure, in so great a
disorder. For many times courtiers are compelled for their honor and
reputacions sake, to inuit their hosts and owners of the lodging where they
lie: and beesides the great charges they are at that way, yet come there
vnbydden to dinner and supper a company of iesters, players of enterludes,
mynstrells, and musicians, or other pleasant companions whom he can not refuse
and turn away for honesties sake, but must needs make them eat and drink
beesides the reward they look for. So that when he has made his account of
ten or xx. shillings charges for his dinner or supper, let him look in his
purse, and he shall find these mates have picked up in rewards as much, as ye
hole charges of his dinner or supper besides. More over they are daily visited
of their friends and kinsfolks, and vitells are so dear and of so excessive
price, that to make their provision at the best hand, they must send out posts
and lackeis into all parts to be their purueiers. And yet are they further
recharged that many times their servants rob them of all their money and
run their way when they have done, and sometimes they must new array them
selves, al with things ye courtier (in respect of his estimacion) is bound to do
thoroughly, and with the best manner, or else to sequester and banish him self from
court and courtiers life. It is true that a poor gentelman or other suitor
(that of necessity must follow ye court) knows very well the cause that
moves him to be a courtier, and attend on the court, but yet he shall not
know what his charge and expense wilbee about the suyt. If he have any favor
or credit in the court, he may happily obteyn a quick and ready dispatch, and
so perhaps save some part of his money in his purse he determined to spend:
without which he shall not only be enforced to borrow, but to send a new
messenger to his house for more money. O (the more is ye pyty) how many have I
seen in princes courts spend til that ever they brought to the court to follow
their suyt, and yet could not be dispatched in any thing he came for, save
that in steed of their money they consumed, they have purchased them great
troubles and displeasures, bewayling their lost time, and vayn expense. And it
is to be considered also, that if it be a great dyfyculty to speak to the
prince in our matter, to the presedent of the counsel, to the master of the
requests, and to the privy counsel, to the marshals of ye house, to ye
treasorers, to ye cofferers, to the fouriers and to the favored of ye court, it
is far greater and more trouble to enterteigne, and content their servants
and officers. For I dare assure you, you shall sooner and more easly win the
love of ye master, then you shall obtein the favor and good will of the
setuant. Princes are contented if we obey them: the favored of the court if
we serve them: but ye servants are never contented, nor in quiet, if they see
we do not worship them and entreat the^. And surely I will tell you a true
tale, and will not lie a word to you. In those days when I my self was also a
courtier in the court of princes, it stood me upon many times rather to
trouble ye masters, then to pray the servants. If perhaps (for penance of his
sins) the suter show him self importunat in his affairs, and that he
presume to dare say to him some nipping or unpleasant word, let him be well
assured he will not be revenged on him, to hurt him with sweord or lance: but
only in holding back his pen, to delay him in his dispatch. For I remember,
that once being but a poor priest, I was entreated by the procter of a
province to say him a douzen of masses for a great noble man (and in great
favor in the court) that had his matter in his hands, and he coniured me very
earnestly that I should not say them for the health and salvation of his soul,
but only that god would inspire him and put into his mind to dispatch him
quickly of his buysines. Therefore as we have spoken of the one, it is reason
we should also speak of the other. And therefore I say that there are some of
these officers and clerks of Judges, Magistrates, counselors, secretaries,
treasorers, marshals, fouriers, and other officers also of the court that are
so wise, and men of such honesty, and ciuility, that the dyscurtesyes and
wrongs sometimes their lord and masters do to us, they do the best they can
either to take them from us quite, or at the least to lessen or dymynish them.
For the contrary also, others there are so proud, and shameless, such tatlers,
and vile persons, and so unconscionable with all: of whom as it is a great
pleasure for us to see that they write, and to hear that they can speak so
well, and promise so liberally, only to win your money, and pick your
purse: so it is a great spite to us, and more shame, reproach, and infamy for
them, when afterward we see the contrary effects of their fair words, and
feigned promises, where with they feed us continually. And addyng thereto also
we see many times that such a young courtier, in less then four years that he
has remained in service with a noble man, or other officer of the kings in ye
court, has gotten by his practice and policy a fair moyle of great price,
with her harnes all gilt, his cofers well sylled, his tent for the feelde with
feeld bed and other furniture to it, his carpets on his table, his clothes of
tapestry over his doors his gowns richly furred for the winter, and those of
satin and damask and taffeta for the summer: and yet notwithstanding all this
glory, he may possible keep a curtesan for his pleasure and maintayn her. Al
which things considered and put together, it is impossible he should do it by
the gains of his pen or service, but only by dishonest means, and robbing
of his master. I saw once in my presens a poor suter, offer the clark of a
Secretary eight Rialls of silver for to dispach him of his suyt, and he
refused them flatly, and would none of them by no means, notwithstanding the
poor man turned him up the bottom of his purse, and showed him that he had
but only four rialls left to bring him home withal. So ye poor man came to
me, and entreated me to speak to this clark for him, to persuade him to take
his money he offered him, and to dispatch him, since he had no more left then
he showed him.

And I did so. And this woorshipfull clerk made me this dishonest answer. Sir,
behold my face and complexion, and you shall find that it is all of gold, and
not of silver. For I swear to you by our blessed lady of Lancet, that yt is
more then two years that I received for reward of my payns no other but gold,
and not silver laid in my hands. It can not be but that servant ye vauntes him
self to have a face of gold, will one day put his masters face in ye mire. Now
albeit we see the kings officers and others peradventure under them to ride on
their nagges with their foot clothes, to be brave in apparel, to be rich in
jewels, and happily to have a hundredth crowns in his purse, we should not
marvel of it at all: but if we have cause to think any thing ill in them, it
is for that many times they play away more money fondly, the^ woold serve any
other man to spend in all his necessaries. That officer or clerk that has not
above a hundredth crowns in his purse, and that in a night plays away two
hundredth crowns, what judgment shall a man geeue of him? but that either he
deceyueth others in his office, or he steals and pilfreth from his master
or lord, or else he exacteth upon the poor suitors, and racks them withal
extreamyty, without conscience and honesty, and that he will have yt on them
even with plain brawlyng? Yea and though these good felows be liberal in play
(as you have hard) yet I warraunt you they are not spare of diet neither, but
if they call their friends at a time to their table in the hall, or else bid their
curtesans to some gardein, you may be assured they want no deynty meats, nor
delycat wines to please their lyking lust: yea peradventure with more copy, and
better meat and drink then their masters or lords have any. Hear could I mate
them with like companions to them selves, ye marchaunts prentices, wc for their
lavish expense, their excessive play, their lusty banketing and feasting,
otherwhile their secret friends in gardens and blind tauerns, come not behynd
them at al in delicacy of fare, and in suptuous expense, but rather go before,
and leave them far behynd. And how think you, can these foul ryots and
disorders be born by any likelihood of the prentices own abylity? nay suer of
the masters cost (as best able) whose purse paieth for yt good cheer, though
he good man fare at home but thynly. But well, sense it touches not our
matter, I will retorn again where I left. All these things notwithstanding, they
are dishonest, are sometimes tolerable and to be born, so yt with these faults
they would be diligent to dispatch men, and easly to talk withal. But alas for
pyty, we see that for all these complaints they hear, and for all the requests
and entreaty that may be made to them, they will never take pen in hand
before the poor suter take his hand out of his purse, that they may feel him
a little. We have spoken al these things, to admonish, remember, and to beseech
the favored of the prince, and other their officers, that neither them selves
nor their servants under them, be long and slow in dispatchyng such things as
they have in charge, and cheefely of poor and miserable suitors. For if we
consider the qualities and conditions of men, we see that to many suitors yt
were less detriment and more profyt, to be answered quyckly (though they
were denied) then dyspatched slowly (and to have it granted) to their great
charge and long trouble. Truly me thinks it is a great secret of god to know,
why all those that are suyters in the court of princes, and those also whom we
sue to are all mortal: And all the suyts yt we labor for, seem (yea to say
more truly) are immortal. And hereof we see a daily experyence, that the
suyters dye, and their suyts live for ever, being never determined. O
excellent art, and fine devise of suyt that courtiers are wont to use, that
are grateful to princes, as for familyar example. They find a way to put in a
thousand manner of lets to hinder and delay the suyts, because that when by
tract of time they have more then half dyspayred the hopeles suyters, they
then, to revive them again, and to make their honor seem the greater, dispatch
them even in a moment without let or delay, and to the suitors whole
contentation. It is good reason the prince have a regard of the things he
geeues, and to whom he graunts them, and like wise of the time and place. For
in receiving favor or a good turn at the princes hand, they sometimes make
more account and estimate of the lyberalyty, and bountyfull mind of the prince,
then they do of the gyfts them selves. Suer it is a good thing, and laudable,
for those that are contynually about the person of the prince, that they be
easy to be spoken wythall, pacyent to hear, wise in aunswering, of good fame
in their life, and ready to dispatch and do good. For being otherwise, they
may be assured they shall show the mark and white for their enemies to shoot
their persyng shaft at, and shall geeue the suyters also cause to complayn and
speak ill of them. And therefore to cuite them short, I counsel them, that in
those things they are besought, that they be not too hard to be entreated:
and in that they are requested, that they be never too strange, nor drawyng
back, much less covetous, and in those things that are geeuen them, they be
never unthankful: and with those that they are conuersaunt, that they be very
well advised and considered: and those things whereof they are advertised, that
they endeavor them selves to keep yt in mind and memory, and never to forget
yt. And if they shall do otherwise, let them assure them selves, and trust
unto yt, that if they in time of suit shall shut the doors against the poor
suyters, that the common people also will never open their hearts once to serve
or love them. Princes servant should so govern them selves, that though there
were found some ill persons that despised them, for that they might do much,
and were of great authority: yet that there might be many others also honest,
that shoold praise and commend them for the great good they do. That man that
is enuyed, dispraysed, defamed, disloued, and ill thought of of al, should
think it lesser ill to dye honestly, then to live with shame and in disgrace of
every man. For to say truly, me thynks no man could live a more bitter and
hard life, although he abode many sorows, the^ to see him disliked generally
of ye whole common weal. It is an honest and natural thing for men to endeavor
them selves by all dilligence and industry to get much, but it should be far
better, and much more worth, to procure them selves good will. For in effect
nothing does more satisfy and glad the heart, and makes it more quiet, then to
think that he is beloved, and well accepted of all. It is a most certain rule,
that the foes and enemies of the favored courtiers never ioyn in friendship with
others, but with those whom they know to be full of passions and quarrels like
the^ selves. Of which detractors if any one happen at times to go to the house
of the honored of the court, upon any occasion of suit, and that they cannot
presently speak with him: they will not say I warrant you that he was busy,
and coold not speak with him, but that he was so proud and so haughty that he
woold not once hear nor see them. We are so wylling and forward in wishing
well, and so self willed and obstinate in hating, that upon a very light
occasion many times we love those we love, and with a much less occasion we
defame and speak ill of those we hate. Therefore the favored of princes shall
do great service to God, and much profitt to the common weal, if they geeue
order to dispatch all suitors (high or low) speedely: Since it is to the king
only that they impute the denial of their suites, but for the delay and
prolongation of them, they only lay it to the charge of the favored and
beeloued of princes. And those that are great with the Prince, may not excuse
them selves by reason of the nombers of matters they have in their hands. For
if he be alone, and that it lie in his hands only to dyspatch all, and that
he is not able to satisfy them all, yt cannot be but that some one of his
friends will advertise the king that he cannot do all, and how the people
complain, and the poor suitors find them selves agreeued, which purchase him
great enemies and ill willers, by reason the common wealth is so altered. So
that he shall not tarry long, but the Prince understanding of these
complaynts, will ioyn a companion with him to ease him of some part of his
pain. And therefore the good Princes shoold admonish, and warn the officers
well (whom they take to help to dispatch matters) that they be wise and
learned men, and of good life, and that they be not too partial in their
doings, nor too sharp and rough in their aunswers. For many times there happen
more troubles and sinister chances to Princes and noble men, for the
discourteous language of their officers and deputyes, then for any ill that they
them selves do commit. And therefore those that are in favor and auctority
with ye prince, must of necessity foresee to choose under them such persons, to
whom they geeue the care and charge of their affayrs and busynes, to dispatch
men's matters and suyts, that they be liberal of condition, pleasant in their
conversation, courteous in aunswers, true in their wrytings, easy and dyligent
in their dispatches, very honest and modest in that they geeue or take, and
sincere and perfitt in all their other virtues if it be possible: So that they
may ever be more careful to get friends for their masters, then money. For
like as the life of the master of the ship consists, and depends in the
only guide and judgment of the Pilot, and the conscience of the judge in his
constitute, the goods of the merchant in his factor, and the victory of the
prince in his Captayn: Even so likewise does the honor of the favored consist
in those he has chosen officers under him for the dispatch of men's affairs.
And although the servant of the beelyked be no partaker with his master of
his favor with the prince, yet is he a coadiutor to him to support his credit
and favor; and many times also a ready mean utterly to undo his master and to
dishonor him for ever. The like watch and care the good bishop has over his
flock, to preach unto them the Gospel of Ihesus Christ: the self same ought
the magistrates and higher powers have to their officers that are under them, in
taking heed that they be not slow and negligent in dispatching such business as
they have in charge, that they be not dishonest of life, presumptuous in
demanding, and false in their writing. For the least of these faults suffiseth
utterly to undo the servant, and also to defame the master. And therefore so
soon as the beloved of the court have any suspicion in the world, or ynkling
(be it never so little) that his servant is grown to be proud, dishonest,
and of a naughty conscience; he ought not only immediately to correct him for
it: but to put him out of his service forthwith, and to turn his coat over his
ears. Otherwise they will murmr so much at the servant that does all these
faults, as at the master that will not see them, and suffers them. Therefore
the reputed of court must first see, and peruse over the writings and doings
of their servant and secretaries, before they dispatch them out of their
hands, and to moderat their gayn with reason that is due to them. Otherwise
their enemies might justly say, that they keep not such under them to dispatch
poor men that sue to their masters, but rather to spoil and rob them. And
therefore they were better augment their wages they geeue those officers and
servant, then to confent or dissemble with their theft. For so doing, the
servant can never rise in wealth, but the master must needs diminish in
honor. It may happen many times yt the esteemed of the court shall be so
occupied in thaffairs of the comonweal, yt he cannot (though he woold) give
audiens to the suitors. But when they are thus occupied that they cannot in
deed, they must then command their servant and officers, that they
courteously entreat them, and hear them, and not check or rebuke them, and call
them importunat suitors. For it is no reason, yt for dispatch of their business,
the poor souls shoold be laden with injurious words.

That the derelings of the court beware they be not proud, and high minded,
For lightly they never fall but through this wicked vice. Chap. xiii.
WE read that Hieroboham succeeded his father in xii. realms that were his,
although they were but small realms. Who being requested and exhorted by the
grave aged men of his realm, to be courteous and temperat, and not gredy, nor
auaricious in recovering the tribuis and subsidies the other realms gave him,
and merciful and pitiful in punishing the offenses committed, answered them
thus. My father beat you only with simple whips, but I will not scurge you with
whips, but plague you with scorpio^s: for my little finger is greter tha^ was his
whole arm. Which happened very ill to him, yt for to chastise ye proud and
arrogant words he spoke to the^, and to punish him for his wicked doi^gs and
enormities co^itted, they afterward revolted against him, and took from
him.xi. of his realms, and al his fre^dz forsook hi^: so yt as he augme^ted i^
greatness of his fyngers, he diminished as much in his realms and riches. So
great was ye pride likewise of king Pharao, yt not contented yt god had pardoned
him his sins, and with the ten plagues that he had sent him, did yet
notwithstanding resist and pursue the people of Israel. Wherefore the sea,
(that was made a plain passage and high way, for the sauegard of the children
of Israel his enemies) was prepared a sepulture for him and his. Pompey the
great also being in Asia, when it was told him that he shoold leuy his power,
and prepare his men to be in redines to resist ye battle ye Julius Caesar came
to geeue him: with a great fury he stamped his foot upon the ground, and
proudly spoke these words. Next to the gods I fear no man, no not all mortal
men, although they all were bent against me, my power being so great, that I
am able to destroy Julius Caesar, and all his power coming against me. And not
only the realms of Asia shall fight for me, but also I will command the
ground that I tread on to rise against him. But what was the fattal end of
Pompeies pride? His captains lost the battle, his children their Realms and
seignories, and he in fine his head, Rome her liberty, and his friends their
lives. Themperor Domitian also was so vicious in his doings, and so proud in
his thoughts, that he openly commanded the governors and magistrates of his
realm in all their edicts and proclamations to say these words. Domitian our
god, and our prince commands that this thing be done. But lo the fynall
end of his pride, in taking upon him the name of a god, by consent and
counsel of his wicked wife Domitia, he had seven deadly wounds geeuen him in
his bed with a dagger. And thus woefully he ended his glorious life. Plutarch
recounteth also that king Demetrius was the proudest prince that ever reigned.
For he was not contented to see him self served of al men like a great and
mighty prince as he was, but he made them also honor him as a god. And he
woold not suffer any strange imbassatours to come into his presence, but they
shoold be appareled like priests. Aman was also very familier with the king
Assuerus, and although all those of his realm did him great service, and that
strangers had him in great veneration and did honor him maruelously, yet was
there a glorious Mardocheus, that woold never do him reverence, nor once put
of his capp to him: by reason whereof this Aman that was in so great favor,
commanded a gybbet of fyfty yards high to be set up for Mardocheus, whom he
woold have hanged on that gibbet, to be revenged on him for the injury he had
done him. But the divine will of God was such, and Fortune did permit it, that
on the same galloes Aman thought to have putt Mardocheus to death, on the self
same himself was hanged.

Themistocles and Aristides were two famous men among the Greeks, and because
they were both great Princes and Philosophers, and had in great reputation of
all those that knew them, there was such a secret emulation and ambition
between them, the one to reign over the other, that both aspyring each to
command other, there followed great disorders and oppressions of the subjects
of their commonweal. Wherefore Themistocles moved with pity and compassion of
so great a tyrant, which for their sakes their commonweal endured, one day in
the market place before all his people with a loud voice spoke these words,

Know you, O you people of Athens, that if you do not lay hands on my
exceeding presumption, and on the ouergreat ambition of Aristides, that our
gods wilbee offended, the temples will fall down to the hard foundation, our
treasures wilbee consumed, our selves destroyed, and our commonweals brought
to utter ruyn and decay. Therefore once again good people I say, bridle, bridle
these our inordinat and unspeakable affections beetymes, lest the rayns laid on
our necks we run to far. O golden words of a prince, and worthy
eternal fame. Lucanus also when he woold reprove the presumption and pride of
the Romayn princes, said, that Pompei the great coold never abide to have any
for his compagnion or equal with him within Rome: And Julius Caesar also woold
never suffer that there shoold be any greater in the world then him self. And
therefore to discourse a little of this abominable and horrible vice of pride,
we have not without great reason laid before you these approved examples,
before we begin to reprove it. For in all things thexamples we show you
are wont to move us more, then the reasons we seem to tell you of. For that
that I have seen, for that I have read, and for that that I have hard say also
of others, I am most assured and resolved thereof, that by the only cause of
this wicked sin of pride, proceeds the ruyn and utter decay of all our
greatest things and affairs of our life, for by all other sins a man may in
deed descend and declyne from his degree and state of honor and estimacion,
but by this only sin, he cannot chose, but he must fall down flat to the
grownd. They find out the midst and center of the earth, the depth of the
sea, and the highest tops of Riphei mountains, the end of the great mount
Caucasus, and the beginning of the great fludd Nile: and only the little heart
of man, touching desire to rule and command, can never find end. Thinsatiable
covetousness is such, that it cannot be contented with the things we have, but
only with those we repute of less price. Likewise ambition and pride to
command cannot be contained within bounds, but only by obeying. For never no
vice can have end, if he that has it does not leave it, and banish it from
him. After Alexander the great had conquered all Asia, and had subdued the
great India, he was one day reproved of the great Philosopher Anacharses, who
told him these words. Since thou art now, O Alexander, lord of all the earth,
why do thou weary thy self so much in thy affairs, as no pain seems
troublesome to thee? To whom Alexander answered. Thou have told me many times
Anacharses, that besides this world there are also three others. And if it be
so (as thou say) how great a reproach and infamy were it to me, that being
three other worlds, I shoold be lord but only of one. Therefore I do daily
sacrifyce to the gods, that though they take me out of the life of this world,
yet at least that they will not deny me of so glorious a conquest. I confess
that the Scriptures excepted, I have no words so ryfe in memory as these,
whereby may easily be perceived, that to quiet and content a proud heart, the
seignory of ye whole world is not yet sufficient, and how ended the pride of
this glorious prince? even thus. He that hoped to co^quer and be lord of the
three other worlds, did not rule this one only above.iii. years. We may boldly
say this, and swear it, and may also plainly prove it to any that desire to see
it, yt he wants both wit and knowledge, that takes upon him to be proud,
and presumptuous. For the more he looks into him self, and considers and
reconsidereth his state and calling, and what he is, he shall find in him a
thousand occasions fit to humble him, but never a one only to make him proud
and haughty. How great, rych, mighty, noble, and worthy so ever the parson
be, every time that we happen to see him, and that we have no acquayntaunce
of him. And that we desire to know what he is, we do not ask of what
element, of what sea, of what fire, of what planet, of what clymat, of what
sun, of what moon, nor of what aier, but only of what country he is of,
and where he was borne. For we are all of the earth, we live in the earth,
and in thend we have to turn into the earth, as to our natural thing. If the
planets and the beasts coold help us with the instrument and benefit of the
tongue, they woold take from us the occasions of vayn glory. For the stars
woold say, that they were created in the firmament, the Sun in the heavens,
the birds in the air, the Salamaunder in the fire, and the fysh in the water:
but only the unhappy man was made of earth, and created in the earth. So that
in that respect, we cannot glory to have other kinsfolk nearer to us, then are
ye woormes, the flies, and horseflyes. If a man did consider well what he
were, he woold assertain us that the fire burns him, water drownes him, the
earth wearies him, the air troubles him, the heat greeues him, the cold hurts
him, and the day is troublesome to him, the night sorrowful, hunger and thirst
makes him suffer, meat and drink filles him, his enemies daily follow him, and
his friends forget him. So that the time a man has to live in this wretched
world, cannot be counted a life, but rather a long death. The first day we
see one borne, the self same we may make rekening that he begins to dye:
and although that parson lived amongst us a hundredth years after in this world,
we shoold not say therefore that he lived along time, but only that he
tarried a great time to dye. Therefore that parson that has his life tied to so
many trybutes, I can not deuyse or think with my self why, or wherefore he
shoold be proud. But now returning again to our purpose, let us say, and
exhort the servant and familiers of princes, that they take heed they be
not proud and presumptuous. For it seeldom happens, that the favored of kings
and princes fall out of favor and credit for that they have, or can do much,
nor for that they crave and desire much: but for that they are to bold, and
presume to much. For in the court of kings and Princes there is nothing more
hurtful and less profitable, then pride and presumption. For often times the
ouerweening of the courtier, and the foolysh vain pride and reputacion he
has of him self, brings him to be in the princes disgrace, and makes the
people also to be offended and angry with him. For till this day we never
saw, nor hard tell of any that ever got into the princes favor and credit, for
that he was proud and high minded: but only for that he has showed himself
an humble, obedient, courteous, loving, and a faithful servant. I woold be of
this mind, that the courtier that sees he is received into favor in the
princes court, shoold ever wax better in serving well, then grow worse in
presuming to much. And I dare boldly say and affirm, that it is a mere point
of folly, by his pride and rashenesse to lose all that good in one day, that by
great good fortune he has attained to in many years. And though that the
favored courtier (subject possible to his fantastical humor) be sometimes
overcome with cholor, carnal desire, drawn with auaryce, and addicted to the
gorge, enuenomed with envy, plunged insloth and ydlenes, or some other vice and
imperfection, it shall not skill much, neither be any great wonder, since all
mankind is subject to those passions: and neither the prince, nor the common
weal, will reckon much of that. For of all these faults and vices there can
come no greater hurt to him, save only that that the common people woold
murmr against him. But his pride and pecokes glory once known and espied,
every man casts his eyes upon him to beehold his princely gate, and curses
him in word and deed. Therefore let a man be in as great favor as he can
deuyse to be, as worthy, noble, rich, and of as great power and aucthority
as he desires to be: I never saw any ill in all my life, if with all these
virtues he were proud and high minded, but in thend he was persecuted of
many, and hated and enuyed of all. For those that are in greatest favor about
the prince, have secret enemies enough to hinder their credit, although they
do not purchase them new, to accuse them of their pride and presumption. And
as we are taught by experience, ye burning coal cannot long be kept alive,
without it be covered with the whot ymbers. Even so I mean, that the favor of
the prince cannot be long maintained, without good bringing up, and civil
manners, gentle conversation, and familiarity. The great me^ of auctority about
the prince run estsones into great and many dangers: and this happens,
because they woold not be reproved in any thing what so ever they do, much
less here any word that shoold displease them, neither can they abide to be
told of their faults, much less suffer to be corrected for them. Nether do
they suffer willyngly to be counseled in any thing, be it never of so great
weight and importance, neither woold they have any compaygnion with them in
favor and credit with the Prince, but they desire to be both on the right hand
of the prince, and of the left: still they only woold be the favored of the
prince, and none other: aspiring to govern them in all their doings, and to
be thought and reputed the sole and only rulers of the affairs of the prince,
and his common weal, and to be believed in all things of the prince, and to
be obeyed also of the common people. Those therefore that are continually resient
in the court of princes, and that have the cheifest rooms and offices of
auctority in the court, let them well consider, and keep in memory this one
word that I will tell them. And that is this. That the first day that they
take upon them to be superinte^de^ts and governors of the common weal, even
in the self same day they shall come to put in hasard their honor, favor, and
credit, how great so ever it be. For with great difficulty are the lest things
the prince himself commands, executed or done in his realm or common weal:
and therefore may the favored of the court see, how much more hard it is for
him to rule, (as sole and absolute lord) the affairs of the realm, and to be
obeyed in the common weal: since the king him self cannot do it by his regal
auctority. And therefore the less he shall desire to meddle with thaffairs of
the people, the more shall he live in quiet and contented. For naturally the
common people are so unstable and uncertain in their doings, unthankful of
benefits received, and so ungrateful of a good turn done them: that the
beloved of the court or any other person in favor with the prince can ever do
any thing for the people, (be it never so well) but they will speak ill, and
mislyke of him, and find fault with some of his doings. It is impossible that
those that will command many things in the court of princes shoold alwais do
their things so, but they shoold sometime tread awry. And admit their faults
be but light, and of small moment, yet they may be assured there wilbee enough
that will both open them to the common weal, and tell them also secretly to the
prince alone. For those that seek to deuorce the favored of the court from the
prince, do not complayn or find fault for that they are more in favor with the
prince tha^ others, but they will show they take it in ill part, they have more
aucthority, and command more then others in the comonweal. Saying that by mean
of their place and authority, and under color of good zeal to minister Justice,
they geeue commonly foul and injurious words, far unfit for the aucthority
of the person, and woorthynes of the place. So that it cannot be otherwise
chosen, but that continuing this disorder, they must needs make the king
suspect them, and besides that bring a great discord betwixt the king and those
that he favors, and make him meruelously offended with them. For in thend,
princes woold alwais be served, and obeyed, but not ruled, and commanded. And
yt is a most true saying. Over much familiarity bredeth contempt, wc although
yt may be borne between men of like degree and equality, yet is it not
tolerable between the prince and the beliked of the prince. But rather every
day, hour, and moment that the favored courtier enters into the princes
palace, or into his privy chamber, he ought ever to do it with as great
curtesy, reverence, humility, and honor, and in speaking to the king, as if he
had never spoken with him, nor seen him. So that he shoold let all men see,
that though it please the kings majesty to make of him, and to accept him into
his favor, yet that he leave not to serve him, and do him that duity that all
other servants do, and are bound to do. The suerest and most certain way to
maintain those that are sublimed, and exalted in the court of princes, and to
raise and bring those to auctority that are low and of base condition, is: that
the esteemed repute him self ever a servant, and that the servant never vaunt
nor bost him self to be favored or esteemed. The familiers of princes ought
ever to be ware that there come no complaints of them to the princes ears. For
as a drop of water, by time and continual fall comes to perce the hardest
stone: so it might happen that the nombers of complaints, might be occasion
for the prince to wtdraw his favor and love from the courtier again. If his
only seruyces were sufficient to induce ye prince to favor and love him: so the
number of his subjects complaints against him, were occasion enough to make him
mislike him, and put him out of favor clean, changing his love and favor, to
hate and discredit it. For it a certain thing, that when the prince does look
well into his own doings, he had rather be beloved of all, then served of
one alone. The honored of the court may not regard so much the honor and credit
he is called to by his prince, as ye baseness and poverty he was in, when it
pleased the king to like of him, and that he came first acquainted with the
king. For if he did otherwise, it might happen, that like as fortune had
brought him to that high estate he had: So pride might overthrow him again,
and bring him as low as he was before. For I shoold have said more truly a
great deal, saying that it woold have made him fall down right, being the
right property of fortune, to suffer the baser sort (whom she had called to
honor) only to return them to their mean estate and call, they were of at the
first, and never to leave the favored of ye prince, and men of auctority (nor
never satisfied) till she have thrown them down hedlong into extreme misery,
never to rise again. Agathocles (first the son of a Potter, and afterward
made king of Scicillia) whilst he lived, he ever used this manner, that in
his tresory or jewel house, yea and also at his table, amongst all his cupps
and dishes of gold and silver, he had some also of earth amongst them: and
being asked the occasion, why in so great a treasure, and mass of gold and
silver he had so vile a thing as earth, answered thus. I drink in golden
cupps and eat in earthen dishes, to geeue thanks to ye gods, which of a potters
son that I was, brought me to this royal state of a mighty king. And I do
it also to have evermore cause to be humble, and to fly pride. For it is an
easier thing, and more lyker for a king to become a potter, then for a potter
to attayn to the greatness and state of a king. These words of Agathocles were
ever worthy to be noted and had in memory, since we see plainly, that to
geeue a man a fall, a little stone suffices to make us stumble and fall to the
ground: but to raise us up again, we must needs help us with power of hands
and feet. It may well be, that this brave courtier and favored of the court
before he came to this degree of honor, was but of a mean house, and basely
borne, and besides that esteemed of few, for his nobility of blood: of an
unknown country, of poor parentage, of small substance, and no better nor
otherwise favored of fortune in his birth or lynage. of all which things he
has no cause to be ashamed, but rather to glory, and praise god. For he
shall ever be more esteemed in the court, and well thought of, to remember
from whence he came, and to regard his first estate: then he shall, if he
wax glorious, and high minded, by reason of the favor he is in at this present
utterly forgetting his first rising. Titus Liuius recites that ye renowned
Romayn Quintus Cincinatus, before he came to be made captain of Rome, he was
taken out of ye feelds a laboring man, plowing and tilling ye ground. And this
so noble person, being occupied in great affairs of ye common weal, either in
provisions, or munitio^, or in expeditions of war, was wont to sygh before
all the captains, and say. Alas, who coold tell me now any news, how my
beefes do in my graunge, my sheep in the mountains, and whether my servant
have provided them of hay and pasture to keep them the next year? Surely it is
to be thought, that who so ever speaks these words with his mouth, must
needs have little pride in his heart. And undoubtedly he proved his words
true, and showed that he spoke as he thought, and in good earnest, without
intent of jest: since afterward he returned home again, to follow the plough,
to plant his vynes, and to see his own things governed, leui^g behind him a
perpetual testimony of his noble and worthy doings. And his common weal also
greatly enryched by his famous acts. Saul was king of Israel, and taken for a
god, and was anointed of Samuel his father a poor husba^dman of ye country,
and he from his youth brought up in that trade to hold ye plough: and yet when
he was king, he never disdeined to plough his ground, to sow his otes, and to
drive his beasts, now to pasture them home again. So that the good king did
glory this day to hold the plough, and to morrow to fight with his sword. When
fortune therefore shows her self enemy to any, and that from great dignity
and high call, she overthrows him, and brings him to low and mean estate:
it is then that he has good cause to complain of fortunes cruelty, and to
bewail his wretched happ, ashamed to see his lothsom misery. But when she
woorketh contrarily, and from mean estate brings him to great honor and credit,
that must needs be great honor and glory to him. Therefore I say let them
beware, beware, that bear rule and aucthority in the court, that they be not
proud, glorious and high minded, neither otherwise detected of any kind of
vice, though the be never so much in favor and estimation. Since fortune
shows most her spite against the proud, and disdainful heart, rather then to
the humble and meek. To stopp the enemies mouth, there can be found no better
means, then for the derlyng of the court not to be too proud and presumptuous,
since no man is found so mad or foolish in the same, as once to dare to say, I
accuse this man, because he is in favor and estimation: but he may boldly do
it, when he sees in deed that he is a proud glorious fool. If we see the
favored of the court offended one with the other, we will say it is but heat,
if we see him eat to much, we will say it is but of a good stomach. If he
rise late, we will excuse him, and say it was late ere he went to bed, and
that he was weary with watching. If he play often, we will say he does it for
pastime: if he be careful in keeping that he has together; that he is wise
and pollytike: if he speak much, that he is a pleasant man and geeuen to be
merry: if he speak little, that he is wise and modest: if he spend much, that
he is liberal and bountiful: but if he be glorious and proud, what shall a
man say on him, and with what honest mean can we excuse him? Surely let others
look, For I know not. Truly for all other faults and errors of men, they may
honestly be excused, save only that of pride. For though many times we commit
other offenses, it is but through frailty: but if we offend in pride, it
comes of a great folly, and want of discretion. And for the contrary, the
lowly and courteous condition of ye courtier, do not only depresse and resist
the detractions and murmurings of their enemies, but does enforce them against
their wills to say well of the^. For god does suffer many times that the
perverse nature and condition of one, is subdued and overcome, by ye good and
gentle usage of an other. Therefore the beloved of court shoold take great
heed, that they show not them selves proud in their words, and much less in
their ceremonies wc they use in the court: as in going up ye stairs, in entering
in at the doors, in taking the stool to sit down, and also in putting of his
cap. And though perhaps he that shall read these our aduertisments, will thynk
them rather precepts for children, then for men: yet I will answer him
nevertheless, that they are very necessary for those that are in favor in the
court, and for all other courtiers, without the use of which he may happily
noorish a venomous Serpent in his breast. And therefore not without great reason
we have spoken that we have, that of too little heed taking, sometimes there
may follow great trouble to the favored courtier. For many times they murmr
more against him, in not putting of his capp, when he is courteously saluted:
then they do, if they deny their favor when they are requested. If one
courtier leave to do courtesy to an other, they say he does yt not for that
he bears him ill will: but for want of bringing up. But if he be great
with the king, then they say it is not for want of good manner, but for that he
is too proud. To say truly, it is an unhappy life, the life of ye beloved in
the court, since they attribute all their faults and errors to folly: although
they committed them rather through negligence, and want of foresight, then of
pretensed malice, or ill will, as it is taken and thought. Gneus Flaccus a
noble Romayn, going in company with other Romans to visit a sick man, and
coming also an other romain to see the same sick person likewise, and being no
place commodious in the chaumber where the last might sit down, neither any
stool left to sit down upon: they say, he rose of on his stool, and gave
him place that came last. The which humanity and curtesy was afterward
published among all the Romans, and after also greatly praised of the writers.
And the Romans also, being very true, grave, curious, and worthy of great
faith and credit in all that they wrote, it is to be credited, that that act
of curtesy was much noted and esteemed, since they woold write it in the most
noble and heroycall acts of their common weal. When the favored courtier is
accompanied with knights and gentlemen of the court, that brings him to the
court, and it happen any to go up the degrees before him, he shoold not pass
for that, much less show any token that he made any rekening of it. For to
say troth, it is no great matter for him to go up before him on the degrees
of stone, since he went before all on the degrees of favor. What matter is it
to the favored or officer of the court, to see an other enter in at the staier
door before him, if afterward when they shall come where the king is, he
shall go into the privy chamber, as one that in deed is in favor and beloved,
and the other shall stand without like a sheep? And to conclude I say, if I were
in the number of those that are thus belyked, and favored of the king, I woold
in the kings chamber use my favor and credit, and abrod, all curtesy and
ciuility.

That it is not fit for courtiers to be too covetous, if they mean to keep
them selves out of many troubles and dangers. Cap. xiiii.
AVlus Gelius and Pliny render true testimony in their writings, that the
honesty of the Romans was so great in their eating, and their modesty in their
mainteining of them selves such, that they did not suffer any romain citezen to
have any more houses then one to dwell in, nor but one gown to put on his back,
one horse to ride upon, not above two yoke of oxen to till his land. Titus
Liuius, Macrobius, Cicero, Plutarch, Salust, Lucan, Seneca, Aulus Gelius,
Herodian, Eutropius, Trebellius, Vulpitius, and all the other romayn writers
do never cease to praise the ancient romain poverty, saying the common wealth
of Rome never lost one iott of her greatness, and honor, during the time that
they went abroad to conquer other realms and dominions: but only since they
began to geather treasor together. Licurgus the Philosopher (who afterward was
king of the Lacedaemonians) ordained in his laws he made, that no neighbor
shoold have any more goods then an other: but that all houses, lands, vynes,
and possessions, gold, silver, apparel, mouables, and generally all other
things what soever, shoold be indifferently holden among them to the common
utility of all. And being asked, why he woold not consent the common weal
shoold have her own private commodities and particulers, answered thus: The
payns and travels men endure in this mortal life, and the great troubles and
disorders that come daily to the common weal, chance not so much for that men
have need of living to maintain them selves with all, but for that they do
desire to leave to their heirs and successors. And therefore I have appointed
every thing in common among subjects, because that during their lives they
might have honestly to maintain them selves with all, and that they shoold leave
any thing to dispose by will after their deaths. Herodotus says also, that it
was decreed by thinhabitans of the Isles Baleares, that they shoold suffer none
to come into their country to bring them any gold, silver, silk, jewels, or
precious stones. And this served them to great profit. For by means of this
law, for ye space of.iiii. C. years that they had wars with the Romans, the
Carthagians, ye French and ye Spaniares, never any of these nations once
stirred to go about to conquer their land, being assured that they had
neither gold, nor silver, to rob or convey from them. Promotheus that was the
first that gave laws to the Egiptians, did not prohibit gold nor silver in
Egypt (as those of the Isles Baleares did in their territories) neither did he
also command that all thing shoold be common, as Licurgus: but only commanded,
that none in all his kingdom shoold be so hardy once to gather any mass or
quantity of gold or silver together, and to hoard it up. And this he did upon
great penalties: for as he said, avarice is not showed in buylding of fair
houses, neither in having rich moueables, but in assembling and gathering
together great treasure, and laying it up in their coffers. And Plutarche in
his book De consolatione says also, that if a rich man dyed among the
Rhodians, leaving behind him one only son and no more suruyuing him, they
woold not suffer that he shoold be sole heir of all that his father left:
but they left him an honest heritage, and living, so his state and call, and to
mary him well withal, and the rest of all his sethers goods they dissipated
among the poor and orphans. The Lydians, that neither were Greeks nor
Romans, but right barbarous people, had a law in their common weal, yt every
man shoold be bound to bring up his children, but not to be at tharges in
bestowing them in marriage: So yt the son or daughter yt were now of age to
mary, they gave them nothing to their marriage, more then they had gotten with
their labor. And those yt will exactly consider this lawdable custom, shall find
that it is rather a law of true philosophers, then a custom of barbarous
people. Since thereby ye children were enforced to labor for their living, and
the parents also were exempted from al manner of covetousness or avarice, to heap
up gold and silver, and to enrich them selves. Numa Pompilius second king of
the romans, and establisher of their laws and decrees, in ye law of the seven
tables wc he made, he left them order only, wc way the Romans might rule
their common weal in tranquillity: and put in no clause nor chapter yt they
shoold make their wills, whereby their children might inherit their fathers
goods. And therefore being asked why he permitted (in his laws) every man to
get as much goods as he coold, and not to dispose them by will, nor leave them
to their heirs: He answered, because we see, yt albeeit there are some
children that are unhappy, vicious, and abominable, yet are there few fathers
notwtstanding this, that will deprive and disherit them of their goods at their
death, only to leave them to any other heir: and therefore for this cause I
have commanded, that all the goods that remain after the death of the owner of
the^, shoold be given to the common weal, as sole heir and successor of them:
to thend that if their children shoold become honest and virtuous, they shoold
then be distributed to them: if they were wicked and unhappy, that they shoold
