never be owners of them, to hurt and offend the good. Macrobius in his book De
somno Scipionis says, that there was in the old time an old and ancient law
amongst the Tuscans duly observed, and kept, and afterward taken up of the
Romans: that in every place, where so ever it were, (in town or village)
within their territories, on new years day every man shoold present him self
before the judge or magistrate of the place he was in, to geeue him account
of his manner of life, and now he maintained himself, and in this examinatio^s
they did accustom to punish him that lived ydlely, and with knavery and
deceit maintained them selves: as minstrels, ruffyans, dycers, carders, and
iuglers: coggers, foysters, cosiners of men, and sylching knaves, with other
loytering vacabo^ds and rogues, that live of others swett and toil, without any
pain or labor they take upon them to deserve that they eat. I woold to god (if
it were his will) yt this Tuscan law were observed of christians: then we
shoold see how few they be in number, that geeue them selves to any faculty or
science, or other trade, to live by their own travel and industry: and how
many and infinite a number they be that live in idle sort. The divine Plato in
his Timee says, that although an idle man be more occasion of many troubles
and inconveniences in a common weal, then a covetous man, yet is it not alwais
greater: for the idle man, and that gladly takes his ease, does but desire to
have to eat: but ye covetous man does not only desire to eat, but to be rich
and have money enough.

All the eloquence and pleasant speech that the Orators studied in their
orations, the lawyers in their law, and the famous philosophers in their
doctrine and teaching, was for no other cause, but to admonish and persuade
those of the common weal, to take very good heed in choosing of their
governors, that they were not covetous and ambitious in thadministration of
their publyke affairs. Laertius recyteth also, that a Rhodian jesting with
Eschines the philosopher said unto him. By the immortal gods I swear to thee O
Eschines, that I pity thee to see thee so poor, to whom he answered. By the
same immortal gods I swear to thee again, I have compassion on thee, to see
thee so rytch. Sith riches bring but pain and trouble to get them, great care
to keep them, displeasure to spend them, peril to hoard them, and occasion of
great dangers and inconuenyences to defend them: and that that greeueth me
most, is, that where thou keep thy treasure fast locked up, there also thy
heart is buried. Surely Eschines words seemed rather spoken of a christian,
then of a philosopher. In saying, that where a man's treasure is, there is also
his heart. For there is no covetous man, but daily he thinks upon his hid
treasure: but he never calls to mind his sins he has committed. Co^paring
therefore those things we have spoken, with those things we will speak, I say:
that yt becomes ye favored of princes to know, yt it is less seemly for the^
to be covetous then others: For ye gretnes of their favor ought not to be
showed only in being rich, but also in being noble and worthy Plutark shows,
that Denis the Siracusan coming one day into the chamber of the prince his
son, and fyndyng gryat riches of gold and silver that he had geeuen him, he
spoke very angerly to him and said, thou had been far fytter for a
merchant of Capua, then to be as thou art the kings son of Scicilla sith
thou have a wit to gather, but not to spend. Which is not fyt, nor lawful for
thee, if thou wylt succeed me after my time in my kingdom. And therefore I
do remember thee, that kingdoms and high estates are not maynteyned with
keepyng of riches, but only with geeuing, and honorably bestowyng them well.
And to this purpose also recyteth Plutarke, that Ptholomeus Philadelphus was
demanded, why he was so slow, and with so great difficulty received the
services of others: and was so liberal and noble in geeuing, and grauntyng
favors: he answered. I will not get reputacion amongst the gods, nor good
renown amongst men for being rych, but only I will be praised and esteemed
for making of others, rych, and having under me rich subjects. These words
that Tholomee said to a friend of his, and those that Denis spoke to his son
me thynks the beloved of the court should not only be contented to read
them, but to seek to keep them still in mind, sith by them we may manifestly
see, yt riches are ever more profitable for a man that owes them, and geeueth
them bountifully: then to have them, and with covetousness to hoord and lock
them up in their coffers. And the favored of princes should not be enuyed, for
the goods that they can get by their favor and credit, but only for the good
that thereby they may do to their friends and kynsfolk. For they are those that
with others goods, make the people slaves to the^. What greater nobility can
there be in this world, then to make others noble? what greater riches, then
to make others rich? and what more lyberty, then to make others free? The glory
yt the princes, and those that they esteem and have in their savor ought to
have, should not consist in getting together much goods, but in winnyng many
servant and friends. Great are the privileges that the noble and lyberall men
have, for their children are obedient to them, their neyghbors love them, their
friends do accompaigne them, their servant serve them faithfully, strangers
vysyt them, and the enemies they have, dare not speak against them: for
although they spite at their greatness and favor, yet they dare not once
presume to rebuke or reprove their lyberalyty. Phalaris the Agrigentine, Denis
the Siracusan, Catelyne the Romayn, and Iugurth the Numidian: These four
famous tyraunts did not mayntayn their states and roial kingdoms with the
virtues they had, by only but force and ample gifts they gave. So that we may
well say, that in ye world there is no stone so phylosophicall, nor hand so
liberal as treasor and riches: sith that in geeuing it, good men become great,
and tyra^ts thereby are supported. I would those yt are princes familiars woold
note well this word, that is, that great favor joined with much covetousness is a
thing impossible to continue long in any. For if he mean to keep him self in
favor, he must needs fly avarice: and if he will needs stick to avarice, he
must of necessity lose his favor. There is no better means for him that seeks
the princes favor, to get into favor: then to serve him dilygently, and to
trouble him seldomly. The kings officer that serves him in his house, must
endeavor to make the king know yt he serves him more for the love he bears
him, then for any gayn or profyt he hops at his hands. For in doing so, ye
king will not only with his favor and benefits bestowed on him, treat and handle
him as one he loves and makes account of, but also love him as if he were
his own son. It is most just, ye beloved of the prince, love and honor ye
prince with al his heart, sense he loves him, and needs not. Those yt are
beloved, made of, and favored in princes courts, should make great account of
yt, and therefore they shayld serve willingly. For the love we bear to
princes, comes commonly rather of the necessity we have of them, then of our
own proper wills. But the love of princes to us, comes of mere good will,
and not of necessity. If any man do company me, speak to me, and serve me:
yt is only in that respect that I ever geeue him, and for that he hops I
will geeue him in time to come. And to such a man I might truly say, he rather
flaterith then loves me. The esteemed of the court must note if it please
the^, that though the prince have others about him, who^ he favors and
loves as well as him self, yt he be not therefore offended nor displeased a
whit. For else all those he sees accepted into favor with ye prince, he woold
make the^ his enemies, and because they may avoid this inco^uenie^ce, they must
take it in very good part. For albeit ye prince geeue his favor to one alone,
yet he imparteth his gifts to diverse. Those that newly begun to rise in ye
court, and to do much: may not even upon a soden show them selves to be rich,
but only study daily to increase in favor. For every time that the courtier
does assure me he does not diminish in favor, I will be bound to him he
shall never be poor. The way they must observe in the court to be great, and
to be able to do is this: That is, to visit often, to suffer, to present to
persevere, to be beloved, and to continue in the princes favor: Which I assure
you, is a great secret, and right alchimyne of court, sodeinly to rise in
favor, and to be rich, and al in short time. By this I infer, that the wise
man ever desires first to be in favor, before he covet to be rich: but the
fool and Idiot desires first to be rich, and then in favor last. Not few but
many we have seen in princes courts, wc though fortune in short time has
exalted to ye first degree of riches and made the^ chief in favor, yet wtin
short space after, she has made the^ also lose their riches, and fall from ye
top of their honor. It is most certain, yt if one have enemies in the court,
only for that he is infauor, he shall have as many more, if being in favor,
he be also rich. For we are al of so ill a condition, in things that touch
our particular profyt, that all that we see geeuen to others, we think
sodeinly taken away from our selves. We have heretofore said, yt it is not fit
for the courtier, and those yt are in favor, to command for his profit all that
he list, neither al those yt he may. And we now at this present also advise
them to take heed, yt they do not accept and take all that is offered and
presented, although they may lawfully do it. For if he be not wise in
co^mau^ding, and moderatin taking, a day might come yt he should see himself in
such extremity, yt he should be enforced to call his friends not to counsel
him, but rather to help and succor him. It is true, yt it is a natural thing
for a courtier that has 20. crowns in his purse, to desire sodeinly to
multiply it to a.100. from a.100. to.200. from 200. to a.1000. from a.1000. to
2000. and from.2000. to 10000. So yt this poor wretched creature is so blinded
in covetousness, yt he knowth not, nor feels not, yt as this auar ce
continually increases and augmenteth in him, so his life daily diminishes and
decreaseth, beesides that that every man mocks and scorns him, that thinks
the true co^tentacion consists in commanding of many, and in the faculty of
possessing much riches. For to say truly it is not so, but rather disordinat
riches troubles and greeueth the true contentacion of men, and awaketh ever in
them daily a more appetite of covetousness. We have seen many courtiers rich
and beloved, but none in deed that ever was contented, or wearied with
commanding, but rather his life should fail him then covetousness. O how many
have I seen in the court, whose legs nor feet have been able to carry them,
nor their body strong enough to stand alone, nor their hands able to write, nor
their sight has served them to see to read, nor their teeth to speak, neither
their jaws to eat, nor their ears to hear, nor their memory to travail in
any suyt or matter, and yet have not their tongue failed them to require
presents and gifts of the prince, neither deep and fine wit, to practice in
court for his most avail and vantage. So incurable is the disease and plague
of avarice, that he that is sick of that infirmity, can not be healed neither
with poverty, nor yet be remedied with riches. Sense this contagious malady
and apparent danger is now so commonly known, and that it is crept into
courtiers, and such as are in high favor and great authority by reason of this
vile sin of avarice, I would counsel him rather to apply him self to be
well thought of, and esteemed, then to endeavor to have enough. Albeit Queen
Semiramis was wife to king Belius, and mother of king Ninus, and although by
nature she was made a woman, yet had she a heart never other wise but valiant
and noble. For after she was wyddow, she made her self lord by force of arms
of the great India, and conquered all Asia, and in her life time caused a
goodly tomb to be made wheare she would life after her death, and about the
wc she caused to be graven in golden letters these words.

Who longs to swell with mass of shining gold,
and craves to catch such wealth as few possessed:
This stately tomb let him in haste unfold,
where endless hopes of hateful coin do rest.
Many days and kings reigns past before any durst open this sepulker, until
the coming of the great Cyrus, who commanded it to be opened. And being
reported to him by those that had the charge to seek the treasure, that they
had sought to the bottomless pyt and wolrds end, but treasure they coold find
none, nor any other thing, save a stone wherein were graven these words.

Ah haples knight, whose high distraughted mind
by follies play abused was so ^ych:
that secret tombs the care as could not bynd,
but thou would reaue them up for to be rich.
Plutarke and also Herodotus which have both written this history of Semiramis
do show and affirm, yt Queen Semiramis got great honor by this gest, and king
Cyrus great shame and dishonor. If courtiers that are rych, think and believe
that for yt they have money enough and at their will, yt therefore they should
be far from al troubles and miseries, they are far deceived. For if ye
poor soul toil and hale his body to get him only that yt he needs, much
more does ye rich man torment and burn his heart, til he be resolved wc way to
spend yt superfluous he has. Ihesu what a thing is it to see a rich man how
he tormenteth him self night and day, imagyning and devising with him self
whether he shall with that money yt is left, buy leases, mills, or houses,
a^nuities, vines, or cloth, lands, teneme^ts, or pastures: or some thing in
fee: or whether he shall e^rich his son with ye thirdes or fifts, and after al
these vain thoughts, gods will is to stryke him with death sodeinly, not only
before he have determined how he should lay out or spend this money, but also
before he have made his will. I have many times told it to my friends, yea and
preached it to them in the pulpit, and written yt also in my books, that it is
far greater trouble to spend the goods of this world well, and as they ought
to be spent: then it is to get them. For they are gotten with swet, and spent
with cares. He that has no more then he needs, it is he yt knows well
how to part from them, and to spend the^: but he yt has abunda^s and more
then needeful, does never resolve what he should do. Whereof follows many
times, that those wc in his life time were enemies to him, shall happen to be
heirs after his death of all the goods and money he has. It is a most suer
and certain custom among mortal men, yt commonly those yt are rych men (while
they are alive) spend more money vaynly in things they would not, and that they
have no pleasure in, and where in they would least lay it out: and after their
death they leave the most part of their inheritance to those, whom they loved
least. For it happens many times, that the son which he loved woorst,
inheryteth his goods, and that son which he loved best, and made most of,
remains poor. Therefore contynuyng still our matter I say, that I know not
the cause why the favored of the court desire to be so rych, covetous, and
insatiable, sith they alone have to get the goods where afterward to spend
them, they have need of the counsel and advise of many. Let not those also
that are in favor with the prince, make too great a show openly of their riches,
but if they have abundance, let them keep it secret. For if their lurking
enemies know not what they have, the woorst they can do, they can but murmur:
but if they see it once, they will never linne til they have accused him. To
see a courtier buyld sumptuous houses, to furnish them with wonderful and
rich hangyngs, to use excess and prodigality in their meats, to have their
cubberds maruellously decked with cups, and pots of gold and silver, to see
infinite presents brought into his house, and to be greedy of money in taking,
and to have a great trayn of servants to wait upon them: al these are things
not only to make them murmur and repine at, but also when time and place
serves, to condemn and accuse them, to the prince. And this were but little
to murmur at them, and accuse them, so that they did not defame them, and
diminish their honor and reputacion. For they tell yt abroad afterward, either
that they are corrupted with presents, or that they do rob and steal from
the prince their master. And therefore I return once again to admonish them,
and specially the officer of the court, that they shall not need, neither is
it requisite they make any ostentacion of their riches, if they be wise at
least. For besides that every body will murmur against him, they will not spare
to bring it to the princes ears quyckly, so that by mysfortune yt might happen
to him, that the king would do that with his servant the hunter does often
with his beasts he takes, that many times he cheerisheth him and geeueth him
meat to eat, not to bring him up, but to fat him, and kill him for his own
eating.

That the favored of the court shoold not trust too much to their favor and
credyt they have, nor to the great prosperity of their life, a worthy chapter
and full of good doctrine. Cap. xv.
WHat reputacion Paul the apostle had amongst the christians, the like had the
great Cato the judge, among ye Romans, who in ye progression of his life
proceeded so honestly, and in the government of the public weal was so just,
that he deserved that this Epitaphe should be written upon his palace gate.

O Cato great, whose everlasting fame
Amid the earth still lives with honor dew,
was nere none, could the oppress with shame
for judgment wrong, whereby the giltles rue.
Was nere none, durst press to thee with suyts,
or fill thy hands with bribes, or flatter thee
whereby thou should not show the worthy fruits
of justice zeal, as judges all shoold be.
Among all the noble and renowned Romans, he only would never suffer stature
or Image of his, to be set up in ye high Capitol. Whereat diverse marueling,
and imagynyng dyuersly what was his meaning, he being one day in the senate
said to them these words openly. I will they shall seek the good woorks I
have done, by which I did deserve that my Image should be erected in the
Capitol: then to geeue them cause to go search and inquier what lynage I was
of, and what was my life, with intent to pull down my Image. For yt happens
many times, that those whom inconstant fortune from mean and low estate has
raised to high degree and step of honor, do become afterward by the same
occasion rather defamed, then praised. For there are many that are reverenced,
and honored openly, by reason of their honor and dignity they have at this
present, of whom they make a iestyng stock afterward when they see them fall.
Lucan says, that Pompeius woold say many times, when he would speak of these
worldly things, my friends, I can tell you a true thing, whereby you may know
the little occasion we have to trust humayn felycityes. Example you may see in
me, which attained to the Romayn Empire, without any hope I had ever to come
unto yt: and afterward also not mystrusting any thing, even sodeinly it was
taken from me, and I depryued of yt. Lucius Seneca being banyshed from Rome,
wrote a letter to his mother Albuina, in which he did both comfort her, and
him self, and wrote thus. O my dear mother Albuina, I never in all my life
believed or trusted unstable fortune, although there have been many peaces and
leagues made betwyxt her and our house. For if at a time the trayteresse
consented that for a space I should be quiet and at rest, she did it not of
good will she had to leave to pursue me, but to geeue me a more cloked
security. For when she sees we think our selves assured, then with al her
force and fury she gives us the assault, as if she came to assault ye
enemies camp. And I tell thee further yet (good mother) yt all the good she
wrought in me, and the honor she heaped on me, and all the faculties and
abundance of riches she brought to my house, she told me she gave me
them freely, but I always answered her I did accept them in way of impressed,
and not of gift. Her promises therefore she offered me, ye honor she laid
upon me, and ye riches she gave me, she laid the^ up in such a corner of my
house, yt either by day or by night she might at her pleasure when she would
take them al from me, without yt she should trouble at al therefore my
judgment, or yt she should sorrow my heart awhit. And because thou shooldst
know how I did esteem of fortune, I tell thee, yt I ever thought it good never
to let any thing come wtin me, nor into my heart, but only near unto me: and
so I was contented to esteem it, and keep it under good safty, but not that I
therefore applied and gave all my affection and mind to yt: I was glad to have
fortune my friend, but if I lost her, I was never sorry for her. Finally I
conclude, that when she came to assault me and to rob my house, she might
well convey all that was put in the arc, but not that she could ever carry
away ye least sigh of my heart. They say yt king Phillip father of Alexander the
great being advertised of three great victories happened in sundry places to
his army, kneeled down on both his knees, and holding his hands up to ye
heavens said. O cruel fortune, O merciful gods, O my good luck, I beseech you
most humbly, that after so great a glory and victory as this, you have hitherto
geeuen me: you will moderate your correction and punishment, which after this
I look for that you will geeue me, that you punish me with pyty, and not with
utter destruction and ruyn. And yet he added this further to his words. Not
without cause I conjure thee O fortune, and do beeseech you immortal gods,
that you will punish me favorably, but not to undo me: because I am assured,
that overmuch felicity and prosperyty of this life, is no more but a prediction
and presage of a great calamity and ill ensuyng hap. Truly all the examples
above recited are worthy to be noted, and to be kept always before the eyes
of our mind, since by them we come to know, that in the prosperity of this our
thrawled life there is little to hope for, and much to be afraid of. It is true
we are very frail by nature, since we are borne frail, we live frayl, and
daily we fall into a thousand fraylties: but yet notwithstanding we are not
so frayl, but we may if we will resist vice. And all this comes only,
because one sort of people follows an other, but one reason seeldome follows
an other. If we fall, if we stomble, if we be sick, if we break our face,
are we suer (that serving as we do ye world) that the world will recure and
remedy us? No sure, it is not so. For the remedy the world is wont to geeue to
our troubles, is ever notwithstanding greater trouble then the first, So that
they are like to searing yrons, that burn ye flesh and heal not the wound. For
the world is full of guile and disceyt, and subtle to deciue, but very slow to
geeue us remedy. And this we see plainly. For if it persuade us to revenge any
injury received, it does it only in revenging of that, to make us receive a
thousand other injuries. And if sometimes we think we receive some comfort of
the world, of our payns and troubles of ye body, it afterward over lodeth our
mynds, with a sea of thoughts and cogitacions: So that this accursed and
flattering world makes us believe, and persuades us the right and perfyt way,
and in the end we are cast unawares into the nets of all wickedness, privily
laid to snare us. How great so ever a man be in favor with the king, how noble
of blood, how fine of wit, and how ware so ever he be, let every man be
assured that practices in the world, he shall in the end be deceived by him.
For he costeth us very dear, and we sell our selves to him good cheap. I
told you but little, to tell you we sold our selves good cheap, for I should
have said better, in saying we have geeuen our selves in pray wholly to him,
without receiving any other recompense. And in deed they are very few, and
rare, that have any reward of him: and infinite are they that serve him, without
any other recompense, more then a foolish and vayn hope. O traiterous world, in
how short a time do thou receive us, and afterward with a glimse of an eye
sodeinly do put us from thee, thou gladdest and make us sorofull, thou
call us to honor and abasest us, thou punishest us, and do us a thousand
pleasures. And finally I say thou do make us so vile, and poysonest us with
thy vile labors, that without thee, we are yet ever with thee: and yt that
greeues us woorst of all is, that having the thief in the house, we go out
of the house to geeue him place, and make him owner. When the world knows one
once that is proud and presumptuous, he procures him honor: to another that
is covetous, riches, to an other that is a glutton, good meats: to an other
that is carnal, the commodity of women: to an other that is idle, quiet and
ease: and all this does the traterous world, to the end that after as fysh
whom he has fed, he may lose the net of sin upon us to catch us in. If we
would resist the first temptacions ye world offers us, it is impossyble he
durst so many times assault us. For to say truly by our small resistaunce,
increases his over great audacity. I woold these lovers of this world woold
but tell me a little, what reward or what hope they can hope of him, why they
should suffer so many incombers broiles and troubles as they do. To think the
world can geeue us perpetual life, it is a mockry, and extreme madness to hope
of it. For we see when life is most dear to us, and that we are lothest to
leave the world, then ariueth death in an unhappy hour to swallow us up, and
to deprive us of all this worldly felicity. To hope that the world will geeue
us assured mirth, this is also a madness. For the days excepted we must lament,
and the due hours allotted out to co^plain, alas we shall see a small surplus
of time left, to laugh and be meery. I can say no more, but exhort every man
to look well about him what he does, and that he be advised what he
thinks. For when we thynk, and believe we have made peace with fortune,
even then is she in battle against us. And I do assuredly believe, that that
I now prepare my self to speak even presently, shall be read of many, but
observed of few: and that is, that I have seen those come out of their own
propre houses, moorning and lamenting that had spent and consumed all their
time in laughing and making good cheer, and serving this miserable world.
Which is but only a geeuer of al euels, a ruyn of the good, a heap of sin, a
tyrant of virtues, a traitor of peace and war, a sweet water of errors, a
river of vices, a persecutor of the virtuous, a comb of lies, a deviser of
novelties, a grave of the ignorant, a cloak of the wicked, an oven of lechery,
and finally a Caribdis, where all good and noble hearts do perish, and a right
Silla, where all noble desires and thoughts are cast away togeethers. For it is
most certain, that this worldling, that is not content with this world, and
that leaves his first state, and that takes upon him a new manner of life,
and changes from house to house, and country to country: he shall never
notwithstanding content him self, nor quiet his mind. And the cause hereof is,
that if a worldling depart out of his house, never to come again into it: there
are yet at hand immediately other ten licentious persons, that do but watch
to enter into his house. Speaking more particulerly I say, that in the court of
princes they account them happy, and fortunat, that be in favor with the
prince, yt have great affairs in court, that be rich and of power, that be
served and honored of every man, and that take place and go before every man.
So that it may be said, that the common people do not call those fortunat,
that deserve to be fortunate: but only those that have enough. But the
ancient philosophers were not of this mind, and much less are the wise men
and virtuous men at this day: For we see that in the court of princes many
rather lack favor, then life: and others lack both favor, and life togethers:
and others not only their life and favor, but also all their goods and
faculties. So that, all that that their favor and credit have geeuen them in
many years and by sundry greefes and troubles, they come afterward to lose
them even upon a sodeyn, and in short time. I grant notwithstanding that it
is a great honor, profyt, and furtheraunce, for the courtier to be in his
princes favor, but nevertheless he cannot deny me, but that it is a dangerous
thing also. For naturally a great famyliarity, brings also a great envy with
yt, sith the beloved of the prince is commonly ill willed of the common weal.
And that, that is yet most dangerous is, that to obtayn the savor of his
prince, he must so behave him self, yt his service must be more rare, better,
and exquysite, then all others: and otherwise, to fall in disgrace, and to make
the prince forget all the good service he has done him his whole life time,
he need but the least displeasure and fault he can commit. Eusenides was
maruelously beloved with Tolomey, who after fortune had exalted and brought him
to honor, and that he was grown to great wealth, said one day to Cuspides the
philosopher these words. O my friend Cuspides tell me I pray thee, of thy
faith, is there any cause in me to be sad, sith fortune has placed me in so
great autoryty and honor, as she can devise to do, and that the kynk Tolomey
my lord has now no more to geeue me, he has already been so bountyfull to
me? To whom the philosopher answered, saying. O Eusenides, if thou were a
philosopher, as thou art a beeloued servant, thou would tell me an other
tale, then that thou tellest me now. For although king Tolomey has no more to
geeue thee, know not thou that spyghtfull fortune has power to take away
from thee many things? For the noble heart feels more grief, and
displeasure, to come down one staire, or step, then to clymme up a hundred. Not
many days after these words passed between Cuspides, and Eusenides, yt
happened that one day King Tolomey found Eusenides talkyng with aleman or
curtesan of his wc he loved dearly, whereat he was so much offended, yt he
made her straight drink a cup of poison, and caused him to be hanged before
his own gates. The emperor Seuerus had one in so great favor and credit which
was called Plautius, and he loved him so extremely, and trusted him so much,
that he never read letter, but Plautius must read it, and he never granted
commissyon or license to any man, but it must pass under Plautius seal:
neither did he ever grant any thing, but at the request of Plautius, nor did
make wars or peace, without the counsel and advice of Plautius. The matter
fell out so, that Plautius entering one night into the emperors chamber armed
with a privy cote, his ill hap was such, that a little of his breast before was
open, whereby was spyed the mayle, which Bahhian seeing, being the emperors
eldest son said unto him these words. Tell me Plautius, do those that are
the beloved of princes use to come into their bed chamber at these hours,
armed with Iron coat? I swear to thee by the Immortal gods, and let them so
preserve me in the succession of the Empire, that sith thou come armed with
Iron, thou shall also dye with Iron. Which presently took place. For before
he went out of the chamber, they struck of his head. The Emperor Comodus (that
was son of the good Emperor Marcus Aurelius) had a servant called Cleander,
a wise and grave man, old, and very pollytyck: but with all a little covetous.
This Cleander was often times requested of the pretoryne compaigny, that is to
say of the whole band of soldiers, that he woold command they might be
paid their pay dew to them: and to persuade him the better to pay it, they
showed him a bill signed from the Emperor, to which bill he answered. That ye
emperor had nothing to do in the matter. For although he were lord of Rome,
yet had he not to deal in the affairs of the common weal. These
discourteous, and unseemly words related to the emperor Comodus, and
perceiving the small obedyence and respect of duty that Cleander showed to him,
he commanded forth with he should be slain to his great shame, and that
all his goods should be confiscat. Alcimenides was a great renoumed king among
thee Greeks, as Plutark writes of him, and he favored one Pannonius entierly
well, to whom only he did not commit his person, his trust, but also the whole
affairs and doings of ye the common weal, and he might dispose of the goods
of the king, at his will and pleasure, without leave or license. So that all the
subjects found, they had more benefit in serving of Pannonius then in pleasyng
of the King. Therefore the king and the beloved Pannonius playing at the balle
togethers, they came to contend upon a chase, and the one said it was thus,
the other said it was contrary, and as they were in this contention, the king
commanded presently those of his guard, that in the very place of the chase
where Pannonius denied, they should strike of his head. Constantius the Emperor
also had one whom he lyked very well, and made much of, called Hortentius, wc
in deed might well be counted a princes derling, for he did not only rule
the affairs of the common weal, of the palace, of wars, his goods, and
person of the emperor: but also he was ever placed above all the Imbassatours
at his table. And when the emperor went in progress, or any other iorny, he
ever had him to his bedfellow. Thus things being in this state, I tell you, it
happened that one day a page geeuing the emperor drink in a glass, the glass
by myshap fell out of the pages hand and brake in pieces, whereat ye emperor
was not a little displeased and offended. And even in this evil and unhappy
hour came Hortentius to the King to present him certain bylles to sign of
hasty dyspatch (which was a very unapt time chosen) and the emperor contented
yet to sign yt, could neither the first nor the second time, because the pen
was ill fauordly made, and the ink so thyck that yt would not write: which made
the king so angry, that even presently for anger he commanded Hortensius head
to be stricken of. But to the end we may come to the knowledge of many things
in few words, I will show you how Alexander the great slew in his choler his
dear accounted Cratherus, and Pirrhus King of the Epirotes, Fabatus his
secretory. The Emperor Bitillion his greatest friend Cincinatus. Domitian the
emperor, Rufus of his chamber. Adrian the Emperor his only favored Ampromae,
Dioclesian his friend Patritius, whom he loved as him self, and always called
him friend and compaignion. Diadumeus, Pamphilion his great treasorer. For whose
death he was so sorrowful, that he would have made him self away, because
he caused him to be so cruelly slain. All these above named, and infynyt
others also, some were masters, some lords, some kings, and some of great
authority and favor about princes, by whose tragical histories and examples we
may plainly see, that they did not only lose their goods, favor and credit,
but also upon very light occasions were put to death by sweord. Therefore
mortal men should put no trust in worldly things, sith that of little occasion
they become soon great, and of much less they sodeinly fall, and come to
worse estate then before. And therefore king Demetrius askyng one day
Euripides ye philosopher, what he thought of humayn debility, and of the
shortness of this life answered. Me thinks O King Demetrius, that there is
nothing certain nor suer in this unstable life: sith all men living, and al
things also that serves them, endure daily some clipse: and hereunto replied
suddenly Demetrius and said. O my good Euripides, thou had said better that
all things vegitiue, and sensitive, and each other living thing does not only
feel the eclipses efforce, and change from day to day, but from hour to
hour, and minute to minute. Meaning king Demetrius by these words he spoke,
that there is nothing so stable in this world, be it of what state or condition
yt will be, but in a twyinkling of an eye, is ready to run into a thousand
dangers and perils: and albeit we be all subject (of what state or degree so
ever we be) to sundry and diverse thrales, and mishaps, yet none are so near
neighbors to them, as those that are in highest authority, and greatest favor
with princes. For there are many that shoots to hit down the white of their
favor, but few that (being down) will once put it up again and restore yt to
his place. For to live a contented life, a man had need to want nothing:
neither to have any occasion to trouble him. But ye things that trouble us in
this vale of misery, being so many and of such abundance, and those things
contrarily so few, and rare to come by, that we need and want: we may justly
account this life woeful, and miserable above all others. For sure far
greater are the greeues and dyspleasures we receive, for one only thing we
want: then the pleasures are great we have for a hundredth others, whereof we
have abundance. Besides that, the familiars of princes cannot think them
selves so mighty and fortunat, that any man may presume to call them blessed or
happy. For if some serve and honor them, others there are that persecute them,
and if in their houses they have that flatter them, and make much of them,
there want not in the court others that murmur at them, and speak ill of them.
And if they have cause some times to rejoice that they are in favor: so have
they likewise continual trouble and fear that they shall fall, and be put out
of favor: And if they glory to have great treasure, they sorrow also to have
many enemies. And if the services and company they have do delight them, the
continual buysines they have do vex them: So that we may say of the^, as of
plaistering of houses, which are never so fair, but they become black with
some spot in time, and woormes and other vermin do eat and wast them. If there
be none that dare once admonish these great men in authority, and tell them
their faults by word of mouth: yet I will take upon me to do yt with my
writing, and say, that they speak nothing but it is noted, their steps they
tread are seen, every morsel of meat they eat is marked, they are accused for
the pleasures they take, and all things that they have are observed, All the
pleasures that is done them is regystred, and all ill that that they know by
them is published: And finally I conclude, that the favored of princes, are a
game at tables, whereat every man plays: not with dyce, nor cards, but only
with serpents tongues. And therefore I have said it, and once again I return
to say: That all those that are accepted of princes must live contynually very
wisely, and aduysedly in all their dooyngs, for it is true, and too true, that
every man's tongue runs of them, and much more if they had time and
opportunity, like as they defame them with their tongues, so would they offend
them with their hands. We do not speak this so much that they should look to
defend their life: but to foresee that they may preserve their honor, and goods
from peril, and to geeue them by this precept a good occasion to look about
them. For to put them in disgrace with the King, all the days of their life
(to their utter vndooyng and overthrow) the king need but only geeue ear to
his enemies.

The aucthor admonishes those that are in favor, and great with the prince,
that they take heed of the deceipts of the world, and learn to live, and dye
honorably, and that they leave the court before age overtake them. Cap. xvi.
When king Alderick kept Seuerine the Romayn consul prisoner, otherwise named
Boethius: that consul complained much of fortune. Saying alas fortune, why have
thou forsaken me in my age, since thou dyddest favor me so much in mine
youth, and that I had served thee so many years, why have thou left me to the
hands of mine enemies. To which complaynts fortune made answer thus. Thou art
unthankful to me O Seuerius, since I have used my things with thee in such
manner, as I never used the like with any other Romayn. And that this is true I
tell thee. Consider, O Seuerius, that I made thee whole, and not sick: a man
and no woman: of excellent wit and understanding, and not gross and rude: rych
and not poor: wise, and not foolysh: free, and not bond: a Senator, and no
plebeyan: noble and valiant, and not cowardly: a Romayn, and no barbarus, or
stranger born: in great, and not mean estate: a grave man, and no light nor
vayn person: fortunat, and not unlucky: worthy of fame, and not obliuyon: to
conclude I say, I gave thee such part in the common weal, that thou had good
cause to have pyty of all others, and all others cause to have spite and envy
at thee. Again replied Seuerius to this answer and said. O cruel and
spightfull fortune, how liberal thou art in the things thou speak, and
resolute in the things thou disposest, since always thou do what thou will
and seldom that thou oughtst. And thou know there is no such myshap, as to
remember a man has once been rich, and fortunat in his time: and to see him
self now brought to extreme mysery. Hear fortune thou oughtst to know yt, if
thou know yt not, that he that never was rich, scant knows his poverty.
But alas for pyty, he that was rych, and had once all pleasures and ease,
does sorrow much for the present extreamyty and bewayleth the forepassed
felycity. And I tell thee also, and thou oughtst to believe me, that we
repute them more happy who^ thou never exaltest nor gave honor to: then we
do those whom thou have called to high honor, and afterward have ouerthrown
them, and brought them lower, and in worse state then before. And as for me,
O fortune, I tell thee truly, I think no man fortunat, but him that never knew
what good fortune meant. And this was the discourse betwixt fortune and the
consul Seuerius. By which we may perceive and comprehend, that truly none may
be thought unfortunate and miserable, but such as have been before in great
honor and reputacion: and he cannot be thought abased of his state, or
countenance, if he were not before in prosperity, and favored of fortune. So
that we may well say, that never no man in this world was so free, as he that
never suffered fortune to enter into his gates. I have been desirous to tell
you of these things, because that such as are in favor and credyt with princes,
should not reckon too much of their favor: neither that those that are not in
favor with them, should be sorry for it a whyt. For the great aucthority and
credyt that a man has by the court, is in this mortal life in the end nothing
else, then as a little woorme in an appell, a wyuell in the corn, and a maggot
in pease: which without seem very good, and within they are all rotten and
eaten. Princes aucthority above all others is most supreme, for they are not
subject to the Censors and judges, to reprove them of their words and
sayings, neither to magistrates, to whom they shoold render any account of
their doings, whereof proceeds, that as they have free will to love, so have
they a free liberty to hate, and absolute power to punysh. Therefore those
that are in favor in court, and that shall read these writings of mine, must
well consider what we mean by all those things we have spoken: whereby they
shall easily know, that princes are no less apt to hate him to day they loved
yesterday: then to love him to morrow, whom they hated ye other day. The first
and cheifest thing the courtier ought to have, is to fear god, and to follow
the profession of a good christyan. For in thend they live in court with more
safty, having a good and pure conscience: then with all the great credit and
favor they can have. And therefore let every courtyer believe me, as well in
favor as out of favor, that it is the best and surest way to get the goods of
this world, as also for the preseruacion of their souls, to esteem and make
account of the scriptures and gods commandments. And if he do otherwise, it
shall happen many times unto him, that in the dispatch of his weightyest
affairs, and needful business, even when he thynks his matter brought to a
good end, and that it is without al doubt of dyspatch: then steps in crooked
fortune with her wonted poison against him and either makes him in manner
beegynne his suyt anew again, or at least utterly overthrows yt quite. For
there are in princes courts many times certain suytes, that have a good and
better end then looked for: and contraryly many others that are at the point of
dispatchyng, and yet by synister accident clean ouerthrown, and succeding
contrary to their assured expectacion. And yet notwithstanding it seems to
the suter, that ye cause hereof comes, either through the soliciters
negligence and default, and little care to follow it, or else through the malice
and ill will of the favored of the court, that took upon him the suite: and
yet neither the one, nor the other was cause of the disorder, but only the
divine prouydence of God, to admonish us that in all our actions and doings it
little preuayleth us to move the king or his officers in all our matters, if
we do not deserve at gods hands to obtein it. And therefore said the divine
Plato in his Timeon, that these that have honor and prosperity in this life,
have as much need of good counsel, as the poor afflicted creatures have, of
help and remedy.

And surely it was wisely and profoundly spoken of him. For as need and misery
in this wretched life brings men to despair: So likewise we see prosperity
induce men, to forgett them selves, and their state. And that that I have
hitherto spoken of, and that I hope yet to speak: none can understand nor
conceive, but such as once in their time, in their navigations had a fortunat
and lucky wynd, and afterward turnyng contrary, even at shore side have cast
them on rocks, and utterly perished them. To thend that those in readyng these
my writings, may yet lament and moorne for pity: where the other can but only
read, and go no further. If we compare and put togeether the rych with the
poor, the sorrowful with the merry, the fortunat with the unfortunate, the
favored with the banyshed, the virtuous and noble, with the vycious and
defamed: we shall find without doubt the number of those far greater, that
coold rise again being down, and had taken a fall: then those that coold keep
them selves in the aucthority and favor, that fortune had brought them to. I
have not said it a few times, but every moment I woold return to say it again,
that this traiterous world in all his doings is so deceiptfull, and Fortune in
all that she promyseth so doubtful, that they make them believe whom they
make rych, beloved, and raise to high estate, that they do it but to honor
them: and afterward contraryly they spinne a thousand deceypts and trumpryes,
to make them sooner fall to the ground. Surely I have seen but few, and I
remember I have read of none, to whom Fortune ever showed herself so benygne
and courteous, that ever putt a man in his cheifest topp of prosperity and
favor, but in few days after she took his life from him, or at least in ye
end of his journey she made him run into some secret disgrace or mishap. And
therefore I woold that the courtier that obtains favor in the court, and
riches in the common wealth, that he shoold reckon and esteem them as lent
him, not geeuen him, and that he shoold so govern the things of fortune, as
he woold that man, whom he trusted not at all. For as Seneca says. No man is
afficted with fortune, but he only yt trusted to her, without fear or suspect
at all of her. For courtiers and those that are in great favor and auctority
ought to know, that like as in the deepest seas, soonest perish the ships:
and as in the highest mountains the Sun has always least force and power,
and as in the greenest bows is soonest hidd the fowlers little nett, to katch
the sely byrds: And as with the fullest bayts of meat the fish are soonest
taken, and that with great force the wynd does blow on highest trees, and as
the most proud and stately buyldings, the earthquake does most hurt, and
soonest overthrow them: even so by this I mean, that Fortune never strove to
throw down any, but such as she had made great in honor and favor. For I do
not take yt for no great good luck, (though all things succeed to be favored
of the court better then he looked for) nor to see them brought by their
friends, to great estate and honor. For albeeit fortune for a time dyssemble
with him, it is not for that she has forgotten him, but afterward to geeue
him a greater punishment. Those that will marvel at that I will speak even
now, it proceeds of nothing else, but wantyng wit, and capacity to understand
yt. There is no greter sickness in this world, then to be in health: No greater
poverty, then never to have need of any thing. And there is no greater
temptation, then to be never tempted: Nor there can be no greater sadness,
then to be always merry: Nor greater danger, then never to be in danger. For
many times it so happens, that where a man thinks to pass over a
dangerous flood safe enough, his horse falls over head and ears, and
drowneth his master, or he escapes hardly.

Socrates being one day demanded which was the most sure and certain thing of
this life: answered thus. There is nothing more certain in this life, then to
account all things uncertain he has: nor among riches any greater, then to
have life and health: But if the life be doubtful and unquiet, what surety or
certeinty may be found in it? Surely none. King Agesilaus being requested of
certain of his Grecian captains, to go see the Olimpiade in mount Olimpus,
where all the Philosophers did assemble to dispute, and where all the rich men
of the country came to bye and sell any thing, he answered them. If in mount
Olimpus they sold and exchaunged sorrow for mirth, sycknes for health, honor for
infamy, and life for death, I woold not only go to see yt, but I woold also
spend all that I am worth, and that I have: But since the byer is mortal, and
the thing also he byeth condemned to death, I will buy nothing in this life,
since I cannot carry yt with me into my grave. Yet is there an other deceit
which the poor courtiers falls into daily, and that is: that in living many
years, they thynk and assuredly believe in thend to light of a time, when they
hope to have ease and rest, which is a mockry to thynk it, and an extreme
madness to hope for yt. For if their years grow by ownce and ownce, their sorows
and troubles increase by pounds. Who can deny, but that mylk that is kept many
days does corrupt and becomes sharp and sower? Yea the garments that are now
very old, and have been long worn, (without that ever moth did touch it)
does in the end also become rags and dust. By this therefore I do infer,
that if it be a most certain thing for young men to dye quicly, much more
shoold old men be assured that they have no long time to live. And there are
many in the court of Princes also, that find them selves so laden with sins
and wickedness, that they think assuredly, that in changing their age, time, and
fortune, they shall not only leave their vices, but shall be discharged also of
many greeues and troubles. Which we see afterward happen contrary to them.
For there is no way so plain in this world, but there is some ascent or descent
for us to go up to the top, or some river for us to pass over, or some
terrible mountayn to fear, or some crooked ill favored way to lose us in, or
some cave or hole to fall into. Those also that thynk certeynly that the sun
cannot lose his light, nor that the moon can be Eclipsed, nor that the
stars may be darkened, and that the earth shall not cease to bring forth,
the seas to flow, the water to run, the fire to burn, and winter to be
cold, let them also be assured, that man cannot be excused to suffer and
abide much. For sure it is impossible he shoold pass one day without some
trouble or sinister happ of Fortune. And the greatest trompery and deceit that
courtiers for the most part are abused in, is, that the more they wax in years,
the more they enter daily into greater affairs and business: with a vayn hope
and assurance they have to dispatch them, and bring them to such end, as they
list or desire. But afterward when they come to look into their matters, it
is the will of god, and their deserts do procure it, that the poor old men
find (when they think to go home to their houses) that they see death approach
near them, and they afterward are carried to be buried in their graves.

O how many are there in court that beecome aged men, by long serving in court,
with a vayn hope afterward in their age to depart from the court, and to
repose their aged years in their own houses, in quiet and tranquillity, which
abuses them very much: So that they may be called Christians in name, and
thoughts, but right wordlings and courtiers in doings. And therefore many
times I reproved diverse old courtiers my friends, for that they did not leave
the court when they might have left it, with honor, and commodity: tellyng them
it was more then time now they shoold depart from the court, since age had
stolen upon them. Which coold not tell how to answer me, nor what to say,
more then that they woold within a short time go home to their houses, with
deliberation and intent to take their ease at home, for the better health of
their persons, which they had not till then: and so to seclude them from all
doings, save only in the morning when he ryseth, to go to the church and
serve god, and from thence to go to the hospitalles, to visit the sick and
diseased, to seek out the poor orphans and wydows amongst his neighbors, to
make peace between neyghbor and neyghbor, and to relieve the poor. And
albeeit they have told me this tale many a time and often, yet I never saw any
of them put it in execution with good will. And I saw once an honorable and
rich courtier, that was so old, that for very age he had never a black hear on
his head, nor any teeth in his mouth, neither any children, sons, or
daughters to inherit his goods, who notwithstanding was of so foolysh and
fantastical oppinion (brought to that madness by his sins) that he swear to
me, that for discharge of his conscience only he woold never leave or geeue
up his office he hadd in court, to change that servile trade of life for
quiet rest at home. Thinking assuredly, that enjoying rest at home in his own
house, he might easily be damned, and abiding the payns and service of court,
he believed undoubtedly he shoold be saved. Surely we may aptly say, that
this old courtier was more then a dotard, and that he had mard the call of his
conscyens, since he believed it was a charge of conscience to depart the court.

The a^bition to do much, and the covetousness to have much, makes ye
miserable courtiers believe that they have yet time enough to live, and to
repent them when they will. So that in the court, thinking to live two years
only in their age good men, they live fifty and three score years wicked and
naughty persons. Plutarch in his Apothegmes says, that Eudonius, that was
Captain of the Greeks, seeing Xenocrates reading one day in the university of
Athens, he being not of thage of eyghty five years, asked what that old man
was: and it was answered him, that it was one of the philosophers of Greece,
who followed virtue and serched to know wherein true philosophy consisted.
Whereupon he answered. If Xenocrates ye philosopher tell me, that he being
now eyghty five years old, goes to seek virtue in this age, I woold thou
shooldest also tell me what time he shoold have left him to be virtuous. And
he said more over, in those years that this philosopher is of, it were more
reason we shoold see him do virtuous things, tha^ at this age to go and
seek it. Truly we may say the very like of our new courtier, that Eudonius
said of Xenocrates the philosopher, the which if he did look for other three
score years, or three score years and ten to be good, what time shoold
remain for him to prove and show that goodness. It is no marvel at al, that ye
old courtiers forget their native country and bringing up, their fathers that
begat them, their friends that showed the^ favor, and the servants that served
them: but at that yt I do not only wonder at the^, but also it geeueth me
cause to suspect them, is, that I see they forget them selves. So that they
never know nor consider that they have to do, till they come afterward to
be, that they woold not be. If the courtiers, wc in princes courts have been
rich, noble, and in auctority, woold counsel with me, or at least believe my
writing, they shoold depart from thence in time, to have a long time to
consider before of death, least death unawares and sodeinly came to take
execution of their lives. O happy and thrice happy may we call ye esteemed
courtier, whom god has geeuen so much wit and knowledge to, that of him self
he do depart from ye court, before fortune has once touched him wc dishonor,
or laid her cruel hands upon him. For I never saw courtier but in the end did
complain of ye court, and of their ill life that they lead in court. And yet
did I never know any person yt woold leave it for any scruple of conscience he
had to remain there, but peradventure if any did depart from ye court, it was
for some of these respects or altogether, that is to say. Either that his favor
and credit diminished, or that his money failed him, or that some has done him
displeasure in the court, or that he was driven from the court, or that he
was denied favor, or that his side and faction he held with, had a fall, or for
yt he was sick, to get his health, he went into ye country. So that they may
say he rather went angry and displeased with him self, then he did to lament
his sins. If you ask pryuatly every courtier, you shall find none but will say
he is discontented with the court, either because he is poor, or afflicted,
enuyed or ill willed, or out of favor, and he will swear and reswere again that
he desires nothing more in the world, then to be dismissed of this courtiers
travel and painful life. But if afterward perchance a little wynd of favor
be put stirring in the entry of his cha^berdore, it wilsodeinly blow away all the good and former thoughts from his mind. And yet that, that makes me wonder
more at these unconstant courtiers and unstable brains, is, that I see many
buyld goodly stately houses in their country, and yet they neither dwell in
them, nor keep hospitality there. They graffe and set trees, plant fruits, and
make good gardens, and ortchyards and yet never go to enjoy them: they puchase
great lands and possessions, and never go to see them. And they have offices
and dignities geeuen them in their countries, but they never go to exercise
them. There they have their friends and parents, and yet they never go to talk
with them. So that they had rather be slaves and drudges in the court, then
lords and rulers in their own country. We may justly say that many courtiers
are poor in riches, strangers in their own houses, and pilgrims in their own
country, and banyshed from all their kinreds. So that if we see the most part
of these courtiers, bakbyte, murmr, complayn, and abhor these vices they
see daily committed in court. I dare assure you that this discontentation and
dyslyking proceeds not only of these vices and errors they see committed, as of
the spite and envy they have daily, to see their enemies grow in favor and
credit with the prince. For they pass little of the vices of court, so they may
be in favor as others are. Plutarch in his book de exilio shows, that there
was a law amongst the Thebans, that after a man was fyfty years of age, if he
fell sick, he shoold not be helped with physicians. For they say that after a
man is once aryued to that age, he shoold desire to live no longer, but rather
to have to his journeys end. By these examples we may know that infancy is till
vii. years. Childhood to.xiiii. years: youth, to xxv. years: manhod till.xl.
and age, to three score years. But once passed three score, me think it is
rather time to make clean the nets and to content themselves with ye fish they
have til now, then to go about to put their nets in order again to fish any
more. I grant that in the court of princes all may be saved, and yet no man
can deny me, but that in princes courts there are mo occasions to be damned
then saved. For as Cato the Censor says, the apt occasions bring men a desire
to do ill, though they be good of them selves. And although some do take
upon them and determyne to lead a godly and holy life, or that they show
themselves great hipocrits, yet am I assured notwithstanding that they cannot
keep their tongue from murmuring, nor their heart from envying. And the cause
hereof proceeds, for that there are very few that follow the court long, but
only to enter into credit, and afterward to wax rich, and grow in great
aucthority. Which cannot be without hearing a little secret hate and envy
against those, that do pass them in this favor and auctority, and without
suspect and fear of others, which in this are their equals and companions. It
were a good counsel for those that have lived in ye court of princes til they
be grown old and gray headed, that they shoold determine and live ye rest of
their years as good christians, and not to pass them as courtiers, so that
though they have given ye world the meal, yet they shoold in thend geeue the
bran to Jesus Christ. I know every man desires to live in princes courtz, and
yet they promise they will not dye in court. And since it is so, me thinks it
is a great folly and presu^ption for such men to desire to live long in such
state, where they woold not die for all ye gold in ye world. I have lived in
court many years, and at this present I have forsaken it quite: wherefore I dare
boldly sai, that if once a man come to enjoy a quiet life and reposed rest, I
am assured he woold for ever hate and dislike to be a courtier longer. But
alas, like as these se^celes courtiers remember not the life to come, but only
account of their vain and courtly life present, reputing that the most blessed
and happy of any other: So god seeing their folly and fond addicted mind to the
vanity of court, to plague them with all, and scourge them with their own rodd,
does grant them no other nor better rest, then that they only enjoy in
princes court, and so feeds them with their own humor. And therefore it is
truly said. That rest and contentation never enters into a sinners house. O
you worthy and noble courtiers, O you beloved, and favored courtiers, I will
remember you, yea and again remember you, that you presume not to cut or pull
of ye wings of time, since you neither shall have time nor mean to pluck one
fether from him: much less the least knowledge how to do it. And therefore it
is said. Ill cutteth the knife if the edge be broken: and ill can he gnaw
bones that lacks his teeth. And if it seem good unto you and me also, that
to day it is time to gather the fruit of the vine of our youth, let us go now
again to seek it about by the means of our amendment. And if the pype or
caske wherein we shoold put our wine be fusty, with the malignity and
perverseness of our wicked doings: Let us season them with new and better wine
of good and holy desires. And now to conclude if to sequester them selves from
court, it be a holsom counsel for courtiers: much more wholesome and necessary
it is for such as bear sway and reputation about the prince. For other
courtiers daily live in hope to enlarge their countenance, and credit, and to
grow into favor and auctority: but these darlings, and belyked of princes, are
continually afraid to fall, and utterly to be put out of favor.

Of the continency of favored courtiers, and how they ought to shonne the
company and conversation of dishonest women, and to be careful quickly to
dispatch all such as sue unto them. Cap. xvii.
TItus Liuius and Plutarch writes, that the Romans had in such veneration
those men that lived chaste, and those weomen also that professed virgins life,
that they erected statures of them in the senate house, carrying them thorough
the city in tryumphant chariots, recommending them selves to their devout
prayers, and geeuing them great gifts and presents: and finally adored them as
gods. And this was their reason in that they honored them as gods: for that
they being of flesh, and living in flesh, did leave to use the woorks and
instinct of the flesh: which they held a thing more divine then humayn,
Filostratus says, that Appolonius Thianeus was borne without any pain or grief
to his mother in all her travel. And that the gods spoke to him in his ear,
that he raised the dead to life, healed the sick, knew the thoughts of men,
diuined of things to come, how he was served with princes, honored of the
people, and followed of all the philosophers: and yet they did not make so great
a wonder of all these things spoken of him, as they did for that he was never
married, and more over never detected with the knowledge of any woman living,
much less suspected. Whilst Carthage was environed with seege one each side,
a virgin of Numidia taken prisoner, was presented to Scipio, and she was very
fair: which Scipio notwithstanding woold not only not deflower, but set her at
lyberty, and married her very honorably. Which act of his was more apprised of
the romayn writers, the^ was his conquest of Numidia, the restoring of Rome her
liberty, the destruction of Charthage, the socour and relife geeuen to Asia,
and the enobling of his common wealth. For in all these enterprises, he still
fought against others: but in the effects of the flesh, he fought against him
self. And therefore he must needs be marvelous wise and of good judgment, that
can subdew the desiers and motions of the flesh. For we do as much covet to
follow these carnal desiers, as we are apt to our meat when we are a
hongred. Cruel and bitter are the assauts of the flesh to the spirit, and
wonderful is the pain the spirit abides, to resist the motions of the same,
which by no means can be overcome, but by eschewing the occasions thereof. As
in brideling the desires, punishing the flesh, living with spare diet,
incresing learning, geeuyng him self to tears, and all together shutting the
gates of our desires. O, if this vice of the flesh came of abou^dance of heat,
or rage of blood, we might soon remedy yt with letting our selves blood. If
it were by any sickness of the heart, yt should be cured by interior medecines:
If of the liver, we would refresh it with ointments. If of melancony humor,
we would wash away all the opilations. If of cholex, we would procure esy
purges. But alas it is a disease so far from pity, that it misliketh we
should call for physicians, and cannot abide we should offer it any remedy. It
cannot be denied but that civil war is most grievous and dangerous in a common
wealth: But much more perilous is that at home beetwixt the husband and the
wife: but most ieoperdious of all is, that a man has with him self. For we
cannot reckon any other our enymy, but our own desyers. I remember I saw once
written in a courtiers house these words, which truly deserved to be written
in golden letters: and the words were these.

The dreadful wars, that I alas sustain against my self, perforce my self
does strain where blind desire, becomes my mighty so the wreckfull gods,
vouch save it do not so. Surely he that wrote this for his word, me think
he was no fool, nor evil christian, sith he nether sought for money, nor by
slyght of wytt procured to deceive or begyle, nether he called his friends to
help him to withstand his enemies, but only craved remedy, against his dishonest
and vain desires. And undoubtedly he had reason. For a man may easily absent
him self from his enymys, but to fly from him self, it is an impossible
thing. And therefore me thinks it is a thing more to be lamented then written,
to see that a multitude of corporal enymes, cannot vanquish and overcome us:
and yet notwithstanding when we are alone, and think nothing of it, this only
vice of the flesh does not alone make us stumble, but fall down ryte on the
ground. For nether to become religious a priest, a friar, nor to dwell in
churches, nor to be shut up in cloisters, to sequester our selves from ye
world, nor to change state and condition: For all this I say, I see none of
all these things help us mortal me^, to defend us from this vice and sin,
But the further we seek to fly from yt, the more danger we find to fall in to
it. And albeit to avoid other vices and sins it shall suffice us to be
admonished: yet against that alone of the flesh, it behooves us to be armed.
For there is no sin in ye world but yt there are means for me^ to avoid it:
this only excepted of the flesh, where with all we are overcome, and taken
prisoners. And to prove this true it is aparant, thus. Where rayneth pride, but
amongst the potentates, where envy, but amongst equals? anger, but amongst the
impatient? glotony, but amongst gourmans: avarice, but amongst the rych?
slothe, but amongst the idle? And yet for all these the sin of the flesh
generally reigns in all men. And therefore, for not resisting this abominable
vice, we have seen Kings lose there Kyngdoms, noblemen there lands, and
possessions: the married wives their auowed faith: the religion nonnes, their
professed virginity: so that we may compare this sin, to the nature and
condition of the venomus serpent, which being alive stings us, and after he
is dead, offends us with his noisome stink. Examples by David, who for all
his wisdom could not preuayl against that sin: nor Solomon, for all his great
knowledge: nor Absolon for all his divine bewty: nor Sampson, with his mighty
force: which notwtstanding ye great fame they had for their renowned virtues:
yet thorough this only defect they lost al, acco^paniyng with harlots and
licencious weomen. Into wc shameful fellowship fell also, Holofernes, Annibal,
Ptholomeus, Pirrhus, Julius Caesar, Augustus, Marcus Antonius, Seuerus, and
Theodotius, and many other great princes, with these above recyted: the most
part of the which we have seen deprived of their crowns, and afterward them
selves have come (to their utter shame and dishonor) on their knees to yield
them selves to the mercy of these their infamed lovers, craving pardon and
forgeeuenes. Many grave writers of the Gretians say, yt the imbassadors of
Lidia coming one day into the chamber of Hercules, upon a sode in to speak
with him, they found him lying in his curtesans lap, she pulling his rings of
on his fyngers, he dressed on his head with her womenly attier: and she in
exchange on hers beedect with his royal crown. They write also of Denis ye
Siracusan, that albeeit of nature he was more cruel then the wild beast, yet
he beecame in the end so tractable, and pleasant, by the means of a curtisan
his friend called Mirta, yt she only did confirm all the provisions, and
depeches, of the affairs of the weal public, and he only did but ordein
and appoint them. And if the histories written of ye Goths deceive us not, we
find that Antenaricus the famous king of the Goths, after he had triumphed of
Italy, and that he had made himself lord of all Europe, he beecame so far
in love with a lover of his called Pincia^ that whilst she combo his head, he
made clean her slippers. Also Themistocles, the most famous captain of the
Greeks, was so enamored of a woman he had taken in the wars of Epirus, that
she being afterward very sick: when she purged her self, he woolde also
be purged with her: if she were let blood, he would also be let blood: and
yet that that is woorst to be lyked is, that he washed his face with yt blood
that came out of her arm, so yt they might truly say, though she were his
prisoner, yet he was also her slave and subject. When King Demetrius had taken
Rhodes, there was brought to him a fair gentlewoman of the cyty, which he
made his friend in love, and this love beetwixt them by time grew so great, yt
she showing her selue upon a time to be angry with Demetrius, and refusing to
sit nere him at ye table, and also to ly with him: Demetrius utterly forgetting
him self, and royal estate, did not only on his knees pray her to pardon him,
but also imbrasing her, co^ueighed her in his arms i^to his chamber. Myronides
the Gretian, albeeit he had made subject to him the Kingdom of Boetia, yet
was he notwithstanding made subject with ye love of Numidia his lover. He
enflamed thus with love of her, and she like wise stricken with covetous desire
of his goods, in fine they agreed, that he should geeue her all the spoil he
had won in the wars of Boetia: and yt she shoold let him lie with her in
her house, only one night. Annibal made wars seuenteen years with the
romans, and in all that time he was never vanquished, till that he was
overcome with the love of a young maiden in the City of Capua, which proved a
most bitter love to him, since thereby it happened, that where as he had so
many years kept in subjection all Italy, he now was made a subject at home in
his own country. Plutarke in his book De republica writes, that Phalaris the
tirant woold never grant a man any thing he desired, nether ever denied any
thing yt a dissolute woman requested. No small, but great disorder happened to
the common weal of Rome, by ye occasion of the Emperor Calligula, who gave but
6000. sexterces only to repair the walls of Rome: and gave otherwise for
surring one gown alone of his lemans, a 10000 sexterces. By all these examples
above resyted, we may easily understand, how dangerous a thing it is for the
courtier, to have friendship and acquaintance with weomen of so vyld a faculty.
For the woman is of like quality, that a knot tied of cords is: wc is easily
tied of sundry knots, and very hardly afterward to be undone again.
Heretofore we have beesought courtiers, and ye favored of princes, that they
shoold not be so liberal in commanding: and now once again we pray them to
be ware of fornication and adultry, for albeeit this sin of ye flesh be not
the greatest in faut, yet is it the most dangerous in fame. There is no King,
prelat, nor knight in this world so vicious, and dishonest of life, but woold
be glad to have honest, virtuous, and well condicioned servants, so that it is
impossible therefore for the favored courtier (living dishonestly) to continue
any long time in favor with his prince. For we have seen many in princes courts,
and commonweals also, yt have lost their honor, favor, and riches, not for
any pride they showed in the^ selves, nor for Enui yt they had, nor for any
treasure nor riches that they robbed, nor for any euel words yt they shoold
speak, neither for any treason that they committed: but only thorough ye evil
fame yt went of them for hau^ting the company of naughty weome^. For weomen be
of the right nature of hedgehogges, wc without seeing or knowing what they have
in their heart, do not wtstanding draw blood of us with their pricks. And let
not any man deceive him self, hoping yt if he do commit a fault thorough ye
flesh that it shallbee kept from the princes ears, or that it shall not be
blased abroad in the court. For this sin is of such a quality, that though it
may be hidden within curteins, yet it cannot be kept silent with tongues. How
wise and slye so ever a woman be, yet at all times when she geeueth ear unto
men's requests, even at that present she resolves to impart the whole with some
friend of hers. For these weomen do glory more, to be the friend of a courtier:
then to be a true wife unto their husbands. I have my self seen in princes
courts many weomen, very humble, courteous, piteful, pacient, charitable, wise,
devout, and otherwise marvelous honest, and yet amongst al these I never found
any one secret. And therefore that a man will have published to ye world, let
him hardly tell it a woman in great secret. I marvel how it shoold come to
pass, that we see daily weomen carry upon their heads a forest of hears, a
coyfe, a hood, gimmeus hanging at their ears, partless upon their shoulders,
smocks on their bodies, peticotes, gowns, kertels, hose, clokes, bardingales,
hattes, cheyns, braslets, ryngs, plumes of feathers in their hands, and many
other trinkets not named, all wc they carry lightly upon the^ and think it no
burden: and yet they cannot abide in no case to keep or carry one secret in
their breast. Alas what pity is it to see these affected courtiers, what means
they use to win a ladies favor, what pleasant purposes and discourse they put
forth unto them, what bitter sighs they let fall, what service they offer them,
what jewels they geeue the^, what castles in the air they promise the^, what
sorows they fayn, and what lies they make them believe: and these seely weomen
(by nature proud, and foolish) are wc a few gifts overcome, and with a few
flattering words beguyled. Now let this courtier and his lady continue this
mutual friendship between them, one, two, three, four, or five years, though
perhaps not fully these years complete neither many months also, and you shall
see in the end undoubtedly a marvelous breach, and hate beetwixt them. For this
amorus courtier, yt so dearly seemed to love his lady, will now make court a
fresh to others, and dislyke that heretofore he loved, and fly from her whom
erst he followed, abhorring yt he, once delyted in, mislyking the taste of
those meats that once were sweet and pleasant to him: and cannot abide her
face now, whose Image before he had ingraued in his mind. So if he before had
spent three years service in making her his mistress, he spe^deth now six other
years in ye forgetting of her. And therefore these noble courtiers, and beloved
of princes, must beware they make not these yo^g and dishonest loves common in
every place. For the sweet and fragrant rose wc they seek to gather,
continues scantly one hour: but ye pricks and plagues of the persing thorn,
rests hydden in their flesh, their whole life time after. A man erreth in
nothing more in this world, then in taking to his charge a dishonest woman. For
if he will bring her with him to ye court, she shall shame him, put him to an
unreasonable charge, besides ye burden of his conscience. And if afterward he
woold put her away from him, she will not depart for any thing: and if he
woold co^pel her to it, ere she depart it wilbee al ye court over: so what
things have past betwixt them two alone in secret, shall afterward be known
of every man abroad. And therefore we have not causeles told you, that it must
needs be a marvelous expense to ye courtier, to bring his lover with him to the
court. For he must always be at the charges to keep a page, maid or gentle
woman to weight upon her. He must content ye hostice of his house to lodge her
secretly, please ye marshal to seem not to know of it, the harbinger yt he
prepare him a good lodging, the page that he be dilligent, and at her hand:
and her self also must have to live with al, so yt the expe^ce and charge he
shall be at with her, must needs far exceed all the benefits and commodity
he has by court. Beesids that he may assure him self, that this their lewd
and fond love cannot long e^dure, neither can care also of her self be kept
secret. For either his hosts yt lodged her, or ye bawd that procures their
meeting, or ye page that brings comme^dacions and messenges beetwixt them, or
ye neighbors that sees him frequent ye house, or the servant that shall suspect
him, or the mother that sold her to him, in ye end will beewray their secret
