practice and friendship. Whereof springs afterward disdain, and from disdayn,
to defame each other: so yt of extreme lovers they were first, they afterward
beecome mortal enemies. And therefore ye wiuel is not so hurtful to ye corn,
nor the locust to ye otes, nor ye woormes to ye vines, nor maggots to ye fruit,
nor the moth to ye garments, as the woman is to a man, yt once was his friend,
and now become his enemy. For like as in time of her love, she robbed and
spoiled him of al his goods: so likewise in ye time of her hatred, she
deuoureth al his good fame and reputacio^. But what shall we say of yt man yt
co^tenteth not him self with one fre^d alone, but like an insatiable leacher
takes upon him to keep an other. Truly I cannot tell what to say of this man,
but yt it had been better for hi^ he had never been borne, the^ to have kept
company with such vile and common weome^. For he shall never appease ye first
neither with anger, nor flattery: nor humble her with prese^ts nor ca^ expel her
hate with promises, neither please her with cherishing of her and much less shall
ouerco^e her with threttes. The Occean sea is not so dangerous, nor ye sweord of
ye tyra^t so cruel, neither lyghtnyng so sodein, nor earthquakes so horrible,
and fearful, nor serpe^ts so venymus as a harlot: when she does but suspect
her friend loves another beside her self, for she cease not to defa^e him,
and to follow ye other, to raise a sclau^der amongst her neighbors, to
complain to his friends, to bewray ye matter to ye justice, to quarrel with
officers and always to have spies for him in every place, as if he were one
of her mortal enemies. O I woold to god ye courtier would as much esteem of
his co^scie^s, as his lover makes account of his parso^: happy were he. For I
dare assure him if he know it not, yt she spieth out al ye places he goth so,
and cou^ts every morsel of meat he eats, and becomes ielious of al yt he
does, and of all those whose company he freque^teth, yea she deuiseth and
imagines all yt he thinks. So yt he yt seeks a cruel revenge of his
enemy, cannot do better the^ persuade and induce him to love one of these well
co^ditioned women. Now let him think yt he has great wars, yt by his evil
hap has made her his enemy, wc heretofore he so e^tierly loved. For any man
yt exteemeth his honor, and reputacio^, does rather fear ye evil tongue of
such a woman, the^ ye sweord of his enemy. For an honest man to strive, and
co^te^d with a woman of such quality, is eue^ as much, as if he woold take upon
him, to wash an asses head. Therefore he may not set me to make account of
those injuries done him, or euel words she has spoken of him, but rather
seek to remedy it ye best he ca^, that she speak no more of him. For women
naturaly desire to enjoy yt person they love, without let or interruption of any,
and to pursue to ye death those they hate. I woold wysh therefore ye favored of
princes, and such as have office and dignity in ye court, that they beware they
incur not into such like errors. For it is not sitting yt me^ of honor, and
such as are great about ye prince shoold seem to have more lyberty in vice
the^ any other, neither for any respect ought ye beloved of ye prince to dare
to keep company, much less to have friendship with any such common and defamed
women, sith ye least euel yt can come to the^, they cannot be avoided. But at
ye least he must charge his co^scie^s, trouble his friends, wast his goods,
consume his person, and lose his good fame, joining with al these also, his
co^cubine to be his mortal enemy. For there is no woman liui^g yt has any
measure in loui^g, neither end in hati^g. Oh how wareli ought al me^ to live,
and specialy we yt are in ye court of princes, for many women (under ye color
of their authority and office) go often times to seek the^ in their cha^bers, not
only as humble suitors, to sollycyte their causes, but also liberaly to offer
the^ their persons, and so by yt color to conclude their practices and
deuyses. So yt ye decisio^ and co^clusio^ of process wc they fain to solycite,
shall not go with him yt demands there goods of the^, but rather with him yt
desires but their parso^s to spoil the^ of their honor. Now ye princes
officers must seek to be pure, and clean from al these practices of these
common stru^pets, much more from those yt are suitors to the^ and have matters
before the^. For they should highly offend god, and commit great treason to ye
King, if they should send those weome^ from the^ that sued unto the^ rather
dishonored and defamed, the^ honestly dispatched of their business. And therefore
he binds him self to a marvelous inconuenie^ce, yt falls in love with a
woman suter. For even from yt instant he has receued of her ye sweet
delights of love, eue^ at ye present he by^deth him self to dispatch her
quickly, and to end al her suits, and not without great grief I speak these
words. There are many women yt come to ye court of princes to make
unreasonable and dishonest suits, wc in ye end notwtsta^ding obtain there
desire: And not for any right or reason they have to it, save only they have
obtained yt thorough ye favor and credit, they have won of ye favored courtier,
or of one of his beloved. So as we see it happen many times, that ye unjust
fornication, made her suit just and reasonable. I should lie, and do my self
wrong me thinks, if I should pass over with silence a thing yt happened in the
emperors court touching this matter, in the wc I went one day to one of the
princes chief officers, and best beeloued of him to sollycyte a matter of
importau^ce wc an hosts of mine should have before him. And so this favored
courtier and great officer, after he had hard of me ye whole discourse of ye
matter, for full resolution of ye same, he axed me if she were young and
fair: and I au^swered him yt she was reasonable fair and of good favor. Well
than says he bed her com to me, and I will do ye best I can to despatch her
matter with speade: for I will assure you of this, yt there never ca^e fair woman
to my hands, but she had her business quickly dispatched at my hands. I have
known also many women in ye court so dishonest, that not contented to follow
their own matters, would also deal with others affayrs, and gain in soliciting
their causes, so yt they with their fine words and frank offer of there parsons
obtained that, wc many times to men of honor and great autorytye was denied.
Therefore these great officers, and favored of princes ought to have great
respect, not only in ye co^uersatio^ they have with these women, but also in ye
honest order they ought to observe in hering their causes. And yt to be done
in such sort, that what so ever they say unto the^ may be kept secret,
provided also the place where they speak with them, be open for other suitors
in like case.

That the nobles and beloved of princes exceed not in superfluous fare, and
that they be not too su^ptuous in their meats. A notable chapter for those yt
use too much delicacye and superfluity. Chap. xviii.
ONe of the greatest cares and regard ye nature laid upon her self, was, yt men
could not live without sustina^ce: so that so long as we see a man eat (yea if
yt were a thousand years) we might be bold to say that he is certainly
alive. And he has not alone laid this burden upon me^, but on brute bests
also: For we see by experience, that some feeds on ye grass in ye fyelds
some lives in the air eating flies, others upon ye worms in carin, others with
that they find under the water. And finally each beast lives of other, and
afterward ye worms feed of us al. And not only reasonable me^ and brute
beasts live by eating, but ye trees are norrished thereby, and we see it thus
yt they instead of meat, receive into the^ for nutriture ye heat of ye sun,
ye te^perature of ye air, the moisture of the earth, and deaw of heaven. So
that the sustenance for men is called meat, and that of pla^ts and trees,
Increase. This being true therefore that we have spoken, we must needs
confess that to live we must eat: and yet with all, we must understand that
the sin of gluttony consists not in that that we eat for necessity, but
only in that that is eaten with a disordinat appetite and desire. And sure now
adays men use not to eat to content nature, but to please their lycorous and
deinty mouths. He that geeueth him self over to the desire of the throat,
does not only offend his stomach, and distemper his body, but hurts also
his conscience. For all gluttons and dronkards are the children or the brothers
of sin. And I speak but little to say that the mouth and sin are cousin
germayns togethers: for by their effects and operations me thinks them so
knyt and combined together, as the father and the son: Sith burning leachery
acknowlegeth none other for her mother, but only the insatiable and gurmand
throat. And the dyuersity of meats is but a continual and importunat awaking of
dishonest thoughts. Do we not read of saint Iherom, that albeit he remained
in ye wilderness, burned of the sun, his face dried up and wrinckled,
barefooted, and also bare headed, clothed with sackcloth, his body scourged
with bitter stripes, watchinge in the night, and fasting in the day,
continually exercising his pen, and his heart in contemplacion, and yet for
all this grievous penance, him self confessed, that in his sleep he dreamed
and thought he was among the courtisans of Rome. And saint Paul the apostle,
who was a man of rare and exquisite knowledge, and deserved to see the very
secrets of paradise, never heretofore seen, travailing in his vocation more
then any other of the apostels, did not he get his living with his own hands?
and also went a soote preaching through all the world, bringyng infynit
barbarous people to the faith of christ, being beaten in the day time by
others, for yt he was a christian, and in the night time he beat him self for
that he was a sinner, punishing the flesh, to make it subject to the spirit.
And yet nevertheless he says also of him self, that he coold not defend him
self from dishonest thoughts, wc did ever let him to preach and pray with a
quiet mind. Saint Austin recites of him self in his book de confessionibus,
that al ye while he inhabited in the deserts he eat little, wrote much, prayed
often, and sharply chastised his body, with continual fasts, and grievous
disciplines. But yet perceauing that notwithstanding all this his dishonest
thoughts suppressed his holy desires, he began to cry with a loud voice
thorough the deserts, and rocky hills, saying. O lord my god, thou commaundest
me to be chaste, but this frail and accursed flesh can never keep yt. And
therefore I humbly beseech thee first to indue me with thy grace to do that
thou will have me, and then commau^d me what shall please thee: otherwise I
shall never do yt. If therefore these glorious saints with their continual
fasts and contemplations, and extreme punishing of their bodies, could not
defend them selves from the burning motion of the flesh: how shall we believe
that a company of dronkards, and gluttons, can do yt, which never lynne
bibbyng and eating. We may be assured that the less we pamper and feed our
bodies with delicacy and idleness, the more we shall have them obedient, and
subject to our wills. For though we see the fire never so great and flaming,
yet it quickly wastes, and is brought to ashes, if we leave to put more wood
unto yt. Excess is not only unlawful for the boddy but it is also occasion of
a thousand dyseases, both to ye body and ye soul. For to say troth, we have
seen more rych me^ dye through excess, the^ poor me^ of necessity. And in my
opinion, me thynkes ye sin of Gluttony need not to be otherwise punyshed
by divine justice, sith yt of yt self yt bri^geth penance enough. And to
prove this true, let us but require these glutto^s to tell us, upon their
oaths, how they find the^ selves in te^per being full pau^ched: and they will
confess to us yt they are worse at ease the^ if they had fasted: That their
mouth is dry, their body heavy, and ill disposed, yt their head aketh, their
stomach is cold, and that their eyes are slepy, and their bellyes full, but yet
yt they desire to drink still. And therefore Diogenes Cinicus, deryding the
Rodians, said these words. O you dronken and gluttonus Rodians, tell me I
beseech you, what occasion mooues you to go to ye church, to pray to ye gods
to geeue you health, when at al times, keeping sober diet, you may keep yt with
you? And more over he said unto the^ also, and if you wilbee ruled by my
counsel, I tell you, you need not go to ye churches to beseech ye gods to
grant you health, but only to pray to them to pardon you your sins and
iniquities you daily commit. Also Socrates ye philosopher was wo^t to say to
his disciples, of ye vnyuersity of Athens: Remember O you Athenians, yt in ye
well governed pollycies, me^ live not to eat, to glut the body: but do only
eat, to live and sustayn ye body. O grave saying of ye good philosopher, and I
woold to god every good christian would carry this lesson in mind. For if we
woold but let nature alone, and geeue her lyberty and disposition, of her self,
she is so honest, and of such temperau^ce, that she will not leave to eat yt
that shall suffice her, neither will also trouble us with that yt is
superfluous. Yet an other foul offense brings this vice of Gluttony, and
that is, that many put them selves in service to wayt on others, not so much for
the ordinary fare that is commonly used in their house, as for the desire they
have to fill their bellies with dainty and superfluous meats. And in especial
when they know they make any marriages, or feasts for their friends, then they
geeue double attendance, not conse^ted alone with that themselves have eaten,
but further in remembrance of ye worthy feast, commits to the custody of
his trusty cater (his great hose) perhaps a two or three days store of those
rare and dainty dishes, which I am ashamed to write, and much more ought they
to be ashamed to do yt. For that man that professes to be a man, ought to
enforce himself never to engage his liberty for that, that his se^sual appetite
incyteth him to: but only for that that reason byndeth him to. Aristippus the
philosopher, washyng lettyse one day with his own hands for his supper, by
chance Plautus passing by that way, and seeing him said: If thou wooldst have
served King Dionisius, we should not have seen thee eat lettises as thou
do now: Aristippus au^swered him again, O Plautus, if thou were content to
eat of these lettyses that I eat, thou shooldst not serve so great a tyrant as
thou do. The excess of meats is greater in these days, both in quantity,
and in dressing of them, then in times past. For in that golden age, which the
philosophers never cease to beewaile, men had no other houses but natural
caves in the ground, and apparelled only with the leaves of trees, the bare
ground for their shoes, their hands serving them in steed of cups to drink
in, they drank water for wine, eat to^ ^^s for bread, and fruyts for flesh: and
finally for their bed they made the earth, and for their covering the sky,
being lodged always at the sign of the star. When the divine Plato returned
out of Cicill into Greece, he said one day in his college. I do advertise
you my disciples, that I am returned out of Cicill maruelously troubled, and
this is by reason of a monster I saw there. And being asked what mo^ster it
was, he told them that it was Dionisius the tyrant. who is not contented with
one meal a day, but I saw him suppe many times in the night. O divine Plato,
if thou were alive as thou art dead, and present with us in this our pestilent
age, as thou were then in that golden time: how many should thou see, that
do not only dyne and suppe well, but before dinner break their fast with
delycate meats and wynes, and banquet after dynner and supper also before they
go to bed. So that we may say, though Plato saw then but one tyrant suppe,
he might see now every body both dyne and suppe, and scant one that conte^teth
him with one meal a day, in which the brute bests are more moderate, the^
reasonable men. Sith we see that they eat but so much as satisfyeth them: and
men are not contented to eat enough, yea till they be full, but more then
nature will bear. And brute beasts have not also such diversity of meats as men
have, neither servants to wayt on them, beds to lie in, wine to drink, houses
to put their heads in, money to spend, nor phisitio^s to purge them as men
have. And yet for all these commodities, we see men the most part of their time
sick. And by these things recyted, we may perceive, that there is nothing
preserves so much the health of man as labor, and nothing consumes sooner
then rest. And therefore Plato in his time on spoke a notable sentence, and
worthy to be had in mind, and that is this. That in that city where there are
many phisicions, yt must needs follow of necessity that the inhabitaunts there
of, are vicious, and ryotous persons. And truly we have good cause to carry
this saying away. Since we see that physicians commonly enter not into poor
men's houses, ye travel and exercises their body daily: but contrarily into
the rych and welthy men's houses, which live continually idly, and at ease. I
remember I knew once a gentleman (a kynsman of mine, and my very friend) which
having taken physyck, I came to see how he did, supposing he had been syck,
and demanding of him the cause of his purgacion: he told me he took it not
for any sickness he had, but only to make him have a better appetite against
he went to the feast, which should be a two or three days after. And with in
six days after I returned again to see him, and I found him in his bed very
sick, not for that he had fasted too much, but that he had inglutted him self
with the variety of meats he eat at the feast. So it happened, that where he
purged him self once only to have a better stomach to eat, he needed
afterward a douzen purgacions to discharge his laden stomach of that great
surfeit he had taken at the feast, with extreme eating: And for the four
hours he was at ye table where this feast was, he was lodged afterward in
his chamber for two months, to pay vsery for that he had taken, and yet yt
was the great grace of god he escaped with life. For if it be ill to sin,
yt us far worse to seek and procure occasions to sin. And therefore by
consequent, the sin of Gluttony is not only dangerous for the co^sciens,
hurtful to the health of the body, and a displeasing of god: but it is also a
worm that eats, and in fine consumes wholly the goods, and faculties of him
that uses yt. Beesyds that, these gurmands receive not so much pleasure in the
eating of these dainty morsells, as they do afterward grief and displeasure,
to hear the great accounts of their stewards, of their excessyue expensis. Yt
is a sweet delight to be fed daily with dainty dishes, but a sower sauce to
those delicat mouths to put his hand so often to the purse. Which I speak not
with out cause, sith that as we feel great pleasure and felicity in those
meats that enter into our stomach, so do we afterward think that they pluck
out of our heart that money that pays for those knacks. I remember I saw written
in an Inn in Catalogia these words. You that host here must say, when you
sit down to your meat, Salve regina, yea and when you are eating, Vitae dull
cedo, yea and when you reckon with the host, Ad te Suspiramus, yea and when you
come to pay him, Gementes, and flentes. Now if I would go about to describe by
parcells the order and manner of our feasts and banckets, newly invented by our
own nation, there would rather appear matter to you, to lament and bewail,
then to write. And it had been better (by way of speech) to have invented
diverse fashions of tables, forms, and stools, to sit on, the^ such diversity
of meats to set upon the tables, as we do use now a days.

And therefore by good reason did Licurgus (King of Lacedemonia) ordeyne and
comaund, that no stranger coming out of a strange country into his, should so
hardy bring in any new customs upon pain, that if it were known, he should
be straight banished out of the country, and if he did use and practice yt,
he should be put to death. I will tell you no lie. I saw once served in at a
feast xlii. sorts and kinds of meats in several dishes: In an other feast
of diverse sorts of the fish caled Tuny. And in an other feast, being flesh
day, I saw diverse fishes broyled with lard. And at an other feast wheare I saw
no other meat but Troutes, and Lampereis of diverse kinds of dressinge. And at
an other feast, wheare I saw only, vi. persons agree togethers to drink each of
them.iii. pottels of wine apeece, with this condition further, yt they should
be.vi. hours at the table, and he that drank not out his part, should pay
for the whole feast. I saw also an other feast, where they prepared iii.
several tables for the bidden guests, the one board served after the Spanish
manner, the other after the Italian, and the third after the fasshion of
Flaunders: And to every table there was served xxii. sorts of meats. I saw
also at an other feast such kinds of meats eaten, as are wont to be seen,
but not eaten: as a Horse roasted, a Cat in gely, litel Lysars with whot broth,
Frogs fried, and diverse other sorts of meats which I saw them eat, but I
never knew what they wear till they wear eaten. And for gods sake what is he
that shall read our writings, and see that that is commonly eaten in feasts
now adays, that it will not in manner break his heart, and water his plants.
The only spices that have been brought out of Calicut, and the manner of
furnishing of our boords brought out of France, has distroied our nation
utterly. For in the old time, they had no other kinds of spice in Spain, but
Saffron, Common, Garlic, and Onyons, and when one friend inuyted an other, they
had but a piece of beef, and a piece of veale, and no more: and yt was a rare
and dainty matter to add to a hen. Oh mis^^appes of worldly creatures, you
embrace not now the time that was, for now i^ he be an officer, or popular
person of any like condition, and that he inuyte his friend or neighbor, he
will not for shame set before him less then vi. or vii. several disshes,
though he sell his cloak for hit, or fare the worse one whole week after, for
that one supper or dinner. Good lord yt is a wonder to see what sturr there is
in that man's house that makes a dinner or supper. A.ii. or iii. days before,
you shall see such resort of persons, such hurly burly, such flying this way,
such sending that way, some occupied in telling the cooks how many sorts of
meats they will have, other sent out to provide a cater to by their meat, and
to hyer servants to wait on them, and other poor folks to look to the
dressing up of the house: brauling and fyghting with their servants,
commanding their maids to look to the buttry, to rub the tables and
stools, and to see all things set in their order, as sit as may be, and to
taste this kind of wine and that kind of wine: so that I would to god they would
(for the health of their souls) but employ half this care and pains they take
in preparyng one dinner, to make clean their conscienses, and to confess them
selves to allmighty god. I would fayn know, after all these great feasts, what
there remains, more, then as I suppose, the master of the house is trobled,
the stewards and caters weried, the poor cooks broyled in the fire, the house
al foul, and yet that that is worst of al, sometimes the master of the feast
comes short of a piece of plate that is stolen. So that he can not choose
but be sorry for the great charges he has been at, beesyds the loss of his
plate and vessel stolen, and the rest of his implements of house mard, and in
manner spoiled: And peradventure also the invited not satisfied nor contented,
but rather will laugh him to scorn for his cost, and murmr at him beehind
his back. Marcus Tullius Cicero was once bidden to supper of a covetous Roman,
a citizin borne, whose supper agreed with his avarice. So the next day it
cha^ced this covetous citizen to meet with Cicero, and he asked him how he
did with his supper, very well said Cicero, for it was so good a supper, that yt
shall serve me yet for all this day. Meaning to let him understand by these
woodrs, that his supper was so miserable, and he left with such an appetite,
as he should dine the next day with a better stomach at home.

The author continues his purpose.
Yt is now more then time we do bring you apparaunt proofs (as well by
scriptures, as profane autors) that there was never made feast or bancket but
the devil was ever lightly a guest, by whose presence always happens some
mischief. The first Ba^cket that ever was made in the world (...) that the
devil made to Adam and Eve with the fruit of terrestrial paradyse: after which
followed a disobeing of gods commandment, the less that Adam had of his
innocency, and a soden shame and perpetual reproach to our mother Eve, man's
nature presently brought to al sin and vice. So that we may well say they
eat the fruit, that set our teeth an edge. Did not Rebecca like wise make a
feast to her husband Isaac, in wc Esaw lost his heritage, and Jacob succeeded
in the same blessing Isaac (through fraud) whom he took for Esaw, and all
through the counsel of his mother Rebecca, she having her desiere and purpose
as she wished. Absalon, did not he make an other to all his breethern after
which followed the death of Aman one of his brothers, and by one of the other
brethren their sister Thamar was defamed, and their father King David very
sore grieved and afflicted, and all the realm of Israel slaundered? King
Assuetus made an other of so great and foolish expense, that he kept open
house for a hundred and fourscore days, and it followed, that Queen Vasti was
deprived of her crown, and the fair Hester invested in her rome, many noble
men of the city of Hul were murdered and he we^ in pieces, by means whereof the
Ebrues came into great favor and credit, and Aman, the chief in authority and
favor about the prince, deprived of all his lands, and shamefully executed upon
the gallows, and Nardocheus placed in his room, and greatly sublimed and
exalted. Also the xiiii. children of the holy man Job (which were.vii. sons
and so many daughters) being all feasted at their eldest brothers house,
before they rose from ye board, were they not all slain? Also Baltezar son
of King Nabucodonosor made a bancket to all the gentlewomen and his co^cubines
within the city, so sumptuous and rich, that the only vessel he was served
withal, and the cups they drank in, were robbed out of the temple of
Jerusalem by his father: and this followed after his great banquet. The self
same night the King with all his concubines dyed suddenly, and his realm taken
from him, and put into the hands of his enemies. Yt had been better for all
these I have recited, that they had eaten alone at home, then to have dyed so
sodaninly accompanied. Now let al these gourmands and licorous mowthed people
mark what I shall say to them, and carry yt well in mind, and that is this: that
ye sin of Gluttony is nothing else but a displeasure, great peril, and a
marvelous expense. I say that it is a displeasure: for the great care they have
continually to seek out diuersityes of fine and curious meats: great peril,
because they plo^ge their bodies into many diseases: and in unmerciful charge,
for the curiosity and nombers of dishes. So that for a litel pleasure, and
delight, we take in the sweet taste of those deinty meats, being but a
satisfaction to the mind for a short time: we afterward have infinite
greefes, and trobles, with a sower sauce, to our no small pain. And therefore
Aristotell mocking the Epicuriens said, that they upon a time went all into the
temple togethers, beseeching the gods they would geeue them necks as long as
the cranes and herens, that ye pleasure and taste of the meats should be more
long, before yt came into the stomach, to take the greater delight of their
meat, complaining of nature that she had made their necks to short: affirming
that the only pleasure of meats co^sisted in the swallowing of yt down, which
they said was to soon. If we saw a man even upon a sodein throw al his goods
into ye sea or river, would we not imagine he were mad, or a very fool? Yes
undoubtedly. Even such a one is he that prodigally spendith al his goods in
feasting and bancketing. And that this is true: do we not see manifestly that
all these meats that are served to noble men's boordes to day, and to morrow
co^ueighid into the privy from the eaters by their page or servant? Suerly man's
stomach is nothing else but a gutt or tripe forsed with meat, bread, and wine,
a paueme^t fyld with wine lees, and a vessel of stinking oil, a recepit of
corrupt air, a synke of a kitchen, and a secret place, wherinto we cast all
our goods and faculty as into the river. And therefore Esaias said, that all these
noble cities of Sodom, and Gomorra, by this only curse did incur into such
execrable sins, for wc afterward they were distroied: and this was even
through excess of eating, and drinking, and to much ydlenes: and it is no
marvel. For it is an infallible thing, that where ydlenes and glottony
reigns, there must needs come some ill end to that man. The Greeks, the
Romans, the Egiptians, and the Scithes, although they were detected of many
other sins and vices, yet were they alwais sober and temperat in eating and
drinking. Justin that wrote of Trogus Pompeius recites, that among the Scithes
(wc were the rudest and most barbarous that came into Asia) used to reprove
those that let go wind, and to chastise and punish those that vomited, saying
that breaking wynd and vomiting, came only of too much eating and drinking.
Plutarche in his Apothegmes said, that there was a philosopher in Athens called
Hyppomachus, that was so great an enemy to Gluttony, that he used in his
college such and so great an abstinence, that his disciples by that were
known amongst all the other philosophers. And not for no other thing, but to
see them buy their cates and provision to live with all: for they never bought
meats to fatt them and keep them lusty, but only to susteyn nature, and that
but little. The Romans made diverse laws in ye old time to expel out of their
cities dronkards and Gluttons, whereof we will recite some unto you, to thend
that those that shall read our present writings, shall both know, and see what
great care our forfathers took to abolish this horible vice of gluttony. First
there was a law in Rome called Fabian law, so called, because Fabian the consul
made it, in which it was prohibited that no man shoold so hardy in the greatest
feast he made, spend above a hundred sexterses, which might be in value a
hundred pieces of.vi. pence, salets and all other kynds of fruit not comprysed
within the same.

And immediately after that, came out an other law called Messinia, which the
consul Messinius made. By which they were also inhibited in all feasts to
drink no strange wynes, wc only were permitted to be geeuen to those that were
disseased. After which followed also an other law Licinia, made by ye co^sull
Licinius, forbidding in all feasts all kinds of sawces, because they incite
appetit, and are cause of a great expense. An other law Emillia, of Emilius the
consul also, commanding the Romans shoold be served in their bankets but
only with five sorts of diversities of meats, because in them there shoold be
sufficient for honest refection, and no superfluity to fill the belly. And then
was there the law Ancia made by Ancius the consul, charging all the Romans to
endeavor to learn all kind of sciences, except cookry. For according to their
saying, in that house where there was a cook, those of ye house became poor
quickly, their bodies diseased, their mynds vicious, and altogeether geeuen to
Gluttony. After this law there came forth an other called Iulia, of Julius
Caesar, commanding all romans, yt none shoold be so hardy to shut their gates
when they were at dinner, and it was to this end, that the censors of the city
might have easy access into their houses at meal time, to see if their
ordinary were respondent to their ability. And there was also an other law made
afterward called Aristimia, of Aristmius the consul, by which it was enacted
that it shoold be lawful for every man to inuit his friends to dinner to him
at noone, as they liked, provided that they supped not together yt night. And
this was established thus, to cut of the great charge they were at with their
suppers: For the Romans exceeded in superfluity of daynty and fine meats, and
more over they sat to long gulling and eating at their suppers. Of all these
laws heretofore recited, were auctors Aulus Gelius, and Macrobius. And for this
was Caius Gracchus well reputed of, of the Romays, who not withstanding he had
been consul indyuers provinces (and that many times) and was a man of great
gravity and auctority in Rome, yet he woold never keep cook in his house, but
when he was at Rome, his wife was his only cook: and traueling, his hostess
of his house where he lay dressed his meat. Marcus Mantius in times past, made
a book of diverse ways how to dress meat, and an other of the tastes, sawces,
and diverse manners of serving of them in at the bankets, and a third book how to
cover the table, set the stools in order, order ye cubberd, and also how
servants shoold wayt and geeue their attendance at ye table: which three books
were no sooner imprinted and published, but presently and publikly they were
burned by the senate of Rome, and if his aucthor had not quickly voided Rome,
and fled into Asia, he had acco^panyed his books in the fire. The ancient
writers never seized to reprove enough Lentulus, Caesar, Scilla, Sceuola, and
Emilius: For a banquet they made in a gardein of Rome, where they eat no other
meats but black byrds, torteises, mallard, nettles, pigs brayns, and hares in
sauce. But if the Romain writers wrote in these days. I do not believe they
woold reprove so simple a banquet made by so noble and famous persons as they
were. For now a days they do so far exceed in variety of dishes at noble
men's bourds, that neither they have appetite to eat, nor yet they can tell the
names of the dishes. But now retourning to our purpose, I say the intent why
we have laid before you these forepassed examples, was only to this end, to
admonish the favored of princes to look into them selves yt they avoid this
fylthy sin of gluttony, Being a foul blott in a courtier, to be counted a
greedy gutt, and Carmarant at his meat, and being one, whose manners and
behauior every man marketh. For sure it is more sitting for the^ to be moderat
and sober, in eating and drinking then others, and good reason why. For as they
are more noble then others, so have they many that sue unto them, and they have
also ye weightiest matters of government, passing under their charge: by reason
where of if they surcharge them selves with excess, they are then very unapt to
dispatch any matters: for much eating causes sleep, and much drinking
depriueth them of their judgment, and senses both. Is it not to be wondered
at, yea and to be reproved also, to see a magistrate or counceller set in his
chair to here poor men's causes and suits, and ye suter opening his cause unto
him, he sits nodding with his head in his bosom ready to sleep? Even so do I
say like wise, that it is a great reproach to ye beloved of the prince, and
great damage to the common wealth, that it shoold be spoken amongst courtiers
and suitors, that to day he was of this opinion, and to morrow he is of an
other. So that the courtier or suter shoold have hope to dispatch that to
morrow, he coold not do to day. King Phillip, father of Alexander the great,
although he was a prince, noble and fortunat, yet was he noted and rebuked
for drinking of wine, whereof followed that after he had given judgment upon a
time against a poor wydow woman, she answered straight she appealed. The
noble men that were present, heering what was said by the king, asked her to
whom she woold appele, since ye king in person gave sentence of her, and no
other: And this was her answer she made them. I appeal to king Philip wc is
now dronk: that when he is sober, he return to geeue sentence. And as ye
historiographers say, that writes this history, this poor woman was not
deceived in her appellation at all: for after King Philip had reposed and slept
a little, he revoked and repealed that sentence that he had before geeuen
against her. And therefore concerning this matter, I say, that how wyld or tame
so ever a beast be, he still continues a beast in his kind, only man except,
who very often through too much excess of meat and drynk, strayeth so far from
reason, forgetting him self, that neither he him self, nor any other knows
well, whether he be then a man, or a beast. Those that are the favored of
princes must be very circumspect, yt they be not too sumptuous, and
prodigal, in their feasts and bankets, for that they have many eyes attendant
of them. And some will say, that they make not these great feasts of them
selves, but by ye gyfts and presents of others: others will not stick to say yt
they make it with that they have robbed of others. I wish them in this case that
they shoold not hope to excuse themselves by saying that they only feast their
kinsfolks, and familier friends. For the envy that commonly one bears against
ye power and auctority of a man, is so great, and extreme, that it spares not
friends, remembers not kinsfolks, neither makes account of the benefits
received: but rather as soon as ye bidden guests are departed from his house
that bad the^, they go talking among them selves, and murmuring amongst
others, saying many times that it is more worth, that is lost by the vayn and
lavish expenses of the favored courtier: then that yt is como^ly served to ye
princes own board. Also I counsel the belyked of princes, that they take heed
whom they trust, and whom they inuit to their tables. For many times if they
be but four yt are bidden, one of them sure goes to eat and banquet, and the
other three to fleere, and mock, and to mark all that is brought in, and the
manner of the service. And the woorst is yet, that he shall many times bring
such to eat with him, that woold more willingly eat his flesh, then his meat.
These reputed courtiers must be well advised, that though they be too delicat
and superfluous in their meats, yet at least that they bridle their tongues.
For they may be assured, that as their guests they bad go full paunched from
them, so carry they away with them, all the superfluous and vayn words they
hard at the table. Besides that, that what so ever the courtier said at ye
board, reporting it otherwhere, they will not say that he spoke yt of him
self, but that the king him self told it him. And yet is there a far greater
danger and peril then this we have spoken of, and that is: that they will not
simply tell that they hard of ye beloved courtier, but will add to it of their
own heads, what they think best, and what was his meaning in speaking of it. So
that we may say, that there are not so many comments upon the bible, as they
make gloses upon the same reports (by their rash judgments and fond
interpretacions) which they did descant, upon one only word spoken unawares
perhaps, by some at the table of this favored courtier. It is a general custom,
amongst all estates and conditions of people: that where there are sumptuous
tables, and abundance of dishes, there the inuyted sit long at their meat,
and are liberal to speak evil. Which sure such as are in favor with the
prince, neither ought to do, nor suffer it to be done by others at his board.
For the good and honorable feast, ought only to be served, with good and
dainty meats: but in no wise marred with the defaming of his neighbor. O how
many feasts and bankets are made in princes courts, where without all
comparison there are more detractions used of their neighbors, then there are
diversities of dishes to eat. A pernicious thing doubtless, and not to be
suffered nor abidden: For no man hurts the reputation of an other with his
tongue, but with the self same he condemns his own conscience: and therefore
let men be aduysed of their spech, and what they speak of others. For it is
alwais an easy matter to detract and hinder the fame and reputation of a man,
but very hard afterward to satisfy the party. Therefore I council, and
admonish these courtiers, that they do not often feast others: but also that
they do not accept to go to others tables where they are bidden.

For they may be assured, that they are beloved of few, and hated of all: and
besides that it might so happen, that others shoold be at the charge of the
feast, and that they shoold lose their lives. Also let not the favored courtyer
trust those to much, that come ordinarily to his table, and that do rebydd him
again to theirs, yea though they seem even to be wholly his to dispose, and
possible as it were his right hand, and that they be those whom he happily too
has done much for, in dispatching their affairs. For lightly in such like
feasts, treasons and poisonings are not practiced with the master of the feast,
but only with him that waits at ye table to geeue drink, or else by the cooks
that dresseth the meat. Also let not ye courtier trust too much those whom he
has been in company with all at diverse feasts (where he never had hurt) much
less knew any little occasion to suspect ill of them, touching any treso^ment
toward him. For so at a time when he suspecteth least, he may be in most
danger, and find him self deceived. And therefore by my council he shall not
easily be entreated to every man's board, unless he be first well assured of
the company that are bidden as also of the servants that wayt. For the holes
and spaces of the french rydles (with which they dust their corn) sometimes is
even stopped with the very grains of the same corn, and lets the clear
passage of all the rest. One of the greatest troubles (or to term it better)
one of the greatest dangers I see the favored courtiers in, is this: that al
ye courtiers, and in manner all the citizens, desire to see them out of favor,
or dead, by some means. For every man is of this mind, that with ye change of
things, by his fall or death he hops he shall rise, to some better state, or
happily to catch some part of his offices, or lyuings. An other mischief and
inconuenie^ce yet happens to this favored courtier, by haunting others
tables, and that is: that many times it chances, unseemly and dishonest words
are let fall at the table, and perhaps quarrel rise upon it, wc though he be
present, yet he can neither remedy, nor appease it. And because these things
were done and spoken in the presence of the esteemed of the prince, he that
spoke them has credit, and those that hard it discried it. Yet is there an
other disorder that comes by these feasts, that is, that he that makes the
feast, and bids guests, does it not for that they are of his acquayntaunce,
his kinsfolks, or his faithful friends, nor for that he is bound and
beeholding to them, but only to obtayn his desire in his suits that he has in
hand: for they are few that seek to pleasure men, but in hope to be greatly
recompensed.

Therefore those that are in favor and auctority about the prince, and that
accept others bydding, sure one of these two things must happen to them. Either
that he must dispatch his busynes that inuyteth him, yea although it be
unreasonable, and so unjust and damnable, that obtaining it, both he and the
favored courtier go to the devil togeethers for company, for ye wrong and
injury they have done to an other: or on the other side refusing to do it,
the bydder is stricken dead, and repents his cost bestowed upon him. Above
all things, I chiefly admonish the courtiers, and officers of princes, not to
sell change, nor engage their liberties as they do, ye same day that they
begin to follow such feasts, or to receive gyfts or presents, or to lynk them
selves in straight friendship with any, or to deal parcially in any cause. For
by these foresaid occasions, they shall often bynd them selves to do that that
shall not be fit for them, besides the loss of their liberty they had
before, to do that was most honest, and commendable.

That the favored of princes ought not to be dishonest of their tongues, nor
enuyous of their words. Cap. xix.
ANaxagoras the philosopher, disputing one day of the cause why nature had
placed the members of man's body in such order as they are, and of the property
and complexio^ of every one of them, and to what end they had been so orderly
placed by nature, each member in his place: falling in the end to treat of the
tongue, said thus of it. You must understand my good disciples, that not without
art and great mystery nature gave us ii. feet, ii. hands.ii. ears, and ii.
eyes, and yet for all this but one tongue, whereby she showed us, ye in our
going, feeling, smelling, hearing, and seeing, we may be as long as we will:
but in speking we shoold be as sparing, and scant, as coold be: alleging
further that not without great reason also nature suffered us to go open and
bare faced, the eyes, the ears, the hands, the feet, and other parts of the
body bare also, except the tongue, which she has environed with laws, and
inured with teeth, and also shut with lips: wc she did, to geeue us to
understand, that there is nothing in this present life that has more need of
guard, and defense, then has this our unbridled tongue. And therefore said
Pithachus ye philosopher, that a man's tongue is made, like the iron point of a
lance, can but yet that it was more dangerous then that: For the point of ye
lance can but hurt the flesh: but the tongue perseth ye heart. And truly it
was a true saying of this philosopher. For I know not that man how virtuous or
pacient so ever he be, but thinks yt less hurt, the bloody sword shoold
perce his flesh, then that he shoold be touched in honor, with the venomous
point of ye serpentyen tongue. For how cruel so ever the wound be, time does
heal it, and makes it well again: but defame or infamy, neither late nor never
can be amended. We see men refuse to go by water for fear of drowning: not to
come too near the fire, for fear of burning: not to go to the wars, for
fear of killing: to eat no ill meats, for being sick: to clym up a high, for
fear of falling: to go in ye dark, for fear of stumbling: to avoid ye ill
air, and rayn, for fear of rewmes: and yet I see very few, or none, that can
beware of detractors, and ill tongs. And that this is true I tell you, I do
not think that in any thing a man is in such peril and danger, as when he
lives accompanied with men dishonest in their doings, and vile and naught in
their tongues. I have also read touching this matter, that Aformius ye
philosopher, being asked what he meant to go the most part of his time amongst
the desert mountains, in hasard every hour to be devoured of wyld beasts,
answered thus. Wild beasts have no other weapons to hurt me, but their horns
and nayls, and their teeth to devour me: but men never cease to hurt, and
offend me, with all their whole members. And that this is true, behold I pray
you how they look at me with their eyes, spurn me with their feet, torment
me with their hands, hate me with their heart, and defame me with their
tongue. So that we have great reason to say, that a man lives with more
security, amongst wyld beasts: then among malignaunt and envious people.
Plutarche in his book De exilio says, that the Lydians had a law, that as
they sent the condemned murderers to row in the gallyes, so they confyned
those that were detractors, and ill tongued men, into a secret place (far of
from all company) the space of half a year. Inso much as many times these lewd
mates chose rather to row in the galley iii. years, then to be exempt from
company, and speaking with any, but syx months. Much like unto this law did
Tiberius the emperor make an other, and condemned a great talker and rayler of
his tongue, and commanded straightly that he shoold never speak word, the
space of a whole year. And as ye history says, he remained domme, and never
spoke during the whole term: but yet that he did (with his domnes) more hurt
with nods, and signs with his fingers: then many other woold have done with
their ill tongues. By these two exaumples we may see, that since these naughty
tongs are not to be repressed by silence, in secret, nor to entreat them as
friends, nor by doing them good, nor by sending them to galleys, nor to make
them hold their peace, and to be as domme men: by my aduyce, I woold have them
banished (by general counsel) out of al colleges, counsels, chapters, towns
and common wealths. For we see daly by experience, that let an apple have
never so little a broose, that broose is enough to ^ott him quickly, if he be
not eaten in time. Demosthenes the philosopher was of great auctority for his
person, grave in manners, and condition, and very sentencious, and profound in
his words: but with these he was so obstinate, and wylfull, and such a talker
in all his matters, that all Greece quaked for fear of him. Whereupon all the
Athenians one day assembled in their hall, or common house, and there they
appointed him a great stipend of ye goods of the common wealth, telling him
that they gave him this, not that he shoold read, but because he shoold hold
his peace. Also this great and renowned Cicero, that was so valiant and
politic in martial affairs, so great a friend to the common weal of Rome, and
more over a prince of eloquence for ye latin tongue: though he was cruelly put
to death by Mark Antony, it was not for any fact committed against him, neither
for any wrong or injury he had done him, save only for that he enueied
against him, and spoke evil of him. Also the noble poet Salust, and famous
orator of Rome, was not hated of strangers, and not beloved of his own
neighbors for no other cause, but for yt he never took pen in hand to write,
but he ever wrote against the one, and never opened his mouth to speak, but
he alwais spoke evil of ye other. Plutarche touching this mai^er recites in
his books de republica yt amongst the^ of Lidia, in their publik weal it was
holden an inuiolat law, yt they should not put a murderer to death for kylling
of any, but yt they should only execut, and put him to torture, that would
defame his neighbor, or in any one word seem to touch him in honor or
estimation. So that those barbarous nation thought it more execrable so defame
a man, then to kill and murder him. And therefore I say, he that burns my
house, beats my person, and robs me of my goods, must needs do me great
dommage: but he yt takes upon him to touch my honor and reputacio^ with infamy,
I will say he offends me much, and that so greatly, as he may well stand in
fear of his life: For there is not so little an offense ^oon to a man of stout
courage, but he carries it ever after imprinted in his heart, till he have
revenged the villainy done him, even so in princes courts there the more
quarells, and debates, through evil tongues, and dishonest reports, then there
does for any play or shrewd turns yt are done. I know not what reason they
have to strike of his hand, ye first draws sword, and favors and leaves
him unpunished, that draws blood with his ill tongue. O what a happy good turn
were it for the common weal, if (as they have in all towns and well governed
policies penal laws prohibiting to wear or carry weapon) they had like laws
also to punish detractiue and wicked tongues. Surely there ca^ be none so
great a blot or vice in a noble man, knight, or gentleman of honest behauior
and countenance, as to be counted and reputed a tatler of his tongue, and
there wtal a detracter of others. But let not such deceive them selves,
thinking yt for their countenance or estates sake they be priuileged above
others, at their wills and pleasure to enlarge their tongues on whom they list
in such manner, but that their inferiors far, will as liberally speak of
them, yea and as much to their reproach, as they before had done of them:
reputing as much of their honesty and credit for their calling (being
inequiualent in estate or degree to the^) as they do of their dignity and
reputacion. At that time when I was a courtier, and lived in princes court,
there dyed out of the court a worthy knight, who at his noble funerals was
recommended of us all, and praised in his life to be a noble, valiant,
worthy, and wise man, and a good and devout christian, and cheefely above all
his noble and heroycall virtues, he was only landed and renowned, for that
they never hard him speak ill of any man. So one of the company that was
present, hearing this great praise of him, took upon him to say this of him.
If he never spoke ill of any, then did he never know what pleasure those have
that speak ill of their enemies. Which words when we hard, though we passed
them over with silence, yet was there none but was greatly offended at them,
and good cause why. For to say truly, the first degree of malignitie is, for a
man to take a felicyty in speaking ill of his neighbor. King Darius being at
dinner one day, there were put forth of the weighters and standers by, certain
arguments of the acts and doings of Alexander the great: in which dispute, one
Mignus (a Captayn of the king, and greatly in favor with him) was very earnest
against Alexander, and went too far in speech of him. But Darius perceiving
him thus passioned said to him: O Mignus hold thy tongue, for I do not bring
thee into ye wars with me that thou should infame Alexander, (and touch his
honor with thy tongue, but yt thou should with thy sweord overcome him, By
these examples, we may gather, how much we ought to hate detraction, and ill
speaking, syns we see that the very enemies the^ selves can not abide, to here
their enemies ill spoken of in their presence: and this is always observed of
the honorable, grave, and wise men that are of noble mynds. For suer each noble
heart dysdaigneth to be revenged of his enemy with his tongue, for his iniures
done him: if he cannot be revenged on him with his sweord. It is syttyng for
all in generally to be modest, and honest in their speech, but much more yt is
dew for him that embraces the favor and credit of his prince. For it is his
profession to do good, to help every man and to speak ill of no man. They have
such Centinells of spies upon them continually (which are officers in court and
about the prince) to mark what they speak and do, that treading once awry (how
little so ever it be) it is straight blown into the princes ears, and they
perhaps accused of that that they never thought, delyghtyng and taking great
pleasure to tell openly what they hard them say. Such therefore as are daily
courtiers, attendyng upon the prince, and infauor with him, must (if they mean
to continue that favor and credit) be gentle, and courteous in their words,
and bountiful to those that stand in need of them. Also the esteemed courtier
must beeware he do not only speak ill of no man, but also that he be not
too great a talker. For commonly these great talkers besides that they are not
esteemed, be also reputed of small judgment, and of simple counsel. Pithias,
that was the great gouerner, and Duke of the Athenian nation, was a noble
prince, beloved and feared, hardy and valiant, and yet in the end as says
Plutark, the abundance of words, obscured the glory of his heroical deeds.
Although these great talkers, and men too full of words, be of noble birth or
woorship, wealthy in possessions, and otherwise of auctority and estimacion,
yet nevertheless all that time they spend in speaking too much, others that
here them, occupye the same in deriding and scornyng of them. I beseech you
what greater reproach could a courtyer have, then to be called a babbler a
prater of his tongue, and a liar? For when he thynks every man is attentive,
and listening to him, it is quyte contrary: for even at that instant do they
laugh him to scorn, and yet this is nothing to the shame they do him
afterward. For those that talk to him, whilst he is thus babblyng, pots at
him with their mouths behind his back, nodde with their heads, holds down
their eyes, and soothes him in all that he says, and all this not to praise
or commend him: but to be meery afterward at the matter, when they are
togethers. And it is a sport to note, and here one of this great talkers, if
any man talk of war, of the liberal sciences, of hunting, or of husbandry,
he will straight leap into the matter, allthough he be utterly ignorant in
the thing preponed, taking upon him to reason of the matter, as if he were
very skillful, or master of the faculty, And to make the herers believe that,
that is true he says he brings in an example, saying that he has seen
yt, read yt, or hard yt, and all perhaps a stark lie, that he neither saw yt,
read yt, nor hard yt of any, but only devised of his own head, on a sodeyn,
under the color of troth to make a false lie. Acaticus ye philosopher, being
one day at a feast, where he neither spoke, nor offered once to speak: asked
after dinner what was ye occasion of his silence, answered them thus. It is
better for a man to know his time when to speak, then it is to know to speak.
For to speak well, is given us by nature: but to choose time to speak, proceeds
of wisedo^. Epimenides ye painter, after he had dwelt long time in Asia,
returned to Rhodes from whence he first departed, and because none of ye
Rhodians ever hard him speak any thing, either of that he had seen, or done
in Asia, they marueiled very much, and prayed him to discourse unto the^ some
part of that he had seen, and suffered in Asia. To whom he made this
answer. Two years I sulked the seas, abydyng the peril of the water, and
ten other years I was resient in Asia, to learn the perfection of a paynters
ark: syx other years I studied in Greece to accustom my self to be silent,
and now you would I shoold feed you with tales and news. O Rhodians, come to
me no more with any such motion: for you should come to my house to bye
pyctures, and not to here news. Albeit in so many years and in such far and
strange contreis yt could not be but Epimenides had seen many things worthy
to be recounted, and pleasant to here: yet he woold never tell the^ nor show
them: and suer herein he did like a good philosopher, and answered like a
wise and grave person. For in tellyng of strange things, and of diverse
countries, there are few that will believe them, and many that will stand in
doubt whether they be true or no. And therefore touching this matter also,
Pithagoras the philosopher was one day asked upon what occasion he made his
scholars use so great silence in his college, yt in two years after they were
entered, they might not speak. He answered thus. In other philosophers
schools they teach their disciples to speak, but in mine there is taught
nothing but to hold their peace. For in the whole world there is no better nor
higher philosophy, then to know to brydel the tongue. It is a marvelous thing
to see a man, that with time his beard and hears of his head become all white,
his face wythered, his ears deaf, his legs swollen, his breath stynk, his
spleen stopped, and his body faint and feeble with age, and all the parts
thereof consumed, save only the heart, and tongue, which we never see wax old
in manner, how aged or impotent so ever he be, but rather daily become green:
and that that is woorst of all is, that what evil the wretched heart thinks
in that crooked and miserable age, that does the accursed tongue with all
celeritie utter. There is a company of courtiers in the court, that presume to
be eloquent, and well spoken, and of courtly enterteignement, which when they
will talk of some pleasant matter, they must first tell you a lie, and surely
these kind of courtiers we may better call them detracters of others, then
cyuil enterteigners. Accursed be he that to the prejudice of his neighbor,
makes profession to be a courtly interteigner, and you shall hardly see none
of these recyted courtiers jest of any, but they have in secret spunne the
threede, to weaue a great cloth of malice. And yet we do these men great
honor and reverence, not for any good will we bear the^, but for yt we are
afraid of their ill tongs. And although to disse^ble otherwile, it is a grave
and wise man's part, yet for all yt we may not judge il of the^, since we see
ye best man's honor and credit commonly to be no greter nor less, then a
maligna^t person shall seem to use his tongue to speak of him. I remember there
was in the court in my time a noble man, noble of birth and person both, whom I
reproved diverse times (as his familiar friend) of his prodigal living, and ill
speaking. And he made me this answer* Truly sir, those yt report that I
speak ill of the^, it is them selves yt do yt of me: and if I follow them
therein, it is for nothing else, but to be a witness for the^, if any seek to
impugn their saiyngs: but suer of my self I never uttered, or devised word,
yt might be to ye prejudice of any. O what ill causes he, that speaks ill
of an other, he only offends not that begins, but he that assisteth
him, and much more he that hears him, and after publishes it: but above all
he that tells it abroad, and adds more then he hard. The favored of
princes must also think, that though they are prohibited to speak much, yet it
is most fyt and decent for them to be true and faithful secretaries. For there
is no thing ye prince priseth more, then ye secret breast of his favored
courtier. And therefore I say not without cause that they ought to be secret,
but most secret. For the esteemed courtier must have a better consideracion of
his princes secrets committed to him, then of ye benefits he receives of him.
Suer yt is no small, but a great and most necessary virtue in a man, to be
close, and of few words, and so secret in deed, that he make no more
countenance of that was told him privily, then if he had never hard it spoken
of. I know an other manner of people so prone to speak ill, that they cannot
keep secret their own faults, much less others faults, publishing them in
every corner. Cecilius Metellus being asked one day of a Centucion, what he
meant to do the next day followyng: answered thus. Think not Centurion that
those things I am determined to do, my hands shall so lightly discover: for I
am of this mind, if I knew yt my shirt had any knowledge of that I will do to
morrow, I woold put it of, and throw it straight in the fire and see it burned
before my face. It is not a like trust, to put money into one man's hands of
trust, and to commit secrets to ye breast of an other, and this to be true we
see it plainly, that the prince delivers his goods and treasure to the
custody of many, but his secrets he commytteth only to one. The favored of
princes ought to be so secret, that what so ever they see the prince do or
say (be it in the presence of dyners, and that they are told of it by many)
Yet they ought not to be acknowen of it. For in deed the prince speaks many
things commonly for his pleasure, which being reported again of the favored
courtier, wilbee thought true, and most certain. Therefore speaking generally
of this matter I say, that surely friends are greatly bound to keep the
secrets of their friends: For that day I discover my intent to any, the self
same I make him lord of my liberty. Therefore let that man think he has
woonne a marvelous treasure, that has a secret friend. For without doubt it is
no such matter of importance, to keep treasure saflye locked up in a chest, as
it is to commit and trust secrets to the heart of an other. Plutark writes,
that the Athenians having wars with king Phillip because there came certain
letters of king Phillips to their hands (intercepted, by their scouts) directed
and sent unto his wife Olimpa: Which they no sooner understood, but they
presently returned again safely sealed, and untouched of them, as they came
first unto them saying: that sith by their law they were bound to be secret,
they would not reveal the secrets of others, notwithstanding they were their
mortal enemies, as king Phillip was to the^: and therefore they woold neither
see them, nor read the^ openly. Diodorus Siculus says also, that among the
Egiptians it was a criminal act for any man, to bewray the secrets of an
other, which was proved true by thexample of a priest, that in the temple of
the gods Isis had deflowered a virgin, and they both trusting to ye
fydelitie of an other priest, making their love known unto him, even as they
were in Venus sweet delights, he not regarding any longer their secrets, in
ipso facto exclamed and cried out, and thereupon co^uict and apprehended by ye
justice, these poor lovers were myserably executed, and this spightful and
unfortunate priest condignely banished. And this banished priest co^plaining of
thiniust sentence, saying, yt that he reveled, was in favor of ye religion,
and for ye behoof of the common wealth, ye judge au^swered him thus. If thou
had known their offense of thy self, without their notice geeue^ thee, you
had had reason to have complained of our sentence, but since they trusted
thee with their doings, and thou gave the^ thy word and promis to be secret,
if thou had called to mind ye bond thou were bound to them in, and yt thy
self did freely without their co^pulsio^ submit thy self unto, thou wooldst not
once have dared to have published the fact as thou have done. Plutark in his
book de exilio says, yt a man of Athens once demanded an Egiptian (disciple
of a philosopher) what he had under his cloak, au^swered him thus. Truly thou
have studied little, and born away less, although thou art an Athenian born,
sith thou see yt I carry secretly yt thou demaundst, because thou nor no other
should know it, and yet thou ask it of my self, what it is that I carry.
Anasillus yt was a captayn of ye Athenians, was taken of ye Lacedaemonians, and
put to ye torture, because he should tell that he knew, and what the king
Agesilaus his Land master did, to whom he gave this answer. You
Lacedemonia^s have liberty to disme^ber me, and heaw me in pieces: but so have
not I to reuele my lord and masters secrets. For in Athens we use rather to
dye, then to be wray the secrets of our friend. King Lisimachus, entreated the
philosopher Philipides very earnestly, yt he woold come and dwell with him: but
he made them this answer. I woold be very glad to be in your company,
knowi^g you to be a fauorer of philosophy: and if you will go to ye wars I will
follow you: and if you trust me with your goods, I will keep them carefully, and
faithfully: if you have children, I will teach them with al my heart: if you will
use my counsel in your affairs, I will geeue you the best I can. And if you will
also geeue me ye charge of your common wealth. I will govern it with my best
discretion. Only one thing I will request you that you will never command me,
yt is, not to make me partaker of your secrets. For it might happen that what
you had told me in secret, your self unawares at a time might tell it openly,
and yet not think of it: and being afterward told you by some other, you
woold presently enter into suspect yt it came to knowledge by me. This
philosopher woold first indent with the prince (before he woold come to his
service) that he shoold never here any of these things, the knowledge whereof
brings many a man to their end, or at the least to some great mischife: only
to show us ye imminent peril and danger the secretary of a prince stands
in. For our heart is such a friend of news, that every hour it feels a
thousaund temptations to utter that to others, that was delivered to it of
secret. In this our age we do not use to keep secrets so well, as in old
time the Grecians were wont, sith we see by experyence, that if one friend
have to day told his friend a thing in secret, to morrow, yea perhaps the
self same night before, it was told amongst the neighbors.

There are also some kind of men so desirous to here news, that to know it,
they will swear a thousand oaths never to reuele in again to any. But so soon
as they know it, they are like unto the blood hounds, that follow the dear now
here now there smelling with their noses, till they have found the hurt dear,
then they open, and bay for their master. Therefore I counsel, and exhort all
wise and discreet men, that they do not accompany with those whom they know
are not secret. For the hurt that comes by them, consists not only to tell
that they know, see, and here: but with this they tell that they have imagined
of their own wicked and malicious heads. It cannot be otherwise, but being
men, we are also subject to the frailty of a man, as for example. To fall
sometimes into ye sin of the flesh, and in that to forget the sin of
gluttony, and to have small consideracion of that of sloth, to be assured in
that of auaryce or with that to be overcome with passion and rage, or to be
puffed up in the sin of pride. And if perhaps by misfortune any one chance
into such man's company, that has but part, or all these conditions, and such
one as do discover and disclose both his own secrets and others to, what other
can there be hoped of, then a fire enflamed in his good fame and reputacion,
and a co^tagious plague and pestilence in his house. For that that I have hard,
seen, and read, yea and also proved, I say and affirm, that there is no bread
so il spent, as that that is geeuen to the servants which open and reuele their
masters secrets: And sure it may be said, that such are not servants that
serve them, but traitors that betray them, and sell their masters liberty. And
it is of such importance, for the favored of princes, to keep secret, and not
to reuele any part of the princes secrets, that every man must think, that when
the prince tells them any thing in secret, he tells it not alone unto
them, but rather he confesses it to them. Princes being men (as in deed
they are) and much busyed with the cares of the common wealth, yt cannot be,
but when they are withdrawn a part into their privy chamber, they will both
play, talk, sleyt, sygh, laugh, be angry, threaten, and make, much again of
some before others: All which things though they do before their servants in
secret, it is not their pleasure, neither will they like, it should be told
abroad amongst their subjects. And sure they have great reason, for men of
grauyty and authority, do not lose their reputacion for doing things grave,
and of good example: but they are justly noted, when publicly they will show
any lightness or folly, how little so ever it be. Not only those that be in
aucthority and favor about the prince but such other officers of the court, and
servants of household of the prince also, ought not to tell nor reuele any thing
they see their prince do. For they may be well assured, that the prince wilbee
more offended and displeased, to have that he does in his privy chamber told
abroad, by those of the pryuy chamber, or other whom it pleases him to make
familier with him: then he woold be, if his treasorers and receivers should
rob him of his treasure. It was told to Denis the Siracusan on a time, that
Plato the philosopher was at the chamber door to speak with him: and he
presently sent Bias one of his privy chamber (that he loved well) to him, to
know what he would with ye king, and Plato asked Bias what Denis did, and he
au^swered that he lay stark naked upon a table, which when Denis understood,
he was so offended with Bias, that he commanded forthwith he should be
beheaded, saying first these words unto him. I will yt like a traitor yt be
beheaded, since thou have traitorously betrayed me, presuming to disclose ye
secrets of my chamber. For I sent thee not to Plato to tell him what I did, but
to know what he woold of me. Now princes familiars and beloved of them, as
they must be very circumspect and heedeful yt they tell no man ye princes
secrets, so they must be much careful yt they tell it not chiefly to women,
yea though they were their own wives. For as women are very good and
profitable, to look to things of household, and safly to lock up their husbands
goods: so are they on ye other side very dangerous for a man to commit any
secrets to the^. For notwtstanding a woman know, yt in reueling the secrets of
her husband, she puts her life in peril, ye honor of her husband, the
loss of her children, ye reputacion of her house and kynred, and peradventure
ye peace and tra^quility of ye common weal: yet had she rather dye, then she
shoold not utter yt she knows. And many times for no other respect, but to
make these weome^ believe yt hears her, yt she only commands her husband
and al besides in her house. Well, I will enlarge my self no further of this
matter, for if I woold but geeue my pen leave to write yt I know, I shoold find
lyme and sand enough to buyld a tower as high as Babylon. But to end my
purpose, I will speak this one word, and yt is, that I counsel and exhort,
and with al my heart request princes familiars, or servants, yt they commit not
their princes secrets to any, how great a fre^d or near kinsman so ever he
be to the^. For they may be assured, yt since they refuse to keep secret
that ye prince commands the^, yt much less their friend will keep it secret
for any request they make to him. If thou can not keep yt secret, that to open
it, imports ye loss of thy favor and credit, and happily thy life also: how
can you think an other will do it, yt in tellyng it, wins both honor and
credyt.

A comendation of troth, which professed courtiers ought to embrace, and in no
respect to be found defective in the contrary, telling one thing for an other.
Cap. xx.
EPimenides the philosopher, being requested of ye Rhodians to tell the^ what yt
virtue was they called verity, he au^swered the^ thus. Verity my friends, is a
thing wc ye gods above al other profess, and her virtue is such, yt it warmeth
ye heavens, lights ye earth, maintayns justice, and governs ye common weal,
and suffers no ill thing in her, making plain and clear al doutfull and
hidden things. The Corinthians asked ye like question also of Chilo ye
philosopher, what veryty was, who au^swered yt it was a perdurable pillar,
never diminishi^g, nor decresi^g: a buckler or shield impassable, a fair time
yt is never troubled, an army yt never perishes, a flower yt never withers,
a sea yt never fears fortune, and a suer haue^ where never was shipwrak.
Anaxarchus ye philosopher, was also demanded of ye Lacedaemonians, what verity
was, who au^swered that it was a health without sickness, a life without end, a
iuleppe and syrop yt heals al, a sun yt never darkneth, a moon without
eclipse, an herb yt never dries, a gate that is never shut, and a way that
never werieth man. The like was asked of Eschines ye philosopher touching
verity by ye Rhodians. And he said, that it was a virtue without wc al force was
weakened, Justice corrupted, humility fained and disse^bled, patiens
insupportable, chastity vayn, liberty lost, and pyty superfluous. The like was
also demanded of Pharmacus ye philosopher by the Romans. And his answer was,
that veryty was a true center wherein al things reposed, a card to sail by, to
direct ye pylot and mariners, a wisdom to hele and recure every man, and a
present remedy for all evils, a height in ye top whereof every man rests, and a
bright light to lighte^ ye whole world. And surely this makes me think that
these philosophers were great friends and lovers of verity, sins they did so
much enrich, and sublime the same, with so many rare and excellent titles. But
omitting now these philosophers, who have truly spoken that they knew: let us
come speak of him, that above all the world has exalted veryty, which was the
divine word, and that was Ihesus Christ, the only begotten son of god, and
true glass of eternity, who being asked the self same thing of Pylate, said
not to him, I am wisdom, neither Justice, nor chastity, nor paciens,
humility, nor charity: But only said to him, I am verity, to let him
understand, yt every creature might be partaker of yt verity. But our lord
Ihesus Christ, was not partaker of yt verity: but ye sole and only possesser of
ye same, he being ye very truth it self. O, of how many is this virtue
desired, and of how few (yea most few) observed. For in effect it is nothing
else, but a mark whereat all good me^ shoot with their eyes, and al il and wicked
persons lose their sight. The emperor Augustus in ye triumph he made of Mark
Antony, and his love Cleopatra, amongst others brought to Rome an Egiptia^
priest, of 60. years of age, and ye senate being informed of a surety that days
of his life he never told lie, they agreed not only to restore him to liberty
but to make him high priest of their temple, and to erect a stature of him,
among the noble and princely parsons of Rome. Sparthianus writes, that in the
time of Claudian Emperor of Rome, there deceased a citizen of Rome called
Pamphilus, whose doings after his death examined, it was manifestly proved, yt
he never spoke one true word all his life time, but always lied in that he
said. Which related unto the Emperor, he commanded his body should not be
buried, his goods should be confiscate, and his house rased to the foundation,
and his wife and children for ever banished Rome and all her territories, to
the end there should remayn no memory to the common wealth, of so pestiferous
and venomous a beast. At that time when these two things thus happened, the
Romans and Egyptians were mortal enemies, and therefore by these examples we
may see, of what force and power this virtue of veryty is, sith the romans
made a stature to their enemy, only for that he was a true and just man: and
depryued of sepulture their native child, and a Romayn born, for that he was a
liar. A true man may go in any place where he lysteth, freely without
interruptio^, accompanied with all men not fearing to be accused of any, and
may with saftie reprove the vicious and ill persons: and finally to conclude,
he may without the fear of any speak in the face of the world, and show his
face amongst the best. If a man will choose a friend, he need not be
inquisityue if he be wise, just, chaste, careful, courageous, or noble, but
only if he be true of his word. And if that be so, it follows that all
virtues and honesty must abound in him. Helius Sparthianus recyteth of the life
of Traian the Emperor, that being one night at supper, and accompanied with
noble men at his board, they argued of the fydelyty of friends, and infydelity
of enemies, whom Traian answered: That he never had friend in his life but he
was good, true, honest, and faithful: whereupon his lords besought him that yt
woold please him to tell them the occasion of his good hap in this. And he
answered thus. The cause why I have ever been so fortunat herein was this, I
never woold choose to my friend a liar, and covetous man. For in him that
reigns avarice, and lying, there can never dwell perfyt friendship. Those that
are honest, and like so to be reputed, must endeavor them selves to speak well
allways, and ever to say that that is true: and if they will not do this for
conscience sake, let the^ do it yet to avoid ye shame that follows them. For
there can be no greater mockry or dispight done to a man, then openly to make
him know he has lied. We see ye child when he perceives he has told a
lie, he blusheth straight, and is ashamed: much more ought men grown of
years, whose face is covered with hears, not only blush, but shame to tell a
lie. Many times I think what a great greef the merchant suffers every hour
