not to be counted a liar, when he utters his ware, and suer he does it
but because he woold not lose his credit. And lo here why they swear commonly
by ye faith of a merchant to be more assured, where to ye contrary we see
many other, that in apparaunce seem to be honest and grave men, that use not
that manner: but rather they will stick no more to tell you a lie, then to lose a
wheat grayn. But here I speak not, neither do mean to touch those that are in
deed virtuous and good men: but I speak of those that thinks them selves
honest, and yet be not god knows. And therefore we may be assertayned,
that a merchant esteems more his goods and marcha^dise, then a lier does
his honor, otherwise honesty. There is nothing that preiudiceth troth so much,
as a tattling tongue that never lies: being in manner impossible, that amongst
many words some lie be not enterlaced. All things consists not in other
more, or less, save only in the use that men have of yt. For if a man do use
to eat little, he always goes from the table: if we use to sleep little, we
also leave our bed: And if we accustom our selves also to lie, we shall
have it in such a continual use, as though we woold we shall never leave it
after. For there are diverse sorts of men, that as they accustom them selves to
eat and drink often times in a day, so do they use to lie every hour. But I ask
what is ye greatest and most parfyt thing in this life, that a man whilst he
lives may enjoy. I dare boldly say, that it is neither nobility, great
parentage, nor favor, neither the great estate, health, nor riches: but rather
that it is the sole honor, wc tatlers and liars may never enjoy, because they
are never credited, nor believed in their words. What fame, credyt, honor,
reputacion, or good can he have, out of whose mouth there comes nothing but
lies? A liar deserves credit of no man, neither that any man shoold deal with
him in any thing, much less commit any matter of trust into his hands, no nor
love him, nor accept of him, but rather as detracter, and defamer of men's good
name, we should banish him our company. Anniball that was ye mighty prince of
ye Carthagians, so valiant in warlick prowes, so hardy to follow yt, and
therewithal so fortunat to overcome his enemies: was yet notwithstanding
blamed of Titus Liuius, and reputed for a malignant and perjured person. For
he never gave that he promised to his friends, neither ever kept any covenant
or agreement made with his enemies. Such was not Gneus Pompeius (son to
Pompeie the great) with whom Octauian and Mark Antony (both, his mortal
enemies) being at supper with him on the sea: Menodorus the captayn of his army
sent him word, if it were his pleasure, he woold so lively have hoyst up the
sails of the ship, that he would soon have peryshed them, or sunked the ship
they were in. To which message Pompeie gave this au^swer. Thou shall tell
Menodorus my captayn, that if I were Menodorus as he is, that never knew what
trothment, I would have followed his advice, and have done that he sends to
me for: but if he were Pompeius as I am, which keeps my word and promise
with all men, such a thought and treason would never have occupied his head.
Words suer worthy of so noble a prince, son of so great and worthy a
father. Herodotus writes also, that when the Egiptians woold make any new
amyty betwixt them selves, or be in league, and confederate them selves with
strangers, they used to bynd their thombs hard to the thombs of those with
whom they woold join in frendshyp, and then with an instrument pricked every
one of their thombs yt the blood spurted out, wc they sucked ye one ye other with
their tongue: inferring thereby, yt they woold rather shead their whole blood,
then in one jot to falsify and break yt friendship promised between the^. Is it
not a goodly thing to hear him yt swears by ye mass, of mine honesty, so
god ketch me, by my good sooth, by cock and pie, and other like nyse oaths,
only under simplicity thereof to make you believe a lie he will tell you, wc in
deed we shoold least then believe, when he is most ruff in his oaths. For
it is most certain, the more a liar enforces his words with abundance of
oaths, ye less he is to be believed. For that is a plain demonstration, yt
it is a prepensed lie he woold make us believe for a truth. It is a sport to
see a true man, and a liar in argument together: for the true man enforces his
words none otherwise but thus. Truly friend, it is even thus as I tell thee,
thou may if thou will believe me. And ye other to defend and maintayn his
lie, he will invoke for witness all the saints in heaven, and as many relics
as are on ye earth, yea and all the devils of hell: so that for defense of the
truth, it suffices to stand fast on his feet: but for defense of a lie, he
must run through ye whole world. If I were a king or prince, to throw the
beloved out of favor, to put my men out of service, to deprive men of their
office and dignity, or to disgrade a knight of his order of knighthood, or to
geeue no more faith nor credit to an other: I woold desire no better occasion
or testimony, then once to take him with a lie. And I woold thynk it less ill,
that the fathers shoold rather pardon a great fault in their children, ye friend
in his friend, and the master in his servant, the^ to bear with them in one lie.
For by time the wings of sin is cut: but to lie is of such condition, the
elder a man waxes, the more force and power it has of him. It is not enough
for a man to be free of this vice, but he must also fly and sequester him
self from the fellowship of those, that are possessed with that foul and
inueterate error. For it is commonly seen, when a man woold bring out a sodein
lie, to geeue it more credit, he will avouch his friend for a witness, saying
he knows yt, and was present with me. Now those that hears this famous
lie, and knows the very troth in deed of the matter as it was, condemns
his friend he avouches (although he be innocent in the matter) for that he
is brought in for testimony, as they do this notorius and shameless liar. I
should ly also for compagny, if I should deny to tell you, that, being in the
court upon a time in a good presence, a friend of mine stuck not to forge a lie
amongst others, and said that he had sailed in a ship made all of the canes of
Synamon, and he avouched me for a witness, affyrmyng that I was likewise
with him in his company in the ship: and I to save his honor (he being my
very friend) being ashamed he should incur the name of a liar, was compelled
seriously to confyrm his tale with him, whereof I repented me after with all
my heart. For thereby I was in secret noted of the hearers, to be as great a
liar as he. Also an other time when I went to preach at ye court, being
diseased of ye gout, I walked up and down with a staff of a reed to stay me with
al, the self same person I told you of before, told amongst ye prelates yt were
in the chapel where I preached, that he had geeuen me a reed or cane to
walk withal, that from one knobb to an other, it woold hold three great pottes
of wine. Lo now by my example you may gather what shame and dishonesty an
honest and virtuous man sustaineth, to be a friend and co^panyon of so
shameless and horrible a liar. For to be plain, I was brought to this pass,
by means of this friend of mine, that I coold not tell what I shoold do, but
when I hard him begin to speak, to fly from him, and leave him, because I
woold not be reputed a like of reputacio^ with him. Howbeit in thend I was
forced to use this pollycy: that what he had openly avouched me a witness in,
secretly again I woold excuse my self, and deny yt. But now returning to our
matter again, I say: That these courtiers, and familiers of princes, ought to
exyle and banish from them this abominable crime of lyeng.

For if a mean gentleman or simple plebeyan happen some times to tell one thing
for an other, it is but taken of the hearers straight for a simple ly. But
being spoken by one of the favored of the court, or other gentleman of
reputation, it is thought a kind of treason. For like as betwixt god, and the
sinner, our savior Ihesus Christ is our only mean and mediator, being called
upon by the priest, even so betwixt the king and his subjects, that are suitors
to his majesty: those that are in favor with the prince, are mediators for
them. Now therefore, if these priests be double in their words, and dissemblers
in that they speak, how shall the sins of the one be pardoned, and the
business of the other dispatched. O woeful and unhappy sinner, that puts his
sins into the hands of a naughty and wicked prist, and like wise unfortunate
and miserable is the poor suter, that commits his affaiers to the trust and
dispatch of a lying and dissembling officer. There are many officers in Princes
courts, that tells the poor suitors still they will dispatch them, but when
it comes to the push to follow the matter, al his fair words are then but
wynd, and in deed they make an art of it, to speak all men fayer, to promis
much, and to perform nothing, weaning with their sweet flattering words to
win the hearts and good wills of all, little regarding the great expense and
loss of time of ye poor suter, much less also respecting their own honor,
honesties, and credyt. Sure it were less dishonor for them, to be counted
rough and churlish, then to be bruted for liars, and breakers of their promys.
The officer of the princes palace, that is a dissembler, and liar in his
words and doings, he may for a time maintain his suits, and go through with
his matters: but in the end, his tretcheries perceived, him self, his fautor,
and all his dealing lie in the dust, and are utterly overthrown. O how many
have I seen rise in court of nothing, to great matters and offices, and this
not through their painful service, but altogeethers by means of their deceit
and flattery they cunningly used: not exalted also for their merits, but only
by a subtle mean and policy they had to draw water to their myll: not for any
good conscience they had, but only for their great diligence used in their
practices. And all this not without ye prejudice of others, but rather to ye great
hurt and utter undoing of their neighbor: and not for any bounty they had to
give liberally, but a gredy and covetous desire to get: not for any needful
business, but to have those yt are superfluous: and not for to reliue ye poor
and needy, but only to satisfy their insatiable apetits: and infyne, their
account cast, we have seen after their death their goods co^fiscated, their
servants dyspersed, and gone away, and their children for ever undone. So yt in
brief there was no more memory of the^ in this world, and god grant also yt in
ye other life their souls were not damned. Courtiers may easily with their
favor and credit attain to great possessions, as the Judges may also in
robbing, the counselors in pleading, and maintaining naughty causes, the
captains in powling the prince of the soldiers wages, the merchants in their
false weights and measures, and their brokers, in telling lies out of all
measure. But in thend of their journey, and pilgrimage, they may be assured
that the souls of the fathers shall not only be damned in hell, but the goods
also shall be taken from their children. And that yt is truly and justly gotten
by ye honest industry and travel of the man, with a good zeal and holy intent,
and to a good and just end: it is written that it shall be of long continuance,
and by the permission of god, and prayer of the people, it shall also prosper,
and increase. For the true gotten goods, achiued by swet and labor of man, god
does always prosper and augment and therefore continuing our matter I say,
that ye princes officers ought to determine with them selves, to be upright in
all their accions and doings, and above all, true and just of their words: wc
doing they shall be sure to be beloved of all, not alone of them that pass
under their lee, but also of those whom they have denied favor. And also they
need not to be afraid to speak boldly in all places where they come, besides
that they shall be reverenced of all men. Where to ye contrary, if he be a
liar, a babbler, and dissembler, there are few that will fear them, much less
love them, and least of all do them reverence, or honor. And although we
cannot deny, but that these officers of the court, and other men of auctority
be waited upon, visited, accompanied, reverenced, and honored of much sort of
men: yet it were a folly for us to believe, yt their trayn and attendants do
them all that honor and reverence, for any desire they have to do them any
service: but only they use all that curtesy, and capping, to get them selves
and their suits quickly dispatched. And this to be true, we see it daily in
experience. For when these suitors have atchiued their suit and desire, they do
not only leave to accompany him, and attend upon him, but more over they get
the^ home, without either thanking of them, or once taking their leave of him. If
all those that have function or office of estate or dignity, (having charge of
the dispatch of great and weighty matters, being also liars and dissemblers in
their doings) knew yt ill reports that go of them, and how they conde^pne
their corrupt and naughty co^scie^ces: me thinks it impossible (if they be
not altogether graceles) but they must needs either change condition and
estate, or else quyte geeue up their rooms and offices. For they are in every
man's mouth called bablers, liers, disse^blers, traitors, periurers, miserable,
auaricious, and vicious. And yet a worser thing then all this, and that is:
whylest they live, a thousand co^playns of him: and after they are dead and
buried, they take up their bones out of the grave to hang the^ up upon a
gybbet. For thus says the proverb. Such life, such end. So that we may say,
that to these officers above recyted, rests nothing but only these goodly
rytles. And heereunto we may add also, that officers of like condition to
them, need not to have any to accuse them, neither yet to punish the^: For a
time will come one day, that they will plunge themselves so deep into a sea of
troubles, that it cannot be chosen, but they must needs at last drown, and
utterly perish, or at the least to be driven into the haven of their greatest
enemies, so that they shall carry the burden of their own wickedness, and be
condingly chastised with their own folly. Therefore I pray all those that shall
read these writings of mine, to observe them in their heart, and imprint them
well in mind: being a matter of such morality and wisdom, that it can hardly
be vnderstandid of any, but of such as first have had some proof thereof.
Helius Spat^hianus writes that there was sometime a senator in Rome called
Lucius Torquatus, who was a tyrant, a dissembler, a great liar, and very
seditious, deuysyng only to set discord between the emperor Tytus, and the
people: who being many times complained upon by the people unto Tytus, he
answered them thus. I pray you good people, let no man seek to reprove him,
persuade him, threaten, nor punish him: for he is so wicked, and perverse in all things, that I trust in the gods one day his own crooked and naughty
condition, shall make revenge and satisfaccion of all the mischiefs he has
done me: wc was a wonderful thing in this prince, that for an injury of such
importance as that was, he woold have no other revenge of him, but refer al
to that he hoped to see by his own ill nature. And sure the matter well
considered, he had good reason to do yt. For a wicked person is of this
condition, that after he has once begone to do evil, he never cease daily
to do worse (if he be not reclaimed by some honest man) until such time as
unawares (not looking to him self) he utterly falls to ruyn and perdition. So
that we may aptly compare an ill man, to a ca^dell, wc after it is once light,
it never leaves burning, till it have made an end of it self. In great and
weighty matters sometimes, such as have the dispatchyng of them, are wont to
speak one word for an other, and also to make some faint promises to their
suitors, not in respect to lie to them nor deceive them: but to prolong them
longer in suit, to increase their gaigne the more. Which I must say they ought
not to do, much less once to think it. When the favored courtier or officer
of the prince is moved in any matter by ye suter, let him consider well if it
be any thing that may displease ye prince, be it never so little: for they
must take great heed that they tell not princes, nor their servants, any thing
yt they know may be displeasant to their years: but only that, yt shall be both
pleasant to ye ear, profitable to ye purse, and there withal, that it be
true and necessary to be told and looked to. For there is no greter
destruccio^ to ye common weal, then to bring false reports unto ye king of his
affairs. It is one of the gretest kinds of treason yt can be, for a prince to
disclose ye secrets of his heart to his favored courtier, and for him again to
tell ye prince nothing but lies, and tales. How great a friend so ever the
prince be to his favored courtier, the beloved courtier ought not to presume to
advance him self to tell, or make his prince believe one thing for an other.
For the matter afterward discovered, and the troth known, it shall not be
enough for him in his excuse to tell the prince yt he made him believe so, only
to satisfy his friend. For the king may justly tell him, that it is but an
excuse, and that he meant no other but to deceive him. For princes ears and
conditions, are so delicate: that I am bold to admonish the^ that are his
familyers, and beloved of him, that they endeavor them selves always to speak
(with all humble duity and reverence) that that is true, yea though in secret
it pleases the prince to be merry with them. This is ever true: he that is a
friend of verity, is also of justice: and he that is a friend of justice, is
also of the common weal: and he that is a friend of the common weal, is ever
endued with a good conscience: and he that has a good conscience,
consequently is of a good life, he that is of a good life, is also of a good
same, and beloved of all. Albeeit we cannot deny, but that his enemies will
ever speak ill of him: yet we may say also, that they can never hurt nor
condemn him: but rather he shoold be counted a fool of all men, that will
go about or seek to be his enemy, who is honest in his doi^gs, true in his
words, modest in his behavior, beloved, and well thought of of al. Therefore
he puts him self into a great peril, that dare make him self a companion,
and fellow in doings, with a wise and virtuous man. For he must think, yt
acco^panying with such a man, he acco^panyeth not his person alone, but also
ye virtues that reign in him: and if he do repugne and gainsay reasonable
things, he shall straight show him self to come of a wicked race, and to be
plunged and rooted in all malice. Now to ye end we may leave nothing beehind,
that may serve to advise and counsel this our favored courtier, I say also:
that there are many other in favor with the prince, that often times do procure
the prince to geeue offices of dignity, and realty of the realm, sometimes to
their kinsfolks, otherwhiles to their friends, and afterward to their servants
also: wc perhaps are so unmeet and unworthy for them, that neither their merits
shall deserve to have them, nor their knowledge and experience also fit, for
so weighty an administration. And they do not procure these offices for them,
for that they are wise, and capable: but only to advance them above others, and
because they are very troublesome and importunat. I am sorry to write it, and
much more to see it, that offices are not geeuen now for ye benefit of the
common wealth, but to recompense those of whom the favored courtier has
received pleasure, or else to satisfy the importunacy of his servants of his own
house. But by process of time it might happen (by means of their skillesse rule)
that ye king woold take from them altogether their offices, or remove them from
one place to an other, although they were never well settled in a town, and
commodiously. And being the princes pleasure to do thus, the wise and beloved
courtier must take heed he do not contrary ye king, much less take upon
him to defend the ill government of those officers, hoping thereby to come to
greater honor. For it were less hurt for him, ye officer lost his estate and
office, then he his credit and reputation. Therefore those in favor and
auctority ought to content them selves with the prince, the servants with their
masters, and the parents and kinsfolks with the princes officers, for that
they procured them these offices at ye kings hands, with the ill wills of many:
without that they further prease, and importune the^, to suborn their faults. For
after that ye doings of these worthy officers be once discovered to be
naught and corupted, it is impossible by any means to make them good before ye
prince, with whom all ye means the parents and kinsfolks of such persons can
make, cannot stead the^ to bring them to their first honor, by their own folly
lost. And now to end this our present volume of the favored courtier, I do
assure al ye beloved courtiers, that if god shall find purity in their souls,
ye common weal justice in their house, and the king troth in their mouths, and
fidelity in their hearts, the good and honest men grace in their favor, and that
the ill and wicked boast them selves no more of their authority and office, and
that ye poor shall praise them for their good woorks, and the king also find
them faithful servants, I will at this present with mine own hand geeue the^
such faith and assurance, that they shall need never to fear that god will
forsake them, nor that men can hurt them, and that they shall never be detected
of any infamy, overthrown by any misfortune, neither put out of favor and
credit with their prince at any time.

Finis.
Here follows certain other letters written by Marcus Aurelius, Selected
out of the Spanishe copy, not written in the French tongue.
Of the huge monstre seen in Scicily in the time of Marcus Aurelius: And of
the letters he wrote with blood upon a gate. Cap. i.
IN the year of the foundation of Rome.720. and.xlii. of the age of Marcus
Aurelius, and two years before he took possession of the Empire, the twenty
day of August, about the going down of the Sun, in the Realm of Sicill in
the City of Palermo (a port of the Sea) there chanced a thing perilous to
them that saw it then, and no less dread full to those which shall hear it
now. Whiles they of Palermo were celebrating a great feast with much joy,
that they had vanquished the navy of the Numidians, the pirates dividing their
booty, were prevented by the magistrates of the city, who commanded the
whole spoil to be laid up till the wars were finished: for such was the
law of the I Will. And truly it was a just law, for oftentimes the only let why
the peace is not made, between princes, is because there wants riches to
satisfy the domages done in wars. When all the people were returned home
unto their houses to supper (for it was in the Summer) there appeared an hughe
monster in the city in this form. He seamed to be of the length of three
cubits, his head was balde, so that his scull did appear. He had no ears,
save only two holes in his neck, whereby men judged that he heard: he had
two wrythen horns like a goat, his right arm was longer then his left, his
hands were like the feet of horses, without throat, his shoulders and his head
were both of one height, his shoulders shone as does the scales of fishes, his
breast was all rough of here, his face in all things was like unto a man, save
that it had but one eye which was in the midst of his forehead. In his nose
there was but one nosethril. From the middle downwarde there was nothing
seen, because it was all covered, he satte on a chariot with four wheles,
which was drawn with four beasts, that is, two Lions before, and two Bears
behind. No man could tell of what wood the chariot was made. In fashion it
differed nothing from those which other men do accustomably use. Within the
chariot stood a great chauldron with ears, wherein the monstre was, wherefore
it could not be seen but from the middle upward. It wandered a great space in
the city from one gate to an other, castinge out sparks of fire. The fear
was so great throughout all the city, that some women with child were with
great danger delivered, and others being faynte hearted fell down dead. And
all the people both men and women great and small ran to the temples of
Jupiter, Mars, and Februa, with doleful clamoures and cries making their
importunate prayers. At the same time, all these rouers were lodged in the
governors palace of the city, whose name was Solyno, borne at Capua, where
also the riches was kept. After the monstre had been in all parts of the
city (or in the most part thereof) it came to the palace where the pirates
were, and cut one of the Lions ears of, and with the blood thereof wrote
these letters upon the palace gate which was shut R. A. S. P. I. P. These
letters were of diverse men diversely interpreted so that the interpretations
were mo then the letters. And in the end, a woman prophetess greatly esteamed
for her science, (to whom God had given this secret knowledge) opened the true
meaning of these letters, saying R. signifies Reddite, A. aliena, S. si
vultis. P. propria, I. in pace, P. possidere. Which altogethers is to say.
Render unto other that which is theirs, if you in quiet will possess your
own. Truly the pirates were wonderfully afraid of this sudden commandment,
and the woman was highly commended for her exposition. This being done, the
monstre went the same night out of the City unto a high hill called Iamicia,
and there stood for the space of three days in the sight of the city, the
Lions with terrible voices roaring, the Bears with no less fearful cries
ragyng, and finally the monstre most dreadful flames casting. During all this
time there was neither bird seen in the air, nor beast in the fields. And
the people offered such great sacrifices unto their Gods, that they brake the
veins of their hands and feet, and offered the blood thereof to see if they
could appease their wrathes. These three days being passed, there appeared in
the element a marvelous dark cloud, which seamed to darken the whole earth,
and there with it began to thunder and lighten so terriblye, that sundry
houses fell to the ground, and infinite men ended their lives. And last of
all there came such a flame of fire from the monstre, that it brent both the
palace where the rouers were, and all other things that were therein, so that
all was consumed with fire: yea the very stones them selves. The tempest was
so great, that there fell above two thousand houses, and there died more then
ten thousand persons. In this place where this monstre was on the top of the
hill, the emperor edified a sumptuous temple to the god Jupiter in perpetual
memory of the same. Whereof afterward Alexander emperor, having war with
the people of that Isle made a strong castle.

Of that which chanced unto Antigonus a citezen of Rome, in the time of
Marcus Aurelius. Cap. ii.
AT the same time when this woeful chance happened in the Isle, there dwelled a
Roman in the same city called Antigonus, a man of a noble blood, and well
stricken in age, who with his wife and daughter were banished two years before
from Rome. The cause of his banishment was this. There was an old laudable
custom in Rome instituted, by Quintus Cincinatus the dictatour, that two of
the most ancient senators should ^o with ye censour newly created (in the
month of December) to visit al Rome and to examine severally every Romain,
declaring unto him the.xii. tables, and also the particular decrees of the
senate, demanding of them, if they knew any man that had not observed these
laws: and if they did, they should enfourme the senate thereof. And so every
man should receive condign punishment according to his offense. But they never
punished before they warned, for they used the one year to admonish them of
their faults, and the next year if they did not amend to punyshe them, or
else to banyshe them. These were the words of the law in the fifth table,
and third chapter.

The sacret senate does ordeyne, the happy people do consent, and the ancient
colonies do allow, that if men as men in one year do trespass, that men as
men for that year do wynke at them: but if they as evil men do not amend,
that then the good as good do punish them. Moreover the law said, the first
faults are dissembled withal, because they are committed through weak
ignorance: but the second shall be punished, because they proceade of
negligence and malice. This inquiry was made in the month of December, because
in the month of January following the officers of Rome were elected. And it
was reason the good from the evil should be known, to thentent they might
know who merited to have them, and who deserved to go without them. The chief
cause why this Antigonus, his wife, and his daughter were banished was this. It
was ordained by the eleventh emperor of Rome Augustus, that no man should be
so hardy as to piss nere the doors of any temple. And Caligula the fourth
emperor commanded, that no woman should give, or sell any letters of
witchecrafts to hang about the peoples necks, to deliver them from the fever
quartaine. And Cato the censour made a law, that neither young man nor maid
should talk togethers at the conduictes where they used to fetch water, nor
at the river where they washed their clothes, nor at ye bakehouse where they
baked their bread: because all the wanton youth of Rome ordinarely haunted one
of these two places. It chanced when the censours and consulles visited the
ward of mount Celio, Antigonus, who dwelled thereby, was accused to have
pissed against the walls of the temple of Mars: and his wife likewise was
complained of for selling wrytinges to cure the fevers: and his daughter was
noted for one that commonly haunted the conduictes, rivers, and bakehouses to
talk with young men, the which in those days was a great shame to maids of
Rome. The censours therefore saying the evil president which they found in
the house of Antigonus at that time, registered also before, and that he had
been gently thereof admonished: banished him into the Isle of Scicilly, for as
long time as it should please the senate. And like as in sumptuous and goodly
buyldinges one stone falls not without shaking of an other, so it chances
likewise to men. For commonly one mischaunce comes not alone but that another
immediately follows. I speak it for this purpose, for that Antigonus was not
only deprived of his honor, goods, and country, but also by an earth
quake, his house fell down to the ground, and slew his dearest beloved
daughter. Whiles both these great mischaunces happened, I mean of the monstre
of Scicily, and of the banishement of Antigonus from Rome: Mark the emperor
was in the wars against the Argonautes where he received a letter from
Antigonus of his banishemente, whereof the emperor was marvelous sorry: as it
appears by the answer which he sent to comfort him.

How Marcus Aurelius sought the wealth of his people, and how his people
loved him. Cap. iii.
IN the second year that Mark was elected emperor the.xlv. of his age, when
he returned from the conquest of the Germans, and the Argonautes, (from
whence he brought great riches, and treasures, to the Roman empire) he to
rest him self, and to appointe his men, lay at Salon until such time as the
Romans had prepared all things convenient for such a glorious triumph:
There was one thing done which never was seen in Rome, for yt same day of his
triumph his son Comodus by the assent of the whole people of Rome, was
chosen emperor after the death of his father. He was not chosen at the request
of his father, for he was against it: saying that the empire ought not to be
given for the merits of those which are dead, but he should be chosen for his
own good works being alive. This emperor said oftentimes that then Rome
should be undone, when the election shall be taken from the senate, and when the
emperor shall enherite the empire by patrimony. Now to come to our matter:
the emperor being at Salon trauayled much to bring his men into Rome in good
order: and Rome was more careful for to receive him triumphantly, as it
appertained to such a great conqueste. He was marueilously well beloved of all the empire, and he always studied the wealth of his people, and they were
always most faithful in his services. So that sundry times there was a
question moved in the senate, which of these two things was better beloved,
Either the emperor of his people, or the people of their emperor. So that one
day they appointed two judges in this case, the one was the Ambassador of the
Parthes, and the other was the Ambassador of the Rhodes, and the information
was given on both parts in writing. The emperor alleged the great profit
that he had done to the common wealth, and the many evils which he had
delivered it from. On the other part the senators declared ye good deeds they
had done in his absence, and the great love they bare him always in his
presence. So likewise the emperor an other day moved an other question to the
senate, affirming that it was more glory for him to have such subjects, then
for them to have such an emperor. The senate denied it, affirming that the
comfort was greater that they had of him: then that which he could have of
them. And in this wise the emperor gave the glory to his people, and the
people gave the glory to their emperor. Thus merrily this matter was reasoned
of again. It was a pleasant thing to hear the reasons wherewith each part
proved his purpose. For the good emperor attributed the whole laud for a
perpetual memory unto the people, because of the great obedience, diligent
service, and faithful love which he had found in them. And on the other part
the fortunat people gave the glory unto the emperor, for his clemency, and
mercifulnes, for his vprightuous gouerninge, for his honesty of living, and
for his stout courage in conquering. It was a thing worthy of noting, to se how
the people gave the honor to their emperor, and how the emperor attributed
ye praise to his people. These matters were delivered in trust to the strange
Ambassadors, to thend that all people might learn to obey their princes, and
also princes learn to love their people: to the end that by such examples (as
it was reason) the good should be encouraged, and the evil discomforted. Thus
the emperor prepared al things ready with his capitaines and captives for his
entering, and the people of Rome made as great preparation for to receive him.
It was a marvelous thing to see what people came forth of Rome to mete him,
and what an infinite number were at Salon to behold him. They that were at
Salon had their eyes there, and their hearts at Rome: and they that were at
Rome, had their hearts at Salon, in such sort that their eyes daseled with
that they saw, and their hearts also rejoiced for that they hoped to see. For
there is no greater tormente to the heart, then when it is deferred from that
which it greatly desires.

How at the intercession of many which the Empress had sent, the Emperor
granted his daughter Lucilla license to sport her self at the feasts. Cap.
lxi.
YOu shall understand, that the Romans used always, in the month of
January, to permit that their emperoures should triumph. And it chanced that
at that time when they prepared for the triumph, Faustine the empress caused
diverse noble barons to demand license of the emperor, that her daughter
might come from her mistres where she was taught, to ye feasts. Her name was
Lucilla: who was elder then the prince Comodus her brother. She had a goodly
gesture, she was well made in the body, and derely beloved of her mother, whom
she resembled not only in beauty, but also in living. Though the request seemed
to be reasonable, and those that made it his counselors and great about him,
and though him whom they asked was the father, and she that demanded it was
the mother, and she for whom this request was made was the daughter: yet the
emperor would not grant it, but half against his will. Faustine when she had
obtained license was exceading glad, and so sone as she might possible, she
brought her daughter home unto the palace. And when the day of the great
feast and solemn triumph came: the young damoisel perceiving her self at
large without any governor, trusting in the innocence of her self, esteemed
not the malice of any other man: but rejoiced with those that rejoiced, talked
with them that talked, beheld them that beheld her, and she thought because
she mente evil to no man, that no man wylled evil to her. In those days it
was as great an offense for a maid of Rome, to laughe in the company of men:
as it was for a woman of Grecia to be taken in adultery with a priest. So
greatly was the honesty at that time of the Roman Matrones regarded, and the
lyghtnes of the maidens was so detested, that they gave more sharper
punishment for one offense done openly, then for two other which were
committed in secreat. Among all other things, from these seven the Roman
Matrones did marueilously refrain, that is to wete: from talkyng much at
feasts, from gready eating among strangers: From drynkyng wine whiles they
were whole: From talkyng in secreate with any man: From lifting up their eyes
in the temples: From gasyng much out at the wyndowes. And from wandryng
abroad without their husbands. For the woman that was apprehended in any of
these things, was always after counted as one defamed. There are many things
suffered in persons of mean estate, which can not be endured in those of
higher degree: For Ladies of high renown, can not keep the reputation of
their estates, unless they are marvelous circumspecte in all their doings.
All things that degenerate from their kind deserve blame: but the dishonest
woman meriteth infamy. If ladies wylbe counted ladies in deed, let them know
how much they excel others in riches, so much less license have they then
other to go gaddinge in the streates. For of a surety the abundance of
their riches, and the liberty of their persons, should not be a spur to
provoke them to gadde abroad, but rather a bridle to keape them within. All
this is spoken for this cause that Lucilla, as a maid tender and young, and
Faustine her mother, as one not very old: sometimes on foot, and sometimes
ryding: sometimes openly, and now and then secreatly: Sometimes with company,
and at other times alone: Sometimes by day, and ofttymes by night: used to
foot the streates of Rome, to view the fields of Vulcane: To sport them by
the river of Tiber: to gather the fruits in the Ortechardes of Saturn: to
suppe at the conduites of Nero, and such other vagaries they used. The which
things though their age did desire, and their idleness allure them unto: yet
the gravity of such ladies ought to have withdrawn them from it. I will
speak one thing, to the end that other ladies and gentlewomen may take warning
thereby: which is, that I can not tell which was greater, either the small
discretion which moved Faustine, and Lucilla, to wander in such sort about
the streates: or the audacitie that evil men took thereby to talk of their
persons, and doubt of their honesties. The keaping of women in their houses,
is like unto a bridle to hold still evil men's tongues. The woman that is a
strayer abroad, puts her good name in much danger. Of troth it were
better for a woman never to be borne: then to live with an evil name. Among
all the families of the ancient Romans, that of the Cornelians was counted
most fortunate, for among the men there was never any found a cowarde, nor
among the women any that was defamed. The historiographers say, that there was
one woman of that lynage, only for being light in her behavior, was by the
hands of her own parents executed and put to death. Surely it was well done
of the Romans, to the intent that the lightness of one woman alone, should not
defame the whole family. Where as is noblenes, and honesty: there the matters
that touch the honor, ought not to tarry whiles they be remedied by justice:
but from that man or woman which among al has lost his good name, from the
nombre of the living he also ought to be taken. It is not sufficient for one to
him self to be good: but it is requisite that he give no occasion to others to
judge him to be evil. All the losses of temporal goods that chance unto men in
this life, ought not to be compared with a little blemishe of a man's good name.
The man that hasardeth for a trifle his good name in this world, shall at a
hundredth shootes scarsly shoot one right. And co^trariwyse, the man that has
lost his honesty, and that estemeth not the reputation of his person: truly
from him we shall never see any good thing proceade. Now the emperor like unto
a wise shipmaister, fearing after the great calmes some tempestuous storm:
seeing the lightness of his daughter and vanity of the mother (I mean in the
time of this great mirth and gladness) feared lest any infamy should ensewe unto
these two ladies. And for a surety he doubted not without a cause for it is an
infallible rule of envious fortune, to give us in many years a little
prosperity, to thinte^t that afterward suddenly she may bring us into some
great adversity. By experience we see, yt the sea is seldom times calm: but
immediately follows some perilous tempest. The extreme heat of ye day does
prognosticate, yt terrible tho^der in ye euentide. I mean, when fortune does
flatter us with her golden pills, it is a token that she entendeth to catch us
in her snares. The mylner before the banks broken repareth the dammes. The
husbandman before it raineth, thacketh his house, fearing the snow and rain
that is to come. So likewise the sage man ought to consider, that during this
life he has prosperity but by leave, and adversity as by patrimony. Marcus
Aurelius among al other men was he that knew how to enjoy prosperity, and also
to prevail of adversity. Though fortune gave him much prosperity: yet he never
trusted therein, nor for any troubles that ever he received in this life, he was
at any time abashed,

Of the sharp words which Marcus Aurelius spoke to his wife, and to his
daughter. Cap. v.
WHen the tryumphes before named were finyshed, this good Emperor being
willing to vnbourden his heart and to advise Faustine, and to teach the youg
damosel his daughter, and to the end that no man should hear it, he called them
a part, and said unto them these words. I am not content Faustine with that
thy daughter did, nor yet with that which thou have done being her mother. The
daughters if they will be counted good children, must learn to obey their
fathers: and the mothers if they will be counted good mothers, must learn to
bring up their daughters well. When the mother is honest, and the daughter
shamefast, the father is excused in geuyng council. It is great shame to the
father being a man, that the mother being a woman should chastise his son.
And it is a great reproach to the mother, that the daughter should be chastised
by the hands of any man. There was a law enacted among the Rhodiens, that
neither the father should have to do with the daughters, nor the mothers with
the sons, but the men used to bring up the men, and the women the women. And
in such wise, that they abiding al in one house, it seems unto the fathers
that they had no daughters, and unto the mothers that they had no sons. O
Rome, Rome, I bewail the not for to se the streates vnpauid, nor to se the
houses so decayed, nor to se the battlements so fallen down, nor the timber
hewed down, nor for the dyminishing of the habytaunts, for all this time
brings, and time takes away, but I weep for the, and weep for the again,
to se the unpeopled of good fathers, and unprovided in the nourishing of their
children. Rome began to decay, when the disciplyne of sons and daughters was
enlarged, and that their bridle was let at lybertye. For there is now such
boldness in boys, and so little shamefastnes in girls, with dishonesty of the
mothers, yt where as one father suffised for.xx. sons, and one mother for xx.
daughters: now xx. fathers dare scarcely undertake to bring up well one son,
and xxx, mothers one daughter. I say this to you Faustine, you remember not how
you are a mother, for you give more liberty to your dougher then ought to be
suffered. And now Lucilla remember not how you are a daughter: for you show to
have more liberty then requires for a young maiden. The greatest gift that the
gods have given to the Matrons of Rome is: because that they are women, they
keep them selves close and secret, and because they are Romans, they are
shamefast. The day when the women want the fearre of the gods secretly, and
shame of men openly, believe me they shall either fail the world, or the world
them.

The common wealth requires it of great necessity, that the women which therein
enhabyte should be as honest, as the captains valiant: for the captains
going to war defend them, and the women which abide at home conserve them. As
now.iiii. years passed ye saw this great pestilence: and I demand then to
have account of the people, and I found that of C. and xl.M. honest
women.lxxx.M. dyed: and of.x.M. dyshonest women in manner they escaped al. I
cannot tell for which I should weep, either for the lack that we have of the
good and virtuous women in our common wealth, or else for the great hurt and
domages that these evil and wicked women do to the youth of Rome. The fire that
brenneth in mount Ethna does not so much endomage those that dwell in Scicil, as
one evil woman does with in the walls of Rome. A fyerse beast, and a perilous
ennemy to the common wealth is an evil woman for she is of power to commyt all
euyls, and nothing apt to do any good O how many realms and kingdoms read
we of, which by the evil behauiours of one woman have been lost, and to resist
against them, there has been need both of wisdom, perils, money, and force
of many men.

The vices in a woman is as a grene read that boweth every way: but the
lightness and dyshonesty is as a dry kyxe that breaks, in such wise that the
more evil they utter, the more unlikely is the amendment thereof.

Behold Faustine, there is no creature that more desires honor and worse
keeps it, then a woman, and that this is true, we se by justice, by orations,
by writing, and other travails, man gets fame and renown: but without it
be by flattering, and fair speaking, this hour by ancient writers we ca^
read of few women or none, which either by writing, redyng, workyng with nedle,
spinning, or by weauing, have gotten them any great renown. But as I say of
one, I say of an other, certaynely of diverse we read, by keeping them close in
their houses, being well occupied in their business, temperate in their words,
faithful to their husbands, well ordered in their persons, peasable with their
neighbors, and finally for being honest among their own family, and
shamefast amongst strangers, they have obtained great renown in their life,
and left a perpetual memory of them after their death. I will tell you an
ancient history as profitable to restrain our vices, as it did then augment
virtues, which is this. The realm of the Lacedemoniens as Plato says, was a
long time as dissolute through the unthriftiness of women, as infamed by the
vices of men, so that of al nations they were called barbarous, what time
Greece of the philosophers, was called the mother of philosophers, Licurgus a
wise philosophers in knowledge, and a right just king in governance, partly
with his doctrine very profitable, and partly with his life most pure, ordained
laws in the said realm, whereby he expelled all vices, and planted al virtues.
I cannot tell which of these two were most happiest, the king having so
obedyent people, or else the realm to have so worthy a king. Among other
laws for women he enacted one worthy of high commendacion, the which
commanded, that the father which dyed should give nothing to his daughter:
and another, that neither living nor dieng he should give any money to mary her
with, to the intent that none should take her for her goods, but al only for
her virtues: and not for her beautye but for her qualyties: where as now some
be forsaken because where as now some be forsaken because they are poor, so
then they abode unmarried because they were vicious, O time worthy to be
desired, when maidens hoped not to be married with their fathers goods, but by
the virtuous works of their own persons, this was the time called the golden
world, when neither ye daughter feared to be disherited by the father in his
life, nor the father to dye sorrowful for leuynge her without dowrye at his
death. O Rome, cursed be he yt first brought gold into thy house, and cursed be
he that first began to horde up treasour. Who have made Rome to be so rich of
treasure, and so poor of virtues? who has caused noble men to mary the
Plebeians, and leave the daughters of Senators unmarried? what has made that
the rich man's daughter is demanded unwilling, and the daughters of a poor
man none will desire? What has caused that one marieth a fool with five hundredth
marks, rather then a wise woman with ten thousand virtues? then I will not say
that in this case ye flesh vanquished ye flesh, but I say that vanity is
overcome of malice. For a covetous person will sooner now a days take a wife
that is rich and foul, then one that is poor and fair: O unhappy woman that
bring forth children, and more unhappy be the daughters that are borne: the
which to take in marriage no man desires, neither for the blood of their
predecessors, nor the favor of their friends, nor the worthynes of their
persons, nor for the purity of their lives. O wicked world, where the daughter
of a good man without money shall have no marriage: but it was not wont to be
so. For in the old time when they treated of marriages, first they spoke of the
persons, and after of the goods, not as they do at this present in this
unhappy time: for now they speak first of the goods and last of al of ye
persons. In ye said golden world, first they spoke of the virtues that the
person was endewed with: and when they were married, as it were in sport they
would speak of the goods. When Camillus triumphed over the Gauls, he had then
but one son, and he was such one that his deserts meryted great praise, and
for the renown of his father, diverse kings desired to have him to their
sons, and diverse senators desired to have him to their son in law. This
young man being of the age of xxx. years, and the father at lx. was
importunately stirred by his natural friends, and desires of strange kings, for
to marie him, but always the old Camille withstode ye concel of his friends and
the importunity of the strangers. When it was demanded why he determined not
upon some marriage for his son, sith thereby should ensue the quiet life of
the man, and the joy of himself in his age, he answered. I will not mary my
son, because some offer me rich daughters, some noble of lineage, some young,
and some fair. But there is none has said to me, I give you my virtuous
daughter. Certainly Camil merited triumph for yt he did, and deserved eternal
memory for that he said. I spoke to you Faustine, all these words, because I
se you lead your daughter to theaters, and plays, and bring her into the
capitolle, you put her to the keaping of the sword plaiers, you suffer her to
see the tumblers, and yet do you not remember that she is young, and you not to
aged, you go into the streates without license, and sport you by the ryuers:
I find no vyllannye therein, nor think that your daughter is evil, but I say
it, because you give occasion that she should not be good.

Beware, beware Faustine, never trust to the race of flesh of young people, nor
have no confidens in old folks: for there is no better way, then to fly the
occasion of al things.

For this intent the virgins vestalles are closed up between the walls, to
eschew the occasions of open places, not to be more light and folyshe, but to
be more sad and virtuous flieng occasions. The young shall not say, I am young and
virtuous: nor the old shall not say, I am old and broken. For of necessity the
dry flax will bren in the fire, and the grene flagge smoke in the flame.

I say though a man be a dyamond set among men, yet of necessity he ought to
be quick, and to melt as wax in the heat among women, we cannot deny that
though the wood be taken from the fire and the Imbers quenched: yet
nevertheless the stones oftentime remain hot. In likewise the flesh, though
it be chastised with hot and dry disseases, consumed by many years with
travail, yet concupiscens abides still in the bones.

What need is it to blase the virtues, and deny our naturalyties? certainly
there is not so old a horse, but if he se a mare will ney once or twice: there is
no man so young nor old but let him se fair young damsels, either he will give a
sigh, or a wish. In all voluntary things I deny not, but that one may be
virtuous: but in natural things, I confess every man to be weak. When you
take the wood from the fire, it leaves burning: when summer comes the cold
winter cease: when the sea is calm, the waves leave their vehement mocions:
when the son is set, it lightneth not the world. I will say, that then, and
not before, the flesh will cease to trouble us, when it is laid in the grave, of
the flesh we are borne, in the flesh we live, and in the flesh we shall die: and
thereby it follows, that our good life shall sooner end, then our fleshly desires
forsake us, oftentimes some wholesome flesh corrupts in an evil vessel, and
good wine sometime favors of the foist. I say, though that the works of our
life be virtuous: yet shall we feel the stench of the weak flesh. I spoke this
Faustine, since that age cannot resist these hot appitites, how can the tender
members of youth resist them? unless you that are the mother go the right way,
how should the daughter that follows you find it? the Roman matrons, if they
will bring up their daughters well, ought to keep these rules, when they se
that they would wander abroad, that they break their legs: and if they
should be gasing: then put out their eyes: and if they will lysten, stop their
ears: if they will give or take, cut of their hands: if they dare speak, sow
up their mouths: if they will pretend any lightness, burye them quycke: death
ought to be given to an evil daughter, instead of her dowry: for gifts, give
her worms, and for her house, a grave.

Take heed Faustine, if you will have much joy of your daughter take from her
the occasions whereby she shall be evil. To underset a house behooves diverse
proppes: and if the principalles be taken away, it will fall down, I say you
women are so frail, that with kepers, with great pain they can keape them
self, and for a small occasion they will lose altogether. O how many evil has
there been, not because they would be so, but because they followed such
occasions, the which they ought to have eschewed. It is at my pleasure to enter
into this battle, but yet it is not in my power to attain the vyctorie, it
is for me to enter into the sea, yet it lies not in my hands to escape the
peril: it is in the hands of a woman to enter into the occasion, and after yt
she is therein, it is not in her power to escape from evil, to deliver her from
tongues. Peradventure Faustine, thou will say to me, none can speak to your
daughter Lucil, unless thou hear it: nor se her, but thou see him: nor
convey her, but thou know where: nor make any appointment, without thy
consent: and yet thou know, that those which will her evil, seek with their
tongues to dishonor her: and those that with their hearts love her, speak
only in their hearts. We love in young blood, in the springing time and
floryshing youth is a poison, that forthwith spreads into every vain, it is
a herb that enters into the entrayles, a swowning that incontinently
mortyfieth all the members, and a pestilence that sleeth the hearts, and finallye
it makes an end of al virtues. I know not what I say, but I feel yt which I
would say, for I would never blase love with my tongue, except I were sore
wounded therewith in my heart. Ouide says in his book of the art of love, love
is I wot not what, it comes I know not from whence, who sent it I wot not, it
engenders I know not how, it is satisfied I wot not wherewith, it is felt, and
I wot not how, often it sleeth, I wot not wherefore, and finally without breakyng
the flesh outwardly, love takes root, and molesteth the heart inwardly. I know
not what Ouide means hereby, but I trow when he said these words, he was as
far banyshed from him self, as I am at this time from my self. O Faustine,
they that love together, utter the secrets of their hearts by diverse ways, and
in sleaping they reason and speak and by signs they understand each other. The
many words outwardly, declare small love inwardly: and the fervent inward love,
keeps silence outward.

The entrayles within embraced with love, cause the tongue outward to be mute:
he that passes his life in love. ought to keep his mouth close. And to
the intent that ye shall not think yt I speak fables, I will prove this by
ancient histories, we find aunciently, that in the year.cclxx. after the
foundation of Rome. Etrasco a young Roman that was dombe, and Verona a fair
Lady of the Latins which was dombe also, these two saw each other on ye mount
Cel^o at the feasts, and there fell in love togethers, and their hearts were as
sore fixed in love, as their tongues were tide from speech. It was a maruailous
thing to se then, and fearful to note now that this young lady came from Salon
to Rome: and he went from Rome to Salon sundry times by the space of 30. years,
without the knowledge of any parson, and never spoke together. It chanced at
the last that the husband of the lady Verona died, and the wife of Etrasco
also, and then they discovered their love, and treated a marriage between them.
And these two dombe parsons had issue a son of whom descended ye noble lineage
of our Scipions, which were more famous in the feats of arms, then their
father and mother were troubled for want of words.

Then Faustine mark this thing, it had little auailed to have cut out the
tongues of the two dombe persons to have remedyed their love, and not to have
cut out their hearts. And I shall tell you of Masinissa a worthy knight of
Numidie, and Sophonissa a famous lady of Carthage, al only by one sight as
they saw each other on a ladder, he declares his desire unto her and she
knowing his lust breaking the oores of fear, and lyftyng up the ankers of
shame, incontinente raised the sails of their hearts, and with the ships of
their persons they joined each to other, here may we see, how the first sight
of their eyes, the knowledge of their parsons, the consent of their hearts, the
copulacion of their bodies, the decay of their estates, and the loss of their
names, in one day, in one hour, in one moment, and in one step of a ladder
were lost, what will you that I say more to this purpose? do you not know what
Heleyne the Greek, and Paris the Troyan, of two strange nations, and of far
countries, with one only sight in a temple their wills were so knit together,
that he took her as his captive, and she abode his prisoner. In Paris appeared
but small force, and in Heleyne but little resistance, so that in manner those two
young persons, the one procuring to vanquyshe, and the other suffering to be
vanquished: Paris was cause of his fathers death, and they both of their own
deaths, loss to their realms, and scaunder to all the world. All this love grew
of one only sight. When great king Alexander would have given battle to
the Amosones, the queen (captain of them) no less fair then strong and
virtuous, came to a river side, and the space of an hour each of them beheld
an other with their eyes, without vtteringe of any word.

And when they returned to their tents, their fiersnes was turned into sweet
wanton amorous words. When Pirius the faithful defender of the Tharrentines,
and renowned king of Epirotes was in Italy, he came into Naples, and had not
been there but one day, but he was enamoured of a fair lady named Gemelicia,
of a high lignage, and greatly esteamed of her beauty, and the very same day
she was gotten with child, and shamed throughoute al Italy, and cast out of the
city: and after that she was delivered of child, she was slain by one of her
own brethren. Also Cleopatra in the province of Bithiny, in the wood Sechin
made a goodly banquet of Marcus Anthonius her lover, and though she was not very
honest, yet had she with her chaste women And thus the banquet endured a great
part of the night. And the wood being thick, young damsels were not so wily to
hide them, but the young men Romans found them: so that of.60. daughters of
the senators, 55. were gotten with child among the thick bushes, which thing
made a great sclander in the people, and augmented the infamy of Marcus
Anthonius. Thus as I have showed of a small number, I could say of many other.
Al men are not men, nor al women are not women. I speak it, because I would it
should be said, let it touch them that it touches, and let them that come
understand me. There are some ships which are so light, that they will sail
with a little wind. And there be other some mils that will grind with a little
water. I say there be some women so brickle, that as a glass with a phylyppe
will break, and will slyppe with a little mire.

Tell me Faustine, have you suffered your daughter to speak but with her uncles,
and keep company but with her cousins? I say in this case that the mother is in
as much blame, as the daughter in peril. Do you not know that the hot fire
does not forbear the wood, be it wete or dry: but in likewise it consumes
the hard stones? Do you not know, that the extreme hunger causes beasts to
devour with their own teeth, the thing that was bread in their entrayles? Do
you not know, that the gods made a law over al things, except over lovers,
because they may not abide it? and doubtless it was right wisely done. Rome
condempneth not these foolyshe innocents, because they have no understanding.
The gods give no pain to amorous people, because they are deprived from
reason. Ye know when I was censour, there was a young woman which had a child
by her own father, and another had a child by her son, and a niece by her
proper uncle: and there was sentence given on them, that the father should be
given to the lions, and the children buried quycke, and the mothers were burnt
in the camp of Mars. The matter was so horrible to here, that I might not
endure to se the cursed men, and I commanded by my decrees, that none should
be so bold to speak in such a case any more.

And if this case were fearful to men, then certaynlye the Roman Matrones
ought to live chastlye. Then if the fire of the father do chafe the daughter,
inflameth kinsefolke, and burns them self: ye may be sure if he find
either cousin, or fair sister, the flames of his concupisence will not leave to
take hold on her, for any parentage. If this riotous flesh will obey reason,
then it may be that your daughter may speak lyberally with her cosins, but
since that passion repugneth so much at reason, I counsel you, trust not to
much in her brethren. You se by experience, that the worm that is bred in the
timbre, and the mothes which are bred in the clothes, eats that same cloth. I
say that sometime a man brings him up in his house, which afterward takes
his honor and life from him.

Faustine, take this that I have said for a warnyng, and these last words I
give you counsel. If you will keep your self from thought, and your
daughter from peril, let your daughter be always occupied with some good
works: for when the hands are occupied with any good exercise, then the heart
is void from many idle and vain thoughts. Every lightness done in youth,
breaks down a lompe of our life: but idleness whereby our envy enters, is
it which opens ye gate of al vices. Know thou Faustine, from whence
proceeds the undoing of the young Roman daughters? I will tell the: for as soon as they be borne, they presume to be amorous, they as unmindful (with the
rechelesnes of the father, and wantonness of the mothers) despise the honest
travails, and embrace the pleasant ydlenes. Of idle mocions, and outrageous
thoughts, the eyes take license without leave, the mind alters, and the will
is hurt. And finally, thinking to be the white that amorous men shoot at, they
remain as a but full of al vices. And in conclusion, there is nothing that more
chaseth the bal of the thought in this play then the hand set a work therewith.

The Emperor causes his wife to take away al occasions of evil from her
daughter, wherein is declared the frayltye of the tender flesh. Cap. vi.
THen the good Emperor Marcus, having a clear understanding, and a quiet
mind, took right great head of all things that were past, prudently waying
things present, and things to come. Seeing that the perdicion of princes
depend al in will wholly, either geuinge them selves to strange things,
forgetting their own, or else to entend to their own only, nothing regardyng
strange things: His heart was so agreeable to him, that neither the great
business of them, nor for all the affairs of his house he would leave him the
empire vndispatched. I speak this, because this emperor Marcus had iiii.
daughters, whose names were Lucilla, Porsenna, Matrina, and Domicia. All
resembled their mother in excellent beauty, but they resembled not their
father in honesty nor virtue. And though they were in governance under their
masters out of his presence, yet he had them always in memory, and the elder
they were, the more study and thought he took for them. And when they came to
lawful age, he studied to make prouysion for them. It was a lawdable custom,
that the daughters of the officers of the senate should not mary without
license, nor the Emperors daughters without the consent of the senate. Then it
is so, that one of the said princesses his daughter being of age, and of will to
be married, her father seeing her importunity, to accomplish her desire: because
he was sick, he sent for Faustine, that she should go and talk in the senate:
the which with all her power she with stood, because yt secretly she had treated
for an other marriage for her daughter, and openly she excused her self, saying
that her daughter was to young and tender of age. And as the gods had given
age sufficient to the father, so had not the daughter of years. When the emperor
understood this, he called Faustine to his bed side whereas he lay, and said:
diverse things are dissimuled in particular persons, the least of them is not to
be suffered in them which are governors of other, the prince is never well
obeyed, onelesse he has good crede^ce among his people. I say this Faustine,
because you do one thing in secret, and say another openly: herein fails the
credence of so high a lady, and puts in suspect the auctority of so great an
empire. If you suppose my good desires be sinister in your heart, for ye wealth
of your own children: how should we hope then in any of your good works, for
the children of strangers? It seems to you better to give your daughter to
them, that demand her of the mother, and refuse them that the father does
chose. Certainly because you are a woman you desire pardon, but in that you are
a mother you augment your fault. Do you not know that marriages are guyded some
by fortune, and some by virtues and wisdom? Such as demand the daughters of
the fathers, believe me, their eyes be more upon their own proper vtility, then
upon the wealth of another. I know well you bring forth the children, but the
gods will mary them, sith they have endewed them with so marvelous beauty.
Do you not know that the beautye of women sets strangers, on desire, and
puts neighbors in suspection? to great men it gives fear, to mean men
envy: to the parents infamy, and peril to the persons them selves? with great
pain it is kept, that is desired of many. Of truth I say, the beauty of women
is nothing but a sign for idle folk, and an early waking for them yt be
light, whereas of straung desires lies ye renown of themselves, and I deny
not, but that a light person sercheth sooner a woman with a fair face, then one
of an honest life. But I say that a woman that is married, only for her beauty,
may hope in her age to have an evil life. It is an infallyble rule, yt she
that was married for her fayrenesse, shall be despised for her foulness.

O what trouble he offers himself unto, which marieth a fair woman It
behooves him to suffer her pride: for beauty, and folly, always go together.

Also he must suffer her expenses, for follye in the head, and beauty in the
face, be two worms which freate the life, and wast the goods.

Also he must suffer her riots, for a fair woman will that none but she have
her commandments in the house. Also he must suffer her nice minions, for many
fair women will pass their lives in pleasure. Also he must suffer her
presumption, for every fair woman will have prehemenence before al other.
Finally he that marieth with a fair woman, puts himself in great ieopardy.
And I shall tell you wherefore, surely Carthage was never so enuyroned with
Scipions, as the house of a fair woman is with light persons.

O unhappy husband when his spirit is at rest, and the body sleping, then
those light persons run about the house, sleying his body with ielosye,
casting their eyes at the windows, scalyng the walls with ladders, singing
sweet songs, playing on diverse instruments, watching at the gates, treating
with bands, vncoueringe the house, and waytinge at every corner thereof.

Al these things in case they shoot at the prick of woman's beauty, they
leave not to shoot at the butte of the sorrowful husbands good name: and
whether this be true or not, let them ask my self that am married with your
beauty, and let them wite of my renown that go so about the city.

I say much, but truly I feel more: no man complayneth of the gods, for
geuyng him a foul wife among his destinies, white silver is not wrought, but
in black pitche: and the tender tree is not preserved but by the hard bark.
I say a man that marieth a foul wife, leads a sure life, let every man
chose as he lysteth: and I say a man that marieth a fair wife: casts his
good name at hasard, and puts his life in peril. All the infamy of our
predecessors stood in exercising of deeds of arms, and now all the pastime of
the Roman youth, is to serve Ladies. When a woman is bruted to be fair,
then every man goes thither, and takes great pain to serve her, and the
woman will be seen. I say Faustine, you never saw a damosel Roman greatly
renowned in beauty, but either in deed, or in suspicion, there went some evil
report of her name. In that little that I have red, I have herd of diverse fair
women, both of Greece, Italy, Parth, and Rome, and they be not in memory
because they were fair, but for the great perils and misaduentures which
through their beautyes chanced in the world. For by reason of their excellent
beautyes they were vysited in their own lands, and for their infamy shamed
through all the world. When the realm of Carthage flourished in riches, and was
fortunate in arms, they ruled the common wealth by wise philosophers, and that
they repulsed their enemies by strong arms. Arminius the philosopher was as
greatly esteamed among the Carthagians as Homere was among the Greeks, or
Cicero among the Romans. He lived in this world.122 years.80. of the which
good years he lived most quyetly, he was as much turned from women, as given
to his books. Then the senate seeing he had such experience in the affairs of
the weal publyke, and so withdrawn from al natural recreations, they desired
him with great instaunce to be married, to the intent the memory might be had of
so excellent a wise man in time to come, and the more importune they were, the
more he resisted, and said.

I will not be married: for if she be foul, I shall abhor her. If she be rich
I must suffer her. If she be poor, I must maintain her. If she be fair, I
must take heed of her. If she be a shrew I cannot suffer her. And the lest
pestilence of al those is sufficient to slay a.M. men. With such words this
wise man excused himself. But in the end through great study in his age, he
lost his sight, whereby the solytarines of his sweet lybertye, constrained him
to take the company of a woman, by whom he had a daughter, of the which
descended the noble Amilears of Carthage, competitours of the Scipions, of
Rome. The which showed no less worthiness in the defense of Carthage, the^
ours did courage in the amplifiyng of Rome. Tell me Faustine, may not such
suspicion fall upon your daughter, though her virtue succor her in the peril,
and her honesty assure her person? I will discover a secret thing to you. There
is nothing that can chance evil to a woman, if she be environed with feminine
shamefastnes. Greatly they desire, and with much importunytie they procure
those things which highly may be attained. There is nothing so certain as
this, that the wealth of an other, is the cause of his own evil. And Faustine,
ye know, that the most honest women, by our malice are most desired. Certainly
their shamefastnes, and keeping close, be arrows in defense of our honesty. We
read not that the blood, riches, nor beauty of the unhappy matrone Lucrece,
were the cause that she was desired: but the beauty of her vysage, the
grauytie of her person, the honesty of her living, the keeping of her self
close in her house, the spendyng of her time and credit among her neighbors,
and the great renown yt she had among strangers, provoked the folish Tarquine
to commit with her adultrye by force. What think you? whereof came this? I shall
show you. We that be evil, are so evil, that we use evil the goodness of them
that be good. The fault hereof is not in the Ladies of Rome, but rather in the
immortal gods. Their clean honestye, declares our cruel malice. Faustine,
you say your daughter is to young to be married. Do you not know, that the good
father ought to endoctrine his sons from their age: and to provide for his
daughters whiles they be young? Of a troth, if the fathers be fathers, and the
mothers mothers: as soon as the gods have given them a daughter, forthwith
they ought to be myndfull thereof, and never forget it, til they have provided
her a husband. The fathers ought not to tarry for riches, nor the mother for her
lineage, the better to mary them: so what with the one and the other, the time
passes, and the daughter waxes aged: and in this manner they be to old to be
married, and to live alone they cannot, so that they themselves live in pain,
the fathers in thought, and the parents in suspection least they should be
cast away. O what great ladies have I known, ye daughters of great senators,
which not for fault of richs, nor of virtues in their persons, but al only for
differring of time, and driuyng from one hour to an other, so that at last
sudden death come to the fathers, and no provision was made for the daughters.
So that some were covered under ye earth, after their death, and others buried
with forgetfulness, being alive. Either I lie, or else I have red in the laws of
the Rhodians these words.

We command the father in maryinge ten sons, to travail but one day: but
to mary one virtuous daughter let him travail ten years, yea and hazard his
body in the water up to the chinne, sweat drops of of blood, alter the
stomach, disherite all his sons, lose his goods, and adventure his person.
These words in this law were pitiful for the daughters, and no less grave for
the sons. For.x. sons by the law of men, are bound to go over all the world:
but the daughter by this good law, ought not to go out of the house. I say
moreover, that as things unstable thret falling, so likewise it chances to
young damsels, which thinks al their time lost and superfluous, unto the day
of their marriage. Homere says, it was the custom of ladies of Greece to count
the years of their life, not from the time of their birth, but from the time of
their marriage. As if one demanded a Grecian her age, she would answer.20.
years, if it were.20. sith she was married: though it were.60. years since she
was borne. Affirming after they had a house to govern and to command, that
day she begins to live. The Melon after it is ripe, and abides still in the
gardeine, cannot escape, but either it must be gathered, or else it rotteth. I
say the maiden that tarieth long till she be married, can not escape either to
be taken, or infamed. I will say no more As soon as the grapes be ripe, it
behooves that they be gathered: so it is necessary that the woman that is come
to perfect age be married. And the father that does this, casts peril out of
his house, brings himself out of care, and gets much contentacion of his
daughter.

Of a letter which the Emperor Marcus Aurelius sent to Piramon his especial
friend, to comfort him in his troubles. Cap. vii.
Mark orator Roman, borne at mount Celio, to Piramon of Lion, my great
friend, desires health to thy person, and strength and virtue against thy
sinister fortune. In the third kalendes of Ianuarye I received thy letter,
whereby I perceive thou have received one of mine. I regard not much thy words,
but I esteame greatly thy meaning. So that without declaring thereof, I have
gathered the sentence. Reason would, because I have written so often to the,
that thou shouldeste the better understand me: but thou art so slouthful, yt
though I call the, thou will not hear: nor though I strike the, thou will not
feel. But now to come to the purpose. Thou know Piramon how nere we be in
parentage, ancient in friendship, steadfast in love, and tender of herts, and
how faithful in all things, wherein one true friend might prove another. Thou
remembrest well, when we were at Rhodes, that we dwelled together in one house,
and did eat at one table: and all that thou thoughtest, I did it in effect: and
that I said, thou never gainesaydest. Certainly thou were in my heart, and I in
thine entrails. I was thine, and thou were mine. We being together, it seemed
to al other that we were but one, and of one will. What a matter is this? Thou
writest how thou art heavy, and yet thou do not tell the cause why. Thou
complaynest yt thou art almost dead, and thou show me not who takes from
the thy life. If thou will not show to me thy troubles, since thou art my
friend, I will thou know that I demand it of right. If thou will not, I will
that thou know, that the piteful gods have determined, that al pleasures and
joy shall depart from my house: and that al heuines and sorrows shall be lodged
in my person. Since I am prince of al honor in tribulacion, if thou would,
thou can not escape out of my siegnory. For if thou complain that thou art
unhappy in fortune, then I esteem my self to be happy in unhappiness. I
demand one thing of the: when have thou seen me have sufficient, and thou
need? when have thou seen me sleep, and thou wake? and when have thou
travailed, and I rested? Of troth since the goods and persons are their own
proper, the travails and evil adventures are always common One thing thou
ought to know, if in mine amytie thou will persevere, that all my goods are
thine, and al thine euyls are mine, since thou was borne to pleasure, and I to
trouble. I say not this fainyngly: for thou haste had experience of me that
