when Maria thy sister died (who was no less virtuous then fair) thou
perceiuedst well when she was with earth covered dead, I was with sorrows
overwhelmed alive, and at the sown of my tears thine eyes daunced. Sithe thou
have such confidence in my person, surely thou may discover to me thy pain.
Yet as often as I have demanded, there has no famed excuses wanted. I require
the, and desire the again, and in the name of the Gods I pray the, and in
their names I conjure the, that thou power al thy sorrows into mine entrails.
For from that way that thou go, I will not depart one jot: if thou go, I
will go: if thou rest, I will rest: if thou work I will work: if thou leave of,
I will do the same: if thou will die, know thou I will not live, Look friend what
thou will do: For thy troubles and mine, torment both one heart. If thou have
displeasure, al things dysplease me: if thou weep, I swer fro henceforth never
to laugh: if thou discharge ye of thy pain, fro henceforth I shall take it for
mine: if thou go alone, I will forsake company, and forthwith live solytarilie.
What will thou that I should desire? For all that ever thou wylt I will. Thou
complainest that in all thy trauayles thou can find no parent to remedy the
nor friend to council the. I swear to the friend Piramon, that of these, ii.
things I have as great need in my house, as thou have sorrow in thine. I know
well the remedy should come by riches, and by council, and consolacion of them
that be wise. And by reason of my heavy destinyes, slou^h has taken from me
the knowledge of wisdom: and fortune will not permyt me to have great riches.
Certainly I weep for my myserie, and yet there is but small remedy in me.

Thou say in thy letter, that thy neighbors and friends in promysinge have
behight the many things: but in performyng it they do nothing. Hereof I
marvel not, for the virtuous hand is not bound to make the tongue a fool.
Truly our fete dance, our hands should work at the sown of the tongue: our
life ends in few days, and our renown in fewer.

Promise is an ancient custom among the children of vanytie, and of custom
the tongue speaks hastily, and the hands work at leisure. Now let us speak
more particularly. Thou ought not to complain, in that thou find not but
in few, that diverse have found in the alone: it have been a custom to receive
merelye, and willyngly, but to give slowly, and with evil will. They that be
presumptuous do the one, and they which be the slouthful do the other. The
Greeks say, that he that promyseth, and is long in fulfillynge, is but a
slack friend.

We Romans say, that he is much better that denies forth with, because he
does not deceive him that asks. In this case I say, he that may give and
gives not, is an open enemy: and he that promyseth forthwith, and is long
before he perform it, it is but a suspicious friend What need words to our
friends, when we may succor the^ with works? It is not right, to whom we give
our hearts, which is the best thing of our hearts: that we give him our
tongue, which is the worst thing of our lives. In good so the the gods will not
suffer in the place of amity, to desire any thing of our friend in haste, and
to be driven of with long delaying. Plato in his laws says, we command
that in our governing, politic counsel be given to them that be in
prosperity, to the intent that they decaie not: and to succor them that be in
heuines and trouble, to the intent that they despair not. Certainly under
these words are comprised diverse great sentences. Thou know well, my friend
Piramon, that sweet words comfort the heart but little, that is in tribulation,
unless there be some good works therewith. I will not deny, but that they to
whom we have given our good wylles in the time of our prosperity, be bound
to give us of their goods, and to show us favor in our adversity. I
demand one thing of thee, wherefore hold thou a presumptuous license to
demand, and reprouest on the other part the liberty of denyinge? Truly as
the shamefast man should not have denay, in any of his requests being honest:
so the shameless and importunate man should be denayed, what so ever he
demands.

Thou may know, if thou know it not my friend Piramon: that to attain to
every thing that is demanded, belongs only to the Gods. To give all thing
that is demanded, is the sign of a servant: and to deny any thing, is a
token of liberty. To weep for that is denied, is the condition of tyrauntes:
to be unthankful for that is given, is the condition of Barbarians. And to
have a stout heart, though things are denied, is the guise of the Romans.
One of the things wherein Caius Caesar showed him self to be of high courage
was, that he had most greatest joy, when the senate denayed any thing desired
by him. Oftentimes he said. There is nothing where in Rome gives more glory
nor renown to my person, then when I show my self most hasty to demand,
and she most stiff to denay: to the intent that after she should know how
great my will is to desire, and how that my strength is to acquire. Me
thinks it is better to have recourse to the gods with virtue, then to
displease them with vices. And to give contentation to thy reposed will, when
thou see thy self in tribulation: and that thy demaundes of the gods and of
men be frustrate, thou ought to measure it with a right measure, and to wey
it in a right balaunce, the many things which they have given thee, and the few
things which they have denied thee. O how discourteous be we to the gods, and
ungracious to men, when we minish with forgetfulness that we have received of
them: and that little that has been denied us, we augmente with complaints?
Friend Piramon, I am beguiled, if thou be not fifty years of age, and all that
season thou haste done nothing but received gifts: and yet for all that, I
have not seen thee do one days service. Certainly it is no reason to
complain of eight days of evil fortune, being fifty years of age. Thou
say in thy letter how thou haste much pain: because thou know all thy
neighbors to be enuyous. In good sothe I have pain for thy pain, and of thy
marueylyng, I have great marueyle. For all admyration proceadeth of abundance
of ignorance, and fault of experience.

Does the quick understanding of men rule the life of them that be mortal,
that they neade not to think of the travail to come, having in their hands
present remedy? If they be hungry, they may eat: when they are cold, they may
warm them: if they be drowsy, they may sleep: when they be weary, they may
rest: when they are sick, they may be healed: and when they are heavy, they
may rejoice In such manner, that the careful life passes, some to make tiltes
and listes, some to make armoure and scaffolds, some to inuente new ginnes,
and some to repair bulwarks. I say the world and the flleshe do naught else
but fight against us, and we have need at all times to defend us from them.
All these remedies are against the travail of the fleashe. But what shall we
do, that the cursednesse of envy ends not among all these? Cursed is that
wealth, that every man enuieth. Certainly against envy is no fortress, nor
cave to hyde, nor high hill to mount on, nor thick wood to shadow in, nor
ship to escape in, nor horse to bear away, nor money to redeem us. Envy is so
venomous a serpente, that there was never mortal man among mortalles, that
could escape from the biting of her toothe, scratching of her nails, defyling
of her feet, and the castinge of her poison. I swear to thee my friend
Piramon, that such as fortune lifts up with great riches, she full of
cruelty sonest overthrows. Envy is so envious, that to them which of her
are most denied, and set farthest of: she gives most cruel strokes with her
feet. This unhappy envy prepares poison secretly for them that enjoy great
pleasures.

I have red diverse books of Hebrewe, Greek, Latin, and Caldei. And also I
have spoken with many excellent wise men, to see if there might be found any
remedy against an envious man. I confess the truth: read all that can be
read, and imagen all that can be, demand all that can be demanded: and ye
shall find none other cure against this cursed envy, but to banishe us fro all
the prosperity, and to dwell in the house of adversity. O how unhappy are
they that be in prosperity? for justly they that be set up in high estate,
cannot fly from the peril of Scilla, without falling into the danger of
Caribdis. They cannot escape the peril, without casting their treasures into
the sea. I say yt the malady of envy will not suffer them to escape from death,
and the medecin that is applied to them, will not assure their life. I cannot
determine which is the best, or to say more properly the worste: extreme
misery without the danger of fortune, or extreme prosperity that is always
threatened to fall. In this case to be so extreme I will not determine, sith in
the one is a perilous life, and in the other renoume is sure. I shall tell thee
what wise Cicero said, when he was pursued with many at Rome. Behold you
Romans, I hold you not for so good, nor my self so evil, to say the
troth always, nor always to make lies. I am certain that ye bear me no
envy, for that I am not as ye be: but it is, because ye can not be as I am. In
this case I had rather that my enemies had envy at my prosperity, then my
friends at my poverty.

This Orator spoke after the appetite of them that be in prosperity, leaving
to give remedy to them that be sorowefull. And after this Cicero had seen the
fields of Farsale, he took other council and remedy, such as pleased him in
Rome. For though Caesar had granted him his goods, yet that turned not his
credence and renown. Surely friend Piramon, I know no remedy to give thee
against envy, since thou see all the world full thereof. We see how we be the
sons of envy, and we live with envy, and die with envy, and he that leueth
most riches, leueth the greatest envy. The ancient wise men counseled rich
men, that they should have poor folks nere them: and they admonished the
poor, that they should not dwell nere to the rich. And truly it is good
reason. For the riches of rich me^, is the seed of envy to the poor. And
because the poor man lacks, and the rich has to much, causes discord
among the people. I swear by the gods immortal, friend Piramon, though they
that be evil would that I swear falsely, as much as riches with thought
nourishes couetise, so much the envious nourishes envy thereby. I tell the one
thing, and that is, that it is no good council to fly envy, and to avoid the
virtue contrary to the same. Homer says, that in his time there were two
Greeks extreme in all extremities: the one was extreme in riches, and
therefore he was persecuted by envy, and that was Achilles: and the other was
sore noted of malice, but no man had envy at him, and that was Thiestes.
Certainly I had rather be Achilles with his envy, then Thiestes without it.
Thou know well, that we Romans search not but for rest in our life, and
for honor after death. And since it is so, it is not possible but the man that
every man enuieth his renown, ought to be exalted in the rest of his life.
And sith I see those two things in thee, such as be my friends takes little
thought, for that thine enemies murmr against thee. Thou wrytest to me how
they of Lions do well, and are merry: except thy self, that art heavy, and full
of pensiuenes. And since they show not to have pleasure at thy displeasure, show
not thy self displeased with their pleasure. For it may chance one day they
shall be sorrowful, when that thou art merry: and so thou shall be quite with
them. In an evil person there can be no greater evil, nor in a good man a
greater fault, then to be displeased with another man's wealth, and to take
pleasure af another man's harm. And in case that all do us damage with envy,
yet much more a friend, then the enemy. For of mine enemy I will beware, and for
fear I will withdraw: but my friend with his amity may beguile me, and I by
my fidelity shall not perceive. Among all mortal enemies there is none worse,
then a friend that is envious of my felicity. Piramon my friend, I will
conclude, if thou will withdraw thy self fro enemies, then keep company with
thine own familiar friends. I wot not what to write more to thee, but with all
my heart I lament thy heuines. Thou know how thy niece Brusia slew with a
dagger her own husband. I was very sorry for her death, and for the renown
that she left behind her. Flauius Priscus thine uncle is newly made censoure.
The process between thy brother Formio and Britio is determined by the senate,
and it pleases me right well, that they be friends, and every man well
contented. The book entitled the consolation of heaviness I have ended, and
laid it in the capitol. I have written it in Greek, and that is the cause that
I sent it not to thee. But I do send thee a rich sword, and a fair girdle.
Faustine my wife does salute thee, and sends thy wife two sclaues. The gods
be my kepers, and comfort thee in thy present heuines.

Mark the man fortunate, to Piramon sore discomforted.

A letter sent by the Emperor Marcus Aurelius to Catullus Censorius, that was
so sorowefull for the death of Verissimus the Emperoures son, worthy to be
red and noted. Cap. viii.
Mark the young, and new Censour, saluteth thee, old and aunciente
Catullus. I have written two letters to thee, and thou have made answer to
none of them. If it be because thou could not, I hold my peace: if it be
because thou would not, then I complain me: if it be for forgetfulness, the^
I accuse thee: if it be because thou set little by me, then I do appeal
thee: if thou have dreamed that thou have written, I say believe not in
dreams: and if thou wylt not it should avail to glorify me, as a friend,
yet thou might write it, aduertising and repreuing me as the father to the
son: young virtuous persons are bound to honor ancient wise men, and no
less old wise men ought to endoctrine the young people, and very young as I
am. A just thing it is, that the new forces of youth, supply and serve them
that are worn by age. For their long experience instructs our tender age,
and natural ignorance. Youth is evil applied, when it abounds in force of
the body, and wants the virtues of the mind: and age is honored, wherein the
force dies outward, whereby virtues quickens the more inward. We may see
the tree, when the fruit is gathered, the leaves fall, and when flowers dry,
then more grene and perfect are the roots. I mean, that when the first
season of youth is passed, which is the Summer time: then comes age called
Winter, and purifieth the fruit of the flesh, and the leaves of favor fall,
the flowers of delight wither, and the vynes of hope dry outward, then it is
right, that much better are the roots of good works within. They that be old
and ancient, ought to praise their good works, rather then their white
hears. For honor ought to be given for the good life, and not for the white
head. Glorious is that common wealth, and fortunate is that prince, that is
lord of young men to travail, and ancient persons to council. As to regard
the sustaininge of the naturalitie of the life, in likewise ought to be
considered the policy of governance, the which is: that all the fruits come
nor dry not al at once, but when one begins, another fails. And in this
manner, ye that be ancient teaching us, and we be obedient, as old fathers and
young pullettes, being in the neste of the Senate: Of some their feathers
fallinge, and other young fethered: and where as the old fathers can not
fly, their trauayles are maintained by their tender children. Friend Catullus,
I purposed not to write one line this year, because my pen was troubled with
thy slouthe: but the weakness of my spirit, and the great peril of mine
offices, always called on me to demand thy council. This privilege the
old wise men hold in their houses where they dwell. They are always lords
over them that be simple, and are sclaues to them that be wise. I think thou
have forgotten me, thinking that sith the death of my dear son Verissimus,
the time has been so long, that I should forget it. Thou have occasion to
think so, for many things are cured in time, which reason can not help. But
in this case I can not tell which is the greatest, thy tru^pery, or my dolor.
I swear to thee by the gods immortal, that the hungry worms are not so
puissaunt in the entrales of the unhappy child: as the bitter sorrows are in
the heavy heart of the woeful father. And it is no comparison, for the son is
dead but one time, and the heavy father dies every momente. What wylt thou
more that I should say? But that one ought to have envy of his death, and
compassion of my life, because in dyeng he lives, and in the living I dye. In
the mischaunces of life, and in the great inconstancy of fortune, whereas her
gyles profits but little, and her strength less, I think the best remedy is
to feel it as a man, and dissimule it as discrete and wise. If all things as
they be felt at heart, should be showed outward with the tongue, I think that
the wyndes should break the heart with syghinges, and water all the earth
with weping. O if the corporal eyes saw the sorrow of the heart, I swear to
thee, they should see more of a drop of blood sweatinge within, then all the
weeping that appears without. There is no comparyson of the great dolours of
the body, to the least grief of the mind. For all travail of the body, men
may find some remedy: but if the heavy heart speak, it is not heard: if it
weep, it is not seen: if it complain, it is not believed. What shall the poor
heart do? Abhor the life, wherewith it dies: and desire death, wherewith it
lives. The high virtues among noble virtuous people, consiste not all only
to suffer the passions of the body, but also to dissimule them of the soul.
They be such, that alter the humors, and show it not outward: they bring a
fever without altering of the poulce, they alter the stomach, they make us to
knele to the earth, to suffer the water up to the mouth, and to take death
without leaving of the life: and finally they length our life, to the intent
that we should have no more travail, and denies us our grave, to the intent
that we should not rest. But considering, as I am troubled with sorrows, so am
I void of consolations: for when I have either desire of the one, or werynes
of the other, I use always this remedy: to dissimule with the tongue, to weep
with the eyes, and to feel it with my heart. I pass my life, as he that hoped
to lose all that he has, and never to recover that that is lost. I say this,
though ye see me not now make funeral wepinges and waylinges, as I did at the
death of my son: yet think not but it does bren my heart, so that with the
great heat inward, is consumed the humiditie of the eyes, for it brenneth al
my spirits within. Thou may know what an honorable father suffers, to
lose a good child: in all things the gods be liberal, except in giving us
virtuous children. Where there is abou^daunce of great estates, there is
greatest scarsitie of good inheritours. It is a doleful thing to hear, and
greater pity to see, how these fathers clime to have richesse, and to see
their children descend to have viciousnes. To see the fathers honor their
children, and the children to infame their fathers: yea and the fathers to give
rest to the children, and the children to give trouble to their fathers: yea
and sometime the fathers die for sorrow that their children die so sone, and we
see their children weep, because their fathers die so late. What should I say
more, but that the honor and riches that the fathers have procured with great
thought, the children consume with little care. I am certain of one thing, that
the fathers may gather riches with strength and craft to sustain their
children, but the Gods will not have durable, that that is begone with evil
intention: as that is, which is won to the prejudice of other, and possessed
with an evil heir.

And though the heavy destinies of the father permit, that the riches be left
to their children, to serve them in all their vices for their pastime: at last
yet according to their merits, the Gods will that the heir and heritage
should perish. Mark what I say, I had two sons, Comodus, and the prince
Verissimus, the younger is dead, that was greatest in virtue. Always I imagined,
that while the good lived, I should be poor: and now that the evil
remains, I think to be rich. I will tell thee the cause, the Gods are so
pitiful, that to a poor father they never give evil child: and to a rich
father they never give a good child. And as in all prosperity there chances
always some sinister fortune, either sone or late: so therewith fortune does
arm and apparel us, wherein she sees we shall fall to our greatest hurt.
And therefore the Gods permit, that the covetous fathers, in gathering with
great travail, should die with that hurt, to leave their riches to their
vicious children. I weep as much for my child that the Gods have left me, as
for him that they have taken from me. For the small estimation of him that
lives, makes immortal memory of him that is dead. The ill rest and
conversation of them that live, cause us to sighe for the company of them that
be dead. The ill is always desired for his illness to be dead, and the good
always meriteth to have his death bewailed. I say my friend Catullus, I
thought to have lost wy wit, when I saw my son Verissimus die: but I took
comfort again: for either he of me, or I of him must see the end,
considering that the Gods did but lend him to me, and gave him not, and how
they be inheritours, I to have the use of the fruit. For all things is
measured by the just will of the Gods, and not by our inordinate wylles and
appetites. I think when they took away from me my child, I restored him to
another, and not that they have taken mine. But sith it is the will of the
Gods to give rest to the good child, and hurt the father because he is evil:
I yield thanks to them for the season that they have suffered me to enjoy
his life, and for the patience that I have taken for his death. I desire them
to mitigate therewith the chasticement of their ire. And I desire, since they
have taken away the life from this child: to plant good customs in the
prince mine other son. I know what heaviness thou haste taken in Rome for
my sorrow. I pray the Gods to send thee joy of thy children, and that I may
reward thee with some good pleasure, for that thou have wept for my pain. My
wife Faustine saluteth thee, and truly thou would have had compassion to see
her, for she wepeth with her eyes, and sigheth with her heart, and with her
hands hurts her self, and curses with her tongue. She eats nothing on
the day, nor sleapeth in the night. She loves darkness, and abhors light,
and thereof I have no marueyle: for it is reason that for that was nourished in
her entrayles, she should feel sorrow at her heart. And the love of the mother
is so strong, that though her child be dead, and laid in grave, yet always
she has him quick in her heart. It is a general rule, that the person that
is entierly beloved, causes ever great grief at his death. And as for me, I
pass the life right sorowfully, though I show a joyful face, yet I want mirth
at my heart. And among wise men being sorrowful, and showing their faces mercy,
is none other thing but burying the quick, having no sepulture. And I swear
by the Gods immortal, I feel much more than I have said. And diverse times
me think I should fall down, because I dare not weep with mine eyes, yet I
feel it inwardly in my heart. I would feign common with thee in diverse things.
Come I pray thee to Briette, to the intent that we may speak together. And
sith it has pleased the Gods to take my child fro me, that I loved so well,
I would counsel with thee, that art my loving friend. But few days passed,
there came thither an Ambassador fro the Rhodes, to whom I gave the most
part of my horses: and fro the farthest part of Spain, there were brought me
eight, of the which I send the four. I would they were such as might please
ye. The gods be thy saulfegard, and send me and my wife some comfort.

Marcus Aurelius right sorrowful, has written this with his own hand.

A letter sent by Marcus Aurelius Emperor to Catullus Censo^ius, of the news
which at that time were at Rome. Cap. ix.
MArcus the new Censore, to thee Catullus now aged, sends salutations. There
are ten days paste, that in the temple of God Ianus I received thy letter. And
I take that same God to witness, that I had rather have seen thy person. Thou
desire that my letters may be long, but the sshortnes of time makes me to
answer thee more briefly, than I would. Thou wyllest me to give thee
knowledge of the news here. Thereto I anwere: that it were better to demand,
if there were any thing remaining here in Rome, or Italy, that is old. For
now by our evil destinies, all that is good and old, is ended: and new
things, which be evil, now begin. The Emperor, the Consul, the Tribune,
the Senators, the Ediles, the Flamines, the Pretours, the Centurions, all
things be new, save the veretues which be old. We pass the time in making
new officers, in deuisinge new counsels, and in raising new subsidies. In
such wise, that there has been now mo novelties within these four years,
the^ in time passed in.400. years. We now assemble together.300. to counsel in
the capitol, and there we brag and boste, swear and promise, that we will
exalte the virtuous, and subdue the vicious, favor the right, and not wink at
the wrong, punish the evil, and reward the good, repair old, and edefie
new, pluck vices up by the roots, and to plant virtues to amend the old, and
follow the good, reprove tyrauntes, and assist the poor: and when that we are
gone from thence they that spoke best words, are often taken with the worst
deeds. Oh wicked Rome, that now a days has such senators, which in saying
we will do, we will do, pass their life: and so every man seking his own
profit, forgets the weal publyke. Oftentimes I am in the senate to behold
others as they regard me: and I marvel much to hear the eloquence of their
words, the zeal of justice, and the justification of their persons: and after
that I come thence, I am ashamed to see their secret extortions, their damnable
thoughts, and their il works. And yet there is an other thing of more
marvel, and not to be suffered: that such persons as are most defamed, and
use most wicked vices, with their most damnable incencio^s, make their auowes
to do most extreme justice. It is an infallible rule, and of humain malice
most used: that he that is most hardy to commit greatest crimes, is most cruel
to give sentence against an other for the same offense.

Me think that we behold our own faults, as through small nets, which
cause things to seame the lesser: but we behold the faults of other in the
water, that causes them to seame greater. O how many have I seen condemned by
the Senate, for one small fault done in all their life, and yet they them
selves commit the same fault every hour. I have red, that in the time of
Alexander the great, there was a renowned pirate on the sea, called Dionides,
which robbed and drowned all ships that he could get: and by commandment of
this good king Alexander, there was an army sent forth to take him. And when he
was taken and presented to Alexander, the king said unto him: show me
Dionides, why do thou spoil on the sea, that no ship can sail out of the
east into the west for thee? The pirate answered and said: if I spoil the
sea, why do thou Alexander rob both the sea and land also? O Alexander,
because I fight with one ship in the sea, I am called a thief: and because thou
robbest with two hundred ships on the sea, and troublest all the world
with.200000. men, thou art called an Emperor.

I swear to thee Alexander, if fortune were as favorable to me, and the gods
as extreme against thee: they would give me thine empire, and give thee my
little ship, and then peradventure I should be a better king then thou art,
and thou a worse thief than I am. These were high words, and well received of
Alexander: and of troth to see if his words were correspondent to his
promises, he made him of a pirate a great captain of an army, and he was more
virtuous on land, than he was cruel on the sea. I promise thee Catullus,
Alexander did right well therein, and Dionides was to be praised greatly for that
he had said. Now adays in Italy, they that rob openly, are called lords:
and they that rob privily, are called thieves. In the annals of Liuius I have
red, that in the second troublous war punike, between the Romans and
Carthagians, there came an Ambassador Lusitain sent from Spain, to treat of
accord of peace. When he came to Rome, he proved before the senate, that sith
he entered into Italy, he had been ten times robbed of his goods: and whiles he
was at Rome, he had seen one of them that robbed him, hang up another that had
defended him. He seeing so evil a deed, and how the thief was saved without
justice: as a desperate man took a cole, and wrote upon the gibet as follows.
O gibet, thou art planted among thieves, norished among thieves, squared of
thieves, wrought of thieves, made of thieves, set among thieves, and hanged full of
innocents, with innocents. The original of these words are in the history
of Liuius, where the whole Decade was written with black ink, and these words
with red vermilion. I can not tell what other news I should send thee, but
that every thing is so new and so tender, and is joined with so evil sement,
that I fear me, all will fall suddenly to the ground. I tell thee, that some
are suddenly risen within Rome unto honor, whose fall I dare rather assure,
then life. For all buildinges hastily made, can not be sure. The longer a tree
is kept in his kind, the longer it will be ere it be old. The trees, whose
fruit we eat in summer, do warm us in winter. O how many have we seen
whereof we have marueyled of their rising, and been abashed of their falls.
They have grown as a whole piece, and suddenly wasted as a skumme. Their
felicity has been but a short moment, and their infortune as a long life.

Finally they have made a mylle, and laid on the stones of increase, and after
a little grinding, left it unoccupied all the whole year after. Thou know
well my friend Catullus, that we have seen Cincius Fuluius in one year made
consul, and his children tribunes, his wife a matrone for young maidens, and
beside that, made keeper of the capitol: and after that, not in one year but the
same day we saw Cincius beheaded in the place, his children drowned in Tiber,
his wife banished fro Rome, his house raced down to ye ground, and all his
goods confisked to the common treasury. This rigorous example we have not red
in any book, to take a copy of it, but we have seen it with our eyes, to keep
it in our minds. As the nations of people are variable, so are the conditions
of men diverse. And me thinks this is true, seeing that some love, some hate,
and that some seek, some eschew: and that some set little by, other make much
store. In such wise, that al can not be content with one thing, nor some with all things can not be satisfied. Let every man chose as him list, and embrace
the world when he will, I had rather mount a soft pace to the falling, and if I
can not come thereto, I will abide by the way, rather then with the sweat to
mount hastily, and then to tumble down headlong. In this case sith men's
hearts understand it, we need not to write further with pens. And of this
matter mark not the little that I do say, but the great deal that I will say.
And since I have begone, and that thou art in strange lands, I will write thee
all the news from hence. This year the.xxv. day of May, there came an
Ambassador out of Asia, saiynge he was of the Isle of Cetin, a baron right
propre of body, ruddy of aspect, and hardy of courage. He considered being at
Rome, though the summers days were long, yet winter would draw on, and then
would it be dangerous sailyng into this Isle, and saw that his business was
not dispatched: On a day being at the gate of the senate, seeing all the
senators enter into the Capitol, without any armor upon them, he as a man of
good spirit, and zelatour of his country, in the presence of us all, said
these words. O fathers conscript. O happy people. I am come from a strange
country to Rome, only to see Rome: and I have found Rome, without Rome. The
walls wherewith it is enclosed, has not brought me hither, but the fame of
them that govern it. I am not come to see the treasoury, wherein is the
treasure of all Realms: but I am come to see the sacred senate, out of the
which issues counsel for all men. I came not to see ye, because ye
vanquishe all other: but because I thought you more virtuous then all other. I
dare well say one thing, except the Gods make me blind, and trouble mine
understanding, ye be not Romans of Rome, nor this is not Rome of the Romans
your predecessors. We have heard in our Isle, that diverse Realms have been
won by the valiantnes of one, and conserved by the wisdom of all the Senate:
and at this hour ye are more like to lose, then to win as your fathers did.
All their exercise was in goodness, and ye that are their children, pass all
your time in ceremonies. I say this, ye Romans, because ye have almost
killed me with laughing at you, to see how ye do all as much your diligence,
to leave your armure without the gate of the Senate, as your predecessors did
take to them to defend the Empire. What profit is it to you, to leave of
these armours which hurt the bodies, and to put on them those which slay all the world: What profits it to ye careful suitor, that the senator enters
unarmed into ye senate without sweard or dagger: and his heart enters into ye
senate armed with malice? O Romans, I will ye know, that in our ysle we esteem
you not as armed captains, but as malicious senators. You fear us not with
sharp grounden swoordes, and daggers, but with hard hearts and venomous
tongues. If ye should in the senate put on harneis, and therewith take away your
lives, it were but a small loss: seeing that ye sustain not the innocents,
nor dispatche not the business of suitors. I can not suffer it. I can not tell
in what state ye stand here at Rome: for in our isle we take armoure from
fools, whether your armoures are taken away as from fools or mad folks, I
wot not. If it be done for ambitiousnes, it comes not of Romans, but of
tyrauntes: that wranglers and ireful folk should be judges over the peacible,
and the ambicions over the meke, and the malicious over the simple? If it be
done because ye be fools, it is not in the laws of the gods, that three
hundred fools should govern three hundred thousand wise men. It is a long
season that I have tarried for mine answer and license, and by your delays I
am now farther of, then I was the first day. We bring oil, honey, saffron,
wood, and timber, salt, silver. And sold out of our ysle into Rome, and ye will
that we go else where to seek justice. Ye will have one law to gather your
rentes, and another to determine our justice. Ye will that we pay our tributes
in one day, and ye will not discharge one of our errandes in a whole year. I
require you Romans, determine your selves to take away our lives, and so we
shall end: or else hear our co^plaintes, to the intent that we may serve you.
For in another manner it may be, that ye know by hearing with your ears, which
peradventure ye would not see with your eyes. And if ye think my words be out
of measure, so that ye will remedy my country, I set not by my life. And thus I
make an end. Verily friend Catullus, these be the words that he spoke to the
senate which I gate in writing. I say of troth, that the hardiness that the
Romans were wont to have in other countries, the same (as now) strangers
have in Rome. There were that said that this Ambassador should be punished,
but God forbid, that for saying troth in my presence, he should have been
corrected. It is enough, and to much to, to suffer these evils, though we slay
not, and persecute those that advertise and warn us of them. The sheep are not
in sucrtie of the wolf, but if the shepehearde have his dog with him. I
mean, dogs ought not to leave barkinge, for to awake the shepeherdes. There
is no God commands, nor law counsayleth, nor common wealth suffers, that
they which are committed to chastise liars, should hang them that say
truth. And sith the senators show them selves men in their living, and
sometime more human than other that be Sclaues, who else should deliver them
from chasticement? Oh Rome, and no Rome, having nothing but the name of Rome:
where is now become the nobleness of thy triumphs, the glory of thy
children, the rectitude of thy justice, and the honor of thy temples? For as
now they chastise him more that murmureth against one only senator, tha^ they
do them yt blaspheme al ye gods at once. For it greueth me more to se a
senator, or ce^sore to be worst of al other: than it displeases me yt it
should be said, yt he is the best of all other. For of a troth I say to thee
my friend Catullus, that as now we need not to seek to the Gods in the
temples, for the Senators are made gods in our hands. There is difference
between them that be immortal, and they that be mortal. For the Gods never
do thing that is evil, and the Senators do never any thing well. The Gods
never lie, and they never say truth. The gods pardon often, and they never
forgive. The gods are content to be honored five times in the year, and the
Senators would be honored ten times a day. What will thou that I say more?
but what so ever the Gods do, they ought to be praised: and the Senators in
all their works deserve to be reproved. Finally I conclude, that the Gods are
constant in every thing, and err and fail in nothing: and the Senators
assure nothing, but err in all thing. Only in one thing the Senators are not
of reason to be chasticed, and that is: when they intend not to amend their
faults, they will not suffer the Orators to wast their time to show them the
troth. Be it as may be, I am of the opinion, that what man or woman
withdraws their ears from hearing of troth, impossible it is for them to
apply their hearts to love any virtues: be it Censore that judges, or
Senanatour that ordeineth, or Emperor that commands, or Consul that
executes, or Orator that preaches. No mortal man, take he never so good
heed to his works, nor reason so well in his desires, but that he deserves
some chasticement for some cause, or counsel in his doings. And sith I have
written to thee thus of others, I will somewhat speak of my self, because of
the words of thy letter I have gathered, that thou desire to know of my
person. Know thou for certain, that in the kalendes of January, I was made
Censore in the senate, the which office I desired not, nor I have not deserved
it. The opinion of al wise men is, that no man, without he lack wit, or
surmounteth in folly, will gladly take on him the burdein and charges of other
men. A greater case it is, for a shamefast man to take on him an office to
please every man: for he must show a countenance outward, contrary to that
he thinks inward. Thou will say, that the good are ordained to take the
charge of offices. O unhappy Rome, that has willed to take me in such wise, as
to be the best in it. Grievous pestilence ought to come for the^ that be good,
sith I am escaped as good among the evil. I have accepted this office, not
for that I had need thereof, but to fulfill the commandment of Antonius my
graundfather. Have no marvel of any thing that I do, but of that I leave to
be done. For every man that is wedded to Faustine, there is no villainy but he
shall do it. I swear to thee, that sith the day we were wedded, me seameth
that I have no wit. I leave wedding for this time, and return to speak of
offices. Surely a peacible man ought to be in offices, though it be painful:
for as the offices are assured among them that be virtuous, so perillously
goes the virtuous folk among offices. And for the troth hereof, reckon what
they win, and then thou shall see what they loose. Say that is good, if thou
know it, and hear the evil, if thou desire to know it. He that will take the
charge to govern other, seeks thought and trouble for him self, envy for his
neighbors, spurs for his enemies, poverty for his rychessee, a waking of
thieves, peril for his body, end of his days, and torment for his great
renoume. Finally he seeks a way to reiecte his friends, and a repeal to
recover his enemies. O an unhappy man is he, that takes on him the charge of
children of many mothers, for he shall be always charged with thoughts how he
should content them all: full of sighs, because one has to give him: fear
that one should take from him, weping if he lose: and fear that they infame
him. He that knows this, without long tariing ought to set a bridle in his
head. But I say of one, as I say of another. For I will swear, and thou will
not deny it, that we may find some now a days, that had rather be in the
park to fight against the bulls, than be in suertie upon the scaffold.
Oftentimes I have heard say: Go we to the Theaters to run at the Bulls: go
we to chase the Hearts and wild Bores: and when they come there, they run
away, not the beasts from them, but they from the beasts. In such wise as
they went running, they return again fleing. I say, these ambicious
persons procure to govern, and are governed: they command, and are
commanded, they rule, and are ruled: and finally thinking to have diverse
under their hands, these wretches put them selves under every man's foot. For
ye remedy of al these perilles, my thought is comforted with one thing, and
that is, without procuring or offering my self, the senate of their own will
has commanded me. In the.viii. table of our ancient laws be these words.
We command that in our sacred senate, charge of justice be never given to him
that willingly offreth him self to it, but to such as by great deliberation
are chosen. This is certainly a just law. For men now be not so virtuous, nor
so loving to the common wealth, that they will forget their own quietness and
rest, doing damage to them self, to procure another man's profit. There is
none so folish that will leave his wife children, and his own sweet country, to
go into strange countries: but if he see him self among strange people,
thinking under the color of justice to seek for his own vtilite. I say not
this without weping: that the princes with their small study and thought, and
the judges with their couetise, have undermined and shaken down the high
walls of the policy of Rome. O my friend Catullus, what will thou that I
should say, but that our credence so minisheth, our couetise so largely
stretches, our hardines so boldeth, our shamefastnes so shameless, that we
provide for judges to go and rob our neighbors, as captains against our
enemies: I let thee to wit, where as Rome was beloved for chastising the evil,
now it is as much hated for spoiling the good. I do remember that I red, in the
time of Dennis Siracusan, that rules al Sicile, there came an Ambassador fro
Rhodes to Rome, being of a good age, well learned, and valiant in arms, and
right curious to note al things. He came to Rome to se the majesty of the
sacret senate, the height of the high Capitol enuironned with the Colliset: the
multitude of senators, the wisdom of ye counsailours, the glory of
triumphs, the correction of the evil, the peace of the inhabitauntes, the
diversity of nations, the aboudaunce of the maintenance, the order of the
offices: and finally seeing that Rome was Rome, he was demanded how he thought
thereby. He answered and said. O Rome, at this present world thou art full
of virtues and wise men, hereafter thou shall be furnished with fools. Lo
what high and very high words were these. Rome was seven hundred years
without any house of fools, and now it has been three hundred years
without one wise or virtuous man. Look what I say, it is no mockery, but of
troth, if the pitiful Gods now a days did reise our predecessors from death
to life, either they would not know us for their children, or else they would
attached us for fools. These be things used in Rome, but thou sendest no word
of that is used in Agripine. I will write nothing to the to put the to pain:
write to me some thing to rejoice me, if thy wife Dinisila chanced well of the
flote that came out of Cetin with salt, oil, and honey, I have well provided for
her. Will thou know that Flodius our uncle was cast down by the rage of his
horse, and is deceassed. Laercia and Colliodorus are friends together, by
occasion of a marriage, I do send the a goune, I pray to the gods to send the
joy thereof. My wife Faustine saluteth the. Recomend me to Iamiro thy son. The
gods have the in keeping, and sinister fortune be fro me.

Marcus, thy friend, to thee Catullus his own.

Marcus Aurelius writes to the amorous ladies of Rome. Chap. x.
Mark orator, Reading in Rhodes the art of humanity, to you amorous Ladies of
Rome, wishes health to your parsons, and amendmente of your desired lives. It
was written to me that at ye feast of the mother Berecinthia al you being
present together, made a play of me, in which you laid my life for an example,
and slaundered my renown. It is told me, that Auilina composed it, Lucia
Fuluta wrote it, and thou Toringua did sing it, and you altogether into the
Threatre did present it. You brought me forth painted in sundry forms, with a
book in my hand turned contrary, as a fained philosopher: with a long
tongue, as a bold speaker with our measure: with a horn in my head as a common
cuckold: with a nettel in my hand, as a tremblying lover: with a banner fallen
down, as a cowarde captain: with my berd half shaven, as a feminate man:
with a cloth before my eyes, as a condemned fool: and yet not content with
this, another day ye brought me forth portracted with another new deuyse. Ye
made a figure of mine, with feet of straw, the legs of amber, the knees of
wood, the thighs of brass, the belly of horn, the arms of pitche, the hands
of mace, the head of Iron, ye ears of an ass, the eyes of a serpent, the
here is of rotes iagged, ye teeth of a cat, the tongue of a scorpion, and the
forhead of lead, in which was written in two lines these letters. M. N. S. N. I,
S. V, S. which in my opinyo^ signifies this. This picture has not so many
metalles, as his life has chaunges. This done, ye went to the river and tied
it with the head douneward a hole day, and if it had not been for the good Lady
Messelyne. I think it had been tied there till now.

And now ye amorous Ladies have written me a letter, by Fuluius Fabricius, which
grieved me nothing, but as an amorous man from ye hands of ladies I accept it as
a mockery. And to ye intent I should have no laysure to think thereon, ye send
to demand a question of me, yt is: if I have found in my books, of what, for
what, from whence, when, for whom, and how women were first made. Because my
condition is to take mockes, for mockes, and since you do desire it, I will show
it you. Your friends and mine have written to me, but especially your imbassadour
Fuluius has instantly required me so to do. I am agreued with nothing and will
hold my peace, save to your letter only I will make answer. And sith there
has been none to ask the question, I protest to none but to you, amorous
ladies of Rome, I send my answer. And if any honest lady will take the
demand of you it is a token that she does envy the office that ye be of. For
of troth, that Lady which shows her self annoyed with your pain openly,
from henceforth I condemn her that she has some fault in secret. They that be
on the stage, fear not the roaring of the bull: they that be in the dongeon
fear not the shot of the cannon. I will say, the woman of good life, fears no
man's slanderous tongue The good matrons may keep me for their perpetual
servant, and the evil, for their chief enemy: I answer. It is expedyent you
know of what the first women were made. I say, that according to the
adversities of nations that are in the world, I find diverse opinyons in this
case. The Egiptians say, that when the river Nilus brake, and over ran the
earth, there abode certain pieces of earth which cleued together, and the son
coming to them, created many wild beasts, amongst whom was found the first
woman, Note ladies, it was necessary that the flood Nilus should break out,
so that the first woman might be made of earth. Al creatures are nourished and
bred in the intrayles of their mothers, except the woman, which was bred
without a mother. And it seems most true, that without mothers ye were borne,
for without rule ye live, and with order ye dye. Truly he takes upon him a
great thing, and has many cares in his mind, much to muse upon, neadeth much
council, neadeth long experience, and ought to chose amongst many women, that
thinks to rule one only wife by reason. Be the beasts never so wild, at
length the Lion is ruled by his keaper, the bull is enclosed in his park, the
horse ruled by the brydel, the little hoke catches the fysh, the Ox contented
to yealde to the yoke: only a woman is a beast which will never be tamed, she
never loses her boldness of commaundyng, nor by any bridel will be commanded.
The gods have made men as men, and beasts as beasts, and man's understanding
very high, and his strength of great force: yet there is nothing, be it of never
so great power, that can escape a woman, either with slight or might. But I
say to you amorous ladies, there is neither spur can make you go, rain that
can hold you back, bridel that can refrain you, neither fish hoke, ne net
that can take you: to conclude, there is no law can subdue you: nor shame
restrain you, nor fear abashe you, nor chastisement amend you. O to what
great peril puts he himsselfe unto, ye thinks to rule and correct you. For
if you take an opinyon, ye whole world cannot remove you: who warns you of
any thing, ye never believe him If they give you good council, you take it not:
if one threaten you, strait you complain. If one pray you, then are ye
proud: if they rejoice not in you, then are you spiteful. If one forbear you,
the^ are ye bold: if one chastise you strait you become serpents. Finally a
woman will never forget an injury, nor be thankeful for a benefit received.
Now a days the most symplyst of al women will swear, that they know less then
they do: but I swear, which of them that knows least, knows more evil then
al men, and of troth yt wisest man shall fail in their wisdom, Will ye know my
ladies how little you understand, and how much you be ingnoraunt? that is, in
matters of importance ye determine rashly, as if ye had studied on it a
thousand years: if any resist your council, ye hold him for a mortal ennemy,
hardy is that woman that dare give council to a man, and he more bold that
takes it of a woman? but I return and say, that he is a fool which takes
it, and he more fool that asks it, but he most fool that fulfilleth it. My
opinyon is, that he which will not stomble amongst so hard stones, not prick
himself amongst such thorns, nor styng him with so many nettels, let him
hark what I will say and do as he shall se, speak well, and work evil. In
promysing avow much: but in perfourmyng, accomplish little. Finally allow your
words, and condemn your counsels. If we could demand of famous me^ which are
dead, how they liked in their life the council of women. I am sure they would
not now rise again to believe them, nor be revived to here them. How was king
Philippe with Olimpia, Paris with Hellen: Alexander with Rofana, Aneas with
Dido, Hercules with Deanyrya, Anibal with Tamira, Antony with Cleopatra, Julius
with Domitian, Nero with Agrippina: and if you will not believe what they
suffered with them, ask of me unhappy man what I suffer amongst you. O ye
women, when I remember that I was borne of you, I loath my life: and thinking
how I live with you. I wish and desire my death. For there is no such death to
tormente, as to have to do with you: and contrary no such life, as to fly from
you. It is a common saying among women, that men be very unthankful, because
we were bred in your entrails, We order you as servants. Ye say for that ye
brought us forth with peril, and norished us with travail, it is reason that
we should always employ us to serve you I have thought diverse times with my
self, from whence the desire that man has to women comes. There are no eyes
but ought to weep, nor heart but should break, nor spirit but ought to wayle,
to se a wise man lost by a foolish woman. The foolyshe lover passes the day to
content his eyes, and the dark night in tormenting himself with sond
thoughts, one day in hearing tidings, another day in doing seruyces, sometime
liking darkness, sometime lothing light, being in company, and solitary lives:
and finally the poor lover may that he will not, and would that he may not.
More over the counsel of his friends avails him nothing, nor the infamy of his
enemies, not the loss of goods, the adventure of honor, the losing of, his
life, nor the sekyng of death, neither coming near, nor flyeng far, nor
seeing with his eyes, ne hearing with his ears, nor tasting with his mouth, nor
fealing with his hand: and to conclude, to get vyctory he is always at war with
him self. Then I would ye lovers knew, from whence your love does come, it is
this. The entrayles whereof we are bread be flesh, the breasts that we sucked
are flesh, the arms wherein we be fastened be of flesh, the thoughts which we
think be fleshly, the works which we do are fleshly, the men with whom we
live are of flesh, and the wonder for whom we dye are flesh: by which occasion
comes, the reuerting of our flesh to flesh, many fre hearts are entangled with
the snares of love. It seems well my ladies ye were gendered in puddels as
before is mentioned of the Egiptians: ye puddels have no clear water to
drink, nor fruit to eat, nor fish to be taken, nor ship to sail in.

I mean, that in your lives ye be filthy, your persons without shame, in
aduersitye weak and feeble, in prosperity full of deceit and guyle, false in
your words, and doubteful in your doings, in hatynge without measure, in
love extreme, in gifts covetous, in taking unshamefast: and finally, I say ye
are the ground of fear, in whom the wise men find peril, and the simple men
suffer injury. In you, the wise men hold their renown slaundered, and the
simple men their life in penury. Let us omit the opinion of the Egiptians, and
come to ye Greeks, which say, that in the deserts of Arabia, the son shines
hottest: and at the beginning there was found one woman, with one bird called
the Phoenix, which bird was created on the water, and the woman engendered by
the great heat of the son, and of the powder of trees in this wise. There was
a tree sore eaten with worms and upon a time a blast of lightning set it on fire
and burnt it, so as amongst the ashes of that rotten tree, the first woman was
made and found. Although I be a Roman philosopher, yet can I not disalow the
opinion of the greek philosopher. Of troth ye amorous dames, ye have your
tongues of the nature of fire, and your conditions like the powder of a rotten
tree. According to the dyuersity of beasts, so nature has in diverse parts of
the body placed their strength: as the Eagle in her byl, ye Unicorn in the
horn, the serpent in the tail, the bull in the head, the bear in his paws,
the horse in the breast, the dog in the teath, the bore in the tuske, the
doves in the wings, and the women in their tongues. For of troth the flight
of the dove is not so high, as the fantasy of your folyshnes is vain: the cat
scratcheth not so sore with her nails, as ye scratch the folish men with your
importunities. The dog hurts not him so much that he runs after, as ye
do ye sorrowful lover that serves you: the life of him is not in so much
danger that catches the bull by the horns, as the same of him that falls in
your hands. To conclude, the serpent has not so much poison in his tail: as
ye have in your tongues. I accept the Roman ladies a part, for there are many
very noble, whose lives are not touched with complaint, nor good fames had in
suspect. Of such, neither my letter speaks ought, nor my pen writes: but
of those women I speak that be such, as all the venomous beasts in ye world
have not so much poison in their bodies, as one of those has in their tongues.
And since the gods have commanded, and our fate does permit, yt the life of men
cannot pass without women: I advise the youth, and beseech the aged, I wake the
wise, and instruc^ ^^mple, to shonne women of evil name, more then the common
pestilence. R^^^^ng the ancient laws of Plato, I find written this. We
comaund that al women openly defamed, be openly banished the city, to
thintente that others seeing the sin punished, may abhor the same, for fear
to fall in the like pain. The same law said further, we comaund yt they pardon
a woman for all her faults she commits bodily, in case ye se amendment
likewise in her: but we will that no fault be pardoned, committed by the tongue.
For actual sin done, is the frailety of nature, the tongue, only of malice. O
deuyne Plato, master and measure of al knowledge and science, and prince of al
philosophers. When thou in the golden world maydst such laws, in which time
there was such scarsitye of those women which were evil, and so great plenty of
them that were good: what should we do now in Rome, where there be so many evil
openly, and none good in secret? women naturally ought to be shamefast in
their face, temperate in words, wise of wit, sober in going, honest in
conversation, pitiful in correction, ware in their living, avoiding companyes,
faithful in their promise, constant in love. Finally she that will be counted
honest, let her not trust to the wisdom of the wise, nor commit her fame to
the wanton youth: let every wise woman take heed what he is yt promyseth her
ought. For after that the flames of Venus be set on fire, and Cupide shot his
arrows, the rich offers all that he has, and the poor all that he may. The
wise man will ever be her friend, and the simple man for ever her servant. The
wise man will lose his life for her, and the simple will accept his death for
her. The old men say, they will be friends to their friends: and the young man
will say, he will be enemy to their enemies. The aged promysing to pay her debtes,
the other to revenge her injuries. Finally the one because to hide their
poverty, and the other to publyshe their beauty, lead these fools losing
their lives, and bringinge their fame to end. I will leave to speak of the
good women, for I mind not to charge them with ought. I ask you amorous ladies
if Plato was amongst you when ye made a play of my life, and drew my picture
about Rome? no surely, for that I se in your act now, I do suspect that to be
true which has been said of others, for there are few in Rome that execute
the pain of Platoes law. One thing ye cannot deny, if I were the worst of al
men, at the last ye se the end of my vylanies: but this you cannot deny, that
she which is least evil of al you, ye naughtines of her life, I could not
sufficiently set out in my life. Yt is great peril to wise women to be
neighbored with foles, it is great peril to ye shamefast to be with the shameless,
it is great peril to the chaste to be with the adulterers, great peril it is for
the honorable to be with the defamed, for there is no slaundered woman but
thinks every one defamed, or at the least desires to have them so, procures
to have them slaundered, or says they be infamed. And in the end to hide their
infamy, they slander all the good. It is long sith I knew you amorous ladies,
and you me. If ye speak, I speak, if you know I know. If ye hold your peace,
I am still: if ye speak openly, I will not talk in secret. Thou know well
Auilma yt did compass yt jest of me, that Eumedes sold caulfes dearer in
the butcherie, then thou did innocent virgins in thy house. And thou
Toringa know well yt before me thou could not count all thy lovers on thy
fingers, but did desire to have a bushel of peason. Thou wottest well Liuia
Fuluia, when thou were thou wottest with whom) at Bretus, we made agreement with
thy husband, thou tokest him aside and said, unless I may lie out of my house
one night in a weke, thou ^hal not lie quietly in thy house, thou know well
Rotoria, yt in thy youth thou were two years on the sea, and did co^pound
with the pirate yt no woman should serve the hundred soldiers but thou alone
in a galy. Thou know right well Enna curtia that when the censor came to take
the, he found.v. men's apparel, the which thou warest in the night season, and
but one womans attire wherewith thou was clothed in the day time. Thou know
well Pesilana Fabricia yt Alluines, Metelles, and thou being married, demanded
openly what thou had gotten in his house with thy friends in secret thou
know well Camilla, not being content with thy own country folks, thou
had such resort and haunte of strangers to the, that thou can speak al
languages.

I will mark them that have marked me, hurt them that have hurted me, persecute
them yt have persecuted me, defame them that have slaundered me, al other my
pen pardons, for yt they pardoned me in their play. Because my letter begone
with that ye did to my parson, therefore I will end it, with that it knows of
your good names. And thus I conclude, yt a man may escape from al dangers in
shonning them: but from women, there is no way but to fly from them. Thus I end,
and beseech the gods that I may se of you that which you would se of me: and
since ye be lovers, I counsel you, as ye have sent me the play in a mockery,
even so to receive my answer.

Mark now the Rhodian, to the amorous Ladies of Rome.

Of a letter sent by Marcus Aurelius to his love Boemia, for that she desired
to go with him to the wars. Cap. xi.
MArcus the Roman praetor, being in the wars of Dacia: sends health to his
loving Boemia, remainyng in the pleasours of Rome. Escapinge from a cruel
battle thy few lines I red, and understood thy large informacion. I let the
know thou have astonyed me more, then mine enemies have feared me: and taking
thy letter in my hands, the herb of malice entered into my heart. When I temper
my body with ye delights, I think my heart fre fro the venyme of thy amors:
since I of my will, and thou for want of power have given us to be fre of our
pleasures, I think as well to make a deuorce of our sorrows. But ye be such, ye
such I say, as are ye banishmentes of love: and the treasour of grefes. The
love of you al ought to be digested with pills, but the passion of one of you
will not be oppressed, with all the rubarbe, in Alexandria. Ye show your selves
cruel to pardon an enemy: and ever lightly you change your friends. I have
curiously made search, whylest delight governed my youth: yet could I never se
in a woman stedfastnes, nor reason in their love, nor end in their hate. The
present wantones quarelleth with my youth passed, because thou see not in me
the ancient good will toward the, nor ye present service. And certainly hearing
thy accusacion, and not my iustificacion: thou myghtest pay me as justly with
death, as I pay the with forgetfulness. The which forgetfulness ought to be as
strange in him that serves as ingratitude in the lady that is served.
Think thou yt I have forgotten the law of Venus? when I commanded that the
curious lovers should exercise their strength in chiualry, and occupy their
hearts in love? and more it wills a man to wear his gear cleanly, their
feet right, their bodies constant, their voice soft and humble, demure and
modeste of there: they ought to have eyes open always loking up to the
wyndowes, and their hearts ready to fly into the air. For a troth my friend
Boemia, he is a gross lover that has his will in captivity: and his judgment
fre. The judgment is of no value, where the will is in thraldom. This I say,
yt thou may know, though my age has left the exercise: yet my understanding
has not forget the art, Thou complainest because I give my self to much
quiet, and that I have forgotten the, I will not deny the truth, the day of my
forgetting makes the pryuy of my thoughts. And reason the ouerseer declares,
that it is not requysite for my grauytie to permyt I should love: nor in thy
age to suffer to be beloved. The world does dissemble many things in youth:
which in age meriteth grievous corrections. The wanton toys of youth proceed of
ignorance, but the vylanies done in age grow of malice.

When I walked in nyghtes I ietted the streates, I sange ballades: I gased to
the wyndowes, I played on the gittornes: I scaled the walls, I wakened ye
youth. Think thou I wiste what I did in my youth? but since I se my self
bereued of all my wonted wanton toys, and polished with so many white hears,
clad with so many sorrows: either I think now I was not then, or else I dream
now, not knowing the way I straye in, nor seeing that stony way ready to
stumble in. Unwittingly I have fallen into ye stairs, not foreseing the
wherilpole: guidles I entered, in the rashenes of my youth I lost me: for the
which I ask pardon. And now that I am out of ye briers, thou would have me
further in then ever I was. Now that I can not take the purgations, thou
offerest to me the siroppes. I have waked all night, and now thou geuest me a
fresh alarm. By our ancient friendship I pray thee, and by the gods I conjure
thee: that since my heart is rebel to thy will, that thy doubtful will do
suffer, and let alone, my will out of doubt. And because thou should not
think any ingratitude in my white heeres as I may in thy young wanton person,
I will that we account that we have gotten, and that we hope to get. Tell me
what comes of these vain pleasures? the time evil spent, the fame in way of
perdition, the goods consumed, the credit lost, the gods offends, the
virtues sclaundered: from whence we get the names of brute beasts, and sir
names of shame. Such be ye, and others. Thou writest in thy letter how thou
would willingly leave Rome, and come to see me in the wars of Dacia.
Considering thy folly I laugh, but knowing thy boldness I believe thee. And when
I think on this, I turn to my bosom, and peruse thy seal: doubting whether
the letter were thine or not. The veins of my heart do change, my color does
turn, imagening that either shame has utterly forsaken thee, or else gravity
has wholly abandoned me: for such lightness should not be believed, but of the
like persons. Thou know well he that does evil, deserves punishment sooner,
then he that does infamy. I would ask the whether thou will go? thou
suffredest to be cut as sower grape, and now thou would be sold for good
wine? thou came in with cheries, and yet would remain as quinces. We have
eaten the in blossoms, and thou will be like the fruit? the nuttes be
pleasant, but the shelles be hard. By dong thou were made ripe in thy youth,
and thou wenest to be in still. Thou art naught else but rotten. And if thou be
rotten, you art to be abhorred. Thou art not content with.xl. years which you
have, whereof xxv. thou did pass in taste, like to swear wine that is sold,
or like the melo^s that be ripe and melow. Art not thou that Boemia which
lacks two teethe before? are not thine eyes sonken into thy head? thy hears
whiter, thy fleashe wryncled, and thy hand perished with the gout, and one
ribbee marred with child bearing? Whether do thou desire to go? put thy
self then in a barel, and cast it into the river, so shall thou become pure
and white. We have eaten the fresh fish, and now thou would bring hither the
stinking salt fish. O Boemia, Boemia, in this case I see no trust in youth,
nor hope in age. For under this thy hored age there is hid, the panges of
frail youth. Thou co^plainest that thou have nothing, it is an old quarrel of
the ancient amorous ladies in Rome that taking all things, they say they have
left them nothing. The cause thereof is, where you do lack credit, there ye
would have it accomplished with money. Believe me loving friend, the folish
estate of unlawful gaming both gives an unsure state, and also an evil fame
to the person. I know not how thou art so wastful, for if I pulled of my
ringes with ye one hand, thou pickedst my purse with the other: greater wars
had thou then with my coffers, then I have now with my enemies. I never had
jewel, but thou demaundedst of me, and thou never askedst me thing that I
denied thee. I find and bewail now in my age, the high parts of my youth. Of
travel and poverty thou complainest. I am he that has great need of the
medicine for this opilation, and plasters for the son, and cold water for
such a burning fever. Do thou not well remember, how I did banish my
necessity into the land of forgetfulness, and placed thy good will, for the
request of my service? in the winter I went naked, and in the summer loded with
clothes. In the mire I went on foot, and rode in a fair way. When I was sad I
laughed, when I was glad I wept. Being afraid, I drew out my strength, and out
of strength cowardnes. The night with sighs, and days in wayling I consumed.
When thou hadest need of any thing, I robbed my father for it. Tell me Boemia,
with whom did thou fulfill thine open follies, but with the misorders that I
did in secret? wot ye what I think of the amorous ladies in Rome? that ye be
mootes in old garments, a pastime for light persons, a treasure of fools,
and the sepulcres of vices. This that seems to me is, that in thy youth every
man gave to thee, for that thou should give to every one: now thou geuest
thy self to every man, because every one should give them to thee. Thou
tellest me yt you have two sons, and lackest help for the^. Give thanks to
ye gods for ye mercy they have showed thee. To.xv. children of Fabritius my
neighbor, they gave but one father: and to thine only two sons, they have
given.xv. fathers. Wherefore divide them to their fathers, and every one shall be
well provided. Lucia thy daughter in deed, and mine by suspect, remember that I
have done more in marieng of her, then thou did, bringing her forth. For in
the getting of her, thou call many: but to mary her, I did it alone. Very
little I write to the, in respect of that I would write. Butrio Cornely has
spoken much to me on thy behalf, and he shall say as much to the in my part. It
is long ago sith I knew thy impacience, I know well thou will send me another
more malicious. I pray the, sense I write to the in secret, discover me not
openly: and when thou read this, remember what occasion thou have given me
to write thus. Although we be fallen out, yet I will send the money. I send
the a gown, and the gods be with thee Boemia, and send me from this war with
peace.

Mark pretour in Daci, to Boemia his lover and ancient friend in Rome.

The answer of Boemia to the Emperor Marcus Aurelius. Wherein is expressed
the great malice, and little patience of an evil woman. Cap. xii.
BOemia thine ancient lover, to thee Mark of mount Celio her natural enemy,
desires vengeance of thy person: and evil fortune during thy life. I have
received thy letter: and thereby perceive thy spiteful inte^tes, and thy cruel
malices. Such naughty persons as you art, have this privilege: yt since one does
suffer your villainies in secret, you will hurt the^ openly: but you shall not do
so with me Mark. Although I am not treasoresse of thy good: yet at ye least I am
of thy naughtines. Al yt I cannot revenge with my person: I will not spare to do
it with my tongue. And though we women for weakness sake, ar easily ouercom in
person: yet know you that our hearts are invincible. Thou say, escaping
from a battle, thou receiuedst my letter: whereof thou wast sore agaste.

It is a common thing to them that be slothful to speak of love, for fools
to treat of books, and for cowards to blase of arms. I say it, because the
answer of a letter was not nedeful, to rehearse to a woman whether it was
before the battle, or after. I think well thou have escaped it, for thou were
not the first that fought, nor the last that fled. I never saw yt go to the
war in thy youth, that ever I was fearful of thy life: for knowing thy
cowardlines, I never took care for thy absence, I always judged thy person
safe. The^ tell me Mark, what do thou now in thy age, I think thou carieste
thy lance, not to serve thy turn in thy war: but to lean on, when the gout
takes the, Thy head piece I judge, thou have not to defend the from stroks of
swords: but to drink withal in tauernes. I never saw the strike any man with
thy sword: but I have seen the kill a thousand women with thy tongue. O
malicious Mark, if thou were as valiaunte, as thou art spiteful: thou
should be no less feared among the barbarous nations, then thou art
abhorred (with good reason) amongst the Romans. Tell me what thou list, but
thou can not deny? but both thou have been, and art a slack lover, a
cowardly knight, an unknown friend, auaricious, infamed, an ennemy to all men:
and friend to none. Moreover we yt knew the a light young man, condemn the now
for an old doting fool. Thou say, yt taking my letter into thy hands,
forthwith thy heart received the herb of malice. I believe the well unsworn:
for any thing touching malice, does straight find harber in thy breast. The
beasts corrupted do take poison, which the sound, and of good complexion,
refuses. Of one thing I am sure, thou shall not die of poison. For seldom
times one poison hurts another: but it drives out the other. O malicious
Mark: if al they in Rome knew the, as well as the unhappy Boemia does: they
should se how much the words that thou speak, differ from the intencion of
thy heart. And as by the books thou make, thou meritest ye name of a
philosopher: even so for the ilnes thou inuentest, thou do deserve the name
of a tiraunt. Thou say, thou saw never constancy in a woman's love, nor end
in her hate. I joy not a little, that other ladies in Rome as well as I, do know
thy small wisdom. Behold Mark, I will not mock the: For thou art such a one,
as never deserved that one should begin to love, nor end to hate Will thou have
stabilite in love, and thou unthankful of thy service? will thou serve in
mockery, and be beloved faithfully? will thou enjoy the parson, without
spending any of the goods? will thou have no complaints on the, and thou
ceasest not thy malice? Thou know the il of women: I will thou know that we
be not so folishe as ye wene us: nor thou so wise as thou praisest thy self to
be. Hitherto we have seen mo men follow the desire of women, then women have
liked to follow men. I have seen a thousand times, yea and thou thy self, that
one man has not so mighty a heart, as to overcome three wise women: and one
woman holds her self strong enough, to subdue.iii. C. light persons. Thou
say thou art ashamed of my lightness, to se me forsake Rome, and come to the
into the wars. Great is the love of the country, and many leave much goods
which they have in strange lands, to live poorly in their own: but greater
is thy love, since I would leave Rome with the delites therein, and come to seek
the in straung lands among the rude soldiers. O malicious Mark, O strange
friend. If I leave Rome, it were to go seek my heart, which is with thee in
the wars. And certainly oftentimes when I think, of thy absence, I fall into
a swoune, as one that had no heart: but I never find remedy. I think our
love is not like to these beasts, which have their minds only upon sensual
pleasures, without the co^ioyning of the loving hearts. I swear to the by the
goddess Vestal, and the mother Berecinthia: that thou owe more to me for the
love I have borne to thee in one day, then for the service I have done to thee
in.xxii. years. Behold unhappy Mark, how much and dearly I loved thee. In thy
presence I always beheld thee, and absent I always thought of thee: sleping
I dreamed on thee, I have wept for thy sorrows, and laughed at thy pleasures:
and finally al my wealth I wished thee, and al thy misfortunes I took as mine.
I ensure thee of one thing: that I feel not so much the persecution thou have
done to me, as I do the wayling forgetfulness thou show to me. It is a great
grief to a covetous man to lose his goods: but without comparison it is a
greater torment for the lover, to see his love evil bestowed. It is a hurt
that is always sore, and a pain always paynefull, a sorrow always sorrowful,
and it is a death that never ends. O if men knew how dearly and faithfully
women do love, when they are bent to love: and with what malicious heart they
hate, being set to hate: I swear to you, ye would never company with them in
love: or if ye did love them, ye would never leave for fear of their hate. And
as there is never great hate, but where there was first much love: even so thou
shall never be greatly hated, for that thou were never truly beloved of the
ladies. The sorrowful Boeme has loved thee xxii. years of her life: and now
she only hates thee till after her death.

Thou say I may be eaten for veriuyce: and yet would be sold for wine. I
know I have erred, as one both young and light: and when I found me to straye
out of the way I was to far gone, and my mishappe could no other way, nor
remedy. It is a great loss of all losses when there is no remedy. I have
offended as a weak and frail woman, but thou as a man strong. I erred by
simple ignorance, but thou of a purposed and wilful malice. I sinned not,
knowing that I did amiss: but thou knew what thou did. I did credit
thy words as a faithful knighte: and thou betraidest me with a.1000. lies, as
a common lier. Tell me, did not thou seek occasion to come into my mothers
house Getulia, to entise me her daughter Boemia to thy mind? did not thou
promise my father, to teach me to read in one year: and read me Ouide of
the act of love? did not thou swear to mary me, and after withdrewe thy
hand as a false adulterer? do thou not know that thou never foundest in my
person any vyllany, nor in thy mouth any truth? At the least thou can not
deny, but thou have offended the gods, thou art defamed amongst me^, odious to
the Romans, a sclaunderer of the good folks, an example to the ill, and
finally a traitor to my father, a breaker of thy faith to my mother, and to me
the unhappy Boemia an unkind lover. O malicious Mark, have thou not cut me in
leaves, offering to my father to keep his vines safe? Evil may the chicken
trust the Kyte, or the Lambs the Wolf, or the Doves the Faucon, but thou
art worse to bring up the daughters of good men. O cursed Mark, a hurtful
keaper of vines has the Matrone of Rome found thee, in keapyng their
daughters. I swear, that there was neither grape nor cluster, but it was
either eaten, or gathered by the. Thou did eat me grene, for the which I
promise the it has set thy teeth on edge. Thou say I was riped by power of
heat and straw. It greueth me not so much that thou say it, as that thou
geuest me occasion to say to the, thy shame is so shameless, and thy evil so
malicious, yt I cannot make answer to thy purpose, unless I rub the on the
quycke. I ask the when thou mariedst Faustine: whether thou foundest them
grene or ripe? thou know well, and so do I also, that other gaged the vessel,
and thou drankest the lyees: other had the meat, and thou the husks: other
did eat them being grene, and with the refuge set thy teath on edge. O cursed
Mark: behold how great thy euels are, and how the gods have justly punished
the, that being young, thou could not deserve to be beloved of thy lovers,
nor yet now in thy age, thy wife keep her faith to the. For me to be revenged
of thy parson, I need no more but to se the married to Faustine. By the mother
