Berecinthia I promise the, that if thy small wisdom might attain to know at
the full, what they say of the, and her in Rome: thou would weep both day and
night for the life of Faustine, and not leave the woeful Boemia. O Mark, little
care is taken for the, and how far is our understanding uncoupled from thy
thoughts. For through thy great learning, thy house in the day time is a
schole of philosophers, and the wantonness of thy wife Faustine in the night
makes it a receite of ruffians. It is a just judgment of the gods, since
that thy malice only suffices to poison many that be good, the euilnes only
of one woman, shall be enough to spoil, and take away thy good renowm. One
difference there is between the and me, and thy Faustine, which is, that my
facts are in suspect, and yours done in deed, mine be in secret, but yours
known openly. I have but stombled, but you have fallen. For one only fault I
deserve punishment: but you deserve pardon for none. My dishonor dyed with my
fact, and is buried with my amendme^t: but your infamy is borne with your
desires, nourished with your malices, and still with your works. Finally your
infamy shall never dye, for you lived never well. O Mark malicious, with all that
thou know, do not thou know yt to dye well, does cover an evil fame, and
to make an end of an evil life, does begin a good fame? Thou ceasest not to say
evil only of suspect, which thy false judgments gives: and yet would thou
we should conceal that, we se with our eyes? Of one thing I am sure, that
neither of the, nor of Faustine there are has been any false witness. For there
are so many true euilles, yt there neadeth no lies to be invented. Thou say
it is an old custom, with the amorous ladies in Rome, though they take of
many, yet they are the porest of al: because we want credit, we are honored
for silver. It is most certain, yt of holly we look for pricks, of acorns
husks, of nettels stinginge, and of thy mouth malices. I have seriously noted:
I never heard ye say well of any, nor I never knew any that would the good. What
greater punishment can I desire for thy wickedness, nor more vengeance for my
injuries, then to se all the amorous ladies of Rome discontented with thy life,
and joy to think on thy death, cursed is the man whose life many do bewail,
and in whose death every one does rejoice. It is the property of such
unthankful wretches as thou art, to forget the great good done to them, and to
repent yt little they give. How much the noble hearts do rejoice in giving to
other: so much they are ashamed to take service unrewarded. For in giving they
are lords, and in taking they become sclaues. I ask what it is thou have given
me, or what you have received of me? I have adventured my good fame, and given
thee possession of my person: I have made thee lord of me and mine: I banished
me from my country, I have put in peril my life. In recompense of this, thou
do detect me of misery. Thou never gave me ought with thy heart, nor I took
it with good will, nor it ever did me profit. As all things recover a name,
not for the work we openly see: but for the secret intention with which we
work. Even so thou unhappy man desire me, not to enjoy my parsonne, but
rather to have my money. We ought not to call thee a clear lover, but rather a
thief, and a wily person. I had a little ring of thine, I mind to throw it
into the river: and a gown thou gave me, which I have burnt. And if I
thought my body were increased with ye bread I did eat of thine, I would cut
my flesh being whole, and let out my blood without fear. O malicious Mark,
thy obscured malice will not suffer thee to understand my clear letter. For I
sent not to thee to ask money, to relieve my poverty and solitarines: but
only to acknowledge and satisfy my willing heart. Such vain and covetous men
as thou, are contented with gifts, but the hearts incarnate in love, are not
satisfied with a little money. For love is rewarded always with love. The man
that loves not as a man of reason, but like a brute beast, and the woman that
loves not where she is beloved, but only for the gain of her body: such
ought not to be credited in words, nor their persons to be honored. For the
love of her ends when goods fails: and his love when her beauty decaieth.
If the beauty of my face did procure thy love, and they riches only allured my
good will: it is right, that we should not be called wise lovers, but rather
folishe persons. O cursed Mark, I never loved thee for thy goods, although
thou likedst me for that I was fair. Then I loved with my heart, and now I
abhor thee with all my heart. Thou say the gods used great pity on me, to
give me few children, and them many fathers. The greatest fault in women is
shameless, and the greatest villainy in men is to be evil sayers. Diverse things
ought to be borne in the weakness of women, which in the wisdom of men are
not permitted. I say this, for that I never saw in the te^perance to cloak
thine own maliciousnes, nor wisdom to shadow the debilitie of others. Thou
say my children have many fathers: but I swear to thee, that the children
of Faustine shall not be fatherles, although you die. And if the gods as thou
say have been pitiful to my children, no less art thou to strange
children. For Faustine keeps the but to excuse her faults, and to be tutor to
her children. O cursed Mark, thou nedest not take thought, for thy children
have no need to be married. For one thing we are bound to thee, that is: the
example of thy patience, for since thou suffrest Faustine in so many open
infamies, it is no great need we suffer any secrets in thee. For this present
I say no more, I end my letter, desiring to se shortly the end of thy life.

Marcus Aurelius writes to the lady Macrine the Roman, of whom (beholding
her at the wyndowe) he became enamoured. Which declares what force the beauty
of a fair woman has in a weak man. Cap. xiii.
Mark the very desirous, to the lady Macrine greatly desired. I know not
whether by my evil adventure, or by hap of my good adventure: not long ago I
saw the at a window, where thou had thy arms as close, as I my eyes
displayed, that cursed be they for ever: for in beholding thy face, forthwith my
heart abode with the as prisoner. The beginning of thy knowledge, is the end of
my reason, and falling in: shonnyng one evil, come infinite trauayles to men. I
say it for this, if I had not been ydel, I had not gone out of my house: and
not gone out of my house, I had not passed by the streat. And not going through
the streate, I had not seen yt at the window: and not seeing the at the window,
I had not desired thy person. And not desiringe thy person, I had not put thy
fame in so great peril, nor my life in doubt: nor we had given no occasion to
Rome to speak of us. For of troth lady Macrine, in this case I condemn my
self. For willyngly I did behold the. I did not salute the, although thou
desiredst to be seen. Since thou were set up as a white, it is no merueile
though I shot with the arrows of my eyes, at the but of thy beauty, with
rollyng eyes, with brows bent, well colored face, incarnate teth, ruddy lips,
courled here, hands set with ringes, clothed with a thousand manner of
colors, having purses full of sweet sauoures, the bracelettes and earinges
full of pearls and stones. Tell me what this means? The most that I can think
of this is, since you show us your bodies openly, ye would we should know your
desires in secret. And if it be so, as I believe it is, it seems to me lady
Macrine, thou oughteste to love him that lyketh the, to enfourme him that
seeks the, to answer him that calls the, to feale him that fealeth the,
and to understand him that understands the: and since thou understand me, I
do understand the, and understand that thou know not. I do well remember as I
went by the streat solitarily to se ii. thieves put to death, my eyes saw the at
a window: on whom depends al my desires. More justice thou do to me, then I
to the theaues: for I being at justice, thou have iusticed the justice, and
none dare pain the. The gallows is not so cruel to them, which never knew but
doing evil: as thou art to me, which never thought other but to serve the. They
suffer but one death, but thou make me suffer a thousand. They in one day
and one hour end their lives, and I each minute do feel the pa^ges of death.
They died gilty, but I innocently. They die openly, and I in secret. What will thou I say more to thee, they wept for that they died, and I weep tears of
blood from my heart for that I live. This is the difference, their torments
spreads abrod through al their body, and I keep mine together in my heart. O
cruel Macrine, I know not what justice this is, yt they kill men for robbing and
stealing of money, and suffer women to live, which steal men's hearts. If they
take the lives from them yt pick purses, why then do they suffer ladies which
rob our entrails? By thy noblenes I pray the, and by the goddess Venus I
conjure the, either satisfye my desire, or restore to me my heart which thou
have robbed from me. I would thou knew lady Macrine, ye clear intencion of my
heart, rather then this letter written with my hand. If my hap were so good, as
thy love would permit me to speak with the, I would hope by sight and speech to
win that, which I am in suspect by my letter to lose. The reason whereof is,
because thou shall read my rude reasons in this leter, and if you saw me,
thou should se ye bitter tears which I would offer to thee, in this my
unhappy life. O yt my mouth could publishe my cruel peines, as my heart fealeth
the^. I swear to thee lady Macrine, yt my woeful plaintes would stir up thy
small care, and as thy beauty has made thee thine own, so the knowledge of my
grief should make the mine. I desire thou would regard the beginning and
therewith note the end.

For of truth, the same day that thou imprisonest my heart at the window, in ye
dungeon of my desires, I had no less weakness to overcome, then thou had
strength to enforce me: and greater was thy power to take me from my self,
then my reason was to put me from the. Now lady Macrine, I do not ask other
mercy of the, but that we may declare our minds together. But in this case what
will thou I say unto the? but that thou have so much power over me, and I so
little of my liberty: that though I would not, my heart must needs be thine, and
that being thine, thou will show thy self to be mine. And since it may not be,
but that my life must be condemned in thy service: be thou as sure of my faith,
as I am doubtful of thy good will. For I shall have a greater honor to be lost
for thy sake, the^ to win any other treasure I have no more to say to the
now, but yt thou have respect to my perdicion, and draw life out of my death,
and turn my tears to joy. And because I hold my faith, and will never
despair in thy hope, I send the x. little ringes of gold, with x. ringes of
Alexandria, and by the immortal gods I co^niure the, yt when thou put the^
on thy finger, thou receiuest my love into thy heart.

Marcus thy lover, wrote this with his own hand.

Of an other letter which the emperor sent to the Lady Macrine, wherein he
expresses the fiery flames which consume sonest the gentle hearts. Cap. xiiii.
Mark thy neighbor at Rome, to the Macrine his sweet enemy. I call the sweet
for it is just I die for the: and enemy, because thou ceasest not to kill me. I
cannot tell how it is, but sith the feast of Ianus hitherto, I have written three
letters unto the, in the answer whereof I would have been contented to have
received but ii. from the. If I wuld serve the, thou will not be served: if I
speak to the, thou will not answer me. If I behold the, thou will not look
at me: if I call the, thou will not answer me. If I visit ye, thou will not se
me: if I write to the, thou will make no answer. And ye worst of al is, if
others do show the of my grefes, thou take it as a mockery. O yt I had so
much knowledge where to complain to the, as thou have power to cease my plaint:
then my wisdom should be no less praised among the wise, then thy beauty
amongst the foles. I beseech the heartily not to have respect to the rudenes of
my reasons, but regard ye faith of my tears, which I offer to yt as a witness
of my will. I know not what profit may come by my harm, nor what gain of my
loss thou may hope to have, nor what surety of my peril thou may attain,
nor what pleasure of my pain thou maiste have. I had answer by my messenger,
that without reading my letters, with thy own hands thou did rent them in
pieces, it ought to suffice to think how many parsons is tormented. If it had
pleased you lady Macrine to have red those few lines, you should have perceived
how I am inwardly tormented Ye women be very extreme, and for the misaduenture
of one man, a woman will complain of al me^ in general, So ye al show cruelty
for one particular cause, openly ye pardon all men's lives, and secretly ye
procure death to al. I account it nothing lady Macrine that thou haste done,
but I lament yt which thou causest thy neighbor Valerius to say to me. One
thing I would thou sholdest remember, and not forget, that is. Since my liberty
is so small and thy power so great, that being wholly mine, am turned to be
thine: the more injury thou do to me, the more thou hurtest thy self, since
by the I die, as thou by me do live. In this peruers opinion abide not, so
may thou hasarde the life of us both. Thou hurtest thy good name, and
destroyest my health, in the end thou must come to the same physic. Pardone
me lady Macrine, if I say ought that may offend thee. I know ye women desire
one thing greatly, that is, to have soueraintie of us, and yet not seame so
much as by thought to wyshe the same. Thou had the same of a gentle nature,
though in deed thou were not so: yet thou had the same thereof, and an
ancient good name ought not to be lost with a new unkindness. Thou know
how contrary ingratitude is, to virtue in a virtuous house. Thou can not be
called virtuous, but if thou be courteous. There is no greater ingratitude, then
not to love again. Though I visit the, and thou not me, it is nothing: though
I remember thee, and thou forgettest me, it is nothing: though I weep, and thou
laugh, it is nothing: though I crave of thee, and thou deny me, it is nothing:
though thou owe me, and pay me not, it is nothing. But if I love thee, and
thou not me, this is a great thing: which the eyes can neither dissimule, nor
the heart suffer. All the vices in mortal men are to be pardoned, because they
offend naturally: save only this discourtesy in women, and ungentleness in
me^, which are counted of malice. Diverse services by me done to thee, and all
the good wills I have heretofore borne to thee, thou only lady Macrine with
one thing reward me. I pray thee be not slack to help me, for I was not so
to offer me into peril. If thou say that Patroclus thy husband has the
property in thee, at the least yet receive me upon proof, and I will pretend
a possession of thee: and in this wise the vain glory in being thine, shall
hyde the hurt being mine. thou make me maruayle not a little, that for so
small a reward, thou will suffer so great an importunity. For certainly we
grant many things to an importunate man, which we deny to a temperate man.
If thou lady Macrine hopest to overcome me: behold I yield me as vanquished.
If thou will lose me, I hold me lost: if thou wylt kill me, I hold me dead.

For by the gestures which I make before thy gate, and the secreate sighs
which I fetch in my house, thou may know how greatly I mind to rest:
but thy brave assaults, are rather buyldinges to nouryshe death, then to
comfort the life. If thou wylt I escape this danger, deny me not remedy. For
it shall be a greater dishonor for to slay me, then shame to save me. It is no
just thing for so small again, to lose so faithful a friend. I wot not how
to make thee my detter, nor how to make thee pay me, and the worste of all
is, I know not what to say, nor how to determine. For I was not borne to
mine own wealth, but to be faithful in thy services. And sithe thou know
whom thou haste trusted with thy message, the same I do trust with this open
letter, and my answer in secret. I do send to thee a jewel of pearl, and
a piece of gold, I pray the gods make thee receive them as willingly, as I do
freely send them.

Mark Orator to the inexorable Macrine.

Of a letter which the Emperor Marcus Aurelius sent to the beautiful lady
Liuia, wherein he proves that love is natural, and that the most part of
the philosophers and wise men, have been by love overcome. Cap. xv.
Mark full of sorrow, to thee careless Lyuia. If thy little care did lodge in
me, and my sorrows were harbored in thee, thou should then see how little
the quarrel is that I make to thee, in respect to the torment I suffer. If the
flambes issued out, as the fire does burn me within, the heavens should
perish with smoke, and the earth should make imbers. If thou do well
remember, the first time I saw thee in the temple of the virgin Vestals, thou
being there did always pray to the gods for thy self, and I upon my
knees prayed to thee for me. Thou know, and so do I, that thou did
offer oil and honey to the gods, but I did offer to thee tears and sighs.
It is just thou give more to him that offered his heart, then to him which
draws money out of his purse. I have determined to write to thee this letter,
whereby thou majesty perceive how thou art served with the arrows of my
eyes, which were shot at the white of thy service, O unhappy that I am, I
fear least this present calm, does threaten me with a tempest to come. I will
say, that discourtesy in thee, causes doubtful hope in me. Behold my
misaduenture, I had lost a letter, and tourning to the temple to seek it, I
found the letter which was of some importance: and had almost lost my
self, which is the greatest thing. Considering my small reward, I see my
eyes (the ladders of my hope) set on so high a wall, that no less certain is
my fall, then my climming was doubtful. Thou bending down thy harnes of thy
high deserts, and putting me to the point of continual service, suffrest me
to enjoy the fruit, and give to whom thou will the leaves. By the immortal
gods I swear, that I marvel not a little, for I thought that in the temple of
the virgin Vestalles no temptation could have come to man. But now by
experience I find, that that woman is easelier overcome, which is most
watched: then the other that has honest liberty. All bodily diseases be first
had or they be known, and known or they be seen, and seen or they be felt,
and felt or they be tasted: and so in all things except this darte of love
whom they first feale the stroke thereof, before they know the way how it
comes. The lightning comes not so sudden, but it is known before by the
thonder. The wall falls not sodeinly, but first some stones fall down. The
cold comes not so fast, but some small shiuering is seen before: only love
is not felt, until he has had power in the entrails. Let them know that are
ignorant, and thou lady Liuia if thou will know. Love sleapeth when we wake,
and waketh when we sleep, laugheth when we weape, and wepeth when we laugh. It
assures in taking, and takes in assuring: it speaks when we be still, and
is still when we speak. And finally it has such a condition, that to give us
our desire, it causes us to live in pain. I swear unto the, when my will
became thy servant, and thy beauty made the my mistres, when I was at the
temple, and there found thee, neither you in thy prayer did mind me, nor I
unhappy man did think on thee. O unhappy heart of mine, that being whole thou
art divided, being in health thou art hurt, being alive thou art killed, being
mine thou art stolen, and the worst of al is, that thou not helping to my life,
consentest that death shall assault me. Considering many times lady Liuia with
my self my thoughts to be high, and my fortunes base, I would have separated
my self from thee: but knowing my travail to be well employed in thy service,
I say though I might, I would not be separated from thee. I will not deny one
thing, that is: the cursed love takes away the taste of al things, and in
those things only it gives us pleasure, which are greatly against our profit.
This is the proof of him that loves heartily, that one frown of her that he
loves, does more grieve him, then all the delights of the rest of his life ca^
please. I deem lady Lyuia, thou art abashed to se me openly as a philopher,
and to know me secretly as a lover. I beseech thee heartily discover me not. For
if the gods grant me long life, I am now a young fool, yet in age I will be
wise. The gods know what I desire, and the force which does enforce me
thereunto. And as the flesh is weak, and the heart tender, the occasions many,
the virtues few, the world deceitful, the people malicious: so I pass this
spring time with flowers, in hope that in harvest I shall have some fruit.
Think thou lady Liuia, that philosophers be they never so wise, are not
touched with the sharp darts of love? and that under their course clothes,
there is not soft flesh and white? Certainly among hard bones, is nourished
soft flesh: and within the pricking husks, grow the chesse nut. I say,
that under simple attire, is the faithful love. I do not deny but our frail
nature does withstand our virtues. Nor I deny not but that the wanton
desires, are repressed with virtuous minds. Nor I deny not but that the
rashenes of youth are restrained with the reins of reason. I deny not but many
times wisdom does withstand that that the flesh procures: and yet I
confess, yt he that is not amorous, is a fool. And do not thou know,
although we be wise, we leave not therefore to be men? do not thou know, all
that ever we learn in our life, suffiseth not to govern the flesh one hour?
do not thou know, that to wise men in this case has fallen many errors?
do not thou know that there has been, and are many masters of virtues: and
much more there are and has been folowers of vices? then why do thou make
such a wonder only of me? I will not say it without a troth, that I never had
my judgment so good and perfect, as when Cupide blewe wind on me with his
wings. There was never man until my time accounted wise, but first he was
entangled with Cupides snares. Gratian was in love with Tamira, Solon
Salaminus, the geuer of the laws, was enamored with one Gretian. Pittacus
Mitelenus left his own wife, and was in love with a bond woman yt he brought
from the war. Cleobulus when he was.lxxx. year old, and had red philosophy
lxv. years, climming up a ladder to scale his neighbors house, fell, and of the
bruise died. Periander prince of Achaia, and chief philosopher of Greece, at the
instaunce of his lovers, slew his own wife. Anacharsis a Philosopher, a
Sithian by his father, and a Greek by the mother side, loved so dearly a
woman of Thebes, that he taught her all that he knew: in so much that he being
sick on his bed, she red for him in the schools Epimenides of Crete, that
slept.xv. years without waking, Although he was agreat worshipper of the Gods,
yet was he bannished Athens.x. years for the loving of women. Architus
Tarentinus, the master of Plato, and scholar of Pithagoras, occupied his mind
more to inue^t new kinds of love, then to employ his mind to virtues and
learning. Gorgias Leontinus, borne in Scycil, had mo co^cubines in his house,
then books in his study. Al these were wise men, and we knew them wise, yet at
thend they were overcome with the flesh. Therefore blame me not alone, for as I
have told thee of these few, so could I of a whole army. For of troth he ought
to have many things, yt will be accounted a curious lover. He must have his eyes
displayed on her that he loves, his understanding much altered in that he
thinks, his tongue troubled in that he should speak: so yt in seeing he be
blind, in thinking dismayed, in speaking troubled. O lady Liuia, the loving in
mockery, passes by mockery: but whereas true love is, there is grefe and no
mockery: there love spitteth his poison, and cruel Cupide fixes his arrows
up to the feathers. The eyes weep, the heart sigheth, the flesh trembles, the
senewes do shrink, the understanding is gross, reason fails, and so al
falls to the earth. Finally the heavy lover abiding in himself, holds
nothing of himself. All this I say, because if I want knowledge to make me a
lover, yet am I sure that the works fail not in me to work thy service. And
though by mishap I saw the, yet by good chance I knew thee. I ask nothing of
thee but that you love me faithfully, since I love the unfeignedly. And if thou
hear that I am sick from my heart, I desire the to do me some good. Since it
is only in the to help me, it is reason thou only do seek for remedy. I was
greatly comforted when Fulius Carlinus desired me in thy behalf to do a
pleasure, which I did incontinent al yt thou desiredst, to the intent that thou
another day should do frankly that I desire thee. And behold lady Liuia,
the woman that is served with services, it is reason within a while she be sued
unto by prayer. And though my strength cannot open the gates of the purpose, or
not agreing to thy demand, yet al my labors slake not to uphold thy renown.
I pray the discover not the one, nor beguile me with the other. For thou see
in granting is remedy, and in hoping is comfort. But promise is deceiuable,
and delayeng is perylous, and the entertaining byndeth. I se well that the hearty
demand, requires a long answer: but I would not thou should do so. But
as I love the, so love me: as I desire of the, so grant thou me. I will say
once again I am all thine, and nothing mine own. And note lady Liuia, that it
is as much honor to thee, as profitable for me, that thou change these thy
desires, and put in order thy disordered will. For thou see it is much
better to heal shortly, then to late, with failing thy purpose. All women
observe one evil opinion, that is: ye never receive council, although it be
given you in never so weighty a case. And if it be not so, then because thou
art esteemed beautiful, be likewise honored for taking of good counsel. In
this sort, though my loss be much, and thy patience little, yet shall they
account me wise in giving counsel, and the most happy to follow it. One thing I
will say to thee, and pardon me therein. Women be much defamed in that they will
take no council, and such as do assure their renown so much on the judgment
of others, as they condemn well doing before. I think good if it so like thee,
and would if thou will, that thou should do in all points as I have
counsayled thee. I will say no more lady Liuia, but that I do present to thee
all my unfortunate troubles, my sighs as a desperate man, my service as thy
servant my troubled griefs, my words of philosophy, and my tears as a
lover. I send thee here a girdle of gold, on condition that thou always fix
thy eyes on that, and thy heart on me. I pray the gods give me to thee, and
thee to me.

Mark the open Philosopher wrote this in great secreate.

FINIS.
